site_title: How big can be beautiful
summary: The article discusses the recent merger of Marriott and Starwood, the world's largest hotel company. Despite the combined entity's promise to maintain quality and service, many travelers have noticed a decline in amenities, such as reduced breakfast options, organic butter, and welcome peanuts. The article argues that the focus on cost-cutting and shareholder returns is eroding the "H" in hospitality, with young PR managers prioritizing brand image over customer satisfaction. The merger aims to increase sales, but the long-term impact on the customer experience remains uncertain.

site_title: Buildings & birdsong
summary: The Singapore Institute of Architects Architectural Design Awards recognized several winning projects, including Gwen Tan's home, a lush sanctuary for humans and birds, and DP Architects' Goodlife! Makan, a social initiative for seniors to cook and socialize. RT+Q Architects' House Off Cluny and Wallflower's Secret Garden House also received awards. The awards showcased innovative designs that prioritize sustainability, inclusivity, and community engagement.

site_title: Vietnam group TTC plans US$600m S'pore listing of sugar unit
summary: Vietnam's TTC Group plans to list its sugar unit in Singapore, seeking US$600 million in funding. The company aims to become a global player, expanding sugar production in Cambodia and Laos. TTC Sugar will merge with another sugar company, creating a combined entity worth US$200 million, and production at a new sugarcane plantation is expected to increase five-fold. The company plans to invest US$600 million in its sugar business by 2020, with the goal of making Vietnamese sugar products more competitive globally.

site_title: New York police to buy 1,000 body cameras
summary: The New York Police Department has agreed to purchase 1,000 body cameras as part of a nationwide effort to increase police transparency. The $6.42 million contract is part of a five-year initiative, with plans to roll out the cameras in 20 precincts by 2017. The move comes after the death of Eric Garner in 2014 and a series of killings of unarmed black men by police, sparking public outcry and calls for reform. The cameras, which can be clipped onto uniforms, have been shown to reduce complaints and uses of force in other police departments.

site_title: Sharks: feared predator in need of protection
summary: Sharks are facing increased pressure due to unmanaged commercial fishing and trade, leading to a significant drop in numbers. An estimated 100 million sharks are killed annually, threatening many species' survival. The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (Cites) conference in Johannesburg is voting on increased protection for several shark species, including the silky shark and thresher sharks. The proposal aims to regulate fishing and trade to ensure sustainability, with Fiji, Sri Lanka, and the Maldives leading the push for stronger protection.

site_title: Swiber's proposed judicial management gives no indication of recoverable debt
summary: Swiber Group's proposed judicial management (JM) application is set for an October court hearing, with unsecured creditors questioning the projected returns of the proposed JM. The interim judicial managers (IJMs) from KPMG have pledged better returns than a liquidation scenario, but the exact figures remain unclear. The group's order books, valued at $1.67 billion, are considered crucial to determining the JM's returns, with six of seven ongoing projects over 60% completed. The IJMs plan to raise cash through asset disposal and realising outstanding receivables, but industry sources flag challenges in raising cash through this option.

site_title: Bomb scare at KL Bursa triggers evacuation
summary: A bomb scare at Bursa Malaysia's headquarters in Kuala Lumpur triggered an evacuation of the building and surrounding Hindu temple on Friday. The incident was confirmed as a hoax, but not before the benchmark FBMKLCI index lost 1% due to late afternoon selling. Trading resumed after the police declared the building safe, and the market's decline was attributed to investors taking profit ahead of the long weekend. The incident occurred amidst economic challenges, including a weak ringgit and slumping oil prices, and heightened security concerns in the region.

site_title: China factory gauge signals economic stabilisation still intact
summary: China's official factory gauge remained steady at 50.4 in September, indicating the economy's stabilisation continued and reducing prospects for policy easing. The manufacturing PMI and non-manufacturing PMI rose to 50.4 and 53.7 respectively, showing improving conditions. The data suggests growth could edge up to 6.9% in Q3 and Q4, bringing the annual figure to 6.8%, driven by government fiscal support and a soaring property market.

site_title: Changes needed for Basel III: EU official
summary: The European Union's financial services commissioner, Valdis Dombrovskis, has expressed concerns over the Basel III banking reform, stating that it risks negatively affecting European banks and needs to be changed. The proposed reform, which aims to make the sector safer, could lead to significant capital requirement increases for European banks, particularly those with large loan portfolios. The EU is seeking a more balanced proposal, with a focus on calibrating capital requirements on banks' risks and business models.

site_title: South Korea Sept exports down, as expected due to Hyundai strikes
summary: South Korea's exports fell 5.9% in September to $40.86 billion, as expected, due to a strike at Hyundai Motor and shipment disruptions. The trade surplus increased to $7.11 billion. Exports to China, the US, and the EU declined 9.1%, 6.1%, and 14.5%, respectively. The economy is improving, but the prolonged export contraction is a concern for policymakers.

site_title: Comic writer confirms Wonder Woman is 'queer'
summary: Comic writer Greg Rucka confirms Wonder Woman's bisexuality, stating that her island home, Themyscira, is "involving, although not necessarily exclusively, romantic and/or sexual interest toward persons of the same gender." This interpretation aligns with the concept of the Amazonian warriors, who don't view same-sex relationships as a possibility. Rucka's confirmation comes after years of speculation, and the news was largely welcomed by fans on social media.

site_title: UK's Hammond says Brexit deal should not harm economy: Telegraph
summary: UK Finance Minister Philip Hammond stated that Britain's new immigration powers should not harm the economy following the country's decision to leave the EU. Hammond assured investors that the new controls would be used "responsibly" and would not hinder the economy or shut out highly-skilled individuals. His comments aim to ease concerns among investors and businesses, including Japanese carmaker Nissan, which is worried about potential barriers to its exports. Hammond's goal is to ensure a smooth transition and support the UK economy.

site_title: Threat from extremist groups to South-east Asia growing: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Singapore Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen warned of a growing threat from extremist groups in South-east Asia, citing the rise of Islamic State's influence and the influx of over 1,000 locals joining the group. The threat is becoming more organized, with militants planning coordinated attacks and using networks to fund and arm operations. Ng stated that destroying Islamic State's base in Iraq and Syria may increase the risk to the region in the short-term, as seasoned fighters may return home.

site_title: China paper says US, South Korea will 'pay the price' for planned missile system
summary: China's top newspaper, the People's Daily, warns the US and South Korea that deploying an advanced missile defense system will lead to a "counter attack" and "pay the price" for their decision. The system, Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (Thaad), is set to be deployed in South Korea to protect against North Korean threats, but China sees it as a threat to its security. China has repeatedly promised to take specific steps in response, but has not elaborated on its plans.

site_title: Yuan goes into IMF's Special Drawing Rights basket
summary: The Chinese yuan has been included in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, effective October 1, 2016. While this move is seen as a recognition of China's economic ascendency and a potential boost to structural reforms, its impact on the global economy is expected to be minimal, with the yuan remaining an indirect and tiny part of global reserves. The inclusion may encourage China to push for further reforms, but Beijing has downgraded the priority of structural reforms, potentially leading to reform complacency.

site_title: Baltic buy will boost market development: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has acquired the Baltic Exchange for £77.6 million, creating a clearing house in Asia that is neutral about market share. The deal aims to boost market development and remove structural hurdles for new indices and products. SGX will benefit from the growth of the freight derivatives market, including iron ore, and increase the use of hedging in Asia. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to diversify SGX's revenue streams and capture potential growth in the market.

site_title: Gold slips as concerns about Deutsche Bank ease
summary: Gold prices fell 0.3% to $1,316.32 per ounce as safe-haven demand decreased after stocks recovered from a sell-off on easing concerns about Deutsche Bank's US$5.4 billion settlement with US authorities over mortgage-backed securities charges. The settlement was less than the previously demanded US$14 billion, alleviating concerns about the bank's stability.

site_title: Disgruntled customer runs amok at Apple store in France
summary: A young French man, reportedly dissatisfied with his experience at an Apple store in Dijon, France, caused significant damage by smashing Apple products with a metal ball. The incident, captured on camera, resulted in 55,000 euros in damages. The man claimed he was seeking reimbursement but was refused. Authorities plan to seek a fast-track trial against the suspect, who remains at large.

site_title: In support of stroke survivors, caregivers (Amended)
summary: A charity organization, S3, founded by Chew Poh Yim, aims to support stroke survivors and their caregivers in Singapore. The charity, which opened in May, provides a wellness center with care and support services, and collaborates with hospitals to ensure accessible post-stroke care. S3 plans to expand its services by opening more wellness centers in neighborhoods and partnering with local organizations. A charity gala dinner is being held on October 15 to fund the expansion, and mobile applications are being developed to assist with rehabilitation.

site_title: Euro edges higher against US dollar on reduced Deutsche Bank fears
summary: The euro recovered against the US dollar, rising to a 9-day high, after reduced concerns about Deutsche Bank's health, which had pressured the currency to a low of $1.1153. The euro is on track to gain 0.8% in September, its best month in six, and 1.2% for the third quarter. The US dollar, meanwhile, hit a 9-day high against the Swiss franc, while the yen gained 1.8% against the dollar for the quarter.

site_title: Multi-concept draw (Amended)
summary: Two new eateries, Picnic and Plentyfull, are set to open in Singapore, offering unique dining experiences. Picnic, launched by Omakase Burger's director Cheng Hsin Yao, is an "immersive outdoor experience" featuring nine "hot food" stalls with various cuisines and four "cold" stalls. Plentyfull, owned by Claudia Sondakh, serves global cuisine with a focus on healthy and nourishing food, offering a market table luncheon spread and a full-service modern brasserie. Meanwhile, SPRMRKT Daily, a local lifestyle concept, has launched a new outlet with a grocery store, retail space, and riverside cafe, featuring artisanal food and drinks.

site_title: Singapore to amend company laws
summary: Singapore plans to amend its company laws to require companies and limited liability partnerships to disclose beneficial ownership information, in line with international standards. The move aims to increase corporate transparency and comply with the Financial Action Task Force's recommendations. Senior Minister Indranee Rajah stated that the proposed amendments will also include steps to identify beneficial owners and maintain relevant information. A public consultation will be conducted towards the end of the year to gather views on the proposed changes.

site_title: Clinton moves to cement post-debate lead in pivotal Florida
summary: Hillary Clinton strengthened her lead in Florida after a series of high-profile visits to the state, including a rally in Coral Springs. The Democratic candidate has been gaining momentum since the first presidential debate, and a recent Suffolk poll showed her up by six points in Nevada. Clinton's campaign is capitalizing on Trump's setbacks, including a vociferous protest by Trump supporters in Fort Pierce. With Florida's pivotal electoral votes, a Clinton victory in the state would significantly boost her chances of reaching the White House.

site_title: Independent refiners in US hit by Opec output deal
summary: US independent refiners face a challenge due to Opec's output deal, which led to a 4.6% drop in the BI North America Refining & Marketing index. Crude prices rose 7% in two days, and refining profit margins slumped due to "stubbornly high fuel inventories" and costs from government-mandated renewable fuel credits. The deal has made life harder for independent refiners, who buy crude oil to process into fuel, and companies such as Marathon Petroleum Corp and Valero Energy Corp saw significant declines.

site_title: Pentagon chief reassures Asean ministers over future US commitments
summary: Pentagon Chief Ashton Carter reassured Asean ministers that the US will continue its "rebalance" to Asia under the next administration, committing to strengthen cooperation on regional security challenges, including countering China's growing presence in the South China Sea. Carter emphasized the US will ignore Beijing's claims and maintain its military operations in the region. Despite Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's recent attacks on the US, Carter expressed confidence in retaining the US's Asia focus, citing opportunities for continued cooperation and solidifying the US's position in the region.

images.alt_text: Pentagon Chief Ashton Carter met Friday with Southeast Asian defense ministers to discuss regional security issues and reassure them America's "rebalance" to Asia will continue under the next US administration.

site_title: Market value of Singapore stocks up in Sept
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.8% in September, with a total market capitalization of S$866.9 billion, up 4.5% from September 2015. The Straits Times Index (STI) benchmark gained 15.8% to S$463.5 billion, led by the mining and quarry, real estate investment trusts, and hotels and restaurants sectors. Transportation, storage, and communications companies fell 3.7%. UOB and DBS Group Holdings were the second and third biggest market value gainers, respectively. The largest 10% of companies by market value increased their market cap by 1.3%, while the smallest 10% declined by 2%.

site_title: Japan, India to sign nuclear cooperation deal in Nov: report
summary: Japan and India are set to sign a civil nuclear cooperation pact in mid-November, following a visit by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to Japan. The agreement was reached in December, but technical and legal differences were cited as reasons for not signing. Japan has demanded non-proliferation guarantees from India before exporting nuclear reactors, which has a nuclear weapons program. The deal would benefit US firms, including GE-Hitachi and Toshiba's Westinghouse Electric Company, which have already secured land for nuclear plants in India.

site_title: BT newshounds snag top financial journalism prizes
summary: Top financial journalists from The Business Times (BT) and The Straits Times (ST) won prestigious awards for their work, including the Financial Journalist of the Year, Financial Story of the Year, and Most Promising Journalist of the Year. BT's Kenneth Lim and Melissa Tan received recognition for their investigative reporting on corporate governance issues at SingPost, while ST's Marissa Lee and Lorna Tan won awards for their work on investor education. These awards acknowledge the importance of financial journalism in promoting transparency and accountability in the market.

images.alt_text: SHOWING THE WRITE STUFF: (From left) The Straits Times' Marissa Lee and Lorna Tan with BT's Kenneth Lim and Melissa Tan.

BIG WINNERS: The Business Times' Kenneth Lim and Melissa Tan winning the top prizes for financial journalism at the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) Investors' Choice Awards 2016 on Friday evening.

site_title: Canada says returning suspects to China needs to be done by law
summary: Canada has agreed to start talks about an extradition treaty with China, with the understanding that suspects must meet Canadian legal standards. This move follows a high-level national security and rule of law dialogue between the two countries, during which Canada expressed its hope to "expose" China's judicial system to its own way of administering justice. The agreement was made after the release and deportation of Kevin Garratt, a Canadian held in China for two years and charged with spying, sparking questions about what Canada had given up to secure his freedom.

site_title: EU 'cautiously optimistic' on global pact to curb aviation emissions
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is making progress in negotiations for a global pact to curb aviation emissions, with Europe's transport commissioner expressing "cautiously optimistic" sentiments. A proposed global mechanism, Corsia, aims to freeze or reduce greenhouse gas emissions from civil aviation by 2035, with 63 nations representing 84% of aviation traffic agreeing to participate starting in 2021. The EU will continue to defend the current text to prevent weakening of the measure, which is seen as crucial to limiting global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees by 2050.

site_title: Small gasps of life in August business lending
summary: Singapore's business lending rose 1.6% in August to S$357 billion, reversing July's contraction. Lending in the building sector grew 1.3%, while transport and storage lending increased 6.6%. Consumer loans grew 0.4% and mortgages remained stable. However, core business demand remains weak amid uncertainty over the US elections and eurozone stability, with full-year forecasts indicating a 1.5% contraction for bank lending.

images.alt_text: A little life in business lending might have crept into August after the months of ho-hum lending activity earlier this year, but comes as business demand stays weak amid uncertainty over the US elections and the eurozone.

site_title: Indonesians line up to beat deadline for tax amnesty
summary: Indonesians have joined the tax amnesty scheme, declaring $359.8 billion in assets, with nearly 330,000 taxpayers participating since its launch in July. The program has generated $97 trillion in government revenue, exceeding 60% of the target. The first phase ends Friday with a 2% penalty, and the penalty rates rise on Saturday and January 1. The success of the amnesty is seen as a significant revenue collection effort, with Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati calling it the most successful tax amnesty in the country's history.

site_title: Global IPO activity to slow in '16 due to geopolitical uncertainty: EY
summary: Global initial public offering (IPO) activity is expected to slow in 2016 due to geopolitical uncertainty, with 39% lower proceeds and 23% fewer deals compared to the same period in 2015. However, EY predicts a recovery in 2017 as some companies mature and economic fundamentals improve, with a positive outlook for the year. The Asia-Pacific region, particularly Singapore, is expected to drive global IPO activity, with a surge in proceeds and deal volume in the third quarter.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on Deutsche Bank deal
summary: US stocks rose on Friday as financial shares surged following news that Deutsche Bank was near a settlement with US regulators over its sale of toxic mortgage bonds. Deutsche Bank shares surged 14% on a potential $5.4 billion deal, bolstering US bank shares and contributing to a 0.9% gain in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with tech stocks advancing 0.8%. The news helped alleviate concerns about Deutsche Bank's capital position and boosted shares of US banks and other companies, including Costco and McCormick.

site_title: UK economy flying blind after Brexit vote
summary: The UK economy remains uncertain after 100 days since the Brexit vote, with no clear exit strategy from the European Union. Firms are struggling to make investment and hiring decisions due to lack of clarity on future trading arrangements. The Bank of England expects the pace of expansion to more than halve next year and has raised near-term growth estimates. The government's slow approach to formal exit negotiations has pushed any clues about the new relationship into the distance, causing uncertainty and weighing on business investment.

site_title: Tee off in new courses
summary: Two new golf courses in Indonesia have recently opened: The Els Club Desaru Coast on Desaru Coast and Laguna Golf Bintan. The Els Club features three nine-hole layouts, including the Ocean Course, with strong bunkering and water hazards. Laguna Golf Bintan underwent a $730,000 renovation, resulting in a stunning layout with beachfront holes and challenging finishing holes. Both courses offer resort-style facilities and stay-and-play packages, making them popular options for golfers in Singapore.

images.alt_text: GREEN ADVENTURE: There's usually a battle against the sea breeze when one plays at Els Club Desaru Coast course, as it is next to the ocean.
GREEN ADVENTURE: Laguna Golf Bintan reopened in July this year, and features a number of beachfront holes on both the front and back nine.

site_title: VirnetX wins US$302.4m trial against Apple in Texas
summary: A US federal jury in Texas awarded VirnetX Holding Corp $302.4 million in damages against Apple Inc for infringing two patents related to secure computer and mobile communications, specifically its FaceTime calling feature and Virtual Private Network on Demand technology. This was the third trial in the case, following previous awards of $625.6 million and $23 million. The decision is subject to review by the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, which will use the patent office's legal standard when reviewing the agency's decisions.

site_title: New US 'secret' clearance unit hires firm linked to 2014 hacks
summary: The US government's new National Background Investigations Bureau (NBIB) has hired KeyPoint Government Solutions, a company linked to 2014 hacks that stole the personal data of 22 million federal employees. KeyPoint's login credentials were used in the hacks, but it's unclear if the company's credentials were stolen in 2014 or used by hackers. The NBIB, set to open next week, aims to improve security clearance investigations. OPM has implemented enhanced security measures and technical controls to mitigate risk.

site_title: Europe: Shares lifted by late surge in Deutsche Bank
summary: European shares closed higher on Friday, lifted by a late surge in Deutsche Bank shares after a media report that it was close to settling with US authorities over alleged mortgage-backed securities misselling. The Stoxx 600 index ended 0.1% higher, with Deutsche Bank closing up 6.4%. A potential US$5.4 billion settlement was cited as a contributing factor, although the company declined to comment. Despite this, Deutsche Bank shares remain near record lows, down nearly 50% in 2016.

site_title: Hong Kong leader calls for unity with China as protesters gather
summary: Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying urged unity with China amidst increasing calls for independence, as protesters gathered outside the auditorium where he delivered his annual address. The protests come as tensions rise over Beijing's perceived erosion of Hong Kong's freedoms, with some lawmakers calling for self-determination and independence. Leung described the current system as the "most beneficial and practical" for Hong Kong, while others, including former protest leader Nathan Law, boycotted the event due to China's human rights violations.

site_title: CBOE Volatility Index volume up 50% on pace for record
summary: The CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) has seen a 50% surge in volume this month, with futures on the index priced about 40% higher, and is on pace for a record year. This surge is attributed to investors seeking protection from a potential market downturn, despite the VIX trading 30% below its historical average in September. Fund manager Christopher Cole attributes the steep VIX curve to investors no longer relying on central bank support, and instead, hedging against potential market declines.

site_title: Google combines cloud, corporate software offerings
summary: Google has reorganized its cloud services and corporate software offerings into a new unit called Google Cloud, led by executive Diane Greene. The new division includes G Suite, machine-learning tools, and Android devices, aiming to compete with Amazon and Microsoft in the cloud sector. Google's cloud service now has over 1 billion end-users and has invested $9 billion in the division over the past year. The company has also introduced new locations for its rentable servers and a customer support unit, and has picked up new cloud customers, including The Home Depot and Pokémon Go.

site_title: Airbus Group to merge with planemaking unit, sources say
summary: Airbus Group is set to merge with its main planemaking unit, Airbus SAS, as part of a corporate restructuring aimed at simplifying its structure. The move, finalized on Thursday, will consolidate the company's position as a European aerospace champion. The merger, first debated over a decade ago, will remove confusion over the brand and the company's governance, with German-born CEO Tom Enders becoming sole CEO. Analysts expect the reorganization to reinforce Enders' leadership and avoid "massive" redundancies, with around 137,000 staff affected.

images.alt_text: HEAD MAN: Analysts say that the reorganisation will reinforce Mr Enders as sole CEO.

site_title: Hotels face headwinds in H2 despite growth in visitor arrivals
summary: Hotel occupancy levels in Singapore remain strong at 85% for the January-to-July period, but average room rates have slipped 3% and revenue per available room has dropped 2% due to economic headwinds and a rise in new hotel rooms. Visitor arrivals are expected to surpass 15.2 million, with China being the biggest source market, but growth has slowed down since April. The hotel industry faces challenges from a supply spike and a weaker global economy, with some analysts predicting a sluggish performance for the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: SLOWDOWN: One trend is that the growth in number of tourists from China has slowed since April. China is Singapore's biggest source market for visitors.

site_title: High-end luxury car market hit hard
summary: The high-end luxury car market in Singapore has seen a 27% decline in sales from January to August, with 91 units registered, compared to 125 units last year. The gloomy economy and Indonesia's tax amnesty scheme are cited as major factors contributing to the downturn. Dealers attribute the decline to cautious spending among wealthy buyers, who are waiting to see how long the economic climate will continue. The tax amnesty scheme has also affected the business, with some customers scrambling to pay taxes on their assets and others putting off discretionary purchases.

site_title: New manpower plan for pre-school sector launched, including skills-focused initiatives
summary: Singapore has launched two new skills-focused initiatives for the pre-school sector, as part of the nationwide SkillsFuture movement. The initiatives include the Skills Framework for Early Childhood Care and Education, aimed at giving people more opportunities to join the sector and develop their careers. The SkillsFuture movement aims to roll out 30 initiatives for different sectors over the next few years, providing Singaporeans with more opportunities for skill development and career advancement.

site_title: The Skittles Dabblers
summary: A US company, The Skittles Dabblers, isn't mentioned in the article. Key global news includes a 6,000% stock gain for an elevator empire in Japan due to a succession crisis, Alibaba risking a US$100 billion decline amid a turf war, and China's Xi signaling an end to deflationary price wars. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite trade tensions, while Huawei seeks AI chip customers in the Middle East and South-east Asia. US President Trump unveiled new tariff rates, including a 50% levy on Brazil.

site_title: Swede sensation
summary: Volvo's new S90 luxury sedan marks a quantum leap for the Swedish carmaker, offering a unique premium experience distinct from German competitors like Mercedes-Benz, BMW, and Audi. The S90 boasts unparalleled quality, craftsmanship, and a Scandinavian design, with features like CleanZone technology for pristine cabin air. Volvo aims to acquire a "human-centric" image, focusing on comfort and controlled driving, with the S90 as its flagship sedan in the premium mid-sized segment, representing a huge leap forward for the brand.

site_title: US rail safety under microscope after deadly crash
summary: A deadly train crash in Hoboken, New Jersey, killed one woman and injured over 100 others, highlighting US rail safety concerns and chronic underinvestment. The crash, the fifth deadly rail accident in under three years, occurred when a train traveling at a high speed plowed into the station. Experts point to recurring safety problems and sluggish investment in upgrading railroads, with the Positive Train Control system still not installed on New Jersey trains or tracks. The cost of implementing the system is estimated to be $10-$15 billion, with funding constraints and differing railroad systems also hindering progress.

site_title: Jazzing up a star-studded night of nostalgia
summary: Jeremy Monteiro headlined the Jazzy Business concert, celebrating 40 years in show business. Grammy-winning stars Lee Ritenour and Ernie Watts performed alongside local artists, including Rahimah Rahim, Jacintha Abisheganaden, and Hong Kong singer Frances Yip. The event featured a 1970s segment and a final number with organist Alberto Marsico. President Tony Tan Keng Yam attended as guest of honour, marking a milestone in The Business Times' anniversary celebrations.

images.alt_text: Grammy Award-winning musicians, saxophonist Ernie Watts (L) and guitarist Lee Ritenour (R) bounced riffs of each other and Jeremy Monteiro at the Jazzy Business concert, at the Esplanade Concert Hall on September 30. The concert was part of BT's 40th anniversary celebrations.
Jacintha Abisheganaden revisiting early collaborations with Jeremy Monteiro, at the Jazzy Business Concert at the Esplanade Concert Hall on September 30.
HAVING A BLAST: Monteiro and Rahimah in Jazzy Business, a musical tour of his four decades in show business.

site_title: Duterte's peso rout conflicts with Philippine economy
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's verbal attacks on the US and UN have triggered a massive exodus from stocks and led to the peso's seven-year low, with the currency forecast to drop further. Despite this, the Philippine economy is expected to grow at 6.4% this year, the fastest in Southeast Asia, driven by increased spending, tax reforms, and remittances. Currency strategists predict a rebound once investors focus on the country's strong fundamentals and growth drivers.

images.alt_text: STRONG WORDS: Since taking office at the end of June, Mr Duterte has laid out plans to boost spending on infrastructure, security and education.

site_title: Stock-pickers left out as US$50b rushes to EM
summary: Investors are pouring into emerging markets, with a net $50 billion rushing into developing-country stock and bond funds in 2016. However, only 20% of the funds went into shares, favoring lower-cost passive exchange-traded funds. Active money managers have experienced outflows of nearly $11 billion, indicating investors are cautious about the longer-term prospects for emerging-market equities. Despite projected earnings per share growth, investors remain skeptical, with many recommending buying Indian and Indonesian stocks. Emerging-market stocks are on course for their best quarterly return since 2012, with analysts projecting a 10% gain in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index over the next 12 months.

site_title: 'Brangelina' reach stop-gap deal over kids
summary: Angelina Jolie has reached a temporary agreement with Brad Pitt, granting her physical custody of their six children and Pitt visiting rights. The agreement includes one-on-one counseling for both parents and Pitt's supervised visits. The deal, effective until October 20, will keep the children at Jolie's rented LA house. The agreement was reached after the Los Angeles County Department of Children and Family Services intervened, following an alleged incident on a plane. The FBI is gathering information before deciding whether to launch a federal probe into the incident.

site_title: Volkswagen will pay US$1.21b to settle US dealer claims
summary: Volkswagen AG will pay US$1.21 billion to settle claims from 652 US brand dealers as part of its US$16.5 billion diesel emissions settlement. Dealers will receive an average of US$1.85 million each over 18 months. The US Justice Department and other parties are seeking final approval for buyback offers and diesel remediation efforts at a court hearing on October 18.

site_title: Luxury goods veteran appointed head of Bottega Veneta
summary: Kering appoints Claus-Dietrich Lahrs, former Hugo Boss CEO, as the new head of Bottega Veneta, following a year of declining sales. Lahrs faces a challenging task to revitalize the brand, which has been stagnant due to markdowns and weaker demand from Chinese buyers, its largest customer base. Analysts say the brand needs a creative reboot and product innovation to compete with smaller, more innovative luxury brands. Lahrs' appointment comes after Gucci's turnaround under Marco Bizzarri, putting pressure on Bottega Veneta to improve its performance.

site_title: Bond risks: information beats regulation
summary: A recent spate of bond defaults has prompted calls for more regulation to protect investors, particularly those who may not fully understand the risks associated with high-yielding instruments. However, experts argue that over-regulation can lead to more complexity and innovation to bypass regulations. Instead, a local agency issuing ratings on unsecured investment products could provide a simple guide to risks and encourage issuers of good-quality debt to list their bonds. This approach would allow companies to raise funds easily while protecting vulnerable investors.

site_title: Japanese consumers ignore Spotify's 40 million tunes
summary: Spotify's 40 million tunes in Japan go largely unnoticed, with Japanese consumers preferring physical CDs. A recent visit to a Tokyo music store showed customers browsing CDs, with one 21-year-old student discovering new rock artists and purchasing their albums. This trend highlights the challenges Spotify faces in the world's second-largest music market, where consumers may prioritize physical music over streaming services.

site_title: New infocomm media body to lead way into future: Yaacob
summary: Singapore has launched the Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA), a new body created from the merger of IDA and MDA, to lead the country into a digital future. Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim emphasized the need for IMDA to harness the full potential of technology and media to empower possibilities for all Singaporeans. The agency's three-fold strategy is to develop a strong infocomm media sector, build a trusted environment through regulations, and improve the lives of Singaporeans through ICM. IMDA will work with the government, industry, and the people to address digital divides and promote innovation.

site_title: Industrial rents could dip 6-8% in Q4: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's industrial rents are expected to fall 6-8% year-on-year in Q4, according to a Knight Frank report. Rentals have already declined 4.4% cumulatively for the first half of 2016. The decline is attributed to the relocation of industrialists to lower-rent locations and the impact of the oil and gas industry on the Pioneer-Tuas cluster. However, freehold industrial units and business park space are expected to remain resilient. Average prices for leasehold factory and warehouse units are expected to fall 4.5-6.5% and 0.5-2% year-on-year, respectively.

site_title: Japan still mired in stubborn deflation
summary: Japan's deflationary trends worsened in August, with core consumer prices down 0.5% and household spending falling 4.6% year-over-year. The Bank of Japan's inflation gauge rose 0.4% year-over-year, its slowest gain in 1.5 years. The central bank's policy of targeting interest rates through "yield curve control" is being challenged, and its ability to achieve 2% annual consumer-price inflation remains uncertain. The opposition Democratic Party is stepping up attacks on Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policies, which aim to combat deflation.

site_title: Caixin PMI points to stabilising China economy in Sept
summary: China's economy appears to be stabilizing, according to the Caixin PMI, which rose to 50.1 in September, its second strongest reading in 19 months. The manufacturing sector showed signs of expansion, with new orders and employment rising month-on-month. This supports other economic data, including a rebound in imports and inflation, and suggests that GDP growth may edge up this quarter. Analysts are revising their forecasts upwards, but concerns remain about rising debt and a potential real-estate bubble.

site_title: The seductions of Xiamen
summary: Xiamen, a city in China's Fujian province, is a culinary hub for Hokkien cuisine, offering a unique and diverse repertoire of dishes that go beyond traditional stereotypes. The city's kitchens showcase an abundance of seafood, with almost 80% of dishes being seafood-based, and the inhabitants place great importance on food. Chef Zhang Cong Ming highlights the city's use of unique ingredients such as dried seaweed, mustard paste, and peanut sugar, setting Xiamen's popiah apart from other versions. The city's rich food culture is a reflection of its history and geographical location.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths in talks over petrol station sale
summary: Woolworths Ltd, Australia's top grocer, is in talks to sell its petrol station chain valued at over US$1 billion. The sale, facilitated by investment bank UBS, is part of the company's asset divestment program to refocus on its core grocery business amid intense competition with Coles and ALDI. The deal, if successful, would mark Woolworths' exit from the fuel business, with shares rising on the news, and analysts calling for a clean liquor and supermarket business.

site_title: Analysts don't expect annual holiday Wall Street rally this year
summary: Wall Street analysts are bearish on the annual holiday market rally, with most expecting the S&P 500 Index to end 2016 at 2,171, about 1% below its current level. This is the lowest estimate in decades, with strategists citing concerns over interest rates, valuations, and election politics. Despite some upbeat revisions, analysts remain cautious, with many citing elevated stock valuations and lackluster earnings. The S&P 500's average gain from September to year-end is expected to be around 6.7%, lower than its historical average.

site_title: Tackling sleep apnoea
summary: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a common and serious sleep disorder that causes repeated airway blockages, leading to oxygen deprivation and potential long-term health consequences. In Singapore, approximately 1 in 3 people have moderate to severe OSA, which can lead to hypertension, heart disease, Alzheimer's disease, depression, and cognitive impairment. Untreated OSA can also affect children, causing behavioral and cognitive problems, poor academic performance, and cardiopulmonary disease. Treatment options include general and behavioral measures, medications, oral appliances, and CPAP machines, with surgery being an effective solution for patients with nasal obstruction or adenotonsillar hypertrophy.

site_title: PepsiCo posts Q3 net income of US$1.99b, beats analyst estimates
summary: PepsiCo reported a Q3 net income of US$1.99 billion, beating analyst estimates. Revenue fell 2% to US$16.03 billion, but North America's beverages unit rose 3%. The company raised its 2016 adjusted profit forecast by seven cents. PepsiCo's healthier brands, such as Propel and Naked Cold Pressed juice, drove sales growth. The company's businesses in Russia, China, and India improved, while Western Europe's performance was stable.

site_title: Lee Rubber sells Lavender shophouse block
summary: Lee Rubber Company sold a block of 11 conservation shophouses in Lavender Street to Broadway Textile for nearly S$55.56 million, with a 99-year leasehold interest. The property, known as Lavender Place, has a 3.0 plot ratio and spans two storeys with a four-storey rear extension. CBRE brokered the transaction, which drew strong interest from family offices and property funds. The sale price works out to S$1,229 per square foot.

site_title: Airline caterers adapt to survive with shift to buy-on-board
summary: Airline catering firms are adapting to survive by shifting to buy-on-board food, driven by customer demand and cost savings. Companies like British Airways, LSG SkyChefs, and Gategroup are investing in retail and data expertise to maximize profits. The industry's fragmented market is forcing companies to merge and acquire, with mergers and acquisitions seen as a more attractive investment opportunity than the airline industry itself. Data analytics is helping airlines optimize buy-on-board sales, with potential increases of 30-50% in sales.

site_title: US money funds have small exposure to Deutsche Bank debt
summary: US money market funds hold approximately $2.7 billion in Deutsche Bank debt, a small fraction of their total assets. This tiny exposure reduces the likelihood of a massive sale of Deutsche Bank securities, similar to the 2008 crisis, when money funds sold Lehman Brothers' securities to meet heavy redemption. The holdings are a result of traders' speculation about Deutsche Bank's future following a US$14 billion fine for its misselling of mortgage-backed securities.

site_title: China to scrap limits on QFII, RQFII asset allocation
summary: China's securities regulator will scrap limits on asset allocations under the Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (QFII) and yuan-denominated RQFII schemes, aiming to attract more long-term capital. Previously, investors were required to allocate at least 50% of their assets in stocks and a maximum of 20% in cash. The move comes as China seeks to boost investment quotas, with $81.5 billion granted to 300 QFII institutions and 510.3 billion yuan to 210 RQFII institutions by the end of August. The changes will allow investors to decide their own asset allocations.

site_title: Swiber receives claims of US$223.6m
summary: Swiber Holdings Limited has received approximately US$223.6 million in claims, according to an update on September 29. The company is seeking legal advice on the claims and is verifying the accuracy and completeness of the information. The interim judicial managers stated that the information is based on documents and information provided by the company.

site_title: Smooth ride
summary: The Mercedes-Benz SLC 200 is a compact, responsive, and refined roadster with a sleek exterior design. Despite its compact proportions, the interior offers spacious cabin with good head and elbow room. The SLC 200 features a 2-litre turbocharged engine, 9-speed automatic transmission, and Dynamic Select driving modes. With a top speed of 237 km/h and 0-100 km/h in 6.9 seconds, the SLC 200 is a smooth and nimble ride, with a build quality that is impressive and reassuring.

site_title: Deutsche Bank problems eat away at STI's gains
summary: Deutsche Bank's financial woes have led to concerns of a potential repeat financial crisis, despite initial gains from an oil price surge and the US presidential debate. Hedge funds reduced their exposure to the bank after a US Justice Department report ordered Deutsche Bank to pay $14 billion in fines for its role in the 2008 sub-prime crisis. This led to heavy selling in Western markets, including Singapore, where the Straits Times Index dropped 16.24 points, cutting its weekly gain to 0.5%.

site_title: A culture of benchmarking to the best
summary: Singapore has been ranked Asia's Number One and the world's No 2 in a sustainability ranking study, outperforming 70% of Asian cities. Despite having opportunities to emulate Singapore's success, neighboring countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam have struggled to follow suit. Singapore's key to success lies in its culture of benchmarking to the best, adopting best-in-class models for infrastructure, public services, and institutions, and embracing bilingual education with a focus on English. The country's strong outward push and adherence to a culture of excellence have enabled it to participate in global trade and investment, setting it apart from its neighbors.

site_title: California proposes giving more freedom to test self-driving cars
summary: California proposes revised regulations allowing companies more leeway in testing self-driving cars on public roads. The new rules permit the absence of a driver in some instances, provided for two-way communication with the vehicle. The changes aim to promote innovation in the autonomous vehicle industry, which California has been at the forefront of. The revised regulations also restrict the advertising of semi-autonomous systems using terms like "autonomous" or "self-driving." The draft regulations face a public comment period before being finalized.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore property developers are keen to replenish their land banks despite a muted residential outlook, with the recent GLS tender at Fernvale Road attracting 14 bidders and a top bid of S$287.1 million. The winning consortium, a joint venture between Sing Development and Wee Hur, has a construction arm to help maintain cost discipline. The sector remains neutral, with diversified blue chips preferred, while Thaibev launches a new soda water product, Rock Mountain, to gain market share from Boon Rawd, and Sheng Siong Group maintains its "buy" recommendation due to earnings growth and efficient operations.

site_title: Team Singapore eye cycling glory at Speedway Championship
summary: Singapore's cycling team will compete in the OCBC Cycle Southeast Asian Speedway Championship on Saturday, facing off against teams from Brunei, Cambodia, Myanmar, the Philippines, and Malaysia. The six teams will participate in three rounds of races, with Singapore aiming to win the title after finishing second last year. Team captain Ho Jun Rong is optimistic, citing a strategy and training with a new squad to improve their performance. The winning team will receive S$6,000, while the second and third-placed teams will receive S$4,000 and S$2,000 respectively.

site_title: Thailand still golden for Chinese tourists despite Zika fears
summary: Thailand reported its first confirmed cases of microcephaly linked to the Zika virus, but Chinese tourists are not deterred from visiting the country during the upcoming "Golden Week" break. Despite US officials advising pregnant women to postpone travel to Thailand due to Zika, industry officials and tourists believe the risk is low and Thailand's public health system is effective. The country expects 220,000 Chinese visitors during the break, a 30% increase from last year, and Zika fears are not expected to impact tourism.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Cheng Yu-tung dies aged 91
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Cheng Yu-tung, founder of New World Development Co Ltd, has died at 91. He amassed a US$16 billion fortune through various business ventures, including real estate, hotels, and telecommunications. Cheng joined Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group Ltd in 1947 and made it a household name across Asia. He suffered a brain haemorrhage four years ago and was succeeded by his son Henry Cheng. The cause of death was not disclosed, and Henry Cheng stated that it would have no impact on the company.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte likens himself to Hitler, wants to kill millions of drug users
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte likened himself to Adolf Hitler, stating he'd be "happy" to exterminate 3 million drug users and peddlers in the country. The comments triggered shock and anger among Jewish groups, potentially straining US-Philippines relations. US officials and UN special adviser Adama Dieng expressed alarm, urging Duterte to exercise restraint and support an investigation into anti-drug campaign killings.

site_title: Oil rises in New York, buoyed by Opec cheer
summary: Oil prices rose in New York, closing at $48.24 a barrel, after OPEC countries agreed to cut daily production by 750,000 barrels. The move, announced two days prior, boosted prices by over 5% and led to further gains on Friday. In contrast, London's North Sea Brent fell to $49.06 a barrel. The price increase is seen as a continuation of bullish sentiment following the OPEC meeting, with analysts attributing it to gathering momentum from the positive news.

site_title: OPC banks on supplying world's priciest wood
summary: A Singapore-based company, OPC, aims to supply the world's priciest wood, agarwood, by utilizing modern agriculture technology and management to create a better-managed industry. The company's Cambodian venture seeks to promote social change through vertical business practices. Demand from the Middle East, China, and other sectors drives the high demand for agarwood, which is prized for its health qualities and used in perfumes. The company's initiative could address the existing supply shortage and create a wider range of agarwood-based products.

site_title: LaFerrari Aperta sells out before official debut
summary: Ferrari's LaFerrari Aperta sports car has sold out before its official debut at the Paris car show, with 200 hybrid convertible units reserved for carefully selected clients. The limited edition model, priced at $2.8 million, is a sign of the super rich's demand for exclusive Ferrari products. Ferrari aims to raise overall shipments to 9,000 by 2019, with the company's stock price hovering below its initial public offering price of $52. Analysts praise limited editions as a key source of profit for the luxury brand, but question whether Ferrari can sustainably produce and sell special models in high volumes.

site_title: Deutsche Bank 'must solve own problems': Dijsselbloem
summary: Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem warned Deutsche Bank to "solve its own problems" after the bank's shares plummeted amid concerns over its financial strength. Dijsselbloem also criticized a $14-billion fine demanded by the US Department of Justice, calling it "too high" and stating it would amplify problems within the banking system. The fine is related to Deutsche Bank's role in the subprime mortgage crisis. The bank must set things right, with the bill to be presented to investors, shareholders, and bondholders, not authorities, Dijsselbloem said.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SPH has announced key appointments in its Chinese Media Group (CMG). Lee Huay Leng will head CMG as of Dec 1, 2016, replacing Chua Chim Kang. Loh Woon Yen will lead the newly renamed Culture, Education and New Growth division, while Ang Yiting will become deputy digital editor. Chee Li Foong will head Chinese, Malay and Tamil titles in SPH's integrated marketing division, starting Oct 12.

site_title: Govt to beef up financial sector competencies for future needs
summary: Singapore's Financial Sector Tripartite Committee launches the Professional Conversion Programme to support financial professionals in transitioning to in-demand areas, such as compliance functions. The programme, in collaboration with the Singapore Workforce Development Agency, provides on-the-job training and aims to strengthen industry competencies. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is also working with polytechnics and universities to prepare the workforce for fintech development, with a focus on core capabilities and digital transformation. The programme is part of the government's effort to support current financial services professionals and boost the pipeline for financial sector opportunities.

site_title: China's yuan joins elite club of IMF reserve currencies
summary: China's yuan has joined the International Monetary Fund's special drawing rights (SDR) basket, marking a milestone in the country's campaign for global economic recognition. The move, announced on the same day as China celebrates the founding of the People's Republic, makes the yuan the 5th reserve currency, alongside the US dollar, euro, yen, and British pound. The IMF's decision is seen as a recognition of China's economic development and openness, but critics argue it is largely symbolic and the yuan does not fully meet IMF criteria.

images.alt_text: China's yuan joins the International Monetary Fund's basket of reserve currencies on Saturday in a milestone for the government's campaign for recognition as a global economic power.

site_title: Sale of SMRT's operating assets to LTA completed
summary: The sale of SMRT's operating assets to the Land Transport Authority (LTA) was completed on September 30, 2016. SMRT Trains surrendered existing licences, while LTA granted SMRT Trains a New Rail Financing Framework (NRFF) licence, allowing it to operate lines for 15 years starting October 1. This deal was part of the NRFF, which aims to provide financing for rail projects in Singapore.

site_title: Global coffee exports rise 9.5% in August: ICO
summary: Global coffee exports rose 9.5% in August to 9.76 million 60kg bags, the International Coffee Organization (ICO) reported. Arabica coffee exports increased 17.3% to 6.35 million bags, while Robusta coffee exports fell 2.4% to 3.41 million bags. For the first 11 months of the 2015/16 season, coffee exports were down 1% to 102.75 million bags.

site_title: US: Wall St boosted by financial, tech stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, driven by gains in financials and technology sectors. The S&P 500 financial index increased 0.92%, outpacing other major sectors, while the technology index rose 0.43% led by Apple's 0.7% gain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reached new highs, with the Nasdaq Composite also advancing. Notable gains included Deutsche Bank's 6.8% rise and Qualcomm's 3.5% increase after a reported $30 billion deal.

site_title: EU seeks to contain looming battle over top jobs
summary: The European Union is facing a potential power struggle as the mandate of EU parliamentary speaker Martin Schulz ends in January, potentially triggering a battle among political parties and member states for influence. Schulz's centre-left group had promised a conservative successor, but this could give the right control of all three major EU bodies, including Luxembourg's Jean-Claude Juncker and Poland's Donald Tusk. Juncker and Tusk are expected to want to stay in their positions, and Schulz has hinted at potentially challenging Chancellor Angela Merkel in Germany's parliamentary election. Diplomats are urging stability and caution, as the EU grapples with Brexit and other crises.

site_title: Cosco Corp delays delivery of completed rig
summary: Cosco Corp has delayed the delivery date of a completed $200-million accommodation rig for Axis Offshore by another year, pushing it back from July 15, 2016, to August 20, 2017. The rig was originally scheduled for delivery in the first quarter of 2015. Shipowner Axis Nova Singapore can take delivery anytime during the extension period with at least 80 days' written notice, or risk having the right to cancel the contract before August 4, 2017. The financial impact of the agreement is unclear at this time.

site_title: US funds hold global portfolio steady in September
summary: US fund managers maintained their global portfolio steady in September, trimming equity allocations to 52.2% and increasing bond exposure to 35.8%. Recommendations for non-traditional instruments, such as derivatives and commodities, rose to 6.1%. The decision reflects a gloomy economic outlook and anticipation of a possible Federal Reserve rate hike in December, following better-than-expected US data.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss for H2, while London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, and Singapore stocks rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US consumer sentiment climbs for first time in four months
summary: US consumer sentiment rose to 91.2 in September, the first increase in four months, as Americans grew optimistic about income prospects and low inflation. The University of Michigan's final index of sentiment rose from 89.8 in August, driven by moderate wage increases and subdued gasoline and grocery costs. However, consumers' assessments of current economic conditions were the weakest in almost a year, which may keep spending moderate. The gauge of expectations six months from now increased to 82.7, the highest since May.

images.alt_text: Consumer confidence rose in September for the first time in four months as Americans grew more upbeat about the prospects for incomes and persistent low inflation.

site_title: Much 2017 oil demand growth to bypass refineries: BP
summary: BP's head of refining economics, Richard de Caux, predicts that US shale gas will displace a significant portion of the world's growing energy demand in 2017, cutting into the need for oil products from refineries. NGLs from the US shale boom, such as ethane, could meet up to a third of demand growth, while existing refined oil products in storage will further undercut refinery profits. This is expected to limit refinery margins and runs, potentially leading to closures of ageing units in Japan and the US.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Credit Suisse upgraded Singapore's 2016 GDP growth estimates due to improved growth in Europe and China. Bank lending in Singapore rose 1.1% in August, the same pace as in July. Jurong Port appointed Ng Chee Keong as its new chairman, and Vietnam's TTC Group plans a US$600m Singapore listing. Meanwhile, Serrano was ordered to pay S$33.4m within a week, and global IPO activity is expected to slow down in 2016 before picking up in 2017.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse (CS) has upgraded its forecast for Singapore's GDP (gross domestic product) growth in 2016 to reflect its belief that exports will become less of a drag with improved growth outlook in Europe, post-Brexit United Kingdom as well as China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 17.090 points to 1,652.550. The index saw 586 losers compared to 230 gainers, with a total volume of 1.749 billion lots worth RM2.186 billion.

site_title: India's April-Aug fiscal deficit reaches 76% of full-year target
summary: India's fiscal deficit for the April-August period reached 76.4% of its full-year target, totaling 4.08 trillion rupees (S$83.07 billion). This is higher than the 66.5% of the full-year target for the same period last year. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley aims to reduce the deficit to 3.5% of GDP from 3.9% in the previous year.

site_title: Aston Martin's first powerboat
summary: Aston Martin unveiled its first powerboat, the AM37, at the Monaco Yacht Show. The 37-foot day-cruiser combines expertise from the luxury automotive and yachting world, with two versions available: one powered by Mercury diesel or petrol engines, reaching speeds of up to 50 knots. Owners of an Aston Martin car can opt for a matching color, further blurring the line between road and sea.

images.alt_text: ALL ABOARD: Aston Martin has teamed up with Quintessence Yachts and developed the AM37.

site_title: Thailand confirms first Zika-linked microcephaly in South-east Asia
summary: Thailand reported the first confirmed cases of microcephaly linked to mosquito-borne Zika in South-east Asia, with two cases confirmed. The World Health Organization (WHO) urged action against the virus across the region. US health officials recommended that pregnant women postpone non-essential travel to 11 South-east Asian countries due to the risk of Zika. The WHO's warning comes as the virus spreads across the region, raising concerns about its impact on public health.

images.alt_text: FULL DISCLOSURE: Mr Prasert has dismissed accusations that Thai officials are playing down the risk of Zika to protect its thriving tourist industry.

site_title: Swiss franc drops sharply, chatter that SNB intervening
summary: The Swiss franc plummeted, hitting a two-month high on concerns about the European banking sector, with some speculating the Swiss central bank intervened to cap its strength. The euro fell to a two-month low, while the dollar surged to a 9-day high. The Swiss National Bank may intervene by selling francs and buying euros to control the currency's value, bolstered by expectations of Middle Eastern investment pulling out of the US and into the franc.

site_title: UOL to buy London property through joint-venture firm for £229.6 million
summary: UOL Group Limited has agreed to acquire Holborn Island in London through a joint-venture firm for £229.6 million (S$406.2 million). The freehold nine-storey mixed-use property is located in Farringdon, within walking distance to two tube stations. A deposit of £22.96 million was paid upon signing, with the remaining amount due on November 10, 2016. The acquisition is expected to be financed through internal resources and external borrowings, with no material impact on UOL's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2016 financial year.

site_title: Google rebrands cloud business
summary: Google has rebranded its business-to-business cloud computing brand to Google Cloud, with a focus on improving work efficiency through artificial intelligence. The company aims to better compete with Amazon and Microsoft in the lucrative cloud business. Under the leadership of Diane Greene, Google has made significant progress in courting customers and enhancing its technology. The company has also reported a 33% surge in "other revenue" in its most recent quarter, attributed to gains in cloud computing, and has announced new partnerships and acquisitions to expand its cloud offerings.

site_title: CSC secures S$178 million worth of contracts since April
summary: CSC Holdings Limited secured S$178 million worth of contracts since April 1, 2017, driven by infrastructure projects in Singapore and Malaysia. The company has awarded contracts for MRT station foundations, airfield land preparation, and a foundation project for Petronas' RAPID project. As of Friday, its order book stands at about S$200 million.

site_title: US consumer spending falls unexpectedly in August
summary: US consumer spending unexpectedly fell 0.1% in August, marking the first decline in seven months, according to the Commerce Department. This mixed signal may keep the Federal Reserve cautious about raising interest rates. Despite the decline in spending, inflation showed signs of accelerating. The unexpected drop in consumer spending contradicts analyst expectations of a 0.1% gain.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries appoints Yap Chee Keong as independent director
summary: Sembcorp Industries has appointed Yap Chee Keong as an independent director, effective October 1. Yap brings financial and audit expertise, as well as experience in various industries, to the board. He is a former executive director of The Straits Trading Company and chief financial officer at Singapore Power. His appointment is seen as a boost to the company's audit and risk committees.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks fell amid President Trump's new tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating losses as in H1. London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. MAS and the PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: ST Kinetics' share capital contribution in unit SDDA rises to S$41.2m
summary: ST Engineering's land systems arm, ST Kinetics, has contributed S$31.2 million to the capital of its subsidiary, SDDA Pte Ltd, bringing the total contribution to S$41.2 million. The injection of capital is expected to have no material impact on ST Engineering's consolidated net tangible asset per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower as Deutsche Bank's problems ensure weak end to Q3
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 16.24 points, or 0.56%, on Friday due to global market pressure following Deutsche Bank's struggles. The bank's role in selling sub-prime mortgages that contributed to the 2008 financial crisis has raised concerns about a potential repeat meltdown. Hedge funds reduced their exposure to Deutsche, leading to a sell-off in regional markets. Despite a 0.5% gain for the week and a 1% rise for the quarter, the index's performance was weighed down by the concerns over Deutsche's financial stability.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares down on Deutsche Bank worries
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted 1.46% on Friday, led by concerns over Deutsche Bank's financial woes. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 243.87 points to 16,449.84, while the Topix index dropped 20.47 points to 1,322.78. The decline was attributed to the uncertainty surrounding Deutsche Bank's future, affecting other financial firms.

site_title: Singapore to enhance transparency of firms' beneficial ownership information
summary: Singapore plans to introduce a requirement for companies and limited liability partnerships to maintain information on beneficial ownership in an effort to combat dirty money. The move follows a recommendation from the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) to improve transparency in the beneficial ownership of legal persons. Under the new rules, companies and LLPs will be obligated to identify beneficial owners and make this information available to law enforcement authorities upon request. The Ministry of Finance and the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority are working on the proposed amendment to the Companies Act and the Limited Liability Partnerships Act.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint's new group CEO to start on Oct 1 (Amended)
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited announced the appointment of Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi as group CEO, effective October 1, 2016. He succeeds Lim Ee Seng, who has been CEO for about 12 years. Panote previously relinquished his role as CEO of Univentures Public Company Limited and will step down as remuneration committee member, with Chan Heng Wing replacing him. The remuneration committee will consist of Philip Eng Heng Nee, Charles Mak Ming Ying, and Chan Heng Wing.

site_title: DFI to transfer to SGX Mainboard from Catalist on Oct 5
summary: Duty Free International Limited (DFI) has received shareholder approval to transfer its listing from the Catalist board to the Mainboard of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on October 5. The move aims to expand the company's investor base and enhance its brand recognition, allowing it to better tap into the capital markets for future growth. This strategic move is expected to support DFI's business in Malaysia and the region, with Gebr Heinemann, a travel retail conglomerate, set to play a key role in the company's future growth.

site_title: Yanlord Land appoints CEO's son as executive director
summary: Yanlord Land Group appointed 29-year-old Zhong Ming as executive director, effective October 1, as the son of chairman and CEO Zhong Sheng Jian. Zhong Ming has held various positions since 2013 and will oversee strategies and developments in Shanghai and Tianjin. The appointment comes after Yanlord shares closed 1.06% lower at S$1.40 on Friday.

site_title: Malaysia stock exchange evacuated after bomb threat
summary: Malaysia's stock exchange, Bursa Malaysia, was evacuated on Friday after a bomb threat was reported. Authorities were notified, and as a precaution, all tenants and staff were evacuated. Trading resumed after lunch, but it was unclear if the threat was a hoax or if everyone had been allowed back to work. No further details were immediately available.

site_title: Australian storm disrupts supply of raw materials to Asia
summary: A severe storm in South Australia has caused a massive power outage, disrupting the supply of raw materials to Asia. The Olympic Dam mine, Australia's fourth-largest copper deposit, has been indefinitely idle, and production at steelworks has halted. Lead futures have surged as Asian buyers scramble for alternative supplies, with some plants potentially facing a two-week shutdown. The power outage has raised concerns about the security of electricity in the region, potentially deterring investment in the resources industry and relying on Australia as "Asia's quarry."

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive on Deutsche Bank crisis
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.86% on Friday, wiping out the previous day's gains, due to concerns over Deutsche Bank's future. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 23,297.15, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.49%. The decline was attributed to fears about Deutsche Bank's stability, which has been a significant concern in the financial sector.

site_title: Syrian army, rebels wage fierce battles north of Aleppo city
summary: Syrian government forces and rebels clashed north of Aleppo city on Friday, a week into a Russian-backed offensive. The Syrian army captured the Handarat refugee camp and Kindi Hospital area, according to Hezbollah's Al Manar television. However, a rebel source denied the government's capture of the hospital area, saying battles were ongoing. The conflict intensifies the struggle for control of the entire city, which has been a key battleground in the Syrian Civil War.

images.alt_text: Syrian government forces and rebels waged fierce battles north of Aleppo on Friday, sources on both sides said, a week into a Russian-backed offensive by the Syrian army to take the entire city

site_title: Airbus Group to merge with planemaking unit
summary: Airbus Group will merge with its planemaking unit, simplifying its brand and management structure. The company will be renamed "Airbus" after its core planemaking brand. Fabrice Bregier has been promoted to chief operating officer for the whole group, overseeing digital operations, global supply chain, and quality. This shake-up marks a break with Airbus' complex corporate roots and prepares for tougher competition.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end down on Deutsche woes, won pares losses
summary: South Korean shares fell 1.2% on Friday due to offshore investor selling, amid rising global risk aversion and concerns over Deutsche Bank's financial health. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,043.63 points, ending the month with its third consecutive gain. The won edged down but rose for the fourth straight month, closing at 1,101.3 to the dollar.

site_title: SPH's Chinese Media Group makes key appointments
summary: SPH's Chinese Media Group (CMG) has made key appointments, including Lee Huay Leng as head, effective Dec 1, 2016. Lee, editor of Lianhe Wanbao and senior vice-president of Lianhe Zaobao, will oversee CMG's commercial and operational aspects. Chua Chim Kang will take over as editor of Lianhe Wanbao, and Loh Woon Yen and Ang Yiting will assume new roles in CMG and SPH Radio. The Cultural Industry Promotion Department will be renamed and reorganized. The appointments aim to navigate challenges and seize growth opportunities ahead.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE Press Holdings (SPH) on Friday announced several key appointments in the Chinese Media Group (CMG).

site_title: Indonesia raises cigarette excise tax by 10.5% for 2017
summary: Indonesia plans to increase its cigarette excise tax by 10.5% in 2017 to safeguard public health, following a 11.3% rise this year. The move aims to limit the distribution of cigarettes, which contribute 10-12% to the state budget. Indonesia is one of the world's fastest-growing markets for tobacco products, with US$16 billion in cigarette sales last year. The tax increase will follow a crackdown on the illegal circulation of cigarettes, with the government targeting the country's relatively cheap cigarette prices.

site_title: BOJ's bond buying amount could fluctuate: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank's bond buying amount could fluctuate depending on the amount needed to achieve its yield curve target. The BOJ is internally debating exit strategies for its ultra-easy monetary policy, but Kuroda cautioned against discussing specific means too hastily to avoid market confusion. This comes after the BOJ shifted its policy target to interest rates from the pace of money printing.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO seeks to reassure staff over market concerns
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan reassured staff amid declining shares due to speculation and a disputed US$14 billion fine. Cryan stated the bank is solid with over 20 million customers and has weathered similar cases from competitors. He emphasized that the current turmoil is driven by market forces, not the outcome of the fine. Cryan's internal letter aimed to boost confidence and maintain business operations despite the challenges.

site_title: Chan Yeng Kit, Ng Chee Khern appointed chairman of IMDA, GovTech respectively
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information announced the appointment of Chan Yeng Kit as chairman of the Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) and Ng Chee Khern as chairman of GovTech, both taking effect October 1. Chan replaces himself as chairman of IDA, while Ng replaces himself as chairman of MDA. The agencies will officially be established on October 1 following the restructuring of IDA and MDA. The appointments aim to leverage experience from previous boards, with 17 of the 18 IMDA board members and 6 of the 13 GovTech board members having served on IDA or MDA boards.

site_title: Thailand confirms two cases of Zika-linked microcephaly, first in region
summary: Thailand has confirmed two cases of Zika-linked microcephaly, a rare birth defect, marking the first time the condition has been linked to the Zika virus in South-east Asia. The cases were found in two babies born with small heads, and health authorities have confirmed 349 Zika cases in Thailand since January, including 33 pregnant women. The World Health Organisation has also reported over 1,800 confirmed cases of microcephaly linked to Zika in Brazil.

images.alt_text: Thailand confirmed on Friday that the Zika virus had caused two cases of microcephaly, a condition that results in babies being born with small heads, the first time microcephaly had been linked to Zika in South-east Asia.

site_title: Growth in peril as east Europeans "sweat blood" to find workers
summary: Eastern European countries, particularly Hungary, Poland, and the Czech Republic, are struggling to find workers to fill labor shortages, threatening economic growth and living standards. The countries' heavy emigration to Western Europe has led to a brain drain, with many skilled workers leaving for richer neighboring countries. To address the issue, some countries are trying to poach workers from poorer, non-EU neighbors, but economists warn that this could damage the quality of the labor force and deter foreign investors, ultimately hurting the region's economic growth.

images.alt_text: At peak harvest time, Hungarian winemaker Sandor Font has enough work for 30 people at his vineyard south of Budapest - if only he could find enough grape-pickers.

site_title: Sting back to rock and striving to stay optimistic
summary: Rock legend Sting is set to release his 57th and 9th album, marking a return to his rock roots after a decade of experimentation. The album, out November 11, includes songs about the refugee crisis, climate change, and mortality, with Sting citing empathy as a key solution to these issues. Sting also performed with Syrian musicians who fled the country, asking for their permission to record a song about their experiences. The album's release comes as Sting reflects on his own mortality and the changing world around him.

site_title: Australia shares end lower, NZ regains footing
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.7% to close at 5,435.9, driven by losses in financials. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.24% to 7,361.09, marking its fourth consecutive quarterly gain. Telecom counters led gains in NZ, while Southern Cross Media was the worst performer in Australia, down 13.2% after Nine Entertainment Co exited the company.

site_title: Panama Papers dents new Panama incorporations, seen down 20%
summary: Panama's new company incorporations are expected to drop 20% this year due to the Panama Papers scandal, which exposed offshore financial data and sparked criticism of the country's lack of transparency. The decline in company openings began in 2008, accelerating this year, and is attributed to higher transparency requirements. The scandal has not affected the Panamanian economy or its credit rating, according to Finance Minister Dulcidio De La Guardia.
