site_title: Why top fashion models never smile
summary: Fashion models are often seen as expressionless and unsmiling, a trend dating back to the 1980s with Japanese designers Yohji Yamamoto and Comme des Garçons. This style was a reaction to the more expressive supermodels of the 1960s. Fashion historians argue that the trend was also influenced by the rise of feminism and women's need to be taken seriously in their professional lives. However, some designers, like Paul Smith, encourage models to smile, and a few iconoclasts, like Jean Paul Gaultier, have cast models smiling in their shows.

site_title: CIMB Bank gets licence to operate full subsidiary in Vietnam
summary: CIMB Bank has received a licence to operate a full subsidiary in Vietnam, marking the country's first foreign bank to do so in seven years. The bank aims to offer full commercial and retail banking products by December 2016. CIMB Vietnam will be based in Hanoi and is expected to advance bilateral and trade ties between Malaysia and Vietnam. The licence was granted by the State Bank of Vietnam, with Deputy Governor Nguyen Phuoc Thanh expressing support for cooperation between the two countries.

images.alt_text: CIMB Bank has obtained the licence to operate in Vietnam, and aims to start offering the full range of commercial and retail banking products in the country by December, it said in a release on Friday

site_title: China to submit homegrown nuclear reactor design for UK review
summary: China is set to submit its Hualong One nuclear reactor design for UK review, marking a significant step towards building two reactors in southern England and expanding exports. The reactor design will be reviewed by UK regulators, with the aim to complete the process in five years. China General Nuclear Power Corp plans to build two reactors with a capacity of 1.15 gigawatts at the proposed Bradwell B project, with a 66.5% stake. This move aims to increase China's nuclear technology exports and pave the way for wider acceptance of its atomic technology globally.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open on Deutsche Bank woes
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading on Friday due to concerns over Deutsche Bank's weak financial strength. The DAX 30 index in Frankfurt dropped 1.6%, while London's FTSE 100 index fell 1.3% and the Paris CAC 40 index lost 1.4%. Deutsche Bank shares plummeted over 7%, affecting its peers such as Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays. The declines weighed on overall market sentiment, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 and London's FTSE 100 indices experiencing significant losses.

site_title: Sharp says to invest 57.4b yen in OLED business
summary: Sharp Corp plans to invest 57.4 billion yen (S$772 million) in its OLED business between April and June 2018, shifting towards display production for smartphones, cars, and TVs. The investment won't affect financial results in the year to March.

site_title: AXA, Allianz vie for StanChart general insurance distribution deal
summary: AXA and Allianz have advanced to the second stage of bidding for a Standard Chartered distribution deal, which could be worth around $300 million. The deal would enable the sale of general insurance products through Standard Chartered's Asian branches. Other bidders include Japan's MS&AD and another Japanese insurer, with the bank set to evaluate offers after the second round to decide on a preferred bidder. Standard Chartered will decide on a preferred partner for the bancassurance deal in a hotly contested race.

images.alt_text: AXA and Allianz SE have advanced to the second stage of bidding for a Standard Chartered distribution deal that would enable sale of general insurance products through the bank's Asian branches, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Creditors seek bankruptcy restructuring for Dongbei Special Steel
summary: Creditors of Dongbei Special Steel, a Chinese state-owned steelmaker, are seeking bankruptcy restructuring after the company's parent, Fushun Special Steel, announced that a court is reviewing an application. Dongbei has defaulted on nine bonds this year and has been involved in a struggle with creditors over debt restructuring. The company had proposed a debt-to-equity swap, but creditors objected. A court-managed bankruptcy process may lead to liquidation, setting a worrying precedent after the recent liquidation of Guangxi Nonferrous Metal Group.

site_title: Hot stock: SMRT shares resume trading in large volumes, remain sticky at Temasek's price
summary: SMRT Corporation shares resumed trading on Friday after a one-day halt, guided towards Temasek Holdings' offer price of S$1.68 per share. Trading volumes were high, with 7.3 million shares changing hands in the first two hours. The share price opened at S$1.675 and remained sticky, with some shareholders approving Temasek's buyout offer and others voting on the sale of rail operating assets to the government. The share price has not yet reached the offer price, but has shown a 1.2% increase from Wednesday's close.

site_title: Indonesian scavengers scrape a living by recycling
summary: Indonesian scavengers collect used plastic bottles and sell them to companies for reuse, providing a rare example of recycling in the city of Jakarta, where a lack of official recycling systems and overflowing waste have become major issues. The city generates 6,500 tonnes of rubbish daily, with much ending up in the main garbage dump or rivers, posing a threat to the environment and public health. However, some parts of the city have seen improvements in waste management, with authorities increasing river cleaning efforts.

images.alt_text: Sifting through piles of pungent trash in the Indonesian capital Jakarta, scores of men and women collect used plastic bottles with their bare hands and put them into big bags.

site_title: Credit Suisse upgrades its Singapore 2016 GDP growth estimates
summary: Credit Suisse has upgraded its GDP growth forecast for Singapore in 2016 to 1.4%, citing improved growth in Europe and China. The upgrade also reflects the region's pro-growth fiscal policies and lighter burden on Asian central banks. The bank maintains its negative view on Singapore's structural growth prospects and forecasts 1.1% GDP growth in 2017. Inflation forecasts for 2016 and 2017 are also raised, with expectations of -0.7% and -0.1% year-on-year growth, respectively.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall as central bank holds rate, track overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.7% on Friday, following weakness in overseas markets and a decision by the central bank to hold interest rates unchanged. The TAIEX index closed at 9,207.15 points, with the electronics subindex sinking 0.6% and the financials subindex losing 1.1%. The Taiwan dollar also weakened to NT$31.374 per US dollar. The central bank cited a need for structural policies to support the trade-dependent economy.

site_title: Thai Aug factory output unexpectedly rises 3.1%, 40-month high
summary: Thailand's industrial output unexpectedly rose 3.1% in August, the fastest pace in 40 months, driven by stronger demand for air conditioners, electronics, and steel. This marks a reversal from July's decline of 4.99%. Industrial goods accounted for 80% of total exports, which rose 6.5% from a year earlier. The Bank of Thailand forecasts shipments will contract 2.5% this year, but the economy is expected to grow 3.2%.

site_title: Asia: Markets track US losses on Deutsch Bank worries
summary: Asian markets tumbled on Friday, tracking a US sell-off due to concerns over Deutsche Bank's viability after a US$14 billion penalty. Deutsche Bank plunged 7% in New York, affecting other financial stocks such as Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and HSBC. The declines also dragged broader markets down, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney experiencing losses. Despite a 0.2% gain in Shanghai, the region's markets overall fell, with currency markets also affected by the unease.

site_title: Tesla says Autopilot not to blame in crash with bus in Germany
summary: A Tesla car operating under Autopilot in northern Germany collided with a bus, but the electric car maker claims the collision was unavoidable due to the bus swerving into the vehicle's lane. The driver, 50, was slightly injured, while 29 bus passengers were uninjured. Tesla denies Autopilot was at fault, stating it was functioning properly and the accident was unrelated. The incident has raised scrutiny over the safety of Tesla's Autopilot system, which has been the focus of intense scrutiny since a fatal accident in July.

images.alt_text: A Tesla Motors Inc car operating under Autopilot collided with a bus in northern Germany, but the electric car maker said a collision was unavoidable because the bus swerved into the vehicle's lane.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.43% in the first few minutes of trade on Friday, driven by concerns over the future of Deutsche Bank. The Hang Seng Index fell to 23,400.13, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.14%. The decline was attributed to worries about Deutsche Bank's financial stability, affecting financial firms.

site_title: US seeks joint settlement of banks' mortgage claims: FT
summary: The US Department of Justice is seeking a joint settlement with Deutsche Bank, Barclays, and Credit Suisse over mortgage mis-selling, potentially extracting multibillion-dollar fines. Grouping the banks together could secure maximum publicity for the large penalties ahead of the US presidential election. Deutsche Bank has already faced a US$14 billion settlement request and is negotiating a lower amount. A combined settlement with Barclays and Credit Suisse could shift attention away from Deutsche Bank. The outcome could have significant implications for the European banks involved.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Justice hopes to agree a combined settlement with Deutsche Bank AG, Barclays Plc and Credit Suisse Group AG, extracting multibillion dollar fines from the three European banks for mis-selling mortgage securities, the Financial Times reported Friday.

site_title: Australia: Shares pressured by European bank worries, New Zealand inches down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Friday, led by financials, due to concerns over European banks, particularly Deutsche Bank. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 42.95 points to 5,428.3. National Australia Bank and Australia and New Zealand Banking fell 1.2% and 0.3%, respectively. Weaker iron ore prices also pressured mining stocks. New Zealand's benchmark index edged down 0.05% as utilities led losses.

site_title: Jurong Port appoints new chairman, adds two board members
summary: Jurong Port has appointed Ng Chee Keong as its new chairman, effective October 1, replacing Lee Chong Kwee. Two new board members, Robert Yap Min Choy and V Sivarajan, have also been added. Subramaniam Iyer will step down. Ng brings 44 years of experience, including a stint as senior leadership at PSA, while Yap and Sivarajan bring finance and industry expertise. The board now consists of nine members.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stock selloff pares best quarterly advance since 2009
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.3% on September 30, trimming their best quarterly gain since 2009. The Hang Seng Index's 13% increase since June was pared as financial companies, led by Bank of Communications Co, declined 2.8%. Concerns over Germany's largest lender's health drove the sell-off.

site_title: Wealthy Indonesians line up for tax amnesty after slow start
summary: Wealthy Indonesians are signing up for the country's tax amnesty program, more than doubling the number of participants from the previous week. As of Friday, 299,087 people and institutions had declared assets worth 3,196 trillion rupiah (S$334.71 billion), far below the government's initial target of 165 trillion rupiah. Despite this, the government has earned 93.5 trillion rupiah in revenue, and some of Indonesia's wealthiest individuals, including the son of former dictator Suharto, have signed up for the program.

site_title: Modi's hunt for undisclosed assets set to go down to the wire
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is urging officials to work late to handle a last-minute rush of declarations of undisclosed assets, which is set to end this month. The government aims to curb black money, estimated at 30 trillion rupees, with a one-time chance to declare foreign funds. Despite previous efforts, only about 25 billion rupees were declared last year, and tax rates may be a major obstacle. The government's goal is to improve India's tax-to-gross domestic product ratio and boost revenue, but critics argue that past promises have been empty, and the true impact of the initiative remains to be seen.

site_title: Duterte rejects Hitler comparison, 'happy' to kill drug addicts
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has rejected comparisons to Adolf Hitler, saying he'd be "happy to slaughter" 3 million drug addicts, following a speech where he claimed the deaths of 1,000 to 3,000 people since his anti-drug campaign began were comparable to Hitler's genocide of 3 million Jews.

site_title: Bank lending expands for second straight month in August: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore increased 1.1% in August from July, with business loans rising 1.6% and consumer loans growing 0.4%. The August growth is the same pace as in July, but year-on-year, lending fell 1.6% due to a 2.2% contraction in July. The Monetary Authority of Singapore reported a total of S$604 billion in loans, with S$357 billion in business loans and S$247 billion in consumer loans.

site_title: Europe's populist surge fuelled by migrant crisis
summary: Populist movements across Europe are fueled by the migrant crisis, with several countries holding referendums or elections that reflect growing anti-immigrant sentiment. In Germany, the Alternative for Germany party won seats in the regional parliament, while in Austria, the Freedom Party narrowly missed winning a presidential election. Hungary is set to hold a referendum on a migrant relocation quota plan, and in Poland, the Law and Justice party has capitalized on fears over refugees. Other countries, including Denmark, Finland, Britain, France, and the Netherlands, also have populist parties gaining traction, often fueled by concerns over immigration and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Oil prices down on doubts over Opec deal
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia as doubts emerged over the long-term success of the Opec agreement to cut output and stabilize the oversupplied market. The deal, announced on Wednesday, aims to trim collective production by around 750,000 barrels per day, but analysts are skeptical about its execution and potential impact on the market. Relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran, crucial to the deal, are also uncertain, and the planned cuts may not materialize until 2017. As a result, oil prices dropped, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate down 27 cents at US$47.56 and Brent easing 31 cents to US$48.93.

site_title: World leaders gather for funeral of Nobel laureate Peres
summary: World leaders, including US President Barack Obama and Prince Charles, gathered in Israel for the funeral of Nobel laureate Shimon Peres, who died at 93. Peres, a former prime minister and president, was hailed as a peacemaker after his death, but was criticized by Palestinians and Arab nations for his involvement in conflicts and occupation of Palestinian territory. Peres will be buried next to Yitzhak Rabin, his rival and partner in negotiating the Oslo peace accords. The funeral drew an estimated 30,000 mourners and represented over 70 countries.

site_title: Singapore shares open 22.91 points lower on Friday
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 22.91 points, or 0.79%, to 2,862.80, with 141.1 million shares changing hands. Investors were cautious amid oil-producing countries' production cuts and concerns over Deutsche Bank. The market saw 99 losers and 35 gainers, with a total trading value of S$189.5 million.

site_title: Oil heads for second monthly gain as Opec agrees to output cut
summary: Opec agreed to reduce oil production for the first time in eight years, aiming for a range of 32.5-33 million barrels a day. The deal is set to bring oil prices up 6.8% for the month, marking the first September increase since 2010. Iran will be exempt from the cuts, and an Opec committee will recommend production caps in November. However, the implementation of the cuts faces challenges, with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley expressing skepticism about its feasibility.

site_title: Jack Nicklaus golf course picked to thwart North Korean missiles
summary: A Jack Nicklaus-designed golf course in South Korea has been selected as the new site for the US Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense (Thaad) missile system, replacing the original location in Seongju county. The move aims to address concerns over the system's impact on local health. China and Russia remain opposed to Thaad, which they believe will destabilize the region, while North Korea has threatened dire consequences if the system is deployed. The decision still faces obstacles, including opposition from local groups and China's economic retaliation.

site_title: Japan's Aug jobless rate at 3.1%, jobs availability at 1.37
summary: Japan's jobless rate rose to 3.1% in August, matching the median forecast, and the jobs-to-applicants ratio remained unchanged at 1.37, the highest level since 1991. This indicates a tight labor market. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was the lowest since 1995, but the number of unemployed people actually increased.

site_title: The UK economy is flying blind 100 days after the Brexit vote
summary: The UK economy remains uncertain 100 days after the Brexit vote, with Prime Minister Theresa May's exit strategy unclear. Firms are struggling to make investment and hiring decisions due to the lack of clarity on the business environment and future trading arrangements. The Bank of England warns of a slowdown in economic growth, with economists expecting a more than 50% decline in expansion next year. The government's slow approach to formal exit negotiations has pushed any clues about the new relationship into the distance, leaving businesses and investors in the dark about the future.

site_title: South Korea's factory output falls at fastest pace in 19 months, misses expectations
summary: South Korea's factory output fell by 2.4% in August, the largest decline in 19 months, exceeding analyst expectations of a 0.5% drop. This marks the sharpest decline since January 2015. The service sector output grew 0.7% in seasonally adjusted terms, following a revised 0.3% decline in July. The data suggests a slowdown in the country's economy.

site_title: Former party boss of China's Guangzhou jailed for life
summary: A Chinese court has jailed Wan Qingliang, the former Communist Party boss of Guangzhou, for life after finding him guilty of corruption. The conviction was made in a Nanning court, and Wan's assets have been ordered seized. Wan was put under investigation in 2014.

site_title: Saudi Arabia warns of 'disastrous consequences' over US 9/11 law
summary: Saudi Arabia has warned of "disastrous consequences" following the US Congress's override of President Barack Obama's veto of the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act (JASTA), allowing 9/11 victims to sue the kingdom. The law weakens state immunity, a concern among Gulf Cooperation Council members, including Saudi Arabia. Analysts predict a potential reduction in Saudi security and intelligence cooperation with the US, citing a decades-old relationship based on the exchange of American security for Saudi oil. Saudi officials have threatened to pull out billions of dollars in US assets if the law becomes law.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open down on Deutsche Bank worries
summary: Tokyo shares dropped 1.28% on Friday due to concerns over the global financial system, particularly Deutsche Bank. The benchmark Nikkei-225 index fell 213.76 points to 16,479.95. Hedge funds reduced their exposure to Deutsche Bank, questioning its strength.

site_title: Spotify's 40 million tunes won't go far with CD-happy Japanese
summary: Spotify has entered Japan's music market, but its success may be limited due to the country's strong preference for physical music formats, such as CDs. On a recent visit to Tokyo, a 21-year-old university student found CDs at a music retail chain, highlighting the potential challenge for Spotify. The service's 40 million tracks may not be enough to compete with the country's existing CD market, which is estimated to be worth around $1.3 billion.

images.alt_text: On a recent muggy afternoon in Tokyo, 21-year old Shintaro Naganuma joined several hundred customers browsing CDs at the eight-story downtown outpost of music retail chain Tsutaya.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.12 points to 1,668.52. Volume was 87.47 million lots worth RM23.2 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 92 to 76.

site_title: Australia's Woolworths in takeover talks for its petrol business
summary: Australia's Woolworths is in talks with potential buyers for its petrol business, valued at A$1.5 billion. The company has received several incomplete and conditional proposals, but no formal bid has been submitted. Woolworths is undecided on its outlook for the business, stating it is evaluating whether to retain or dispose of it. The move comes after reports that Caltex Australia was in final-stage negotiations with Woolworths for a deal worth A$1.5 billion.

site_title: Japan Aug industrial output up 1.5% month-on-month: data
summary: Japan's industrial output increased 1.5% month-on-month in August, surpassing market forecasts, following a 0.4% decline in July. Manufacturers predict further growth, with a 2.2% increase in September and 1.2% in October. This tentative sign of a factory activity pickup comes amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: One dead, 114 hurt as New Jersey train crash causes major damage
summary: A New Jersey train crashed into a station during morning rush hour, killing one person and injuring 114. The train, carrying 250 passengers, entered the Hoboken station at a high speed, crashing through barriers and into the terminal. The sole confirmed fatality, Fabiola Bittar de Kroon, was a 34-year-old resident of Hoboken. Investigators are working to determine the cause of the crash, which has caused major damage to the transit hub. The engineer was treated and released, and no indication of a system failure or human error has been found.

site_title: Oil prices down on profit-taking after two-day jump
summary: Oil prices dropped on Friday, retreating from a 7% two-day surge, as investors took profits amid doubts about the impact of Opec's first output cut in eight years on the global crude glut. London Brent crude fell 8 cents to $49.16 a barrel, while NYMEX crude dropped 8 cents to $47.75 a barrel. The Opec agreement aims to remove 700,000 barrels per day from the market, but analysts estimate the global oversupply at 1.0-1.5 million barrels per day.

site_title: UK consumer confidence surges to pre-Brexit levels: survey
summary: British consumer confidence surged to pre-Brexit levels in September, according to a survey, contradicting expectations of lasting economic damage. The GfK index, based on a poll of 2,000 people, rose to -1 from -7 in August, with analysts attributing the rebound to growing wages, employment, and low interest rates. However, economists warn that the rebound is fragile and that rising inflation pressure from the pound's slump could erode consumers' spending power in the months ahead.

site_title: Deal signed for giant UK nuclear project
summary: The UK has signed a contract with a French-Chinese consortium to build Britain's first nuclear plant in a generation, the Hinkley Point project. The £18 billion deal, which includes a 1/3 stake from China, has been delayed due to concerns over national security and funding. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's power needs by 2025 and create 26,000 jobs. The government has set conditions for the deal, including limiting China's control and requiring more scrutiny of national security concerns.

site_title: Global IPO activity to slow down in 2016, pick up in 2017: EY
summary: Global initial public offering (IPO) activity is expected to slow down in 2016 due to geopolitical uncertainty, but is expected to pick up in 2017. According to Ernst & Young, global IPO proceeds in the first nine months of 2016 were 39% lower than in the same period in 2015, with deal volumes down 23%. However, the Asia-Pacific region emerged as a focal point for IPOs globally, with a 138% surge in proceeds in the third quarter. Stability is expected to return in 2017 due to improving economic fundamentals and lower volatility.

site_title: Mexico, Cuba, US talk again on 'Doughnut Hole' in Gulf waters
summary: Mexico, the US, and Cuba held a second round of talks on the limits of the Western Polygon, a Gulf of Mexico oil-rich area, with the aim of defining the coordinates of their respective limits. The discussions, prompted by restored diplomatic ties in 2014, are guided by international law allowing countries to claim resources within 200 nautical miles of their territory. The talks concluded on Friday, with officials seeking to craft an agreement to resolve the overlapping claims in the "Doughnut Hole" area.

site_title: Serrano told to pay S$33.4m within a week; bankruptcy proceedings against director adjourned
summary: Serrano, an interior-design contractor, has been asked by Maybank to pay approximately S$33.4 million within seven days. The company has received letters of demand from Maybank's lawyers regarding corporate guarantees. If the amounts are not paid, Maybank reserves the right to commence legal proceedings. Meanwhile, two bankruptcy proceedings against Serrano's directors have been adjourned to October 20.

site_title: Market won't play ball with BOJ's new rate regime
summary: The Bank of Japan's new monetary policy framework, aiming to control the 'yield curve' and keep 10-year bond yields at zero percent, is facing skepticism from the market. Despite the central bank's pledge, 10-year yields have fallen to minus 0.09 percent, putting pressure on the BOJ to take action. Reducing bond purchases could undermine the stimulus policy, triggering a yen spike and market volatility. BOJ officials remain confident in their ability to manage the yield curve, but experts question the feasibility of such control.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SMRT, Serrano, oil-related counters
summary: Shares of SMRT Corporation may be affected due to Temasek Holdings' approved buyout offer at S$1.68 per share. The transport operator's trading halt has been lifted, and its share price will be closely watched. Serrano and its subsidiary must pay S$33.4 million within seven days, while two bankruptcy proceedings against its directors have been adjourned. The OPEC's deal to cut oil output has raised concerns about its lasting impact, as Saudi Arabia exempted Iran, a bitter rival.

site_title: Renault-Nissan boss says needs UK Brexit guarantees
summary: Renault-Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn stated that his company needs UK Brexit guarantees before committing to further investment in Nissan's Sunderland plant. Ghosn expressed concerns over the impact of Brexit on the plant's tax regime and cross-border duties. He mentioned that if favorable conditions are met, Renault-Nissan can proceed with investment, but the company cannot stay if conditions do not justify it. The Sunderland plant, employing 6,700 people, is Nissan's largest European factory.

site_title: Europe: Shares flat as weak drugmakers offset strong oils; Commerzbank dips
summary: European shares ended flat on Thursday, with energy shares rising 4.3% following the Opec agreement to cut output to 32.5-33.0 million barrels per day. However, drugmakers offset these gains, and Commerzbank slid 3.1% after freezing dividend payments and cutting over a fifth of its workforce. Analysts expect European equities to continue seeing-sawing due to sluggish earnings growth, but central bank liquidity may provide support.

site_title: World's top soft-drink stock taps Chelsea FC
summary: Thai energy-drink maker Carabao Group Pcl has partnered with Chelsea FC in a £30 million, three-year sponsorship deal to fuel its global expansion. The company aims to increase its foreign revenue share to 50% and boost its UK market share, with plans to distribute 2 million free cans of its drink to challenge market leader Red Bull. Despite concerns about the impact on earnings, analysts expect the company's sales to compensate for the initial high marketing expenses.

site_title: Deutsche Bank shares sink 7% after report on withdrawals
summary: Deutsche Bank shares dropped 7% after a report revealed that 10 hedge funds withdrew excess cash and derivatives from the bank, amid concerns over its financial strength. The US Department of Justice is pressing for a $14 billion penalty over mortgage-backed securities, which could weaken the bank's capital foundations. The bank's clients have largely remained unaffected, with the vast majority making no changes to their exposure. Despite the bank's reassurances, shares continued to fall, affecting Frankfurt and New York markets.

site_title: Meet 8 ambitious wine upstarts
summary: The article highlights the emergence of a new generation of ambitious winemakers in Napa Valley, expanding beyond the traditional Cabernet Sauvignon model. These up-and-coming vintners, including Rory Williams of Calder Wine Co, Ketan Mody of Beta Wines and Jasud Estate, and Alex and Graeme MacDonald of MacDonald, are experimenting with elegant reds, syrah, and riesling. They are also focusing on terroir-driven wines and investing in sustainable practices, offering a fresh perspective on the region's wine scene.

site_title: Global warming set to pass 2 deg C threshold in 2050: report
summary: Global warming is projected to surpass the 2-degree Celsius threshold by 2050, according to a report by seven top climate scientists. Since 1990, devastating weather events have doubled in number due to climate change. The planet has already warmed 1.0 degree Celsius above pre-industrial levels, and the Paris Agreement aims to limit warming to "well under" 2 degrees Celsius. However, the report finds pledges to reduce greenhouse gas emissions are "totally inadequate," requiring governments to double their efforts to meet the target. Urgent steps are needed to decarbonize the global economy.

images.alt_text: Since 1990, devastating weather-related events - floods, drought, more intense storms, heat waves and wild fires - due to climate change have doubled in number, Watson and the other scientists said in a report.

site_title: Saudis agree to surprise oil output cut with exemption for Iran
summary: OPEC agreed to cut oil production by 1.2 million barrels per day, marking the first reduction in eight years, with Saudi Arabia allowing Iran to be exempt. The deal aims to stabilize prices, which surged 6% after the announcement. Analysts say the move may not have a lasting impact due to OPEC's poor track record of fulfilling commitments and the ongoing rivalry between Saudi Arabia and Iran.

site_title: City buzz
summary: The Business Times celebrates its 40th anniversary with a series of events, including a concert by jazz legend Jeremy Monteiro, dubbed Jazzy Business, featuring an all-star lineup. The concert coincides with Monteiro's 40th year in showbiz and the launch of his new album, Montage. The event also marks the launch of his own timepiece brand, J. Monteiro Watches. Meanwhile, the National Gallery Singapore showcases a large body of work by acclaimed potter Iskandar Jalil, and the Australian World Orchestra performs a debut concert in Singapore, featuring musicians from top orchestras around the world.

site_title: Federal Reserve orders Chinese bank to tighten laundering controls
summary: The US Federal Reserve ordered the Agricultural Bank of China to strengthen its internal controls against money laundering after a former staffer alleged mistreatment for reporting possible violations. The staffer, Natasha Taft, settled her complaint without public findings of guilt. The move follows a 2020 complaint from Taft, who claimed she was mistreated after reporting the bank's potential money laundering issues.

images.alt_text: A paramilitary policeman walks past an Agricultural Bank of China building in Beijing, China, on Aug 26, 2016.The US Federal Reserve said on Thursday that it had ordered the Agricultural Bank of China, one of China's largest banks, to strengthen its internal controls against money laundering.

site_title: Don't let math take over your marketing
summary: Marketers are increasingly relying on advanced analytics and technology to measure return on investment, but this approach can lead to a lack of creativity and memorable storytelling. Effective marketers strike a balance between data-driven decision-making and creative capabilities, recognizing that magic and intuition are essential for great marketing. A survey of 430 US and Canadian companies found that leaders were more likely to use data and rely on their own creative capabilities, while also experimenting and taking calculated risks.

site_title: US: Deutsche Bank worries hit stocks
summary: US stocks plummeted 0.9% on Thursday after a report revealed Deutsche Bank withdrew funds from 10 hedge funds due to financial stability concerns. The S&P 500 finished at 2,151.13. Analysts fear a potential US$14 billion penalty from the US Department of Justice could undermine Deutsche Bank's capital foundations. The news sparked worries about the health of the world's largest bank, likening it to the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Shareholders okay Temasek buyout, sale of rail assets
summary: SMRT shareholders overwhelmingly approved Temasek Holdings' S$1.2 billion buyout plan, with 84.83% voting in favor. The deal also includes the sale of rail assets to the government under the new rail financing framework, valued at S$991 million. Shareholders expressed concerns about the "political" nature of Singapore's public transport system, which may impact future profit margins and fare increases. The proposal now awaits High Court approval, with a payout expected around November 1 and delisting expected after.

images.alt_text: SMRT shareholders leaving after the scheme meeting at Star Vista on Thursday. 84.83 per cent, or 3,747, of the minority shareholders present and voting in person or by proxy voted in favour of Temasek's offer.

site_title: Vietnam sugar producer plans US$600m Singapore listing
summary: Vietnam's TTC Group, a sugar, energy, and real estate conglomerate, plans to list its sugar unit in Singapore, raising approximately $600 million. The company aims to become a global player and has already expanded its sugar operations beyond Vietnam to Cambodia and Laos. TTC Sugar will merge with another sugar company, creating a combined entity worth $200 million and Vietnam's largest sugar company. The company expects its sugar business to generate $35 million of its 2016 pre-tax income and will invest an additional $600 million in its sugar business through 2020.

site_title: US$ surges vs yen after Opec deal
summary: The US dollar surged to an eight-day high against the yen on Thursday after an Opec deal to cut oil output, with the dollar jumping 1.1% to 101.75 yen. The deal, which reduces oil output by 0.7-2.2%, was seen as a risk-on driver, but analysts questioned its efficacy and potential for market volatility. The greenback remained up 0.8% on the day, trading above 95.46 on a basket of currencies, as markets remained cautious on the deal's implementation.

site_title: Holding their own (Amended)
summary: Female choreographers in the male-dominated field of contemporary dance are gaining recognition in Singapore. Sarah Foster-Sproull's work, "In the Distance," explores migration and human relationships, while Emmanuele Phuon Brodal Serei's "Brodal Serei" delves into the macho world of Cambodian boxing. Raka Maitra's "The Second Sunrise" is inspired by war stories in Sri Lanka, featuring Odissi dance and Indian classical music. These choreographers are breaking down barriers and creating a space for women in dance, showcasing their unique perspectives and talents in Singapore's dance festivals.

site_title: Prices of high-end homes bottoming out: JPMorgan
summary: JPMorgan reports that high-end residential home prices in Singapore are bottoming out, with a 25% average price decline from the peak. The decline is driven by increased volume, foreign interest, and limited supply. Foreign buyers, who previously shied away due to the 15% ABSD, are returning, and developers are offering discounts and innovative payment schemes to clear inventory. The report also notes that average selling prices for high-end homes have fallen below replacement costs, making Singapore a more attractive option for wealthy individuals.

images.alt_text: Prices of high-end residential homes are bottoming out on the back of a host of reasons such as a significant volume pick-up, return in foreign interest, relatively cheaper pricing compared to global peers and a limited supply in the medium to long term.

site_title: US dollar's movements split on forex markets
summary: The US dollar experienced mixed movements on currency markets, falling slightly against the euro but gaining against the yen and the pound. Analysts attribute this to rising crude prices, which could signal an improvement in the global financial market backdrop, and falling stock markets, including a 7% decline in Deutsche Bank's share price. Despite this, oil futures have gained 7% since OPEC's production cut agreement. The dollar's movements suggest a nuanced response to economic factors, with some analysts seeing it as a positive sign for the dollar's value.

images.alt_text: The US dollar fell slightly against the euro on currency markets on Thursday but gained against the yen and the pound.

site_title: Will Trans-Pacific Partnership rise from the dead?
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) may not be dead yet, despite President Barack Obama's term ending and his influence waning. Representative Kevin Brady, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, believes the agreement can still be ratified in the lame-duck session after the election. Brady cites geopolitical and economic reasons for approval, including maintaining US influence in the Asia-Pacific region and eliminating tariffs among member countries. However, anti-trade sentiment is prevalent, and approval would require a significant shift in Congress, particularly from Democrats.

site_title: Yahoo slow to invest in security defences, sources say
summary: Yahoo failed to invest in security defenses, prioritizing creating a cleaner look for services and developing new products over improving security. Despite a 2014 hiring of a new chief information security officer, the company's security efforts were hindered by concerns over added protection's impact on user experience. A 2016 breach resulted in the theft of 500 million user credentials, the largest known intrusion into a company's network, and is now under investigation. The breach is a black eye for CEO Marissa Mayer's failed turnaround effort, which may impact the sale of Yahoo's core operations to Verizon.

site_title: Q2 GDP growth revised up as businesses boost investment
summary: US economic growth in the second quarter was revised up to a 1.4% annual rate, beating analyst expectations. Businesses boosted investment, with overall business investment rising at a 1.0% annual rate, its first gain since last year. Consumer spending and exports also drove growth, but companies reduced inventories and home building declined. The revision suggests the worst of an energy sector-led slump in business investment may be over, but Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen expects interest rates to be raised by the end of the year due to labor market growth and inflation concerns.

site_title: High Court dismisses application by Lee Kuan Yew's estate on recorded transcripts
summary: The High Court of Singapore dismissed an application by Lee Kuan Yew's estate to use and have copies of the oral history transcripts of the late Mr. Lee. The estate had claimed copyright after Mr. Lee's death, but the court agreed with the government that the late Mr. Lee's right to grant permission for access was personal, not transferable to his estate. The transcripts were part of a government oral history project and were protected under the Official Secrets Act, requiring the government's authorization for use.

site_title: BlackBerry stops making its iconic handsets
summary: BlackBerry has stopped producing its iconic handsets, shifting its focus to its growing software business. The Canadian company, which invented the smartphone, will license its brand to overseas partners and design smartphone applications. BlackBerry's CEO John Chen aims to increase software margins and revenue, with a goal of hitting break-even in the full year. The move comes after the company's smartphone business struggled to compete with Apple and Samsung, and BlackBerry's market value has fallen from $80 billion to $4.3 billion.

site_title: China property tycoon warns of bubble
summary: China's richest man, Wang Jianlin, warns that the country's property market is the "biggest bubble in history," citing rising prices in big cities and falling prices in smaller ones with huge unsold inventories. The warning comes amid concerns about China's growing debt mountain and sluggish economy, which has dragged on GDP growth. Wang suggests that the economy hasn't bottomed out and that a hard landing could occur if leverage is removed too quickly, and is instead waiting for the economy to rebound before reducing leverage and debts.

site_title: China drugmakers take on global rivals
summary: China Grand Pharmaceutical and Healthcare Holdings Ltd, a private company, aims to compete globally against Big Pharma firms. The company, which was initially set up by the Chinese army in 1939, has evolved into a state-owned drug company and is now privately owned. China Grand Pharmaceutical seeks to scale up production and expand its market share. Its owner is listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and is poised to take on global rivals in the pharmaceutical industry.

site_title: Norway wealth fund rejects call to boost EM bet
summary: Norway's $890 billion wealth fund has rejected a call to increase emerging market investments, citing limits to such an allocation. The fund has built a 10% position in emerging markets over the past four years, with a focus on China, Taiwan, and India. Despite opportunities in infrastructure and private equity in developing economies, the fund's deputy governor, Egil Matsen, stated that it is comfortable with its current geographic distribution. The decision comes as the government withdraws money and amid negative rates, forcing institutional investors to re-evaluate their investment strategies.

site_title: China turns on charm offensive for Bhutan
summary: China has launched a charm offensive towards Bhutan, a Himalayan kingdom heavily reliant on India, in a bid to establish diplomatic relations. The move comes as China seeks to expand its influence in the region, while India watches with concern. China and Bhutan have held secret talks and exchanged people-to-people contacts, including tourism and scholarships. The development has raised concerns about Bhutan's vulnerability to being caught in the middle of a regional power play between China and India.

site_title: Younger Cabinet members will pick next leader: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has stated that the next leader will likely come from among the younger members of his Cabinet. This decision is expected to be made by the younger Cabinet members themselves. Lee, 64, plans to step down after the next general election by April 2021. He emphasized the importance of assembling a team with qualities such as being "able people, good people, committed people" to lead the country.

site_title: US healthcare system still among least efficient in the world
summary: The US healthcare system remains one of the least efficient in the world, ranking 50th out of 55 countries in 2014 according to the Bloomberg Health-Care Efficiency Index. The country's healthcare spending per capita averaged $9,403, with life expectancy at 78.9 years, the lowest among developed countries. Experts attribute the inefficiency to the system's fragmentation, lack of organization, and coordination.

site_title: Credit Suisse, Barclays in settlement talks with US regulators: sources
summary: Credit Suisse and Barclays are in settlement talks with US regulators over toxic mortgage bonds, following Deutsche Bank's recent $14 billion settlement offer. The negotiations could lead to a deal within several weeks, with the Justice Department seeking $2.47 billion from Credit Suisse and $4.4 billion from Barclays. The talks aim to wrap up pending cases before a new administration takes over, with the government already securing $46 billion in penalties from six firms related to mortgage-backed securities.

site_title: Contrary to popular belief, startups are not SMEs
summary: Startups and Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) are distinct, with startups being newly-established businesses and SMEs defined by annual sales turnover or employment size. This distinction is crucial, as startups are increasingly recognized as critical to Singapore's economic future, sparking a need to correct the confusion between the two.

site_title: The many valuable returns of R&D investments
summary: Singapore's public research-and-development (R&D) investments have paid off, with the local semiconductor industry experiencing a near-9% growth in the first eight months of 2016. A partnership between US-based Applied Materials and the Institute of Microelectronics (IME) is expected to reach around S$190 million, expanding the R&D scope of fan-out wafer-level packaging. This is part of a larger effort to anchor high-value manufacturing activities in Singapore, resulting in a significant increase in manufacturing output for the electronics cluster, from S$74 billion to S$82 billion over the decade from 2004.

site_title: M'sia pension fund to diversify to PE, property, infrastructure
summary: Malaysia's largest pension fund, the Employees Provident Fund (EPF), plans to diversify its investment portfolio to boost returns. The EPF aims to invest 10% of its assets in private equity, property, and infrastructure over the next three to four years. This diversification is in response to struggling returns from traditional investments due to low interest rates and market volatility. The fund is particularly keen on acquiring UK property assets, focusing on logistics and healthcare sectors, and is looking to acquire real estate assets in these sectors.

site_title: Chiho-Tiande rides China scrap wave, takes over Germany's Scholz
summary: Chiho-Tiande Group Ltd, a Chinese recycler, has acquired Scholz Holding Gmbh, a 144-year-old German scrap metal company, for 236 million euros. The deal aims to expand Chiho-Tiande's European procurement channels and provide technical expertise to process a surge of scrap metal in China, expected to start in 2018. China's growing car pool and increasing emphasis on recycling will lead to a significant increase in scrap metal, posing a threat to mining companies. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to become the world's first fully integrated metal recycler.

site_title: A very private public transport operator
summary: Singapore's public transport operator, SMRT Corp, will be delisted from the stock market after minority shareholders voted to merge it with state investor Temasek Holdings. The move ends 16 years of shareholder scrutiny and allows Temasek to consolidate its control. The decision follows years of struggling to meet commuter expectations and managing capital expenditure, leading to a decline in investor confidence. The delisting simplifies dynamics in the public transport sector, allowing for clearer communication between the public and government.

site_title: Next year's cyber security bill an important piece of essential legislation
summary: Singapore is strengthening its cyber security, with the upcoming Cyber Security Bill aiming to enhance legislation and operational readiness. The bill will address issues such as mandatory reporting of cyber attacks, safe-harbour clauses for companies, and provide a comprehensive framework to tackle the growing threat. This follows recent statistics showing Singaporeans lost S$15 million to scams this year, with 19 reported cases of ransomware. Experts also note the need for centralized reporting channels to share information and prevent similar incidents. The bill, along with existing laws, will help Singapore's Cyber Security Agency focus on operational readiness.

site_title: Singapore tops regional corporate governance rankings
summary: Singapore has topped the 2016 "Corporate Governance (CG) Watch" rankings, surpassing Hong Kong. However, the city-state's top spot is under threat due to its consideration of dual-class shares and minimum trade price scrapping, which could compromise its ranking. Singapore's close competitor, Hong Kong, is likely to challenge its position if these plans are implemented. The city-state's corporate governance ranking is closely watched, and any changes could have significant implications for its financial markets and economy.

images.alt_text: Singapore has pipped its closest competitor, Hong Kong, to emerge at the top of closely watched regional corporate governance rankings, "Corporate Governance (CG) Watch 2016".

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Pan-United Corp's port business is expected to drive earnings growth, despite a decline in Basic Building Materials (BBM) business. Analysts upgrade their recommendation to "hold" with a target price of S$0.56, citing improved port volumes and utilisation. Nera Telecommunications is expected to benefit from the upcoming 4G airwave auction and pay out a special dividend. The company's estimated one-off gains from the disposal of its POS business are also expected to support earnings.

site_title: 2026 start for S'pore-KL high-speed rail 'realistic but not easy'
summary: A French railway company, Alstom, says a 2026 operational deadline for the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur High Speed Rail is "realistic but not easy" to meet. Alstom, which is interested in providing trains and tracks for the project, believes that strong political commitment is necessary to make the deadline. The company's senior vice-president, Jean-Francois Beaudoin, notes that deadlines and technical specifications need to be issued soon for the project to move forward. Alstom's involvement puts it in competition with Chinese and Japanese companies, which have also expressed interest in the project.

images.alt_text: The 2026 operational deadline for the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur High Speed Rail, though realistic, will not be easily met and requires political commitment for it to happen, a regional director for French rail company Alstom has said.

site_title: Singapore committed to growing biopharmaceutical sector: Iswaran
summary: Singapore has committed to growing its biopharmaceutical sector, aiming to create over 300 jobs in the next three years, according to Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran. The sector has seen significant growth, with employment tripling from 1,900 in 2000 to 6,000 in 2015, and average annual salaries reaching S$102,000. The government plans to invest S$19 billion over five years in advanced manufacturing and health sciences, and AbbVie's new plant in Tuas Biomedical Park will employ over 250 local workers.

images.alt_text: Singapore remains steadfast in developing the biopharmaceutical sector to drive growth and create jobs by catalysing innovation in manufacturing technologies, developing infrastructural solutions, and building talent.

site_title: Vietnam's growth eases to 6.4% in Q3
summary: Vietnam's economy experienced a slight dip in Q3, with GDP growth reaching 6.4% compared to 6.81% in the same period in 2015. Despite this, analysts expect the country to remain a star performer in South-east Asia due to its private investment and growing middle class. Foreign investment and exports rose, and agriculture recovered after a drought, contributing to the growth. Vietnam aims to achieve a GDP growth target of 6.5-7% by the end of 2016.

site_title: Crowds throng showflats of two new projects
summary: Thousands of potential buyers flocked to the showflats of Forest Woods and The Alps Residences in Singapore, with over 6,000 visitors recorded over the weekend. The projects, developed by MCC Land and City Developments Ltd, have garnered strong interest due to their prime location and competitive pricing. Over 2,000 visitors visited Forest Woods alone, with nearly a third of units priced below S$1 million. Analysts see this as a signal of stabilisation in property prices, with sales volume expected to be a key data point.

site_title: What a gig!
summary: British Telecom (BT) has launched a Telegram account (t.me/BizTimes) for daily updates and specially selected content, particularly on weekends. The move aims to expand its online presence and reach a wider audience.

site_title: 'Tis the season for dance
summary: Contemporary dance enthusiasts have a plethora of options from now until December, with numerous festivals and events taking place. Jerome Bel's "Gala" aims to represent diverse bodies on stage, including the mentally disabled, while Korean choreographers Lee Yun Kyung and Ryu Seok Hun will perform "The Road" at the DanzINC festival. Meanwhile, Singapore Dance Theatre's contemporary season features world premieres by Timothy Harbour and Natalie Weir, and the M1 Contact Contemporary Dance Festival will showcase new works by Kuik Swee Boon, Kim Jae Duk, and Arthur Bernard Bazin. The Esplanade - Theatres on the Bay's da:ns festival will also feature iconic choreographer Pina Bausch's work "Nelken."

site_title: Teachers - like you've never seen them before
summary: A play titled "Micromanage Overwork Exasperate" sheds light on the challenges faced by teachers in Singapore, revealing the personal emotional toll of the profession. The script is based on interviews with schoolteachers, exposing the pressures of a demanding administration, unsympathetic parents, and clamorous pupils. The play highlights the futile pretence that "every school is a good school" and the daily temptation of leaving the profession. The production features a young cast, blending realistic drama with physical theatre and vaudevillian absurdity, leaving audiences convinced that teaching is one of the hardest professions in the country.

site_title: US shale drilling gets revival as oil prices start to climb
summary: US shale drilling is expected to experience a revival in 2017 due to rising oil prices, with demand for land rigs projected to increase 29% to 579. Average West Texas Intermediate crude prices are forecast to climb 23% to $52.18 a barrel, while natural gas prices are expected to rise 26% to $3.05 per million Btu. This surge in drilling activity is expected to benefit oilfield service companies, with some producers considering boosting spending and putting more rigs back to work.

site_title: Air Berlin to axe 1,200 jobs as it splits into 3 businesses
summary: Air Berlin to eliminate 1,200 jobs as it splits into three businesses, including one operating 40 aircraft for Lufthansa and another for its tourism arm. The airline will retain a core fleet of 75 planes based at Berlin and Dusseldorf hubs, with Lufthansa acquiring 35 planes from Air Berlin to expand its Eurowings discount unit. The changes aim to boost Lufthansa's fleet size by over a third and reduce Air Berlin's losses, which have exceeded €1 billion in the past three years.

site_title: Japan retail sales down more than expected; govt to review data reliability
summary: Japan's retail sales declined 2.1% in August, exceeding market predictions, and marking the sixth consecutive month of decline. The drop underlines the fragile state of Japan's economy, with sluggish wage growth and uncertain spending prospects. The government is reviewing the reliability of its economic data, aiming to improve sample sizes and modernize collection methods to provide more accurate indicators of economic growth and consumer spending. The review is expected to be completed by the end of the year, which could impact policy decisions, including those related to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policies.

site_title: Air rage incidents up 17% worldwide in 2015
summary: Reports of unruly passengers on flights worldwide increased by 17% in 2015, with 10,854 incidents reported by airlines, resulting in one incident per 1,205 flights. IATA attributes the rise to factors such as alcohol intoxication and reduced seat pitch, which can lead to increased frustration among passengers. Industry officials estimate the cost of diverting a flight due to an unruly passenger at $200,000, and IATA is pushing for countries to join an international treaty to allow authorities to prosecute unruly passengers at a plane's destination.

site_title: Opec deal buoys oil & gas-related stocks
summary: Oil and gas-related stocks experienced a slight rebound on Thursday following a preliminary agreement by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) to cut production. The deal, which aims to reduce output levels to 32.5-33 million barrels per day, is expected to be finalized in November and could add up to $10 per barrel to oil prices. Several offshore marine companies, including Keppel Corp, Sembcorp Marine, and Ezra Holdings, rose significantly, with some stocks increasing by as much as 13%. Analysts predict a potential oil price recovery, leading to a rebound in oil and gas stocks.

site_title: Sensational epic tale on love, lust, power
summary: Beauty Is A Wound, a novel by Eka Kurniawan, tells the epic tale of Dewi Ayu, a prostitute forced into sex work by Japanese soldiers during WWII, and her four daughters. The story is a sensational and intricate plot filled with sex, politics, and superstition, exploring themes of love, death, and power. Set in a fictional Indonesian town, the book weaves together ancient folklore and realistic portrayals of women and men, earning it worldwide acclaim and comparisons to Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Pramoedya Ananta Toer.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Serrano Holdings, an interior-design contractor, received a letter of demand from Maybank in Vietnam for $2 million and 32.4 billion Vietnamese dong after a supplier defaulted on payments. Xpress Holdings reported a net loss of $12.3 million in its fourth quarter, widening from a year-ago loss of $169,000. The printer company is seeking shareholder approval to expand its business activities and plans to acquire e-commerce company Amplify Me.

site_title: Pressure mounting on Wells Fargo CEO
summary: Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf faces mounting pressure as he testifies before the House Financial Services Committee for the second time in under 10 days. The bank is under investigation for opening up to 2 million unauthorized credit card and deposit accounts to meet sales quotas, resulting in a $20 billion market value drop and lawsuits. The California state government has suspended business relationships with the bank for a year and is working to change the management structure. Stumpf has vowed to eliminate sales quotas, but lawmakers are questioning his leadership and calling for greater accountability.

site_title: US pending home sales drop as inventory remains weak
summary: US pending home sales dropped 2.4% in August to 108.5, the lowest level since January. This decline follows a jump in July, and economists had forecast no change. Housing inventory has declined for 15 straight months, contributing to the decrease. Despite this, the overall housing market remains strong due to low mortgage rates and a robust labor market.

site_title: Singapore Pools and Turf Club get nod to launch online betting
summary: The Singapore government has granted exemptions to Singapore Pools and Singapore Turf Club to launch online betting services. The exemptions, valid for three years, allow the operators to offer lottery and sports bets online, with specific conditions including age verification, no credit betting, and pre-determined daily limits. Online services will launch on October 25 and November 15, respectively. The move aims to regulate online gambling while preventing unlicensed activities, which are associated with money laundering and other illicit activities.

images.alt_text: The government has given the green light to Singapore Pools and Singapore Turf Club (STC) to offer punters the option of placing their lottery or sports bets online.

site_title: Singapore, London in race to be top global fintech hub
summary: Singapore and London have tied as top global fintech hubs according to a Deloitte report, both scoring 10 out of 100 in three indices. Singapore's business-friendly environment, excellent government support, and regulation contributed to its high ranking, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore setting aside S$225 million for fintech projects. However, Singapore faces challenges in its risk-averse culture and underdeveloped startup scene. London, ranked number one as a global financial centre, lags behind Singapore in attracting foreign startups and ease of doing business, but remains a key hub for fintech innovation.

site_title: Arts attendance hits all-time high in 2015
summary: Arts attendance in Singapore reached an all-time high in 2015, with 78% of residents attending at least one arts event, a 38% increase from 2013. Participation in arts activities also rose, with 28% of residents engaging in workshops, courses, and other activities. The National Arts Council's 2015 National Population Survey found that 78% of Singaporeans recognize the benefits of arts and culture, and 80% believe it helps express thoughts and feelings. The survey's results, influenced by the 50th anniversary celebrations, may dip in the next survey, but the CEO noted consistent interest across all segments of the population.

site_title: Who should bear the cost of tax transparency?
summary: Singapore has committed to implementing country-by-country reporting (CbCR) for multinational groups, a global financial disclosure regime recommended by the OECD to combat Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS). Under CbCR, companies will report key financial information to the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore, providing tax authorities with a global tax profile. The regime aims to facilitate risk assessment, but concerns arise over the potential for revenue authorities to overstep their role and use the information unilaterally to raise tax assessments. Implementation details are expected to be released soon, with experts warning of significant challenges and costs associated with compliance.

site_title: A realistic, classic hero story
summary: Deepwater Horizon, directed by Peter Berg, tells the story of the 2010 oil rig disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, based on a New York Times article. The film follows electronics technician Mike Williams (Mark Wahlberg) as he navigates the rig's complex systems and safety measures before a catastrophic blowout occurs. The second half of the film focuses on the heroism of the crew as they try to save themselves and the injured. The film concludes with a realistic portrayal of the disaster's aftermath, including the names of the deceased and the findings of the investigation.

images.alt_text: Deepwater Horizon recounts the final hours at the centre of the biggest environmental disaster in US history from the perspective of an electronics technician (Mark Wahlberg) aboard the oil rig.

site_title: Big luxury brands and some mass brands skip Paris Motor Show
summary: Luxury brands such as Rolls-Royce, Aston Martin, and Ferrari are skipping the Paris Motor Show, opting instead for exclusive events in exotic locations. In contrast, mass brands like BMW, Mercedes, and Porsche will participate, showcasing electric and hybrid vehicles. The event is expected to focus on green energy sources, with crossovers and vehicle electrification being key reveals. Despite the absence of big brands, the show will still feature notable debuts from luxury and mass manufacturers, including Tesla, Land Rover, and Lexus. The shift in strategy reflects changing consumer habits and the growing importance of social media in car marketing.

images.alt_text: Mercedes unveiling its new AMG GT R during its media night on Wednesday ahead of the Paris Motor Show.

site_title: Music plays on despite hitches
summary: Singapore's 100 Bands music festival, now in its third edition, has overcome several challenges, including changes in location and bad weather, to deliver a stellar lineup. The festival, featuring 100 local acts, includes veteran indie band Plainsunset and all-star group TypeWriter, and concludes with instrumental post-rock act Amateur Takes Control. Organiser Razi Razak praises the team's adaptability and notes an increase in quality local music, with newer bands giving veteran acts a run for their money. The festival's finale is set to be a bittersweet one, marking the end of the event and the "emotional rollercoaster" experienced by the team.

images.alt_text: Local indie act TypeWriter has "been living life and crafting our next release", says frontman Yee Chang Kang (centre), and the group is on Saturday's line-up at this year's 100 Bands festival.

site_title: Slackening demand swells unemployment in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's unemployment rate rose to 3.5% in the seven months to July, above the five-year average, due to weak global and domestic demand. Businesses, particularly manufacturers, are right-sizing, resulting in fewer job vacancies and higher unemployment rates. Retrenchments have accelerated, with some 200 employees laid off by TS Solartech Sdn Bhd in Penang, a hub for semiconductor and tech manufacturing. The weakening labor market is expected to impact GDP growth, projected at around 3.8%, below the government's target of 4-4.5%.

site_title: US economy less sluggish in 2nd quarter; companies investing more
summary: US economic growth in the second quarter expanded at a 1.4% annual rate, exceeding expectations, as exports grew more than imports and businesses raised investments. The revision showed businesses cut investments in buildings and equipment less than initially estimated, while they increased research and development. Consumer spending rose at a 4.3% annual rate, while the economy remains below historically normal rates, fueling concerns about the impact on long-term growth.

site_title: A sweet, smart take on the First Couple
summary: The film "Southside With You" chronicles the first date of future US President Barack Obama and Michelle Obama in 1989 Chicago. Written and directed by Richard Tanne, the movie shows a sweet and smart portrayal of their initial interactions, avoiding overt politics. The film explores their differences in personality, interests, and values, as they bond over art, music, and basketball. The movie reveals the foundation of their relationship, which would eventually blossom into the power couple they became. The film provides a genuine warmth towards its characters, offering insight into their development into the world's most powerful couple.

site_title: STI back in positive territory for the year
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 27.7 points, or 0.97%, to 2,885.71, driven by a 5% increase in oil prices to around $47 per barrel and a modest rise in Dow futures. Oil and gas stocks gained, while bank stocks, such as DBS, also rose. However, economists expressed caution, citing concerns over the impact of the proposed OPEC production cut and the lack of detail in the agreement.

site_title: Local rapper wants to go beyond performing
summary: Local rapper TheLionCityBoy (TLCB), whose real name is Kevin Lester, has released his hip-hop album "Paradise", which celebrates life in Singapore with references to the country's history and culture. The album took a year to write and record, featuring collaborations with local artists and using Singlish terms to make it sound authentically local. TLCB aims to be an all-rounder in the music business, diversifying his trade and skills, and is inspired by artists like Drake. The album's success has shown signs of growth for the local hip-hop scene, with TLCB and other artists gaining mainstream recognition.

site_title: Japanese artist's life is an open scrapbook
summary: Japanese artist Shinro Ohtake, known for his voluminous scrapbook compilations, has completed a residency at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute (STPI). During his stay, he created a giant sculptural scrapbook, experimented with large-scale paper pulp works, and revisited techniques from his past, including lithography and silkscreening. Ohtake's work explores the layering of memories and emotions, often incorporating neon colors and mass media imagery to convey his concerns about the brevity of life and chemical pollution. His residency at STPI has reignited his passion for scrapbooking, which he plans to continue despite having an abundance of materials.

site_title: Hollande's tax boost for French firms yields 100,000 jobs: study
summary: President Francois Hollande's tax credit scheme for French firms has saved or created up to 100,000 jobs, according to a government-sponsored study. The Tax Credit for Competitiveness and Jobs (CICE) scheme, introduced in 2013, has offered a six percent tax credit on salaries up to two and a half times the minimum wage. While this provides limited relief to Hollande, who faces a struggling economy and low opinion poll ratings, it does not mark a significant turnaround in his economic record.

site_title: Betting operators unveil safeguards against addiction to online gaming
summary: Singapore's two main betting operators, Singapore Pools and Singapore Turf Club, have unveiled safeguards against online gaming addiction. The operators, which have been granted a three-year exemption under the Remote Gambling Act, will implement measures such as a rigorous registration process, daily funding limits, and alerts for excessive spending. They will also provide advisory messages on responsible gambling and display win-loss records. The operators aim to offer a "safe, trusted and legal" channel for online betting, with Singapore Pools launching its online operations on October 25 and STC launching its web-based service and mobile app on November 15.

site_title: Keppel Land acquires Shanghai mall
summary: Keppel Land China has acquired a newly completed retail development in Shanghai's Jiading District for 500 million yuan (S$102 million). The retail development, with a gross floor area of 40,927 sqm, will be managed by Keppel Land Retail Management. The acquisition is part of Keppel Land's strategy to seize opportunities in key Chinese cities. The deal is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2017 and is not expected to materially affect Keppel Corp's per-share earnings and net tangible asset.

site_title: China's FX regulator says no policy hurdle to moving asset sale proceeds overseas
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator, the State Administration of Foreign Exchange, has stated that there are no policy obstacles for offshore institutions to transfer proceeds from Chinese asset sales overseas. This clarification comes after reports suggested that China's efforts to limit capital outflows could hinder Deutsche Bank's plans to move proceeds from the sale of a stake in Hua Xia Bank. The regulator's statement indicates that such cross-border transfers do not require approval from the administration.

site_title: German inflation surges to 16-month high in September
summary: German inflation surged to a 16-month high of 0.7% in September, exceeding analyst expectations and beating the European Central Bank's inflation target of 2.0%. The increase is attributed to rising energy prices, but analysts warn that Germany still has a long way to go to reach the desired inflation rate. The ECB's efforts to boost prices through stimulus programs appear to be paying off, but more policy support may be needed to achieve its goal.

site_title: London to launch inquiry into foreign property ownership: report
summary: London's mayor Sadiq Khan plans to launch an inquiry into foreign property ownership in the city, citing concerns over housing costs and the impact of overseas investment on the market. The inquiry aims to understand the scale of foreign ownership and potential action to support development and help Londoners find homes. Real estate firm Savills estimates that 7% of London's residential transactions are driven by overseas purchases for investment purposes, with nearly £200 million believed to be proceeds of foreign corruption spent on British properties since 2004.

site_title: Nissan seeks Brexit compensation deal as condition for investment
summary: Nissan is seeking a Brexit compensation deal from the UK government before committing to further investment in its Sunderland plant. The company's CEO, Carlos Ghosn, stated that Nissan needs a deal to mitigate potential trade costs resulting from Britain's exit from the EU. Nissan plans to make a decision on building the next Qashqai SUV early next year, before the terms of Brexit are finalized. A compensation deal is necessary to ensure carmakers like Nissan can export to Europe without facing tax barriers.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB Bank gets licence for Vietnam subsidiary: Vietnam central bank
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Bank has been granted a licence to open a 100% foreign-owned bank in Vietnam, according to Vietnam's central bank. The new bank, CIMB Bank Vietnam, will have a registered capital of 3.2 trillion dong (S$190 million) and can operate for 99 years. This move marks CIMB's entry into Vietnam's banking market, with the bank's subsidiary to be established in Hanoi.

site_title: In hunt for tax cheats, Denmark pays US$900,000 for more Panama Papers
summary: Denmark has paid $900,000 to access Panama Papers documents to identify hundreds of suspected Danish tax cheats. The leak revealed offshore financial arrangements of world leaders and exposed tax evasion in Denmark, which lost $2.52 billion in tax revenue over three years. Danish authorities will investigate the suspected tax cheats and consider pressing charges. The move is part of global efforts to combat tax evasion and comes after raids in Britain and elsewhere to recoup money paid out in fraudulent tax refunds.

site_title: US jobless claims rise less than expected
summary: US jobless claims rose 3,000 to 254,000 for the week ended Sept 24, below expectations of 260,000. This suggests the labor market remains strong, supporting Federal Reserve plans to raise interest rates this year. The four-week moving average of new claims fell to 256,000. Continuing claims also fell to 2.062 million, indicating a relatively healthy labor market.

site_title: SMRT shareholders vote in favour of sale of rail assets to the government
summary: SMRT shareholders voted 98.8% in favor of selling the rail assets to the Singapore government for $1.68 per share, with Temasek Holdings holding a 54% stake in the company. The sale includes ownership of the North-South and East-West Lines, Circle Line, and Bukit Panjang LRT, and will result in improved free cash flow for the government. SMRT will pay an annual licence fee to LTA for operating the lines for 15 years, with the possibility of a five-year extension.

site_title: In the lap of luxury
summary: The inaugural Singapore Rendezvous, a four-day luxury lifestyle event, will take place at Raffles Marina, featuring high-end brands, vintage cars, and yachts. The event aims to revive the marina's popularity and offer a unique experience with champagne, sunset views, and entertainment. With a mix of activities for families, investors, and young adults, the event is expected to attract 5,000 visitors. It is the first of its kind in Singapore and is organized by Heart Media, with a focus on creating a "stickiness" experience that encourages visitors to spend the day.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks jump on Opec deal
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks surged Thursday, driven by oil prices after Opec's surprise agreement to cut crude output. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.51%, the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.36%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index increased 0.39%. The rally was largely attributed to the energy sector, with oil prices rising ahead of the Opec deal.

site_title: UK should not expect special deal on Brexit: Renzi
summary: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said the UK should not expect special treatment in Brexit talks, as the country faces a tough stance in negotiating access to the European market while introducing immigration controls. International Trade Minister Liam Fox warned that protectionism will harm the people of Europe, and a new report estimated that planning for Brexit could cost Britain's government £65 million a year.

site_title: Yuan joins SDR basket on Oct 1, but analysts say full liberalisation not in sight
summary: The Chinese yuan will be included in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) special drawing rights (SDR) basket on October 1, marking a significant step in Beijing's efforts to internationalize its currency. However, analysts say the yuan still has a long way to go before it becomes fully liberalized and makes a meaningful global impact. The yuan's inclusion will make it a "freely usable" currency, but downward pressures, including a 3% drop against the dollar this year, will continue to weigh on its value.

images.alt_text: The yuan will enter the SDR basket at a weighting of 10.92 per cent. The US dollar will remain relatively unchanged at 41.73 per cent, with the euro, yen and pound at weightings lower than this.

site_title: Philippines businessmen to accompany Duterte to China: sources
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte will visit China from October 19-21, accompanied by a business delegation of around two dozen Filipino businessmen. The trip aims to strengthen commercial ties and set aside sovereignty squabbles, following a legal challenge to China's claims in the South China Sea. Duterte will meet Chinese President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Keqiang, signaling a shift in his foreign policy away from the US and towards Russia and China. The visit comes after a cancelled trip by special envoy Fidel Ramos, but China's foreign ministry has welcomed Ramos to visit at any time.
