images.alt_text: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte will visit China from Oct 19-21 accompanied by a business delegation, business and diplomatic sources said on Thursday, signalling his intent to set sovereignty squabbles aside and forge a stronger commercial relationship with Beijing.

site_title: US: Wall St lower as oil pulls back
summary: US stocks declined slightly on Thursday as oil prices pulled back, following a nearly 6% rally the previous day due to an agreement among major oil-producing countries to curb output. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.04%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Yellen's speech for hints on the timing of the next interest rate hike. US economic growth expanded at a 1.4% annual rate in the second quarter, beating prior estimates, and jobless claims rose less-than-expected last week.

site_title: Challenger's new flagship store to open at Bugis Junction by Q2 2017
summary: Challenger Technologies has confirmed the lease of its new flagship store at Bugis Junction, spanning 14,000 sq ft, set to open by Q2 2017. This addition to its existing store in the mall and almost 50 stores across Singapore demonstrates the company's confidence in the local retail market despite a soft climate. Challenger's shares closed 4.12% lower following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher thanks to 5% jump in oil price after Opec agreement
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.9% to 2,883.57, driven by a 5% surge in oil to $47 per barrel after OPEC agreed to a production cut deal. The Dow futures also rose, boosting the market. Oil and gas stocks gained, with the FTSE ST Oil and Gas Index up 3.5%. However, Bank of Singapore's Richard Jerram expressed caution, citing the limited impact of the cut and concerns about its enforceability.

site_title: Euro-area economic confidence rises to highest since January
summary: Euro-area economic confidence has risen to its highest level since January, according to a European Commission official. Valdis Dombrovskis, the bloc's financial-services chief, urged regulators to reconsider proposed new rules that could increase capital requirements for European Union lenders by hundreds of billions of dollars. Dombrovskis argued that the rules would unfairly burden European banks and hinder economic growth, echoing concerns from European banks and industry leaders.

site_title: Toyota drops diesel from new model, signals likely phase-out
summary: Toyota will drop diesel engines from its new C-HR compact model, following Volkswagen's emissions scandal, and is likely to phase out diesel powertrains from future model renewals. Executive Vice President Didier Leroy cited falling demand for diesel technology as the reason. This decision is part of the industry-wide shift to meet stricter emissions standards, which will require costlier emissions treatment systems starting from 2019.

site_title: Goldman sees Opec buying time as deal could boost oil US$7-US$10
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts OPEC's production cut deal could boost oil prices by $7-$10 per barrel, citing a potential increase in prices due to reduced supply and resilient demand growth. However, the analysts remain skeptical about the deal's implementation and long-term impact. The proposed cuts, if strictly implemented, could support prices in the short term, but the group's history shows oversupply and quota compliance issues, which could negate the effect of lowering targets.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc said Opec's deal to cut output could add as much as $10 a barrel to oil prices, though it remains skeptical along with other banks on how the accord will be implemented.

site_title: Fed's Harker wants to raise rates 'sooner, rather than later'
summary: Federal Reserve President Patrick Harker expressed support for raising interest rates "sooner rather than later" to combat inflation, citing progress toward the Fed's 2% inflation target. He emphasized the importance of acting before falling behind the curve, echoing concerns from other Fed members. Despite a recent rate decision that saw three hawkish dissents, the Fed's Chair Janet Yellen expressed a gradual increase in rates, with economists focusing on the December meeting, which may coincide with the US election.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve policy makers should begin raising interest rates to get ahead of inflation and avoid "falling behind the curve," Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker said.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore topped regional corporate governance rankings, "Corporate Governance (CG) Watch 2016", surpassing competitors. SMRT shareholders voted in favor of Temasek's privatization offer, while Singapore Pools and Turf Club received approval to offer online gambling services. Challenger announced plans for a new flagship store, and AbbVie opened a S$400 million plant in Singapore. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.9% on Thursday, closing at 2,883.57.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.680 points to 1,669.640. The index saw a gain in volume, with 1.839 billion lots worth RM1.739 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 448 to 342.

site_title: UK trade minister says Germany risks becoming 'world's greatest ATM' after Brexit
summary: UK Trade Minister Liam Fox warns that post-Brexit, Germany risks becoming the world's largest contributor to the European Union due to the bloc's financial instability. Fox, a pro-Brexit campaigner, stated that without Britain, Germany will lose a key ally in enforcing economic rigor and may end up paying for other EU nations, potentially making it the "greatest ATM in global history." Fox emphasized that Britain must reform its economy to boost growth after leaving the EU.

site_title: BlackBerry phones will live on for die-hard fans in Indonesia
summary: BlackBerry phones will continue to be manufactured in Indonesia, catering to die-hard fans, despite the Canadian company's shift to software production. PT Tiphone Mobile Indonesia Tbk has partnered with BlackBerry to form a local joint venture to produce BlackBerry devices in Indonesia, with plans to manufacture phones domestically and potentially partner with another local company. Indonesia remains one of BlackBerry's biggest markets, with over 6 million users still using the brand, and BlackBerry is optimistic about its growth potential in the market.

site_title: Singapore's next PM to be decided among younger members of Cabinet: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the next Prime Minister will be decided among the younger members of the Cabinet. He emphasized the importance of their support and teamwork in making the system work. This decision is seen as a move towards a smoother transition and a more inclusive leadership. The younger members of the Cabinet will have to work together to choose a suitable candidate, considering the country's future needs and priorities.

site_title: Keppel Land China to acquire retail mall in Shanghai for 500m yuan
summary: Keppel Land China has agreed to acquire a 500 million yuan (S$102 million) retail mall in Shanghai's Jiading District. The 40,927 sq m mall, part of a mixed-use development, will be managed by Keppel Land Retail Management. The acquisition is part of Keppel Land's strategy to capitalize on opportunities in Shanghai, with completion expected by Q1 2017. The deal is not expected to impact Keppel Corp's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share materially for the current financial year.

site_title: Singapore Pools, Turf Club given green light to offer gambling services online
summary: Singapore Pools and Singapore Turf Club have been given the green light to offer their gambling services online for a three-year period under the Remote Gambling Act. The operators will roll out a Web-based service on October 25 and November 15, respectively, with strict conditions in place, including age verification, no credit betting, and funding limits. Regular audits and inspections will ensure compliance, with penalties of up to S$1 million for non-compliance. The move aims to drive demand and activities underground, rather than banning remote gambling.

site_title: Commerzbank says to cut 9,600 jobs by 2020
summary: Commerzbank, Germany's second-largest lender, plans to cut 9,600 jobs by 2020 as part of a 1.1-billion-euro restructuring. The move aims to achieve "sustainable profitability" by focusing on private and business banking customers and shrinking investment banking activities. The bank will also cease dividend payments for the time being, marking the first time it has not paid a dividend since the 2008 financial crisis. This restructuring is expected to create savings of 6.5 billion euros per year and allow the bank to create 2,300 new jobs.

site_title: High Court dismisses application by Lee Kuan Yew's estate on his oral history transcripts
summary: The High Court of Singapore has dismissed an application by the estate of Lee Kuan Yew against the Government, allowing the Government to use and have copies of the late former Prime Minister's oral history transcripts. The court ruled that Lee Kuan Yew's right to grant permission for access was personal, not extending to his estate, and not intended to grant the estate free use or custody of the transcripts.

site_title: India launches strikes on suspected militants in Pakistan
summary: India launched "surgical strikes" on suspected militants in Pakistan, targeting units preparing to infiltrate Kashmir. The strikes, based on "very specific and credible information," caused significant casualties and were launched across the Line of Control. Indian Army Director General Lt Gen Ranbir Singh informed his Pakistani counterpart of the operation. The strikes were reportedly in response to suspected militant activity, with General Singh stating that the operation was necessary to protect India's sovereignty.

site_title: EU's Vestager 'exploring' need to probe deals with valuable data
summary: European Union antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager warns that firms may face greater scrutiny for deals involving valuable data, such as user data, in mergers. Vestager suggests that companies may buy rivals solely to acquire their data, even if it hasn't generated revenue. The EU is exploring the need to review data-sharing in deals, considering factors like data durability and market competition. Vestager emphasizes the importance of ensuring companies don't use data to stifle competition and maintain a fair market. The review of Microsoft's acquisition of LinkedIn Corp is expected to focus on data leverage.

site_title: Petronas faces US$27b dilemma after Canada LNG approval
summary: Petronas, the majority owner of the Pacific NorthWest LNG project, faces a US$27 billion dilemma after receiving conditional approval from the Canadian government. The project, which would produce 19.2 million tons of LNG per year, was approved despite a challenging market environment with low spot prices and over-supply. Petronas must review 190 conditions before deciding whether to proceed, amid concerns about capital constraints and the need for long-term offtake agreements to secure financing.

site_title: Countries must step up cooperation in challenging environment: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for countries in the Asia Pacific region to strengthen cooperation in the face of major geopolitical shifts and internal challenges. He stated that countries can only succeed by working together, not by turning inward. This comes as the region navigates a difficult environment.

images.alt_text: The Asia Pacific region is entering a period where there are major geopolitical shifts and difficult internal conditions to navigate, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said on Thursday.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals sink to lowest since Nov 2014 in August: BOE
summary: UK mortgage approvals fell to 60,058 in August, the lowest level since November 2014, as the housing market slowed after the Brexit vote. However, lending to consumers continued to grow rapidly, with net mortgage lending rising £2.943 billion and consumer credit increasing £1.574 billion. The Bank of England's data showed lending growth at an annualized rate of 10.4% on a three-month basis, close to a 10-year high.

site_title: SMRT shareholders vote in favour of NRFF sale, Temasek's privatisation offer
summary: SMRT shareholders voted in favor of Temasek Holdings' buyout proposal, allowing the state investor to take the transport operator private. The buyout, valued at S$1.2 billion, was approved by 84.93% of present shareholders, who hold 92.89% of the scheme shares. The sale of SMRT's rail assets to the government, part of the New Rail Financing Framework, is expected to be completed on Oct 1. The deal will see SMRT pay an annual licence fee to the Land Transport Authority for 15 years, with the possibility of a five-year extension.

images.alt_text: Shareholders of transport operator SMRT Corporation have voted on Thursday - after struggling with a frustrating 40-minute delay caused by technical glitches - to allow state investor Temasek Holdings to take it private, after they agreed to transfer SMRT rail assets to the government.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end up after touching 3-week high, won eases
summary: South Korean shares ended up 0.8% at 2,068.72 points, reaching its highest level in three weeks after Opec's oil output limit agreement sparked a global rally. The won currency fell 0.2% to 1,098.8 to the US dollar, reversing earlier gains. The rally in global shares was attributed to the Opec agreement, which boosted investor confidence despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: China's slow economy, overcapacity limit investments: central bank vice governor
summary: China's central bank vice governor, Fan Gang, stated that the country's slowing economy and industrial overcapacity issues have reduced investment opportunities. Private investment grew just 2.1% in the first eight months of the year, the same pace as in January-July, and remains at record lows. Fan emphasized that China cannot solely drive reforms without considering the global impact, citing potential problems such as unemployment. Beijing aims to cut industrial capacity, particularly in steel, and Fan attributed the recent weakening of the yuan to its tracking against depreciating currencies like the pound and euro.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open after Opec deal
summary: Europe's main stock markets rallied at the start of trading on Thursday, driven by Opec's surprise deal to cut oil output. The FTSE 100 jumped 1% to 6,917.76 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 also rose 1% and 1.3% respectively. The gains follow Opec's announcement, which lit a fire under oil prices and boosted petroleum-linked shares.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets rallied at the start of trading on Thursday as energy share prices surged following Opec's surprise deal to cut oil output.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares up as energy firms surge on oil deal
summary: Tokyo's stock market surged Thursday, led by energy firms, after OPEC agreed to cut crude production, boosting oil prices. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.39%, and the Topix index climbed 0.94%. This rally follows a global trend, with US stocks also reaching fresh records despite US-China trade uncertainty.

site_title: Senior German lawmaker says no more aid for ailing banks
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservative bloc will not provide any further state aid to struggling banks, according to Hans Michelbach, a senior lawmaker. The decision comes after Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest lender, disputed a $14 billion US fine and saw its shares hit a record low. Michelbach criticized the European Central Bank's low interest rates, stating they have failed to implement reforms, and called for an end to the policy. This move follows a denial of a rescue plan for Deutsche Bank, which has been facing financial difficulties.

site_title: Thousands of Indonesian workers protest against tax amnesty
summary: Thousands of Indonesian union workers protested against a government tax amnesty scheme in Jakarta, claiming it unfairly pardons wealthy tax dodgers. The amnesty program, launched in July, has seen almost $200 billion in assets declared, mostly from the country's wealthy elite. Workers, who make up the bulk of Indonesia's workforce, consider the program unconstitutional, citing past tax evasion by rich individuals. The protesters, led by the Confederation of Indonesian Workers Union, have filed legal action against the amnesty law and may stage further protests if the government continues with the program.

site_title: Indonesia central bank deputy gov says rupiah could appreciate further
summary: Indonesia's central bank deputy governor Perry Warjiyo expressed optimism about the rupiah's future appreciation, citing the country's recovering economy and fiscal position. The currency has gained over 6% against the US dollar this year, trading at 12,960 a US dollar. Warjiyo believes the rupiah may strengthen further, driven by increased confidence in Indonesia's economic recovery.

site_title: Australia shares rise, energy firms lead on Opec deal; NZ stocks up
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% on Thursday, driven by a surge in energy stocks following a surprise Opec agreement to trim production. The energy index posted its largest intraday percentage gain in over 7.5 years. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,471.3, with job vacancy data also contributing to the positive sentiment.

site_title: Samsung to resume South Korea sales of new Note 7 phones
summary: Samsung resumes sales of new Galaxy Note 7 smartphones in South Korea, marking a significant step in recovering from a global recall sparked by battery explosions. The company had previously recalled 2.5 million units shipped worldwide after faulty batteries caused the phones to explode while charging. As of Tuesday, 60% of US users had swapped their handsets for replacements, with 80% of Note 7 customers expected to complete the exchange in South Korea by Saturday. New Note 7 phones with fault-free batteries will gradually hit stores in other markets, including European countries on October 28.

images.alt_text: Samsung said Thursday it would resume sales of new Galaxy Note 7 smartphones in South Korea this week, hoping to turn the page on the troubled device after an ongoing global recall prompted by battery explosions.

site_title: Planned global banking rules not balanced, need changes: Dombrovskis
summary: EU financial services commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis stated that planned global banking rules, set by the Basel Committee, risk negatively affecting European banks and need changes. The current proposals would significantly increase capital requirements for European banks, posing a threat to the sector's stability. Dombrovskis emphasized the need for adjustments to avoid a substantial increase in capital requirements, highlighting the need for a more balanced approach to banking regulation.

site_title: South Korea's finance minister says anti-graft law may weigh on growth
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Yoo Il Ho, stated that the country's economy may temporarily slow due to the introduction of an anti-corruption law. The law, which went into effect on Wednesday, bans public officials and others from accepting bribes and meals worth more than 30,000 won. Despite this, the minister predicted the economy would still expand by 2.8 percent this year.

site_title: Top Philippine diplomat assures US after Duterte drills remark
summary: The Philippines' top diplomat, Perfecto Yasay, has assured the US that joint military exercises will continue despite President Rodrigo Duterte's comments that the upcoming drills would be the last. Duterte's remarks referred to ending joint patrols in the South China Sea, but Yasay stated that the president respects treaty arrangements and commitments with the US. US officials have confirmed the exercises will proceed as planned, with significant security commitments to the Philippines.

site_title: China's US$5b health-care deal spree shows global ambitions
summary: China is aggressively expanding its healthcare industry, with over $5.2 billion in overseas acquisitions this year, a 15-fold jump from 2012. Chinese companies, such as China Grand Pharmaceutical and Healthcare Holdings, are seeking to break into global markets and compete with Big Pharma firms. Despite facing challenges and safety questions, Chinese companies aim to increase innovation and internationalization, with some exporting finished pills to developing markets and others seeking to become bigger suppliers to Western multinationals.

site_title: US health-care system still ranks among the least-efficient
summary: The US health-care system remains one of the least-efficient in the world, ranking 50th out of 55 countries in the Bloomberg Health-Care Efficiency Index in 2014. The US spent $9,403 per person on healthcare, with life expectancy at 78.9 years, and had the highest health-care spending per capita among developed countries. Experts attribute the inefficiency to the US system's fragmentation and lack of coordination, which is likely to lead to further inefficiency.

site_title: Spotify debuts in Japan, complete with karaoke lyrics
summary: Spotify has launched its music streaming service in Japan, offering a free, ad-supported version and an ad-free subscription for 980 yen (S$13.19) per month. The service features karaoke lyrics and will be available on Sony Corp's PlayStation consoles. This marks Spotify's entry into Japan's large and lucrative music market, where consumers prefer physical media like CDs. The company aims to bring two million global artists to Japan and Japanese artists to the rest of the world, with CEO Daniel Ek betting on carving out a piece of the world's second-largest music market.

site_title: Thailand cracks down on migrant workers as anti-immigration feelings rise
summary: Thailand is cracking down on migrant workers, particularly from Myanmar, Vietnam, and Cambodia, amid rising anti-immigration sentiments and economic stagnation. Authorities have arrested over 150 migrants, including 14 from Myanmar, and face up to five years in prison for "stealing jobs from Thais". Critics argue that the crackdown is driven by economic concerns and xenophobia, and that it risks pushing migrants into human trafficking. Thailand's economy, which has stagnated in recent years, relies heavily on migrant labor, but the government claims it needs to maintain order and protect Thai jobs.

site_title: Ferrari sells out open-top Aperta to underpin push for growth
summary: Ferrari sold out its open-top LaFerrari Aperta model before its Paris Motor Show debut, indicating the brand's allure despite expanding its line-ups with more affordable models. The limited-run model's exclusivity helps safeguard Ferrari's profit growth, while the GTC4 Lusso T signals a strategy to broaden appeal. Ferrari aims to increase annual production to 9,000 cars by 2019, and its stock has shown resilience and price power, erasing most of its losses since the initial public offering in November.

site_title: New Adidas CEO sets off in pursuit of Nike
summary: New Adidas CEO Kasper Rorsted, 54, takes charge in October to close the gap with market leader Nike. Investors expect improvements in profitability, with the Adidas share price rising by two-thirds since his appointment in January. Rorsted aims to scrutinize the product portfolio and sales structure to boost lagging margins.

site_title: Indonesia central bank expects foreign exchange reserves to rise to US$151.5b by end-2017
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects foreign exchange reserves to reach US$151.5 billion by the end of 2017, a US$38 billion increase, according to Governor Agus Martowardojo. As of last month, reserves stood at US$113.5 billion. The projections were made during a parliamentary commission without providing an explanation.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank expects a US$38 billion increase in foreign exchange reserves by the end of 2017, its governor told a parliamentary commission on Thursday.

site_title: Oil prices retreat as investors wait for clarity on Opec deal
summary: Oil prices retreated on Thursday as investors lost confidence in Opec's plan to curb oil output, following the group's decision to limit production by 700,000-800,000 barrels per day. Benchmark prices, including Brent and US WTI, fell as the market awaited more details on the deal, with some analysts questioning the implementation of the cuts. Energy Aspects estimated the net effect would be around 400,000 barrels a day, while BMI Research noted that a production freeze would do little to reduce the market's oversupply.

images.alt_text: Oil futures retreated on Thursday as the market grew more sceptical on how Opec would implement a plan to curb oil output a day after the group agreed to limit production.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rise on gains in oil, metals
summary: Australian shares rose 0.97% to 5,464.6, driven by gains in materials and energy shares following a 6% increase in oil prices. The OPEC agreement to cut crude output boosted Brent crude to a two-week high of $48.96. Iron ore futures in China also rose, lifting mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.6% as industrial stocks, including Auckland International Airport, gained.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars rise as oil prices rally
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose due to a surge in oil prices after the OPEC agreed to trim output, benefiting commodity-exporting countries. The Australian dollar reached a three-week high at 77 US cents, while the New Zealand dollar climbed to a 1-1/2 month high against the Canadian dollar. However, traders expect limited future gains as the Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep its policy rate at 1.5% and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand may cut rates again in November.

site_title: UN envoy urges probe of South Korean 'water cannon death'
summary: A UN rights envoy, Maina Kiai, has called for an independent investigation into the death of a South Korean protester, Baek Nam Ki, who died after being hit by a police water cannon during an anti-government rally last year. Kiai expressed "dismay" over the incident, which sparked widespread outrage and criticism of police use of force. The UN envoy also demanded accountability for those responsible and compensation for the victim's family. The case has highlighted concerns over human rights in South Korea, where critics say freedoms have been eroded under President Park Geun Hye.

site_title: China property tycoon warns on real estate bubble
summary: China's richest man, Wang Jianlin, has warned that the country's property market is the "biggest bubble in history" due to rising prices in big cities and falling prices in smaller cities. The warning comes amid concerns about China's growing debt mountain and a sluggish manufacturing sector, which has hit growth and led to a warning from the Bank for International Settlements about an imminent banking crisis. Wang says the government's measures to limit purchases and credit have been ineffective, and that the economy may suffer further if leverage is reduced too quickly.

site_title: Three Japan conglomerates aim to merge nuclear fuel operations
summary: Japan's Hitachi Ltd, Toshiba Corp, and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd are in talks to merge their loss-making domestic nuclear fuel operations as early as spring 2017. The three companies aim to form a joint holding company before merging their fuel businesses into one entity. The move comes as the outlook for Japan's nuclear reactors remains bleak due to public opposition and regulatory obstacles, with only three of 42 reactors currently online. The companies are seeking to revitalize their domestic nuclear fuel business, which has been struggling since the 2011 Fukushima nuclear crisis.

site_title: Seoul court denies arrest warrant for Lotte Group chairman
summary: A South Korean court rejected a request for an arrest warrant for Lotte Group Chairman Shin Dong-bin in a corruption probe, but prosecutors may re-submit their request. The investigation has hindered the conglomerate's plans, including a billion-dollar deal and a planned IPO. The court found the arrest not necessary, but prosecutors expressed disappointment. Despite the setback, Shin could still face trial, which could take months. The investigation has uncovered embezzlement and breach of trust worth about $209.7 million.

site_title: China to build deepest, largest high-speed rail station at Great Wall
summary: China plans to build the world's deepest and largest high-speed railway station at Badaling, a popular section of the Great Wall, as part of preparations for the 2022 Winter Olympics. The 102m-deep station will have an underground area of 36,000 square meters and will sit along a railway network linking Beijing and Zhangjiakou. Advanced explosion technologies will be used to protect the Unesco World Heritage Site, ensuring the station's construction does not harm the area. The project aims to boost tourism and infrastructure in the region ahead of the Olympics.

site_title: Nasa to help China improve air traffic management
summary: NASA has signed a memorandum of understanding with China's Civil Aviation Administration to improve air traffic management at Chinese airports. The US space agency will use data from Chinese airports to identify potential efficiencies in air traffic management, aiming to improve predictability of ground delays and increase efficiencies for US and Chinese aviation operations. China plans to invest up to $10.2 billion to develop its air traffic management system, with NASA's cooperation expected to help China's airports manage long flight delays. The partnership is seen as a significant step for China's growing aviation market.

site_title: Samsung expects to get over 80% of recalled Note 7s in South Korea by Oct 1
summary: Samsung Electronics expects to recover over 80% of recalled Galaxy Note 7s in South Korea by October 1, when the company plans to resume sales. The recall, due to faulty batteries, was announced on September 2 for at least 2.5 million Note 7s in 10 markets. Samsung has resumed domestic TV ads and will pay 50% of repair costs for new Note 7 screens purchased in October. The company reiterated its request for consumers to turn in their recalled devices.

site_title: China's yuan firms, seen stable ahead of SDR inclusion
summary: China's yuan firmed slightly on Thursday ahead of its inclusion in the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket on October 1. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.6700 per US dollar, and the spot market opened at 6.6724 per US dollar, 51 pips firmer than the previous late session close. State banks offered US dollars at 6.67 level to support the yuan, and analysts expect the central bank to maintain modest room for onshore yuan depreciation.

site_title: Duterte's stance on South China Sea faces test on Hanoi trip
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is set to meet with Vietnamese leaders in Hanoi, testing his stance on territorial disputes in the South China Sea. Duterte has signaled a shift towards greater cooperation with China, while opposing US involvement, which has raised concerns among fellow claimants Vietnam. The US and Vietnam have started naval drills in the waters, while China has increased its military presence. The meetings will focus on maritime security and law enforcement, but discussions on disputed territory are unlikely, with talks focusing on maintaining regional stability.

site_title: In Bali's deaf village, silence is golden
summary: In Bali's deaf village of Bengkala, a unique culture has developed around deaf residents, who make up about 1.3% of the community. Despite initial superstitions and prejudices, the village has come to accept and integrate deaf villagers, offering them opportunities to work, learn, and participate in local activities. A developed sign language, Kata Kolok, has been created to facilitate communication, and the community has even developed a dance project, "dance of the deaf," which has attracted foreign visitors, giving residents hope for a brighter future.

site_title: Relief arrives for US shale firms as Opec folds in price battle
summary: US shale oil producers have welcomed Opec's agreement to cut production to 32.5 million barrels per day, establishing a floor on prices near US$50 a barrel. This move lifts low prices that have ravaged their budgets for over two years, making it possible for many US shale oil companies to make money and drill new wells. The agreement effectively halves the global oversupply and provides relief to US shale firms after a prolonged period of low oil prices.

site_title: Wells Fargo chief Stumpf heads to Hill with pressure mounting
summary: Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf is facing increasing pressure to resign amid a sales scandal that has led to the bank's market value being wiped off by over $20 billion. The bank has clawed back $41 million in stock from Stumpf, an unprecedented move for a major US bank CEO. California has suspended business relationships with Wells Fargo for a year and is working to change the bank's management structure. Stumpf will testify before the House Financial Services Committee, which may be softer on him than a previous bipartisan tongue-lashing he received from the Senate Banking Committee.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co's chief executive John Stumpf returns to Capitol Hill on Thursday with his job still under threat and the bank facing rising political pressure over a sales scandal that has become a major issue in Washington and on Wall Street.

site_title: Hundreds brought down from slopes of erupting volcano in Indonesia
summary: Hundreds of tourists, including 639 foreigners, were safely evacuated from the slopes of Indonesia's Mount Rinjani volcano after it erupted on Tuesday. The volcano, located on the island of Lombok, had a smaller eruption, sending ash into the sky. Authorities have closed the park gates and advised visitors to stay at least 3km away. Several tourists who declined to leave were not accounted for, but were described as "aware of the dangers." The Rinjani caldera is about 8-10 hours walk from the entrance, and rescue efforts are complete.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise with ringgit as Opec deal boosts oil; yen falls
summary: Asian stocks rose, with Malaysia's ringgit and oil climbing to a three-week high after OPEC agreed to cut crude production for the first time since 2008. The deal boosted oil prices to above $47 a barrel, with energy shares jumping 3.6% and leading gains on the MSCI Asia Pacific Index. The ringgit strengthened 0.9% against the dollar, while the yen fell 0.7% for a third day. The deal's impact is expected to ease global deflationary concerns and boost economic growth.

site_title: Turnbull steps up attack on renewables after Australian blackout
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull criticized the country's renewable energy targets, citing a recent storm-driven blackout in South Australia, which relies heavily on wind and solar power. The blackout, caused by severe storms knocking over transmission towers, has led Turnbull to label the state's renewable energy targets as "extremely aggressive, extremely unrealistic, and have paid little or no attention to energy security." This is the latest in a government attack on renewable energy, with Turnbull stating that the storm should be seen as a "real wake-up call."

site_title: Vietnam's economic growth slows to 6.4% y-o-y in Q3 2016
summary: Vietnam's economy grew 6.4% in Q3 2016, the fastest pace since Q4 2015, but below last year's 6.87%. The 9-month growth was 5.93%, with adverse weather affecting industrial and agricultural production. The government projects 6.7% growth for the year, down from 6.68% in 2015. Weather-related issues, including drought and salination, impacted the country's export and import sectors.

site_title: China bubble trouble risks missing lessons from Japan crash
summary: China's real-estate market is experiencing a credit boom similar to Japan's 1980s bubble era, with concerns growing over excessive debt and potential financial crisis. China's total debt has surged to 2.5 times GDP since 2008, with much of the credit flowing into property, fueling a 33% surge in house prices. Regulators are slow to recognize bad loans and shut down zombie companies, leaving the government and taxpayers at risk. Economists warn that China is repeating Japan's mistake, with warnings coming from within China, including a Peking University professor and a London-based analyst who worked in Japan during its bubble years.

site_title: US prepares to cede key role for Internet
summary: The US government is set to relinquish its oversight of the Internet, transitioning the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (Icann) into a self-regulating non-profit international entity. This change, effective midnight Friday, marks the end of US control over the Internet's "root zone" and will allow Icann to manage the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority. Critics, including Republican Senator Ted Cruz, argue this shift could threaten the Internet's integrity, while supporters say it will strengthen the Internet as a stable and secure tool for global empowerment.

site_title: Singapore tops regional corporate governance rankings
summary: Singapore has topped regional corporate governance rankings, "Corporate Governance (CG) Watch 2016", beating competitors Hong Kong, Japan, and others. The rankings were announced by CLSA and the Asian Corporate Governance Association. Singapore's strong corporate governance practices earned it the top spot, surpassing other countries in the region. This achievement is a testament to Singapore's reputation as a business-friendly and stable economy.

site_title: Gold rebounds as US dollar wanes after oil advances on Opec accord
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,325.96 an ounce after the US dollar weakened following an Opec agreement to limit oil production for the first time in eight years. The deal, aimed at stabilizing oil markets, led to a decline in the US dollar against currencies of crude-producing countries. Gold has rallied 25% in 2016, boosted by low interest rates. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, with gold exchange-traded funds holdings increasing by 0.5 metric ton to 2,032.2 tons.

site_title: Clinton enlists former foe Sanders in appeal for youth votes in US presidential race
summary: Hillary Clinton enlisted former rival Bernie Sanders to appeal to youth voters in the US presidential election, as opinion polls show a close race with Donald Trump. Clinton vowed to make public colleges tuition-free for families earning less than $125,000 a year. Despite a majority of Americans believing Clinton performed better in the presidential debate, her campaign is concerned about low youth voter turnout. Clinton praised Sanders, calling him a passionate champion for equality and justice, and her campaign hopes to get him to make more appearances on her behalf.

site_title: The underground pipeline shaping North Korea's new capitalists
summary: A North Korean defector in South Korea is secretly funding the country's burgeoning market economy through clandestine channels, providing hundreds of thousands of dollars to support dozens of small businesses, including noodle shops and grocery stores. This approach, known as "jangmadang generation," aims to foster gradual change from within by promoting marketization and the circulation of information. Defectors and organizations are using alternative funding routes, such as China banks, to support entrepreneurs and undermine the state's power.

site_title: Ringgit leads gains in emerging currencies as crude oil rallies
summary: Malaysia's ringgit led gains in emerging-market currencies after Opec reached a preliminary agreement to reduce crude production. The ringgit jumped 0.6% to 4.1165 per US dollar, its biggest one-day gain since Sept 22. South Korea's won strengthened for a third day, while Brent crude surged 5.9% on the news. The agreement bolstered developing-nation stocks and demand for higher-yielding assets. Analysts attribute the gains to market sentiment improvement and the transmission of Brent's surge to oil-related currencies.

site_title: Mitsubishi Regional Jet lands in US to start flight testing
summary: Mitsubishi Aircraft's regional jet, capable of carrying up to 92 passengers, has successfully landed in the US after two previous attempts. The aircraft, which made its first flight in November, is now set to undergo certification testing in the US, with the goal of applying for certification after 2,500 hours of flying time. The plane's arrival may help Japan challenge the regional-jet duopoly held by Brazil's Embraer and Canada's Bombardier. The aircraft's first flight was aborted twice due to air-conditioning sensor issues and costs around $47.3 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Opec deal
summary: Hong Kong shares rose on Thursday morning following a surprise deal by Opec to cut oil production and lift prices. The Hang Seng Index climbed 0.58% to 23,755.82, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.14%. The Opec deal boosted energy firms, contributing to the market's positive momentum.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won hit 3-week intraday high on Opec output deal
summary: South Korean shares and the won rose to a three-week high after Opec members agreed to limit crude oil output, its first deal since 2008. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) gained 0.8% to 2,068.81 points, while the won reached 1,096.0 against the dollar. Analysts attributed the surge to Opec's decision, as well as Japan's monetary easing and Clinton's perceived victory in the US presidential debate. Offshore investors also purchased Kospi shares, boosting the index, and shares related to Lotte Group rose following a court decision.

site_title: Obama says US needs to be 'judicious' about troop use in Syria
summary: President Barack Obama stated that the US needs to be "judicious" in deploying troops in Syria, as there is no scenario where large troop deployment can stop the civil war without escalating into a conflict with Russia or Iran. Obama has re-examined his Syria policy and is open to outside experts' ideas, but believes that sending in more troops is not the answer. The US military remains involved in Afghanistan and Iraq, and Obama wants to prioritize leading in non-security challenges without overextending US resources.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 2.67 points to 1667.63. The index saw 48 million lots traded worth RM17.7 million, with 109 gainers outnumbering 32 losers.

site_title: China's auto boom is warning to world miners facing age of scrap
summary: China is poised to enter a "scrap wave" in the next two years, with an estimated 30 years of industrialization resulting in a massive volume of metal goods being recycled. The country's car and appliance pool is expected to return to the market, threatening the global supply chain and mining companies. Chiho-Tiande Group, a top recycler, is acquiring Scholz Holding Gmbh, a 144-year-old German company, to expand its capacity and provide technical expertise. This move could lead to a profound impact on the global steel industry and mining companies, with China's steel scrap supply potentially exceeding global demand.

images.alt_text: China is on the cusp of a scrap wave that will return metal from ageing cars and expired fridges to the supply chain in a growing threat to mining companies, according to Chiho-Tiande Group Ltd, a top recycler, which is taking over one of the biggest and oldest names in Europe's scrap business.

site_title: China's Fosun to invest in 46.2b yuan Chinese high-speed rail project
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun International Ltd will invest in a 46.2 billion yuan high-speed rail project in Zhejiang province, becoming the first private firm to participate in a Chinese high-speed rail project. The investment will be made by wholly owned subsidiary Shanghai Fosun High Technology Group Co Ltd in partnership with the Zhejiang government. This move aims to alleviate the debt burden of local authorities and follows China's government promise to support private-partnership projects.

images.alt_text: Chinese conglomerate Fosun International Ltd said on Thursday it will invest in a 46.2 billion yuan (S$9.4 billion) private-partnership project (PPP) to build a high-speed rail link, becoming the first private firm to take part in a Chinese high-speed rail project.

site_title: Drugmaker AbbVie opens S$400m Singapore plant
summary: AbbVie, a US-listed drugmaker, has opened a S$400 million manufacturing plant in Singapore, its first foray in Asia. The 120,000 sq m facility, located in Tuas Biomedical Park, will produce small molecule active pharmaceutical ingredients and biologics. The plant is expected to employ over 250 new employees, with the majority being hired locally. AbbVie aims to strengthen its manufacturing capabilities and support its pipeline in oncology and women's health, providing geographic balance to its global network. The facility is expected to be fully operational by the end of 2018.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise after 2-day typhoon break; central bank rate meeting awaited
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose on Thursday after a two-day break due to a typhoon, boosted by gains in overseas markets. Investors await the central bank's quarterly policy meeting for clues about the domestic economy. The central bank is expected to refrain from cutting rates for the first time in a year, citing improving economic prospects for the trade-dependent economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open 12.35 points higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.43% or 12.35 points to 2,870.36 on Thursday, driven by overnight US gains. Oil and gas names, including Keppel Corp, Sembcorp Industries, and Ezion Holdings, increased after the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to cut output for the first time in eight years.

site_title: South Korea's August department store sales rise for third month
summary: South Korea's department store sales rose 4.1% in August, marking the third consecutive month of growth, driven by widespread discounting ahead of a major public holiday. This follows a 7.0% increase in July. The increase is attributed to discounting and promotions, which contributed to the rise in combined sales at department stores run by Hyundai Department Store, Lotte Shopping, and Shinsegae Co.

site_title: Xpress Q4 loss widens to S$12.3m after losses from selling units
summary: Xpress Holdings reported a widened net loss of S$12.3 million for the fourth quarter, down from a S$172 million loss the previous year. The loss was primarily due to S$11.7 million from the disposal of loss-making subsidiaries in China, Malaysia, and Hong Kong. For the full year, the printer swung into a net loss of S$21.8 million from a profit of S$311,000. The company is seeking shareholder approval to expand into smart technologies, publishing, and investments.

site_title: Serrano faces demand over guarantees for defaulting supplier
summary: Serrano Holdings, an interior-design contractor, has received a letter of demand from Maybank in Vietnam for US$2 million and 32.4 billion Vietnamese dong (S$1.97 million) over defaulted supplier payments. The amounts stem from guarantees provided by Serrano Holdings for term loan facilities granted to Sorrento Vietnam Shareholding Company, a major supplier. Serrano is seeking professional advice on the matter, while Sorrento Vietnam is in negotiations to dispose of a factory to discharge its credit facilities.

site_title: Masterminds brings botched 'Hillbilly Heist' to cinema
summary: The comedy film "Masterminds" follows the true story of the 1997 Loomis Fargo Robbery, also known as the "Hillbilly Heist," where a group of thieves stole $17.3 million. The film stars Zach Galifianakis and Kristen Wiig as the masterminds of the heist, who make numerous mistakes that lead to their capture. Director Jared Hess pokes fun at the absurdity of the events, saying the thieves' decisions were so ridiculous they made for an outrageous comedy. The film is set to be released in US theaters on September 30, 2016.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rally after surprise oil deal
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Thursday following a surprise OPEC oil production cut deal, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.76% to 16,590.68. The Topix also rose 0.61% to 1,338.88. The rally was seen as a positive reaction to the global market, with US and European markets also rallying on the news. The deal aimed to stabilize oil prices and boost economic growth, leading to a strong market reaction.

site_title: Australia job vacancies jump to 4-year high in August quarter
summary: Australia's job vacancies surged to a 4-year high in the June-August quarter, reaching 177,300 seasonally adjusted. This represents a 9.8% increase from the same period last year and a 4.5% jump from the previous quarter. Private sector vacancies rose 4.6% to 160,100, while public sector vacancies increased 4.9% to 17,200, the highest since 2011. The data is seen as a reliable leading indicator of labour demand and employment growth, offering a promising sign for a pick-up in labour demand.

site_title: Top Malaysian pension fund seeks to diversify assets for returns
summary: Malaysia's largest pension fund, the Employees Provident Fund (EPF), plans to diversify its investment portfolios to boost returns. The fund aims to increase investments in private equity, property, and infrastructure to around 10% of total assets in the next 3-4 years. This move is in response to low interest rates and global uncertainties, which have affected investors worldwide. The EPF, with almost $170 billion in assets, is looking to acquire real estate assets in the UK, particularly in logistics and healthcare sectors, to meet its long-term inflation-hedging targets.

site_title: Fed politics in spotlight as Yellen cornered by lawmaker
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen faced criticism from Republican Congressman Scott Garrett for potential conflict of interest after Fed Governor Lael Brainard, a potential Clinton pick for Treasury secretary, donated to Hillary Clinton's campaign. Yellen hesitated and demurred when asked about the conflict, saying she would consult counsel and was not aware of a conflict. The questioning came during a House Financial Services Committee hearing, with the election taking place on November 8. Yellen rejected the suggestion that the US central bank has a political bias.

site_title: Not all diamonds enjoy recovery as budget stones get left behind
summary: The diamond market is experiencing a recovery, with prices increasing for higher-quality stones, but smaller and lower-quality diamonds are being left behind. Prices for gems smaller than three grains have dropped 15% this year, while rough-diamond prices slid 18% last year. The slump is partly due to producer stockpiling and the rise of man-made diamonds, which threaten the traditional market. Manufacturers are shifting to bigger, higher-quality stones to boost demand and profits, and some executives question whether the recovery will last.

images.alt_text: The recovery in diamond prices is leaving out the smallest and lowest-quality gems.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Rickmers Maritime, SGX, Xpress, Serrano
summary: Rickmers Maritime's trustee-manager expects no revision to its restructuring plan for S$100 million of notes. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is launching an initiative to provide brokerages with data on possible market rigging. Xpress Holdings reported a widened net loss of S$12.3 million for the fourth quarter. Serrano's wholly owned subsidiary, Serrano Holdings, received a US$2 million and 32.4 billion Vietnamese dong letter of demand from Maybank in Vietnam due to overdue payments.

site_title: Asia: Stocks gain as crude oil surge improves risk appetite
summary: Asian stocks rose on Thursday as oil prices surged, with MSCI's broadest Asia-Pacific index up 0.6% and commodity-heavy Australian and South Korean shares advancing 0.6% and 0.7%, respectively. The deal by OPEC to limit crude output boosted investor risk appetite, driving oil prices up nearly 6% and lifting other commodity-linked currencies, including the Canadian dollar and Norwegian crown. The Dow also rose 0.6% on the back of the oil rally.

site_title: Cosco eyes Hanjin terminals after US$738m Abu Dhabi deal
summary: China Cosco Shipping Corp is considering buying some container-terminal assets of Hanjin Shipping Co after spending US$738 million on a new port in Abu Dhabi. Hanjin's chairman, Xu Lirong, expressed willingness to sell but said it's not currently on the agenda. The deal would help Cosco expand its footprint in the US after China's government merged its key shipping companies last year.

site_title: Britain must explain Brexit strategy to limit uncertainty: think tank
summary: Britain must clearly outline its Brexit strategy to avoid prolonged uncertainty, a London-based think tank warned. Since taking office, Prime Minister Theresa May has been silent on her negotiating stance, which has frustrated businesses and EU partners. The Institute for Government calls for May to clarify the process and timescales for agreeing the UK's initial negotiating position to prevent internal squabbling from undermining the government's position. This comes as the EU's Article 50 exit process is set to begin next year.

site_title: Chinese giant turns to France to meet soaring demand for baby formula
summary: Chinese baby formula producer Synutra has opened a 170 million euro factory in France's Brittany region, marking the country's largest foreign investment in the milk processing sector. The factory, which will produce 100,000 tons of powdered milk annually, is supplied by Sodiaal, France's biggest dairy cooperative, and employs 12,000 people worldwide. The move aims to meet China's growing demand for baby formula, as the country continues to mistrust domestic production following a 2008 contamination scandal.

images.alt_text: China's third largest baby formula producer on Wednesday opened a vast plant in France's Brittany region, whose prized dairy cows are set to contribute 100,000 tons of powdered milk a year to a growing Chinese market that mistrusts domestic production.

site_title: Rich world's most indebted consumers caught in bubble mystery
summary: Denmark's households hold the world's largest household debt burden, with an average debt of three times their disposable income. A 2006-2008 boom-bust cycle saw home prices plummet 20% from peak to trough, triggering a recession. Now, prices in Copenhagen are higher than at the peak, raising concerns of a potential bubble. Nordea, the Nordic region's largest bank, warns of a possible next bubble. This debt burden echoes the 2006-2008 crisis, where a housing market bubble burst, and investors are now on high alert for similar signs.

site_title: China capital exodus accelerates as further yuan weakness seen
summary: China's capital outflow through cross-border sales of funds accelerated, with mainland investors' accumulative net buying of Hong Kong-registered public funds more than doubling to 7.8 billion yuan as of Aug 31. The yuan's 7% drop since devaluation in August last year and the mainland stock market's volatility have driven the exodus. Authorities have granted mutual recognition status to seven Hong Kong funds, attracting more than 90% of the capital, but investors remain wary due to yuan depreciation and market volatility.

site_title: Global container shipping firms raided in South Africa over suspected collusion
summary: South African authorities raided six global container shipping companies, including Maersk and Mediterranean Shipping Company, on suspicion of colluding to inflate rates between Asia and South Africa. The Competition Commission suspects the firms of fixing incremental rates on cargo shipments, resulting in inflated prices and potentially harming economic growth. The raid follows a tip-off and involves confiscating documents and electronic data. The companies involved have confirmed the raids and are cooperating with authorities, with Maersk stating it had already changed its pricing practices to avoid fines.

site_title: Congress rejects Obama veto, Saudi Sept 11 bill becomes law
summary: Congress has overridden President Barack Obama's veto, making the "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" a law. The bill allows relatives of 9/11 victims to sue Saudi Arabia, which Congress voted 348-77 against in the House and 97-1 in the Senate. The override marks the first veto override of Obama's presidency and is seen as a blow to Saudi Arabia and Obama's stance on human rights. The law grants an exception to sovereign immunity, clearing the way for lawsuits seeking damages from the Saudi government, and may have diplomatic implications.

site_title: Air Berlin to cut 1,200 jobs
summary: Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline, announced a major restructuring plan, cutting 1,200 jobs and shrinking its fleet. The airline will concentrate on higher-yielding markets from its hubs in Berlin and Dusseldorf, and provide 40 Airbus 320 aircraft to rival Lufthansa. The restructuring plan aims to reduce staff and operate a core fleet of 75 aircraft. Air Berlin has struggled with significant external market pressures and a record loss of 447 million euros last year, partly due to Etihad's regular cash injections. The agreement is expected to be finalized in the fourth quarter of this year.

site_title: Spotify in advanced talks to buy SoundCloud: FT
summary: Spotify is in advanced talks to acquire German music-streaming service SoundCloud, potentially valuing the company at $1 billion, according to the Financial Times. This move comes as music-streaming companies struggle to turn a profit amid increasing competition. The acquisition would be Spotify's first major move to expand its market share in the music streaming industry. Details of the deal have not been disclosed, but the talks are reportedly ongoing.

site_title: South Australia limps back to life as more storms threaten
summary: South Australia experienced a blackout after "unprecedented" thunderstorms, causing widespread damage and 80,000 electricity strikes. Power was restored to 90% of homes, but 75,000 remained without power, with services expected to resume in a couple of days. Authorities warned of more severe weather, including gale-force winds and heavy rain, as a low-pressure system crosses the state. No serious injuries or deaths were reported, but the federal energy minister raised questions about the state's electricity supply. The premier accused him of playing politics, stating it could have happened anywhere.

site_title: Currencies steady as Yellen confirms Fed eyeing December
summary: Major currencies remained steady despite a 5% surge in oil prices and a tentative Opec deal to curb output. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's confirmation of a potential rate hike by December also failed to impact the dollar. The Canadian dollar rose 1.1% due to the oil price move, while the British pound edged higher against the dollar. Other currencies, including the euro and yen, remained unchanged.

site_title: Ship shake: Hanjin woes may help float tech, data start-ups
summary: The global shipping industry, hit by declining revenues and consolidation, is turning to technology to improve efficiency. Startups like Flexport, Freightos, and Xeneta are streamlining the logistics process, providing real-time data and transparency, and automating quote and sales processes. This shift is expected to reduce costs and increase efficiency, with McKinsey predicting shipping oversupply will stay above 20% this year. While some industry veterans question the impact of these startups, others see benefits, such as reduced paperwork and faster quote generation, with one CEO citing a 90% reduction in paperwork.

site_title: Yahoo hacked by criminals, not state sponsor, security firm says
summary: Yahoo's accounts were hacked in 2014 by cybercriminals, not a state-sponsored party, according to InfoArmor. The hackers, known in the underground community, broke into Yahoo's data, potentially exposing 500 million users' information, including names, email addresses, and security questions. This contradicts Yahoo's previous claim that a state-sponsored actor was responsible. The incident raises concerns about cyber-espionage and targeted attacks, but Verizon, which is acquiring Yahoo, still evaluates the potential effect on the deal. Yahoo has not released evidence supporting its initial claim.

site_title: China's US$5b healthcare deal spree shows global ambitions
summary: China's pharmaceutical industry is aggressively expanding globally, with over $5.2 billion in overseas healthcare acquisitions announced this year. Companies like China Grand Pharmaceutical and Healthcare Holdings Ltd are seeking to break into the US and African markets, while also exporting finished pills to developing countries. Despite challenges in competing with international rivals, Chinese companies aim to increase innovation and internationalization, with some seeking to acquire established manufacturers of pharmaceutical ingredients in Europe and the US.

site_title: Fighter jet sales to Gulf allies backed by US after a wait
summary: The US has approved the sale of fighter jets to Bahrain, Qatar, and Kuwait, valued at up to $20 billion, in deals backed by Boeing Co and Lockheed Martin Corp. The sales, worth up to $12 billion for planes, could include 72 F-15 jets to Qatar, 32 F/A-18s to Kuwait, and 19 F-16s to Bahrain. The sales aim to bolster the weaponry of Sunni-led nations in the Middle East and keep open assembly lines for older planes.

site_title: US Senate passes spending measure to avoid shutdown
summary: The US Senate passed a stopgap spending bill, 72-26, to fund the government through December 9, avoiding a shutdown. The measure includes funding for the Zika virus, flood damage in Louisiana, veterans' programs, and addresses the opioid abuse crisis. The bill also includes $1.1 billion for Zika, $500 million for flood relief, and $37 million for opioid abuse. The Flint water crisis was resolved through a separate water bill, with House lawmakers planning to vote on an amendment authorizing $170 million for Flint. The bill now heads to the House for approval.

site_title: Vancouver tops list of cities at risk of housing bubble: UBS
summary: Vancouver tops a list of cities at risk of a housing bubble, according to a UBS analysis, with housing prices increasing by almost 50% since 2011. The city's ranking rose to first from fourth place in 2015, with detached single-family houses reaching C$1.6 million. Other cities at risk include Vancouver's Canadian counterparts, London, and Stockholm, as well as Sydney, Munich, and Hong Kong. Low interest rates and investor optimism have fueled the surge in prices, with UBS warning that a rapid decline in house prices could occur if macroeconomic momentum shifts or investor sentiment changes.

site_title: Oil soars 6% as Opec reaches deal to limit output in Nov
summary: Oil prices surged 6% on Wednesday after Opec reached a deal to limit crude output to 32.5-33.0 million barrels per day in November, its first production cut since 2008. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries aims to decrease production by 700,000 barrels per day. This agreement follows a market crash due to oversupply. The move is expected to stabilize oil prices and alleviate concerns about oversupply.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as Deutsche Bank recovers
summary: European shares rose on Wednesday, with Deutsche Bank recovering from record lows after its CEO ruled out a possible capital increase and sold its British insurance business. The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 0.7%, with commodity stocks gaining 1.4% on higher metals prices. The news boosted sentiment, easing concerns over the bank sector, which has been struggling due to low interest rates and sluggish growth.

site_title: Turkey set to extend state of emergency, 32,000 jailed
summary: Turkey's National Security Council recommended extending the state of emergency imposed after the July 15 coup, which has seen 32,000 suspects arrested. The emergency has raised concerns about eroding the rule of law and has sparked criticism from opposition leaders. The council also proposed marking July 15 as Turkey's "Day of Democracy and Freedoms." The trials of tens of thousands of people, including top former generals and journalists, are set to put the system under enormous pressure, with the government planning to build 174 new prisons over the next five years.

site_title: WEF ranks Switzerland as most economically competitive for 8th time
summary: Switzerland has been ranked as the most economically competitive country for the 8th time by the World Economic Forum (WEF), with unrivaled innovation, a sophisticated business landscape, and the world's most efficient workforce contributing to its top spot. Singapore and the US followed in second and third place, respectively. The report highlighted the importance of institutions, infrastructure, and education in driving competitiveness, while warning that rising trade barriers and insufficient monetary policy measures pose risks to global growth.

site_title: Opec agrees surprise oil output cut
summary: OPEC agreed to cut oil production by 750,000 barrels a day to 32.5 million barrels per day, aiming to boost weak crude prices. The surprise move sparked a 5% increase in crude prices, with Brent North Sea crude rising to $48.69 and West Texas Intermediate rising to $47.05. The agreement was reached after Algerian Energy Minister Noureddine Boutarfa pressed demands for action on an oil supply glut and higher investment. OPEC members include Saudi Arabia, Iran, and Russia, with disagreements between Saudi Arabia and Iran hindering progress.

site_title: Teenager killed father before opening fire at South Carolina school
summary: A 14-year-old boy shot and killed his father before opening fire at Townville Elementary School in South Carolina, wounding two children and a teacher. The suspect, who was never inside the school, was subdued by volunteer firefighter Jamie Brock on a playground until police arrived. Authorities praised Brock for risking his life to mitigate the incident. The motive behind the shooting is not specified, and the suspect's identity is not provided.

images.alt_text: A 14-year-old boy shot and killed his father then drove to an elementary school in South Carolina and opened fire with a handgun, wounding two children and a teacher on Wednesday, authorities said.

site_title: Vancouver commercial real estate likely to be new focus
summary: Wealthy foreign investors are shifting their focus to Vancouver's commercial real estate market to avoid the 15% land-transfer tax imposed on non-Canadian investors in the residential market. Commercial real estate transactions in Vancouver reached C$7.14 billion in the first half of 2016, a significant increase from the previous year. This move comes as the city is at risk of a housing bubble, according to a UBS report, driven by foreign investment and loose monetary policy. The shift in focus is expected to impact the city's office, retail, and industrial property markets.

site_title: S'pore food industry has greater economic splash than thought: study
summary: A study commissioned by Food Industry Asia and the Singapore Manufacturing Federation found that Singapore's food industry has a significant economic impact, contributing S$14.4 billion to the country's GDP in 2014 and providing nearly 300,000 jobs. The industry's value-added contribution to GDP came primarily from food distribution, with manufacturers supporting around 39,000 jobs and contributing S$3.2 billion. The study suggests that Singapore's food industry has immense potential for growth, with many multinational companies setting up R&D centers in the country, citing its favorable business environment and skills availability.

site_title: Israel's former president Shimon Peres dies at 93
summary: Former Israeli President Shimon Peres, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, died at 93 after a major stroke, triggering an outpouring of grief. Peres held multiple government roles, including prime minister and president, and was a key figure in negotiating the Oslo peace accords. World leaders, including US President Barack Obama, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and French President Francois Hollande, paid tribute to Peres, hailing him as a visionary and advocate for peace.

site_title: Saudi Arabia signals willingness to compromise with Iran
summary: Saudi Arabia has signaled a willingness to compromise with Iran, potentially paving the way for the first limit on oil production in two years. Saudi Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih said Iran, Libya, and Nigeria should be allowed to produce at maximum levels, narrowing the gap between Opec countries. A deal is unlikely until the Opec meeting in November, but the mere fact that numbers are on the table suggests progress. The stakes are high, with the International Energy Agency predicting a worsening oil market if Opec doesn't act, and the oil market expected to re-balance in late 2017.

site_title: Does Trump pay taxes? Debate triggers new scrutiny
summary: Donald Trump has faced scrutiny over his tax payments, with some speculating he may be avoiding income taxes due to his refusal to release his tax returns. Trump made a comment during a debate with Hillary Clinton, fueling the debate. Clinton suggested Trump may not be as rich or charitable as he claims. Trump's refusal to disclose his tax returns has become a contentious issue in the US presidential campaign.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump loves to brag about how rich he is. One question swirling through the US presidential campaign now is this: Has he managed to avoid paying income taxes?

site_title: US: News of Opec deal sparks stock gains
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday after a tentative Opec deal to cut oil output sent crude prices soaring over five percent. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.6%, while the S&P 500 rose 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.2%. Oil producers like Exxon Mobil, Chevron, and ConocoPhillips jumped, while oilfield suppliers like Schlumberger and Halliburton also gained. The Opec deal, which aims to reduce output by 32.5 million barrels a day, is set to be finalized in November.

site_title: Germany and Deutsche Bank rush to quash state aid rumours
summary: Germany and Deutsche Bank denied rumors of a rescue plan for the troubled lender, following reports that the German government was working on an emergency plan for Deutsche if the worst comes to the worst. Deutsche's share price rose 2.04% after the denials, while the DAX 30 index of leading German shares gained 0.74%. The bank has been under pressure due to a potentially massive US fine over the subprime mortgage crisis, with shares hitting a record low on Monday. Deutsche has announced plans to offload its British insurance company Abbey Life to boost its capital buffer, but faces further looming problems, including an investigation into alleged money laundering at its Russian branch.

images.alt_text: The German government and Deutsche Bank were at pains on Wednesday to quash speculation of a rescue plan for the troubled lender, in an effort to reassure investors spooked by a potentially massive US fine.

site_title: Federal Reserve's primal divide: Is economy overheating or stuck in a rut?
summary: Federal Reserve policymakers remain divided over whether the US economy is overheating or stuck in a rut, leading to uncertainty about a potential interest rate increase in December. 10 Fed officials emphasized the "Fedspeak" that markets and the public are trying to digest, with some, like Chicago Fed President Charles Evans, arguing that the low interest rate environment is a global phenomenon with underpinnings in economic fundamentals, while others, like Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester, suggest the Fed should raise rates to prevent inflation from rising. The Fed Chair Janet Yellen has kept her options open, saying the case for a rate increase is strengthening, but also stating the economy still has "room to run" on job creation.

images.alt_text: Investors may be expecting a US interest rate increase in December, but Federal Reserve policymakers remain divided over whether the economy is mired in a rut, strong enough to withstand an immediate hike or hovering somewhere in between.

site_title: Tharman again rules himself out of the running for prime minister
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has ruled himself out of the running for Singapore's prime minister, despite being the top choice among 69% of respondents in a recent survey. He reiterated that he is not interested in the role, citing his strengths in policy-making and advising, rather than being the leader. Tharman emphasized the importance of the team culture in the Cabinet, stating that whoever becomes the next PM will be part of a team, not an individual.

site_title: Dubai developers feel growing sense of restraint
summary: Dubai developers are experiencing a growing sense of restraint due to persistently low oil prices, which are undercutting spending power across the region. Home prices may drop by 10% in 2017, following a decline of about 7% this year. Despite new developments being announced, many projects have ambiguous time frames and greater flexibility in terms, with developers focusing on niche demand and enhancing recurring income. Economic growth in the UAE is expected to be the slowest since 2010, with many projects scaled back or delayed.

site_title: US debate shows up two sparring tribes
summary: A US presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump has sparked a divide among Americans, with Clinton's supporters viewing her as the clear winner and Trump's supporters seeing him as the victor. The debate highlights a deepening divide between two distinct groups: those who have benefited from globalization and are comfortable with the status quo, and those in struggling areas of America's Rust Belt who feel left behind. Trump's message of bringing jobs "back home" and restricting immigration resonates with the latter group, while Clinton's policies are seen as too focused on the wealthy and elite.

site_title: US dollar up against yen with focus on Yellen
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen and a basket of currencies, with traders focusing on Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen's semi-annual testimony. The US dollar index was up 0.15%, while the euro was flat at $1.1210, influenced by concerns over the European financial system. Yellen's testimony is expected to discuss financial regulation, Fed rates, and the economy, with Cleveland Fed president Loretta Mester and Kansas City Fed president Esther George also set to speak on the economy.

site_title: South America becomes home for US gas
summary: US liquefied natural gas (LNG) is being shipped to South America, with Cheniere Energy Inc sending over half of its tankers to the region. The glut in global LNG markets has driven prices down, making South America an attractive destination. Latin America lacks reliable energy sources, and the region's trade with the US is easier due to the Panama Canal. The US is poised to become a major player in global LNG markets, with Chile being the leading recipient, followed by Brazil and Argentina.

site_title: HK entering uncharted political territory post 'Umbrella Revolution'
summary: Hong Kong is entering uncharted territory two years after the "Umbrella Revolution," a pro-democracy movement that began in 2014. Former protesters, including Nathan Law and Eddie Chu, have won seats in the Legislative Council, advocating for self-determination or independence from China. This marks a significant shift in the pro-democracy camp, which had previously focused on democratic reform. Beijing has warned against any talk of independence, but the new lawmakers have vowed to promote self-determination, predicting a "chaotic and difficult" first year in the new term of the legislature.

site_title: Volkswagen working hard to get through 'dieselgate': CEO
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller stated that the company is utilizing all available resources to overcome the "dieselgate" emissions cheating scandal. One year after the scandal's revelation, Mueller described it as a pivotal event in VW's history. The issue arose from the use of "defeat devices" in 11 million diesel vehicles worldwide, which increase exhaust treatment during regulatory tests. VW aims to work through the scandal, which is expected to be an "incisive turning point" in the company's history.

site_title: US welcomes MH17 inquiry, notes Russian link
summary: The US welcomed the preliminary results of a Dutch-led inquiry into the downing of MH17, supporting Washington's suspicions of Russian involvement. The inquiry, which uncovered evidence, blamed Russian-backed separatists for the 2014 downing of the Malaysia Airlines jet that killed 298 people. The US had previously blamed Russia for the incident, despite Moscow's denials. The Dutch inquiry's findings support the US's claims, further solidifying the US's stance on Russian involvement in the tragedy.

site_title: Non-Central Region leads price drop for completed apartments, condos
summary: Singapore's completed private apartments and condominium units saw a price drop of 0.9% month on month in August, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) flash estimate. The Non-Central Region fared the worst, with prices easing.

site_title: Brokerages to get more SGX data on possible market rigging
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will start releasing more data on possible market rigging to brokerages, starting with its quarterly reports this week. The data will include details of alerts triggered by suspicious trading activity, which will be sent to each brokerage. This move aims to lift surveillance standards and improve market oversight.

site_title: The digital wave is cresting, it's time to jump on board
summary: The 4th industrial revolution has begun, marking a new era of digital transformation. As traditional industries face disruptions, companies must adapt to stay competitive. Key areas for digital transformation include engaging the workforce with modern tools and experiences, supporting innovation through business-focused IT, and modernizing data centers to manage growing demands. Security also needs to evolve to keep pace with the speed and capabilities of emerging technologies.
