summary: A new anti-corruption law in South Korea took effect, targeting widespread low-level corruption among public servants and education officials. The Kim Young-Ran law, covering 4 million public servants, aims to prevent bribery and favoritism, including teachers accepting bribes for better grades and officials being bought off by businessmen. The legislation is seen as a significant step towards rooting out corruption in the country of 50 million.

site_title: Postal Savings Bank of China shares open flat in Hong Kong debut after US$7.4b IPO
summary: Postal Savings Bank of China (PSBC) shares opened flat at HK$4.76 in its Hong Kong debut, following a US$7.4 billion IPO that priced shares near the bottom of its marketing range. The IPO received tepid demand, with retail investors showing only 2.6 times the demand for shares, and was heavily oversubscribed by institutional investors. The IPO's success comes amidst a cautious outlook for the Chinese banking industry, battling with mounting bad debts amid a slowing economy.

site_title: Typhoon Megi moves on to China after killing four in Taiwan
summary: Typhoon Megi, which killed four in Taiwan, moved into southern China, bringing widespread power outages and injuries to at least 523 people. The storm made landfall in Fujian province with winds of up to 118.8 km/h, prompting a red alert. Over 3.7 million households lost electricity, and about 14,000 people were evacuated. Heavy rains are forecast to continue until Thursday morning in affected areas.

site_title: Point of 'maximum uncertainty' seen after Brexit: Oaktree
summary: The world is at a point of "maximum uncertainty" after the UK's Brexit vote, according to Jay Wintrob, CEO of Oaktree Capital Group. The uncertainty surrounds the UK's exit negotiations and the US presidential election. Wintrob also expressed uncertainty about the outcome of these events, stating "we just don't know how the actual negotiations for exit are going to turn out."

site_title: Deutsche Bank troubles cast long shadow over European banking
summary: Deutsche Bank's financial troubles have cast a long shadow over European banking, with the US Department of Justice requesting $14 billion to settle claims tied to mortgage-backed securities. The bank's losses have dragged down European financial stocks, fueling concerns about its capital levels and refocusing investors on the industry's faults. Despite CEO John Cryan's assurances that capital is not an issue, the bank's stock has tumbled 20% this month, and investors are worried about the bank's ability to pay.

images.alt_text: The turmoil swirling around Deutsche Bank AG has brought simmering concerns about the health of Europe's banks back to a boil.

site_title: Toshiba more than doubles profit forecast as Yen drives sales
summary: Toshiba has more than doubled its profit forecast to 70 billion yen for the first half of the year, driven by growth in storage and electronic devices. A stronger-than-expected yen depreciation boosted sales of hard drives, while the memory division benefited from growth in smartphones. The company now expects 85 billion yen of net income for the period, up from 70 billion yen previously. Toshiba has been recovering from an accounting scandal and is cutting thousands of jobs, shedding operations, and narrowing its businesses.

images.alt_text: Toshiba Corp has raised its forecast for first-half operating profit to 70 billion yen (S$946.9 million) from 30 billion yen previously, crediting growth in storage and electronic devices for a more than doubling of its earnings outlook.

site_title: Duterte woos army as opponents warn of discontent in ranks
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is wooing the military with promises of higher salaries, improved healthcare, and modern equipment. He has given nearly half of his public addresses to soldiers, a significant increase from his predecessors. Analysts say Duterte is trying to curry favor with the military, but warned it could be a bad idea. Duterte's actions come as opponents warn of discontent among military ranks, with some experts suggesting he is trying to consolidate power. The military's response to Duterte's efforts remains uncertain.

site_title: Ringgit falls toward weakest in three months after oil declines
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell to a three-month low against the US dollar as crude oil declined, dampening the energy exporting economy's outlook. The decline in Brent crude, a 3% drop, followed major producers' meeting in Algiers to discuss limiting output. This move reduced investors' expectations of a Donald Trump election victory, which could have roiled financial markets. The ringgit's fall was the largest among emerging-market currencies.

site_title: Post-umbrella Hong Kong opens explosive political chapter
summary: Hong Kong, two years after the "Umbrella Revolution" protests, is entering uncharted political territory as former protesters prepare to take office, advocating for possible split from China. Five new legislators support self-determination or independence, a departure from the traditional pro-democracy stance. The Hong Kong government and Beijing have warned against talk of independence, while the new lawmakers vow to promote self-determination, potentially leading to "fireworks" and a chaotic first year in the legislature.

site_title: Uber aims to win Japan's heart through its stomach
summary: Uber launches food-delivery service in Japan as part of its efforts to enter the country's massive market, where its ride-hailing service has been blocked by regulation and opposition. The move aims to establish Uber's brand in Japan and potentially expand into other Asian countries. Uber plans to enter at least 22 new countries with its UberEats food-delivery service, which will provide valuable information about customer preferences and traffic conditions. The company's pilot ride-hailing projects for elderly people in rural towns and its expansion into food delivery are part of a broader strategy to diversify its services.

site_title: China's retail sales forecast to grow 10.3% in 2016
summary: China's retail sales are forecast to grow 10.3% in 2016, according to the China General Chamber of Commerce. This growth is attributed to stabilizing consumption, with positive signs in the economy, including a recovery in power consumption and increasing exports. China's retail sales beat expectations in August with a 10.6% growth rate, surpassing forecasted 10.3%. This positive trend suggests a stabilizing economy, which could ease pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Israeli ex-president and Nobel laureate Shimon Peres dies: doctor
summary: Israeli ex-president and Nobel laureate Shimon Peres has died at 93, two weeks after suffering a major stroke. He passed away at 3:00am on Wednesday, according to his personal doctor. Peres, who held multiple roles in Israel, including prime minister and president, won the 1994 Nobel Peace Prize for his role in negotiating the Oslo Accords. A press conference will be held to provide further details.

site_title: Asia: Markets down, energy firms hit by oil deal woes
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday, led by Tokyo's Nikkei index, as the yen strengthened and energy firms fell amid concerns over an Opec oil meeting. The meeting, where Opec and Russia will discuss a global oil glut, may not yield a collective output freeze due to Iran's refusal to agree. Oil prices rose, with West Texas Intermediate increasing three cents to US$44.70, but the market remains volatile, with prices trapped between US$40 and US$50 a barrel.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge down as focus turns to earnings, won steady
summary: South Korean stocks edged down 0.3% on Wednesday, pressured by foreign sales and a cautious stance ahead of third-quarter earnings. The Kospi index fell to 2,057.19 points. Samsung Electronics, battling a crisis over faulty Note 7 smartphones, traded flat. Analysts expect the index to move higher in October after corporate earnings are released. Meanwhile, the South Korean won held steady against the US dollar.

site_title: Trump launches harsh new fat attack on ex-Miss Universe
summary: Donald Trump criticized Alicia Machado, a former Miss Universe, for gaining weight after winning the crown in 1996, calling her "Miss Piggy" and "Miss Housekeeping." Machado, who is Latina, accused Trump of publicly humiliating her over her weight gain and claimed he yelled at her and called her ugly. Trump's comments sparked a heated exchange with Hillary Clinton, who invoked Machado's experience as an example of Trump's treatment of women. Machado has since expressed support for Clinton and vowed to vote for her in the November election.

site_title: Trump tweets he raised US$13m in 24 hours in online donations
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump tweeted that he raised US$13 million in 24 hours from online donations, surpassing his August fundraising goal of US$90 million. This move comes as Trump has struggled to secure traditional Republican donor support. Trump's online fundraising efforts follow his August fundraising total of US$90 million, which trailed Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton's US$143 million.

site_title: Job security fears hamper rebound in UK consumer confidence
summary: UK consumer confidence recovered slightly in September, rising to 111.1, but fears over job security due to Brexit talks next year may dampen confidence. Measures of job security and household finances decreased, while expectations of household finances and house values improved. The YouGov/Centre for Economics and Business Research Consumer Confidence Index is still lower than before the Brexit vote, with the lowest job security figures in 20 months. Brexit's impact on the economy will become clearer next year, potentially affecting consumer confidence.

site_title: Saudi oil minister signals he's open to Iran compromise at Opec
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Khalid Al-Falih, signaled openness to a compromise with Iran, potentially paving the way for a first limit on oil production in two years. Al-Falih said Iran, Libya, and Nigeria should produce at maximum levels that make sense, narrowing the gap between OPEC countries' production targets. However, a deal is unlikely until OPEC's next meeting in November, with significant hurdles remaining, including differing production targets between Saudi Arabia and Iran. The International Energy Agency predicts a worsening oil market if OPEC doesn't act.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower over strong yen
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on September 28, 2016, due to a strong yen, causing concerns about exports. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.10% and the Topix index fell 1.06%. This led to a loss of 184.31 points and 14.25 points, respectively.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.05 points to 1664.77. The market saw 29.7 million lots traded worth RM8.9 million, with 73 gainers outnumbering 37 losers.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says exports expected to resume decline
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Yoo Il Ho expects exports to decline again due to ongoing strikes in various industries, despite a slight increase in August. The strikes, including those at Hyundai Motor Co., have resulted in accumulative losses of nearly 2.5 trillion won. Minister Yoo criticized the striking workers, calling their actions "group selfishness" that will harm the public's perception of them. Preliminary export data for September will be released on October 1, and the minister's comments suggest a continued downward trend in exports.

images.alt_text: South Korea's finance minister said on Wednesday he expected exports to fall again, partly due to ongoing strikes in a number of industries.

site_title: Gold holds losses as US consumer confidence boosts US dollar
summary: Gold prices fell 0.8% to $1,326.61 an ounce, the largest decline in a month, after US consumer confidence rose to a nine-year high, boosting the US dollar. The metal's decline was attributed to investors seeking higher returns from interest-bearing assets. A stronger US dollar and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's rising odds of winning the presidency also contributed to the decline. Despite this, platinum gained and palladium fell. Traders expect the Federal Reserve to raise US interest rates by December, which could further curb gold's appeal.

images.alt_text: Gold held its losses after tumbling the most in a month as US consumer confidence rose to a nine-year high, boosting the US dollar.

site_title: 'Recycled Orchestra' turns garbage into gold
summary: A township in Paraguay, Cateura, is gaining international recognition for its "Recycled Orchestra," composed of impoverished children who play instruments made from discarded trash. The orchestra, led by Favio Chavez, was started 10 years ago and has since become a symbol of hope and unity for the community. Through music, the children have transcended their squalor and have gained a newfound respect for education and childhood. The orchestra has toured the world, playing for European royalty and Pope Francis, and has opened doors to opportunities for the community, inspiring others to work hard and strive for a brighter future.

images.alt_text: Orchestra members, impoverished children from Cateura, play violins fashioned from oven trays and guitars made from dessert dishes.

site_title: Australia dollar camps near 3-week peak, NZ dollar lags
summary: The Australian dollar strengthened to near three-week highs on Wednesday, holding at US$0.7671, driven by a surge in global risk sentiment following the US presidential debate. The currency has breached the 77 US cents chart resistance multiple times but has yet to sustain gains. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar struggled near one-month lows, falling 0.2% to US$0.7288. The Aussie's strength is attributed to its favorable status as a carry currency during periods of rising risk appetite, which has also driven gains against the euro and yen.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar steadied near three-week highs on Wednesday as a pick-up in global risk sentiment delivered a third day of gains, while its New Zealand cousin still struggled near one-month lows.

site_title: World Bank unanimously reappoints Jim Yong Kim as president
summary: The World Bank board unanimously reappointed Jim Yong Kim as president for a second term, despite criticism over the reappointment process. Kim was the only candidate, with the US dominating the selection process. The decision was seen as a victory for the US influence at the World Bank, a move that has been criticized by staff and campaigners for lacking transparency. Kim will serve a second term as president of the global lender.

site_title: StanChart tells authorities about corruption allegations at Indonesian firm
summary: Standard Chartered has informed authorities about alleged corruption at Indonesian firm MAXpower Group Pte Ltd, a power plant company majority-owned by its private equity arm. The allegations, reported by the Wall Street Journal, involve possible bribery and misconduct. This comes as the bank faces legal woes, including a deferred-prosecution agreement with the US Department of Justice over alleged Iranian sanctions breaches. The bank is also at risk of prosecution for committing another federal crime. The allegations compound the bank's existing legal issues.

site_title: Goldman Sachs' top South-east Asia investment banker to leave: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs' top South-east Asia investment banker, Michael Smith, is set to leave the bank later this year, according to sources. Smith, a partner and head of the Asian real estate investment banking team, has been with Goldman since 2006. He previously worked at UBS for about a decade. The exact date of his departure is not specified.

images.alt_text: The head of Goldman Sachs' investment banking division in South-east Asia, Michael Smith, is set to leave the bank, two people familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.

site_title: No official confirmation yet of winning Bandung tender: SMRT
summary: SMRT Corporation, a Singapore transport operator, has not received official confirmation of winning a tender to build a light-rail system in Bandung, Indonesia. Despite the mayor's Facebook post suggesting SMRT as the winning bidder, the company claims it has not been notified of any award. A consortium led by SMRT is awaiting a definitive agreement before making any announcements. The bid was submitted on September 9, and the outcome is contingent on the federal government's approval, which has not been issued yet.

site_title: Rowsley gets SGX nod to issue new shares for Ariva purchase
summary: Rowsley, a real-estate company, received approval from Singapore Exchange (SGX) to issue 53.3 million new shares at S$0.15 per consideration share to fund the acquisition of hotel manager Ariva. The final approval depends on disclosing earn-out details, a moratorium, and revealing financial effects on the unaudited financial results of the first half of 2016.

site_title: Taiwan: Markets closed on Wednesday due to typhoon
summary: Taiwan's financial markets were closed on Wednesday due to Typhoon Megi. Markets are expected to reopen on Thursday. This closure is unrelated to the recent market trends in other regions, such as Singapore, Asia, Europe, the US, and the global stock market, which have seen rallies and record highs despite uncertainty.

site_title: US to deploy anti-missile system in South Korea 'as soon as possible'
summary: The US plans to accelerate the deployment of the Thaad anti-missile system in South Korea due to North Korea's increasing missile tests. Assistant Secretary of State Daniel Russel stated that the deployment will be done "as soon as possible" and is not negotiable as part of new UN sanctions. The US is also discussing with international partners, including the European Union, to deny North Korea access to international banking infrastructure. China shares concerns about North Korea's nuclear program but opposes Thaad deployment, and the US and its allies are working to cut off North Korean revenue streams.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO seeks further cost cuts at global markets
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam is seeking further cost cuts at the global markets unit, targeting duplication reduction and better technology use. The unit has already seen significant cuts after $1 billion in unexpected writedowns this year. Thiam aims to boost profitability by focusing on Asia-led wealth management and expects the unit to post a third-quarter profit. The bank's shares fell 3% following the announcement, with analysts predicting a permanent restructuring of securities units among European banks.

site_title: Singapore shares open 5.46 points higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 5.46 points, or 0.19%, to 2,865.69 on Wednesday, driven by investors shifting focus from the US presidential debate to an oil producers' meeting. The market saw 38.3 million shares change hands, with gainers beating losers 63-51.

site_title: House prices lift UK consumers amid residual Brexit concerns
summary: UK consumer confidence is recovering from a post-Brexit referendum dip, driven by positive outlooks for property prices and household finances. A sentiment index by YouGov and the Centre for Economics and Business Research rose for a second month in September, but underlying measures were mixed. Job security concerns and fears about the longer-term impact of the Brexit vote remain, despite better-than-expected economic data. Officials have yet to formally begin negotiating the UK's exit from the EU, which may dampen sentiment.

site_title: Factory closures help lift Brazil beef industry margins
summary: Brazil's beef industry has seen a significant recovery in margins after dozens of meat processing plants closed, lifting prices and providing relief to the sector. Industry profits have improved, with beef hindquarter prices jumping 24% to 12.6 reais per kilo. Benchmark cattle prices have retreated due to reduced demand, but analysts expect a slight increase in consumer income and higher beef consumption over the next three months. This is expected to benefit the whole sector, with small- and medium-sized companies likely to benefit the most.

site_title: US senators accuse Yahoo of 'unacceptable' delay in hack discovery
summary: US senators have accused Yahoo of an "unacceptable" delay in discovering a 2014 hack that stole data from 500 million user accounts. The breach was disclosed by the company just last week, prompting lawmakers to express concern that millions of Americans' data may have been compromised for two years. The senators, led by Patrick Leahy, have demanded an explanation from Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer, calling the handling of the breach "unacceptable."

site_title: Investigators to report on 2014 downing of Malaysian airliner over Ukraine
summary: An international team of prosecutors investigating the 2014 downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 will report findings on Wednesday, but are unlikely to bring charges due to legal and political obstacles. The Boeing 777 was hit by a surface-to-air missile over eastern Ukraine, killing 298 people. Ukrainian and Western officials blame pro-Russian rebels, while Russia denies direct involvement. A civilian investigation concluded the airliner was downed by a Russian-made Buk missile, but prosecutors must conduct their own investigation for evidence to be used in court.

site_title: Elon Musk outlines plans to put humans on Mars
summary: Elon Musk announced SpaceX's plan to colonize Mars, aiming to transport 100 passengers and cargo per voyage. The goal is to make the trip cost equivalent to a US$200,000 house, significantly reducing the initial cost of $10 billion. Musk plans to send a massive Mars rocket capable of carrying large numbers of people and cargo, with the first human mission potentially landing on Mars as early as 2024. NASA also plans to send humans to Mars in the 2030s, with a focus on a public-private partnership.

site_title: US dollar slightly higher after Clinton bests Trump in debate
summary: The US dollar rose slightly after Hillary Clinton bested Donald Trump in the first presidential debate, with most analysts scoring Clinton as the winner. The dollar strengthened to US$1.1217 per euro and 100.36 yen, while the pound rose to US$1.3011. Trump's controversial remarks about trade and foreign policy have unsettled investors, but Clinton's performance alleviated concerns, leading to a relief rally in the dollar. The Mexican peso also jumped 2% after Trump's surge in the polls, which has led to relentless selling pressure.

site_title: US: Stocks lifted by consumer data, Clinton debate boost
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday following positive consumer confidence data and a strong performance by Hillary Clinton in the presidential debate. Consumer confidence jumped to 104.1, beating expectations, and boosted retailers such as Macy's and Best Buy. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty, with investors optimistic about the economy and Clinton's debate performance.

site_title: Chinese coal accident kills 18, traps 2: media
summary: At least 18 people were killed and two remain missing after a gas explosion occurred in a Chinese coal mine in the northwestern Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region. The incident, which occurred on Tuesday, also left 20 miners trapped underground. The mine, operated by Linli Coal Mining company, is the latest in a string of deadly accidents in China's coal mines. Despite officials claiming a significant decline in annual fatalities, some rights groups argue the true figures are higher due to under-reporting.

images.alt_text: At least 18 people were killed and two more missing after an explosion on Tuesday in a Chinese coal mine, state media reported, the latest disaster in the country's notoriously dangerous mines.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady as Deutsche Bank picks up from record lows
summary: European shares edged up 0.1% on Tuesday as Deutsche Bank rebounded from record lows, driven by hopes that US demand for a $14 billion settlement could be lowered. The STOXX 600 index was offset by weaker crude prices and gains in consumer stocks like Nestle. Deutsche Bank initially fell 3.4% before recovering, with investors concerned about potential funding needs for the mortgage case and other litigations.

site_title: Renault, Suzuki said to be among carmakers shortlisted by Proton
summary: Proton Holdings Bhd, a Malaysian automaker, has shortlisted several carmakers, including Volkswagen's Skoda unit, Suzuki Motor Corps, Renault SA, and Peugeot parent PSA Group, to sell a stake and raise money. The company plans to sell up to 51% of itself and has appointed Malayan Banking Bhd to advise on the sale. Proton is struggling due to accumulated debts and a slump in sales, and needs a foreign partner to help with research and development. The list is expected to be trimmed further by the end of October.

site_title: Wells Fargo launches investigation into retail banking sales practices
summary: Wells Fargo has launched an independent investigation into its retail banking sales practices amid a scandal over opening millions of unauthorized accounts to meet sales targets. The bank agreed to pay $190 million to settle charges and has fired 5,300 people. CEO John Stumpf will forfeit $41 million in equity awards and won't receive a salary during the investigation. Former retail banking head Carrie Tolstedt has also left the company, forfeiting $19 million in unvested equity awards. The bank plans to eliminate sales goals in its retail banking by January 2017.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co said on Tuesday that it had launched an independent investigation into the firm's retail banking sales practices.

site_title: Oil slumps as Iran-Saudi discord dims freeze prospects
summary: Iran has ruled out an imminent agreement with other major oil producers to freeze output, citing regional rivalry with Saudi Arabia as a hindrance. This move has led to a decline in oil prices, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling $1.26 to $44.67 per barrel. The price slump is attributed to a global supply glut, affecting the finances of oil-exporting nations. The discord between Iran and Saudi Arabia has hindered efforts to reverse the price slump, sending oil prices sliding further.

images.alt_text: Iranian Oil Minister Bijan Zanganeh said Tuesday on the eve of an informal Opec meeting in Algeria that the Islamic republic was not yet ready to join a mooted production freeze.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's Cryan refutes state aid report, capital increase: Bild
summary: Deutsche Bank chief executive John Cryan has denied a report that he asked German Chancellor Angela Merkel for support in settling a US$14 billion US demand related to mortgage-backed securities. Cryan stated that he never requested help and described the claim as "out of the question." He also ruled out a capital increase, saying the bank is "comfortably equipped with free liquidity" and has "fewer risks in the book than before." Cryan's comments come amid the bank's ongoing legal troubles, but he expressed confidence in meeting the challenges on its own.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank chief executive John Cryan on Wednesday personally refuted a report over the lender having sought the assistance of the German government in settling a US$14 billion US demand, which on Monday saw its shares drop to a record-low.

site_title: Nike turns in solid quarter after Olympics
summary: Nike reported solid revenue growth and beat analyst earnings forecasts for its fiscal first quarter, with revenues up 7.7% to $9.1 billion, and earnings per share at 73 cents. Despite a boost from the Olympics, Nike saw a slowdown in future orders and inventory data, leading to a 3% decline in shares. The company faces increased competition from Adidas and Under Armour, and a shift towards lifestyle and fashion in the sports market. Nike's top-line presence is challenged, with a battle for shelf space in the premium retail channel.

site_title: US government shutdown looms as Senate rejects funding bill
summary: The US Senate rejected a stopgap funding bill, falling short of the 60 votes needed to advance, which could lead to a government shutdown by the end of the week. The bill was rejected due to disagreements over funding for the Flint, Michigan water crisis and Louisiana emergency flood relief. Senate leaders are considering refiled bills without Louisiana aid, raising concerns about the delay in Flint funding. A government shutdown could impact the presidential election, with Republicans in control of both chambers.

site_title: Israel's Peres 'fighting for life' after stroke
summary: Israeli ex-president Shimon Peres, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, is "fighting for his life" after a stroke two weeks ago, according to a source close to the veteran statesman. Peres, 93, has been in intensive care since September 13 and has suffered permanent brain damage. Prominent visitors, including Interior Minister Aryeh Deri and opposition leader Isaac Herzog, have arrived at the hospital to pray and offer support. Peres's condition has been described as "very, very serious" and his doctors are worried about his health.

site_title: As Asians age faster, more of their savings may head offshore
summary: Asian emerging markets, including China, Thailand, and South Korea, will see their populations age faster than developed countries in the next two decades, according to Goldman Sachs. This demographic shift is expected to lead to a net $2 trillion exodus of capital from these countries over the next five years, with 70% of this amount coming from China. The outflow of savings is expected to weaken local currencies, soften financial conditions, and reduce the need for interest rate cuts, potentially exacerbating economic pressures in these countries.

images.alt_text: Asian emerging markets won't just need to worry about "taper tantrums" in future when it comes to the risk of capital outflows. And the hidden danger has nothing to do with the US Federal Reserve's appetite for monetary tightening.

site_title: Goldman says it can beat fintech ventures with online loan terms
summary: Goldman Sachs claims it can offer more competitive loan terms than fintech ventures by using its own deposits to fund loans, rather than relying on outside investors. This approach gives the firm more flexibility in product design and fees. As Goldman Sachs expands its consumer lending business, it aims to boost revenue and bolster its balance sheet. By leveraging its balance sheet, Goldman Sachs views this as a more sustainable and competitive approach to online lending.

site_title: Debt-rating firm bills clients for research
summary: France's Natixis SA, a debt-rating firm, has started charging clients for research, a novel but controversial approach. The company partnered with biotech firm Transgene SA to produce a bullish stock recommendation, disclosing the payment at the bottom of the report. This model is expected to become more prevalent as trading commissions to pay for research will be banned under EU rules in 2018. Industry experts see this as a way for mid-sized shops to pay for research without passing costs to clients, but raises concerns about conflicts of interest.

site_title: Investors bullish on junk bonds as Beijing clamps down on defaults
summary: China's clampdown on defaults has boosted investors' confidence in local junk bonds, with only two defaults this quarter, down from 10 in the second quarter. The average yield premium for AA-rated corporate securities has narrowed to a five-year low of 262 basis points. The government's involvement in preventing bond delinquencies has led to a stabilization of the market, with many analysts expecting continued support in the second half. However, some predict an "explosion" of credit risks in the fourth quarter due to large redemptions and potential government weakness.

site_title: Aviation sector to vote on climate change plan
summary: Civil aviation officials at the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) are set to vote on a proposal requiring airlines to buy credits to offset rising carbon emissions. The 191 member nations aim to reduce emissions while the number of air passengers doubles to six billion in the next 15 years. The head of ICAO, Olumuyiwa Benard Aliu, highlighted the challenge of balancing emissions reduction with growing air travel demand. The outcome of the vote is expected to have significant implications for the aviation sector's environmental impact.

site_title: StanChart refers allegations of impropriety at its Indonesian power unit to authorities
summary: Standard Chartered has referred allegations of impropriety at Indonesian power company MAXpower Group to the relevant authorities. The US Department of Justice is investigating whether the bank failed to stop alleged misconduct, and the allegations could add to StanChart's legal concerns. The bank is also awaiting a decision on whether it will remain under US supervision for several more years due to lapses in Iran-related anti-money laundering efforts. StanChart's head of financial markets unit Jonathan Paul has also quit after less than 18 months in the role.

site_title: Malaysia's banking system grapples with dollar squeeze
summary: Malaysia's banking system is facing a dollar squeeze, with three-month dollar borrowing rates reaching 1.44%, compared to 0.39% for Indian banks. This is due to expected monetary tightening and a seismic overhaul of the US$2.6 trillion money-market industry. The timing is worrisome, as Malaysia is investigating allegations of theft and laundering of billions of dollars from 1MDB, and its deposit growth has stalled. Higher funding costs may squeeze margins, and revenue growth could taper off in the second half.

images.alt_text: Malaysian banks' deposit growth has stalled, led by a 10% decline in foreign-currency deposits so far this year. Also, its three-month dollar borrowing is as expensive as 1.44 per cent.

site_title: Asia again emerges as primary global growth engine: ADB report
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) released its Asian Development Outlook report, stating that Asia is helping to stabilize global growth at low levels. The region's leading economies, such as China and India, continue to show steady growth, while major advanced economies like the US and Japan are experiencing easing growth. The ADB maintained its GDP growth forecasts for Asia at 5.7% for 2016 and 2017, while trimming its forecast for Japan and the euro area. The report also raised China's growth forecasts and expects South Asia to continue its rapid growth pace, with India's growth forecast at 7.4% for 2016 and 7.8% for 2017.

site_title: Trump-Clinton debate seen by record 84 million US TV viewers
summary: A record 84 million US TV viewers tuned in to the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, surpassing the 80.6 million record set in 1980 but falling short of predicted 100 million viewers. Fox News Channel had the largest cable audience with 11.4 million viewers, while NBC had the largest overall audience with 18.2 million. The debate, which was heavily promoted and drew high ad rates, was the first of three scheduled debates before the November 8 election.

images.alt_text: A record 84 million people tuned in to US television networks on Monday night for the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, a huge audience rarely seen on TV in the age of digital streaming and social media.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Land acquires a 25% stake in Quoc Loc Phat Joint Stock Company for S$25.6 million, increasing its effective stake to 45%. FJ Benjamin Holdings posts three consecutive years of losses, and Singtel issues US$500 million 10-year notes at 2.375% interest. Sing Holdings and Wee Hur Holdings emerge as top bidders for a land parcel in Sengkang, offering S$287.1 million.

site_title: Maersk targeting Hanjin and Hyundai in new acquisition strategy
summary: Maersk Line, the world's largest container shipping company, is targeting South Korean firms Hanjin Shipping and Hyundai Merchant Marine in a new acquisition strategy. Following Hanjin's bankruptcy filing and Hyundai's debt-restructuring program, Maersk is seen as the only rival with sufficient financial muscle to manage a takeover. Analysts predict that Maersk would acquire Hanjin's vessels, valued at $1.4 billion, to strengthen its position in the market, particularly in the Trans-Pacific trade, where it currently holds a relatively weak market share.

site_title: SIAS reiterates call for higher GMG offer
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) is urging Halcyon Agri Corp to raise its offer for GMG Global, citing valuation issues and an independent financial adviser's (IFA) finding that Halcyon's offer is unfair. The IFA found that Halcyon's offer is a lower multiple of GMG's net asset value and net tangible assets compared to Sinochem's rubber assets. SIAS is also calling for more disclosure on Halcyon's debt reduction plans and changes to its board.

site_title: Britain should look east post-Brexit
summary: Britain should focus on economic reforms outside the EU, particularly engaging with growing regions like Asia, after the UK's vote to leave. The EU's centralization efforts have distracted from needed reforms, and its major economies are shrinking. The UK can use Brexit to reposition its economy, leveraging its English language and colonial links to trade with India, the US, and other emerging markets. Australia's success with economic reform and engagement with regional economies serves as a model for the UK.

site_title: Shanghai bourse mulls tighter property bond sale rules: sources
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange is considering stricter rules for property developers to sell exchange-traded notes, limiting them to developers rated AA or higher. This move aims to increase transparency and reduce risk in the market. The exact details of the proposed rules have not been announced. The decision is part of ongoing efforts to regulate the property sector and maintain market stability.

site_title: Jeremy Monteiro to launch watch brand
summary: Singer-songwriter Jeremy Monteiro is launching his own watch brand, J. Monteiro Watches, in November featuring two models with black and white faces. Monteiro's passion for watches began at age 16 when his father gave him a Tissot watch. He has since developed an interest in timepieces, inspired by his friend Bruno Brugnano, a multi-talented individual. The watches feature a 21-jewel automatic movement and will be priced at S$750, with an early bird discount of S$608 for orders before Nov 16.

site_title: It's advantage Iran in oil price battle with Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia is offering a deal to boost oil prices, including its first output cut in eight years, amid the country's economic struggles. Iran, on the other hand, is resisting the deal, citing its own economic gains from sanctions being lifted. Saudi Arabia faces a 13.5% fiscal deficit, while Iran's is nearly balanced. The contrast in economic pain has led to Saudi Arabia's reversal, with the country seeking to raise oil prices to US$67 per barrel to stabilize its finances, while Iran seeks to return to pre-sanctions production levels.

site_title: Grocery delivery businesses find new backing
summary: FreshDirect, a US grocery delivery business, has raised $189 million, its largest funding round in 17 years. The influx of cash will aid expansion into new markets and business lines, as well as improve distribution capacity. Despite increased competition, FreshDirect remains profitable, having achieved scale and profitability since 2010. The company's growth has been steady, with revenue now exceeding $600 million annually. This move comes as rivals Instacart and AmazonFresh continue to expand their services.

site_title: PM Lee to launch Singapore's cyber security strategy
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will launch Singapore's new cyber security strategy at the Singapore International Cyber Week (SICW) starting October 10. The three-day event aims to bring together government, industry, and academia to discuss cyber security threats and develop new capabilities. SICW will build on the momentum of the 25-year-old GovernmentWare conference, featuring over 3,000 attendees and 200 sponsors. Cyber security threats are considered global and borderless, emphasizing the need for collaboration and coordination among governments and organizations.

site_title: Elaine Lam is OCBC's new head of global corporate banking
summary: OCBC Bank has appointed Elaine Lam Su Yen, 44, as its new head of global corporate banking, succeeding George Lee, who retired after 16 years with the bank. Lam, with over two decades of experience in corporate banking, joined OCBC 15 years ago and previously held roles including co-head of wholesale corporate marketing and head of wholesale corporate banking. Her appointment takes effect from April 2016.

site_title: Italy slashes growth forecasts
summary: Italy's centre-left government has revised its growth forecasts, slashing its predictions to 0.8% for this year and 1% for 2017. The downward revisions follow data showing the economy stagnated in the first half of the year. Prime Minister Matteo Renzi attributed the change to a "prudent" approach, citing fresh evidence of a stalled economy. The revisions follow previous forecasts of 1.2% and 1.4% for this year and next, respectively.

images.alt_text: Italy's centre-left government has reacted to fresh evidence of a stalling economy by slashing its growth forecasts for this year and next.

site_title: Thailand investigates four cases of suspected Zika-linked microcephaly
summary: Thailand is investigating four suspected cases of Zika-related microcephaly in three babies and a 36-week-old unborn baby. The cases are being thoroughly investigated due to the sensitivity of the matter, with lab results taking at least two days to confirm. If confirmed, it would be the first Zika-linked microcephaly cases in South-east Asia. The World Health Organization has previously linked Zika infections in pregnant women to microcephaly, a birth defect marked by small head size.

site_title: Mexican peso, Canadian $ up after US debate
summary: The Mexican peso rose 2% on Tuesday after a US presidential debate, with investors viewing Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton as a more stable choice than Republican candidate Donald Trump. This move lifted the Canadian dollar and higher-yielding currencies like the Australian and New Zealand dollars. The currency market's "risk-on" sentiment was attributed to the uncertainty surrounding Trump's presidency, with Clinton seen as a more likely status quo maintainer. The peso had touched record lows earlier in the day due to concerns over a potential Trump victory.

site_title: Options exchange CBOE to buy rival for US$3.2b
summary: CBOE Holdings is acquiring Bats Global Markets for $3.2 billion, expanding its presence in US and European stock trading. The deal gives CBOE a significant market share in ETF trading, with Bats handling about a quarter of US ETF trading volume. The combined company will provide marketplaces for both ETFs and ETF options, potentially giving CBOE a boost in challenging Intercontinental Exchange. The acquisition is expected to close in the first half of 2017 and will be based in Chicago.

site_title: US sanctions Chinese firm tied to North Korea's nuclear programme
summary: The US has sanctioned a Chinese firm, Dandong Hongxiang Industrial Development Co (DHID), for its alleged ties to North Korea's nuclear programme. The US Department of Justice has filed charges against DHID and four executives, accusing them of conspiring to evade sanctions and engaging in international money laundering. The firm is linked to North Korea's Korea Kwangson Banking Corp, which has been under US and UN sanctions. The US is seeking the forfeiture of $300 million in funds held in 25 bank accounts associated with DHID and its front companies.

site_title: For healthier European banks, turn off the dividend spigot
summary: European banks face significant capital shortfalls, totaling 123 billion euros, following the European Banking Authority's stress tests. Many banks have distributed 40 billion euros in dividends despite these shortfalls, potentially transferring wealth from taxpayers to private shareholders. Regulators are now considering forcing banks to stop paying dividends to address the issue, a move that could have prevented 50% of the 2016 capital shortfalls if implemented in 2010.

site_title: The myth behind 'winning' the debate
summary: The US presidential debate is often seen as a crucial moment in the campaign, but history suggests that it rarely determines the outcome. Despite initial impressions, no candidate's debate performance has been shown to swing the election in their favor. In fact, JFK's 1960 debate with Nixon may have been overhyped, with some historians attributing his win to electoral manipulation rather than debate performance. The 1980 debate between Reagan and Carter did not directly impact Reagan's victory, and Donald Trump's debate performance did not deter his Republican voters, who ultimately chose him as their nominee.

images.alt_text: A CNN/ORC poll found that 62 per cent of those who watched Monday's TV debate said Mrs Clinton did better, compared to 27 per cent for Mr Trump. Other polls had similar results.

site_title: Cogenra sues SolarCity for stealing technology secrets
summary: Cogenra Solarunit, a solar panel developer, has filed a lawsuit against SolarCity Corp, a rooftop solar developer controlled by Elon Musk, alleging that SolarCity misappropriated trade secrets and intellectual property. Cogenra claims it shared its shingling technology with Silevo Inc, which was later acquired by SolarCity, allowing them to set a new world record for solar panel energy efficiency. SolarCity denies the allegations, stating it independently developed its technology and that SunPower failed to respond to its claim of trade secret theft.

site_title: Bunkering sector aims to enforce high standards
summary: The 19th Singapore International Bunkering Conference and Exhibition (SIBCON) is set to take place next week, attracting 1,500 participants from 500 companies and 60 countries. The event comes as the bunkering sector faces challenges, including the Hanjin container shipping line's restructuring bid and OW Bunker bankruptcy. In response, the International Bunkering Industry Association (IBIA) is working to improve operating conditions for ethically run bunkering businesses and weed out fraudulent practices. The conference aims to address these issues and promote high standards in the industry.

site_title: Undervalued prime offices in Australian suburbs present investment opportunity
summary: A pricing arbitrage opportunity exists in Australia's prime metropolitan office market, where suburban offices are undervalued compared to prime central business district (CBD) offices. Despite strong demand and lower vacancies, metropolitan office assets yield 100-150 basis points lower cap rates than CBD offices, offering a potential investment opportunity. Experts expect cap rates to compress to less than 100 basis points over the next 12-18 months as more money piles into the metro office sector.

site_title: Malaysian ex-DPM expects opposition to form new alliance by year-end
summary: Malaysian opposition leaders expect to form a new alliance by year-end as more members of Prime Minister Najib Razak's ruling party defect. Sacked Deputy Prime Minister expects the pact to unseat Najib and remove the ruling coalition. The opposition aims to capitalize on the scandal-tainted Umno party, which remains firmly in power despite intense pressure for Najib to step down. The new alliance is seen as a significant challenge to Najib's authority, with the opposition seeking to remove him and his coalition from power.

site_title: China fails to cut steel production as mills restart on rally
summary: China's steel production has failed to meet its target of reducing capacity by 13% due to idle mills restarting after a price rally. Despite a February announcement, output has reached record levels, fueled by increased exports and tariffs imposed by the US, Europe, and India. This failure spells trouble for the industry, which suffered widespread losses in 2015. Uncompetitive "zombie enterprises" remain a drain on China's economy, and the government's inability to cut production capacity is likely to exacerbate the issue.

site_title: Asian export growth likely to pick up next year: WTO
summary: The World Trade Organisation (WTO) forecasts Asian export growth to pick up next year, with volumes expected to rise by 1.8-3.2% from 0.3% this year. The South and Central America region is projected to post the strongest export growth, while the volume of world merchandise trade is expected to grow just 1.7% this year. Trade growth is tipped to improve with gains of 1.8-3.1% next year, despite a downgrade from earlier forecasts. The WTO also notes that global trade may bounce back in the second half of the year, but risks remain, including financial volatility and growing anti-trade rhetoric.

site_title: Clinton debate win sparks US futures rally
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's likely win in the first debate with Republican rival Donald Trump sparked a rally in US futures, pushing the Dow up over 100 points initially. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 10.3 points higher, while regional indices such as the Hang Seng and Nikkei also rose. The Mexican peso and Canadian dollar rebounded in the currency market after a CNN poll showed 62% of viewers believed Clinton won. However, volume was below par, and some analysts expressed concerns about the sustainability of the market gains.

site_title: Fixed income 'no longer an asset class'
summary: Swiss private bank Lombard Odier is reassessing the role of fixed income in its portfolios due to negative-yielding bonds, limited liquidity, and increasing market risk. Chief investment strategist Salman Ahmed states that fixed income is no longer an asset class, as investors buying negative-yielding bonds lose money with certainty. To mitigate risks, the bank recommends trading less and constructing buy-and-hold bond portfolios with stop-loss triggers, and is investing in emerging markets, particularly India and China.

site_title: Chinese investors may make up a third of HK trades in 3 years
summary: Chinese investors may soon dominate Hong Kong's stock market, accounting for a third of trading turnover in three years and potentially up to 50% in five years, according to UBS and brokers. This shift could redefine how shares, especially small-caps, are traded and priced in Hong Kong. The influx of Chinese money is driven by the search for higher returns in a slowing economy, potentially displacing Western investors.

site_title: Philippine envoy's China trip shelved until 'proper time'
summary: A Philippine special envoy's trip to China to rebuild ties has been cancelled, with 88-year-old statesman Fidel Ramos still planning to visit Beijing "at the proper time". The trip was shelved due to clashes with President Rodrigo Duterte's schedule, as he is set to visit Vietnam. The visit was intended to address a landmark ruling by the Permanent Court of Arbitration invalidating China's claim to most of the South China Sea. The trip's cancellation follows a foreign policy shift under Duterte, who has rebuked Western nations and aligned with Russia.

site_title: Microsoft joins Adobe to compete with Amazon in cloud products
summary: Microsoft is partnering with Adobe to compete with Amazon in the cloud products market. Adobe will bring its creative marketing software programs, including Photoshop, to Microsoft's Azure cloud service, while Microsoft will make Adobe's programs the preferred choice for its Internet-based customer relationship management software. This partnership aims to boost sales of their cloud offerings and gives Microsoft an advantage over Amazon's Amazon Web Services. The move follows Microsoft's efforts to reorient its business around cloud and productivity services, with annualized revenue from commercial cloud products expected to reach $20 billion by fiscal 2018.

site_title: WTO cuts global trade forecast drastically
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has drastically cut its global trade forecast due to anti-globalisation rhetoric and the Brexit push, which is now the slowest pace since the 2008 financial crisis. The warning comes as talks on a free trade deal between the EU and US face opposition and Britain's EU exit continues to cause uncertainty. The WTO's reduced forecast reflects a decline in trade growth, which is expected to be affected by protectionist policies and economic instability.

images.alt_text: The WTO says that its downgrade follows a sharper-than-expected decline in merchandise trade volumes in the first quarter, and a smaller-than-expected rebound in the second quarter.

site_title: Jetstar Asia aims to strengthen freight business in Asia
summary: Jetstar Asia appoints ECS Group as its general sales agency for freight business at Changi Airport and 25 ports across its network. The budget carrier aims to grow its freight business as e-commerce continues to rise in the region. Cargo can be fed from markets such as China, Hong Kong, and Indonesia, and redistributed to other markets in Jetstar Asia's network. The airline expects demand for air freight to increase due to growing e-commerce and consumption in the Asia Pacific region. ECS Group will handle freight sales, reservations, and processes starting October 22.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Industries' marine earnings are expected to decline due to a low contract win rate, shifting the company's focus towards utilities earnings. Analysts value the non-marine business at 8.5 times its 2015 price-earnings ratio, a 20% discount from its long-term historical mean. The implied valuation suggests a buy recommendation for the company. Meanwhile, two new residential developments in Singapore showed strong interest, potentially signaling a stabilization in property prices.

site_title: Singapore population up 1.3% to 5.61m
summary: Singapore's population grew by 1.3% to reach 5.61 million in June, according to the National Population and Talent Division. The population comprises 3.41 million citizens, 520,000 permanent residents, and 1.67 million non-residents. This marks the highest number of citizen births in over a decade, with 33,725 births in 2015.

site_title: China state enterprise managers spooked by new liability rules
summary: Chinese state-owned enterprise managers are facing new liability rules that could lead to personal sanctions for life if they "fail to, or incorrectly, perform their duties" in M&A deals resulting in a loss of state assets. The rules, part of President Xi Jinping's overhaul of China's bloated SOEs, have prompted bankers and lawyers to say the clauses are draconian and are slowing deal-making. Managers are now reluctant to take decisions, with some spending weeks in meetings to get bosses to take responsibility, and are more likely to report public information rather than making value-added proposals.

images.alt_text: Business development managers at Chinese state-owned firms have been put on notice: mess up on merger- and-acquisition (M&A) deals and you can be held personally liable - for life.

site_title: Asia's poor choking on filthy air
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has declared polluted air a "public health emergency", stating that 9 out of 10 people globally breathe bad air, resulting in over six million deaths annually. Nearly 90% of air pollution-related deaths occur in low and middle-income countries, including Asia.

images.alt_text: A massive garbage site in New Delhi. The WHO warned that nearly 90-per cent of air pollution-related deaths occur in low and middle-income countries.

site_title: China takes aim at HK equity tricksters
summary: China's regulators are focusing on "Lo Tsin" firms in Hong Kong's equity market, referring to shady dealings by "tricksters" in the Cantonese dialect. Chinese investors are warned to avoid these stocks, which may be undervalued or tainted by dodgy financial operators. Hong Kong's approach to regulation differs from China's, with Hong Kong taking a hands-off approach and China's regulators scrutinizing companies before they go public. The city's benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 0.2% on the day, despite concerns over potential Lo Tsin stocks, with regulators working to strengthen market oversight and improve investor protection.

site_title: M&G Real Estate eyes more retail, logistics assets in Asia
summary: M&G Real Estate, the property investment arm of Prudential plc, is expanding its presence in Asia, focusing on retail and logistics assets. The company aims to have half its global assets under management (AUM) outside the UK by the long term. Currently, it has US$2.5 billion in AUM in Singapore, Hong Kong, South Korea, Japan, and Australia. M&G Real Estate is eyeing more opportunities in the region, driven by a growing wealthy middle class, urbanization, and rising demand for high-quality real estate.

site_title: Clinton digs in and prevails in first debate with Trump
summary: In the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, Clinton appeared to gain strength over Trump, bolstering her advantage on temperament and tolerance. Clinton effectively countered Trump's attacks, including his "racist lie" on President Obama's birth and his sexist remarks about women. Trump struggled to provide substance to his criticisms and often appeared thrown by Clinton's attacks. Despite his efforts to portray Clinton as a status quo figure, Trump failed to convince most Americans that he is the right alternative to a broken system.

site_title: ShareInvestor's Aussie tie-up to ride on synergy
summary: ShareInvestor, a Singaporean media firm, has partnered with Australian-based investor services firm Wholesale Investor to offer online investor relations services to at least 30 listed and private companies in Australia and New Zealand. The joint venture, WISI Australia, will provide access to South-east Asian investors and focus on client relations and business development. ShareInvestor will hold a 49% stake in the venture, offering its investor relations platform and technology to small and mid-cap firms in the region, aiming to increase visibility and provide more detailed information for investors.

site_title: Financial reporting better, but sticking points remain, says Acra
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) released its second Financial Reporting Surveillance Programme (FRSP) report, finding 21 cases of non-compliance with accounting standards and 19 areas for improvement among listed companies' financial statements. The report also noted that many companies were prompt in correcting errors, with 95% of non-compliances and 63% of areas for improvement rectified. However, issues persist, particularly with finance teams and directors' understanding of complex accounting matters. Acra plans to review its FRSP policies and processes to improve the enforcement of financial reporting standards.

site_title: Emerging markets rally as investors reckon Clinton clinched round one
summary: Emerging markets rallied after the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, with investors betting on Clinton's victory. The Mexican peso rebounded, while South Korea's won and South Africa's rand reversed declines. Turkish bonds rose, and Saudi Arabian stocks fell due to concerns over wage cuts. The MSCI Emerging Markets Currency Index climbed 0.3%, and the Mexican peso strengthened 1.7%, leading to gains in developing nations.

images.alt_text: Emerging-market stocks and currencies rose as investors bet Hillary Clinton won the first of three American presidential debates, outweighing concern a Donald Trump victory in November elections may plunge financial markets into turmoil.

site_title: LVMH's digital drive yet to show gains despite top Apple hire
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury goods group, has yet to see significant gains from its digital drive despite hiring former Apple music executive Ian Rogers almost a year ago to craft a digital strategy. Despite efforts to bring in more digitally-savvy people and participate in technology startup fairs, Rogers' impact on the company remains invisible.

site_title: Values, values on the wall: Who practises, who recalls?
summary: Wells Fargo has paid $185 million in fines for creating unauthorized deposit and credit card accounts, but no senior executives have resigned or returned personal windfalls from the fraud. Instead, former head of consumer banking Carrie Tolstedt was allowed to retire with $96.6 million in stock awards. The bank's "Vision and Values" statement emphasizes accountability, but its actions contradict this, with many employees fired for cheating on sales targets to meet unrealistic quotas. The lack of accountability raises questions about the bank's commitment to values and doing what's right for customers.

site_title: US consumer confidence hits post-recession high
summary: US consumer confidence reached a post-recession high of 104.1 in September, surpassing a forecast of 98. Consumers are more upbeat about short-term employment, but neutral about business conditions and income prospects. The index has risen 10 points in the past two months, driven by a decline in those saying business conditions are "bad" and a slight increase in those rating them "good." This marks the second consecutive upside surprise in the index.

site_title: S Korea cracks down on low-level graft
summary: South Korea has introduced a new anti-graft law, the "Improper Solicitation and Graft Act", which prohibits government employees, private school teachers, and journalists from accepting meals worth 30,000 won (S$37) or more, and gifts worth 50,000 won or higher. The law aims to curb low-level corruption, including bribery and favoritism, and has prompted some restaurateurs to introduce "graft-busting menus". Offenders may face jail sentences or fines of up to 30 million won. NGOs welcome the law, but critics express concerns about its potential targeting of private sector workers and the government's intentions.

site_title: Bums and cash set tongues wagging at Turner Prize
summary: The Turner Prize, a British art award, has unveiled its finalists for 2016, sparking debate and controversy. The four shortlisted artists, Anthea Hamilton, Helen Marten, Josephine Pryde, and Michael Dean, have created unique exhibitions at Tate Britain, featuring works such as a giant backside, chastity belts, and a mountain of money. The prize, now in its 32nd year, has a history of provoking controversy, with past winners including Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin. The winner will be announced on December 5.

site_title: China's August industrial profits up by 3-year high of 19.5%
summary: China's industrial profits rose 19.5% in August, the highest increase in three years, with steel and oil refining driving the jump. The growth is seen as a sign of economic stabilization, but some private forecasters believe it may be fleeting. The Asian Development Bank raised its growth forecast to 6.6% for this year, citing government stimulus and fiscal measures. However, some economists warn that the growth drivers are unsustainable and may lead to a decline in profits next month.

site_title: Five teams go on to next phase in Jurong Lake District RFP exercise
summary: Five teams have been shortlisted for the Jurong Lake District Request for Proposal (RFP) exercise, with Allies and Morrison, Grimshaw Architects, KCAP Architects & Planners, Mitsubishi Jisho Sekkei, and Nikken Sekkei leading the teams. The five teams will proceed to stage two of the exercise, developing and submitting conceptual master plans and proposals for Jurong Lake District by the end of 2016. The teams scored the highest for their track record and quality of proposal, and will now be assessed by an evaluation panel to select a consultant to be appointed by January 2017.

site_title: Keenly contested Fernvale site gets top bid of S$287.1m
summary: A state tender for a 1.7-hectare private housing site in Singapore's Sengkang area garnered 14 bids, with Sing Holdings-Wee Hur JV securing the top bid of S$287.1 million (S$517.03 per square foot per plot ratio). The bid surpassed market expectations, with analysts predicting five to 10 bids and top bids in the S$440-490 psf range. The project will feature 700 apartments and include amenities such as a 50-metre lap pool and a tennis court. The successful tenderer will also have to include a childcare facility and a public park.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang to be delisted in October
summary: Eu Yan Sang, a traditional Chinese medicine retailer, will request a trading suspension and delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on October 7, marking the end of its 16-year tenure on the main board. A consortium led by UOB-backed and Temasek Holdings made a privatisation bid for the company, offering S$0.60 cash for each share it does not own. The delisting is a result of the consortium's successful bid.

site_title: Aeon Credit Service stands out as finance stock
summary: Aeon Credit Service (M) stands out as a finance stock due to its resilient micro-financing business and healthy receivables growth, despite tepid economic activity and softer loan growth. Its receivables remain healthy, return on equity exceeds 20%, and asset quality is improving, making it better shielded from macroeconomic headwinds affecting the banking sector. Analysts consider it a viable alternative to banking stocks.

site_title: Role of China in global slowdown bigger than thought, says IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that China's economic slowdown is a significant factor in the prolonged global economic slowdown, with the country's share of global imports increasing from 3% in 2000 to 10% in 2015. China's transition to consumption-led growth has coincided with a decline in global trade growth, and its impact on global demand, prices, and exchange rates is substantial. The IMF warns that China's rebalancing has the potential to change the global economic outlook, but a well-managed transition could benefit the global economy in the long term.

site_title: Chances of achieving Europe's 'grand bargain' diminish
summary: The chances of achieving a "grand bargain" in Europe to relax fiscal policy and tighten the European Central Bank's monetary stance are diminishing due to increasing political constraints. The ECB faces a dilemma, as raising interest rates or ending easy money measures risks financial market turmoil, while continuing them may intensify support for anti-establishment parties and undermine the ECB's credibility. The upcoming electoral jousts in key euro economies and tensions following the British referendum vote further exacerbate the vulnerabilities, making a grand bargain increasingly unlikely.

site_title: Aldi will spend £300m to make over UK stores
summary: Aldi UK plans to spend £300m to revamp its stores, introducing a new format with more refrigerator space for fresh goods and emphasizing product quality. The investment aims to maintain a price advantage over competitors, as sales have grown 12% to £7.7 billion in 2015, but operating profit has fallen 1.8%. The retailer now has 13.9 million UK households shopping at its stores, with a record 6.2% share of Britain's grocery market. Aldi plans to open 70 new outlets next year, reaching 1,000 stores by 2022.

images.alt_text: Outlets will be given a new format aimed to emphasise product quality, and there will be more refrigerator space for fresh goods.

site_title: Junk-rated Saipan Island casino bond plan testing Asia's hunger for yields
summary: Imperial Pacific International Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong-listed company, plans to sell dollar bonds to fund its casino resort on Saipan Island, with yields expected to be attractive in Asia's junk bond market. The bond is rated B1, four steps below investment grade, and Imperial Pacific has a short track record and high execution risk. Despite a record low yield of 6.34% in September, Asian junk-rated dollar notes have declined 288 basis points this year, and investors are taking on increasing risk to secure yields.

site_title: Britain promises Brexit will not create legal vacuum at WTO
summary: Britain's trade minister, Liam Fox, assures the World Trade Organization that the country's departure from the European Union will not create a legal vacuum. Fox says Britain will uphold its commitments and pursue a more liberalized trade agenda in the future. His comments come as markets and trade diplomats await details on how Britain will manage its exit from the EU, with some fearing a "hard Brexit" scenario. Fox's appearance at the WTO conference is seen as a positive step, but the negotiations remain unclear.

site_title: Omni-channel the way to go for Singapore retailers
summary: Singapore retailers are urged to adopt omni-channel sales strategies to stay relevant, as the country's younger generation increasingly turns to online shopping. A recent survey found that 57% of Singaporeans have made online purchases in the past month, but e-commerce accounts for only 3% of local retail establishments' operating receipts. This disconnect is attributed to a significant portion of online buying being for international apparel, with other categories also contributing to the trend. To bridge this gap, retailers must adapt to changing consumer behavior and leverage online channels to drive sales.

site_title: SIAS urges Halcyon to raise offer for GMG, citing unfair valuations
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) is urging Halcyon Agri Corp to reconsider its offer for GMG Global, citing an unfair valuation. The offer, which expires on Oct 21, is valued at 0.875 times the GMG share price. SIAS questions the valuations used and advises Halcyon to raise its offer in the interest of all GMG shareholders.

site_title: Fate of Obama's pivot to the East policy hangs in the balance
summary: US President Barack Obama's "pivot to East Asia" foreign policy, aimed at shifting America's focus from Europe and the Middle East to the Pacific Rim, hangs in the balance. The policy, introduced in 2011, has shown success in reassuring China's neighbors and strengthening ties with traditional allies, but its overall goals remain unachieved due to ongoing instability in the Middle East and the US's focus on containing China. The uncertain fate of the policy is threatened by the upcoming presidential election, with both candidates opposing the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement, a key component of the strategy.

site_title: Perry Capital closing NY flagship fund after almost three decades
summary: Richard Perry, a prominent hedge fund manager, is closing his New York-based flagship fund after nearly three decades due to market headwinds and the changing industry landscape. The fund, which managed around $4 billion, has lost more than half its assets over the past year and has struggled to persuade investors of its value. Perry Capital's assets peaked at $15 billion in 2007, but its performance has declined significantly since 2014. The fund will return a substantial amount of client money next month, and the core team will remain in place to liquidate remaining assets.

images.alt_text: One of the biggest names in hedge funds, Mr Perry was also part of an elite group of proteges of Robert Rubin at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Mr Rubin later became US Treasury secretary in 1995, under the Clinton administration.

site_title: Takata, carmakers meet to divvy up responsibility for faulty air bag recall costs
summary: Takata Corp, a major air bag supplier, is meeting with carmakers such as Honda and Volkswagen to divvy up responsibility for paying billions of dollars in recall costs and potential legal liabilities stemming from faulty air bags. The talks come after five bids were made for the company, with carmakers reluctant to help pay Takata's legal bills but now willing to share the burden to avoid potential buyers dropping their bids or the company going bankrupt. The negotiations aim to resolve the largest safety recall in US history, with 90 million air bags to be replaced worldwide.

site_title: Cocoa production shifts to Latin America as Asia declines
summary: Latin America is poised to play a significant role in meeting rising demand for cocoa as Asia's production declines. Ecuador and Peru have led the expansion, now accounting for 16% of global production. The region's growth rate is 10% per year, and it could compensate for 1% of consumption growth. Asia's decline has led to an over-reliance on Africa, with Asia now a net importer of cocoa beans. This shift could alleviate pressure on the global cocoa sector, with Latin America potentially accounting for 20-25% of global production by 2026.

site_title: Apple to expand HealthKit from tracker to diagnosis tool
summary: Apple plans to expand HealthKit, its fitness tracking software, to include diagnosis tools that can analyze patient data, interpret results, and provide advice to doctors and users. The company is hiring healthcare specialists to build improved electronic health record software and is working on new apps for the Apple Watch, including sleep tracking and fitness level analysis. The goal is to improve diagnoses and address interoperability and analysis issues in the healthcare industry, a $8 trillion global market.

site_title: Singapore to step up fight against money laundering
summary: Singapore has vowed to step up its fight against money laundering, following a report by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) that highlighted the country's vulnerabilities as a sophisticated financial center. The government plans to strengthen its capabilities to identify and investigate complex transnational money laundering cases, and will develop more sophisticated data analytics to combat threats of tainted money. Singapore has also scored well in regulations, but has been criticized for not fully disclosing its efforts to combat money laundering, and will improve transparency behind beneficial owners of companies and lift standards in assessing money laundering and terrorism financing risks.

site_title: Changi passenger traffic down slightly in August
summary: Changi Airport passenger traffic decreased by 0.6% in August compared to the same month in 2015, marking the first decline since January 2022. This drop follows a 3.8% decrease in January last year.

site_title: US stocks rise on strong consumer confidence data
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by strong consumer confidence data, which jumped to 104.1 in September, the highest level since the recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all gained, with the Dow up 0.3%, the S&P 500 up 0.3%, and the Nasdaq up 0.5%. Gains were offset by declines in oil stocks, including Halliburton and Schlumberger, due to concerns over a potential output limit agreement in Algeria.

site_title: Malaysian ex-deputy PM expects opposition to form new alliance by year-end
summary: Malaysia's opposition is expected to form a new alliance by the end of the year as more members of Prime Minister Najib Razak's ruling party jump ship. The alliance aims to unseat Najib and remove the ruling coalition. Muhyiddin Yassin, a sacked deputy prime minister, expects opposition leaders to work together to avoid multi-cornered contests at the 2018 general election. The new alliance, led by former prime minister Mahathir Mohamad, will also target Najib's "tainted image" over the multi-billion-dollar scandal.

site_title: Thailand approves cash handouts, debt restructuring to aid farmers
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved measures to aid struggling farmers, including cash handouts of 6.54 billion baht (S$256.5 million) and debt restructuring of 335 billion baht. The cash distribution will benefit 2.85 million farmers, while the debt restructuring is expected to save over 20 billion baht in interest costs over the next five years. The government also approved infrastructure projects, including a 132-km railway and a 26.3-km Red Line in Bangkok. Economic growth is forecast to reach 3.2% this year, up from last year's growth of 2.8%.

site_title: Facebook told to stop taking data from German WhatsApp users
summary: Facebook has been ordered by Hamburg's privacy watchdog to stop processing data of German WhatsApp users, affecting around 35 million users. The order, made by Commissioner Johannes Caspar, requires Facebook to delete any existing data and obtain users' permission before connecting their WhatsApp account to Facebook. The move follows Facebook's plan to use WhatsApp data for targeted advertising, which has raised concerns over user privacy. The US Federal Trade Commission is also reviewing a complaint claiming Facebook's move violates US federal law.

site_title: IMF warns central banks could lose deflation fight
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that central banks worldwide are struggling to combat deflationary forces, with many countries battling disinflation due to weak global economic growth. If central banks fail to halt this trend, economies risk sinking into a deflationary spiral, where prices fall and spending and investment stall. The IMF urges governments to spend to boost demand and strengthen inflation expectations, as companies and people increasingly believe deflation is inevitable.

site_title: Uber launches global assault on food delivery market
summary: Uber is expanding its food delivery service, UberEats, into at least 22 new countries, targeting local rivals such as Takeaway.com and Delivery Hero. The move is part of Uber's broader ambition to dominate the global food delivery market, which is projected to grow to $93.4 billion by 2020. With a significant investment in staff recruitment and logistics, UberEats aims to cut delivery times to within a 30-minute window, undercutting competitors. Amazon's recent entry into the London market also adds pressure on existing players, with Uber's head of UberEats calling the market "winner-take-all" but noting that local players can still thrive.

site_title: German carmakers and technolgy firms form 5G telecoms association
summary: German carmakers Audi, BMW, and Daimler formed a 5G telecoms association with Ericsson, Huawei, Intel, Nokia, and Qualcomm to accelerate development of self-driving car infrastructure. The alliance aims to develop, test, and promote communications solutions for the "Internet of Things." The goal is to enable faster and more reliable mobile networks for widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles.
