site_title: Melting Greenland ice threatens to expose Cold War waste
summary: A US army base in Greenland, "Camp Century", could leak pollutants into the environment as the climate changes, threatening to expose Cold War waste. The base, built in 1959, contained a nuclear reactor and toxic chemicals that were left behind when it was abandoned in 1967. A study found that rising temperatures could result in toxic waste being released into the environment, with the US and Denmark potentially sharing responsibility for a clean-up operation. The logistics of decontaminating the site are complex, but experts believe it may have to wait until the camp has been uncovered by melting ice.

site_title: Malaysian banks brace for profit hits as O&G firms restructure debt
summary: Malaysian banks are bracing for a profit hit due to the restructuring of debt by oil and gas firms, which has been impacted by the slump in energy prices. The sector's volatility has led to increased provisions for sour loans, with Maybank reporting a 27% decline in second-quarter net profit. Despite this, analysts expect the impact on profits to be manageable, as banks' revenues have absorbed higher impairment costs. The sector's exposure to Malaysian banks is estimated at around 3-4% of total loans, with some US$10 billion in exposure overall.

site_title: Gold holds gains as US dollar drops after Fed dials back rate view
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,338.91 an ounce, its biggest weekly gain in two months, after the US dollar weakened following the Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates and scale back tightening plans. The Fed's revised outlook on lower rates in 2017 is seen as positive for gold. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index fell 0.1%, while the Bank of Japan shifted its stimulus focus to controlling interest rates. Gold is headed for its third quarterly gain, the longest rally since 2011.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.33% to 16,698.94, and the Topix index dropping 0.22% to 1,346.65. The decline was attributed to lower oil prices and drops on Wall Street last week.

site_title: Hyundai merchant surges after liner said to assess Hanjin assets
summary: Hyundai Merchant Marine Co surged 12% to 9,190 won after exploring Hanjin Shipping Co's assets for a possible acquisition. Financial institutions approached Hyundai Merchant for sale of its vessels, mostly container ships. The move aims to ease cargo disruptions caused by Hanjin's bankruptcy filing. Hyundai's stock trimmed its year-to-date decline to 70%, while Hanjin shares declined 8.4%. Analysts expect Hanjin's competitiveness to be impacted, leading to a potential shrinkage of its business scope.

site_title: Lotte says South Korea prosecutors requested arrest warrant for chairman
summary: South Korea's Lotte Group stated that prosecutors have requested an arrest warrant for its chairman, Shin Dong Bin, as part of a sweeping investigation into suspected embezzlement and breach of trust. This development comes as part of a broader criminal probe into the country's fifth-largest conglomerate.

site_title: Australia's SAI Global backs $760 mln Baring Asia private equity buyout
summary: Australian risk compliance services firm SAI Global is backing a $760 million takeover bid from Hong Kong-based Baring Asia Private Equity. The deal, valued at $1 billion, is a one-third premium to SAI's last closing share price. SAI's directors will vote unanimously in favor of the offer, recommending shareholders do the same. The deal is seen as a significant premium and represents a premium to SAI's share price. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of 2016, with no impact on SAI's operations.

site_title: Singapore shares open 3.52 points lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 3.52 points, or 0.12%, to 2,853.43 at opening on Monday. Investors are cautious ahead of oil talks and the first US presidential debate. Oil rebounded following its steepest slide in two months, while the US presidential debate may influence the election outcome. A Reuters/Ipsos poll found 20% of the electorate remains undecided, higher than at this stage in previous elections.

site_title: What to look out for at Paris fashion week
summary: Paris fashion week begins with significant changes at top brands, including Saint Laurent, Dior, and Lanvin, with new artistic directors Anthony Vaccarello and Bouchra Jarrar taking the reins. Vaccarello faces the challenge of reviving the Saint Laurent brand, while Jarrar, the first woman to lead Lanvin, is expected to showcase the label's pure, elegant lines. Italian designer Maria Grazia Chiuri makes her debut at Dior on Friday, marking the first time a woman has led the house.

site_title: China's runaway housing market poses latest challenge for yuan
summary: China's rapidly rising housing market is causing uncertainty for the yuan, with prices increasing 30% year-over-year in Tier 1 cities and 25% in US dollar terms. This could lead to capital outflows and downward pressure on the yuan, prompting investors to seek cheaper alternatives overseas. Analysts warn that policymakers may struggle to balance the need to control the market with the risk of a sharp correction, which could have far-reaching consequences for the economy and financial system. A real estate crash could also undermine investor confidence, making it a difficult task for the government to manage.

site_title: Rolling Stone to sell 49% stake to Singapore-based BandLab Technologies
summary: Rolling Stone magazine is selling a 49% stake to Singapore-based BandLab Technologies for an undisclosed sum. BandLab will focus on expanding Rolling Stone's business in new markets and managing live events and marketing. The deal comes as the magazine faces declining print advertising revenue, with a 14% decrease in ad pages between January and August. BandLab will not own any part of Wenner Media, the magazine's parent company, and will not be involved editorially.

site_title: Ley Choon seals debt-restructuring deal with lenders, to dispose unit for S$11.5m (Amended)
summary: Ley Choon Group has entered into a debt-restructuring agreement with its lenders, allowing it to sell its real-estate development subsidiary for about S$11.5 million. The deal provides a mechanism for repayment of project proceeds and other amounts owed to lenders. The group will repay the principal and interest according to a cash sweep mechanism, with a final repayment date of March 31, 2021. This move will enable Ley Choon to re-focus on business operations and improve profitability.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ley Choon, Tee Land, Otto Marine, First Reit, Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust
summary: Several Singaporean companies made announcements that may impact their counters. Ley Choon Group entered a debt-restructuring agreement, selling its real-estate development subsidiary to Tee Land for S$11.5 million. Otto Marine's creditors are seeking to wind up two subsidiaries and claim S$814,580. Meanwhile, the Singapore Stock Exchange rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: PM Lee to attend lunch hosted by Japan's Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will attend a lunch hosted by Japan's Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko during his four-day official visit to Tokyo. This marks the first time the royal couple has hosted Lee to lunch since a tea meeting in March 2007.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, who begins a four-day official visit to Tokyo on Monday (Sept 26), will be hosted to lunch on Tuesday by Japan's Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko, the Imperial Household Agency said in a statement.

site_title: Golf great Arnold Palmer dead at 87
summary: Arnold Palmer, a renowned golfer and ambassador of the sport, passed away at 87. The news was confirmed by the US Golf Association and golf media. Palmer's immense popularity drew a large following and helped propel golf during the television era. He is remembered as one of golf's greatest players, leaving a lasting impact on the sport.

site_title: New Zealand employee confidence rises in Q3: survey
summary: New Zealand's employee confidence increased to 110.1 in the third quarter, up from 101.5 in the previous quarter, according to a survey. A reading above 100 indicates more optimists than pessimists. This is the first time employee confidence has surpassed 100 since 2008. The Westpac-McDermott Miller employee confidence index has risen for two consecutive quarters, suggesting a potential improvement in the country's labor market.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip, US presidential debate awaited
summary: Asian shares fell on Monday, slipping 0.1% due to losses on Wall Street, as investors shifted focus to the US presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. The debate, set for early Tuesday, could determine the election outcome and impact global markets. Analysts expect a strong performance by Trump could boost safe-haven assets, while a Clinton victory could rally US equities. The dollar edged down against the yen, while US crude futures rose 1% after tumbling 4% on Friday.

site_title: Raised-fist Olympians punished in 1968 will be received at White House
summary: Tommie Smith and John Carlos, the 1968 Olympic athletes who protested racial inequality with a raised-fist gesture, will receive a moment of redemption at the White House. They will attend a US team event and meet President Barack Obama. The two were initially punished for their protest, but the US Olympic Committee has come to recognize their courage in making a statement for human rights. The gesture has become a symbol of the fight for racial equality and has inspired recent protests by African-American athletes.

site_title: US dollar wobbles vs yen and euro, US presidential debate awaited
summary: The US dollar wobbled against the yen and euro on Monday ahead of the first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump. The dollar fell 0.2% to 100.800 yen, its lowest since Thursday, as market focus shifted from monetary policy to political risk. The euro rose 0.1% to $1.1238, boosted by upbeat euro zone manufacturing data. A Trump victory could lead to a weaker dollar, particularly against the yen, while a stronger dollar was seen against the Australian and Canadian dollars.

images.alt_text: The US dollar wobbled against the yen and euro on early on Monday, cautiously held in a narrow range ahead of the impending first debate between US presidential candidates that could determine the currency's near-term direction.

site_title: SC Capital to raise US$1b in new fund for Asian properties
summary: SC Capital Partners, a private-equity real estate firm, plans to raise approximately US$1 billion in new funds to expand its Asian property portfolio. The funds will be raised from institutional investors in early 2017, targeting countries such as Japan and Australia. The company aims to capitalize on the low-yield environment and rising tourist arrivals in Japan and Thailand, with a focus on hotels, office buildings, and other properties. This new fund will complement SC Capital's existing portfolio of US$5 billion in assets, including hotels and office buildings in countries across the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Dodging ghosts of leaders past, Japan's Abe could stay on longer
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may extend his tenure, potentially becoming the longest-serving leader since World War II. Senior ruling party lawmakers are working to change party rules to allow Abe to stay in office until at least 2021, despite a lackluster economy and criticism of his policies. Abe's cabinet approval ratings remain high at 50-60%, with many voters supporting his agenda but awaiting economic improvement. A proposed rule change could see Abe stay on beyond 2020, with some polls suggesting a majority favoring the extension.

site_title: Wanda's Wang wants to overrun Disney in China theme park battle
summary: Billionaire Wang Jianlin's Wanda Group is expanding its theme park operations in China, aiming to surpass Walt Disney Co. by 2020. Wanda plans to build 15 multi-billion-dollar theme parks across China, including the 160-hectare Hefei Wanda City, which opened in September. The company has announced an additional 10 billion yuan investment in indoor entertainment facilities, bringing its total investment to 24 billion yuan. Wanda aims to become China's biggest theme-park operator, with a projected 20 million visitors per year.

images.alt_text: Mr Wang has laid out a plan to build 15 multi-billion-dollar theme parks across China by 2020, which he said would be a "pack of wolves" that defeats the one "tiger" of Shanghai Disneyland.

site_title: Saudis willing to act on 'critical' oil market, Algeria says
summary: Saudi Arabia has offered to cut its oil production to January levels, with Algeria's energy minister stating the move is an "interesting step" in addressing the "much more critical" oil market situation. The proposal comes as OPEC producers meet in Algiers to discuss potential production cuts, with Algeria seeking a 1 million-barrel-per-day reduction. Crude prices rebounded after tumbling 3.7% on Friday, and a deal is seen as crucial to stabilizing the market, with Brent crude futures rising to $46.26 a barrel.

site_title: Airlines embrace pollution plan that could cost them US$24b
summary: Airlines are backing a UN proposal to limit international flight pollution, which could cost the industry up to $24 billion annually. The 15-year agreement would require companies to offset their emissions growth by funding environmental initiatives, rather than cutting emissions. The deal has garnered support from 60 nations, including the US and China, and is seen as a critical step in addressing global warming. However, environmentalists have criticized the proposal for being too lenient and allowing companies to "green-wash" their efforts.

site_title: Petrobras to seek builders for six new platforms as of next year
summary: Brazil's state-run oil company Petrobras plans to seek bids for the construction of six new offshore oil platforms starting in 2017, with a budget of around $6 billion. The platforms are part of a larger investment plan, which includes 11 platforms already under construction and aims to ramp up production as part of a $74.1 billion capital spending plan. The company is open to using foreign builders if domestic companies are too expensive or too slow, prioritizing competitive local content that is viable in terms of prices and timelines.

site_title: Otto Marine's two Australian units face winding-up application
summary: Otto Marine's two Australian subsidiaries, Go Inshore Pty Ltd and Go Marine Group Pty Ltd, face a winding-up application by creditors seeking A$787,204. The applications will be heard by the Supreme Court of Western Australia on November 8. The management of Go Marine Group plans to dispute the debts, while Otto Marine's share price remains unchanged at S$0.315.

site_title: BOJ's new framework faces test as market to scrutinise bond operations
summary: The Bank of Japan's new policy framework, aiming to guide the 10-year Japanese Government Bond (JGB) yield around zero percent, faces its first test as market players scrutinize its bond buying operations. The BOJ will conduct its first bond buying operation under the new framework on Monday, with investors expecting the central bank to reduce its bond buying pace, potentially leading to a decline in JGB yields. The BOJ's comfort zone for yield fluctuations remains unclear, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Tudor said to close Singapore trading desk amid global job cuts
summary: Tudor Investment Corp, a US$11 billion hedge fund, has closed its Singapore trading desk as part of a global job cut, according to people familiar with the matter. The firm still employs staff in Singapore for quantitative research, and has dismissed 15% of its workforce since the global financial crisis. Tudor's main fund lost 3.2% this year, and the firm is accelerating its focus on quantitative research amid market volatility. This move comes as hedge funds struggle to navigate markets, with some incorporating units in Singapore this year.

site_title: Bridging the trust gap
summary: Business leaders and companies can rebuild trust by behaving with integrity, telling the truth, and being transparent in disclosures. Establishing a trusting relationship with stakeholders is crucial for success, and trust is built through consistent actions, not just words. To bridge the trust gap, companies must commit to a purpose in society beyond immediate profits, demonstrate integrity and accountability, and provide a 360-degree view of their information to consumers. Trust is engendered when there is alignment between values, words, and actions, and must be nurtured and maintained through good corporate governance and open communication.

site_title: Communist China looks for independent thinking as problems loom
summary: China is establishing independent think tanks to provide advice to policymakers, with President Xi Jinping's administration urging a greater role for research houses in policy making. The Dongguan Talent Institute, founded in 2013, has submitted reports to local officials on issues such as the robotics industry, and measures have been taken to attract top brains with cash payments. However, the influence of these think tanks is limited due to the Communist Party's control over society, and many are dependent on government funding, which may undermine their independence.

site_title: Shipping line Hanjin claims price gouging at US ports
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co, a South Korean shipping line, is facing allegations of price gouging at US ports due to its bankruptcy. Dockside servicers and transportation companies are demanding higher fees to unload and deliver cargo, resulting in a backlog of goods that could impact the holiday shopping season. Companies such as Wal-Mart Stores Inc and Eastman Chemical Co have filed notices to appear in the US bankruptcy case, and estimates suggest that shipping costs have almost doubled. Judge John Sherwood expressed concerns about "complaints of profiteering" but lacked authority to intervene.

site_title: Ausgrid gets bid from local consortium after Chinese, Hong Kong offers blocked
summary: Australia's top two pension funds, IFM Investors and AustralianSuper, have made a joint bid to buy a 50.4% stake in the country's largest electricity network, Ausgrid. The bid, valued at an undisclosed amount, was made after Chinese and Hong Kong interests were rejected due to national security concerns. The proposal, described as "all-Australian," would likely help politicians address concerns over foreign asset ownership. The government has formed a panel to assess the proposal, with a decision expected by the end of the year.

site_title: GM deal grants C$554m in investment: Canada Unifor union
summary: General Motors (GM) has agreed to invest C$554 million in its Canadian plants, with C$400 million allocated to the Oshawa and St. Catharines plants in Ontario. The investment, part of a tentative deal with the Canada Unifor union, will provide job security but less favorable pensions for new hires. The agreement, if ratified, will serve as a template for talks with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV and Ford Motor Co, which have contracts also up for negotiation. The ratification vote, with results pending, affects approximately 16,000 Unifor workers.

images.alt_text: The deal reached on Sept 19 between Canada's Unifor union and General Motors Co will see the auto maker invest C$554 million (S$572.2 million) in its local plants, the labour group said on Sunday ahead of a ratification vote on that agreement.

site_title: Digital map maker Here, automakers team up to share data on traffic conditions
summary: German digital map maker HERE will introduce live traffic services that allow drivers to view road conditions ahead using data from competing automakers, marking an industry first. BMW, Daimler, and Volkswagen will contribute data, with hundreds of thousands of vehicles set to feed visual data by 2017 and millions by 2018. The service aims to provide a comprehensive view of road conditions to aid human drivers and eventually autonomous cars, giving HERE a substantial lead over technology rivals.

images.alt_text: The Berlin-based company, owned by Germany's three premium automakers, will provide four services in which drivers share detailed video views of traffic jams or accidents, potential road hazards like fog or slippery streets, traffic signs including temporary speed limits and on-street parking.

site_title: Oil holds below US$45 as Saudi-Iran impasse dims supply deal hopes
summary: Oil prices dropped below $45 a barrel as a Saudi-Iran impasse on supply management dims hopes for a deal among major producers to stabilize the market. Saudi Arabia and Iran failed to reach an agreement after two days of talks in Vienna, with Saudi Arabia not anticipating a decision on supply at an upcoming OPEC meeting in Algiers. The lack of a deal raises concerns about oil market stability, leading to a 0.7% rise in futures despite a 4% decline on Friday.

images.alt_text: Oil traded below US$45 a barrel after the biggest drop in more than two months as an impasse between Saudi Arabia and Iran on managing supply dims the prospect of a deal this week among major producers to stabilise the market.

site_title: Looking beyond numbers is the way to go
summary: World Business Council for Sustainable Development (WBCSD) president and CEO Peter Bakker advocates for a redefined financial system that incorporates sustainability metrics. He believes that including sustainability metrics in accounting rules will help companies and investors compare environmental performance. WBCSD is working with foundations to change the financial system and is also launching a global standardised framework, the Natural Capital Protocol, to value natural resources. Bakker predicts that in 10 years, a company's performance will be evaluated not only financially but also environmentally and socially.

site_title: Samsung expands early-stage tech funds to 'leapfrog' rivals
summary: Samsung Electronics has opened a branch of its early-stage technology investment program in Tel Aviv, Israel, to tap into the country's innovative engineering. The program will invest US$1 million in individual companies with no limit on the number of beneficiaries or funding amount. This move follows Apple's acquisition of an AI startup, as Samsung seeks to innovate in areas such as artificial intelligence, cyber security, and virtual reality. The Tel Aviv division joins existing teams in California, New York, and South Korea, and is seen as part of Samsung's efforts to increase its innovation capabilities.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics opened a branch of its early-stage technology investment program in Tel Aviv to better tap into the innovative engineering for which Israel is known.

site_title: Young Prince George shuns high-five, low-five from Canada's Trudeau
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was rebuffed by 3-year-old Prince George during a meeting at Toronto's airport, with the toddler ignoring Trudeau's attempts at a high-five and handshake. This awkward moment has been shared widely on social media, with many Canadians feeling the snub. The incident occurred during a week-long official visit by Prince William, Kate Middleton, and Prince George to Canada.

site_title: Algeria urges Opec decision to stabilise oil price
summary: Algeria's energy minister, Noureddine Mr Boutarfa, urged Opec to make a decision to stabilize oil prices ahead of the Opec meeting in Algiers on Wednesday. The world's top oil producers face a production freeze to prevent prices from falling further, with prices currently at around $44.48 a barrel. Venezuela and Iraq support a production freeze to boost prices, but Iran's refusal to participate in a deal led to a failed attempt in April. Algeria hopes to bring together states with political differences to reach an agreement, calling the meeting a "first step" towards market stability.

site_title: Rebound in Ezra seen to be fleeting as oil industry woes deepen
summary: Singapore oil-service provider Ezra Holdings Ltd is experiencing a brief rebound, with its shares surging over 40% in September, driven by speculation of possible refinancing and covering short positions. However, analysts say the rally is short-lived due to deepening financial distress in the industry, with energy-service providers and rig-builders restructuring debt, posting losses, or idling facilities. The sector remains vulnerable to financial strain, with customers reducing spending or delaying projects, and oil prices expected to remain low, according to analysts.

site_title: Pressure is on Clinton, Trump in first debate
summary: The first presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump is set to take place, with the two candidates in a dead heat according to a new poll. Trump's campaign is trying to get inside Clinton's head, while Clinton's team is focusing on Trump's psychological profile. The debate, which will be watched by up to 90 million people, is seen as crucial in the election, with many analysts saying it can either win or lose a candidate the election. Clinton, 68, and Trump, 70, are tied at 41% among registered voters, with Libertarian Gary Johnson and Green Party candidate Jill Stein trailing behind.

site_title: Goldman romps past JPMorgan in Wall St battle of ETF newbies
summary: Goldman Sachs has secured a lead in the US$3 trillion global market for exchange-traded funds (ETFs), attracting $2.4 billion in assets since its quantitative strategy-driven ETF launch a year ago. JPMorgan Chase & Co, which started selling ETFs two years ago, has $800 million in assets. Analysts attribute Goldman's success to its low prices, reputation for financial sophistication, and ability to offer a compelling story to registered investment advisers. Despite lagging in performance, JPMorgan sees room for large players in the ETF market and is committed to expanding its business.

site_title: Divided UK Labour struggles with Brexit
summary: The UK Labour party struggles to present a Brexit vision, with many fearing a "hard Brexit" due to the lack of an alternative. Despite Jeremy Corbyn's leadership, Labour remains divided over access to the single market, with some MPs pushing for control over migration. The party's failure to set a strategy has led to concerns that they will be outmaneuvered by the Conservatives, who have yet to outline their plan for Brexit. Labour lawmakers are considering a referendum on a Brexit deal, but the party's internal divisions and Corbyn's ambivalence on the EU may hinder their ability to shape the debate.

site_title: A weaker currency is no longer the economic elixir it once was
summary: Weaker currencies are no longer an effective economic solution, as seen in Japan and the UK, where weaker currencies failed to boost growth and exports despite significant currency devaluations. Since the turn of the century, the impact of exchange-rate movements on trade and growth in major economies has declined by over half. Central banks' ability to weaken currencies is also waning, with the yen gaining 19% against the US dollar this year. Experts attribute this decline to structural changes in advanced-economy trade and the prolonged effects of the financial crisis, which have reduced the sensitivity of trade volumes to global exchange rates.

images.alt_text: A weaker currency, once the cure-all for ailing economies around the world, isn't the panacea it once was.

site_title: Hong Kong chief executive pledges more land for low-income housing
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying pledged to provide more land for low-income housing to address the city's affordability crisis. He stated that every piece of land should be utilized for building houses, prioritizing housing for Hong Kong residents. The government aims to increase housing supply, which will reach 93,000 apartments in the next three to four years, potentially reducing prices by HK$1 million per apartment. Leung emphasized the need to continue providing more land and building more apartments to solve Hong Kong's housing problem.

site_title: Optimism in Britain's finance industry hits financial crisis low
summary: Optimism in Britain's finance industry has hit a record low since the financial crisis, according to a CBI-PwC survey. Over half of financial firms surveyed said Brexit had a negative impact, with only one in ten seeing any upside. The industry is concerned about the risks to the wider economy and the potential loss of EU "passport" access. Several firms, including Lloyd's of London, are considering relocation or restructuring. The survey also showed a squeeze on profitability due to low interest rates and strong competition, with growth in business volumes expected to slow.

images.alt_text: Optimism about the outlook for Britain's financial services sector is at its lowest point since the financial crisis, a survey of finance firms showed on Monday.

site_title: For a driverless car, software update may remedy a recall
summary: A software update may remedy a car recall without requiring a visit to the dealership, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). The agency has released guidelines for carmakers to update software over-the-air, allowing for 100% recall of safety issues. Tesla has successfully implemented this method, updating its vehicles remotely to fix vulnerabilities and prevent accidents. Other companies, including Google, plan to follow suit, potentially revolutionizing the way car recalls are handled in the future.

site_title: Stocks look set for a strong September finish
summary: US stocks are poised for a strong finish in September, driven by the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan's recent monetary policy decisions. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose to 2,164 last week, just 1% from its all-time high. The central bank's "punch bowl" of liquidity could support record highs, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: 112 companies join initiative for excellence in governance
summary: 112 Singaporean companies have joined the initiative for excellence in corporate governance, committing to uphold and advance good governance standards. The Statement of Support, launched during the 7th Singapore Corporate Governance Week, aims to enhance shareholder value and promote a healthy financial market. Companies such as City Developments, YTL Starhill Global Reit Management, and SMRT Corporation have expressed their commitment to good governance, citing importance of transparency, accountability, and stakeholder trust.

site_title: New Zealand posts wider than expected deficit in August, weighed by milk powder exports
summary: New Zealand reported a wider-than-expected trade deficit in August, totaling NZ$1.26 billion, driven by a decline in milk powder exports to a seven-year low. Milk powder exports fell by half in value and quantity, while meat exports decreased by 26% compared to August 2015. Economists had forecast a monthly deficit of NZ$765.5 million and an annual deficit of NZ$2.7 billion. Despite this, dairy sector gains from rising milk powder prices are expected to bring relief to farmers.

site_title: Terry O'Connor courting omni-channel future for Courts
summary: Courts Asia, a retail giant, is making efforts to stay relevant in the shifting retail scene by adopting an omni-channel approach. The company is enhancing its online presence, offering competitive services, and differentiating itself from competitors. Courts aims to provide a seamless shopping experience across online and physical stores, with a focus on services and financial options. CEO Terry O'Connor believes that the company's long history and connection with local customers will help it maintain a strong presence, despite the rise of online shopping. Courts is also exploring ways to adapt to changes in the retail sector.

site_title: Cracks showing in Germany's fragile truce with ECB
summary: Germany's fragile truce with the European Central Bank (ECB) is showing cracks as conservative lawmakers, including Michael Stuebgen, plan to question ECB President Mario Draghi's policies, particularly the massive bond-buying program known as quantitative easing (QE). The program is set to expire in March and may be extended, sparking concerns among lawmakers about its impact on financial markets and German savers. The fragile truce was reached last spring after Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble criticized Draghi's policies, and its collapse could have significant implications for the eurozone and the ECB.

site_title: Independence vital to Valli amid haute couture success
summary: Roman designer Giambattista Valli's fledgling ready-to-wear line, Giamba, is thriving due to the spillover synergy from his haute couture operation, which has made him a celebrity favorite. Valli credits his success to his ability to create ideas and having multiple outlets to express them, rather than focusing on just one brand. He values independence and has rejected opportunities for a stock market listing or partnership with a luxury brand management company to maintain his creative freedom.

site_title: Tech to block texting while driving not deployed
summary: A 2013 Texas crash involving distracted driving has led to a lawsuit questioning whether Apple or other cellphone makers have a responsibility to prevent drivers from using their devices while driving. The lawsuit cites the fatal crash of Ashley Kubiak, who was texting while driving and killed a driver and a passenger. The court filings paint a picture of the growing incidence of distracted driving contributing to rising driving fatalities. The case raises concerns about the role of cellphone companies in preventing distracted driving.

site_title: Lippo eyes real estate investment fund listing in Indonesia
summary: Lippo Karawaci, Indonesia's largest real estate developer, plans to list a real estate investment fund (Reif) in the country, following the success of Reits in Singapore. The fund, DIRE Bowsprit Commercial and Infrastructure, will hold four office buildings and a distribution center, with a potential distribution yield of up to 9%. Lippo Karawaci aims to capitalize on Indonesia's tax-efficient Reif market, with the government reducing final tax from 5% to 0.5% for Reifs. However, other tax hurdles need to be addressed, including a capital gains tax and transfer tax, before the listing can proceed.

site_title: Opec unlikely to agree on production freeze
summary: Opec producers are unlikely to agree on a production freeze, despite early optimism, as disagreements over quotas and binding measures persist. The group may only agree on stabilizing the market after two years of surpluses, with analysts expecting a more cautious approach. Prices have plummeted from $100 to $30 per barrel, and the meeting, which includes Russia, aims to address the supply glut. Saudi Arabia is willing to cut production if Iran freezes its output, but old rivalries and differing economic situations may hinder progress.

images.alt_text: Members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries seem doomed to disagree on whether to freeze production to reverse a collapse in oil prices.

site_title: Chinese investments in US set to hit new high again this year
summary: Chinese investments in the US, particularly in California, are expected to reach new highs this year, with a potential increase of over 100% from last year's record $15 billion. This surge in investments is attributed to various sectors, including real estate, high-tech firms, and entertainment giants. The National Committee on US-China Relations and research firm Rhodium Group predict a significant increase in Chinese investments in the US, driven by growing economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Food with enough twists to keep your interest
summary: Serial restaurateur Beppe de Vito's latest venture, Braci, offers a unique dining experience on a rooftop space in Singapore with a stunning view of the city. The restaurant features Beppe's own creations with Italian foundations and influences from around the world. The menu is carefully curated, with dishes such as tuna millefeuille, Wagyu tongue, and simple fettucine tossed in a light vermouth sauce. While some dishes excel, others, like the dry-aged duck breast, fall short. Overall, Braci is a promising restaurant with a unique twist, worth visiting before Beppe's next venture.

images.alt_text: Mr De Vito and pork cheek roasted to a rich, golden coffee hue.
Gianduiotto with sticky chewy chocolate as the main event.
Tuna millefeuille featuring slices of lightly aged akami layered with a mixture of raw mushrooms and shredded truffle.
Duck breast dry-aged to self-tenderise before it's cooked in the Josper oven.

site_title: Elon Musk gazes towards Mars as earthbound businesses hit a snag
summary: Elon Musk is set to deliver a keynote address at the 67th International Astronautical Congress in Guadalajara, Mexico, on September 27, where he will discuss his goal of colonizing Mars. Musk's speech, titled "Making Humans a Multiplanetary Species," will focus on the technical challenges and potential architectures for establishing a human presence on the Red Planet. This comes as Musk's company, SpaceX, faces challenges, including a setback with a rocket launch in Florida and a controversy surrounding Tesla's proposed merger with SolarCity. Musk aims to send humans to Mars in the 2020s, with SpaceX planning to fly an unmanned spacecraft to Mars as early as 2018 and a human mission potentially following in 2025.

site_title: American history is also the story of black America, says Obama
summary: President Barack Obama opened the Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture, stating that American history is the story of black America. The museum, which chronicles centuries of black oppression and perseverance, aims to show context for current debates on equality and opportunity. Obama hopes the museum will help Americans understand each other's pain and anger, and promote dialogue and healing. The museum features 37,000 artefacts, including those related to the civil rights movement, slavery, and segregation.

site_title: Director sales lacking for second week
summary: Singapore stock market activity remains subdued, with no director sales recorded for the second consecutive week, according to filings on the Singapore Exchange. A total of 18 companies recorded 34 purchases worth S$2.66 million. Buyback activity also fell, with 14 companies posting 59 repurchases worth S$4.3 million. Notable trades include Global Palm Resources, TEE International, and Aztech Group, with some companies making significant purchases and others seeing increased holdings from executives.

site_title: The future of mobile devices
summary: Future mobile devices could become as thin and light as a sheet of paper due to the development of OLED technology, which could also enable flexible and bendable devices. OLED displays could be used for phones that are foldable or shapeless, and could also be used for augmented reality applications. However, the major obstacle preventing the development of flexible OLED devices is the availability of 5G networks. The market for these devices is expected to be massive, potentially cannibalizing the demand for smartphones, tablets, and PCs. The metal casing segment is also expected to be affected negatively by the new OLED technology.

site_title: Goldman axing nearly 30% of Asia investment banking jobs: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs is cutting nearly 30% of its 300 investment banking jobs in Asia outside Japan, primarily in Hong Kong, Singapore, and China, due to a slowdown in activity. The move, part of a larger cost-cutting plan, aims to save US$700 million a year. Investment banking revenue fell 11% to US$1.79 billion in the second quarter, with the total value of M&A deals in the Asia-Pacific region dropping to US$572.9 billion. This move follows other European banks scaling back operations in Asia.

site_title: Out with hunks: fashion breaks codes for male models
summary: The fashion industry is shifting away from traditional male models, favoring thinner, taller, and more androgynous models. Designers like Hedi Slimane and the Wilhelmina agency are promoting a more edgy, unique look, and the industry is seeing a rise in male models with diverse backgrounds. The lines between men and women are blurring, with some shows featuring clothing that can be worn by either sex. This shift is also boosting ethnic diversity and challenging traditional notions of masculinity.

site_title: 660 of 245,000 recalled Takata airbag inflators rupture in testing
summary: Takata airbag inflators, used in 245,000 cars, ruptured in 660 out of 245,000 recalled tests, posing a risk to drivers. The inflators' degradation over time, combined with materials and manufacturing issues, contributed to the ruptures. 15 deaths worldwide have been linked to the components. Takata is replacing 70 million inflators by 2019, with 660 ruptures reported in testing. The company faces billions in potential recall costs and is seeking a buyer, with KKR & Co and Daicel Corp among potential suitors.

images.alt_text: Testing has shown that the inflators degrade over time, so Takata has been repairing older cars first while replacement parts are being manufactured.

site_title: Uncertainty prevails as markets are hooked on easy money
summary: Global markets remain uncertain, despite central bank efforts to stimulate growth. Eight years after the 2008 financial crisis, markets have surged but face challenges from slow growth and increasing debt levels. The impact of central bankers' pronouncements and actions on markets has decreased, with price movements shrinking since Ben Bernanke's era. Key concerns include the US presidential election, Brexit negotiations, and the potential for higher interest rates, which could hurt equities and bond prices. Technical analysts warn of "double tops" and value investors see opportunities in emerging markets.

site_title: Corbyn victory leaves little resolved for UK Labour Party
summary: Jeremy Corbyn's re-election as UK Labour Party leader has left the party divided, with lawmakers and grassroots members disagreeing over internal processes and policies. Despite Corbyn's assurance that he can unite the party, a ComRes poll found 74% of people saying Labour is more divided now than ever. The party's annual conference in Liverpool has been overshadowed by debates about the shadow cabinet, parliamentary candidates, and Corbyn's leadership. The outcome has raised concerns about Corbyn's ability to win back ordinary voters and has left lawmakers seeking assurances that he won't replace them with activists closer to his views.

site_title: Snapchat introduces sunglasses that take videos
summary: Snapchat introduces sunglasses called Spectacles with integrated video cameras, allowing users to capture memories from their perspective. The sunglasses connect to the service wirelessly and can capture a day's worth of videos on a single charge. The company estimates it has over 100 million users and generates 10 billion video views per day. The Spectacles are priced at $130 per pair and are expected to be available soon, putting pressure on competitors like GoPro.

site_title: Indonesia steps up quest for infrastructure funds
summary: Indonesia is struggling to finance its $264 billion infrastructure development program from 2016 to 2020, with the government accounting for only 29% of the required capital expenditure. To address this, the country is encouraging foreign investment through deepening its capital markets and introducing new financial instruments like real estate investment trusts (Reits). The government has also implemented a tax amnesty program, but it has been deemed ineffective so far, with only 36.3 trillion rupiah collected from penalty payments and repatriated funds reaching 1,307 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Low rates make Robeco more cautious
summary: Dutch asset manager Robeco has become more cautious due to low interest rates encouraging companies to take on debt, while yield-chasing investors are borrowing to pursue returns. The firm has de-risked its bond portfolio, buying higher-quality companies and bonds due sooner, and avoiding leveraged companies. Opportunities for bonds are found in negative-yielding Europe, particularly in investment-grade and high-yield bonds of consumer-oriented companies. Robeco is also investing in subordinated debt and contingent convertible bonds of European banks and emerging-markets assets, such as Indonesia, India, and Mexico.

site_title: No possible explanation for 'unusual' share trading: SunMoon
summary: SunMoon Food Company stated it was unaware of any information not previously announced that may explain the surge in its shares to S$0.055, a 30.95% increase. The company cited four recent announcements, including the selection of a cloud-based ERP software, as potential triggers. SunMoon is exploring opportunities to increase its geographic presence and product range to maximize shareholder value, and is continuing ongoing negotiations with various parties on potential transactions.

site_title: Airline emissions plan backed by 60 nations: White House
summary: At least 60 nations, including major emitters Japan, South Korea, and the UAE, have agreed to join a voluntary phase of a United Nations program requiring international airlines to buy credits offsetting their pollution. The White House sees this as critical momentum for a proposed global climate pact governing the aviation industry. The agreement, set to be discussed at a Montreal conference, aims to penalize airlines for exceeding 2020 emissions levels starting in 2021. However, environmental groups have expressed concerns about voluntary participation, and some major emitters, such as Brazil and India, have indicated they will not participate until offsets become mandatory.

site_title: IMF, World Bank to debate 'low growth trap'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank will debate the "low growth trap" in Washington, focusing on the need for fiscal stimulus, particularly infrastructure spending, to overcome the limitations of monetary easing. The IMF and other development banks, such as the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, advocate for infrastructure spending to boost economic growth, while others, like the World Bank, emphasize its role in tackling poverty. A new approach, issuing infrastructure bonds to be subscribed by central banks, may be considered to inject monetary stimulus into economies.

site_title: GE credit rating cut by S&P on possible deal-related debt rise
summary: General Electric's credit rating was cut to AA- from AA+ by S&P Global Ratings due to concerns over potential debt increases to support future acquisitions. The rating reduction comes despite GE's stable outlook and undiminished industrial business strengths. The company plans to add up to $20 billion in debt to support expansion plans, which may push its debt-to-earnings ratio above 2 times, higher than S&P's expectations. GE is undergoing an overhaul, including selling non-core divisions, to focus on manufacturing heavy-duty machinery.

images.alt_text: General Electric's credit rating was cut by S&P Global Ratings on concern that the industrial giant may add debt to support future acquisitions.

site_title: Sake's overseas appeal grows as Japan market dries up
summary: Sake's popularity is growing overseas, with exports doubling to 18,180 kilolitres in the past decade, mainly to the US, China, South Korea, and Taiwan. Despite a shrinking domestic market, manufacturers are welcoming the increasing demand, with some restaurants in Hong Kong and Singapore featuring sake on their menus. The "Cool Japan" strategy has contributed to the growth, and the government is promoting sake globally. To boost sales, sommeliers are key, and certified sommeliers are being trained to explain sake to international markets, highlighting the drink's potential for further expansion abroad.

site_title: Room for improvement: Matchbox apartments in Paris
summary: In Paris, thousands of people, mostly migrants, live in tiny, often cramped rooms measuring less than nine square meters, commonly referred to as "chambres de bonne" or domestic helpers' sleeping quarters. Many face barriers, including lack of paperwork and guarantors, and are forced to pay exorbitant prices. Authorities have been slow to declare these spaces uninhabitable, with only 50 cases reported annually. Housing officials are working on a plan to reform these spaces, but many residents, like Ivan Lopez and Victoire Ratrimoson, remain without proper housing, struggling to find affordable alternatives.

site_title: 2013: Penny stocks collapse
summary: In 2013, Singapore's stock market experienced a crisis when Asiasons Capital, Blumont Group, and Liongold Corp's stocks plummeted, leading to a probe into possible market manipulation and the largest fraud investigation in Singapore's history. The episode also prompted policymakers to reform the regulatory regime, including introducing a minimum trading price requirement. The year was also marked by a contentious White Paper on Population, which sparked protests, and record haze levels due to Indonesian fires, straining relations between the two countries. The event depressed liquidity in the Singapore stock market and discouraged appetite for penny stocks.

site_title: US presidential debate expected to be rare draw in polarised age
summary: The US presidential debate between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump is expected to draw a massive audience of up to 100 million viewers, surpassing previous records. The debate, held at Hofstra University, will be broadcast live on various networks and streaming sites, including Facebook and Twitter. Viewers are expected to tune in not only for the debate itself but also for the instant analysis and commentary on social media. Despite the large audience, experts warn that viewers may return to their ideological silos, absorbing analysis from preferred news outlets. The debate's impact is unlikely to rival historic moments like the 1960 Kennedy-Reagan debate.

site_title: US-EU economic relations in for stormy weather
summary: US-EU economic relations are experiencing strain due to disagreements over taxation, trade, and subsidies. The recent controversy over Apple's taxes in Ireland and the US Justice Department's settlement with Deutsche Bank have heightened tensions. The US victory at the World Trade Organization over Airbus has also created a dispute over potential compensation. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership negotiations are faltering, with the US seeking to sign the agreement before the end of the year, while the Europeans consider this unrealistic. The uncertainty surrounding the US presidential elections and rising protectionist views in both countries are exacerbating the situation.

images.alt_text: With spats over Apple and Deutsche Bank and squabbles about Airbus and Boeing, approaching elections on both sides of the Atlantic are exacerbating strains in US-European economic relations.

site_title: Dutch speed trader eyes US ETF market
summary: Flow Traders, a Dutch speed trader, plans to expand into the US$20 trillion US exchange-traded funds (ETF) market, targeting the lower-traded corner of the market where bid and offer prices are wider. The firm, which is already the largest trader of European ETFs, aims to differentiate itself using pricing power and has received regulatory approval to trade directly with big US investors and companies. Flow's success in Europe and its unique approach to pricing may pose a threat to US market makers, but experts note that the US market is crowded and robust.

site_title: Next up: Nov's US presidential election
summary: The US Federal Reserve's reluctance to raise interest rates amid the November presidential election is a significant economic consideration. The Fed's "dot plot" suggests only two hikes next year, down from prior expectations of three. Economic data indicates a sluggish 4Q16, and labour market slack remains, making it difficult to justify a rate hike. External shocks, including the presidential election, are a concern, with market-implied probabilities of a December rate hike at 60%. Investors are cautious about the potential impact of a Donald Trump victory on the market.

images.alt_text: One constant theme throughout the past few years is that bad economic news is good for stocks because it means low interest rates and loose monetary policy should continue for longer.

site_title: The direct-to-consumer threat to retail middlemen
summary: The global apparel market, valued at $1.65 trillion, is shifting towards direct-to-consumer marketplaces, threatening traditional retail middlemen. Online retailers have grown in popularity, with 12.1% of the market now serviced by online retailers, up from 4.4% five years ago. Direct-to-consumer marketplaces allow consumers to buy directly from manufacturers, offering cheaper prices and a broader range of products. Manufacturers benefit from increased revenue and profit margins, while retailers lose market share and convenience. The combined apparel market of North America and Western Europe is estimated to be worth $700 billion annually, with 20-30% sourced from within or close to these markets, potentially creating a $200 billion annual revenue opportunity for direct-to-consumer marketplaces.

site_title: Goldman to cut Asian team by 30%: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs is cutting nearly 30% of its 300 investment banking jobs in Asia outside Japan, with most cuts likely in Hong Kong, Singapore, and China, due to a slowdown in activity in the region. The bank will be left with around 200 bankers, as investment banking revenue fell 11% to $1.79 billion in the second quarter. This move follows a broader trend of big banks scaling back operations in Asia, amid a lackluster environment for deals and competition from local banks.

site_title: North Korea air show thumbs nose at sanctions
summary: North Korea held a two-day air show, the Wonsan International Friendship Air Festival, despite international sanctions, weeks after conducting its fifth nuclear test. The festival featured civilian and military aircraft displays, including a US-made Hughes MD-500 helicopter and an early-model Soviet-built Mikoyan MiG-29 Fulcrum. The event showcased North Korea's aviation industry, which was targeted by UN Security Council provisions, but experts believe domestic fuel supply was adequate. The show was seen as a defiance of international pressure, with foreign observers praising the low passes and manoeuvres over the crowd line.

site_title: Thai police raid on suspected foreign forgery gang uncovers body in freezer
summary: Thai police raided a Bangkok compound on Friday, arresting three foreign members of a suspected passport forgery gang. A dismembered body of a foreign man with blonde hair was found in a freezer, leading to charges of attempted murder, document forgery, and concealing a dead body. The men, who spoke English, were using forged US and British passports. Authorities have struggled to combat the black market for fake identity documents, which has been linked to drug trafficking and Islamist militants. The three men will be charged and held at a local court.

site_title: Snapchat will release US$130 sunglasses with built-in camera
summary: Snapchat plans to release US$130 sunglasses with a built-in camera, called Spectacles, in limited distribution this fall. The wearable gadget allows users to record up to 10 seconds of video with a wide-angle lens, transmitted wirelessly to a smartphone. CEO Evan Spiegel has been testing a prototype since 2015, and the product represents Snapchat's first foray into consumer electronics. The release is expected to be showcased in New York next week.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat after Fed-inspired rally; Lundbeck slumps
summary: European shares retreated 0.7% on Friday, snapping a two-week high, after the Federal Reserve signaled a cautious approach to future rate hikes. The STOXX 600 index fell despite a 2.2% weekly gain, its best performance in two months. Banks, which had rallied earlier this month, led the decline, with Lundbeck slumping 15% after a failed Alzheimer's drug study and Aryzta surging 10% after a new board member was announced.

site_title: Fed rules seen speeding commodity trader exodus from banks
summary: The Federal Reserve's new rules to restrict bank commodity holdings are expected to accelerate the exodus of talent from banks to merchant trading firms. The proposed rules require banks to put up more capital, limit trading, and restrict ownership of power plants and copper. This move is seen as a boon for firms like Trafigura Group and Vitol SA, which are already luring employees away with better pay and less red tape. The rules aim to reduce financial risks posed by commodity trading, and are estimated to require about $4 billion in additional capital from firms like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.

site_title: Yale outdoes Harvard with 3.4% gain in investments
summary: Yale University reported a 3.4% investment gain, surpassing Harvard University and most US college endowments, which posted annual losses. Yale's endowment value declined less than 1% to $25.4 billion, with a 5.25% spending rate outpacing the fund's return. The university attributed its success to leveraged buyouts and venture capital, while Harvard blamed poor investments in stocks and natural resources. Yale's 10-year annualized return is 8.1%, with the strongest performance in venture capital at 15.9%.

site_title: Why gold thrives in a weak economy
summary: Gold prices have surged by over 30% since the start of 2016, driven by global economic uncertainty, including negative interest rates, Brexit, and the US presidential elections. As investors seek safety assets, gold is seen as a hedge against uncertainty. A potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike could strengthen the US dollar, causing gold prices to fall, but long-term investors may view this as an opportunity to buy gold at lower prices. Despite short-term market fluctuations, gold's long-term trend is expected to continue upward, driven by ongoing economic uncertainty.

site_title: 'He's a ghost'
summary: Tiger Woods has not played golf competitively since August 2015, citing ongoing back issues. He underwent a second microdiscectomy and a third procedure, leaving his golf career uncertain. Now 40, Woods has not regained his form, finishing four strokes behind winner Davis Love III at the 2015 Wyndham Championship. His status as a competitive golfer remains uncertain, with no updates on his recovery or potential return to the sport.

site_title: Strong 6.3 quake rattles southern Philippines: USGS
summary: A 6.3-magnitude earthquake struck off the southern Philippines early Saturday, causing no immediate damage or casualties. The quake, with a depth of 62km, was offshore and did not trigger a tsunami threat. Local authorities reported no reports of damage or casualties in Davao, a major city 100km from the epicenter. The USGS and Pacific Tsunami Warning Center confirmed there was no tsunami threat. The Philippines is prone to earthquakes due to its location along the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

site_title: Samsung phone emits smoke on Indian airline flight
summary: A Samsung Galaxy Note 2 phone on an IndiGo flight from Singapore to Chennai emitted smoke, sparking a fire, but the aircraft landed safely. The incident occurred in the overhead baggage compartment, and the crew used a fire extinguisher to put out the phone. Samsung has not confirmed if the device is a Note 2, but the company is investigating the incident. The Indian aviation regulator has issued an advisory to airlines to warn passengers about the risks of carrying Samsung Note smartphones on flights.

site_title: Saudis reportedly doubt oil output deal, and prices tumble
summary: Oil prices plummeted late Friday after reports that Saudi Arabia is unlikely to reach an output deal with other Opec producers, with Brent crude and WTI losing over 3% each. The market had been buoyed by earlier rumors of a Saudi-Iranian deal, but traders now doubt the possibility of a production freeze. Oil prices remain below $100 a barrel, with Libya and Nigeria struggling to increase production.

site_title: US State Department maintaining Iran property valued at US$50m
summary: The US State Department continues to manage and maintain Iranian properties valued at over $50 million, nearly 40 years after the diplomatic freeze between the two countries. The properties, including a compound in Washington and homes in Bethesda and San Francisco, were once used for diplomatic purposes but are now empty and being rented out at market rates. The State Department acts as a real estate service for the properties, adhering to guidelines from the 1961 Vienna Convention. Despite efforts to rent the properties, diplomatic relations between the US and Iran remain strained, making it unclear if Iran could sell the properties unless a diplomatic agreement is reached.

site_title: Three dead in Washington state mall, gunman on the run
summary: A gunman killed at least three people and wounded others in a shooting at Cascade Mall in Burlington, Washington, on Friday. The suspect, described as a Hispanic male wearing gray, was last seen walking toward Interstate 5 highway. Police received calls around 6:58pm that shots were fired, and the mall was evacuated. Multiple law enforcement agencies and sniffer dogs searched for the suspect, with survivors being transported to a nearby church. The motive behind the shooting is unknown, and police are actively searching for the suspect.

site_title: Twitter initiates talks with tech companies over sale
summary: Twitter has initiated talks with tech companies, including Google and Salesforce, to explore a potential sale. The company, struggling with stagnant user growth and losses, may receive a formal bid soon. A sale would be a slow-rolling auction, with Morningstar estimating Twitter could be bought for $22 per share. Salesforce, which licenses Twitter's "firehose" of tweets, has expressed interest in acquiring the platform, but its CEO has stated that Twitter is not a good fit for the company.

site_title: Brazil Supreme Court approves probe into allegations citing Temer
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court approved a preliminary investigation into allegations that President Michel Temer solicited campaign donations with illicit origin in 2012. Former Transpetro head Sergio Machado's plea bargain testimony alleges that Temer requested donations for his 2012 mayoral campaign. The probe also cites Senate President Renan Calheiros and others. Prosecutors will decide if charges will be pressed against Temer and other politicians. The investigation comes after months of political turmoil led to Temer's impeachment of former President Dilma Rousseff.

site_title: Meeting and measuring performance expectations
summary: Boards of directors are under pressure to improve company performance, which requires understanding stakeholder expectations. Traditionally, shareholder expectations were prioritized, but stakeholder theory suggests that customers, suppliers, employees, environment, and society are equally important. Shareholders expect timely dividends, medium-term share price increases, and long-term book value growth, while other stakeholders expect secure employment, steady income, skill development, and support for social development and environmental sustainability. To deliver performance, companies must continuously monitor and adapt to changing stakeholder expectations, as benchmarks and core competencies evolve.

site_title: Moody's cuts Turkey debt rating to 'junk' level
summary: Moody's cut Turkey's sovereign debt rating to 'Ba1' from 'Baa3', downgrading it to the speculative or "junk" level due to weakened finances amid increased political turmoil. The rating agency cited a fragile financial environment, rising external debt, and volatile investor perception as key factors. Moody's also expressed concerns about the government's response to the July coup attempt and the persistence of geopolitical threats, raising the chance of a balance of payments crisis. The downgrade affects Turkey's ability to borrow at favorable rates.

site_title: US Fed plans tighter rules on bank commodity activities
summary: The US Federal Reserve proposed new regulations to restrict banks' trading and investments in physical commodities, aiming to limit environmental and financial risks. The rules, open to a 90-day comment period, would cap the amount of physical commodities banks can invest in and re-classify copper as an industrial metal. Banks such as Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, which invest in extracting, transporting, and storing physical commodities, would face heightened capital requirements. The move follows concerns raised by regulators about the risks of commodities investment, as seen in the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

site_title: Massive hack is yet another blow for ailing Yahoo
summary: A massive hack in 2014 affecting 500 million Yahoo users worldwide has been disclosed, further eroding confidence in the struggling internet pioneer. The breach, likely perpetrated by a "state-sponsored actor," included sensitive information such as names, email addresses, and scrambled passwords. The disclosure is likely to impact a pending $4.8 billion deal with Verizon, potentially leading to a lower sale price and further damage to Yahoo's brand. Analysts say the hack is a "massive black eye" for Yahoo, and could accelerate subscriber losses and advertising revenue decline.

site_title: Indonesia struggling to tap volcano power
summary: Indonesia is struggling to tap into the potential of its volcanoes for renewable energy. High exploration costs and government commitment are major challenges facing the sector. A power plant on Java island, Wayang Windu, harnesses steam from an active volcano to generate electricity. The project is a rare example of Indonesia's efforts to utilize its geothermal resources, but it highlights the country's difficulties in developing its renewable energy capabilities.

images.alt_text: The Wayang Windu plant, which began producing electricity commercially 15 years after exploration first began at the site, illustrates some of the challenges in developing geothermal energy in Indonesia.

site_title: Separating good science from folklore in traditional Chinese medicine
summary: A digital revolution is poised to transform traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) by leveraging big data, analytics, and artificial intelligence. Currently, TCM practitioners rely on manual diagnosis and treatment, leading to inconsistencies and a lack of scientific proof for treatments. A smartphone diagnostic app and integrated wrist device could standardize diagnosis and treatment by analyzing patient data, identifying root causes, and recommending herbal remedies. This technology could help TCM practitioners work more closely with patients, improve treatment outcomes, and increase acceptance in modern medicine.

site_title: All about SunMoon and stars
summary: Team SunMoon won the title for the fourth time, capturing the social category. The team, known for their star-studded lineup, had previously won in 2012, 2013, and 2014.

site_title: Marriott's Starwood purchase makes largest hotel chain
summary: Marriott International completed its takeover of Starwood Hotels & Resorts, creating the world's largest hotel company with over 5,700 properties and 1.1 million rooms across 110 countries. The merged company will operate 30 leading brands and put Marriott ahead of competitors Hilton Worldwide and InterContinental Hotels Group. The deal is expected to generate annual savings of $250 million and allow Starwood brands to be grouped with Marriott's brands, including Ritz-Carlton and JW Marriott. The takeover was finalized after Anbang abandoned efforts to acquire Starwood.

site_title: Takata failed to report 2003 air bag rupture to NHTSA
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese air bag supplier, failed to report a 2003 air bag rupture in Switzerland to the US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), according to an internal report released by regulators. The company's US arm was largely responsible for designing and producing defective inflators, linked to at least 14 deaths and over 100 injuries. Takata has disclosed the incident, which occurred in 2003, after being questioned by a US engineer in 2010. The company has also agreed to a $200 million settlement with NHTSA and has been working to address production issues.

site_title: Canada review says Petronas plant would hit environment: sources
summary: A Canadian review of a proposed Petronas-led liquefied natural gas plant in British Columbia has found the project would have a significant environmental impact requiring major remedial measures. The review, conducted by the Canadian Environmental Assessment Agency, concludes the project needs significant work to mitigate its environmental effects. Environment Minister Catherine McKenna must now present the report to the full cabinet with her recommendation on whether to approve the $11 billion project, which has been opposed by local environmental and aboriginal groups. The decision is seen as a key test for the Liberal government's environmental policies.

site_title: Australia welcomes arrest of alleged key Indonesian people smuggler
summary: Australian Immigration Minister Peter Dutton welcomed the arrest of alleged key people smuggler Abraham Louhenapessy, known as Captain Bram, who targeted Australia since 1999. Louhenapessy was arrested in Indonesia for a failed attempt to send 65 Sri Lankan asylum seekers to Australia in 2015. He faces up to 10 years in prison. The arrest is seen as a significant step in stopping people smugglers, with Australia continuing to work with regional partners to bring smugglers to justice, despite criticism over its tough asylum seeker policy and detention camps.

images.alt_text: Indonesian police have arrested an alleged key people smuggler who has targeted Australia since 1999, the Australian government said on Saturday.

site_title: China's Li calls for 'win-win' cooperation with Canada
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang emphasized the importance of 'win-win' cooperation with Canada during his three-day visit, calling for strong relations between the two nations. A free-trade agreement was announced, with the goal of doubling trade by 2025, and a new era in Sino-Canadian relations is expected. Li's visit comes after a month of collaborative engagement, including Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's trip to Beijing, and marks a significant reboot in bilateral relations after a decade of cooling.

images.alt_text: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang called Friday for strong relations with Canada as he wrapped up a three-day visit to the important trading partner.

site_title: Tried & tested
summary: Weekend warriors have become a significant force in the fitness scene, with many taking up regular exercise routines. This shift is attributed to the increasing popularity of fitness among people. In other news, a low-profile property trust has ventured into data centers, while US weekly jobless claims have fallen unexpectedly. China has urged South-east Asian countries to support openness amid US tariffs, and Chinese property shares have surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Additionally, Reliance Jio has delayed its India IPO beyond this year.

site_title: Milan applause boosts Prada's revival hopes
summary: Milan Fashion Week boosted Prada's revival hopes with a warm reception to designer Miuccia Prada's latest womenswear collection. The spring-summer 2017 catwalk show was well-received, despite the brand's flagging fortunes in recent years. Prada has vowed that 2017 will be a year of e-commerce-led revival, with the latest collection offering a promising start to this goal.

site_title: Ireland eyes Asia amid disquiet over Brexit, Apple
summary: Ireland is expanding its financial sector to attract Asian firms amid uncertainty over London's post-Brexit status. The country's Minister of State for Financial Services, Eoghan Murphy, is on an Asian tour to promote Ireland as a gateway to Europe. Murphy aims to capitalize on the UK's exit from the EU by positioning Ireland as a cost-competitive alternative for financial firms. Despite the European Commission's ruling that Ireland gave Apple billions in tax benefits, Murphy insists the country's commitment to the EU remains unchanged and that it will appeal the decision vigorously.

site_title: Obama vetoes bill allowing 9/11 victims to sue Saudi Arabia
summary: President Barack Obama vetoed a bill allowing 9/11 families to sue Saudi Arabia, citing it would be "detrimental to US national interests." Despite Congress's unanimous passage, the White House failed to have the legislation revised. Obama's decision has sparked outrage among families of victims, with some, like Terry Strada, vowing to lobby for Congress to override the veto. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has pledged to sign the bill if elected, while Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton also supports it. The veto may lead to a rare congressional rebuke, with lawmakers potentially overriding Obama's decision.

site_title: China may allow more bond failures with credit-default swap trading
summary: China has approved rules governing credit-default swap (CDS) trading, potentially allowing more bond delinquencies as the economy slows. The move aims to diversify credit risks and facilitate market development. CDS provides insurance against bond failures, which may help investors mitigate risk and alleviate market sentiment. China has seen a surge in corporate bond defaults, but the non-payment rate remains low compared to other countries. The approval may allow more defaults to rise, as the number of firms failing to pay debts has increased since 2014.

site_title: S'pore driverless taxi trial expands with Grab
summary: Singapore's driverless taxi trial, launched last month, is expanding with a partnership between nuTonomy and ride-hailing app Grab. The trial, initially covering a 6km stretch in one-north, will now include a 12km course with an MRT station and more office buildings. Grab users can request a free ride in nuTonomy's driverless taxis, while the company aims to have 12 cars on trial by the end of the year. The partnership aims to better understand commuters' reactions to self-driving cars and enhance Grab's routing technology.

site_title: Driverless but not clueless
summary: Singapore's driverless taxi trial has expanded with Grab, marking a significant step forward for autonomous transportation. The trial, which began in 2015, aims to improve public transportation efficiency and safety. The partnership between Grab and Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) is part of the university's efforts to foster design skills in artificial intelligence. Other companies, including BT, Amazon Web Services, and BHP, have also established AI-focused innovation hubs in Singapore, highlighting the city-state's growing commitment to artificial intelligence and innovation.

site_title: The magnificent 7
summary: Apple's latest iPhone 7 and 7 Plus models boast faster processors, higher storage capacities, and a new solid-state Home button, but lack significant design upgrades. The iPhone 7 Plus features a dual camera system with a wide-angle and telephoto lens, but photo quality is only slightly improved over last year's models. The removal of the 3.5mm headphone jack has been met with criticism, but Apple has provided a Lightning to 3.5mm adapter. The iPhone 7 series marks a relatively minor update, with the company hinting at a more significant upgrade to come in the future.

site_title: US: Wall Street slumps on weak tech, energy shares
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.7% to 18,261.45, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index down 0.6% and 0.7%, respectively. Weakness in energy equities and technology giants Apple and Facebook led the decline, while Twitter surged 21.4% following reports of potential acquisitions. Analysts attributed the market's pullback to the Nasdaq's recent record-breaking performance, which was due for a correction after the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

site_title: US dollar, Japanese yen settle after bumpy week
summary: The US dollar and Japanese yen settled after a bumpy week driven by the Bank of Japan's and Federal Reserve's monetary policy signals. The dollar was slightly lower at US$1.1228 per euro, while the yen strengthened to 101.02 per dollar. The Fed signaled a potential rate hike in December, but its dovish outlook for the next two years kept the dollar from strengthening. The Bank of Japan's efforts to stimulate inflation kept the yen steady, with markets unconvinced about the long-term picture for inflation and interest rates.

site_title: How a US Open champion ranks the majors
summary: US Open champion shares their ranking of major golf tournaments. According to the article, each major is like a different character, with the Masters being about having the best day of your life. The US Open, on the other hand, is more about the physical challenge of the course, while the Open Championship is about the history and tradition of the game. The PGA Championship is seen as the most unpredictable, with a mix of physical and mental challenges. The champion's comments provide insight into the unique characteristics of each major tournament.

site_title: FARC ratifies Colombia peace deal, declares war over
summary: The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) ratified a historic peace deal with the Colombian government, marking the end of its 52-year war. The agreement, finalized on August 24, covers justice and reparations, land reform, disarmament, and the FARC's relaunch as a political party. The group's leaders, including Ivan Marquez and Rodrigo Londono, will sign the accord on Monday, and Colombians will vote on it on October 2. The FARC, responsible for 260,000 deaths and 6.9 million displaced people, has an estimated 7,500 fighters, and plans to announce details on its new life as a political party.

site_title: China state sector reform loses its way
summary: China's state sector reform, aimed at restructuring underperforming state-owned enterprises (SOEs), has stalled four years after Xi Jinping's leadership. Despite initial plans to give the market a bigger role, reforms have advanced slowly due to vested interests and redistribution of wealth.
