The Professional Conversion Programme will allow mid-career professionals to upgrade their skills in sales, project management, and administration, with 2,100 vacancies available. The Skills Framework for Hotel and Accommodation Services will serve as a guide for individuals, employers, and training providers to identify key skills and competencies. The initiatives were launched by the Workforce Development Agency at Hotel Day.

site_title: Harvard endowment's 2% loss magnifies decade of struggle
summary: Harvard University's endowment reported a 2% annual investment loss, shrinking by $1.9 billion to $35.7 billion, its worst performance since the financial crisis. The loss, primarily due to poor stock picks and natural-resource holdings in South America, has damaged the university's long-term record, which once led the endowment world. Harvard's endowment chief left in July, and the board is searching for a new leader, with two finalists, NP 'Narv' Narvekar and Amy Falls, being considered.

site_title: Facebook says it gave advertisers inflated video view metrics
summary: Facebook admitted to inflating video view metrics, only counting a video as "viewed" if it's seen for more than three seconds. This inflated metric may have boosted marketer spending on video ads. The error was fixed, and the company notified its partners, but big advertisers were upset and requested more details. Facebook's stock fell 1.5% in extended trading after the report. The company has since renamed the metric to make it clearer what it measures.

site_title: Gold sparkles as central bank largesse burnishes investor demand
summary: Gold prices rose 2% this week, the largest weekly advance since July 29, as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged and scaled back tightening plans. The metal is headed for its third quarterly gain, the longest rally since 2011, amid efforts by top central banks to bolster growth. The US dollar fell, and investors boosted holdings in bullion-backed exchange-traded funds, driving demand for gold as a store of value. The Bank of Japan's stimulus efforts also fueled bets on European policy makers keeping their easing stance.

site_title: Third night of protests in US city amid heavy security
summary: Protesters gathered in Charlotte, North Carolina for a third night, despite heavy security, amid outrage over the fatal police shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, a 43-year-old African American man. The shooting, which occurred on Tuesday, has fueled protests across the US, with conflicting versions of the incident and the refusal to release police video fueling the unrest. The city's governor has declared a state of emergency, and National Guard troops have been deployed to reinforce local police. A protester was shot by a civilian on Wednesday and died in hospital on Thursday.

site_title: UK may not need two years to get EU divorce deal: minister
summary: Britain may invoke EU Article 50 early next year, potentially avoiding a two-year divorce process. Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said the country is already discussing future ties with EU members, but some officials question the readiness of the government to form a clear negotiating stance. Johnson aims to set out parameters for Britain's exit in the early part of next year, but some lawmakers fear a poor deal if proceedings are triggered too early.

site_title: Obama's Vietnam noodle visit sparks feeding frenzy
summary: US President Barack Obama visited a Hanoi restaurant, Bun Cha Huong Lien, four months ago, where he enjoyed a bowl of the city's signature pork noodles. The restaurant, now dubbed "Obama bun cha," has seen a significant surge in customers, with the owner introducing a US$4 "Combo Obama" lunch special. The visit was featured on Anthony Bourdain's CNN show "Parts Unknown," and Obama praised the local fare, saying it was "killer" and "outstanding." The restaurant's popularity is expected to continue, with the number of customers doubling since Obama's visit.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.32% to 23,836.60, following a rally in New York and Europe after the Federal Reserve's decision not to hike interest rates. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, while Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks continue 6-day rally on BOJ and Fed, won edges down
summary: South Korean stocks continued their 6-day rally, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) up 0.1% at 2,052.03 points. The rally was attributed to decisions from the BOJ and Fed, which were seen as benefiting market liquidity. The won edged down 0.2% against the US dollar. Advancers outnumbered decliners 434 to 350, with shares of Hanjin Shipping and Hyundai Motor Co rising 5% and 2.5%, respectively. The rally is expected to mark a sixth straight gaining session, with gains poised for the week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 5.91 points to 1663.85. The index saw 44.4 million lots traded worth RM23.5 million, with 79 gainers and 57 losers.

site_title: China's yuan slightly weaker, SDR inclusion in focus
summary: China's yuan slightly weakened to around 6.67 per US dollar, but held steady ahead of its inclusion into the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket on October 1. Market sentiment remains mixed about the impact of the yuan's inclusion. The SDR inclusion is seen as a milestone for China's currency, increasing its global recognition and potential influence in international trade and finance.

site_title: US dollar on track for weekly losses in wake of Fed, BOJ
summary: The US dollar is on track to end a week of losses after the Federal Reserve trimmed its interest rate expectations and the Bank of Japan rebooted its monetary policy framework. The US dollar gained 0.3% against the yen but is poised to shed 1.1% for the week. The Bank of Japan shifted its focus to targeting interest rates on Japanese government bonds, while the US Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged but projected a less aggressive rise in interest rates next year.

site_title: Japan PM raises North Korea nuclear programme with former Cuba leader
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called for a unified international response to North Korea's nuclear program in talks with former Cuban leader Fidel Castro. During a 70-minute meeting, Castro expressed the need for peaceful dialogue to resolve the issue. Abe emphasized the urgency of addressing the threat posed by North Korea's nuclear program, stating it was "substantially more serious" than in the past. The two leaders also discussed trade, investment, and strengthening tourism exchange between Japan and Cuba.

site_title: Wells Fargo's Stumpf quits Fed council amid lawmaker pressure
summary: Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf resigned from the Federal Reserve's Federal Advisory Council amid pressure from US lawmakers following revelations of 2 million allegedly bogus client accounts. Stumpf had served on the council since 2015, but lawmakers, including Senator Elizabeth Warren, called for him to resign and face a criminal investigation. Wells Fargo agreed to pay $185 million in fines to resolve claims stemming from the scandal. Stumpf cited his focus on leading Wells Fargo as the reason for his resignation, but it appears the pressure from lawmakers was a significant factor.

site_title: Billionaire Wang's Wanda agrees to invest in Sony Movies
summary: Billionaire Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group Co has agreed to invest in movie projects with Sony Pictures as part of an open-ended partnership. Wanda will highlight China elements in its investments, marking its expansion in Hollywood. This deal follows Wanda's acquisition of Legendary Entertainment for $3.5 billion and its US cinema expansion. The partnership is seen as strengthening Wanda's influence in the global film industry and gaining greater access to China's restricted movie market, where Wanda operates the largest movie theater chain.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group Co agreed to collaborate on movie projects with Sony Corp's film unit as the Chinese tycoon builds on his ambitions to expand in Hollywood.

site_title: Grab, nuTonomy to partner to expand driverless-taxi trial to more users, areas
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing app, partners with nuTonomy to expand its driverless-taxi trial in Singapore, allowing selected users to reserve a free ride in a nuTonomy driverless taxi. The trial will take place in a larger area, including adjacent neighborhoods, with a nuTonomy safety driver and support engineer on board. This partnership aims to meet Singaporean commuters' demand for underserved areas and enhance Grab's routing technology and mapping for self-driving cars. The trial began on Friday, with plans to introduce a fully commercial self-driving taxi fleet by 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Friday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipping 0.28% to 16,759.84, due to a strengthening yen against the US dollar following the Fed's decision to keep interest rates low. Financial markets were closed on Thursday for a national holiday.

site_title: Twitter gets analyst downgrade thanks to record discontent among advertisers
summary: Twitter's stock price tumbled after RBC Capital Markets Analyst Mark Mahaney downgraded the company's shares to 'underperform' due to record discontent among advertisers. A proprietary survey found that 30% of marketing departments plan to decrease ad spending on Twitter, while only 3% saw an improvement in return on investment. This marks a company-specific issue, with online channels becoming increasingly important. Despite this, Mahaney believes Twitter is a "unique asset" with a strong value proposition to core users.

images.alt_text: Advertisers just aren't that into Twitter Inc. That's the conclusion of RBC Capital Markets Analyst Mark Mahaney, who downgraded shares of the micro-blogging social media network to 'underperform' and lowered his price target to US$14 from US$

site_title: Airbnb raises US$555m to grow globally
summary: Airbnb has raised $555 million in a funding round that values the company at $30 billion, making it the most valuable Silicon Valley startup behind Uber. The funding, led by Google and Technology Crossover Ventures, will be used to fuel growth and international expansion. This marks a significant increase from its $25.5 billion valuation in 2015. Airbnb aims to begin showing a profit this fiscal year, following its growth plans.

site_title: Europe: Shares buoyed by miners as Fed keeps rates unchanged
summary: European shares rose to a two-week high, boosted by a rally in mining stocks, after the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged and signaled a less aggressive path for hikes next year and in 2018. The Fed Chair Janet Yellen stated that the US economy is looking stronger and rate increases may be needed to keep inflation in check. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1.6% to its highest closing level since September 9, with mining stocks leading the gains.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.8 points higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.8 points to 2,847.86 on Friday, boosted by US stocks and crude oil price gains. The uncertainty over interest rates from the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan was alleviated, with the Fed leaving short-term interest rates unchanged and the BOJ reaffirming its commitment to monetary easing. The rally follows a 5-day streak for Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data release.

images.alt_text: Shares in the local bourse opened higher on Friday, with the key Straits Times Index rising 1.8 points to 2,847.86.

site_title: CapitaLand buys prime site in Ho Chi Minh City for US$51.9m
summary: CapitaLand acquired a 0.5-hectare site in Ho Chi Minh City for US$51.9 million, with plans to develop a 200-unit serviced residence and a 102-unit residential tower. The project, valued at US$106 million when completed by 2018, will be CapitaLand's ninth residential project and 19th serviced residence in Vietnam. This acquisition brings CapitaLand's total asset size in Vietnam to S$748 million, making it the group's third largest market in South-east Asia. The project is expected to be launched in the fourth quarter of 2016.

site_title: Yahoo hack hit 500m users, likely 'state sponsored'
summary: Yahoo confirmed a massive 2014 hack allowed hackers to steal data from 500 million users, likely state-sponsored. The breach included names, email addresses, birth dates, scrambled passwords, and security questions. Yahoo stated the stolen information may have included encrypted or unencrypted data that could help hackers break into victims' other accounts. The company is urging affected users to change passwords and recommending a precautionary measure for those who haven't changed since 2014. The breach comes two months after Yahoo sold its core internet business to Verizon.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits fresh record as Fed effect boosts US stocks
summary: The Nasdaq reached a fresh record, surpassing 5,339.52, after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates low, boosting US stocks. Apple and Amazon led the gains, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 also rising 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively. The strong performance was attributed to the Fed's decision, which lifted investor confidence and fueled a rally in technology equities.

site_title: Trump vs Clinton: Debate will mark biggest moment of election
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Donald Trump will face off in their first presidential debate on Monday, with history showing that a single bad debate performance can significantly alter the trajectory of a US presidential race. Clinton's once-comfortable lead in opinion polls has evaporated, and she needs to deliver a strong performance to regain her footing. Trump, meanwhile, must show enough gravitas to convince skeptics that he is ready to be commander in chief. The debate will be closely scrutinized, with both candidates' body language and performances under the spotlight.

site_title: Maersk ends mega-ship building era with new acquisition plans
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, is ending its era of mega-ship building by stopping new vessel orders and pursuing acquisitions instead. The company has 27 ships in its order book, but with the industry suffering from overcapacity and falling freight rates, Maersk aims to grow through takeovers, focusing on shipping lines with overlapping trade routes and areas where Maersk is not present. This strategy aims to avoid flooding the market with more ships and capitalize on synergies.

site_title: Maersk Oil seen surviving split to become independent producer
summary: Maersk Oil, a Danish oil company, may survive as an independent producer after being split from its parent company, AP Moeller Maersk A/S. The company will focus on fewer regions, particularly the North Sea, and seek to grow through acquisitions or mergers. Maersk Oil's assets, including a stake in the Johan Sverdrup project off Norway, are expected to attract potential buyers, including Statoil, Lundin Petroleum, and Det Norske Oljeselskap. Listing the company could create value and take advantage of the current market's high demand for high-quality, fully-financed assets.

site_title: Opec under pressure to act in Algiers as oil surplus triples
summary: OPEC is under pressure to reach a deal at its upcoming meeting in Algiers, as the global oil surplus triples to 1.2 million barrels a day. The surplus is fueled by increased production from Russia, Libya, and Nigeria, and is expected to persist into 2017. Analysts predict that OPEC's inability to reach a deal could lead to prices struggling to stay above $40 a barrel. A pact could provide exemptions to countries like Nigeria and Libya to restore output, but without an agreement, the global surplus is projected to swell, risking a price drop to $30-$40 a barrel.

site_title: Bank regulators join investigation into JPMorgan's China hiring
summary: The Federal Reserve and Office of the Comptroller of Currency have joined investigations into JPMorgan Chase's hiring practices in China, seeking a fine of up to $62 million for allegedly hiring relatives of Chinese officials to win business. The probes come on top of settlements being negotiated with the US Securities and Exchange Commission and federal prosecutors, with JPMorgan expected to pay around $200 million to resolve the investigations. The issue centers on whether the bank's hiring practices violated the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

site_title: Supernatural thriller kicks off film festival
summary: Malaysian filmmaker Dain Iskandar Said's fantasy noir thriller "Interchange" will open the Singapore International Film Festival on November 23. The film, which combines noir and supernatural elements, is based on a true incident and stars Malaysian and Indonesian actors. It will make its Asian premiere after receiving critical praise at the Locarno and Toronto film festivals. The director is excited for the Asian debut of his work, which he believes showcases the unique storytelling and flavors of South-east Asian cinema.

site_title: Global mail fraud network targeted by US authorities
summary: US authorities have targeted a global mail fraud network that cheats millions of people out of tens of millions of US dollars annually. The network, which includes companies in Canada, France, Singapore, Turkey, India, and the US, uses direct mailers to send phony letters claiming recipients have won cash or prizes. The US Justice Department has announced criminal charges, economic sanctions, asset seizures, and designations of transnational criminal organizations, affecting companies and individuals in multiple countries. The effort aims to stop the scams, which have taken in $50-60 million annually.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine clarifies statement, says firm's fundamentals are sound
summary: Marco Polo Marine clarified its statement on cautionary risk factors, stating its business fundamentals are sound despite a volatile economic climate. The company assured it has positive Ebitda of S$27.10 million for 2015 and S$4.2 million for the first nine months of 2016. The statement was made in response to news reports that the company expressed "substantial doubt on its ability to operate as a going concern," which was actually part of a customary risk factor disclosure.

site_title: Insurers need to expand offerings to raise customer loyalty: study
summary: A survey conducted by Bain & Company found that insurers must expand their offerings to differentiate themselves and increase customer loyalty. The study, based on 164,000 consumers in 19 countries, including Singapore, revealed that customers who interacted with their primary insurance provider had a 26% to 35% higher loyalty score. To boost engagement, insurers should offer related products and services, improve cross-selling, and refine their marketing campaigns to target specific clients. The study also emphasizes the importance of accelerating the mobile channel and using advanced analytics to improve customer retention.

site_title: Overseas home purchases in Vancouver fall after new tax
summary: Foreign buyers in Vancouver's property market decreased by 2.8 percentage points in August, with 5.8% of transactions involving foreign nationals, down from 8.4% before the 15% tax on foreign homebuying took effect. The tax resulted in a drop to $46.9 million in foreign home sales from $2.3 billion in July. The government collected $2.5 million in additional tax revenue from 60 foreign purchases in August. This decrease suggests the new tax is discouraging overseas buyers in the city.

site_title: Finding an excuse to vote for Trump or Clinton ...
summary: A recent survey suggests Maine, a state that has voted Democratic in the last six elections, may tip towards Republican candidate Donald Trump in the presidential election. A local poll among seven cab drivers found that five were ardent Trump supporters, while one was undecided and looking for an excuse to vote for him. This phenomenon may be repeated among other voters who dislike both candidates, with a focus on finding an excuse to vote for their preferred party's candidate. The upcoming presidential debate could play a crucial role in swaying undecided voters, with Trump potentially drawing attention away from Clinton's weaknesses and projecting steadiness and strength.

images.alt_text: The nightmare scenario among Mrs Clinton's campaign aides is that next week's debate could accentuate some of her weaknesses.

site_title: Canada, China aim to strike free-trade deal
summary: Canada and China have agreed to begin talks for a possible free-trade accord with the goal of doubling bilateral commerce by 2025. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang announced the move during a joint news conference, citing extensive common interests and good relations between the two nations. The deal also includes lifting Chinese bans on Canadian canola and beef imports, and a tourism agreement to double two-way visits by 2025.

site_title: Oil climbs to two-week high as Saudis, Iran said to meet again
summary: Oil prices rose to a two-week high after Saudi Arabia and Iran met in Vienna for a second day before the wider Opec group holds talks in Algiers. US crude supplies dropped to the lowest since February, and futures rose 2.2% in New York. Analysts say the talks increase the likelihood of an agreement next week, but many remain skeptical about a production limit deal. The US dollar weakened, supporting commodities, and oil prices rose, with West Texas Intermediate closing at $46.32 a barrel and Brent at $47.65 a barrel.

site_title: Malaysia confirms plans to hike airport taxes
summary: Malaysia has confirmed plans to hike airport taxes, with Transport Minister Liow Tiong Lai announcing the move, although the exact quantum of the increase has not been disclosed. The new charges are expected to standardize fees between KLIA and KLIA2, potentially benefiting Malaysia Airports Holdings Bhd (MAHB) and Malaysia Airlines. The hike is likely to affect budget carrier AirAsia group, with its founder Tony Fernandes criticizing the move as an attempt to recoup losses from the construction of the budget terminal. The impact on AirAsia is expected to be minimal in the long term.

site_title: Traders grapple with US rate outlook
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) experienced a volatile session on Thursday as traders grappled with the US Federal Reserve's latest statement and dot plots, which suggested a December interest rate hike. Despite initial gains, the STI ultimately closed 4.68 points weaker at 2,846.06, with the Hang Seng Index also reversing its early gains. The Dow futures shift into the red further contributed to the market's decline.

site_title: Bangkok edges out London as world's top travel destination: Mastercard
summary: Bangkok has been crowned the world's top travel destination for 2016, surpassing London, according to Mastercard's annual ranking. The Thai capital received 21.47 million international visitors, just ahead of London's 19.88 million. Tourism has been a bright spot for Thailand, which has struggled with economic challenges since a 2014 coup. The city's affordability and value for money are key factors in its popularity, according to Mastercard's chief economist. Thailand expects to welcome a record 33 million visitors this year, driven by a surge in Chinese tourists.

site_title: Zhou family from Shanghai buys 60% of 139 Cecil Street
summary: The Zhou family from Shanghai has acquired a 60% stake in Ececil Pte Ltd, the company that owns 139 Cecil Street, for S$75 million. The deal values the 11-storey property at S$140 million. The Zhou family also previously acquired 137 Cecil Street, valued at S$210 million, last year. The property is set for a major refurbishment, increasing its gross floor area from 68,809 sq ft to 88,886 sq ft, and will feature a communal roof terrace and F&B space.

site_title: Pentagon helping South-east Asian allies tackle Isis
summary: The US is helping its South-east Asian allies combat the Islamic State group, which has established a presence in several countries including Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, and the Philippines. The Pentagon is providing intelligence sharing and information to prevent domestic attacks and prevent nationals from joining the group in Iraq and Syria. Defense Secretary Ashton Carter plans to discuss the issue with regional defense ministers at a summit in Hawaii, where South-east Asia is seen as a key area for IS to spread. Over 1,000 Indonesians and hundreds from the Philippines have joined IS in Iraq and Syria.

images.alt_text: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter said he was meeting with regional defense ministers next week at a summit in Hawaii and IS would be one subject of discussion.

site_title: Vietnam seeks to raise retiring age as population pressures pensions
summary: Vietnam plans to raise the retirement age to 62 for men and 60 for women to address the country's rapidly ageing population and alleviate pressure on social welfare funds. The Labour Ministry aims to gradually increase the retirement age to take advantage of the current workforce while keeping payouts manageable. The move is in line with the International Labour Organization's recommendations to offset a future decrease in the working-age population and keep pension schemes sustainable.

site_title: Singdollar up on Fed decision but rally tempered ahead of MAS meeting
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) rose to S$1.3528 against the US dollar after the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, but the rally was tempered as investors await the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) decision in October. Analysts expect the MAS to be patient due to sluggish domestic fundamentals, with some even speculating they may delay easing monetary policies. The strong SGD poses a challenge to the local economy, which is struggling with rising unemployment. The MAS is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at its October meeting, according to recent polls.

site_title: 40th anniversary BT, Monteiro concert
summary: The Business Times is celebrating its 40th anniversary with a star-studded concert featuring Grammy-winning musicians and local stars. The Jazzy Business concert, jointly presented by Monteiro and The Business Times, will be held on September 30 at the Esplanade Concert Hall. The program will be a decade-by-decade retrospective of Jeremy Monteiro's career, showcasing his journey from the 1970s to the current millennium. The concert will feature 25 musicians, including international stars like Lee Ritenour and Ernie Watts, as well as local and regional talent.

images.alt_text: Among the artistes who will be supporting Jeremy Monteiro (above) at the Jazzy Business concert on Sept 30 are saxophonist Ernie Watts; Hong Kong singer Frances Yip; and The Count Basie Orchestra's Carmen Bradford.
Saxophonist Ernie Watts.
Hong Kong singer Frances Yip.
The Count Basie Orchestra's Carmen Bradford.

site_title: Lum Chang-LaSalle joint venture buys The Verge for S$190m
summary: A joint venture between Lum Chang Holdings and LaSalle Investment Management Asia has acquired The Verge mall in Singapore for S$189.8 million. The plan is to tear down the mall and build serviced residences with some retail and office components. The deal is expected to be completed in November. This acquisition marks the duo's previous partnership in developing Twenty Anson and the Crowne Plaza Changi Airport.

site_title: At FairPrice, sustainability is in its DNA
summary: NTUC FairPrice, Singapore's largest supermarket chain, has published its first sustainability report, covering data and activities at 130 outlets and warehouse operations for 2015. The report highlights achievements such as stocking over 5,000 products made in Singapore and investing S$1.1 million in supporting local small and medium-sized enterprises. FairPrice also reported a "Grade A" status in food safety since 2008 and donating over S$98 million to the FairPrice Foundation. The company aims to save 11 million plastic bags this year through its bring-your-own-bag initiative.

site_title: Syria meeting breaks up without plan to restore truce
summary: A high-level international meeting on the Syria crisis broke up without an agreement to revive a collapsed truce. US Secretary of State John Kerry stated that Russia failed to promise to ground Syria's bombers and halt city bombardments. The meeting, attended by 22 nations, was described as "long, painful, and disappointing." Kerry expressed a need to restore credibility to the ceasefire process, which requires Syria to stop using its air power. The US diplomat is prepared to meet with Russia again to explore possible solutions, but the UN peace envoy was downbeat about the meeting's outcome.

site_title: Yellen rebuffs pressure to hike rates as Fed gives economy room to run
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen delayed a rate increase, citing the economy's "little more room to run" despite strengthened case for a hike. The decision, which kept rates on hold, drew dissents from three FOMC members. Yellen emphasized the Fed still intends to raise rates this year, with a revised forecast of two hikes in 2017, down from three. The decision was seen as a sign that the US economy is still growing, with discouraged workers returning to the labor market.

site_title: Asia revenue may top Europe in 5 years: Julius Baer chief
summary: Julius Baer, a Swiss wealth manager, predicts Asia may surpass Europe as its largest revenue-generating region within the next five years. The company plans to hire over 200 bankers, with more than half based in Asia, to drive growth. Asia contributed 20% of Julius Baer's revenue in 2020, up from 10% in 2011. The bank is expanding in Asia, drawn by the growing number of wealthy individuals, and has chosen Singapore as a base for a new technology platform.

site_title: Not note-perfect but still an agreeably frothy bio
summary: Florence Foster Jenkins, a wealthy heiress with a passion for opera, is portrayed in the film of the same name. Despite her terrible singing voice, Florence's confidence and devotion to her craft are supported by her loving husband, St Clair (Hugh Grant), who goes to great lengths to keep her happy. The film, directed by Stephen Frears, follows Florence's journey as she prepares for a performance at Carnegie Hall, facing criticism and skepticism along the way. Meryl Streep stars as Florence, delivering a charming and nuanced performance.

site_title: SMEs 'barely keeping their heads above water'
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are facing a challenging six months ahead, with business sentiment falling by 3.3% to 50.2, according to the SBF-DP SME Index. The pessimistic outlook is attributed to weak economic conditions, unfavourable exchange rates, and rising costs, affecting all six industries. Profit expectations have also plummeted to an all-time low score of 4.76, with five out of six industries expecting profits to decline or incur losses.

site_title: Geometric sorcery
summary: MC Escher, a renowned graphic artist, is often underrated in the artistic community but widely revered by mathematicians and scientists. His works on tessellations, geometry, and multiple levels of reality have gained fans among scientists, including Roger Penrose and Chen Ning Yang. A new exhibition at Marina Bay Sands' ArtScience Museum features over 150 Escher artworks, showcasing his evolution from graphic design to masterpieces that influenced the scientific community. Despite his contributions, Escher remained largely unknown to the general public and was even neglected by his own family, leaving a lasting legacy in the art and science world.

site_title: Not everyone walks happy after note-restructuring
summary: Note-holders in the offshore and marine industry are facing anxiety over restructuring negotiations for medium-term notes (MTNs) due to the industry's downturn. With no easy solutions, note-holders must weigh tradeoffs, including deferment of redemption, conversion to other debt or equity, or a haircut. The decision will depend on individual investment objectives and priorities, with no single proposal likely to please all stakeholders. Ultimately, any restructuring exercise will come down to a vote at the note-holders' meeting, with the majority's decision determining the outcome.

site_title: Japan tourist boom not enough to boost Takashimaya, Isetan
summary: Japan's department stores, including Takashimaya and Isetan, saw a 6% decline in sales in August, despite a 13% rise in tourist arrivals. The slump is attributed to deflation, negative interest rates, and a stronger yen making Japan more expensive for tourists. The Bank of Japan's decision to control interest rates aims to combat deflation, but it may be challenging to achieve its inflation goal. Department stores are losing customers to discount chains, with tourists preferring everyday items over luxury goods.

site_title: Celebrating animation again after 5 years
summary: The Singapore Film Society is reviving Animation Nation, a festival showcasing award-winning animation works, after a five-year hiatus. The event will feature screenings of critically acclaimed animator Adam Elliot's works, including "Harvie Krumpet" and "Ernie Biscuit". The festival will also include talks, panel discussions, and a compilation of local animated shorts. Animation Nation director Michael Lim notes that animation has become increasingly popular, especially in Southeast Asia, and the festival aims to highlight independent creations that are not made by major studios.

site_title: MCC's Tampines condo likely to be priced at S$900-1,200 psf
summary: MCC Land's Tampines condo, The Alps Residences, is expected to be priced between S$900-1,200 psf. The 626-unit project will be launched this Saturday, with a significantly higher unit count than initially estimated. The price range is seen as competitive, reflecting the developer's efforts to attract buyers in a weakened market. Analysts estimate a breakeven price of S$920-960 psf, with a potential net profit margin of up to 10%.

site_title: StarHub deploys mesh network at NUS
summary: StarHub has deployed Singapore's first mesh network of connected vehicles at NUS' Kent Ridge campus. The platform leverages vehicles as mobile WiFi access points, providing seamless WiFi coverage and enabling IoT devices to connect. The year-long project aims to test the feasibility of a nationwide mesh network and explore data-driven insights for logistics and transportation companies. The deployment has seen over 78,000 unique WiFi users, resulting in 2 million internet sessions and 175,800 hours of internet surfing.

site_title: Twitter sees jump in requests to remove posts
summary: Twitter reported a 13% increase in official requests to remove posts in the first half of 2016, with Turkey and Russia leading the pack. The company received 4,434 removal requests and 761 court orders, targeting 20,594 accounts. The US made 98 removal requests, with 1 granted, and 2,520 account information requests, getting 82% of them fulfilled. Twitter cited concerns over "surveillance" purposes for its decision to limit government access to data.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's telcos M1 and StarHub may continue to decline despite their sharp drop in share prices, potentially losing 7% revenue share by 2022. DBS Group Research predicts a new entrant will lead to a contraction in mobile sector revenue, citing MyRepublic and TPG's track record of capturing subscribers through price competition. OUE Hospitality Trust's quarterly distribution per unit is expected to improve, driven by new store openings and refurbishments. Delfi Limited's share price has declined but its performance has improved, with the company's own-brand sales driving growth.

site_title: SGX to launch more LNG derivative products in Q2 2017
summary: SGX plans to launch more liquefied natural gas (LNG) derivative products in Q2 2017, aiming to gain pricing dominance in the LNG market. The new North Asia price index will be based on LNG cargoes delivered to ports in Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and China, accounting for 60% of global LNG demand. The launch of the North Asia Sling is expected to complement the Singapore Sling, and analysts believe it could emerge as a predominant index if major Japanese utilities join as participants. This move is seen as a response to the supply glut and a need for more transparent pricing.

site_title: Young S'pore consumers value reliability, trust
summary: In Singapore, a study by HSBC Bank found that 94% of consumers aged 18-34 prioritize reliability and trust when making purchases, surpassing other markets. This shift is driven by changing demographics and consumer behavior. The study also revealed that Singaporean consumers are among the most active online shoppers, with 57% buying goods or services online in the past month. Additionally, the report found that Singapore consumers prefer brands with an ethical bent, and the divide between female and male consumer tastes is blurring, with both women and men valuing leisure equally.

site_title: Back into the groove
summary: A vinyl record revival is underway in Singapore, with new record stores popping up in recent months. Vinylicious Records, Hear Records, Barbershop Music, RetroCrates, and others have expanded their operations, offering a wide range of vinyls, CDs, posters, and other music paraphernalia. The resurgence of vinyl sales is attributed to the ease of finding new releases on wax, with many stores now carrying contemporary pop and indie titles. Owners of these stores attribute their success to catering to a niche segment of music-lovers and creating a welcoming atmosphere for customers to "crate-dig" and enjoy music.

site_title: Self-indulgence ruins this beautiful-looking film
summary: Nicolas Winding Refn's film "The Neon Demon" is visually stunning but narratively shallow, mirroring the superficiality of the modeling industry it critiques. Elle Fanning stars as a young model who rises to fame in Los Angeles, but the film's plot is thin and meandering, with a wonky narrative that includes necrophilia and vampires. The film's self-indulgence and style over substance have sparked a love-hate relationship with critics and audiences, with some praising its visuals and others criticizing its lack of depth.

site_title: Fed makes it easier for Asia-Pacific central banks to stay dovish
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision to delay raising interest rates has made it easier for Asia-Pacific central banks to maintain dovish policies, with Indonesia lowering its rates and Australia and New Zealand considering further cuts. The Fed's stance has boosted demand for longer-tenure bonds and supports easing bias in core emerging markets. Most Asia-Pacific economies have room to ease policy, driven by low growth rates, above-zero official rates, and inflation below targets.

site_title: Rickmers faces uphill task in new note revamp plan
summary: Rickmers Maritime's trustee-manager has proposed a revised note restructuring plan to address concerns from note-holders, which includes a more substantial debt-to-equity swap. The plan involves partially redeeming the S$100 million 8.45% note due 2017, bringing it down to S$40 million, and issuing 1.32 billion new units to note-holders at a 12.4% discount. The proposal aims to deleverage the company's balance sheet and enhance its chances of surviving the container shipping downturn. However, the significant new equity issue has raised concerns about unit dilution, and the company faces an uphill task in securing approval from unit-holders and note-holders.

site_title: Adjustment factor cited for drop in US crude inventory
summary: US crude inventory data showed a 6.2 million barrel drop to 504.6 million barrels, defying expectations of a 3.4 million barrel increase. The drop may be attributed to timing and ongoing production and supply chain issues related to a Gulf of Mexico storm. The adjustment factor, a component of the weekly report reflecting uncertainty around supply and demand data, may also be a factor. Refinery runs remain strong on a year-over-year basis, contributing to the overall large US stock draw.

site_title: Tech takes centre stage at enterprise awards
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Award (EE 2016) in Singapore celebrated technology and innovation, with Minister of State for National Development, Koh Poh Koon, emphasizing the importance of entrepreneurship and resilience. The event recognized 16 finalists, including e-commerce platform ShopBack, medical technology firm Innovfusion, and menswear label Benjamin Barker, with awards for Best Innovation and Most Promising Startup. The award aims to inspire aspiring entrepreneurs and business leaders, providing recognition for the hard work and leadership of companies that have achieved success.

site_title: Flying high!
summary: A passenger on Singapore Airlines' First Class flight from Singapore to San Francisco recently created a wine-tasting session to alleviate the tedium of a 12-hour, non-stop flight. The passenger tasted the airline's entire First Class wine list, including the Corton Grancey Grand Cru 2010, Matanzas Creek Chardonnay 2012, Bischofliche Weinguter Trier Piesporter Goldtroffen Riesling Kabinett 2013, Chateau Rauzan-Segla 2007, and others. The passenger noted that the wines showed a range of characteristics, with some being more youthful and others more mature. The passenger also highlighted the expertise of the winemaker, John Kolasa, who has made significant improvements at Chateau Rauzan-Segla.

images.alt_text: The Corton Grancey Grand Cru 2010 (above left) is a pleasing pinot with very good ripeness of fruit and an accompanying freshness. The Matanzas Creek Chardonnay 2012 (above right) has good fruit but not enough complexity and acidity. It is typical of Napa Chardonnays in its tendency is to be heavy on the wood.

site_title: Number of suspended Philippine nickel mines to more than double
summary: The Philippines has announced plans to suspend more than 10 nickel mines, adding to the 10 already halted, as part of an environmental audit initiated by President Rodrigo Duterte. The country, the world's largest nickel supplier, aims to address concerns about the environmental impact of the industry. The suspensions are expected to affect the global nickel market, with futures rising to their highest level in a year. The government is optimistic that the cleanup efforts will attract investment and stimulate the industry.

site_title: Banks take up higher-than-expected 45.3b euros in cheap ECB loans
summary: European banks took up 45.3 billion euros in cheap ECB loans, almost twice the predicted amount, in a second round of refinancing under the TLTRO 2 programme. The loans are expected to boost economic growth by encouraging banks to lend to households and businesses. The amount is significantly higher than analysts' forecasts, but analysts caution that increased demand may be a sign of banks' willingness to lend rather than a significant increase in lending due to political uncertainties and high unemployment.

site_title: Speed, innovation crucial for airline industry: Iata chief
summary: IATA chief Alexandre de Juniac emphasizes the need for speed and innovation in the airline industry to address potential threats, including rising oil prices, terrorism, and protectionism. Despite record profits of $39.4 billion, airlines must prioritize finance and operational efficiency to stay ahead. Iata plans to establish a global safety predictive analytics research centre with Singapore, aiming to improve aviation safety, reduce costs, and enhance on-time performance.

site_title: Why oil & gas companies should embrace the digital age more fully
summary: Oil and gas companies can reap significant benefits from embracing the digital age, including dramatic cost savings and improved productivity. However, most companies have yet to fully capture the potential of their data due to inadequate digital capabilities and lack of strategic planning. Key pitfalls include a lack of long-term digital strategy, outdated operating models, and unprepared workforces. To overcome these challenges, companies should develop integrated digital strategies, upgrade their operating models, and invest in talent and capabilities. This will enable them to unlock the full potential of their data and achieve long-term competitive advantage.

site_title: US allows Boeing, Airbus to sell planes to Iran
summary: The US has granted licenses to Boeing and Airbus to sell planes to Iran, allowing the country to rebuild its ageing fleet. The decision is a boon for the two companies and Iranian politicians seeking to expand engagement with the world. Iran's President Hassan Rouhani has promised "safe planes" after the lifting of nuclear sanctions. However, the move is likely to draw protests from some members of Congress, who argue it undermines national security. The licenses contain conditions ensuring the planes are for commercial use only.

site_title: F&N names new CEOs for its beer, food divisions
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) has announced changes to its managerial team. Prapakon Thongtheppairot, current CEO of beer, will retire on Oct 1 to focus on his new role as global Spirit Product group CEO of Thai Beverage Public Company. Edmond Neo, previously general manager of regional brand development, will succeed Prapakon as CEO of beer. Neo will be responsible for building and implementing strategies for F&N's food business, which is a newly-created position. Bennett Neo, Edmond's brother, will also become CEO of food on Oct 1.

site_title: Singapore Biennale's full line-up
summary: The Singapore Biennale's 2016 lineup features 60 works by 63 artists and art collectives from 18 countries in South-east Asia, South Asia, and East Asia. The biennale explores the theme "The Atlas of Mirrors," examining topics such as contested borders, resistance, and forgotten histories. The exhibition, which runs from October, includes 49 newly commissioned and adapted artworks, with a focus on Asia and a wider geographical scope than previous editions. The artworks will be displayed across seven venues in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Works to be displayed at the four-month-long Singapore Biennale 2016 include The Covenant by Sharmiza Abu Hassan (Malaysia, above) and Locus Amoenus by Ryan Villameal (Philippines).
Works to be displayed at the four-month-long Singapore Biennale 2016 include The Covenant by Sharmiza Abu Hassan (Malaysia) and Locus Amoenus by Ryan Villameal (Philippines, above).

site_title: August home resales in unexpected fall
summary: US home resales unexpectedly fell 0.9% in August to an annual rate of 5.33 million units, surpassing economists' forecasts of a 1.1% increase. The slowdown is attributed to a shortage of inventory, which is boosting home prices faster than wage growth. Despite this, existing home sales are still up 0.8% from last year. The housing market has been strengthening due to healthy job gains, but the inventory shortage is a key factor holding back the recovery.

site_title: Hanjin gets 50b won credit line from South Korea state lender
summary: Korea Development Bank (KDB) offered a 50 billion won (S$61.6 million) conditional credit line to Hanjin Shipping Co to ease supply-chain disruptions caused by the collapse of the nation's biggest container mover. The loan will be secured by Hanjin's account receivables, pending sufficient collateral from Korean Air Lines Co, chairman Cho Yang Ho, and a former Hanjin Shipping chairwoman. The move aims to prevent further disruptions in the supply chain.

site_title: Pity if strongman politics proves the Philippines' undoing again
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's administration has sparked concerns among foreign investors due to its handling of the war on drugs, which has resulted in over 3,000 extrajudicial killings. This has led to a decline in investor confidence, with weekly stock market data showing a steady fall in net foreign transactions and Standard & Poor's downgrading its outlook to "stable" but highlighting weaknesses. The country's economic growth, which averaged 6.2% under former President Benigno Aquino III, may be threatened by the administration's policy flip-flops and lack of respect for the rule of law.

site_title: ECB hands banks 45.3b euros at zero interest rate
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has handed 45.3 billion euros (S$69 billion) to euro-area lenders at a zero interest rate, as part of its programme to boost credit to the real economy. This is the second round of its targeted longer-term refinancing operation (TLTRO-II). The ECB's move aims to stimulate economic growth and address low inflation concerns. The previous operation in June saw a net 31 billion euros taken up by lenders.

site_title: Wrong FY figures used, so company's penalty for price-fixing is cut
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) reduced a penalty of S$7.6 million to S$4.8 million for Japanese firm Nachi-Fujikoshi Corporation and three other Japanese ball-bearing manufacturers due to an error in interpreting its rules. The penalty was for price-fixing activities in 2014. The error involved using incorrect turnover figures from the previous financial year instead of the most recent year. The Competition Appeal Board found the CCS had properly exercised discretion in determining the penalty, and the decision was seen as significant in preventing anti-competitive behavior in Singapore's markets.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine viable, says CEO
summary: Marco Polo Marine, a Singapore-based shipyard, has a viable business despite the slump in oil prices, according to CEO Sean Lee. The company has asked bondholders to defer the redemption of its S$50 million bonds until 2019 and has proposed a security arrangement to bondholders. Ship building and repair contribute to the company's revenue, and Lee believes the fundamentals of oil are still there, despite the current low prices. The company expects to record net losses for the fiscal year ending September 2016 due to lower utilization rates and charter rates.

site_title: Higher rates for bigger vessels perk up Baltic index
summary: The Baltic Exchange's main sea freight index rose 34 points, or 3.77%, to 937 points, driven by higher rates for larger vessels. The capesize index surged 13% to 2,389 points, with average daily earnings increasing to $15,301. Freight rates for large capesize vessels on Asian routes are expected to climb ahead of China's National Day holiday.

site_title: One impact of HDB cooling measures is cut in consumer spending
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) cooling measures have reduced consumer spending by 10% among high equity homeowners over a six-month period. The measures, introduced six years ago, restrict access to home equity by extending the minimum occupation period for resale HDB flats to five years. Research found that high equity homeowners reduced their credit card spending by 31% and non-durable or discretionary items by 69% due to restricted access to home equity. The findings suggest that governments can use cooling measures to moderate consumption and control inflation.

site_title: India to renew drive to overhaul labour laws
summary: India's government plans to overhaul labour laws, aiming to create millions of new jobs by easing hiring and firing regulations. The move, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government, comes after the passage of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) in August. Two key bills covering industrial relations and wages will be sent to the Cabinet this month, with the aim of presenting them in Parliament's next session. Trade unions argue that the reforms will put jobs at risk, while the government claims they will boost employment and attract foreign investment.

site_title: US$ recovers against yen on Fed message
summary: The US dollar recovered from a nearly 4-week low against the yen on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve meeting hinted at a rise in interest rates this year, but not as far as expected. The dollar rose 0.4% to 100.73 yen, while the euro gained 0.4% to its highest since Friday, breaking into the middle of its US$1.09-US$1.15 range. Analysts expect a possible rate hike in December, which may lead to a stronger yen.

site_title: Singapore dollar rises as US Fed keeps rates unchanged
summary: The Singapore dollar rose to S$1.3528 after the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, but its rally was tempered by concerns about the Monetary Authority of Singapore's potential policy move next month. Analysts expect the MAS to ease policies in October, citing a struggling local economy with rising unemployment and a forecasted 1.8% growth rate for 2016. The Singapore dollar's strength could hinder the local economy, which is already facing challenges.

site_title: Policies can do the opposite of what they promise
summary: A study by the Peterson Institute found that US President Donald Trump's proposed trade policies could trigger a global trade war and a deep US recession without Congressional authorization. Trump's plans for high tariffs on Mexico and China could be implemented by executive order, citing decades of laws that authorize the president to impose tariffs or quotas on imports. The study estimates that a trade war would lead to a severe recession, with unemployment rising to 8.6% in 2020, and weaker global trade and investment.

site_title: US jobless claims drop to two-month low as labour market firms
summary: US jobless claims fell to a two-month low of 252,000 for the week ended September 17, as the labour market continues to show strength. This is the 81st consecutive week that claims remained below the 300,000 threshold, the longest stretch since 1970. The Fed left interest rates unchanged but signaled a potential rate hike by the end of the year, citing a recent economic growth pickup and labour market progress.

site_title: How we age, how we die
summary: Nelson Chia, a renowned Mandarin theatre director, is staging a production of "Red Sky" to explore ageing and death through the eyes of eight senior citizens in a nursing home. Written by Taiwanese theatre doyen Stan Lai, the play reflects on the dual perspectives of optimism and pessimism in growing old. Chia aims to challenge the societal perception of old age as something unproductive, and instead, celebrate the value of wisdom and knowledge that older people bring. The production features a cast of veteran actors aged 51-68, alongside younger actors, and is part of Nine Years Theatre's shift towards Asian classics.

images.alt_text: Veteran actors of Mandarin theatre come together for Red Sky, a play about growing old.

site_title: Lum Chang unit in JV to acquire Serangoon shopping mall
summary: Lum Chang Holdings has formed a joint venture with LAO V Serangoon to acquire Corwin Holding's Chill @ The Verge shopping mall in Serangoon for S$189.75 million. The JV aims to capitalize on the opportunity to collaborate with LaSalle, a reputable real estate investment management firm. This acquisition marks a strategic move by Lum Chang, further expanding its portfolio in the retail sector.

site_title: Zuckerberg fund pledges US$3 billion to banish disease
summary: Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Priscilla Chan pledged $3 billion over the next decade to help banish or manage all disease, with the goal of curing all disease or making catastrophic illnesses manageable within their daughter's lifetime. The funding will be used to create a Biohub in San Francisco, a collective effort to develop new tools to study and understand diseases. The project aims to use innovative research, artificial intelligence, and machine learning to tackle major health culprits like cancer and neurological disease.

images.alt_text: The Zuckerbergs hope that their project will power a movement to fund more medical research around the world.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: The Straits Trading Company has clarified reports of selling its Melbourne office building, stating discussions are ongoing with potential buyers. Vard Holdings secured a US$40 million contract to design and construct two module carrier vessels for Topaz Energy and Marine. Golden Energy and Resources acquired a coal exploration and processing business in Indonesia for US$37.2 million. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: Tapping the untapped Asian market
summary: Zingohub, a Singapore-based crowdfunding platform, aims to connect independent creators across Asia and beyond with a community to raise funds for their creative ideas and engage in early sales. Founded by Sayantan Das, the platform offers on-the-ground support, including consulting and educational talks, to help makers navigate the crowdfunding process. Since its launch, Zingohub has seen exponential growth, with over 20 active campaigns and 35,000 users, and is now expanding to India, the UAE, and other countries, with plans to launch its iOS app and explore new markets.

images.alt_text: Some of the campaigns you can find on crowdfunding platform Zingohub include dancers who want to put on performances, musicians seeking funding for producing albums and makers of hand-crafted jewellery items (above).

Some of the campaigns you can find on crowdfunding platform Zingohub include dancers who want to put on performances, musicians seeking funding for producing albums and makers of hand-crafted jewellery items (above).

Neeye, the most successful campaign on Zingohub, was an attempt to create a video portraying the different languages of love and emotion through the medium of dance (above). It reached its funding goal within three days.

site_title: Dancing for your life
summary: Celebrated choreographer Bill T. Jones' dance piece "A Letter/Singapore" addressed socio-political issues, drawing inspiration from James Baldwin's 1963 book "The Fire Next Time." The dance, performed at the Singapore International Festival of Arts, uses movement, mise-en-scene, and music to convey a message of compassion and humanity, transcending frustrations of racial and sexual politics. Featuring dancers representing disenfranchised minorities and incorporating elements of vogue, hip-hop, and Martha Graham, the piece ultimately promotes forgiveness and love, exemplifying art's response to complex topical issues like racism and violence.

site_title: Opec in new push to clinch first deal to curb output since 2008
summary: OPEC is poised to agree on its first production cut deal since 2008, aiming to curb output and stabilize oil prices. Saudi Arabia, Iran, and Russia are sending conciliatory signals, despite backing different sides in conflicts. Iraq, a key producer, has agreed not to flood the market, while Libya and Nigeria may be granted exemptions due to production curtailment by unrest. The deal, set to last until October 2017, aims to reduce global oil stocks and rebalance the market, potentially helping to boost prices.

site_title: Former top BOA female banker settles 'bro's club' bias suit
summary: Bank of America has settled a lawsuit filed by former top female banker Megan Messina, who accused the bank of being a "bro's club" that favored male employees over women. Messina claimed she was underpaid and punished for complaining about questionable activity, including a boss's bias and a colleague's front-running. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed, but the case was dismissed in federal court. The bank's spokesman stated that the matter was resolved to the mutual satisfaction of all parties, with Messina's lawyer emphasizing the need for financial firms to promote women's careers without regard to gender.

site_title: Vietnam's fundamentals point to robust medium-term outlook
summary: Vietnam's economy is poised for a robust medium-term outlook due to its strong manufacturing and services sectors, driven by low labor costs, a skilled workforce, and increased foreign direct investment. The country's proximity to China, with its economic transformation, has also made it an attractive destination for manufacturers. Vietnam's free trade agreements, such as the EU-Vietnam FTA and the TPP, are expected to boost trade and exports. With a growing domestic market and favorable business environment, Vietnam is establishing itself as a major low-cost manufacturing center, particularly in the electronics and textiles sectors.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits record high after Fed leaves rates unchanged
summary: The Nasdaq reached a record high on Thursday after the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, citing balanced risks to the economic outlook. The Fed slowed the pace of future interest rate hikes and cut its longer-run interest rate forecast to 2.9%. The decision sent a signal for a potential rate hike by the end of the year, boosting stocks. The dollar index dropped, and oil prices rose, contributing to the market's gains.

site_title: European tech firms tiptoe back to IPO market
summary: European tech firms, such as Nets A/S and Takeaway.com, are testing the appetite for initial public offerings (IPOs) as the US market experiences a modest rebound. Several European tech firms, including Telxius and Shop Apotheke Europe, plan to list on their home markets this month and next, with prices potentially justifying their own IPOs. However, venture capital funding in Europe has crumbled, and the region lags behind the US and Asia in terms of larger investments for companies looking to expand.

site_title: SGX looks beyond traditional businesses
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expanding its business beyond traditional equity and IPO sectors, exploring futures on the South Korean stock market and developing products to enhance its position as an Asian hub. The exchange is also reviewing its minimum trading price requirements and board lot size rules to improve market quality. SGX's proposed takeover of the Baltic Exchange is progressing well, and the company is working to attract more regional and international companies to raise capital on its platforms. Despite facing competition and macroeconomic-driven volatility, SGX remains confident in its competitive strength and is preparing for the long term.

site_title: BOJ policy shift bad for the yen, good for banks: analysts
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has shifted its policy stance, moving away from aggressive monetary easing and towards a longer-term approach to achieving its 2% annual inflation target. Analysts believe this shift will benefit Japanese banks but may lead to a stronger yen. The BOJ's decision to adopt "yield curve control" and reduce the emphasis on expanding the monetary base will benefit lenders that "borrow short and lend long." However, some analysts expect the BOJ to ease policy again in 2017, potentially weakening the yen.

images.alt_text: A consensus emerged among analysts on Thursday that the Bank of Japan (BOJ) is close to the limits of its aggressive monetary easing, and that the yen could, for some time, rise as a result.

site_title: Bank of England's Forbes sees no case for further rate cut
summary: Bank of England policymaker Kristin Forbes expressed skepticism about the need for further interest rate cuts to support the UK economy after the Brexit vote. Despite most rate-setters expecting another rate cut later this year, Forbes believed August's rate cut and measures to support bank lending were sufficient. She cited a "modest slowing" in the economy, with resilient consumer spending and rising net exports, and warned that "adverse winds" could prompt a change in her stance if demand remained strong or businesses shed jobs.

site_title: Demand for medical malpractice insurance seen to increase as population ages, says AIG
summary: Demand for medical malpractice insurance in Singapore is expected to rise 40% over the next five years as the population ages and healthcare needs increase. This growth is driven by a projected doubling of residents over 65 to 900,000 by 2030. Institutions providing care to the elderly, such as hospices and nursing homes, are expected to see a 40% increase in malpractice insurance coverage, while general practitioners and family clinics will see a 25% rise. The insurer attributes this growth to concerns over inadequate patient handovers, medication errors, and burnout rates among healthcare professionals.

site_title: Singapore shares end weaker as traders grapple with US rate outlook
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore ended the day 4.68 points weaker at 2,846.06, with a low turnover of S$754.2 million. Traders struggled to adjust to the US Federal Reserve's statement suggesting a December interest rate hike and only two rate hikes next year. The market initially rose, but reversed after Dow futures shifted into the red. This volatility followed the Fed's decision to keep interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, with the Committee stating the case for an increase has strengthened but further evidence is needed.

site_title: Immigration boosts US economy even as low-skilled wages dented
summary: A study by the National Academies of Sciences found that immigration provides a net long-term benefit to the US economy, despite depressing wages for low-skilled Americans. Immigrants are expected to replace aging Baby Boomers in the workforce, lift housing demand, and influence innovation and entrepreneurship. However, high-school dropouts and teenagers with jobs may see negative effects on their wages. The study's findings suggest that immigration will continue to power the US economy.

images.alt_text: Immigration provides a net long-term benefit to the US economy, even though foreign-born workers depress wages for some low-skilled Americans and weigh on state and local budgets.

site_title: US existing home sales unexpectedly fall in August
summary: US existing home sales unexpectedly fell 0.9% in August to an annual rate of 5.33 million units, missing economists' forecasts of a 1.1% rise. The decline was attributed to a shortage of inventory, which boosted home prices faster than wage growth. Home resales were still up 0.8% from the previous year, but inventory levels fell 3.3% to 2.04 million, and it would take 4.6 months to clear the existing stock of houses. The median house price rose 5.1% to $240,200.

images.alt_text: US home resales unexpectedly fell in August, crimped by a shortage of inventory that is boosting home prices faster than the pace of wage growth.

site_title: WWE's heiress Stephanie McMahon on being a mum, villain on TV and engaging global audiences
summary: Stephanie McMahon, WWE's chief brand officer and heiress, discussed her role in the company and her personal life in an interview. She revealed that her family has been involved in the wrestling industry for over 50 years, starting with her great-grandfather as a boxing promoter. McMahon has learned the ropes through internships and various roles, eventually becoming chief brand officer. As a mother of three and a villain on TV, she finds it manageable to balance her work and family life. Social media has changed the landscape of pro-wrestling, but McMahon believes it has been a blessing for WWE, allowing for engagement and surprises.

site_title: China and Brexit pose risks to global growth, says ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) warns that global growth is expected to accelerate next year, but faces significant risks, particularly from China's slowing economy and the UK's decision to leave the EU. A stronger slowdown in emerging markets and increased uncertainty could exacerbate macroeconomic imbalances, denting confidence and resulting in an unexpectedly strong slowdown. The ECB also notes that the UK's exit from the EU could have worse-than-expected economic implications, negatively affecting trade, business confidence, and investment.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
City Buzz: 
- Scott Bradlee's Postmodern Jukebox is set to perform in Singapore, reimagining current hits as old-time classics.
- A wine and sake dinner collaboration between Cocotte and Morsels will take place next Monday, featuring dishes inspired by the UK and Japan.
- Local musical "Innamorati Two" explores themes of self-love and imperfections through music and acting.
- The Rooftop Revelry festival will be held at Lepark, featuring food, drinks, and live entertainment, with a focus on food, fashion, and art.
- Archifest 2016 will showcase architecture photos and provide workshops on photography, celebrating Singapore's urban environment.

images.alt_text: Bradlee (on keyboard) and his ensemble Postmodern Jukebox performing at the Kallang Theatre last year. The group has played to packed houses around the world.
Uni cremeaux with beet and apple tartare and pulut hitam crackers (above).
The musical stars Jacky Chew, Stella Seah, Sunny Yang, Sugie Phua, Wong Jing Lun, Ann Lek and Chriz Tong (cast at right), and is presented by Toy Factory Productions.
Oppa Chicken (above).
His "How to Take Kicka** Architectural Photos on IG" (above) is one of the many free workshops and exhibitions that are part of this year's Archifest.

site_title: StarHub deploys mesh network pilot on NUS's Kent Ridge campus
summary: StarHub and the National University of Singapore (NUS) have deployed Singapore's first mesh network of connected vehicles on NUS's Kent Ridge campus. The mesh platform uses vehicles as mobile Wi-Fi access points, connecting to fixed points in buildings and extending Wi-Fi coverage. The year-long project aims to provide seamless Wi-Fi to NUS staff and students, while also generating anonymized data for urban challenge analysis. This collaboration is part of StarHub's Connected Labs initiative and NUS's Living Lab initiative.

site_title: UK manufacturing expands strongly in September: CBI
summary: British manufacturing expanded strongly in September, with a total order book balance of -5, above its long-run average of -15, according to the Confederation for British Industry. Output expectations for the next three months reached a three-month high, and export order growth eased slightly. The CBI chief economist attributed the boost to the fall in sterling, which has increased international competitiveness for many businesses. However, challenges ahead from the EU exit process were noted, with the finance minister expected to focus on investment in the upcoming budget.

site_title: Indonesia central bank cuts key rate in bid to lift slow growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, cut its benchmark interest rate for the fifth time this year, trimming the 7-day reverse repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 5.00% in an effort to boost economic growth. The move follows the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady and is seen as a sign of the country's stable inflation and exchange rates. Analysts predict further rate cuts, citing policy space for easing, as Indonesia's economic growth rate fell to 4.8% last year and is forecast to reach 4.9-5.3% this year.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank, moving while inflation is the lowest in years and as the Federal Reserve stood pat, escalated efforts to spur lending by cutting its benchmark interest rate for the fifth time this year.

site_title: SGX grilled at AGM over salaries, trading outage
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) faced criticism from shareholders at its annual general meeting over salaries and trading outages. Approximately 800 shareholders attended, questioning the exchange's remuneration packages and addressing trading disruptions. The meeting was marked by an active exchange between the board and management. The issues raised highlighted concerns about the struggling stock market and the need for improvement.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore dollar rose against the US dollar following the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged, but local market sentiment was dampened by potential future policy changes from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. A survey found Singapore SMEs' sentiment at its lowest level in seven years, while Vard Holdings secured a US$40 million contract and PSL Holdings raised S$2.9 million through a private subscription agreement. The STI index ended weaker, closing at 2,846.06, amid uncertainty over the US rate outlook.

site_title: Lloyd's posts higher pre-tax profit of £1.46b for H1 2016
summary: Lloyd's, a specialist insurance and reinsurance market, reported a 21.7% year-on-year rise in pre-tax profit for the first six months of 2016 to £1.46 billion. Gross premiums grew 5.2% to £16.31 billion, despite an increase in major claims. However, underwriting profitability declined on a year-on-year basis.

site_title: Wipro unit to acquire Chinese FMCG firm Zhongshan Ma Er
summary: Wipro's unit, Wipro Unza, will acquire Chinese FMCG company Zhongshan Ma Er Daily Products in an all-cash deal. The acquisition aims to help Wipro "leapfrog into the leading position" in South China's personal care market and add critical brands to its portfolio. Zhongshan Ma Er has a strong presence in China and Hong Kong, with brands including Enear, Zici, Vcnic, Pahnli, and Sunew. The deal is subject to regulatory approval and is expected to generate an annual run rate of close to 1 billion yuan (S$203 million) for Wipro Unza.

site_title: China supervisory body approves launch of credit default swaps soon: sources
summary: China's supervisory body, NAFMII, has approved the launch of credit default swaps, a type of derivative providing insurance against third-party defaults. This move aims to help firms hedge rising risks in China's corporate bond market, where bond defaults have risen quickly over the past year and a half. The approval signifies another step forward in introducing hedging tools to protect against such risk, which has added urgency to the efforts. Guidelines for trading will be released soon.

site_title: Maersk reveals details of historic split into oil, transport
summary: Maersk, Denmark's largest company, will split into separate transport and energy businesses. The conglomerate will become a transport and logistics company, while oil and oil-related businesses will be separated. The move aims to unlock value and increase growth and return on capital. Goldman Sachs sees this as a "clear opportunity" and expects significant sum-of-the-parts value. The shares rose 4.2% after the announcement, bringing this year's gains to 12%. A solution for the oil businesses is expected within 24 months.

site_title: China will crack down on illegal activities to keep forex market stable: Regulator
summary: China's forex regulator announced plans to crack down on illegal activities to maintain stability in the foreign exchange market. Xu Weigang stated that rapid rises in outbound investment have impacted cross-border capital flows. The government will support genuine overseas mergers and acquisitions by Chinese firms.

site_title: State of emergency called to quell Charlotte unrest over police shooting of black man
summary: A state of emergency was declared in Charlotte, North Carolina, after a second night of unrest sparked by the fatal police shooting of black man Keith Scott. Scott's family and a witness disputed the claim that he was holding a gun, and protests turned violent, with officers using tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. One protester was shot and four police officers were injured. Governor Pat McCrory deployed the National Guard to restore peace, and the city's mayor considered a curfew. The incident is part of a growing national conversation on racial bias in US law enforcement.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Thursday
summary: Tokyo's financial markets are closed on September 22 for a national holiday, with trading resuming on September 23.

site_title: Yahoo will soon reveal 'massive' loss of user data: Recode
summary: Yahoo is set to disclose a "massive" data breach affecting 200 million user accounts, including names, scrambled passwords, and birth dates, which were stolen by a hacker selling the information on a dark web marketplace. The breach, which occurred between 2012 and the present, comes as Yahoo prepares to close its independence with Verizon's acquisition of its core assets for $4.8 billion. The revelation confirms earlier reports and raises concerns about the company's security and data protection.

site_title: China's state planner to meet with coal industry on supply, prices
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) has scheduled an "urgent" meeting with coal industry regulators and executives to discuss supply and prices amid efforts to cut inefficient production and reduce pollution. The meeting comes as tighter supplies and increased consumption have pushed up prices, with coking coal prices soaring 20% in the past two months. The NDRC aims to overhaul the industry while maintaining supplies to major consumers, including steelmakers. The meeting will analyze supply and demand, transportation, and prices, but details on decisions to be made are unclear.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources unit acquires Indonesian coal business for US$37.2m
summary: Golden Energy and Resources has acquired a 99.9999% owned Indonesian coal business, PT Era Mitra Selaras, for US$37.2 million. The acquisition includes 68 million tonnes of proved and probable coal reserves and is not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share. The deal was made in full cash consideration and took into account recent Indonesian government regulations on coal mining activities. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the current financial year.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks rise, led by property shares, after Fed leaves rates unchanged
summary: China stocks rose 0.7-0.5% on Thursday, led by property shares, after the Federal Reserve kept US interest rates unchanged, easing investor anxiety. The rally followed a week of low volatility and was driven by gains in developers, with listed companies like Vanke and Jinke Property rising. The Shanghai Composite Index rose to 3,042.31 points, with all main sectors contributing to the gains. The decision removed uncertainty and allowed investors to make big bets, according to Wu Kan, head of equity trading at Shanshan Finance.

site_title: Giant Slow Food Festival kicks off in Italy
summary: The Giant Slow Food Festival kicked off in Turin, Italy, with over 7,000 delegates from 143 countries participating. The 30th-anniversary celebration of the Slow Food movement, founded in 1986, promotes biodiversity, environmental respect, and cultural identities through food, wine, and workshops.
