The event features over 900 gourmet speciality exhibitors, 310 traditional or endangered product producers, and various activities, including cooking lessons, taste workshops, and debates. The festival runs until September 26 and aims to educate the public and mobilize people for concrete action on food production and climate change.

site_title: Japan official says it will act if speculative moves seen in yen
summary: Japan's top currency diplomat, Masatsugu Asakawa, warned that the country will take action if speculative moves in the yen are seen, amid a strengthening currency. The dollar tumbled to a near four-week low against the yen after the Fed kept interest rates steady. Japan's central bank also added a long-term interest rate target to its asset-buying program. The stronger yen is expected to hurt Japanese corporate profits as overseas earnings are eroded when repatriated. Authorities will closely monitor the currency market and respond if necessary.

site_title: India names monetary policy committee members
summary: India has appointed three academics as members of a new monetary policy committee, marking a landmark change in central bank decision-making. Chetan Ghate, Pami Dua, and Ravindra Dholakia will join a six-member board to set interest rates. The move allows the government to select committee members, a departure from the previous system where the RBI governor chose the members. The new committee will provide non-binding advice on interest rates to the RBI governor ahead of each policy review.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.930 points to 1,669.660 on Thursday, driven by a 529-313 gain-to-lose ratio. The index closed at RM2.234 billion in volume. The rally comes despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: German real wages rise 2.3% y-o-y in the second quarter
summary: German real wages rose 2.3% year-over-year in the second quarter, driven by strong wage hikes in the real estate, transport, and logistics sectors. Nominal wages increased 2.4% and consumer prices rose 0.1% during the period. This marks the strongest rate of real wage growth since 1992, partly due to the national minimum wage introduced in 2015 and favourable economic conditions.

site_title: Kerry, Lavrov discuss Syria in New York: Moscow
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov discussed the Syrian conflict in New York, hours after clashing over the issue at the UN. The diplomats talked by telephone and in person to continue discussing a settlement in Syria, amid a ceasefire plan that was recently broken by a US-led coalition strike. The US blamed Russia for the strike, which killed 20 humanitarian workers, while Russia insisted that all sides must rein in rebel groups to ensure compliance with the ceasefire. The two nations will chair a meeting of the International Syria Support Group later on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia government accused of gerrymandering
summary: Malaysia's government is accused of gerrymandering to maintain Prime Minister Najib Razak's power ahead of possible snap polls. The Election Commission plans to redraw electoral boundaries in 112 parliamentary seats and 445 state seats, favoring the ruling party. The opposition claims the new boundaries will bundle opposition voters into larger constituencies, making it harder for them to win. The move is seen as a way to ensure Najib's re-election despite a massive corruption scandal involving 1MDB. The opposition and experts accuse the government of systemic rigging and blatant gerrymandering.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally as Federal Reserve keeps rates unchanged
summary: European shares rose as the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, projecting less aggressive hikes next year and in 2018. The Fed signaled it could still tighten policy by year-end as the labor market improved. Miner stocks led the gains, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Basic Resources index rising 3% to its highest level since August. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index also rose 0.7% as the US dollar fell, making commodities cheaper for holders of other currencies.

site_title: South Korea orders additional measures to ensure Samsung Note 7 battery safety
summary: South Korea ordered Samsung Electronics to take additional measures to ensure the safety of batteries used in Galaxy Note 7 handsets, following a recall triggered by faulty batteries that caused fires in some devices. The Korean Agency for Technology and Standards approved Samsung's plan to recall Note 7 smartphones and ordered a thorough inspection to ensure battery safety. Samsung plans to resume new sales of the Note 7 in South Korea on September 28.

site_title: Fossil fuel reserves would crush climate goals: report
summary: A report by Oil Change International finds that existing fossil fuel reserves, if extracted, would push the Earth past the 2C threshold for global warming, exceeding the Paris Agreement's goal. Current operations would emit enough CO2 to breach the 1.5C barrier, with coal reserves having the most significant impact. The report's findings emphasize the need for governments to stop expanding the fossil fuel industry to achieve climate goals, as many scientists predict staying under 1.5C may be out of reach.

site_title: Straits Trading unit in talks to sell office building in Melbourne
summary: Straits Trading Company's subsidiary Straits Real Estate is in talks with potential buyers to sell its Melbourne office building. The discussions may or may not lead to a sale, and the company has clarified reports of a sale in Australian newspapers. The building, located on William Street, was acquired by SRE last year. There is no certainty of a definitive agreement or transaction resulting from the talks.

site_title: Denmark's A P Moller-Maersk to split up into transport, energy divisions
summary: Denmark's A P Moller-Maersk plans to split its businesses into transport and energy divisions to tackle struggling operations. The 112-year-old conglomerate will establish an integrated transport and logistics company, while separating its oil and energy operations. This move follows a request by new CEO Soren Skou to explore a potential breakup in June. The separation aims to improve the group's competitiveness and better address its challenges.

site_title: Hong Kong follows Asian markets higher after Fed leaves rates unchanged
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, following the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged. The Fed signaled potential rate hikes by year-end and reduced its interest rate forecast. Chinese railway stocks jumped after China and Thailand agreed on a 179 billion baht investment in a high-speed railway project. The Hang Seng index ended at 23,759.80, while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.5%. Investors remain cautious despite the positive signals, reflecting a sharp climb in markets over the past two months.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares climb as Federal Reserve leaves rates steady
summary: Australian shares rose for a third consecutive session, boosted by mining stocks, after the US Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. The Reserve Bank of Australia governor, Philip Lowe, expressed optimism about the economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index increased 0.7%, or 34.94 points, to 5,374.5. The US dollar declined, lifting commodity prices.

site_title: Iraq Opec governor says market circumstances right for global oil deal
summary: Iraq's Opec governor Falah Alamri said the current oil market circumstances are favorable for a global oil production pact among Opec and non-Opec producers to support the market when they meet in Algeria on September 26-28. This comes after a failed attempt in Doha in April due to Iran's refusal to restrict its supplies. With some oil producers having regained market share and Iran's output increasing after sanctions were lifted, Alamri believes the time is right for a deal, which could help stabilize the market.

site_title: UK must meet free-movement conditions to stay in EU market
summary: The UK must meet free-movement conditions to maintain access to the EU single market, European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis said. The EU will allow UK financial firms to continue trading freely if the UK doesn't curb EU citizen immigration and pays into the EU budget. The UK must balance voter demands for immigration controls with financial firms' demands to continue trading freely, with Chancellor Philip Hammond considering a potential interim agreement.

site_title: US celebrities take shots at Trump, rally voters to the polls
summary: US celebrities, including Robert Downey Jr and Scarlett Johansson, have released a video urging voters to cast ballots in the upcoming presidential election. The video, launched by the "Save the Day" Super PAC supporting Hillary Clinton, features actors taking shots at Donald Trump while promoting voter turnout. The three-minute video includes references to Trump's policies and character, with one actor joking about giving nuclear weapons to a candidate who "fires things." The video was released just over a week before the election.

site_title: Dubai said to seek US$2.5b loans to expand metro for expo
summary: Dubai is seeking US$2.5 billion in loans to finance a 15km extension of its above-ground metro line to the World Expo site. Two people with knowledge of the plan reported that banks have submitted proposals, including a US$1.34 billion facility backed by European export credit agencies and a US$1.12 billion unsecured, commercial facility guaranteed by the Dubai government. The funding is expected to be provided mainly by international banks, with a 10-year tenor for the commercial loan and an 18-year maturity for the ECA-backed facility.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks finish at two-week highs on Fed decision
summary: The South Korean won reached a two-week high, closing at 1,103.3 to the US dollar, due to the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) also rose 0.7% to 2,049.70, its highest level since September 8. Foreign investors purchased 149.7 billion won worth of Kospi shares, marking five consecutive net buying sessions.

site_title: Singapore SMEs' sentiment sinks to second lowest level in seven years
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are experiencing low business sentiment, with profit expectations sinking to the second lowest level in seven years. The SBF-DP SME Index fell 3.3% to 50.2, citing high costs in Singapore as a major constraint. SMEs are advised to look overseas for growth, particularly in Asean, where the region is expected to experience 5.2% growth over the next five years. This low sentiment reflects the challenges faced by SMEs in Singapore, highlighting the need for support and innovation to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore are downbeat over their prospects for the next six months with profit expectations having sunk to the lowest level in seven years, according to a survey conducted to gauge business sentiment in the SME space.

site_title: Fairytale and army-inspired looks open Milan fashion week
summary: Milan Fashion Week kicked off with Gucci's fairytale-inspired collection featuring layered gowns, gold decorations, and hippy-style outfits, while Fay showcased military-inspired clothing with Asian details and 1970s-style patterns. Designers aimed to appeal to younger generations with fresh looks, as the sector faces weaker demand in Asia and Europe. The Italian fashion sector is expected to grow to 62 billion euros in revenues by the end of 2016, with Italian brands setting fashion trends.

site_title: Just do it: Chinese city tells cadres to set example and have second child
summary: China's Yichang city has posted an open letter urging young government officials to have a second child to boost birth rates and combat a demographic crisis. The city aims to bolster its working population and raise a fertility rate below one child per woman. The move comes as China eases family planning restrictions to allow all couples to have two children. The letter warns that failing to do so will pose huge risks to the city's economic and social development.

site_title: No evidence MH370 'debris' exposed to fire: Australia
summary: Australian authorities say debris from missing passenger jet MH370, found in Madagascar, was not exposed to heat or fire. The Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) examined the fibreglass-honeycomb composite debris, but found no manufacturing identifiers linking it to the Boeing 777. Further investigation is needed to determine the origin of the items, which may be from a Boeing 777 aircraft. The search for MH370, which disappeared in 2014, remains ongoing with no trace found in the current 120,000-square-kilometre search zone.

images.alt_text: Possible debris from missing passenger jet MH370 handed over by a US amateur investigator was not "exposed to heat or fire", Australian authorities said Thursday, following speculation it was blackened by flames.

site_title: Bangkok edges out London as world's top travel destination: Mastercard
summary: Bangkok has been crowned the world's most popular travel destination for 2016, surpassing London according to Mastercard's annual ranking of 132 cities. The Thai capital received 21.47 million international visitors, just ahead of London's 19.88 million. Thailand expects a record 33 million visitors this year, driven by a surge in Chinese tourists. The city's affordability and food quality are cited as key factors in its success, with Bangkok projected to remain a top destination for years to come.

site_title: Saudi-led raids kill 20 civilians in Yemen rebel port: govt official
summary: Saudi-led air strikes killed 20 civilians in Yemen's rebel-held port city of Hodeida, according to a government official. The strikes hit the Suq al Hunod district in the Red Sea port, just hours after rebels celebrated the second anniversary of their seizure of Yemen's capital.

site_title: Taiwan asks Google to blur images showing new South China Sea facilities
summary: Taiwan's defense ministry has asked Google to blur satellite images showing what appear to be new military installations on Itu Aba, a Taiwanese-held island in the South China Sea. The structures, which include four three-pronged structures in a semi-circle, are located near an upgraded airstrip and port facility. The request comes amid growing tensions in the disputed waterway, where China has built military facilities. Taiwan and the US have expressed concerns over China's militarization of the area, while Google has agreed to review the request and has not previously blurred imagery at the request of public agencies.

site_title: China foreign expenditure tops inward investment for first time
summary: China surpassed foreign firms in outward investment for the first time, with $145 billion in overseas direct investment in 2015, exceeding $135.6 billion in foreign direct investment. This milestone is attributed to China's strategy of encouraging firms to "go abroad" and deepen cooperation. The increase is seen as part of Beijing's drive to transform its economic growth model and enhance its comprehensive national power.

images.alt_text: China invested more money abroad last year than foreign firms piled into the country, data showed Thursday, a first for the world's second largest economy as Beijing looks overseas as part of its drive to transform its economic growth model.

site_title: Beware the Chinese property companies that look like shadow banks
summary: China's property developers, such as Greenland Hong Kong Holdings and China Evergrande Group, are expanding their online finance businesses to offer loans and financial products to retail investors, blurring the lines between the financial sector and property market. This deviation from their core real estate business has raised concerns about the opaque nature of internet finance and potential regulatory issues. The lack of government regulation and the difficulty in tracking peer-to-peer lending and leverage employed in these wealth management products have increased worries among analysts.

site_title: Kiwi off 2-week peak on dovish RBNZ, Aussie strong
summary: The New Zealand dollar dropped 0.3% to US$0.7331 after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand maintained its easing bias, despite solid economic activity. The RBNZ left interest rates unchanged, leaving the door open for another cut this year. In contrast, the Australian dollar rose to a two-week high, boosted by the Reserve Bank of Australia's assessment of the economy and a lower US dollar. The kiwi's resilience is adding downward pressure on inflation, while the Aussie is seen reaching 77 US cents in the near future.

site_title: Mexico tax authority to open probe after "Bahamas Leaks"
summary: Mexico's Tax Authority (SAT) will investigate tax violations by over 400 Mexicans named in the "Bahamas Leaks" documents. The leaked cache includes names of lawyers, former officials, and owners of offshore companies in the Bahamas. SAT will review taxpayers who used structures or companies in tax havens, according to a statement. The probe aims to check for tax violations related to the use of such structures.

site_title: China launches probe into sugar imports as trade tensions mount
summary: China has launched a probe into its sugar imports amid rising domestic industry complaints, with a six-month investigation into possible protectionist measures by foreign countries. The move follows lobbying by China's sugar mills, which have struggled with high local prices and rising farming costs. The investigation targets imports since 2011 and may lead to protectionist measures, as trade tensions between major commodities producers intensify, following recent disputes over China's price supports for grain farmers and exports of excess aluminium and steel production.

site_title: Buy, hold & lose: how commodities roll is undercutting investors
summary: Investors in commodity index funds are experiencing significant losses in 2016, despite rallies in raw materials such as sugar, gold, and soybeans. The Bloomberg Commodity Index is up 16% this year, but the total return for funds linked to the gauge is only about half that amount. This disparity is due to the practice of "rolling" futures contracts, which involves buying and selling commodities at different prices. The resulting expense, known as the "roll yield," has widened to minus 11.5% in some cases, resulting in significant losses for investors.

site_title: US companies lag in race to tap Africa's growth potential
summary: US companies are lagging behind in tapping Africa's growth potential, despite the continent's expanding middle class, untapped mineral riches, and arable land. The US has reinforced its vision of an Africa on rise, but only 1% of total US trade came from sub-Saharan Africa in 2016. Foreign direct investment into Africa fell to $71.3 billion last year, down from $88.5 billion in 2014. Despite this, African leaders and investors are optimistic, with Nigeria's Buhari and Ivory Coast's Ouattara welcoming foreign capital and implementing policies to attract investment.

site_title: Oil rises on US stockpile drop, weaker dollar
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, building on previous gains, following a bigger-than-expected drop in US stockpiles and a weaker dollar. US oil inventories fell by over six million barrels, alleviating concerns of a glut, and a weaker dollar made oil cheaper for holders of other currencies. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 45 cents to $45.79, while Brent added 48 cents to $47.31. The Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates on hold also supported the rally.

site_title: VW agrees to 'action plan' for diesel-car owners after EU talks
summary: Volkswagen AG agreed to an EU-wide action plan to repair diesel-emissions affected vehicles, following EU regulators backing down from demands for consumer compensation. The plan, announced after EU Justice and Consumer Affairs Commissioner Vera Jourova met with VW's Francisco Javier Garcia Sanz, will inform customers and repair vehicles. This comes after criticism from consumer groups over the disparity in packages offered to American and European car owners.

site_title: RBA's Lowe says Australia likely to avoid unconventional policy
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe stated that the central bank is unlikely to resort to unconventional monetary policy measures, instead focusing on a flexible inflation target that accounts for financial imbalances. Lowe emphasized the strong case for infrastructure spending to support growth, citing a strong economy with above-average growth and low unemployment. He also noted that while interest rates and wage growth are at record lows, inflation variability is inevitable and acceptable, and the central bank is watching the housing market closely.

site_title: China conditionally lifts import ban on some US beef
summary: China has conditionally lifted an import ban on some US boneless beef and beef on the bone, subject to completion of quarantine requirements. The ban applies to imports under 30 months old, with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang previously announcing the country would allow imports of beef on the bone from the US. The move aims to increase US beef exports to China, which have been impacted by the ban. The exact details of the quarantine requirements will be issued later.

site_title: Australia central bank governor Lowe says further cut in interest rates possible
summary: Australian central bank governor Philip Lowe stated that further interest rate cuts may be possible, depending on several factors. The Reserve Bank of Australia has already lowered rates in May and August to stimulate inflation and curb a rising currency, setting the cash rate at a record low of 1.5%.

images.alt_text: Australian central bank governor Philip Lowe said on Thursday further cut in interest rates was possible, depending on a number of factors.

site_title: Beyond plastic: Design world goes green and 'meaningful'
summary: The design world is shifting towards sustainable and eco-friendly production, with designers and architects embracing "green" and "meaningful" design. French architect Patrick Nadeau's environmentally friendly social housing project in Reims, France, is a prime example of this trend. The concept, which incorporates plants and natural materials, harks back to the 1920s and 1970s oil crisis, when visionary architects advocated for "less is more" and anticipatory design. Luxury firms like Kartell and Hermes are also joining the trend, launching biodegradable products and upcycling old materials. The "Slow Design" movement, which emphasizes long-term sustainability, is gaining popularity, with designers like Julien Phedyaff creating products that are meant to last and reduce waste.

site_title: Biden sees 'less than even chance' of US Congress approving TPP deal
summary: Vice President Joe Biden expressed doubt about the US Congress approving the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, stating it's a "less than even chance" before the next administration takes office in January. The deal, which has been opposed by both presidential candidates, would be passed during the brief "lame duck" session of Congress after the election. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Speaker Paul Ryan have also expressed skepticism about the deal's passage.

site_title: PSL to place new shares with three Malindo Exim directors to raise S$2.9m
summary: PSL Holdings, a Singapore-listed engineering services provider, has entered into a private subscription agreement to raise S$2.9 million by issuing 7.7 million new shares to three directors of Malaysia's Malindo Exim Sdn Bhd at S$0.3825 each, a 10% discount to the previous day's volume-weighted average price. The funds will be used for growth, expansion, and working capital purposes.

site_title: Loan for embattled shipper Hanjin sends stock soaring
summary: South Korea's Hanjin Shipping, the world's seventh-largest shipper, has received a 60 billion won loan from its largest shareholder, Korean Air, to help alleviate its US$5.37 billion debt. The loan, backed by Hanjin Shipping's accounts receivable, comes after the company entered court receivership and creditors rejected its self-rescue plan. The news sent Hanjin's share price soaring 29.6% and Korean Air's up 5.9%. Hanjin must submit a business revival plan by November 25 under the receivership.

images.alt_text: The largest shareholder in South Korea's Hanjin Shipping has agreed to provide an emergency loan to the cash-strapped firm, sending its share price soaring some 30 per cent Thursday.

site_title: New violence breaks out in southern US city of Charlotte
summary: Violence erupted in Charlotte, North Carolina for a second night as police clashed with protesters following the fatal police shooting of black man Keith Lamont Scott, 43. Riot police fired tear gas, and a man fell to the ground with blood on the sidewalk. Earlier, hundreds marched to the police headquarters, chanting "No Justice! No Peace!" and demanding law enforcement reforms. Tensions have been building among the local black community, with many calling for greater accountability.

site_title: Asia: Shares surge, US dollar lags on slow-motion Federal Reserve
summary: Asian shares surged on Thursday, led by a 0.9% gain in MSCI's Asia-Pacific index, following the Federal Reserve's decision to leave US interest rates unchanged and slow future hikes. The US dollar weakened, and commodity prices rose as investors anticipated a more dovish Fed. The Fed signaled it could hike rates by year-end but cut its longer-run interest rate forecast to 2.9%.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose after the Federal Reserve's decision not to lift interest rates. The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.06% to 23,920.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.41% to 3,038.42. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.55%. The rally followed the Fed's decision, with investors cheering the move.

site_title: US SEC charges thrust billionaire Cooperman into spotlight
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has charged billionaire Leon Cooperman and his hedge fund, Omega Advisors, with illegal trading in Atlas Pipeline Partners six years ago. Cooperman, 73, denies the allegations, which could tarnish his 50-year career as a stock picker. Despite the SEC's charges, Cooperman's investment firm has averaged annual gains of 11.2% since its inception, and he is estimated to be worth $3.1 billion. Cooperman has been known for his value investing skills and outspoken opinions, and his reputation is being scrutinized by regulators.

site_title: Bradxit: London's Madame Tussauds separates Jolie and Pitt wax figures
summary: London's Madame Tussauds museum has separated its wax figure replicas of Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt, mirroring the couple's announced separation and plans for divorce. The figures, launched in 2013, are now displayed at a respectful distance from each other. Jolie is featured with Nicole Kidman, while Pitt is shown with Morgan Freeman. The move reflects the attraction's decision to reflect real-life events.

site_title: Brexit to hurt London hotels as business travellers to stay home
summary: London hotels face a decline in occupancy rates due to companies cutting travel budgets amid concerns about the UK's economic growth post-Brexit. According to PricewaterhouseCoopers, occupancy rates in 2017 will fall to 80% and Revpar will decline by 2.8% this year and 0.5% in 2017. A drop in business travelers will disproportionately affect hotels, with over 3.7 million people visiting London for business in 2016. The hotel industry also faces increased competition from Airbnb, with 7,200 new rooms set to be added to the market.

site_title: Carlyle sues China ATM firm seeking US$369m over missed IPO
summary: Carlyle Group LP funds have filed a winding-up petition against Chinese ATM company ATMU Inc, seeking US$368.9 million over a missed initial public offering (IPO) deadline. The Hong Kong-based funds claim ATMU failed to list within four years of their 2010 investment. ATMU has not responded to redemption notices and is trying to find ways for investors to exit, according to the company. A court hearing will take place in the Cayman Islands on November 10.

images.alt_text: Carlyle Group LP funds are taking legal action against Chinese automated teller machine company ATMU Inc, claiming to be owed US$368.9 million after ATMU allegedly missed a four-year deadline for an initial public offering.

site_title: Bill Clinton delivers defence of his foundation's 'profound' work
summary: Former US President Bill Clinton defended his family's charitable foundation, saying its work has had a "profound advance" in modern philanthropy. The foundation has faced criticism, including allegations of breaching government ethics rules, as Clinton's wife Hillary campaigns for president. Clinton expressed frustration over media focus on donors rather than charitable programs, but acknowledged the foundation would limit operations if Hillary wins the election, including stopping donations from foreign and corporate donors.

site_title: World's best performing tech fund is finally betting on Facebook
summary: DNB Nordic Technology, the world's top-performing tech fund, has started buying Facebook shares after reevaluating its valuation. The fund's managers believe the stock is now attractive due to its estimated adjusted price-to-earnings ratio of 32.6 this year, which is expected to fall to 20.1 in 2018. They see potential for growth in Facebook's business areas outside the core application, particularly with its 1 billion+ users in Messenger and WhatsApp. The fund now holds 2.9% in Facebook, marking its first investment in the social media giant.

site_title: Apple's talks with McLaren, Lit Motors show roads to car product
summary: Apple is exploring strategic partnerships with McLaren and Lit Motors to aid in its car product development. McLaren, a luxury carmaker, would provide a top brand name, high-end buyers, and research-and-development strategy. Lit Motors, a startup developing an electric vehicle, would offer expertise in components and a platform for other automakers. The partnerships would complement Apple's existing efforts on Project Titan, a car project led by hundreds of engineers and a Jony Ive-led industrial design team.

site_title: New Zealand dairy giant Fonterra whips up bumper profit
summary: Fonterra, New Zealand's largest dairy exporter, reported a 65% rise in annual net profit to NZ$834 million, despite challenging global market conditions. The company attributed the increase to cost-cutting measures, including job losses, and efforts to add value to its products. Fonterra's revenue declined 9% to NZ$17.2 billion, but the company lifted its 2016/17 milk price forecast to NZ$5.25 a kilogram, up 65 cents. This is above the break-even payout of NZ$5.00 a kilogram.

site_title: Australian shares surge as Fed keeps rates steady; NZ regains ground
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Thursday, driven by mining and banking stocks, after the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,381.4 points, with mining stocks like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto jumping 3-3.2% and gold stocks rising 6.1%. Reserve Bank of Australia governor Philip Lowe gave an optimistic assessment of the economy, citing growth driven by rate cuts and stable commodity prices. New Zealand's benchmark index also recovered, rising 0.6%.

site_title: Mylan blasted for raising EpiPen prices to get 'filthy rich'
summary: Mylan CEO Heather Bresch faced scrutiny from lawmakers over the company's $19 million pay package and $600 price tag for a two-pack of EpiPen allergy shots. Lawmakers questioned her honesty and ethics, accusing Mylan of downplaying profits while paying senior executives millions. Despite claims that the company only makes $50 in profit per device, lawmakers say Mylan is taking advantage of the healthcare system. The committee ordered Bresch to provide more information within 10 days, and lawmakers predict little will change.

site_title: US tests for mustard agent after rocket attack near Iraq base
summary: The US military is testing for the use of a chemical agent after a rocket attack near the Qayyara West base in Iraq, where hundreds of US forces are stationed. A rocket fell within hundreds of yards of US forces on Tuesday, injuring no one, and a suspicious "tar-like, black, oily" substance was found. Initial tests revealed the substance tested positive for mustard agent, but subsequent tests showed it was negative. The US forces underwent decontamination procedures as a precaution, but no injuries or symptoms were reported.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks jump as Fed signals slow rate-hike approach
summary: The South Korean won and shares rose sharply after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates on hold and signaled a slow pace of future hikes. The won increased 1.4% to 1,104.5, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 1% to 2,055.70 points. The Fed cut its longer-run interest rate forecast to 2.9% and reduced the number of rate increases expected in 2017 and 2018. This move is expected to support the won's strength and volatile trading in the months leading up to the US presidential election.

site_title: Suitcases of cash: China travel data hint at capital outflow
summary: Chinese tourists' spending abroad has surged, with a tourism deficit of $206 billion in 2016, up from $77 billion in 2013. This disparity suggests disguised capital outflows, where Chinese citizens are shifting cash to buy homes, life insurance, or deposit accounts overseas. Former US Treasury official Brad Setser says this is bad news for the global economy, as it reduces demand for Chinese goods and services. The discrepancy is likely due to China's revised balance of payments data and the use of credit card spending, with some outflows disguised as other transactions.

site_title: Singapore shares open 22 points higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 22.17 points higher at 2,872.91 on Thursday, with 118 counters up and 21 down. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US interest rates remaining unchanged, which supported a rally in US markets. The key index has now recorded a 5-day rally.

site_title: Julius Baer CEO says Asia revenue may top Europe in 5 years
summary: Julius Baer CEO Boris Collardi predicts that Asia may surpass Europe as the bank's largest revenue-generating region within the next five years, driven by double-digit growth rates. Asia currently contributes 20% of the bank's revenue, up from 10% in 2011. Julius Baer plans to hire over 200 new bankers in Asia, with more than half based in Hong Kong and Singapore. The bank has expanded in Asia to tap into the growing number of wealthy individuals in the region, but has been cautious about acquiring other private banks due to regulatory risks.

images.alt_text: Julius Baer Group Ltd said Asia may overtake Europe as its biggest revenue-generating region, as the Swiss wealth manager steps up hiring in Hong Kong and Singapore.

site_title: Marco Polo seeks noteholders' consent to defer notes' redemption until 2019
summary: MARCO Polo Marine is seeking noteholders' consent to defer the redemption of its S$50 million notes until October 2019, with the option to include its Batam land as security and pay 1.5% interest in two installments. The firm has reported a net loss of S$7.5 million for the nine months ended June 2016, citing lower vessel utilization rates and charter rates. Marco Polo Marine expects to record net losses for the fiscal year ending September 2016 and may struggle to meet debt service obligations due to high leverage.

images.alt_text: Marco Polo Marine has launched a consent solicitation exercise for its S$50 million notes due next month to seek noteholders' approval to defer the redemption of its debt papers by three years to October 2019.

site_title: Zuckerberg fund pledges US$3b to banish disease
summary: Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Priscilla Chan have pledged $3 billion over the next decade to help banish or manage all disease, aiming to cure all disease or turn catastrophic illnesses into manageable or preventable conditions within their daughter's lifetime. The Chan Zuckerberg Initiative will invest $600 million in a Biohub in San Francisco to develop tools for disease research and understanding. The effort is part of a broader goal to advance human potential and promote equality, with the goal of achieving the objective by the end of this century.

site_title: South Korean won jumps with Malaysian ringgit as Fed holds fire
summary: South Korea's won surged 1.8% to 1,100.95 against the US dollar, its strongest level since September 9, after the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady and reduced forecasts for future increases. Malaysia's ringgit rose 0.9% to 4.1005 per US dollar, its largest gain since August 10. The move was supported by an overnight jump in Brent crude and the Fed's downward revision of interest rate expectations, with policy makers now expecting two rate increases in 2017 instead of three.

site_title: Indonesia palm exports seen climbing most in 22 months on China
summary: Indonesia's palm oil exports likely surged 20% in August to 1.92 million metric tons, the largest increase in 22 months, driven by China's increased imports ahead of the mid-Autumn festival. Shipments may continue to rise due to speculation of low inventories in Indonesia and Malaysia. Indonesian production rose 1.4% to 2.82 million tons, while inventories increased 1.1% to 1.9 million tons, according to analysts and plantation executives. The increase in exports and production is attributed to the return of rains in northern regions of Indonesia.

site_title: Ericsson plans to stop manufacturing in Sweden, cutting 3,000 jobs: media
summary: Ericsson plans to close its last Swedish manufacturing sites, cutting around 3,000 jobs, as demand stagnates in developed markets. The company, which has 120,000 employees worldwide, will end 140 years of production in Sweden. The affected jobs are in the network products division, the company's biggest business area. This move follows Ericsson's decision to double cuts in operating expenses to adapt to a weaker market, resulting in annual savings of 10 billion Swedish crowns (S$1.6 billion).

site_title: Suu Kyi pledges to uphold rights in UN debut
summary: Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's de facto leader, made her UN debut pledging to promote human rights in Rakhine state, where thousands of Rohingya Muslims are displaced. She refused to recognize the Rohingya by name and instead backed a commission to advise on the state. Suu Kyi met with President Barack Obama and agreed to scrap remaining sanctions against Myanmar. Western supporters are dismayed by her stance, citing domestic pressure in Myanmar against the Rohingya. Suu Kyi's delicate relationship with Myanmar's generals and her decision to use "Myanmar" instead of "Burma" sparked attention.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 2.48 points to 1661.23. Gainers outnumbered losers 122 to 33, with a total volume of 28.7 million lots worth RM12.2 million.

site_title: Viacom won't sell Paramount stake; interim CEO leaving
summary: Viacom has abandoned its plan to sell a stake in Paramount Pictures, citing a desire to consider all options. Interim CEO Tom Dooley is stepping down after presenting a strategic plan that was met with skepticism. The move comes amid a power struggle between Viacom's leadership, led by Shari Redstone, and former CEO Philippe Dauman. Viacom also cut its dividend in half and slashed its earnings forecast due to a charge related to an unreleased film. The company will continue to search for a new CEO, with Dooley staying on through November 15.

site_title: Satellite tracking could prevent airliner disappearances, developers say
summary: US companies FlightAware and Aireon have developed a satellite tracking system to prevent airliner disappearances, similar to the Malaysia Airlines MH370 incident. The system, called GlobalBeacon, beams tracking signals to low orbit satellites, providing real-time location data to airlines. Expected to be operational from 2018, it aims to meet the International Civil Aviation Organization's (ICAO) 15-minute tracking standard. The first airline customer will be announced next week, with the system initially conceived to improve air traffic routing efficiency. This technology could potentially prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Malaysia's RM70b transport binge spurs Islamic bond sales
summary: Malaysia's government has boosted spending to stimulate its economy, expected to grow at its slowest pace since 2009. The Prime Minister's spending has encouraged Islamic bond sales, with RHB Investment Bank and AmInvestment Bank forecasting a 7-10% increase in Malaysian corporate sukuk issuance to RM60.2 billion and RM70 billion, respectively. This comes after the Bank Negara Malaysia's monetary easing in July and the launch of a $16 billion infrastructure project. As a result, Malaysian sovereign sukuk yields have fallen to their lowest since 2013.

images.alt_text: Top underwriters see Malaysian corporate sukuk sales rebounding from a four-year low as Prime Minister Najib Razak ramps up spending to boost an economy forecast to grow at the slowest pace since 2009.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime tweaks plan to restructure S$100m notes with debt-to-equity swap
summary: Rickmers Maritime has revised its restructuring plan for its S$100 million 8.45% notes due 2017, following feedback from noteholders. The plan includes a partial redemption of S$60 million of principal in exchange for 60% of enlarged units, reducing outstanding principal to S$40 million, repayable in November 2023. The proposal also includes a debt-to-equity swap, with a new facility of about US$260.2 million and extended maturities of secured bank debts to the first quarter of 2021, aiming to provide the trust with a longer runway to survive the industry downturn.

site_title: Fuel-economy rules threaten one million US jobs, study says
summary: A new study by the Center for Automotive Research found that over 1.1 million US jobs could be lost due to tougher fuel-economy regulations, set to reach 54.5 miles per gallon by 2025, if gas prices remain low. The study analyzed nine scenarios with varying fuel prices and technology costs, concluding that eight cases would result in significant job losses. Automakers are already struggling to meet the fuel economy targets in a low gas-price environment, with some petitioning for relief from regulations starting in 2022.

site_title: NZ's central bank stands pat but keeps door open to easing
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), kept its benchmark interest rate at 2% despite expectations of a rate cut. The decision, made on September 22, 2016, was seen as a surprise by economists, who had polled widely expecting a rate cut. However, the RBNZ left the door open for a cut later this year, citing the need for further policy easing to achieve inflation near the target range of 1-3%. The decision followed the Bank of Japan's policy overhaul and the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep rates ultra-low.

site_title: US Senate clears way for US$1.15b arms sale to Saudi Arabia
summary: The US Senate voted 71-27 to clear the way for a $1.15 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia, including 130 Abrams battle tanks and other equipment. The sale was defended by lawmakers citing Saudi Arabia's importance as a US ally in the Middle East, despite criticism over its role in the Yemen war and human rights record. The Senate vote stopped an effort to block the deal led by Senators Rand Paul and Chris Murphy, who cited concerns about fueling an arms race and supporting extremist groups.

images.alt_text: The US Senate cleared the way for a US$1.15 billion sale of tanks and other military equipment to Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, defending a frequent partner in the Middle East recently subject to harsh criticism in Congress.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing granted US license to sell planes to Iran
summary: Airbus and Boeing received US licenses to sell planes to Iran Air, allowing the companies to proceed with sales worth billions of dollars. The licenses, issued by the US Treasury Department, contain strict conditions to ensure the planes are used exclusively for commercial passenger use. Boeing is set to sell 80 planes, including 29 leased to Iran Air, with an estimated value of $25 billion. Airbus also received a license for 118 aircraft, valued at $10 billion, following a preliminary agreement in January.

site_title: New Zealand keeps interest rates at record low
summary: New Zealand's central bank maintained interest rates at a record low of 2.0% despite inflation remaining below the target range. Governor Graeme Wheeler warned of further policy easing to ensure future inflation settles near the target range. The decision comes after the bank trimmed its base rate by 0.25 points in August. Market watchers expect a potential cut to 1.75% at the next meeting in November. The bank is cautious about cutting rates too aggressively due to concerns over a house price boom in Auckland.

site_title: Twitter sees jump in official requests to remove posts
summary: Twitter reported a 13% increase in official requests to remove posts in the first half of 2016, with Turkey and Russia leading the pack. The company received 4,434 content removal requests and 761 court orders, targeting 20,594 accounts. The US made 98 removal requests, with 1 granted, and 2,520 account information requests, with 82% compliance. Twitter cited privacy concerns for blocking US intelligence from accessing data to prevent violent attacks.

site_title: Schools in Canada province closed by threat, but no device found
summary: Canadian police evacuated all 62 schools in Prince Edward Island after a bomb threat, but no explosive device was found. About 19,000 students were taken to safe locations. The threat was received by fax and claimed bombs had been placed in schools, set to detonate, but no specific time was given. Authorities said the situation was under control, with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau confirming all students and personnel were safe. Separate threats were reported in Nova Scotia and the US, but no immediate link was established.

site_title: With Fed on hold, South-east Asia seen diverging on rate policies
summary: South-east Asian central banks are expected to diverge on rate policies following the US Federal Reserve's decision to hold off on raising interest rates. Bank Indonesia is set to cut its policy rate on Thursday, while the Philippines' central bank is forecast to keep rates steady amid concerns of price pressures from a rapidly growing economy. Economists predict that Bank Indonesia will lower its benchmark rate to 5% from 5.25%, while the Philippines' central bank is expected to maintain its rate of 3%. The divergent approaches may be influenced by the differing growth risks faced by the two countries.

site_title: Heat rises on Wells Fargo CEO after lawmaker grilling
summary: Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf faced criticism after testifying before US lawmakers about a scandal involving 2 million fake accounts created in customers' names. Despite his claims of taking responsibility, critics argue that his responses fell flat and lack accountability. The scandal has led to a $190 million settlement, with $5 million going directly to affected customers. Analysts and investors suggest that the scandal may not significantly impact Wells Fargo's bottom line or share price, with the bank's biggest investor, Warren Buffett, declining to comment.

site_title: Yellen rejects Trump charges that Fed plays politics
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen denied accusations from Donald Trump that the Fed plays politics with its interest rate policy. Yellen stated that partisan politics has no role in the Fed's decisions, emphasizing that discussions about politics do not occur at meetings and are not considered in decision-making. The Fed left interest rates unchanged, following Trump's claim that Yellen was suppressing rates to boost President Barack Obama's popularity.

site_title: Benefits of using electric vehicles depend on where charging takes place
summary: Electric vehicles' environmental impact varies greatly depending on the location where they're charged. In regions with low-carbon energy sources, EVs significantly reduce emissions. However, in areas reliant on coal, the difference is smaller. On average, EVs produce 40-50% less pollution than fossil-fuel cars, but this benefit can vary greatly depending on the energy mix and location.

site_title: Gold at 1-1/2-week high after Fed holds rates steady
summary: Gold prices rose to 1-1/2-week highs on Wednesday, reaching $1,330.08 an ounce, after the US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady but signaled potential policy tightening before the end of 2016. Three Fed policy makers dissented on the statement, favoring a rate hike, but the dovishness in the Summary of Economic Projections drove markets. The US dollar index fell, and other precious metals, such as silver, platinum, and palladium, also gained.

site_title: Oil jumps after third surprise weekly US crude draw
summary: Oil prices surged 3% after a third surprise weekly drop in US crude stockpiles, boosting demand outlook. The US dollar weakened after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, supporting US dollar-denominated crude. An oil workers' strike in Norway also threatened to cut North Sea crude output. US crude inventories fell 6.2 million barrels last week, contrasting with higher Opec output. Brent crude futures rose 2%, and US WTI crude futures rose 2.9%. Despite high US stockpiles, some traders expect prices to rise further.

site_title: Beijing gives nod to Marriott's deal to buy Starwood
summary: China's Ministry of Commerce approved Marriott International's deal to buy Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide, clearing the way for the combined company to become the world's largest hotel chain. The deal, valued at $36 billion, will give Marriott greater access to European and Latin American markets and help compete with Airbnb. The merged group will have over 5,500 hotels with 1.1 million rooms. This approval was the last remaining merger clearance for the deal, following approvals from over 40 countries, including the US and Canada.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits record as Fed keeps rates low
summary: US stocks surged on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite index hitting a fresh record after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates low. The Nasdaq jumped 1.0% to 5,295.18, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.9% and the S&P 500 gained 1.1%. The Fed maintained its ultralow federal funds rate and trimmed its forecast for US economic growth, but expressed confidence in the economy. Key stocks, including Amazon, eBay, and Yahoo, saw significant gains.

site_title: Greater focus on India helps Singapore hedge funds outperform Asian rivals
summary: Singapore-based hedge funds outperformed Asian rivals in the first seven months of 2016, thanks to a focus on India and global markets. Funds headquartered in Singapore returned 2% compared to Hong Kong-based funds' 2.3% decline, while Japan-based funds fell 2.5%. India's S&P BSE Sensex Index rose 9.4% this year, contributing to the success of Singapore-focused funds.

site_title: Japanese yen gains despite BoJ move; Fed stance weakens dollar
summary: The Japanese yen strengthened against the dollar on Wednesday despite the Bank of Japan's efforts to lower its value. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady, but indicated a potential hike by December. The BoJ set new long bond yield targets to stimulate inflation. Meanwhile, the dollar eased as the Fed's stance weakened. The dollar's decline was attributed to the Fed's indication of a potential rate hike by December, which could weaken the dollar.

images.alt_text: The Japanese yen strengthened on Wednesday despite the Bank of Japan's effort to hammer it down with new long bond yield targets.

site_title: Vard Holdings secures US$40m contract to build two vessels
summary: VARD Holdings secured a US$40 million contract to design and construct two module carrier vessels (MCVs) for Topaz Energy and Marine, with delivery scheduled for the second quarter of 2018. The vessels are sister ships of 15 identical MCVs previously contracted by Topaz, and will be built in Vard's shipyards in Romania and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Vard Holdings has bagged a US$40 million contract for the design and construction of two more module carrier vessels (MCVs) for Topaz Energy and Marine.

site_title: China paves way for major govt influx into venture capital
summary: China's State Council is encouraging government agencies and companies to invest in private startups through venture capital, aiming to create a more vibrant market and promote the nation's technology boom. The government wants to level the playing field for foreign venture capitalists and improve the environment for VC exits. China is already a major player in technology deals, with government-backed venture funds managing over $448 billion in assets. The new guidelines aim to prevent investment bubbles and illegal fund-raising, while also easing entry for foreign VC firms.

site_title: US dollar falls as on-hold Fed casts doubt over pace of rate hikes
summary: The US dollar fell after the Federal Reserve left its interest-rate target unchanged, casting doubt on the pace of rate hikes through the end of next year. The Fed's "dot plot" showed policy makers expect one quarter-point rate increase this year and just two next year, weakening the dollar against major peers. Emerging-market currencies strengthened, and traders questioned the resolve of Fed policy makers to raise interest rates. The Bloomberg US dollar Spot Index fell 0.7% as of 5pm in New York, with the greenback losing 0.3% to US$1.1189 per euro and 1.4% to 100.32 yen.

site_title: Fed leaves rates unchanged, signals 2016 hike still likely
summary: The Federal Reserve left its interest rates unchanged for the sixth consecutive meeting, signaling that an increase is still likely by year-end. The Fed's decision, made on September 21, 2016, was based on the view that near-term risks to the economic outlook are balanced, but progress toward its goals has strengthened. Three officials dissented in favor of a quarter-point hike, while the central bank's "dot plot" showed officials expected one quarter-point rate increase this year. The Fed projects two rate hikes next year, down from its June median projection of three.

images.alt_text: A divided Federal Reserve left its policy rate unchanged for a sixth straight meeting, saying it would wait for more evidence of progress toward its goals, while projecting that an increase is still likely by year-end.

site_title: EU scraps time limit on free mobile roaming plan
summary: The EU has scrapped the 90-day limit on its free mobile roaming plan, allowing operators to crack down on users who significantly exceed domestic calls when abroad. Instead, operators can cancel SIM cards used almost exclusively abroad and implement safeguards on residency. The proposal goes to EU national regulators for negotiation, with the goal of implementing the plan by June 15, 2026. This decision comes after consumer groups criticized the original 90-day limit, which was seen as a compromise to telecoms companies.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping gets 60b won loan to unload stranded cargo
summary: Hanjin Shipping, the world's seventh-largest container carrier, has secured a 60 billion won (S$73 million) loan from its largest shareholder, Korean Air Lines, to unload stranded cargo. The loan is in addition to 40 billion won provided by the Hanjin Group's chairman, but still falls short of the estimated 173 billion won needed to unload all cargo. A court has expressed doubts about Hanjin's ability to survive a restructuring, citing its high debt of 6 trillion won and top priority debt exceeding 1 trillion won.

images.alt_text: The largest shareholder of Hanjin Shipping Ltd agreed on Wednesday to lend 60 billion won (S$73 million) to help unload cargo that has been stranded since the world's seventh-largest container carrier collapsed late last month.

site_title: Indian ministers approve Rafale fighter jet deal
summary: India's cabinet committee on security approved a deal for the purchase of 36 Rafale fighter jets from France, worth around $8.8 billion, to counter China's growing military clout. The deal, which was first mooted in 2012, was delayed due to disagreements over the cost and offset clause. The Indian and French defense ministers will sign the agreement on September 23. The purchase is expected to modernize India's air force and provide a boost to the country's military capabilities.

images.alt_text: An Indian cabinet commitee gave its approval Wednesday to a long-delayed deal for the purchase of 36 fighter jets from France's Dassault, as the country looks to counter China's growing military clout.

site_title: 90 companies join initiative for excellence in governance
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 7th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2016, a week-long program from September 26-30, 2016, to promote good corporate governance standards. 90 companies have joined the initiative, signing a statement of support to uphold high standards of corporate governance and enhance shareholder value. The event is endorsed by several organizations, including The Association of Banks Singapore and the Singapore Exchange, and aims to promote transparency and accountability in corporate governance.

site_title: Developer pays record 12,517 yuan psm for southern China land
summary: China's southern manufacturing hub Dongguan sold a 42,500 sq m plot of land for a record 12,517 yuan (S$2,549) per square meter, more than five times the starting price. This sale, won by Times Property Holdings, is part of a bidding frenzy that saw six developers compete for the land. The sale price is the highest ever recorded in the area, contributing to concerns over China's property market being at risk of overheating.

site_title: Europe: Banks and miners help European stocks to end higher
summary: European shares rose to a one-week high, driven by a rally in banks and miners following the Bank of Japan's policy overhaul, which lifted risky assets globally. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.4% higher, while the European banking index rose 2%. Banks such as Spain's Banco Popular and Natixis jumped 9.1% and 4.1% respectively. Miners like Anglo American and Rio Tinto also saw gains, while Ocado Group fell 5.3% after a rating cut. The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged, with no signal of a hike by the end of the year.

site_title: Temasek unit calls for greater cooperation in SEA LNG market
summary: A Singaporean energy company, Pavilion Energy, has emphasized the need for regional cooperation in the South-east Asia liquefied natural gas (LNG) market. At a conference, CEO Seah Moon Ming stated that the industry's capital-intensive nature and diverse value chain require collaboration between governments and private sectors. Pavilion Energy also announced a tie-up with ExxonMobil on LNG bunkering and downstream developments in Singapore.

site_title: Baosteel-Wuhan merger unlikely to cut steel industry's overcapacity
summary: China's Baosteel and Wuhan Iron & Steel Group Corp have agreed to merge, creating the nation's biggest mill and rivaling ArcelorMittal SA. However, analysts see little chance of the deal resulting in capacity cuts, as the companies plan to start new, more efficient plants. The global steel industry remains plagued by overcapacity, with China aiming to cut 150 million tonnes by 2020. The merger is unlikely to address the issue, and other deals are on the cards to establish two major steel groups in China.

site_title: Singapore households 10th richest in the world: Allianz report
summary: Singapore households ranked 10th globally in terms of per capita net financial assets, with a growth rate of 5.7% in 2015. Despite a 4.5% growth in total financial assets, the report notes that the good years may be over due to a decline in asset growth and interest rates. Singapore households have a gross financial asset per capita of 114,160 euros. The Allianz Global Wealth Report attributes the slowdown to the loss of impact of extreme monetary policy and the slide of interest rates into negative territory.

site_title: More brokers restrict ISR Capital trading
summary: Singaporean brokerages Phillip Securities and OCBC Securities have restricted trades in investment firm ISR Capital due to a massive rally in the stock, which may be at risk of reversing. The stock fell 11.8% on Wednesday after hitting an intraday high of S$0.285, with some brokers imposing Internet trading prohibitions and limits on contra trading. The restrictions are aimed at controlling credit exposure, with larger clients requiring approval from credit officers. The Singapore Exchange is also moving towards a shorter settlement period and implementing a 5% collateral requirement for securities trading in 2018.

site_title: Postal Savings Bank of China prices IPO at low end of expectations
summary: Postal Savings Bank of China priced its Hong Kong IPO at US$7.4 billion, near the low end of expectations, valuing 12.1 billion new shares at HK$4.76 each. The bank sought to bolster its balance sheet and fund future lending growth. It is the world's biggest IPO since Alibaba Group in 2014, but investors baulked at valuations higher than domestic rivals. The deal is valued at 1.1% underwriting commission and 0.5% incentive fee, with 26 banks earning up to US$118.4 million in fees.

site_title: Insurance agents' days far from over, says AIA
summary: AIA, a Hong Kong-based insurer, says insurance agents are still relevant despite declining new business from tied agents. The company's regional CEO, Ng Keng Hooi, notes that bancassurance products are easier to sell, while financial advisers focus on mutual fund products. AIA considers setting up a financial advisory firm, but focuses on protection products, citing the need to avoid recommending high-margin plans. The insurer's agency force in Singapore is the second-largest, with 4,200 agents, and has delivered significant growth in new business and premiums per active agent.

site_title: Airbus plans management changes: sources
summary: Airbus Group is planning management changes, including appointing Fabrice Bregier as chief operating officer and president of Airbus Commercial, to refocus the company and cut costs. The move aims to ease tensions between CEO Tom Enders and Bregier, and will involve sweeping away overlapping functions and redefining unit responsibilities. Other senior managers may be given group-wide roles, and the company is considering a rebranding to simplify its structure and operations. The changes are part of a broader effort to unify the company and prepare for global competition.

images.alt_text: The company is considering whether to complete its rebranding by calling the whole group "Airbus" and getting rid of the planemaking unit's separate French "SAS" corporate structure.

site_title: Only small number of dual-class listings expected
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) expects a limited number of dual-class listings, with its Listings Advisory Committee (LAC) proposing safeguards to mitigate governance concerns. The committee, formed to address concerns of a conflicted regulator, will vet listings applicants and impose a maximum voting differential of 10:1. Despite concerns, the LAC believes good governance can be ensured through security laws, shareholder activists, and independent directors, and notes that one-share, one-vote companies also have their own governance risks. SGX will conduct a public consultation before deciding on the issue.

site_title: HK regulator cracks whip on lax anti-money laundering controls
summary: The Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is investigating licensed brokerages for inadequate anti-money laundering controls, with some expected to face cases. The SFC directed brokerages to tighten controls after on-site inspections revealed shortcomings, including failure to scrutinize cash deposits. The crackdown comes amid heightened scrutiny of illicit money flow in Hong Kong, following high-profile cases and the leaked "Panama Papers" which showed Hong Kong's active role in creating shell firms. The SFC aims to comply with anti-money laundering rules that came into force in 2012.

site_title: From carrying wads of cash to mobile money
summary: Myanmar is experiencing a financial revival, with mobile banking services becoming increasingly accessible to its population. The country's embryonic banking system has led to the introduction of mobile money, allowing citizens like maid Khin Myint Oo to transfer money to her children in minutes. Wave Money, a mobile banking firm, has built a network of 4,000 shops across the country where clients can deposit and withdraw cash by phone. The government's regulations allowing non-banks to enter the e-money market have also contributed to the growth of mobile money, which is now used by nearly half of the population.

site_title: Short-selling: when is regulatory action warranted?
summary: Regulatory action against short-selling is warranted when a short-seller uses inflammatory language, causes market panic, and has a significant impact on a stock's price. A recent case in Hong Kong, where short-seller Andrew Left was found guilty of publishing a "false and misleading" report on China Evergrande Group, highlights the need for oversight. While some argue that short-sellers play a vital role in exposing accounting irregularities, others see them as market pariahs. The case raises questions about the line between honest opinion and fact, and whether authorities should intervene to protect investors from reckless behavior.

site_title: Global economy stuck in 'low-growth trap' with no easy escape: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has warned that the global economy is stuck in a "low-growth trap" with poor growth expectations depressing trade, investment, productivity, and wages. Global growth is expected to remain flat at around 3% this year and only marginally improve next year. The OECD attributes the slowdown to slowing world trade growth, overburdened monetary policy, and the lack of strong fiscal and structural policy action. The report highlights the challenges of breaking out of the low-growth trap, which could lead to growing financial distortions and risks.

site_title: Yen rebounds on scepticism over BOJ measures
summary: The yen rebounded against the US dollar and euro following the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) latest measures, which include setting targets for long-term rates and buying long-term government bonds to keep 10-year bond yields around zero per cent. Investors remain sceptical about the BOJ's ability to achieve its 2 per cent inflation target, with the yen initially weakening before regaining ground in European trading. The US dollar fell 0.3 per cent to 101.40 yen, while the euro declined 0.35 per cent to 113 yen.

site_title: The Productivity Paradox: it's real and it's time to face it
summary: The productivity growth in developed economies, particularly the US, has slowed significantly over the last decade, despite advances in technology. The "Productivity Paradox" suggests that this slowdown is not due to measurement issues, but rather due to the slow diffusion of new technologies, inadequate technological innovation, and macroeconomic factors such as deficient aggregate demand. The slowdown is particularly affecting less technologically advanced firms, and addressing skill constraints, income inequality, and investment rates is crucial to addressing the issue.

site_title: Glaxo presses on to find the next critical antibiotic
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) is developing a new antibiotic, gepotidacin, after a decade of research. The company has sunk $1 billion into antibacterial research, a rare effort by big pharma. Gepotidacin shows promise in fighting superbugs, including those resistant to colistin, but it's not a game-changer, and its effectiveness is limited to specific types of bacteria. The pharmaceutical industry has largely exited antibiotic research due to low payoff, and concerns over superbugs, which could kill an extra 10 million people by 2050, are growing. The US FDA has granted gepotidacin special status, and Glaxo is testing another experimental antibiotic, GSK3342830. Despite progress, experts say the industry needs to invest more in antibiotic research to combat the rising threat of superbugs.

site_title: Ocean Sky seeks full ownership of 30% owned construction outfit
summary: Ocean Sky International plans to acquire the remaining 70% stake in construction outfit Ang Tong Seng Brothers Enterprises (ATS) for S$22.8 million. The proposed deal will be satisfied with S$9.6 million in cash and 100.2 million new shares. ATS has a profitable business with a strong operating track record, and Ocean Sky aims to expand its core civil engineering and construction business. The acquisition is subject to shareholder approval and is considered a major transaction under Catalist rules.

site_title: Air France plans low-cost startup to repel long-haul rivals
summary: Air France-KLM is exploring a low-cost, long-haul travel venture to compete with rivals such as Deutsche Lufthansa and Norwegian Air Shuttle. The move, which has been in the works for over a year, aims to expand the airline's presence in the no-frills market. The company is weighing various options, including aircraft and routes, and will announce a plan on November 3. The move is seen as a response to the emergence of new competitors in the market, and Air France-KLM aims to maintain profitability despite the challenges.

site_title: Singapore offshore support vessel sector bleeds more jobs
summary: Three leading offshore support vessel owner-operators in Singapore, Deep Sea Supply, Tidewater, and GulfMark, have downsized operations due to depressed contracting activity and charter day rates in South-east Asia. Deep Sea Supply has halved its staff strength in Singapore, while Tidewater and GulfMark are also reducing their headcounts and fleet sizes. Industry experts attribute the decline to a global cost-cutting drive in the offshore and marine sector, with the OSV sub-sector being the worst hit due to a supply glut.

site_title: S'pore nine-month bond issuance hits 4-year high
summary: Singapore's nine-month bond issuance reached a 4-year high of US$21.5 billion, up 25% from the same period in 2015. This marks the highest-ever first nine-month period for bond offerings in Singapore since 2012. Local companies are tapping both domestic and offshore markets to raise funds, driving the increase in bond proceeds.

site_title: O&M players eyeing govt backstop for debt pool
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) players are seeking relief from the government amid debt woes caused by cheap oil and deep budget cuts. Industry players are lobbying for a government backstop for loans, lower JTC facility rents, and foreign worker levy relief. SBF chief executive Ho Meng Kit said these "low-hanging fruits" could provide immediate relief, but some industry veterans are skeptical of government intervention. Lenders and bondholders have provided some relief to hard-hit firms, with UOB lending a helping hand to Mencast Holdings and AusGroup launching a consent solicitation exercise to extend debt maturities.

images.alt_text: Embattled offshore and marine (O&M) players' ultimate wish list may be for the state to backstop loans to spur banks to lend but for now, they are seeking some "low hanging fruits" for a reprieve amid wrenching times.

site_title: Your vote matters - please take it seriously
summary: A recent Quinnipiac poll found that 29% of millennial voters (18-34 years old) would vote for Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson in the presidential election, despite his party's platform opposing environmental regulation, income tax, and public schools. Johnson's platform also calls for the privatization of education and the elimination of Social Security and Medicare. The author argues that young Americans should take their vote seriously, as it can impact the outcome of the election, and urges them to consider the policy positions of the candidates rather than just voting for a minor-party candidate to make a statement.

site_title: Long stay on fringe of monetary policy a double-edged sword for Japan
summary: Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan, is operating at its limits, extending its monetary policy to achieve 10-year yields close to zero for Japanese government bonds. However, this prolonged period of low interest rates is detrimental to the economy, particularly for risk-averse investors and retirees. Despite accommodative policies, inflation remains stubbornly low at -0.4%, and the BOJ is forced to resort to unorthodox measures. The country's demographic challenges, including a shrinking workforce, also hinder economic growth. The government must act with aggressive fiscal expansion and structural reforms to revive the economy.

site_title: Car COE premiums soften in 2nd Sept bidding
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars fell in the second bidding exercise of September, with Category A and B premiums dropping to S$50,000 and S$55,501 respectively. Category E, the open category, also decreased to S$55,201. However, Category C and D premiums for goods vehicles and motorcycles rose, respectively. Economists attribute the decline in passenger car COE premiums to the slowing economy, with some dealers noting a sharp drop in business during the Hungry Ghost month.

site_title: Abenomics and a Japanese economy on steroids
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic ambitions under Abenomics are being challenged as the country's economy stumbles at an average annual rate of 1% and inflation averages around zero. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has questioned the feasibility of Abe's goals, suggesting they remain "out of reach." The IMF recommends extending the timeframe for achieving Abenomics' objectives and adopting more realistic frameworks to reduce market volatility. The Bank of Japan, under Governor Haruhiko Kuroda, has pushed monetary easing to its limits, leading to negative interest rates and growing indebtedness. Experts argue that the "three arrows" of Abenomics - monetary and fiscal stimulus, and structural reform - are unlikely to work together.

site_title: AIA retains round table crown for second year
summary: AIA, the world's second-largest life insurance company, retained its global crown for having the most million-dollar round table (MDRT) members for a second year, with 5,687 members in 2016, a 47% increase from the previous year. The insurer attributed its success to its agency staff, changing distribution emphasis to prioritize client advice, and a segmented recruitment and training approach, which includes training agents from various backgrounds and ages.

site_title: Investors see Hong Kong property as a one-way bet
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing has made his first bet on Hong Kong's residential property market in years, purchasing a site in the New Territories for HK$1.95 billion. Despite tumbling home prices, analysts predict a 7% drop in prices next year due to Hong Kong's slowing GDP, moderating population growth, and affordability issues. However, the Pearl River Delta, surrounding Hong Kong, is expected to become the world's largest banking-city cluster by 2025, making Hong Kong a prime aspirational territory and driving up property prices.

images.alt_text: Mr Li has agreed to pay HK$1.95 billion for a site in the New Territories.

site_title: SBIO: corporate governance at the edge
summary: SBI Offshore (SBIO) is embroiled in a corporate governance dispute, raising concerns about the effectiveness of its board and the role of sponsors. The company's five-member board, dominated by accounting and finance professionals, lacks significant business experience. This issue is common among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which struggle to attract independent directors at reasonable fees. The case highlights the challenges faced by SMEs in maintaining good governance and the need for sponsors to contribute to this effort. It also raises questions about the competencies and attributes of directors.

site_title: Other revenue sources may cover higher fiscal deficit in Malaysia
summary: Malaysia's fiscal deficit surged to 5.6% of GDP in the first half of the year, largely due to election spending, but economists believe the government can still meet its 3.1% target with additional revenue-enhancing measures. The government has already squeezed as much as it can from industries and companies, and oil prices must recover for further fiscal consolidation. Expected revenue from Petronas, telco spectrum sales, and a tourism service fee may help bridge the fiscal gap, but the government faces concerns about tight cash flow and a sluggish economy.

site_title: Ex-Tiger MD helps women win lead role in China venture industry
summary: Ex-Tiger MD Chen Xiaohong, a former librarian, has helped fuel China's technology boom with her group of female investors, backing successful startups and raising over $1 billion in venture capital. Chen, 46, is part of a growing number of women in China's technology industry, with 17% of investing partners being female. The Chinese government estimates that women founded 55% of new internet companies. Chen's success is attributed to China's more balanced venture capital industry, where women have the best chance to excel by helping each other.

site_title: JTC to trial robot for building inspection
summary: Singapore's industrial developer JTC plans to deploy a robot, QuicaBot, for building inspection in an upcoming project. The 70-kg robot, resembling Wall-E, can detect cracks, uneven surfaces, and other defects using high-tech cameras and laser scanners. In a trial, JTC expects to save costs while ensuring consistency and accuracy, with a human inspector controlling the robot via a laptop. Successful trials could lead to commercial production by end-2017, with potential expansion to other types of buildings and overseas markets.

site_title: Why wait? Burberry joins designers selling off the catwalk
summary: Burberry joins top designers in selling clothes straight from the catwalk, adopting the "see now, buy now" trend that allows consumers to shop immediately after seeing the collection.
