Refiners have focused on premium sales due to healthy margins, with sales increasing at a faster rate than regular gasoline.

images.alt_text: US consumers wasted billions of dollars last year filling their cars with costly premium-grade petrol for no tangible benefit, according to a study by the country's leading motorist advocacy group.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars inch higher, eyes on central bank meetings
summary: The Australian dollar briefly rose to a one-week high on Tuesday after the Reserve Bank of Australia hinted at a steady policy outlook. The currency rose to US$0.7554 after the RBA minutes showed it was comfortable with the current policy. However, trading was overshadowed by looming meetings of the Bank of Japan and Federal Reserve, which may impact the currency's trajectory. The New Zealand dollar remained firm, trading slightly higher, despite speculation that the Reserve Bank of New Zealand may cut interest rates.

site_title: Grab raises US$750m in equity funding
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing platform, has raised US$750 million in equity funding, increasing its total capital to over US$1 billion. SoftBank led the oversubscribed round with participation from existing and new investors. The funding will support Grab's growth, particularly in Indonesia, where it sees a US$15 billion market for ride-hailing services. With this funding, Grab becomes the best-capitalized technology startup and mobile Internet company in South-east Asia, operating a large transportation network in six countries and 31 cities.

site_title: Google smartphone expected at Oct 4 event
summary: Google has sent out invitations to an October 4 event in San Francisco, hinting at the release of a new smartphone powered by its Android mobile software. The event is seen as a major move by the company to show off its new Nougat version of Android software. Industry trackers expect Google to unveil a "Pixel" brand smartphone, potentially setting a standard for Android devices. The release comes weeks after Apple's new iPhone 7 models and could be a contender for the holiday shopping season.

site_title: China should apply more differentiated property policy as prices surge: Xinhua
summary: China's home prices surged 9.2% in August, accelerating from a 7.9% increase in July, according to an official survey. The Xinhua news agency calls for more differentiated property policies based on local conditions to curb speculation and rising prices. Some second-tier cities and areas should implement cooling measures to reduce inventory and leverage. The property market has been a rare bright spot for the slowing economy, but concerns grow that it may be overheating in some areas. Authorities are taking steps to regulate the market, with the eastern city of Hangzhou restricting home purchases.

site_title: RBA says low rates help economy absorb business investment drop
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) stated that record-low interest rates are helping the economy absorb a drop in business investment, despite a decline in resource investment. The economy expanded at an annual 3.3% in the second quarter, driven by a 30% jump in commodity exports. The RBA maintained its cash rate at 1.5% and cited accommodative monetary policy as supporting interest-sensitive sectors. Despite unemployment edging lower, anemic wage growth and weak inflation signal spare capacity in the labor market.

site_title: Australia shares drift down ahead of Fed, BOJ meetings; NZ climbs
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,283, weighed down by financial and telecom stocks ahead of the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan policy meetings. Investors expect the Fed to keep interest rates unchanged, while the BOJ may introduce a stimulus policy. TPG Telecom plummeted 23.1%, while Woodside Petroleum fell 1.9%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.3% to 7,300.82, driven by gains in industrials, utilities, and telecom stocks.

site_title: China's Anbang faces IPO spotlight after quitting Starwood
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group is considering a Hong Kong IPO, following its decision to quit the Starwood acquisition. The insurer has grown rapidly since 2014, fueled by its top-selling product, Anbang Longevity Sure Win No 1, which offers returns of over triple the benchmark bank deposit rate. Anbang's vice chairman, Yao Dafeng, confirmed the IPO plans, citing a desire to align with international market rules and increase transparency. The move aims to set the company free to focus on growing its business.

site_title: Wells Fargo CEO to take 'full responsibility' in Senate hearing: NYT
summary: Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf will testify to US senators, taking "full responsibility" for selling customers unauthorized bank accounts and credit cards. He will acknowledge that the activity was not part of a "schemed" effort, but rather a result of employees' actions. Stumpf will also admit that the bank failed to stop the behavior from continuing. Wells Fargo has fired 5,300 employees and eliminated sales goals in its retail banking division.

site_title: Oil slips as Venezuela says market is 10% oversupplied
summary: Venezuela's Oil Minister Eulogio Del Pino stated that the global oil supply needs to fall by 10% to match consumption levels, citing a current supply of 94 million barrels per day. This led to a drop in oil prices, with Brent crude futures trading at $45.81 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures at $43.08 per barrel. The statement came amid a weak market mood, with hedge funds scaling back short positions in crude oil futures, indicating a lack of negative momentum.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won steady as investors await Fed, BOJ decisions
summary: Seoul's stocks and won remained steady on Tuesday as investors awaited central bank decisions in Japan and the US. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) was nearly unchanged at 2,015.52. The won decreased 0.1% to 1,119.1, compared to Monday's close. Investors remained cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan decisions, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks little changed in choppy trade
summary: Taiwan's stocks were little changed in choppy trade on Tuesday, following their best single-day gain since September 2015 the previous day. The main Taiex index fell 0.1% to 9,144.47, influenced by profit-taking and tracking Asian share declines. Electronics subindex rose 0.2%, while financials subindex remained unchanged. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.349 per US dollar.

site_title: ARM launches new chip design for automotive, health and robotics
summary: ARM Holdings has introduced the Cortex R-52 processor design, targeting new markets such as self-driving cars and surgical robots. The chip is designed for critical safety devices, including automated vehicles and healthcare devices. This move marks ARM's entry into new markets beyond smartphones, following its acquisition by Softbank Group Corp for $32 billion earlier this month.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall ahead of key central bank decisions
summary: Tokyo shares fell 0.70% on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index dipping to 16,403.22, amid a weaker dollar and anticipation of key central bank decisions from the US and Japan.

site_title: US may seek power to pre-approve self-driving car technology
summary: The US Transportation Department, under the Obama administration, is considering seeking the power to review and approve self-driving car technology before it hits the road. The department has issued voluntary guidelines and urged automakers to certify their vehicles' safety. The administration aims to create a unified framework for self-driving cars, sidestepping state regulations. President Obama emphasized the need for safety and said the government will "pull it off the road" if a vehicle is deemed unsafe. The move is seen as a response to automakers' complaints that state and federal safety rules impede the development of self-driving cars.

site_title: Singapore shares open 5.7 points lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 5.7 points lower at 2,846.44 on Tuesday, with 35 million shares traded worth S$85 million. US stocks closed almost flat overnight ahead of the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan meetings, which are on investors' watchlist. Analysts expect the Fed to keep rates steady but raise them in December, while the BOJ may deliver more negative policy rates.

site_title: China offers US$100m in aid for refugees
summary: China has pledged US$100 million in humanitarian aid to address the world's largest refugee crisis. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang made the announcement at the UN summit on refugees and migrants, saying China is committed to addressing the issue and has a US$1 billion fund available to support the effort. The pledge was made on top of previous commitments, and Li described the plight of refugees as a "serious shock to the human conscience." The UN summit adopted a political declaration calling for the dignity of refugees to be upheld.

site_title: Kerry seeks to keep Syria truce alive after renewed bombing
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry expressed concerns over the one-week-old Syrian cease-fire deal, saying it was too early to declare it dead despite reports of President Bashar al-Assad's forces launching attacks on Aleppo and targeting humanitarian aid convoys. Kerry blamed Russia for failing to control Assad's forces, and the US is willing to extend the cease-fire despite Syria's government statement. The deal's failure is seen as a blow to US efforts to achieve peace in Syria, with the US and Russia agreeing to coordinate air strikes on Islamic extremist groups.

site_title: GoPro captures action from the sky with Karma drone
summary: GoPro has unveiled its Karma drone, a first-person-action mini-cameras platform to become a storytelling solution. The Karma drone will be priced at $799 and will feature simple joystick and touch-screen controls, along with an image-stabilizing grip to hold Hero cameras. The company is also introducing new Hero5 cameras and a cloud-based service for storing, editing, and sharing video. GoPro Plus, a subscription service, will be available for $4.99/month, allowing users to upload and share their videos.

site_title: Tritech asked to hold EGM to remove two directors, appoint four others
summary: TRITECH Group has received a requisition notice from three parties to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove two directors, Aw Eng Hai and Lim Yeok Hua, and appoint four new directors. The EGM will also consider resolutions to vote against certain shareholder resolutions and unwind any disposal of its interest in a subsidiary. The company's board is verifying the shareholding of the requisitioners and seeking legal advice on the validity of their request.

site_title: Twitter enables longer tweets as part of growth push
summary: Twitter has lifted its 140-character limit on tweets, allowing users to post longer messages without counting pictures and quoted retweets. The move aims to boost engagement and user base, which has stagnated for the past year. With 313 million monthly active users, Twitter seeks to expand its appeal beyond its core audience of celebrities, politicians, and journalists. The change does not eliminate the limit and is seen as a necessary step by analysts to revive Twitter's growth, but some warn it may be too little, too late to compete with Facebook and Instagram.

site_title: Australia's stock exchange to open on Tuesday after technology glitch
summary: Australia's stock exchange, the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX), will reopen on Tuesday after a technology glitch delayed its opening by over an hour and cut short afternoon trading. The glitch occurred in the previous session, causing trading to be halted. The ASX assured traders that trading will resume as normal on Tuesday, bringing relief to the market. Despite the delay, chief market strategist Chris Weston expressed confidence that the exchange will bounce back, citing subdued volatility and the upcoming Bank of Japan and US Federal Reserve meetings.

site_title: Ernst & Young pays US$9m for inappropriate client relations
summary: Ernst & Young agreed to pay $9.3 million to settle claims with the US Securities and Exchange Commission that two former partners had personal relationships with clients, violating rules on objectivity and impartiality. The partners, Pamela Hartford and Greg Bednar, had romantic relationships with clients while auditing their companies, and were separated from the organization following the incidents. The SEC stated that Ernst & Young did not adequately detect or prevent these relationships, marking the first time the regulator has sued an auditor over failing to maintain independence due to personal relationships.

site_title: Asia: Stocks waver as investors nervously await Fed, BOJ
summary: Asian stocks wavered on Tuesday as investors awaited the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan policy meetings, sparking uncertainty over interest rate changes. The Fed is expected to keep rates unchanged, while the BOJ may consider deepening negative interest rates to maintain an ultra-easy policy bias. This led to a decline in the Nikkei stock index and a six-day low in the US dollar against the yen. Investors also eyed the BOJ's assessment of its policies and potential actions to steepen the Japanese government bond yield curve.

site_title: Rio CEO turns China optimist as construction view improves
summary: Rio Tinto CEO Jean-Sebastien Jacques has expressed cautious optimism about China's demand for commodities, citing recent data showing a pickup in the construction market. China's home prices rose, and factory output, investment, and retail sales exceeded analyst estimates. Jacques believes an "inflection point" has been reached and plans to capitalize on it, with copper expected to be the first commodity to recover. The company will focus on developing existing projects and cutting costs, rather than pursuing acquisitions.

site_title: US and China target Chinese firm suspected of North Korean nuclear link: WSJ
summary: The US and China are targeting Hongxiang Industrial, a Chinese company linked to North Korea's nuclear program. The US Department of Justice has been investigating the firm, and Chinese authorities have frozen assets and launched a probe into "serious economic crimes". The US Congress has passed legislation to sanction firms that facilitate North Korea's proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. US and Chinese leaders have agreed to step up cooperation in the UN Security Council and law enforcement channels following North Korea's fifth nuclear test. A legal action against Chinese firms suspected of providing financial assistance to Pyongyang is expected.

images.alt_text: The United States and China are targeting the finances of Hongxiang Industrial, a Chinese company headed by a Communist Party cadre which the Obama administration thinks has a role in assisting North Korea's nuclear program, the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.

site_title: Brevan Howard, Caxton expand in Asia amid global hedge fund woes
summary: Brevan Howard and Caxton, two prominent hedge funds, are expanding their presence in Asia as the global industry faces struggles with excessive fees and lackluster returns. The firms have incorporated units in Singapore, with Brevan Howard also having a history in the city. Asian hedge funds have historically outperformed global funds, but investors are pulling assets from the industry, with $12 billion withdrawn from Asia-focused funds in the first seven months of the year. Despite this, some investors, including China's sovereign wealth fund, are increasing bets on Asian markets.

site_title: Kmart said to close 64 more stores as Sears division retrenches
summary: Sears Holdings Corp plans to close an additional 64 Kmart stores by mid-December, following a previous push to shut down 68 Kmarts and 10 Sears stores. The move is part of the company's efforts to address underperforming locations and maintain sales at the discount chain. Sears, which merged with Kmart over a decade ago, has struggled to stay afloat due to slowing mall traffic and a shift away from department stores, resulting in over $9 billion in losses in recent years.

site_title: Bitcoin is money, US judge says in case tied to JPMorgan hack
summary: A US federal judge ruled that Bitcoin qualifies as money, rejecting a bid by Anthony Murgio to dismiss charges related to an alleged operation of an unlicensed bitcoin exchange, Coin.mx. The decision, made by Judge Alison Nathan, cites Bitcoin's use as a payment for goods and services, its ability to be bought directly from an exchange with a bank account, and its function as a medium of exchange and means of payment. This ruling is linked to a broader case involving hacking attacks against JPMorgan Chase & Co and other companies.

site_title: Rio judge orders seizure of Olympic broadcasting equipment
summary: A Brazilian court ordered the seizure of International Olympic Committee vehicles and equipment due to claims of labor abuse, alleging that Olympic Broadcasting Services employed over 2,000 workers under illegal contracts requiring 10+ hour workdays. The court also froze the broadcasting service's funds. This is the latest in a series of legal issues plaguing the Rio Olympics, including ticket scalping charges against IOC officials.

site_title: CWT unit gets licence for commodity exchange, clearing house in Indonesia
summary: CWT's financial services arm, Straits Financial Group, has obtained a regulatory licence to operate a physical commodity exchange and clearing house in Indonesia, branded as Asia Commodity Marketplace (ACM). The exchange aims to provide an organised market place for local producers and international market participants to trade physical commodities, with a focus on agricultural products. ACM plans to roll out its services in 2017, offering commodities such as cocoa, coffee, and soyabean, and settling transactions through a dedicated clearing house.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.79 points to 1656.91, with 20.1 million lots traded at RM13 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 67 to 31, as the market opened higher on Tuesday.

site_title: New York bomb suspect charged with attempted murder
summary: A 28-year-old Afghan-born American, Ahmad Khan Rahami, was charged with attempted murder after being shot and captured in connection with bombings in New York and New Jersey. Rahami allegedly carried out the bombings, which wounded 29 people in Manhattan and cancelled a US Marine Corps race in New Jersey. He was also linked to a stabbing rampage in Minnesota, where nine people were wounded. Rahami had no known associations with extremist groups and was born in Afghanistan, where he had traveled extensively. He was set to face $5.2 million bail after being charged with multiple counts of attempted murder and unlawful weapon possession.

images.alt_text: An Afghan-born American was charged on Monday with attempted murder after being shot and captured in connection with bombings in New York and New Jersey, thrusting security fears into the heart of the election.

site_title: JetBlue to burn renewable biofuel mix on some New York flights
summary: JetBlue Airways Corp has signed a 10-year agreement with bioenergy company SG Preston Co to burn a blended fuel mix of 30% renewable plant oils and 70% jet kerosene on some flights at New York City-area airports. The airline will purchase over 33 million gallons annually, reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 50% per gallon. The agreement is the longest and largest of its kind in the US aviation industry, aiming to cut aircraft pollution and costs.

site_title: Yen edges higher ahead of BoJ, Fed policy meetings
summary: The yen edged higher ahead of the Bank of Japan and Federal Reserve policy meetings. The dollar lost ground against the euro, while the pound picked up slightly. The Fed is expected to hold its interest rate unchanged, while the BoJ may cut interest rates deeper into negative territory to boost economic activity. The dollar slipped to US$1.1175 per euro and 101.88 yen.

site_title: Britain's PM, Wall Street banks to discuss Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to meet with Wall Street finance leaders, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, to discuss the consequences of the Brexit vote. The meeting comes as British officials debate the terms of the UK's exit from the European Union. The two sides are expected to negotiate access to the EU common market, with May triggering Article 50 to initiate the formal withdrawal process. The meeting highlights the growing economic concerns surrounding the Brexit outcome.

site_title: North Korea ground test of new rocket engine 'a success': KCNA
summary: North Korea successfully ground-tested a new high-power rocket engine, state media reported. The engine, which can launch various types of satellites, including Earth observation satellites, was tested at the Sohae satellite-launching site. Leader Kim Jong Un called for more rocket launches to achieve a goal of possessing geostationary satellites within a couple of years. This development could advance Pyongyang's weapons program.

site_title: Intel appoints former eBay CFO Bob Swan as new finance chief
summary: Intel appoints former eBay CFO Bob Swan as its new finance chief, replacing Stacy Smith. Swan, 56, will oversee Intel's finance, internal technology, and strategy offices. He joins a company trying to reinvent itself in a declining PC market, focusing on server chips. Swan's hiring comes as Intel seeks to defend its lead in this lucrative market. He will receive a hiring bonus of $5.5 million and a starting base salary of $850,000.

images.alt_text: Intel Corp, the world's biggest semiconductor maker, hired Robert Swan as chief financial officer, replacing Stacy Smith, who's taking a wider role within the company.

site_title: US dollar drops before Fed as Goldman asset sees rally losing steam
summary: The US dollar declined to a seven-week low as investors awaited the Federal Reserve policy decision. Goldman Sachs Asset Management expects the Fed to forgo an interest-rate increase this week and tighten policy more gradually than expected. The currency has weakened 3.4% this year, with the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index falling 0.2% after reaching its highest level since July 29. Hedge funds cut net bullish futures positions on the US dollar, and analysts predict a cautious Fed decision.

site_title: An ad blocker, created to protect users from ads, opens door instead
summary: Adblock Plus, an ad blocker used on over 100 million devices, has sparked outrage after introducing a service that allows publishers to display ads deemed "acceptable" to its users for a price. The move, which began last week, has positioned the company as a gatekeeper between advertisers and its user base, sparking accusations that it has veered from its original purpose of blocking intrusive ads. The service, which aims to make publishers money, has been met with vitriol from consumers who feel betrayed by the company's new direction.

site_title: New York bombing suspect Rahami captured in New Jersey: mayor
summary: Afghanistan-born American Ahmad Khan Rahami, 28, was captured in a gun battle with police in Linden, New Jersey, after wounding 29 people in New York City bombings. Rahami was taken into custody after firing at officers, with two officers shot. Investigators believe more people were involved in the plots, and a backpack containing bombs was found in a New Jersey train station. US President Barack Obama stated there's no connection between the explosions and a separate stabbing incident in Minnesota, which authorities are investigating as a potential act of terrorism.

site_title: Why wait? Burberry joins designers selling off the catwalk
summary: British luxury brand Burberry will sell its entire September collection immediately after its London catwalk show, joining a trend of top brands offering "see now, buy now" models. This shift challenges smaller designers who rely on months-long delays between shows and sales. Burberry's creative director, Christopher Bailey, sees the move as a natural development in the democratization of fashion shows, while luxury brands like Dior and Chanel argue it will disrupt the creative process. The trend has already seen high street giant Topshop selling 60% of its new collection immediately after its London show.

images.alt_text: Burberry will join a raft of top brands Monday in selling clothes straight from the catwalk, but the "see now, buy now" trend transforming fashion presents a challenge to smaller designers.

site_title: US: Apple retreats after gains as market awaits Fed
summary: Apple shares fell 1.3% on Monday, retreating from gains made last week ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy announcement. The Nasdaq dropped 0.2% to 5,235.03, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 were essentially flat. Analysts attributed the decline to investor caution ahead of the Fed's decision, with some predicting minimal market movement until the announcement is made.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound, helped by financials, commodity stocks
summary: European shares rebounded 1% on Monday, ending a two-week losing streak, driven by financials and commodity stocks. The Stoxx 600 index remains down 7% for the year. Financial stocks, including HSBC and Santander, rose 1-2.5%, while Deutsche Bank fell 2.4%. Analysts at Citigroup cautioned against buying into battered bank stocks, citing the sector as a "contrarian trade". Resource stocks, led by Credit Suisse's upgrade of Glencore, also rose. Oil prices rose, supporting markets, amid speculation of a potential OPEC market support deal.

site_title: Oil rises as US dollar dip bolsters investor demand for commodities
summary: US dollar decline bolsters investor demand for oil, leading to a 0.6% rise in futures. The decline in the US dollar makes raw materials priced in the currency more attractive to investors. Opec may call an extraordinary meeting if ministers reach consensus at informal talks next week. Oil prices have fluctuated since rallying in August on speculation of a market-stabilizing agreement. West Texas Intermediate for October delivery rose to $43.30 a barrel, and Brent for November settlement advanced to $45.95 a barrel.

site_title: Egypt edges closer to IMF US$12b loan approval
summary: Egypt is close to receiving a $12 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), its largest loan in the region. The country has secured $5-6 billion of the required funds from oil-rich Gulf Arab states and plans to sell international bonds. The IMF's approval would release the first tranche of a three-year loan, expected to attract aid and investment to Egypt's economy, which has struggled with a foreign currency shortage and high inflation rates. Egypt's international reserves are still below 50% of their pre-2011 levels.

images.alt_text: Egypt will request a meeting of the International Monetary Fund's executive board within days after meeting the requirements for a US$12 billion loan, the lender's largest ever in the region.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings secured S$78.8 million worth of contracts, bringing total contracts to S$168.8 million. IHH Healthcare accepted a S$1.8 billion banking facility for its subsidiary Parkway Pantai Limited. Cedar Strategic Holdings' independent director Wong Pak Him was redesignated as executive director and acquired 13.03% of shares. Mapletree Logistics Trust's CFO Wong Mei Lian resigned, with the trust finding a replacement.

site_title: Trump, Clinton show differences on national security
summary: US presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump differed on national security following a series of terror attacks, including a bomb in New York, a mass stabbing in Minnesota, and a pipe blast in New Jersey. Clinton emphasized the need for resolve and an intelligence surge, while Trump called for radical change and blamed Clinton's and Obama's policies for the attacks. Trump's campaign criticized Clinton's response as a "disgusting attempt to distract" from her alleged failures to tackle the Islamic State group. The attacks come ahead of the first presidential debate, which may further highlight the candidates' differing stances on national security.

site_title: Google steps up travel presence with dedicated trip-planning app
summary: Google unveiled a new trip-planning app called Google Trips, which automatically pulls details from users' Gmail emails and recommends restaurants, attractions, and local gems. The app, available for download, allows users to organize and download itineraries and reservations, making it easier to plan and navigate trips. Trips brings together Google's Gmail, Maps, and Inbox apps, giving users a single platform for trip planning and travel organization, although users will not be able to book activities or restaurants within the app.

images.alt_text: Google unveiling a new smartphone app that helps users plan and organize their trips, extending the tech giant's step-by-step entrance into the online travel market.

site_title: China facing possible debt crisis: bank watchdog
summary: China's banking sector is facing an imminent debt crisis, with a record high credit to GDP gap of 30.1% in Q1, according to the Bank for International Settlements. The country's total debt has reached 168.48 trillion yuan, equivalent to 249% of national GDP. This warning comes as Beijing tries to avoid a "hard landing" for the economy while transforming it from state investment and exports to consumer-led growth. Analysts fear that a financial crisis could have catastrophic implications globally, and Chinese authorities have unveiled policies to tackle the problem of souring loans.

site_title: Securing online data vital to cloud computing & Smart Nation effort (Amended)
summary: Singapore's push to become a Smart Nation relies heavily on cloud computing and big data analytics, but securing online data is crucial to mitigate cyber-security risks and privacy issues. Industry leaders and experts emphasize the need for organizations to implement robust security measures to protect data from unauthorized access. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has released guidelines on outsourcing cloud-based services, and companies are advised to conduct due diligence and governance to ensure data security. Despite these risks, cloud services can provide agility and competitive advantages, and companies like DBS are embracing cloud computing to reduce costs and improve resilience.

site_title: Gaining an edge over the competition
summary: Insurance group AIA collaborates with universities, government agencies, and industry players to stay ahead of disruptions in the industry. The company has launched the Edge Lab, an innovation centre in Singapore, to develop consumer-centric insurance solutions using technology, big data, and analytics. AIA aims to make insurance more accessible and adapt to changing technologies and customer expectations. The lab combines AIA's commercial expertise with NTU's expertise in areas such as computer engineering and medicine to improve customer experience and help the life insurance sector adapt to the digital world.

site_title: Good old brews take a back seat to next hot beer
summary: The craft beer industry is shifting away from legacy brands, with breweries releasing increasingly diverse and trendy beers to appeal to beer drinkers' desire for novelty. This trend is driven by the rise of beer geeks and the use of apps like Untappd, which track and review every beer tasted. As a result, many classic beers from iconic breweries like Bell's, Rogue, and Stone are being replaced by newer, trendier offerings. Legacy brands face the challenge of staying relevant in a beer universe that thrives on hype, with customers increasingly seeking out the newest and rarest beers.

site_title: Hanjin trims fleet as court advises return of chartered ships
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co, a South Korean container line, received a court advisory to return all chartered ships to reduce costs. The company is reducing its fleet as part of its bankruptcy proceedings, with 13 more container carriers set to be removed from service. Hanjin may face penalties of $1.7 billion for early return, but contracts could be renegotiated if the company is revived. The move is expected to spark consolidation among container lines, and a collapse of Hanjin could lead to a disruption in global supply chains, particularly during peak holiday season.

site_title: Oil traders flee amid speculation Opec may freeze output
summary: Oil traders are fleeing amid speculation that Opec may freeze output, following a report that global oversupply will last longer than thought. The International Energy Agency said the supply glut will linger due to slowing demand growth and resilient output. Oil prices rose 7.5% in August after Opec announced talks, but speculators cut their short positions and bets on rising prices declined. Opec is set to discuss a potential output cap in an informal meeting with Russia on September 27.

site_title: Stripe to use Singapore as beachhead in Asian payments expansion
summary: Stripe, a US payment startup, is launching its service in Singapore to help local startups build online businesses. The company plans to expand in Asia, including Japan and Hong Kong, after forays into Europe and Australia. Stripe offers services beyond processing transactions, including security and fraud prevention. The company will take a 3.4% fee plus 50 Singapore cents from each successful transaction. Singapore's e-commerce market is expected to increase five-fold by 2025, making it a key target for Stripe's expansion.

site_title: Euro area recovery from credit crunch still in the shadows
summary: The euro area banking system remains under pressure, despite stress test results showing European banks are resilient. Non-performing loans in peripheral countries are increasing capital needs, with Italy's Monte dei Paschi struggling. European bank stocks have declined by 30% on average, compared to 10% for the market, due to EU "bail-in regulations" and the UK's Brexit vote.

site_title: Chinese companies eye autonomous car market
summary: More than 10 Chinese companies, including traditional carmakers and Internet giants like Baidu and LeEco, aim to launch autonomous cars within the next five years. However, analysts warn that high financing costs, undefined legislation, and technical issues may hinder their success. Despite technological advancements, Chinese autonomous cars face challenges such as safety and applicability on public roads, with no clear regulations governing liability in case of accidents. Analysts predict that only a few companies will make it to the market, citing the high costs and complexity of rolling out production.

site_title: China's rich turn to European bank bonds but managers urge caution
summary: China's wealthy investors are diversifying from a weakening yuan by investing in European bank bonds, boosting capital for European finance companies. Since August 1, $11.9 billion was raised through Basel III bond sales, with HSBC Holdings Plc issuing $2 billion in total loss-absorbing capacity notes. Global fund managers are urging caution due to rising US Treasury yields and European banks' struggling profits, with yields for hybrid issues facing downside risk. Asian investors are seeking yield and taking higher risks, but some are becoming complacent in insurer bonds.

site_title: Greenback slips before Fed and BOJ meetings
summary: The US dollar fell on Monday ahead of central bank meetings in Japan and the US, driven by a stronger oil price. Commodity-linked currencies rose, including the Canadian, Australian, and New Zealand dollars. Oil prices rose 1.5% due to speculation on Opec production controls.

site_title: Axe Brand family pays S$25m for pair of Bukit Pasoh shophouses
summary: Axe Brand's family has purchased a pair of Bukit Pasoh shophouses in Singapore for S$25 million, with a gross yield of 1.5% based on existing rental income. The 8,503 sq ft properties, spanning three storeys and a mezzanine level, are full leased to six tenants. This sale follows several other conservation shophouse properties recently sold by OCBC, including 60 Boat Quay and 18 Circular Road, also in the Chinatown Historic District.

site_title: Let new F1 owners settle down before starting talks to renew deal: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's deal to host Formula One's night race is set to expire after next year's event. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran has stated that the new owners, Liberty Media, need time to settle down before negotiations for a new deal can begin. Iswaran emphasizes the need for a deliberate and circumspect process to ensure a mutually beneficial agreement, as the transaction's completion is still ongoing.

images.alt_text: Mr Iswaran says that as always, any agreement must be anchored to clear mutual benefits.

site_title: Game of Thrones makes Emmy history
summary: Game of Thrones made television history at the 68th Emmy Awards, winning 12 Emmys, including three top prizes, to give it a total record haul of 38 over the years. The HBO series dominated technical categories, but missed out in the acting categories, with its stars failing to win. The People v OJ Simpson: American Crime Story also won nine awards, including the prize for best limited series. HBO took the top spot with 22 Emmys, while FX ended the night with 18, with Netflix trailing behind.

site_title: Bundesbank chief: ECB must tighten rates as soon as justified
summary: Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann urged the European Central Bank (ECB) to tighten interest rates as soon as justified to prevent prolonged low rates and monetary stimulus. Weidmann warned that ultra-loose monetary policy poses larger risks the longer it persists, despite the ECB's efforts to stimulate growth through low rates and quantitative easing. The ECB has maintained low interest rates since early 2016, but Weidmann believes it's necessary to normalize monetary policy to prevent budgetary discipline issues and ensure price stability.

site_title: Infrastructure offers 'silver lining' amid global slowdown
summary: Singapore's Surbana Jurong chairman Liew Mun Leong believes the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and One Belt, One Road (OBOR) initiative can reignite global growth amid a slowdown. The OBOR program aims to facilitate trade between China and other countries, potentially powering growth among the world's economies. Infrastructure spending has a multiplier effect on economic growth, with McKinsey estimating the OBOR initiative could cost $2 trillion to $3 trillion a year. Liew views the OBOR as a "silver lining" in a world plagued by global uncertainty, economic stagnation, and rising inequality.

site_title: Melbourne port sold for higher-than-expected A$9.7b
summary: A group of investors, including QIC Ltd and the Future Fund, have purchased Australia's busiest port, the Port of Melbourne, for A$9.7 billion. The 50-year deal is expected to generate steady income from the port's daily container and car shipments. The investors, which also include Global Infrastructure Partners and Canadian pension manager Omers, aim to capitalize on the current tough equity market conditions and the growing demand for infrastructure investments.

site_title: Artificial intelligence comes into its own for mainstream businesses
summary: Artificial intelligence has reached mainstream business applications, particularly in marketing. Salesforce.com announced the integration of AI into its products, called Einstein, which provides insights on sales leads and product recommendations. This marks a significant step in AI adoption for businesses, as it promises to streamline sales and marketing processes. Other companies, such as BHP, Oracle, and Grab, have also established AI-focused innovation hubs to drive innovation and growth in their respective industries.

site_title: Finnish marine group puts up five industrial properties for sale
summary: Wartsila Singapore, a marine and energy player, is selling five industrial properties in Singapore as part of its asset-light strategy. Two properties, 11 Pandan Crescent and 14 Benoi Crescent, will be sold on a sale-and-leaseback basis, while three others at Gul Drive will be sold outright. The properties, which include workshops and factories, have considerable unused plot ratios and are expected to attract interest from Reits and developers. The sale is aimed at improving operational efficiency and will enable Wartsila to consolidate its operations into the remaining two properties.

images.alt_text: Two properties located at 11 Pandan Crescent and 14 Benoi Crescent will be sold on sale-and-leaseback arrangements, while the other three properties at 43, 45 and 47 Gul Drive are offered on an outright sale basis with vacant possession upon completion of sale.

site_title: Creativity around infrastructure financing not exhausted yet: AIIB
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is urging governments to shift the funding of bankable infrastructure projects to the private sector, as governments are instead taking on more risk. According to AIIB's director-general Pang Yee Ean, governments are funding the most bankable projects themselves, leaving riskier projects to private investors. The AIIB believes that creativity in infrastructure financing has not been exhausted, suggesting the use of different financiers at different stages of a project, and that private equity players, pension funds, and sovereign wealth funds may be potential candidates to finance infrastructure projects.

site_title: Indonesia to chase Google for 5 years of back taxes
summary: Indonesia plans to pursue Google for five years of back taxes, alleging the search giant paid less than 0.1% of owed taxes in 2015. Google Indonesia has cooperated with local authorities and paid applicable taxes, but could face a bill of over $400 million if found guilty. The tax office will summon Google directors and work with the police, with a maximum tax bill of $570 million for 2015. This is a rare case of a state investigation escalating into a criminal case globally.

site_title: Securing Singapore's prosperity amid greater global uncertainty
summary: Singapore's economy is facing a slowdown due to global uncertainty, with China's economic decline casting a shadow on global growth prospects. The country's quarterly growth has not exceeded 3% for the past seven quarters, and the long-term economic outlook is gloomy. To counter this, Singapore can tap into the demand of its fellow ASEAN members, boost productivity by disseminating digital technologies, and expand participation in the workforce to stimulate growth. Immediate action is crucial to secure Singapore's position as a business and investment hub and a truly global city.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, replaces Helen Wong. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for H2. The MAS and PBOC are planning to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Dealing with disruption
summary: Established businesses are adapting to disruption from innovative startups, seeking advantages from disruptive technologies. Disruption has been a recurring phenomenon, as seen in the industrial revolution where production lines replaced craftsmen. Today, industries such as taxi services, hospitality, and professional services are facing disruption. Established players are preparing to defend their territories while creating competitive advantages from disruptive technologies, meeting customers' demands for quality goods and services at competitive prices. This shift reflects the evolving nature of business disruption over time.

images.alt_text: "The (insurance) industry was ripe for disruption as healthcare spend has risen considerably faster than compensation, but employers are not provided the return on investment data to combat worsening employee health." - Ms Koo

"Innovative products, services and processes are continually being created to make things more relevant and convenient for the end-user. What's perhaps different now is the rate of disruption, which is getting faster, thanks to the advancement of technology." - Mr Ong

"What can disrupt others in an industry can also become a source of unique advantage to the one that got ready for the event faster and better than the rest. The things that drove success in the past won't continue to guarantee success in the future." - Mr Agarwal

site_title: Taking a stand against divisive politics
summary: An economist offers a path forward for liberals to respond to rising right-wing anger and populism. The traditional left's lack of conviction and old rhetoric is contrasted with the right's passionate intensity. Decentralization, local bodies, and union organization are proposed as ways to counter nativism and xenophobia. The left should focus on vocational training, social-transfer schemes, and universal basic income to adapt to the changing global value chain. Public investment in infrastructure, green technology, and community-level projects is also recommended to counter corporate capture and promote democratic values.

site_title: Police arrest 28-year-old man over New York, New Jersey bombs
summary: A 28-year-old Afghan-born American, Ahmad Khan Rahami, was arrested in New Jersey after a shootout with police. He is linked to a bombing in New York City that wounded 29 people and another blast in New Jersey. Investigators believe Rahami could be connected to international militant groups or the ongoing conflict in Afghanistan. Multiple improvised explosive devices were discovered at a train station in Elizabeth, New Jersey, and a vehicle of interest was stopped in Manhattan. The arrest comes amid concerns about terrorism in the region and the ongoing UN General Assembly in Manhattan.

site_title: Australia economy braces for headwinds unlike any it has known
summary: Australia's economy, which has experienced 100 consecutive quarters of growth, faces headwinds unlike any it has known. The economy grew 3.3% over the last financial year, but this was largely driven by government spending ahead of an election. Private domestic investment has collapsed, wages are stagnant, and exports have fallen due to a strong Australian dollar. The situation is uneven, with metropolitan areas thriving while Western Australia and South Australia struggle. Household debt has risen to 210% of GDP, and experts predict a potential 40-70% fall in home prices, which could devastate the economy.

site_title: Tech glitch shuts down trading on ASX
summary: Australia's stock exchange, the ASX, suspended trading for the rest of the day due to a technical glitch that caused a 90-minute delay to Monday's open. The issue occurred at a sensitive time with policy meetings scheduled at the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve this week. The ASX has struggled with technical issues in the past, including a 2014 problem that halted trading for two hours and a 2015 disruption that lasted three-and-a-half hours. The ASX's shares fell 2.4% before trading was halted, and the market's reputation has been impacted, with investors and analysts expressing frustration and concern.

site_title: Singapore SMEs slow to adopt business model innovation to gain edge
summary: Singaporean Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) are slow to adopt Business Model Innovation (BMI), a key tool for staying competitive in a rapidly changing business landscape. Despite the emergence of disruptive innovations, only about 30% of local companies can name two examples of BMI. Experts, including Michael Teng and Evangelos Simoudis, emphasize the importance of BMI in identifying profitable niches and creating value for customers and markets. Implementing BMI requires a holistic approach, involving both science and art, and can be challenging due to organizational mindset and culture.

site_title: Traders position for dovish FOMC
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index rose 24.69 points to 2,852.14 on Monday ahead of the US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting. Penny stocks led by ISR Capital, including LionGold, Blumont, and Asiasons, surged in high volume. Despite a robust 1.5 billion units traded, dollar value was low due to low prices. Traders are expecting a dovish FOMC, with only a 20% chance of an interest rate hike, and are focusing on the language of the accompanying statement.

site_title: China fashion retailer buys S Korean brand to expand
summary: China fashion retailer V-Grass Fashion Co has acquired the Chinese business of South Korean fast-fashion brand Teenie Weenie for approximately $900 million. The deal aims to boost V-Grass's sales and profit as the company restructures and focuses on luxury-minded brands. With over six times more stores in China, Teenie Weenie will support V-Grass's expansion plans, including its first overseas store in Milan. The acquisition is part of V-Grass's plan to consolidate the Chinese fashion market and emerge as a dominant local fashion apparel company.

site_title: Chiwayland unit acquires Wuxi land, announces plans for 3 other China parcels
summary: Chiwayland International, a Chinese property developer, has acquired a 73,351 square meter land parcel in Wuxi, China, with plans to develop three other parcels of land. The acquisition, made by a 60%-owned joint venture, is expected to be completed by 2018. Chiwayland also announced plans for two other projects in Wuhan and Zhangjiagang, with estimated completion dates of 2018 and 2019, respectively.

site_title: EU probes tax deals Luxembourg granted French firm
summary: The European Union has launched an investigation into tax deals granted by Luxembourg to French power utility Engie, alleging that the deals may have given the company an unfair advantage over others. The EU's competition commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, said that the deals treated the same financial transaction as both debt and equity, leading to double non-taxation. Engie has been present in Luxembourg since 1933 and employs about 300 people. This probe is part of the EU's campaign against tax avoidance by multinationals, following similar investigations into deals with McDonald's, Amazon, and Fiat.

site_title: Singapore's deal activities down by 17% so far this year
summary: Singapore's deal activities have slowed down by 17% so far this year, with total corporate deals totaling US$37.5 billion, down from US$45 billion in the same period last year. This decline is more pronounced on a quarterly basis, with Q3 deals falling 26.7% to US$12 billion. Despite big-ticket deals such as the BOC Aviation spinoff and Asia Square Tower 1 sale, the Singapore deal-making scene has failed to surpass last year's showing.

site_title: UK allowed only informal non-EU trade talks ahead of formal Brexit
summary: The UK can negotiate informal trade deals with non-EU nations before formal Brexit, but may face fines if it starts official negotiations with countries already in trade deals with the EU. A leaked document from the European Commission warns that the UK could be fined if it begins trade talks with countries already in negotiations with the EU, such as the US, Canada, Japan, and Brazil. The UK is expected to officially leave the EU in 2019 and begin official trade negotiations with countries around the world.

site_title: Technology stocks still relatively cheap, says Henderson
summary: Technology stocks remain relatively cheap compared to past numbers, according to Richard Clode, a portfolio manager with Henderson Global Investors. Despite tech garnering a larger share of global earnings over the last 10 years, it continues to gain prominence in the global economy. Clode expressed optimism about the sector's future growth, stating that technology is becoming increasingly integral to the global economy.

site_title: Morgan Stanley underweight on Genting Singapore
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts have downgraded Genting Singapore, citing a challenging environment for the global VIP segment and Genting's poor management of VIP business, resulting in high bad debts. Despite a surge in tourists from China, Genting's VIP revenue fell 26% year-on-year due to reduced credits. The analysts expect negative earnings revisions for Genting Singapore, while predicting 13% growth for Singapore's VIP gaming sector next year, driven by "normalised luck rather than volume recovery".

site_title: Shadow lenders take bigger slice of real estate debt
summary: Private funds are seeking a record US$32 billion for commercial property debt as buyout firms, Reits, and hedge funds expand lending in the US real estate market. These lightly regulated investors can charge higher interest rates and move quickly on large loans considered too speculative for banks. This trend is driven by heightened scrutiny of commercial real estate lending, allowing these companies to fill the gap left by banks.

site_title: Bags and bling, tourists seek bargains in Brexit Britain
summary: Tourists are taking advantage of the weak pound sterling, boosting high street sales in Britain. Since the Brexit vote, foreign visitors have increased spending on luxury goods, with tourist spending on luxury goods rising by 36% in August compared to the same period last year. This has helped manufacturers see higher export orders and lured visitors away from other European countries. Meanwhile, British households face rising inflation due to the slump in the pound, cutting into their spending power.

site_title: Vietnam planning US$900m Vinamilk stake sale: sources
summary: Vietnam is planning to sell a 10% stake in dairy company Vinamilk, valued at approximately $900 million, with the potential for further sales of the remaining stake. The sale is part of Vietnam's efforts to divest its state-owned enterprises, with the government citing the need to fund infrastructure projects and social welfare costs. Credit Suisse, HSBC, and other foreign investment banks have been invited to advise on the sale, which is seen as a significant step towards offloading the government's most lucrative assets.

images.alt_text: The first chunk of Vinamilk could be sold at a premium as several Asian companies and private equity firms are jostling for shares, said the people.

site_title: The old powerful Fed is dead
summary: The US Federal Reserve's influence as a key policymaker is dwindling, with economists and experts questioning its ability to engineer strong economic recoveries. Despite flooding the world with cheap money, the central banks have achieved only a weak recovery, avoiding a second Great Depression. The Fed's failure to raise interest rates at its upcoming meeting is seen as a major mistake by some economists, but others argue that it is too early to reverse low rates. The Fed's power is being questioned, with some experts suggesting that basic economic problems cannot be solved by easy money and credit, and that it may become a target of public wrath if it fails to meet expectations.

site_title: From cars to college town, Canada's Motor City grows despite GM woes
summary: Canada's Motor City, Oshawa, Ontario, is growing despite General Motors' (GM) decline, with a new university, cancer centre, and nuclear plant expansion. The city's economy has diversified, with manufacturing jobs falling by over 40% since 2001. Oshawa has become a hub for education, healthcare, and technology, with 10,000 students and 14,300 people working in education. The city's 6.9% unemployment rate is lower than the national average, and it has been ranked first in the country for labour market growth.

site_title: UPS to launch 3D printing facility in Singapore
summary: UPS is launching an on-demand 3D printing facility in Singapore by the end of 2016, in partnership with Fast Radius, marking its first 3D printing network outside the US. The facility aims to revolutionize manufacturing, especially at the prototyping stage, and will be supported by an advanced solutions team. Businesses can expedite delivery of industrial parts via UPS's logistics network, with a turnaround time of 24 hours, saving time and money for companies. The facility is expected to strengthen Singapore's position as a manufacturing hub and benefit both multinational corporations and small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

site_title: Moody's: Asia-Pac Reits' refinancing risk manageable
summary: Moody's analysts report that refinancing risk for Asia-Pacific Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits) is manageable over the next 12-18 months, with less than 15% of their debts due for refinancing. The credit rating agency found that Reits across Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, and Singapore have healthy credit metrics, with leverage and interest coverage ratios remaining stable. Moody's notes that Reits with diverse funding sources and spread-out debt maturities are less vulnerable to liquidity crises.

site_title: Noble still seeking strategic investor, expects to take up to 2 years to return to profit
summary: NOBLE Group Ltd, an Asian commodities trader, is still seeking a strategic investor as it aims to return to profit within 2 years. The company, led by founder and chairman Richard Elman, has taken steps to reduce costs and cut jobs, with plans to raise $2 billion. Noble has saved hundreds of millions by exiting low-margin areas and has reduced overhead costs by 20%. The company's shares rose 9.4% to close at 13.9 Singapore cents after Elman stated that a strategic partner is still possible, but at the right time and candidate.

site_title: China coal cuts to spell pain for Japan steelmakers as prices soar
summary: Japan's steelmakers face increased costs as China's coal production cuts drive up metallurgical prices. Spot hard coking coal prices have more than doubled to near US$200 a tonne, affecting quarterly supply contracts. Japanese steelmakers may pay 51% higher prices, up to US$140 a tonne, due to China's market tightness and robust steel output. This surge in prices will impact Japanese steelmakers' profit margins, forcing them to pass along higher costs to customers.

site_title: US home builder sentiment index highest in 11 months
summary: US home builder sentiment index reached its strongest level in 11 months, rising to 65 points in September from 59 in August, according to the National Association of Home Builders and Wells Fargo. This is matched the level set in October 2015. Analysts attribute the increase to renewed interest in home purchases following a summer lull. The single-family market is expected to continue making gradual gains, supporting the US economic expansion and potentially leading to interest rate hikes by the end of the year.

site_title: Joining forces to tackle global food security challenges
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) estimates 795 million people are undernourished worldwide, with 500 million small farms providing 80% of food in the developing world. To address these challenges, 36 agri-businesses launched the Global Agri-business Alliance (GAA) in Singapore to focus on sustainable agriculture, food security, and inclusive growth. The GAA aims to tackle issues like food waste, water security, climate change, and social inequality, aligning with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal 2. The alliance seeks to make a collective impact on reducing environmental degradation and promoting sustainable agriculture practices.

site_title: Australia forces sale of 16 foreign-owned properties
summary: Australia has forced the sale of 16 foreign-owned properties, including 7 owned by Chinese nationals, after failing to obtain government permission. The properties, valued at A$93 million, were acquired without approval from the Foreign Investment Review Board. The move comes amid growing concerns over foreign investment's impact on real estate prices and national interests. The government has previously enforced similar measures, with 46 properties sold since 2013, and has blocked Chinese bidders from buying major assets, sparking accusations of protectionism.

site_title: Thakral JV buys two properties in Australia
summary: Thakral Corporation's joint venture, GTH Resorts, has acquired two properties in Queensland, Australia, to develop retirement housing for seniors. The Bribie Island property will have 404 homes and the Toowoomba property will have 223 homes. Development costs will be funded by senior debt, capital, and proceeds from home sales. Thakral's investment division has committed A$20.5 million to the project, expecting demand for retirement housing to continue growing in line with Australia's aging population. Construction is anticipated to begin in mid-2017.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to cut more than 200 management positions
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc is eliminating more than 200 management positions as part of a wide-reaching restructuring under CEO Warren East's turnaround plan. This brings the total to over 600 management cuts since July 28, aiming to reach a £30-50 million savings target by the end of 2017. The company is also targeting a £1 billion margin improvement, matching those of competitors Pratt & Whitney and General Electric Co, amid a downturn in demand for marine engines and business jet turbines.

site_title: Pimco, BlackRock see December Fed hike amid mini taper tantrum
summary: Pimco and BlackRock predict the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates in December, citing rising consumer prices and inflation expectations. The move would be the Fed's second since 2008, and investors are reacting to concerns about the limits of central bank stimulus. Bond yields have fallen 1.6% over the past month, and traders see a 55% chance of a rate increase by year-end, according to futures contracts. The Fed is set to meet on September 20-21, and Chair Janet Yellen has stepped up rhetoric favoring a rate hike.

site_title: Samsung says China Note 7 phone fire damage caused by external heat
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd stated that a Galaxy Note 7 smartphone in China that caught fire was damaged by external heat, not the faulty battery. The company had previously announced a global recall of the Note 7 due to battery issues, but this incident suggests that external factors can also cause the problem. The investigation by battery supplier Amperex Technology Limited confirmed this.

site_title: Is HK a threat to S'pore's lead in Asia FX trading?
summary: Singapore's status as the world's third-largest foreign exchange (FX) centre and Asia's biggest remains intact, according to the 2016 Triennial Central Bank Survey. Despite Hong Kong's significant growth, Singapore's FX average daily trading volume jumped 35% to US$517 billion in April 2016, driven by growth in G-10 and Asian currencies. Singapore's share of global FX increased to 7.9% in 2016, while Hong Kong's FX market share rose to fourth place globally. However, Hong Kong's growth may be limited by its ties to China, and Singapore's advantages as a more diverse financial centre and not part of China remain.

site_title: Threading towards the future (Amended)
summary: Tantex, a family-run clothing supplier, has leveraged predictive business intelligence tools to prepare for the future. Founded in 1991 as a buying agency for South-east Asia, the company has grown to supply retailers in the UK, Europe, and the US. With a staff of 36 and 25 Asian manufacturers in six countries, Tantex uses technology to design, source, and matchmake with its partners. The company has implemented an Enterprise Resource Planning system and business intelligence software, Qlik, to analyze data and forecast demand. Second-generation management aims to scale up the business and increase its manufacturing presence, while also introducing interns to the trade to support the younger generation.

site_title: Indonesia's Medco agrees to acquire ConocoPhillips' 40% stake in Natuna block
summary: Indonesia's PT Medco Energi Tbk has agreed to acquire ConocoPhillips' 40% stake in the South Natuna Sea Block B, an oil and gas production sharing block off the northwest coast of Borneo island. The deal does not disclose the purchase value. This follows Medco's previous purchase of a majority stake in Newmont Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia's second-largest copper and gold miner. The acquisition is part of Medco's expansion in the energy sector.

site_title: Accelerators pivot to next generation
summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem is shifting, with accelerators evolving to become "innovation enablers" rather than just startup accelerators. This change is driven by the need for a more decentralized approach to innovation, with corporates playing a key role. JFDI, Singapore's first accelerator, has ended its startup boot camp program and is pivoting to co-create startups with corporates. Next-generation accelerators will focus on uncovering customers' needs, working closely with corporates, and grooming more entrepreneurs. The global economic climate is also driving this shift, with corporates seeking tech that can drive positive returns on investment.

site_title: Popular drives business with family-centred approach
summary: Popular Rent A Car, a leading car rental company in Singapore, is confident in its ability to thrive in a car-lite model. With over 300 cars in its fleet, Popular has received the Enterprise 50 (E50) Award for its sustainable business model and commitment to quality services. The company aims to capitalize on the growing demand for car rental and car-sharing services in Singapore, despite the city-state's high car ownership costs.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks jump most in a year as Apple suppliers lead surge
summary: Taiwan's stocks surged 2.8% at close, the largest gain in a year, amid speculation Apple's latest iPhone model will boost earnings for suppliers. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, major Apple suppliers, saw significant gains. The island's dollar strengthened, and expectations for the iPhone 7 line have revived, fueled by T-Mobile and Sprint's orders. Global funds have sold local shares, but the Taiex index snapped a five-day decline, snapping a two-month low.

site_title: Bentley, Lamborghini skip Paris show amid VW cost-cutting drive
summary: Volkswagen's luxury supercar brands Bentley and Lamborghini are skipping the Paris Motor Show due to the company's efforts to cut costs amid the ongoing emissions scandal. Bentley will focus on smaller events, while Lamborghini is revising its strategy for auto show attendance. Other carmakers, including Ford, Volvo, and Aston Martin, are also cutting costs on opulent show stands. VW aims to boost profitability and catch up on new technologies, with a focus on executive speeches on design. The company is reining in spending on auto exhibitions to cushion costs.

site_title: British funds face up to rainy day cash pot demands
summary: Britain's fund managers are facing demands to hold more emergency cash, potentially limiting their ability to pay dividends or expand. Following a review by the Financial Conduct Authority, Aberdeen Asset Management was asked to raise its minimum cash holdings by 140 million pounds. Regulators are scrutinizing the multi-trillion-pound asset management industry to prevent firms from going bust in the event of a market collapse. The move aims to increase capital levels and reduce the risk of asset managers' revenue disappearing overnight.

site_title: EU appoints Briton as commissioner for security
summary: The European Union appointed British diplomat Julian King as the new commissioner for security issues, replacing Jonathan Hill. The appointment was made following the European Parliament's endorsement and applies for the remainder of the current term of office, which ends on 31 October 2019. King's appointment may be affected if Britain's divorce negotiations with EU partners conclude sooner than the end of his term.

site_title: German central bank chief warns City of London on 'hard Brexit'
summary: Germany's central bank chief Jens Weidmann warns that if the UK leaves the European Economic Area, British banks may lose their automatic right to trade in EU states, potentially leading to financial services companies moving elsewhere. Weidmann cites passporting rights, which would automatically cease to apply if the UK is no longer part of the EEA. However, some experts, including Moody's Investors Service, expect global banks based in London to remain accessible to the single market, with some potentially relocating UK-based activities to the EU before the UK's withdrawal negotiations are complete.

images.alt_text: British banks risk losing their automatic right to trade in EU states as the country leaves the European Union, Germany's central bank chief said in an interview out Monday.

site_title: Airbus says cost cuts in pipeline, no extra programme
summary: Airbus has confirmed it plans cost cuts as part of its digitalisation project to modernise its operations. The company denied a report of a new restructuring plan due to cost overruns on its largest planes, stating it aims to offset delays through cost reductions. Airbus aims to introduce digital methods to overhaul the production process and achieve group earnings and cashflow targets, with the goal of growth potential for 2017 and beyond. The company is focusing on synergies between corporate and divisional levels to achieve cost reductions.

site_title: Investment flows into Asian bonds turn fitful; Malaysia vulnerable
summary: Foreign investors' demand for Asian bonds has been patchy in August, driven by concerns over global monetary easing and rising long-term yields. Despite increased holdings in markets like Malaysia and Indonesia, the shift in global sentiment has led to profit-taking, particularly in emerging market bonds. The European Central Bank's lack of future stimulus hints and the Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hold have contributed to the selloff. Malaysia's five-year government bond yield rose to 3.285% in August, while South Korea's expectations for further rate cuts have weakened.

site_title: Google faces US$400m bill as Indonesia starts tax probe
summary: Google faces a potential US$400 million tax bill in Indonesia if authorities find it avoided taxes in 2015. The probe, sparked by similar EU investigations, aims to determine if the company paid all taxes due. Google has insisted it paid all taxes since opening its Jakarta offices in 2011. Tax investigators visited Google's office, and a senior official stated that the company had not fulfilled its tax obligations, potentially leading to a fine of 5.5 trillion rupiah (about $560 million).

images.alt_text: Google faces a bill of over US$400 million in Indonesia if authorities find it avoided taxes last year, an official said Monday, as Jakarta began a probe into the US tech giant.

site_title: Thakral's JV GTH Resorts buys two properties in Australia to build retirement homes
summary: Thakral Corporation's joint venture GTH Resorts has acquired two properties in Australia for retirement home development. The 24.89-hectare Bongaree, Bribie Island, and 9.4-hectare Highfields, Toowoomba, will be developed with funding from senior debt, Thakral's investment division, and PVAP. Development costs will be approximately A$20.5 million, with around half of it raised from managed funds. The properties will cater to seniors over 50, with resort-style retirement housing.

site_title: Oil prices up on Libya unrest, hopes for output deal
summary: Oil prices rose Monday as fighting in Libya increased supply concerns. Brent crude rose 58 cents to $46.35 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate added 59 cents to $43.62 a barrel. Opec member Venezuela indicated a deal to limit output is close, further supporting oil prices. The Libya unrest and potential output deal boosted investor hopes for stability in the energy market.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher as traders expect dovish FOMC; pennies rule the day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 24.69 points to 2,852.14 ahead of the US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting, driven by a late afternoon push. Penny stocks, including LionGold, Blumont, and Asiasons, surged in high volume, with ISR Capital's 71% increase to S$0.26. Despite a robust 1.5 billion units of trading, dollar value was poor, with an average value per unit traded of just under S$0.50. Traders expect a dovish FOMC, betting on a lower interest rate hike probability.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust Management CFO resigns
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust Management announced that CFO Wong Mei Lian is resigning on November 12, citing a desire to pursue other interests. The trust's manager has found a suitable replacement and will announce the candidate once the regulatory filing is complete.

images.alt_text: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust (MLT) Management announced on Monday that Wong Mei Lian has resigned as chief financial officer.

site_title: US: Wall St rises as oil prices recover
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as oil prices rebounded from multi-week lows, with the S&P 500 energy index gaining 0.69%. The Federal Reserve's two-day meeting starts on Tuesday, with investors expecting no rate hike. The dollar index declined, sending gold prices higher, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 90.87 points, or 0.5%, to 18,214.54. Shares of casino operator Isle of Capri jumped 28.5% after Eldorado Resorts acquired the company, while General Motors rose 2.52% after Morgan Stanley upgraded the stock.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 1.280 points to 1,651.710. Volume reached 1.147 billion lots worth RM1.440 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 444 to 333.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) is a path towards free trade in the Asia-Pacific region. In corporate news, M&A deals in Singapore slowed down by 27% in Q3, while the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) partnered to promote Chinese listings. Additionally, India's Masala bond made its debut on SGX, and Noble Group is still seeking a strategic investor.

site_title: China's yuan firms, supported by surging costs of borrowing in Hong Kong
summary: China's central bank set a stronger midpoint for the yuan, fixing it at 6.6786 per US dollar, but the currency came under pressure as mainland banks and corporates bought US dollars. The onshore yuan has firmed since last week due to elevated offshore borrowing rates, which raised the cost of shorting the Chinese currency. The central bank sold a net 191.9 billion yuan worth of foreign exchange in August, and traders expect borrowing rates to remain elevated until the end of the month unless more liquidity is added to the market.

site_title: Singapore Michelin-starred hawker seeks US$1.5m expansion deal
summary: Singapore Michelin-starred hawker Chan Hon Meng is seeking a US$1.5 million expansion deal to open an international franchise. He aims to replicate the success of Asian brands like Tim Ho Wan and Din Tai Fung, which also received a Michelin star. Chan is looking for a partner with overseas operating experience and is willing to accept a share of the company or a US$2 million payout in exchange for the brand's expansion into the international market. His stall has seen long queues since receiving the Michelin star, but regular customers have been affected by the wait times.

site_title: Charity Council seeks public feedback on proposed changes to code of governance
summary: The Charity Council is seeking public feedback on proposed changes to its code of governance, set to be launched in early 2017. The refinements include a 10-year term limit for at least two-thirds of governing board members, promotion of transparency, and emphasis on risk management. The code, first introduced in 2007, will be updated with new reporting requirements for charities starting from 2018. The public can provide feedback until October 18 via email.

images.alt_text: THE Charity Council is seeking public feedback on the proposed changes to the code of governance, which is expected to be launched in early 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stock markets reopen with rallies
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stock markets reopened with rallies on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.92% and Shanghai's benchmark composite index climbing 0.77%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also increased 1.06%. The gains follow a week-long Asia-wide rally.

site_title: Golden Energy secures nod to raise coal production at Indonesian concession
summary: Golden Energy and Resources has secured approval from the Indonesian government to increase its annual coal production from 6.3 million tonnes to 7.5 million tonnes at its PT Borneo Indobara concession. The new cap represents a 19% increase and is a significant step towards the company's target of 12 million tonnes in 2017.

site_title: China ship owners pay up for Australia reef disaster
summary: China's ship owner, Shenzhen Energy Transport Co Ltd, has agreed to pay A$39.3 million to settle a 2010 incident where the fully-laden coal carrier Shen Neng 1 ran aground on the Great Barrier Reef, leaking heavy fuel oil and damaging the coral. The settlement, deemed "woefully inadequate" by Greenpeace, will allow the reef to be restored, but experts warn impacts could last for many decades due to toxic anti-fouling paint remaining in place.

images.alt_text: The owners of a Chinese ship that ran aground on the Great Barrier Reef in 2010 agreed to pay Australia A$39.3 million (S$40.52 million) on Monday, in a settlement dismissed by conservationists as "woefully inadequate".

site_title: More time needed for new F1 owners to settle down before agreement, says S Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran says more time is needed for the new owners of the Formula One business to settle down before an agreement can be reached with the Republic. The deal to host the Singapore Grand Prix is set to expire after next year's night race. Iswaran believes there's no need to rush the negotiations as the takeover by Liberty Media has yet to be finalized.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Monday, with the FTSE 100 index jumping 0.9% to 6,771.53 points. Asian markets also rose, driven by traders waiting for central banks to announce their monetary policies. The European Central Bank's Jens Weidmann warned that low interest rates must not last indefinitely, citing concerns over price stability. The rebound comes amid uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and the Bank of Japan's plans.
