site_title: European banks represent the world's biggest contrarian trade: Citi
summary: Citi analysts say buying European bank stocks would be the world's biggest contrarian trade, citing expected improvements in returns and asset quality next year. European banks are the worst-performing sector over the past decade, with a 22.6% decline this year, trading at 0.7 times book value. Citi prefers Danske Bank, Standard Chartered, and BBVA, while HSBC is less preferred. Despite facing headwinds from low inflation and interest rates, analysts say history suggests a "buy" for the sector, but caution against underweighting it.

site_title: Chiwayland subsidiary acquires Wuxi land, announces plans for 3 other China parcels
summary: A Chiwayland subsidiary acquired a 73,351 sq m parcel of land in Wuxi, near Shanghai, with plans for a 2018 completion. The acquisition is part of the company's efforts to build its land bank in China. Chiwayland also announced plans for three other Chinese land parcels, including a 83,467 sq m project in Wuhan and two mixed-development projects in Wuxi and Zhangjiagang, with expected completion dates of 2018.

images.alt_text: A SUBSIDIARY of mainboard-listed Chinese property developer Chiwayland International has acquired a 73,351 sq m parcel of land in Wuxi, near Shanghai, the group reported on Monday evening.

site_title: Ryobi Kiso adds S$78.8 million worth of new contracts
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings Ltd secured contracts worth S$78.8 million, bringing total contracts since January 1 to S$168.8 million. The contracts include foundation and geoservices work for projects such as the Deepwater Ocean Basin and Seletar Airport. CEO Ong Tiong Siew expects more public and infrastructure projects in Singapore as the nation redevelops, positioning the company for future growth with its strong capabilities. The company's net order book stood at S$127.3 million as of June 30.

images.alt_text: RYOBI Kiso Holdings Ltd, a leading specialist ground engineering solutions provider, announced on Monday that it secured additional contracts worth S$78.8 million, bringing the value of total contracts secured since Jan 1 to S$168.8 million.

site_title: India's poor fear 'rent-a-womb' industry shut down
summary: India's government is planning to ban the commercial surrogacy industry, known as "rent-a-womb," due to concerns over exploitation of poor women. The industry, which has earned the country millions of dollars, has been criticized for its lack of regulation and exploitation of surrogate mothers. The proposed ban would only allow married Indian couples to use unpaid close relatives as surrogates, sparking debate over the ethics of the practice and the impact on those who rely on it for financial gain.

site_title: German economy could slow in third quarter, Bundesbank warns
summary: Germany's economy may slow in the third quarter due to weak manufacturing export demand, according to the Bundesbank. Industrial production fell in July, and exports posted their steepest drop in nearly a year. The central bank downgraded its growth outlook, citing poor industrial output and trade figures. The warning contrasts with the European Central Bank's upgraded 2016 eurozone growth projection to 1.7%. Germany's economy is expected to expand at 1.7% this year and 1.5% next year, but the government faces calls to cut taxes and increase investment to boost growth.

images.alt_text: German economic growth could slow in the third quarter, primarily due to weak manufacturing export demand, the Bundesbank said on Monday, downgrading its outlook for the eurozone's biggest economy after a slew of subdued data.

site_title: Syrian army ceasefire expires, no statement of extension
summary: A seven-day ceasefire in Syria declared by the Syrian army expired at midnight on September 18, with no immediate announcement of its extension. The ceasefire, brokered by the US and Russia, was announced on September 12. Both the government and rebels have accused each other of violating the ceasefire, the second this year. The ceasefire was set to expire at 11:59pm on Sunday, but no statement was made about its extension.

site_title: CLSA unit said to be doing due diligence on 77 Robinson Rd
summary: CLSA Capital Partners has been selected to conduct exclusive due diligence on 77 Robinson Road in Singapore. The pricing is estimated to be above S$530 million, or around S$1,800 per square foot based on the net lettable area. The nearly 293,270 sq ft property is expected to be a significant acquisition, with its price per square foot significantly above the S$3,000 psf benchmark for prime Singapore projects.

images.alt_text: 77 Robinson Road, a 35-storey office tower, is on a site with 99-year leasehold tenure that started in February 1994

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as technical snag halts afternoon trade; NZ up
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Monday due to technical glitches and caution ahead of central bank meetings in the US and Japan. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed down 0.04% as energy stocks declined amid a multi-week low in crude oil. Meanwhile, gold stocks gained 1.8% as spot gold rose. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index advanced 0.4%.

site_title: Malaysia inflation seen edging up to 1.3% year-on-year in August : poll
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate is expected to rise to 1.3% year-on-year in August, according to a Reuters poll, driven by higher food prices. This marks a slight increase from the previous month's 1.1% pace. Despite a slight hike in fuel prices, transport costs remain low. The country's central bank previously projected inflation at 2-3% for the year. This increase in inflation rate follows a moderation in the rate since a goods and services tax was imposed in 2015.

site_title: ASX says markets will not re-open for trading on Monday
summary: The Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) announced that trading will not resume on Monday due to a technical issue with a component managing individual stocks, resulting in a halted afternoon trading session. The ASX will not conduct a closing price auction either. This technical problem occurred after a delayed opening of the bourse.

site_title: IHH Healthcare subsidiary accepts S$1.8b banking facility
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad's subsidiary Parkway Pantai Limited (PPL) has accepted a S$1.8 billion five-year revolving credit facility from mandated lead arrangers BNP Paribas, Credit Agricole Corporate and Investment Bank, and others. The facility is to be used for refinancing, corporate funding, and financing investments and projects. It replaces an existing S$620 million facility, and PPL's general corporate and corporate funding and working capital requirements.

site_title: Taiwan July export orders may rebound after 16 months of decline: poll
summary: Taiwan's export orders are expected to rise nearly one percent in August, marking the first annual expansion in 16 months, according to a Reuters poll. This growth is attributed to improving demand and new orders, as well as a typical increase in production for year-end holiday needs. The export order data will influence the central bank's decision on interest rate cuts to bolster the export-oriented economy, which has been experiencing weak growth.

site_title: UK to lose passporting rights unless in EEA: ECB's Weidmann
summary: UK financial institutions risk losing passporting rights unless Britain is part of the European Economic Area post-Brexit, according to ECB policymaker Jens Weidmann. Passporting rights allow firms to operate across the EU, a key factor in the strength of the City of London. Weidmann expects some London-based businesses to reconsider their headquarters, but does not foresee a mass exodus to Frankfurt. Losing passporting rights would deal a significant blow to the UK's financial sector.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise as selective buying accelerates, won firms
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.8% on Monday, with individuals buying 96.0 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while offshore investors purchased 47.5 billion won. The South Korean won reversed earlier losses, closing at 1,118.1 to the US dollar, up 0.1% from the previous close. This selective buying trend contributed to the increase in the Korea Composite Stock Price Index, closing at 2,015.78 points.

site_title: Samsung carrying out "internal review" after China Galaxy Note 7 fire report
summary: Samsung is conducting an internal review after a Chinese online retailer, JD.com, reported a Galaxy Note 7 battery fire incident. The incident was referred to Samsung, which has not commented on the matter. The review is being conducted in response to the customer report, but no further information is available at this time.

site_title: Egypt government to start IPO programme with oil companies
summary: Egypt plans to launch an initial public offering (IPO) program with government-owned oil companies, aiming to collect up to $10 billion in three to five years. The program is part of a broader plan to narrow the budget deficit and encourage foreign investment. The government will select local and international investment banks to advise on the offerings and restructure electricity companies before listing them on the bourse. Proceeds will be used to address the country's budget deficit, which is one of the Middle East's widest.

site_title: Australia's ASX halts afternoon due to technical problems
summary: Australia's ASX halted afternoon trading on Monday due to technical problems, halting trading at 0446 GMT. The delay occurred after the opening of the bourse was delayed by over an hour. The ASX is working to rectify the issue and apologized for the disruption. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index was flat at 5,294.8 points before the halt. The issue was related to an ASX component that manages individual stocks.

site_title: ECB must tighten screws as soon as justified: Bundesbank chief
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Jens Weidmann warned that low interest rates and monetary stimulus must not last indefinitely, citing growing risks of ultra-loose monetary policy. Weidmann stated that interest rates should be adjusted as soon as justified to maintain price stability, despite sluggish economic growth in the 19-nation single currency bloc. The ECB's headline rate has remained at zero since 2016, while its deposit rate is in negative territory, cutting into banking sector profits. Weidmann argued that ending loose monetary policy would not harm the economy and could even help governments address their debt issues.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank (ECB) must not allow low interest rates and monetary stimulus to last indefinitely, the head of Germany's Bundesbank (central bank) said on Monday.

site_title: Taiwan politicians break ranks to meet with Beijing
summary: A group of Taiwanese opposition officials met with a senior Beijing official on a bridge-building trip, bypassing the Taiwanese government. The meeting, attended by eight local-level chiefs, backs the "one China" concept and is seen as a push by China to win over the Taiwanese public, who are wary of warmer ties with Beijing. China promised to promote agricultural trade, technology, and tourism with participating counties. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to pressure Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen, who has refused to acknowledge the "one China" concept.

site_title: India's Masala bond makes its debut on SGX
summary: India's Indiabulls Housing Finance Ltd (IBHFL) successfully listed its first Masala bond on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), raising 13.3 billion rupees (S$271 million) with a 8.567% interest rate. The bond, with a 3-year tenor, attracted nearly 70% participation from Asian investors, primarily for investments in affordable housing loans. The proceeds will be used for IBHFL's housing-finance business.

site_title: Exploding phone battery: Samsung begins South Korea exchange
summary: Samsung has begun exchanging recalled Galaxy Note 7 smartphones in South Korea, offering replacements to customers who had experienced exploding batteries. Despite the recall, only a few customers visited stores on Monday, leaving the fate of the device uncertain. The company aims to restore brand loyalty and prevent customers from switching to rival Apple or cheaper Chinese-made models. Samsung will expand the exchange program to other markets by next week, including the US and Europe, after a software update is implemented to limit battery recharges.

images.alt_text: Samsung rolled out replacements for Galaxy Note 7s plagued by exploding batteries in South Korea on Monday, but only a handful of customers appeared to have taken the opportunity to swap their handsets.

site_title: Oil investors flee as Opec freeze hopes face supply reality
summary: Oil investors are fleeing as Opec members prepare to discuss freezing output, despite signs the supply glut will linger. Money managers cut wagers on crude prices before talks between Opec and other producers, with speculators trimming their short position in West Texas Intermediate crude by 29,195 futures and options. World oil stockpiles are expected to accumulate into late 2017, a fourth consecutive year of oversupply, according to the International Energy Agency. Opec production rose last month, making a production freeze potentially meaningless, according to some analysts.

site_title: China Vanke in talks to buy assets to speed up new business development
summary: China Vanke is in talks to purchase assets in cash to accelerate new business development. The company entered a non-binding agreement with a potential seller in December and has appointed intermediaries for due diligence. Despite the initial timeframe passing, talks continue. This move comes as Vanke faces a power struggle that has impacted its business operations. The acquisition is part of Vanke's efforts to diversify and grow its new businesses, which have suffered due to the internal conflict.

site_title: Thousands flock to Indian Himalayas for rare Buddhist festival
summary: Hundreds of thousands of people, including monks and devotees, have gathered in India's Ladakh region for the rare Buddhist festival, dubbed the "Kumbh Mela of the Himalayas". The festival commemorates the 1,000th birth anniversary of Buddhist saint Naropa, who started a rich tradition of Buddhist philosophy in the 11th century. Performers in bright costumes and striking headgear entertained the crowd with music and dance. The festival is a unique celebration of Buddhist culture and heritage, attracting tourists and spiritual seekers from around the world.

site_title: Warning indicator for China banking stress climbs to record
summary: China's warning indicator for banking stress reached a record high of 30.1% in the first quarter, exceeding the 10% threshold that signals elevated banking risks. This marks the highest reading since data began in 1995. The increase highlights concerns over the rapid build-up of Chinese corporate debt. The Basel-based Bank for International Settlements reported this data, underscoring potential risks to the nation and the global economy.

site_title: Japanese companies issue record amount of debt to secure cheap funds
summary: Japanese companies have issued a record-breaking 4 trillion yen ($53.5 billion) in bonds in the July-September quarter, more than double the amount issued in the same period last year. The surge in debt issuance is largely driven by negative interest rates and yield-starved investors, with 1.83 trillion yen of the debt maturing in over 20 years. The Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy has created a dilemma for investors, who must balance taking on credit risk or buying lower-rated issues to achieve positive yields.

site_title: South-east Asian haze crisis killed over 100,000: study
summary: A study published in Environmental Research Letters estimates that the 2016 South-east Asian haze crisis caused over 100,000 premature deaths, with 91,600 in Indonesia, 6,500 in Malaysia, and 2,200 in Singapore. The haze, caused by fires set in forest and peatland to clear land for palm oil and pulpwood plantations, was the worst in memory, cloaking the region in choking smog for weeks. The study's findings highlight the need for immediate action to stem the loss of life, with Greenpeace calling it a "killer haze" that will continue to take a toll unless drastic measures are taken.

site_title: M&A deals in Singapore slow down in Q3 by 27% from a year ago
summary: Singapore's M&A deal value declined 27.2% in Q3 compared to the previous quarter and 26.7% from the same period last year, reaching US$12 billion. This brings the year-to-date total to US$37.5 billion, down 17.1% from the same period last year. The average deal size dropped to US$100.5 million, with domestic deal making growing 19.1% in value and inbound M&A activity falling 18.6%.

site_title: Australia shares slip after technical snag delays opening; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.4% on Monday due to technical issues and cautious trading ahead of US and Japanese central bank meetings. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 18.80 points to 5,277.9. Financial and consumer stocks were the biggest drag, with Wesfarmers and BHP Billiton dropping 2.1% and 0.9% respectively. Gold stocks gained, while energy stocks slid as crude oil hit a multi-week low. New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat.

site_title: Money isn't everything as Brexit leave wary Poles to turn to Germany
summary: Brexit is losing its appeal to Polish workers, with Germany becoming a more attractive destination. In 2015, about 41,000 Poles moved to Germany, surpassing the UK for the fourth consecutive year. Germany's proximity and transportation links are key factors, but the UK's higher wages and language advantage initially drew Poles. However, the Brexit vote has led to incidents of aggression against Poles in the UK, making Germany a more appealing option, according to economists.

images.alt_text: The UK is losing its appeal for Poles seeking work abroad.

site_title: Oracle's Ellison takes shot at Amazon with new cloud services
summary: Oracle Corp unveiled "Cloud@Customer" services, allowing customers to access the company's latest gear from its own data centers without having to purchase the technology. Customers can subscribe to the service on a monthly basis, comparable to buying from a distant data center. This move targets rival Amazon.com Inc., the leading public cloud provider, with more powerful products at a lower cost. Oracle Executive Chairman Larry Ellison made the announcement during the Oracle OpenWorld presentation in San Francisco.

site_title: New Zealand's services sector rose in August: Survey
summary: New Zealand's services sector saw growth in August, with a seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) rising to 57.9 from 54.5 in July. The reading above 50 indicates expansion in activity, with all five sub-indices above 50. The sector's growth was driven by strong sales activity and new orders. This expansion, combined with the performance of manufacturing, suggests above-trend economic growth in New Zealand.

site_title: Formula One: F1 can't be a 'dictatorship', says new boss
summary: New F1 chairman Chase Carey has stated that the sport cannot continue as a "dictatorship" under the leadership of long-term supremo Bernie Ecclestone, amid speculation about his role with new American owners Liberty Media. Carey emphasized the need to understand fan demands and find a path forward, contrasting with Ecclestone's authoritarian approach. Carey's comments come as Liberty Media, led by US mogul John Malone, seeks to take F1 to new heights. Carey's stance suggests a shift towards a more collaborative and inclusive leadership style in the sport.

site_title: US presidential campaign front and centre at Emmys
summary: At the 2016 Emmy Awards, US presidential candidates were targeted with jokes, with Donald Trump being compared to Adolf Hitler and referred to as "Malaria" by host Jimmy Kimmel. Comedian Jill Soloway likened Trump to Hitler, while Aziz Ansari joked about Trump's views on Hispanic and Muslim actors. Meanwhile, John Oliver emphasized the importance of humor in the current political climate, calling it a "soothing balm" for an "open sore." The evening also featured a cameo from Jeb Bush, who appeared as a limo driver in a pre-taped sketch.

site_title: China steel falls to lowest since June amid property curbs
summary: China's steel prices dropped to their lowest in nearly three months, with the most-traded rebar on the Shanghai Futures Exchange touching a session low of 2,190 yuan (S$448) a tonne. The decline came amid worries that fresh efforts to curb home purchases could slow demand, with housing authorities in second and third-tier cities restricting home purchases. The move is expected to affect new property projects and eventually demand for steel, with a Shanghai-based iron ore trader stating "the supply of steel is quite big and demand is at risk."

site_title: Opec 'very close' to agreement to stabilise market, Maduro says
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro stated that Opec members are "very close" to reaching an agreement to stabilize the market. Maduro held positive discussions with Iranian and Ecuadorian presidents at the Summit of the Non-Aligned Movement, where an accord is hoped to be reached by the end of the month.

site_title: US dollar retreats in Asia ahead of Fed, BoJ meet
summary: The US dollar retreated in Asia ahead of the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan's policy meetings later this week. The dollar had risen last week after the release of higher-than-forecast US inflation, but recent below-part economic readings have fueled speculation the central bank will hold off on tightening borrowing costs. This has led to a decline in the US dollar's value in Asia.

site_title: Gold rebounds from two-week low as investors await central banks
summary: Gold rebounded from a two-week low, rising 0.5% to $1,317.17 an ounce, ahead of central bank policy maker gatherings this week. Silver surged 2.1% to $19.1777 an ounce, its largest gain since September 6. Investors await the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan's decisions, with the odds of a US rate increase at 20% and above 50% by December. Hedge funds cut bets on a bullion rally, but prices are expected to remain high if rates are pushed to the end of the year.

site_title: Australian dollar near 1-week high; Fed and BOJ in focus
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.57% to US$0.7536, its highest level since September 13, driven by a US$9.7 billion sale of the Port of Melbourne and expectations of no Federal Reserve interest rate hike this week. Traders are looking for a break above US$0.7567 for further gains. The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to release its September meeting minutes on Tuesday, while the Bank of Japan's policy meeting is expected to be in focus on September 20-21.

site_title: China rich help Europe banks raise US$14b since August
summary: Wealthy Chinese investors are helping European banks raise $14 billion since August, diversifying from a weakening yuan. Asian investors, known for their high-risk appetite, are seeking higher yields in European bank bonds, despite a rout in shares of European lenders. European banks are offering lower coupons to attract investors, but with greater risk amid low lending margins. The trend is expected to grow, with Asian investors potentially increasing their demand for overseas assets by 20% next year.

site_title: Lost locomotive leaves world growth struggling to gain speed
summary: The world economy is struggling to gain speed, with global growth stuck in a 2-3% channel since 2010. The US, China, and Europe are preoccupied with local problems, and monetary policy makers in Japan and the euro zone have "run out of firepower" to spur their economies. The Federal Reserve is likely to hold off on raising interest rates, partly due to concerns about boosting US imports. World growth is expected to remain stagnant, with some economists predicting a 2.8% expansion in 2017. The lack of a global locomotive is attributed to the US struggling to advance, with some policymakers hesitant to take on a larger role.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips to a 3-week as Fed, BOJ decisions awaited
summary: The South Korean won dropped to a 3-week low against the US dollar, reaching 1,121.4 as of 0220 GMT, amid market jitters ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. Stronger-than-expected US inflation data fueled concerns of potential interest rate hikes. South Korean shares extended gains, with the Kospi index up 0.5% as foreign investors purchased more equities, and the sub-index for electric and electronics companies rose over 2%.

site_title: Thais search for missing as 15 die in pilgrim boat accident
summary: A boat carrying Muslim pilgrims sank on Thailand's Chao Phraya river, killing at least 15 people and leaving 11 missing. The accident occurred near the ancient city of Ayutthaya on Sunday afternoon. Passengers were trapped on the lower deck of the pleasure boat, which was submerged in swollen waters. Despite efforts to rescue those missing, 14 people remain in hospital. The incident highlights concerns over safety regulations and overcrowding on Thailand's public transport network, particularly in tourist areas.

site_title: Hanjin reduces fleet by returning chartered carriers to owners
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co, a South Korean container line, is cutting its fleet by returning chartered vessels to owners amid financial struggles. The company has already returned four box movers and three bulk carriers, and plans to remove 13 more container carriers. A court hearing will decide whether Hanjin can be revived or liquidated. The collapse of the firm is expected to spark industry consolidation, and shares have dropped 65% this year. Hanjin's largest shareholder, Korean Air Lines Co, has failed to reach a resolution to inject 60 billion won to revive the company.

site_title: SGX, ICBC tie up to spur listings by Chinese firms in Singapore
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has partnered with Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) to promote its capital markets and support Chinese companies seeking to list on the local bourse. The two parties signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to provide guidance on the listing process, post-listing marketing support, and explore collaboration in derivatives trading and yuan-denominated contracts. This move aims to encourage Chinese companies to raise capital and seek investment opportunities through Singapore, further internationalizing the RMB.

site_title: Australia reaffirms RBA inflation target, underlines flexibility
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) reaffirmed its commitment to targeting inflation, maintaining its 2% to 3% goal as part of its monetary policy agreement with the government. Governor Philip Lowe emphasized the flexibility of the target, acknowledging that financial stability considerations can influence policy settings. The central bank expects inflation to pick up next year, rising to 1.5% to 2.5%, with the current low reading of 1% in the second quarter. The decision maintains the RBA's focus on price stability in a world where boosting consumer prices is the primary challenge.

site_title: ICBC signs five deals to boost commitment to infrastructure, financing efforts
summary: ICBC, the world's largest lender by assets, signed five agreements with organizations in Singapore and China to boost its commitment to infrastructure and financing efforts. The agreements, signed at a forum hosted by ICBC, include partnerships with Singapore Press Holdings, Singapore Business Federation, Singapore Exchange, Sinochem International Corporation, and Surbana Jurong. ICBC Singapore will extend up to $10.2 billion in project financing to SBF member companies for "One Belt, One Road" infrastructure investments, strengthening its commitment to infrastructure partnership and financing efforts.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.65% at the open on Monday, following an Asia-wide rally at the end of last week. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,486.62, while Shanghai's composite index edged up 2.47 points to 3,005.32. The Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.20% to 1,984.12. Investors returned from a long weekend to catch up on the market, driven by a rally in other Asian markets.

site_title: Oil up as Venezuela sees output deal, Libya suffers clashes
summary: Oil prices rose in Asian trade as Venezuela said an output deal with Opec and non-Opec countries was close to being announced. Brent crude futures rose 1.4% to $46.39 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures rose 1.5% to $43.66 per barrel. Clashes in Libya raised concerns about disrupting crude exports. Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro stated a deal could be announced this month, boosting oil prices.

site_title: Obama tells Clinton fundraiser US still grapples with powerful women
summary: US President Barack Obama stated that the country's discomfort with powerful women is a major factor in not having elected a female president yet. He expressed confidence in his fellow Democrat Hillary Clinton's chances, but noted that the country's polarized politics would make the election between Clinton and Republican Donald Trump close.

site_title: Bold hues and cool cutouts stand out on Emmys red carpet
summary: The Emmy Awards red carpet featured bold, jewel-toned dresses and subtle cutouts, with many celebrities opting for primary colors like yellow and red. Notable looks included Shiri Appleby's cobalt sequined dress, America Ferrera's deep blue Jenny Packham gown, and Emily Ratajkowski's navy structured Posen gown. Cutouts were also a trend, with models and actresses like Emily Ratajkowski, Melora Hardin, and Portia Doubleday showcasing the style. Despite the hot weather, some opted for black, including Sophie Turner and Kerry Washington.

site_title: NZ consumer confidence ticks up in Q3: Westpac-McDermott Miller survey
summary: New Zealand consumer confidence rose slightly in Q3, reaching 108.0, according to the Westpac-McDermott Miller survey. This indicates more optimists than pessimists, with respondents feeling "a bit more upbeat" due to warmer weather. However, there's still an "air of nervousness" about the economy's trajectory.

site_title: Indonesia stocks jolted by reality as tax amnesty optimism fades
summary: Indonesia's tax amnesty has generated only 18% of its targeted tax revenue, falling short of expectations, and has contributed to a decline in the Jakarta Composite Index. Infrastructure and real estate companies, which were expected to benefit from the amnesty, have been particularly affected. The government's budget outlook has worsened, and it may need to reduce spending or widen the deficit. Analysts predict a 0.1 percentage point reduction in gross domestic product growth this year, with some expecting a buying opportunity in Jakarta stocks in the coming months.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise over 2% on bargain-hunting
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 2.1% to 9,090.61 on Monday, driven by bargain-hunting after a long weekend and five straight sessions of falls. Electronics subindex and chipmaker TSMC led gains, up 2.9% and 4.3%, respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.580 per US dollar.

site_title: Australia could tweak trade policy in wake of Ausgrid row: newspaper
summary: Australia may update its foreign investment policy to ensure a level playing field, following criticism over rejecting bids from China and Hong Kong for a $10 billion energy grid. Trade Minister Steven Ciobo is expected to suggest updating the policy to be non-discriminatory between nation-states. The move comes after the government blocked bids from Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings Ltd and the Chinese State Grid Corp of China for a half share in Ausgrid, citing unspecified security concerns. The decision was criticized as protectionist by China's commerce ministry.

site_title: Asia: Stocks advance with Australian dollar as oil rebounds; copper slides
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday, driven by a rebound in oil prices and a strong Australian dollar. Oil supplies were disrupted in Libya, boosting crude prices, while the US dollar gained amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The MSCI gauge tracking regional stocks outside of Japan rose following its biggest weekly drop in three months. Economists are split on the BOJ's review, with some predicting a rate hike and others expecting no action. The rally in stocks is seen as a sign of risk appetite ahead of policy meetings by the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan this week.

site_title: Putin claims victory for ruling party in parliamentary vote
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's ruling party, United Russia, is expected to secure an absolute majority in the parliamentary elections, with early results showing 53% support and over 40% of ballots counted. Putin hailed the party's victory, citing a desire for stability in society and the political system. Turnout was low, with only 40% of eligible voters participating, and local observers reported some fraudulent voting. Despite these issues, Putin's popularity remains high, and he is widely expected to seek re-election in 2018.

site_title: Australia's ASX says tech snag delays equities market open
summary: Australia's ASX stock exchange delayed its equities market opening due to a technical issue with a component that manages individual stocks. The market is expected to open as soon as possible, with normal operating hours between 10am and 4pm local time. The delay does not appear to have a significant impact on the market, with other news and updates from around the world, including Singapore stocks notching a 5-day rally and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Lotte chairman Shin Dong Bin to be summoned by prosecutors
summary: Lotte Group Chairman Shin Dong Bin will be summoned by South Korean prosecutors on Tuesday as part of an investigation into alleged corruption, including slush funds, embezzlement, and tax evasion. This comes after his father and elder brother were questioned by prosecutors a couple of weeks ago. Shin Dong Bin is scheduled to appear before the Seoul Central District Prosecutors' office at 9am.

site_title: Rio Paralympics end with music - and relief
summary: The 2016 Rio Paralympics concluded with a closing ceremony that celebrated Brazil's passion for music and reflected on the Games' surprisingly successful outcome. Despite initial predictions of failure, the event sold 2.1 million tickets and marked a "mission accomplished" for organizers. The ceremony featured performances by musicians and athletes, including a minute's silence to remember the fatal crash of an Iranian cyclist. The Games also saw China dominate the medal table, with 239 medals, including 107 golds. The event's success was seen as a positive signal for Brazil, with International Paralympic Committee President Philip Craven praising the nation's "very bright future."

site_title: US dollar holds gains as Fed, BOJ week begins with rebound in oil
summary: The US dollar maintained gains at the start of the week, with the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index holding near its highest close since July, amid stronger-than-expected US inflation data and oil price rebounds. The Fed and Bank of Japan are set to review their monetary policies, with investors uncertain about the BOJ's actions. Despite bets on a US interest-rate hike, the dollar strengthened, while South Korea's won weakened, and Asian markets edged higher.

site_title: China August home prices rise 9.2% y-o-y
summary: China's average new home prices rose 9.2% in August from a year earlier, accelerating from a 7.9% increase in July. Home prices surged in coastal cities like Xiamen (43.8%) and Hefei (40.3%), while Shanghai and Beijing saw increases of 31.2% and 23.5%. The booming property market has boosted economic growth, but concerns over unsustainable price trends and asset bubbles are growing, with some cities introducing restrictions on home purchases.

site_title: Norway's central bank seen done easing after oil crisis escape
summary: Norway's central bank is expected to keep its key policy rate unchanged at 0.50% as the economy fights off a slump in crude prices, the largest in a generation. The bank will maintain an easing bias to avoid a strong krone, despite inflation beating estimates at 2.5%. Unemployment remains low at 3.1%, but house prices are rising faster than forecast. The central bank is expected to keep a probability of a rate cut in the first half of 2017, according to economists.

site_title: Netflix series 'Master of None' wins early Emmy for writing
summary: Netflix's series "Master of None" won the Emmy for writing, with Aziz Ansari and Alan Yang receiving the award for their work on the show. The series, which explores various topics through each episode, was created by Ansari and Yang after their collaboration on "Parks and Recreation." The win marks Netflix's first Emmy prize for TV writing, as the company campaigns to de-throne HBO's dominance in the awards.

site_title: Oil rebounds as fighting halts Libya's Ras Lanuf export return
summary: Oil prices rebounded after fighting halted Libya's Ras Lanuf export terminal, which would have been the first shipment since 2014. Oil futures rose 1.2% in New York, reversing a 2% loss from Friday. The halt in shipments may lead to an OPEC meeting if ministers agree at an informal gathering next week. Oil prices had fallen 6.2% last week amid concerns of a global glut, with West Texas Intermediate rising to $43.55 a barrel.

site_title: UK's May will urge UN action to control mass migration flows
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May will urge UN leaders to control mass migration flows at the General Assembly meeting, citing the need to balance refugee safety with the concerns of European countries. The surge in migrants from Syria and Libya has led to debates within the EU about whether to welcome or turn them back. May will propose encouraging migrants to claim asylum in the first safe country they reach, rather than traveling in unsafe boats. This approach aims to reduce the risks of drowning or needing rescue.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Japanese financial markets are closed on Monday for a national holiday. This closure does not appear to impact global markets, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty. In other news, eSIM platform Airalo has raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over $1 billion, while Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Noble Group hunts investor as profit seen up to two years away
summary: Noble Group, a struggling Asian commodities trader, is still seeking a strategic investor as it aims to return to profit within 1-2 years. Founder Richard Elman, set to step down as executive chairman by June, says the company needs the right partner at the right time. Noble has reduced costs, exited low-margin areas, and raised US$2 billion through asset sales, but faces challenges including debt and slumping commodity prices. The company's priority is boosting cash flow ahead of earnings, with Elman aiming to return to a 15-20% return-on-equity.

site_title: TPP is the path towards regional free trade: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong views the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) as a path towards regional free trade, emphasizing the need for countries to work towards free trade to capitalize on cooperation opportunities. Despite US presidential candidate Donald Trump's opposition to the TPP, Singapore hopes the agreement will grow and expand to include more countries, including China and Korea. Lee also highlighted the importance of a strong and cohesive Asean community for regional economic and security cooperation, while expressing concerns about the potential for regional tensions if member countries compete with each other.

images.alt_text: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) is one of the paths towards free trade in the Asia-Pacific region and countries have to work towards free trade so as not to miss out on the many opportunities for cooperation.

site_title: Singapore shares open one point lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 1 point lower on Monday at 2,826.45, with 32 million shares worth S$44.6 million traded. Losers and gainers were almost evenly matched, with 55 counters up and 54 down.

site_title: Australia's Port of Melbourne sold for A$9.7b to QIC-led group
summary: Australia's Port of Melbourne was sold to a QIC-led group for approximately A$9.7 billion, marking a significant investment in the country's infrastructure. The 50-year lease was awarded to the Lonsdale Consortium, which includes various investors such as the Queensland state government, Future Fund, and Global Infrastructure Partners. The sale is expected to bring diversification benefits to the clients of the landlord port.

site_title: Funds dump gold at fastest pace since May as Fed outlook shifts
summary: Funds are rapidly selling gold, the fastest pace since May, as the Federal Reserve's next policy meeting looms. Speculators cut their bets on a gold rally, with hedge funds exiting the market. The Fed is expected to signal higher US interest rates, which would be bad news for gold. As a result, global exchange-traded funds backed by gold are seeing their largest monthly decline this year, and open interest in New York futures is at a three-month low.

images.alt_text: With the Fed's next policy meeting looming this week, hedge funds are exiting from gold.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to cut more than 200 positions from management teams
summary: Rolls-Royce is eliminating over 200 positions from its management team as part of its restructuring efforts under CEO Warren East. This brings the total number of management cuts to more than 600. The company aims to reach its £30-£50 million savings target for the year, with a goal of £200 million by the end of 2017. The cuts are part of East's turnaround plan, which includes a £200 million savings target.

site_title: China seen keeping its deep pockets open to prop up the economy
summary: China is expected to maintain a fiscal stimulus to support the economy, despite a front-loaded spending earlier this year. The central government's fiscal deficit is projected to surpass 3% of GDP this year, with economists forecasting a deeper shortfall in 2017. The shift in focus from monetary to fiscal stimulus is aimed at compensating for asset bubbles and capital flows uncertainty. China's augmented fiscal deficit is estimated to be 10% of GDP this year, with expectations of a higher deficit in 2017, although some economists expect moderation in the second half of the year.

site_title: Takata said to move forward with sale by taking bids this week
summary: Takata Corp, the Japanese air-bag supplier, is moving forward with an auction of the company, with private-equity firms and car parts makers bidding on a sale. Suitors include Carlyle Group, Daicel Corp, and KKR & Co, with bidders asked to submit proposals by early this week. The sale aims to replace defective air-bag inflators linked to 15 deaths worldwide, with 70 million inflators scheduled for replacement between now and 2019. The sale will be closely scrutinized by automakers, which may consider bankruptcy proceedings to mitigate liabilities.

site_title: Opec may hold formal meeting if members agree on oil in Algiers
summary: Opec may hold an informal meeting in Algiers on September 27 if its ministers agree on oil markets, according to Secretary General Mohammed Barkindo. This meeting, which would be a "consultation and not a decision-making" session, aims to address the global oil glut and stabilize prices. Saudi Arabia has expressed willingness to discuss a possible oil production freeze, while Iran insists it will only consider a cap once output recovers to pre-2012 levels. The International Energy Agency has reduced global oil demand projections, citing deceleration in China and India.

site_title: Pro-Putin party wins 44.5% in parliament vote: exit poll
summary: Russia's ruling United Russia party won 44.5% in a parliamentary election, slightly down from the 2011 vote, and secured a majority of seats. The nationalist LDPR party came in second, while liberal opposition parties failed to meet the 5% threshold. The election is seen as a test of the Kremlin's ability to oversee trouble-free elections, and a dry run for President Vladimir Putin's 2018 presidential campaign.

site_title: UK firms reined in investment plans after Brexit vote: survey
summary: UK firms significantly scaled back investment plans in the month after the Brexit vote, according to a Lloyds Bank survey. The overall business confidence index fell to a four-year low of 12%, down from 38% in January. Companies expected to export less, hire fewer employees, and reduce capital spending, indicating a lasting impact on the economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 8.24 points to 1661.87. The index saw a significant increase in volume, with 17.3 million lots traded worth RM14.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 39.

site_title: US urges North Korea to begin 'serious negotiation'
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry urged North Korea to freeze its nuclear program as a first step towards serious negotiations. The US is committed to mutual defense and rolling back North Korea's provocative behavior. The US is ready to discuss peace on the Korean peninsula and economic development if North Korea agrees to denuclearization. Kerry's comments came after a meeting with Japanese and South Korean foreign ministers.

site_title: US, Japan, South Korea ministers discuss tougher measures against North Korea
summary: US, Japanese, and South Korean foreign ministers met in New York to discuss tougher measures against North Korea following its fifth and largest nuclear test on September 9. The ministers agreed on stronger international pressure, considering sanctions and restrictions on North Korea's revenue sources. They reaffirmed their openness to talks on denuclearization, with the US willing to negotiate if North Korea commits to disarmament, which Pyongyang has refused. The meeting is part of UN General Assembly discussions, which will focus on North Korea's disregard for UN resolutions.

site_title: Australia forces sale of 16 foreign-owned properties
summary: Australia's Treasurer Scott Morrison announced the forced sale of 16 foreign-owned properties, purchased without government permission, since May. The properties, valued at A$14 million, include seven owned by Chinese nationals, four by British nationals, and two by Canadians. The sellers were fined for breaking purchasing rules. This move follows a 2013 government crackdown on 46 properties, mostly held by Chinese interests. The sale aims to ensure foreign investment benefits all Australians and aligns with Australia's national interest.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust to refinance term loan facility
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) announced plans to refinance its term loan facility, granted by National Australia Bank. The refinancing will result in all properties being fully unencumbered, with a total portfolio value exceeding S$1.4 billion. The weighted average debt expiry will be lengthened to 3.4 years, with 88.5% of interest rate exposure fixed, and the all-in cost of debt remaining stable at approximately 3.65% per year. This move is part of CIT's prudent capital management strategy, with no major refinancing requirements until 2H2018 and significant insulation from adverse interest rate movements for 3.2 years.

site_title: Motor racing: F1 governing body to investigate marshal incident
summary: The FIA will investigate an incident at the 2016 Singapore Grand Prix where cars were released to race while a marshal remained on the track, despite three warnings from race control. The marshal was helping clear debris after a safety car period and was nearly hit by the racing cars. Mercedes motorsport head Toto Wolff expressed relief that no one was hurt, and the incident is the second in two years to raise concerns about track security. The FIA will review procedures to ensure such incidents are not repeated.

site_title: Samsung crisis began in rush to capitalise on uninspiring iPhone
summary: Samsung's crisis began when managers overheard the next iPhone would lack significant innovations, creating an opportunity for the company to capitalize on Apple's weakness. In response, Samsung accelerated the launch of a new phone, confident it would dazzle consumers and outdo Apple. The decision was made by top Samsung executives, including phone chief DJ Koh. This move ultimately contributed to the company's crisis, as the new phone failed to meet expectations and damaged Samsung's reputation. The incident highlighted the risks of overreacting to perceived weaknesses in competitors.

site_title: Philippine billionaire sees new ports as growth 'spark plug'
summary: Philippine billionaire Enrique Razon, chairman and president of International Container Terminal Services Inc, expects new ports in Australia, Congo, Colombia, and Iraq to boost cargo handling and profit in the next five years. Despite a global trade slump, Razon views the new terminals as a "spark plug for growth." The company's revenue from port operations rose 11% to $284.3 million in the second quarter, driven by expansion and countering sluggish trade. Razon also plans to invest in Iran, Indonesia, and possibly Myanmar.

site_title: Hugh Grant a 'curiosity', not a sex symbol
summary: Hugh Grant, 56, stated at the San Sebastian film festival that he's not a sex symbol but a "curiosity" for young fans. He expressed his inability to comment on Britain's EU vote and instead shared his preference for an elderly rich lady over unemployment. Grant also discussed cultural differences between France and Britain, citing British prioritization of jokes over food and sex. He quipped that he doesn't believe in truth, instead advocating for lying. The actor praised co-star Meryl Streep, calling her a "genius" and describing their collaboration as "intimidating".

site_title: Merkel's party slumps in Berlin election amid populist surge
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's party, the Christian Democratic Union, slumped in Berlin regional elections, losing about 5 percentage points of support. The anti-immigration Alternative for Germany took 12% of the vote, while the Social Democrats secured 23% and the Greens 16.5%. The defeat marks the second straight electoral setback for Merkel's party, potentially leading to a government exit and a three-way coalition between the Social Democrats, Greens, and Left Party. The Alternative for Germany's success is seen as a signal of protest against Merkel's refugee policy.

site_title: Terror threats rise as presidential issue after New York blast
summary: A series of terrorist incidents in the US has raised concerns about national security, with an explosive device injuring 29 people in New York City, and a stabbing incident in Minnesota. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump seized on the incidents, declaring a "bomb" had gone off in New York, while Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton's running mate Tim Kaine urged caution. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie said the incidents were "clearly acts of terrorism." The FBI is leading the investigation, with no suspects confirmed at this time. The incidents have overshadowed other campaign issues, with the presidential election just weeks away.

site_title: Trade body ICS slams EU's unilateral emission regulations
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has criticized the European Union's unilateral emission regulations, calling it a "market distortion" that contradicts the "free and open" spirit of the shipping business. ICS Chair Esben Poulsson expressed concerns that the regulation could lead to penalties based on "theoretical and arbitrary operating ratings". However, the ICS supports the International Maritime Organization's (IMO) draft text for a mandatory global system of data collection on carbon dioxide emissions from international shipping.

site_title: Hints of US oil industry comeback in North Dakota
summary: North Dakota's oil industry is showing signs of a comeback, with a shortage of workers for highly skilled positions in drilling and oil pump maintenance. As crude prices have rebounded to the US$40 range, companies are bringing back workers, but the recovery has been uneven, with skilled laborers seeing improved prospects while less desirable workers feel little optimism. The industry is expected to stabilize in 2017, with some analysts predicting modest growth in supply, but salaries are generally lower than in boom times, and the recovery may not return to its previous levels.

site_title: Women behind EE winner's success
summary: Singapore-based menswear label Benjamin Barker won top honors at the 2016 Emerging Enterprise Awards, beating out two other firms. The company's success can be attributed to the strong leadership and vision of its women, specifically founder and managing director Nelson Yap's wife, who is not named. Yap credits his wife's input and support for the company's growth and success, stating that "women" should be behind successful men. The win marks a notable achievement for the homegrown label, highlighting the importance of women's contributions in business.

site_title: From Wagga Wagga to MIT, new RBA chief prepares for tougher test
summary: Philip Lowe, the new Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) governor, faces a challenging task in achieving his inflation target of 2-3%. With global interest rates at historic lows and asset bubbles forming, Lowe must navigate the delicate balance between controlling inflation and stimulating economic growth. His predecessors, Ian Macfarlane and Glenn Stevens, achieved average inflation of 2.5% during their tenures, and Lowe's approach will be closely watched by central bank watchers. Lowe's background at MIT and his experience studying financial imbalances may provide a fresh perspective for the RBA.

site_title: Obama, Netanyahu to meet in New York: White House
summary: US President Barack Obama will meet with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in New York next week, discussing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and the need for a two-state solution. The two leaders will also focus on strengthening ties between the US and Israel, following a recent $38 billion defense aid agreement. This meeting comes after a difficult relationship between the two, marked by incidents such as Netanyahu's cancelled White House visit in March. The bilateral meeting will take place on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, with Obama's term ending in January.

site_title: Three US attacks in 24 hours probed for terror links
summary: Three US attacks in 24 hours are being investigated for potential terror links. A New York bombing injured 29 people, a Minnesota mass stabbing occurred, and a New Jersey pipe bomb blast took place. Authorities say no evidence of coordination, but the timing raises concerns about security amid the US presidential election.

site_title: Traders' "gut" feelings separate man from machine: study
summary: A study published on Monday found that traders with stronger "gut" feelings tend to make more money and last longer in the profession, contradicting the Efficient Markets Hypothesis. The study, led by John Coates, suggests that human physiological state affects trading success and survival, allowing humans to compete against algorithmic machines. The findings support the idea that human intuition and emotional factors can be valuable assets in trading, rather than a hindrance as previously thought.

images.alt_text: Go with your gut. Traders who have stronger hunches make more money and last longer in the profession, a scientific study published on Monday has found.

site_title: London Fashion Week puts brave face on Brexit
summary: London Fashion Week kicked off with a brave face on Brexit, citing a surge in sales due to the weak pound. Despite fears that the UK's exit from the EU will harm exports and increase costs, designers and industry leaders believe the impact will be negligible. Retail sales in Britain have largely held up, with luxury items benefiting from the drop in the pound. However, concerns remain about the potential loss of access to the European single market and the impact on immigration on the creative industry.

site_title: How much should you put in the SRS?
summary: The article advises individuals in Singapore to consider how much to contribute to the Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) each year. It recommends that contributors first determine how much they need from the scheme and then decide how many years they plan to contribute, typically between 10 to 35 years, to maximize tax savings.

site_title: 2012: Olam fights stains of Muddy Waters
summary: In 2012, Muddy Waters launched a critical report on Olam International, but the company received support from Temasek Holdings, helping it emerge from the attack with minimal damage. Meanwhile, the F&N takeover in Singapore was marked by record-breaking M&A deals, including a Thai Beverage Public Co purchase of F&N shares and an auction process to break a stalemate. The European sovereign debt crisis worsened in 2012, with fears of a Greek default and stagnant growth in affected countries, leading to electoral defeats and street protests.

site_title: Clashes at Libyan oil ports as counter-attack repelled: officials
summary: Eastern Libyan forces have reestablished control over two oil ports, Es Sider and Ras Lanuf, after a brief counter-attack by an ousted faction. The ports were seized by forces loyal to eastern commander Khalifa Haftar's Libyan National Army on September 11-12. The state-run National Oil Corporation had planned to restart oil exports from the blockaded ports. The fighting came as the oil facilities had been under blockade for several years, with the NOC preparing to resume operations. The LNA's control of the ports is seen as a significant victory for Haftar's forces.

site_title: Affording information security
summary: The cost of information security has risen, raising concerns about affordability, particularly for smaller companies. According to a PwC survey, information security threats have intensified, with 38% more security incidents in 2015, and average budgets have increased 24%. The average cost of a data breach is US$4 million, with breaches in regulated industries costing more. Regulators are taking a more active role in setting data security standards, and holding businesses to greater scrutiny for data breaches. To manage cyber risks, companies must implement a well-thought-out information security policy, create a security culture, and consider cyber insurance.

site_title: At BlackRock, a Wall Street rock star makes US$5 trillion comeback
summary: BlackRock's CEO, Larry Fink, has made a US$5 trillion comeback, transforming the firm from a bond shop to an asset-gathering machine using advanced technology. Fink's strategy, which emphasizes rules-based, data-driven investment styles, has been successful in creating newly liquid markets in high-yield and corporate bonds. The firm's risk-mitigation platform, Aladdin, has become popular among 75 firms managing a total of US$10 trillion. Fink's leadership and influence have grown, with the firm's stock price more than doubling since 2011, outpacing major competitors.

site_title: 60 firms back statement of excellence in governance
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the seventh Singapore Corporate Governance (CG) Week from September 26-30, with 60 companies signing a Statement of Support for excellence in corporate governance. The statement emphasizes the importance of good governance in enhancing shareholder value and promoting financial market stability. Companies such as Olam International, Ryobi Kiso Holdings, Sembcorp Industries, Soilbuild Construction Group, and Tai Sin Electric have expressed their commitment to upholding high standards of corporate governance, citing its role in creating sustainable businesses and protecting stakeholders.

site_title: China's business confidence index rises to 51.2% in Q3
summary: China's business confidence index rose to 51.2% in Q3, up 2.2 percentage points from the previous quarter, according to a central bank survey. This marks the second consecutive quarter of growth. Factory output and retail sales also grew faster than expected in August, driven by a strong housing market and infrastructure spending. A bankers' confidence index rose to 46.5%, with 19.7% believing monetary policy would be relatively loose in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Ascenz set to pioneer ship data analytics on world stage (Amended)
summary: Ascenz Solutions, a privately owned company, is set to expand its presence in Europe by establishing a new business unit in Rotterdam, catering to the region's demand for ship data analytics. The move comes as the European Union's monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) regulation for carbon dioxide emissions from maritime transport takes effect in 2018. Ascenz's Shipulse solution, which provides data acquisition and analytics, will help ship owners meet the EU's MRV requirements. The company, which has already installed its system on over 350 vessels, aims to become one of only five marine technology providers in the world to support the regulation.

site_title: Team Sauber revs up for a fresh start
summary: Team Sauber is revving up for a fresh start after a tumultuous season, having been acquired by Switzerland-based Longbow Finance in July. The team's new leadership, led by Monisha Kaltenborn, aims to rebuild and attract new talent. Kaltenborn is optimistic about the team's future, citing a strong motivation among staff and potential for growth in third-party business ventures. The team is also seeking to address revenue disparities in the sport, which they believe can be improved under the new ownership of Liberty Media.

site_title: Malaysia palm oil output may drop 10% in 2016: minister
summary: Malaysia's palm oil production is expected to drop 10% in 2016 due to the effects of El Nino, which led to a 16% decline in production in the first half. Annual output will be the lowest since 2010, at around 17.96 million tonnes. Despite a recovery in production in the second half, yields will still trail last year's levels. The decline in production is expected to lead to lower prices, averaging between RM2,500 and RM2,600 a tonne this year, and a slightly better value for Malaysian palm oil and products exports.

images.alt_text: Palm oil production in Malaysia will probably drop 10 per cent this year after El Nino cut yields in the first half, according to Plantation Industries and Commodities Minister Mah Siew Keong.

site_title: Twitter draws an average of 243,000 viewers in NFL livestream debut
summary: Twitter drew an average of 243,000 viewers for its NFL livestream debut, with mostly positive reactions from users. The event helped Twitter maintain its position as a venue for live video, but the audience was a fraction of the average 15.7 million people watching across platforms. The deal with the NFL aims to attract users and boost advertising revenue, as the platform faces competition from Facebook and struggles with user growth.

site_title: Palm oil firms pursue traceability to bolster sustainability efforts
summary: Palm oil firms are focusing on traceability to boost sustainability efforts, mapping their supply chain from plantations to refineries. Following pressure from companies like Unilever and Nestle, producers like IOI Group and Golden Agri Resources are working to achieve full traceability by 2020 and 2020, respectively. This involves developing processes to track palm oil from individual farmers to refineries, with the goal of making the industry more transparent and sustainable. Companies like Wilmar International are also exploring traceability to plantations, but the definition of "traceable" remains a subject of debate.

site_title: Solution to forest fires must be multi-pronged: observers
summary: Indonesia's forest fires require a multi-faceted approach to address root causes, say industry observers. Suggestions include providing mechanical equipment to villages for land clearing, microfinance schemes, and improving local livelihoods to shift from slash and burn culture to sustainable land clearing. Limited access to finance hinders smallholders from adopting alternative land clearing methods. Industry observers also stress the need for stepped-up law enforcement, public monitoring, and anti-corruption efforts to prevent fires. Long-term solutions, such as alternative livelihoods and institutionalized access to credit, are crucial to addressing rural poverty and promoting sustainable land use.

images.alt_text: Much more work remains in addressing the root causes of forest fires in Indonesia given the complex landscape, with a multi-pronged approach needed, say industry observers.

site_title: Oil falls to multi-week lows on glut worry; petrol up on outages
summary: Crude oil prices dropped 2% on Friday, reaching multi-week lows, due to concerns of a global glut fueled by increased Iranian exports. Petrol prices rose on refinery and pipeline outages. The decline was also attributed to falling US equity markets and a rising US dollar.

site_title: Rosberg wins S'pore GP, opening 8-point lead
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Singapore Grand Prix, opening an 8-point lead over Lewis Hamilton in the drivers' championship. Rosberg, starting from pole position, dominated the 61-lap race, with Daniel Ricciardo of Red Bull finishing second. The Mercedes team's victory solidified their dominance in the Formula One season, while the economy's impact on ticket sales was noted, with overall sales 15% lower than in 2015. With 15 races completed and six more to go, Mercedes is poised to secure the constructors' and drivers' championships.

site_title: Rosberg celebrates 200th race with Singapore win
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Singapore Grand Prix, securing his 200th Formula One race and reclaiming the championship lead from Lewis Hamilton. Rosberg led from pole to flag, outpacing Daniel Ricciardo, and finished with 273 points, eight ahead of Hamilton with six rounds remaining.

site_title: All eyes on the Fed this week
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting this week is expected to be a key market-moving event, with analysts predicting a low chance of a rate hike due to weak economic data. The federal funds futures market is pricing in only a 15% chance of a rate hike, down from above 20% a week ago. The November US presidential election and the Fed's reluctance to hike rates before the election are also factors influencing the market's expectations. Analysts expect the Fed to signal that the door for a rate hike remains open, but a formal pause is also possible, leading to months of uncertainty and volatility in the market.

site_title: Beleaguered airbag maker Takata said to be planning shortlist of bidders
summary: Takata, the embattled Japanese airbag supplier, is planning to shortlist 2-3 bidders for its sale by October. Suitors include Carlyle Group, Daicel Corp, and KKR & Co, which have been asked to submit proposals by early next week. The sale will be closely scrutinized by carmakers, which have been recalling airbag inflators linked to 15 deaths worldwide. The process may involve bankruptcy proceedings, and Takata is working with Lazard Ltd to avoid bankruptcy and find buyers to take a controlling stake.

site_title: When housing takes priority over parking space
summary: In New York City, a group called Save Manhattan Valley opposes the demolition of three parking garages to make space for an 11-storey affordable housing building. Despite the garages' owners claiming no replacement parking spots will be built, the group argues that affordable housing takes priority over parking for low-income residents and workers. Housing Commissioner Vicki Been notes that prioritizing parking over housing contradicts the city's goal of providing affordable housing. The debate highlights the tension between parking concerns and the need for affordable housing in a city facing a housing crisis.

site_title: China pushes Tibetan tourism while critics fear impact
summary: China has unveiled a luxury hotel in Tibet as part of its efforts to increase tourism in the region, aiming for a 50% increase in visitor numbers in the next four years. Critics, however, warn that the influx of tourists will erode native Tibetan culture and lead to the displacement of the local population, with economic benefits largely going to outsiders. The 103-room Artel hotel, which costs $1,000 a night, is part of a larger tourist complex in the village of Lulang, and is expected to bring in billions of dollars but may not benefit the local Tibetans.

images.alt_text: With a presidential suite that costs US$1,000 a night and views over the snow-capped Himalayan mountains, the Artel hotel is a potent symbol of Chinese plans for Tibet.

site_title: Campus bookstores' functions change as Amazon moves in
summary: Amazon has partnered with Stony Brook University, a part of the State University of New York, to become the university's official book retailer. Students can purchase textbooks online and have them delivered to campus, with the option to pick them up from storage lockers. This shift is an attempt to provide more affordable options to students, and Amazon will receive a percentage of sales from the partnership. However, some experts warn that this change may lead to issues with students acquiring the wrong books and difficulties with reimbursement.

site_title: The big bet is on, as the Fed's September meeting looms
summary: The Federal Reserve's September meeting is expected to be a draw between the Hawks, who favor a rate hike, and the Doves, who prefer a looser monetary policy. Despite recent data indicating an uptick in inflation, odds for a rate hike remain low, at 4 to 1, according to Goldman Sachs. A rate cut is considered a non-runner. The outcome may not significantly impact the sluggish stock market, which has been characterized as "fat and flat" by strategists. The tech sector, particularly Apple, is expected to continue its strong performance, driven by innovations in artificial intelligence and virtual reality.

site_title: UK less attractive to Brexit-wary Poles than Germany
summary: The UK is losing its appeal to Poles seeking work abroad, with Germany becoming a more attractive destination. Despite a shared language and higher wages, Germany's proximity and easier travel options are outweighing the UK's advantages. The Brexit vote has also led to incidents of aggression, further reducing the UK's appeal. The UK's 720,000 Polish expatriates face a new challenge, with many considering alternative destinations.

site_title: Porsche caught in VW diesel lawsuits as investors race to file
summary: Porsche is facing German lawsuits, along with Volkswagen, over the diesel emissions scandal. Institutional investors are seeking 2.8 billion euros from VW and 2.2 billion euros from Porsche, claiming both companies failed to disclose the issue sooner. The lawsuits come as investors rush to file claims before the one-year anniversary of the scandal. Porsche shares have dropped 2.5% on the day and 4.2% last week, while VW shares have declined 3.6% on Friday. The total amount sought in lawsuits against VW is expected to exceed 10.7 billion euros.

site_title: San Francisco leaning tower scandal turns political
summary: The 58-storey Millennium Tower in San Francisco's financial district has sunk 40cm, causing uneven settlement issues. This is a concern in earthquake-prone San Francisco, where many new skyscrapers are built on reclaimed land from the bay. The tower's owners are facing a potential lawsuit and have been warned by engineers about the structural risks. The incident has raised questions about the city's building codes and the safety of its new high-rise structures.

site_title: Attendance falls amid weaker economic environment
summary: The 2016 Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix saw a decline in attendance due to a weaker global economy and slower economic growth at home. The event drew 73,000 spectators daily, a 15% decrease from the average attendance since the inaugural race in 2008. The race promoter, Singapore GP, is considering extending the venue beyond 2017 if terms are favorable.

site_title: Style.com bets on a street style star
summary: Style.com, a digital fashion platform, has appointed Yasmin Sewell as its fashion director. Sewell, a 40-year-old Australian-born Londoner, is the idealized embodiment of the site's target demographic, with a strong social media presence and relationships with designers. As fashion director, Sewell is responsible for selecting featured brands, identifying seasonal trends, and compiling articles from Condé Nast's magazines. The site's focus on shopping and e-commerce is a departure from its previous editorial-only format, but Sewell demystifies the change and gives it personality. Her appointment is seen as a crucial role in reconfiguring the site for the e-commerce landscape.

images.alt_text: Yasmin Sewell, the 40-year-old Australian-born, London-based fashion director of Style.com, is the idealised-yet-accessible embodiment of the retail brand she now represents.

site_title: Dyna-Mac says S$1m misappropriated at its unit, files police report
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings Ltd has filed a police report after discovering that approximately S$1 million was misappropriated by a former employee at its subsidiary. The company's board and audit committee have reviewed internal controls and investigated further incidents. Dyna-Mac has taken immediate action to address the issue, but no further details have been released.

site_title: Japan woos Cuba in latest example of Abe's international diplomacy
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to visit Cuba this week for talks with President Raul Castro, marking the first visit by a Japanese prime minister. The trip aims to strengthen economic and strategic ties, counter China's growing influence, and improve relations with North Korea. Japan hopes to attract business investment and export consumer goods to Cuba, while also seeking Cuba's cooperation in resolving North Korea-related issues. The visit follows the US-Cuba diplomatic thaw and Japan's recent meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin, as Tokyo seeks to counter China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: This fight is everybody's business
summary: Singapore is bracing for the potential impact of the Zika virus, which is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. Experts believe the economic impact will be minimal due to the mild nature of the disease, but precautions are necessary to prevent its spread. The government and private corporations are emphasizing the importance of individual responsibility in controlling the mosquito population through the "Mozzie Wipeout" initiative. While some industries, such as tourism, may be affected, overall, the impact is expected to be negligible unless the epidemic turns severe.

images.alt_text: Victor Mills.

site_title: Rain, govt and firms keep haze at bay
summary: Plantation companies and the government in Singapore have successfully kept haze at bay this year, with increased rainfall being a key factor. Despite efforts by firms in fire prevention, preparation, and recovery, the main difference in this year's haze is attributed to favorable weather and wind direction. Industry players acknowledge that while their efforts are crucial, the factors driving deforestation and haze are complex and interlinked, and addressing them requires a holistic approach. The Indonesian government has also shown a stronger resolve to stamp out the problem, with initiatives such as a ban on expanding palm oil plantations and peatland development.

site_title: SBI Offshore independent non-executive director quits
summary: SBI Offshore Ltd's independent non-executive director Basil Chan has resigned with effect from September 17, citing an opportune time to step down and pave the way for new directors. The resignation follows a boardroom shakedown at the company, triggered by a major shareholder's "mutiny" against CEO Chan Lai Thong. The board will now comprise non-executive chairman Mirzan Mahathir, executive director Chan Lai Thong, and six independent directors. The company will announce the final composition of committees and lead independent director in due course.

site_title: US$ gains after inflation data suggests hawkish Fed
summary: The US dollar surged to a two-week high against a basket of currencies after the release of US inflation data, which beat expectations and boosted bets for a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December. The Consumer Price Index rose 0.2% in August, and traders' expectations of a rate hike increased to nearly 52%. The dollar index rose 0.8% to 96.063, while the euro hit a 10-day low against the dollar. Sterling fell to a one-month low against the dollar due to concerns over Britain's "Brexit" and the potential for the UK to give up EU single market membership.

site_title: Elected presidency changes for improving Singapore's future
summary: Singapore's elected presidency changes aim to improve the system for the country's long-term future, not to bar individuals from standing. Law Minister K Shanmugam stated that the changes, proposed by a constitutional commission, include raising eligibility criteria and reserving elections for a minority group if no one from that group has held the office in the preceding five terms. The changes were not intended to target specific individuals, such as Tan Cheng Bock, who ran in the 2011 presidential election.

site_title: Director buying slows, buyback activity stays flat
summary: Directors' buying activity slowed in Singapore, with 18 companies recording 34 purchases worth S$1.59 million from Sept 12-16, down from the previous week. Buyback activity remained flat, with 23 companies posting 63 repurchases worth S$27.5 million. Notable purchases included Koda Ltd, New Silkroutes Group, and BreadTalk Group, while iFast Corporation saw strong price support with buybacks and director purchases. Insider buys also occurred at Mewah International and Tat Hong Holdings following share price corrections.

site_title: Course set for becoming best tanker operator
summary: AET Tankers, the oil shipping arm of Petronas-owned MISC, aims to become the best tanker operator despite the growing supply glut in the market. Under President Rajalingam Subramaniam's leadership, the company focuses on safety, reliability, and human capital development. AET has established itself as a leader in lightering and is expanding its product shipping, VLCC, and shuttle tanker businesses.
