The company has set its sights on overcoming the supply overhang in the product tanker segment and is exploring opportunities to scale up its operations through acquisitions.

site_title: CPF SA vs SRS: Which is better? (Amended)
summary: The CPF Special Account (SA) offers a better rate of return when adjusted for risk compared to the Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS), but cash is locked up in the former. The SRS, a tax-deferred savings and investment plan, provides tax deductions and flexibility to invest in local stocks and funds. It has unique characteristics, such as a 5% penalty for early withdrawals and a 10-year withdrawal period, which can reduce tax liability. However, the SRS also carries an "implicit capital gains tax problem" and an "implicit estate tax" issue if a large sum is accumulated. Ultimately, the SRS is better suited for those willing to take on more risk, while the CPF SA is a more conservative option with guaranteed returns but locked-up cash.

site_title: Swiber says it is unable to pay upcoming coupon payment for fixed rate notes due 2017
summary: Swiber Holdings, a marine group, has announced it is unable to pay its upcoming coupon payment for fixed rate notes due 2017. The company cited financial difficulties, citing received claims of US$231.4 million as of September 15. Swiber's interim judicial managers are seeking legal advice on the matter. The company's debt issuance program includes a S$1 billion multicurrency debt issuance. This is the latest setback for the beleaguered offshore marine group.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages to fund land purchase through share placement worth S$5.25m
summary: Global Yellow Pages Ltd has entered into a share placement agreement to raise S$5.25 million, primarily to fund the purchase of land in Queenstown, New Zealand. The company will issue 34 million new ordinary shares at S$0.154 per placement share, held by two non-executive directors. The funds will be used for the land acquisition, which was initially valued at NZ$19.2 million (S$19.1 million). If the deal is completed, the placement shares will represent about 16.3% of the enlarged share capital.

site_title: Popular Michelle Obama courts young people for Clinton
summary: Michelle Obama visited students in Virginia to encourage young voters to support Hillary Clinton in the upcoming election. She emphasized that young people's votes can make a significant difference in the outcome, citing her own experience as a factor in her husband Barack Obama's 2012 victory. Obama praised Clinton as a qualified candidate and criticized Donald Trump, calling him unqualified for the presidency. The visit comes as a New York Times/CBS poll shows Clinton has more support from people under 30 than Trump, but still lags behind Obama's levels.

site_title: Changes to elected presidency not to bar certain individuals: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Law Minister K Shanmugam stated that changes to the elected presidency are aimed at improving the system for Singapore's long-term future, not at barring certain individuals from standing. Shanmugam emphasized that the changes are for the benefit of Singaporeans and future generations.

site_title: CapitaLand donates S$300,000 to six charities, runs charity campaign
summary: CapitaLand's philanthropic arm, the CAPITALAND Hope Foundation, has donated up to S$300,000 to six charities in Singapore through a charity campaign called #EatSnapGive. The campaign, which runs from September 17 to October 21, aims to promote the spirit of giving by sharing social posts about the special meaning of food. The donations will support programs for underprivileged children in Singapore, benefiting charities such as Autism Association and Muhammadiyah Welfare Home.

site_title: Dyna-Mac Holdings reports on suspected S$1m misappropriation by subsidiary's ex-staff
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings Ltd reported a suspected S$1 million misappropriation by an ex-employee of a subsidiary. The company lodged a police report and reviewed internal controls, finding no other incidents of misappropriation. The board and audit committee investigated and took immediate action upon discovering the misappropriation.

site_title: Who's too young for an app? Musical.ly tests the limits
summary: Musical.ly, a Shanghai-based social media app, has over 100 million users, mostly in the 13-20 age bracket, but many appear to be younger. The app's terms of service prohibit users under 13, but it doesn't collect age information, raising concerns about its compliance with the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA). Despite this, the company claims to be mindful of its popularity with younger users and engages with parents to address concerns. CEO Alex Hofmann expects the app to diversify its audience, but critics argue that the app's popularity with children poses a liability.

site_title: SBI Offshore's independent non-executive director resigns
summary: SBI Offshore's independent non-executive director Basil Chan has resigned with effect from September 17, following an extraordinary general meeting where a board shake-up was triggered by a major shareholder's "mutiny" against the CEO. Chan relinquished his positions as lead independent director, chairman of audit and risk management committee, and member of remuneration and nominating committees. The company's board now consists of non-executive non-independent chairman Mirzan Mahathir, executive director Chan Lai Thong, and six independent directors. The audit and risk management committee, remuneration committee, and lead independent director appointments will be announced in due course.

site_title: Market rebound since Brexit may not reflect risks: BIS
summary: Financial markets rapidly recovered following Britain's Brexit vote, with major stock indexes shedding over 5% in the days immediately after but then rallying. The Bank of International Settlements warns that this rebound may ignore significant risks, citing concerns over low interest rates, bank profits, and the overall stock of sovereign debt providing record negative yields. Central banks' intervention also played a calming role, but the BIS notes a "distinctly mixed feel" to the recent rally, with more frustration than joy, raising questions about whether market prices fully reflect risks ahead.

site_title: Being focused pays off for Saint Pierre
summary: Saint Pierre, a Singapore restaurant, has introduced a new executive chef, Mathieu Escoffier, who brings a classic, focused approach to the menu. The current dishes deliver in terms of flavor, execution, and concept, with most options available on the tasting and ala carte menus. Highlights include the amuse-bouche, artichoke, and Robuchon potato puree, which showcase the chef's restraint and attention to detail. The restaurant's new phase is marked by a more disciplined approach, but it remains to be seen whether this consistency will endure.

site_title: MFA says no reports of Singaporeans injured or affected by New York blast
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs reported no injuries or direct effects on Singaporeans from a blast in New York City. Singaporeans in the area are advised to exercise vigilance, monitor local news, and follow local authorities' instructions. Those requiring consular assistance can contact the Singapore Consulate in New York or the 24-hour MFA Duty Office. The ministry wishes those injured a speedy recovery.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping plan would see sale of most of its ships
summary: Hanjin Shipping, South Korea's seventh-largest container carrier, is considering a plan to sell more than half of its ships as part of a restructuring effort. The company, which filed for receivership last month, is working on scenarios that could leave it with up to 15 ships and return 61 chartered ships to their owners. With a debt of around $7.28 billion and the government's unwillingness to mount a rescue, survival is unlikely. A court ruling on its plan is expected in December.

site_title: Fox accuses Netflix of poaching employees in California suit
summary: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp sued Netflix Inc in Los Angeles, claiming the internet movie and TV service poached its employees by soliciting and inducing them to break their contracts. Fox intends to seek all available remedies to enforce its rights and hold Netflix accountable. The lawsuit comes as Netflix's popularity continues to grow, contributing to the erosion of live television viewership.

images.alt_text: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp sued Netflix Inc, claiming the internet movie and TV service poached its employees.

site_title: Go-Ahead takes over its remaining 11 routes
summary: Go-Ahead Singapore has taken over its remaining 11 bus routes, rolling out services on September 18, 2016, two weeks after launching its first 13 routes on September 4. The new bus services include routes 2, 6, 12, 15, 17, 36, 354, 358, 359, 403, and 518, covering the Pasir Ris Bus Interchange. This marks the completion of Go-Ahead's takeover of the bus services, which had previously been operated by SBS Transit.

site_title: Samsung says it sold stakes in ASML, Seagate, Rambus and Sharp
summary: Samsung Electronics sold stakes in ASML, Seagate, Rambus, and Sharp, totaling approximately $891 million. The company disposed of half its ASML shares, its entire Seagate stake, 4.5% of Rambus, and 0.7% of Sharp stock. The sales do not affect Samsung's business ties with the companies, and the company will focus on its main business with the freed-up capital.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics said on Sunday it sold stakes in ASML Holding NV, Seagate Technology Plc, Rambus Inc and Sharp Corp to free up money and focus on its main business.

site_title: Indonesia 2016 budget deficit may swell to 2.7% of GDP: ministry official
summary: Indonesia's budget deficit may increase to 2.7% of GDP due to higher-than-expected cost recovery for oil and gas contractors, with the government initially planning to pay $8 billion in the first half of the year. This is up from the previous estimate of 2.5% and may put pressure on the government's financial management.

site_title: Obama expresses 'deep concern' over rollout of Syria deal
summary: President Barack Obama expressed "deep concern" over the implementation of a Syria ceasefire, citing the Syrian regime's blockage of humanitarian aid to civilians. Despite a decrease in violence, the deal's key elements are not being upheld, and Obama has set conditions for closer military coordination with Russia, requiring seven days of reduced violence and sustained humanitarian access. The US and Russia agreed to halt bombing and allow aid into Aleppo, but the deal's shaky implementation has raised concerns among Pentagon officials and US allies, who seek more details on the ceasefire.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama voiced "deep concern" that key elements of a Syria ceasefire are not being upheld Friday, after huddling with top national security aides.

site_title: Blast injures 29 in Manhattan; second device found nearby
summary: An explosion in Manhattan's Chelsea district injured 29 people, described by authorities as a deliberate, criminal act, but with no evidence of a terror connection. The blast occurred outside a housing facility, and a possible secondary device was found four blocks away. Investigators ruled out a gas leak and a link to a pipe bomb in a New Jersey beach town. A Joint Terrorism Task Force was called to investigate the Chelsea blast, but no terror connection has been confirmed.

images.alt_text: Police, firefighters and emergency workers gather at the scene of an explosion in Manhattan on September 17, 2016 in New York City. SOURCE:AFP

site_title: Borneo loggers swop chainsaws for cheap healthcare
summary: In Indonesia's Borneo, a community incentive scheme has led loggers to hang up their chainsaws in exchange for affordable healthcare, saving lives and protecting rainforests. The initiative, pioneered in the village of Manjau, offers discounted medical bills and free training in forest conservation and farming. Since its launch, nearly 1,400 logging households have ceased operations, and the destruction of old-growth forests has slowed. The program, backed by non-profit Alam Sehat Lestari, aims to be replicated in other impoverished communities reliant on illegal industries, with plans to expand to other islands.

site_title: Formula One: Supremo Ecclestone warns he could quit F1
summary: Formula One supremo Bernie Ecclestone, 85, warned he could quit the sport if he doesn't get his way under new owners Liberty Media. Speaking at the Singapore Grand Prix, Ecclestone expressed concerns about the American regime, stating he could walk away if his wishes aren't met. This comes after the sport's sale was announced, with Ecclestone and new chairman Chase Carey in attendance.

site_title: Secura's subsidiary partners SBF on cybersecurity capabilities workshops
summary: SECURA Group Ltd's subsidiary Red Sentry Pte Ltd has partnered with the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) to offer cybersecurity capabilities workshops for Singapore companies, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The workshops, part of SBF's business continuity management efforts, will cover cybersecurity threats and management systems. This marks Secura's entry into cybersecurity training, with plans to expand its services to enterprise and consumer markets. Secura has already seen significant growth in its cybersecurity business since launching in 2015.

site_title: Trump vows to undo eased Cuba relations unless his demands met
summary: US presidential nominee Donald Trump vowed to reverse improved US relations with Cuba unless the island nation meets his demands for more religious and political freedom. Trump's comments, made at a rally in Miami, mark a reversal of his previous stance on the issue. The Obama administration has been moving to normalize diplomatic relations with Cuba, including easing travel restrictions and reopening an embassy. Trump's demands are seen as a significant departure from the Obama administration's efforts to improve ties with the island nation.

site_title: Florida man sues Samsung, says Galaxy Note 7 exploded
summary: A Florida man, Jonathan Strobel, has sued Samsung, alleging his Galaxy Note 7 smartphone exploded in his front pants pocket, causing severe burns. Strobel claims the recall came too late and is seeking unspecified damages for medical bills, lost wages, and pain and suffering. This lawsuit may be the first in the US by a Samsung phone user against the company over a battery defect linked to the Note 7.

site_title: Hundreds of thousands to rally in Germany against mega trade deal
summary: Hundreds of thousands of people are expected to rally in Germany on Saturday against a massive transatlantic trade deal, dealing a new blow to the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP). The European Union and US began negotiating the deal in 2013, aiming to create the world's biggest free trade market. Protests in seven German cities, including Berlin and Frankfurt, come as European governments, including Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel, are torn over the planned deals. Opponents fear the deal would undermine labor market and environmental standards, and lead to job losses.

site_title: US forces helping Turkey clear Islamic State in Syria
summary: US special operations troops, totaling about 40, have joined Turkish forces and Syrian opposition groups to clear Islamic State fighters from northern Syria, as part of the Obama administration's deepening involvement in the 5 1/2-year civil war. This move aims to deny the group access to critical border routes, cutting off supply lines in Iraq and Syria. The US had previously agreed to deploy up to 300 special operations troops in Syria to help opposition fighters. The development comes as the US and Russia are working to implement a ceasefire deal to halt fighting and allow humanitarian aid to reach civilians.

site_title: 14 new Zika cases on Sept 16; new cluster in Sengkang
summary: Singapore reported 14 new Zika cases on September 16, bringing the total to 369 since the outbreak began on August 27. Two cases were detected in a new cluster in Sengkang Central/Sengkang East Avenue.

site_title: Pulitzer-winning playwright Edward Albee dies at 88 at his NY home: Reports
summary: Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Edward Albee died at 88 at his home in Montauk, New York. He was a renowned American dramatist known for works such as "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" and "Three Tall Women." Albee won three Pulitzer Prizes for his plays, including "A Delicate Balance," "Seascape," and "Three Tall Women." He was recognized for his provocative and often brutal look at American life, earning him a reputation alongside Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, and Eugene O'Neill as one of the greatest American dramatists.

site_title: Russia says US refuses to share Syria truce deal with UN council
summary: Russia stated that a US refusal to share Syria truce deal documents with the UN Security Council makes a council endorsement unlikely. US Ambassador Samantha Power and Russian Ambassador Vitaly Churkin were set to brief the council behind closed doors but canceled at the last minute. Churkin attributed the issue to the US's unwillingness to share the documents with the council, citing this as a major obstacle to producing a resolution.

site_title: Wells Fargo slammed in customer suit over account abuses
summary: Wells Fargo faces a customer lawsuit over unauthorized account creation, with three Utah customers suing the bank for allegedly creating unauthorised accounts to boost fees. The bank agreed to pay $185 million in fines and penalties, but has fired 5,300 employees and eliminated sales goals linked to cross-selling strategy. The lawsuit seeks damages of at least $5 million and to force the bank to claw back compensation from executives who profited from the alleged misconduct, including Carrie Tolstedt, the former head of community banking.

site_title: Van Gogh may have been 'bi-polar': researcher
summary: Dutch artist Vincent van Gogh may have been bi-polar or had borderline personality disorder, according to a researcher. A two-day panel discussion at Amsterdam's Van Gogh Museum concluded that a combination of factors likely led to his ear cutting and suicide. Senior researcher Louis van Tilborgh emphasized that it's impossible to draw a final conclusion about his illness. The discussion was part of the museum's "On the Verge of Insanity" exhibition, exploring the Dutch master's mental state.

site_title: British Columbia sees foreign home buyers enduring despite tax
summary: British Columbia expects foreign homebuyers to spend approximately C$4.5 billion in real estate by March 2019, despite a 15% tax imposed in July. The tax aims to cool Canada's most expensive property market, with Vancouver being a major hub for global cash. Home prices in the city are nearly double the national average, making it a magnet for international investors. The government's forecast indicates that the tax may not have the desired effect, with foreign investors continuing to drive the market.

site_title: US condemns Russian elections in Crimea
summary: The US State Department has condemned Russia's upcoming parliamentary elections in Crimea, stating that it does not recognize the legitimacy of the elections and will not recognize the outcome. The US maintains that Crimea remains an integral part of Ukraine, and sanctions against Russia will remain until control is returned. The department also expressed concern over the humanitarian situation in Crimea, including reports of human rights abuses and missing persons.

site_title: China's holdings of US treasuries fall to lowest since 2013
summary: China's holdings of US Treasuries dropped to $1.22 trillion in July, the lowest level since 2013, as the country parred its foreign-exchange reserves to support the yuan. This decline is part of China's efforts to manage its foreign exchange reserves and maintain currency stability. The US Treasury Department reported a $22 billion decrease in China's holdings, while Japan's holdings rose $6.9 billion to $1.15 trillion. The move reflects China's efforts to diversify its foreign exchange reserves and reduce its reliance on US Treasuries.

site_title: Viacom said to abandon plan to sell stake in Paramount Pictures
summary: Viacom has abandoned its plan to sell a stake in Paramount Pictures, citing the studio as a key asset. The decision follows opposition from controlling shareholder Sumner Redstone's National Amusements Inc, which would have undermined shareholders' interests. Former Chairman Philippe Dauman had pursued the sale to pay off debt, but the deal could still be revived. Viacom's debt totals $12 billion, and a sale could have generated up to $4 billion in after-tax proceeds. The company's board recently discussed budgets and capital structure without making any announcements on dividend cuts or other measures.

site_title: Oil prices sharply lower in week as global output mounts
summary: Oil prices dropped sharply this week due to gloomy market forecasts, profit-taking, and concerns over the global supply glut. The International Energy Agency warned of slowing demand growth and rising supply. Mounting US stockpiles, Libya's pledge to boost production, and Nigeria's potential increase in oil exports also contributed to the decline. Brent crude fell 4.5% and West Texas Intermediate fell 6.6% for the week, with prices at $45.77 and $43.03 per barrel, respectively. A producers' meeting on September 26-28 may not address oversupply concerns.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls; risk of Deutsche Bank fine hits banks
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the Dow and S&P 500 declining 0.49% and 0.38% respectively, amid uncertainty over a possible US$14 billion fine against Deutsche Bank. The fine, proposed during negotiations over mortgage-backed securities claims, weighed on big banks, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan. Traders have largely ruled out a Federal Reserve interest rate hike at its upcoming meeting, despite lingering doubts and questions about the timing of the rate increase.

site_title: Argentina, IMF to resume financial checkups next week
summary: Argentina is set to resume financial checkups with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) next week, marking the Fund's return to the country after a 10-year hiatus. The IMF mission, led by economists, will assess Argentina's economy by gathering information and exchanging opinions with government officials, private sector members, and civil organizations. The assessment will be conducted under the Fund's Article IV missions, which evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of each member country's economy annually. The visit aims to provide a comprehensive overview of Argentina's economic situation.

site_title: Temasek is said to be among second-round bidders for Learfield
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state-owned investment group, is among the second-round bidders for Learfield Communications Inc, a sports and entertainment company. Temasek is joined by Creative Artists Agency LLC (CAA) and Thomas H Lee Partners in the auction, which could fetch up to $1.2 billion. Learfield has been owned by Providence Equity Partners since 2013 and helps athletic departments negotiate sponsorship and licensing deals. The bidding process is being advised by Moelis & Co, and representatives for the parties involved have declined to comment.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings Pte Ltd, the Singaporean state-owned investment group, is among the bidders for Learfield Communications Inc, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Sensing threat, UPS plans to expand its 3D printing operations
summary: US shipping company UPS plans to expand its 3D printing operations to Asia and Europe in an effort to counter a trend that could reduce its revenue from storing and shipping parts for manufacturers. The company has already launched a US-based 3D printing service and has 3D printers at 60 UPS stores in the US. UPS aims to print plastic parts around the world and deliver them, with plans to establish a factory in Singapore or Japan. The move is seen as a strategic move to stay ahead of the trend and to provide customers with faster and more innovative solutions.

site_title: US dollar gains as US posts modest uptick in inflation
summary: The US dollar rose against other major currencies due to a modest uptick in inflation, with the US consumer price index increasing 0.2% in August and 1.1% over 12 months. The British pound dropped sharply in relation to the US dollar as Britain prepares to begin formal talks on seceding from the European Union. Central bankers in Washington and Tokyo are set to review monetary policy in meetings starting Tuesday, with markets closely watching for decisions. The dollar's gain was attributed to the CPI numbers, with one analyst stating that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to rethink its policies.

site_title: Brexit proves springboard for EU-27 restart to avert collapse
summary: EU leaders, meeting for the first time without the UK, adopted a "roadmap" to strengthen cooperation on defense, spur economic growth, and bolster security. The move aims to counter the bloc's disintegration and address concerns about migration, terrorism, and youth unemployment. Leaders agreed on measures such as enhanced border control, intelligence-sharing, and defense cooperation, with a focus on internal and external security. The EU remains indispensable, according to leaders, who vowed to correct past mistakes and revitalize the bloc's force for good.

site_title: Ads sidelined as cats take over London Tube stop
summary: Cats have taken over a London Tube station, Clapham Common, as part of a campaign to challenge advertising norms. The Citizens Advertising Takeover Service (Cats) project, launched by creative collective Glimpse, replaced ads with portraits of cats from shelters and those owned by donors. The campaign, which raised over £23,000, has attracted hordes of sightseers and improved the station's atmosphere, with many visitors sharing photos on social media. While not everyone is pleased, the campaign's founder says it has had the desired impact of challenging advertising norms and encouraging positive social change.

site_title: Indonesia to probe Google over possible unpaid taxes
summary: Indonesia's tax office is investigating Google for possible unpaid taxes, with suspicions raised after the company refused to cooperate with a request for tax reports. The probe also involves US companies Ford Motor, Yahoo, Twitter, and Facebook, which are believed to owe billions of dollars in taxes on advertising revenue. Google's Indonesian entity was allocated only 4% of total revenue, deemed "unfair" by the tax office. The investigation will begin at the end of the month, amid Indonesia's revenue shortfall due to declining commodity-related income.

site_title: SGX mulls over listing of leveraged certificates
summary: SGX is considering listing constant leveraged certificates, a type of structured product that gained popularity in Europe, contributing to a $4 billion market turnover in the region last quarter. The exchange's director, Luuk Strijers, stated that the decision to list these products is based on market demand. This move could potentially increase market turnover in Singapore.

site_title: Under fire Trump admits Obama is American
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump admitted on Friday that President Barack Obama was born in the US, amid ongoing controversy over claims of Obama's citizenship. Trump initially fueled the "birther" movement, questioning Obama's US citizenship, but now claims Democratic rival Hillary Clinton started the controversy. The White House views Trump's claims as racist, and Obama's birth certificate was released in 2011 to debunk the allegations. Trump's admission is seen as an attempt to neutralize the issue, but it has not eased tensions with black and Hispanic voters who support Clinton.

images.alt_text: After years of fuelling conspiracy theories, Republican White House nominee Donald Trump admitted Friday that President Barack Obama is an American as he tried to neutralise damaging charges of racism.

site_title: 4 more fun
summary: BMW has updated the 4 Series Gran Coupe with a new inline six-cylinder turbocharged engine, the 440i Gran Coupe. The engine produces 326 hp and 450 Nm, a 20 hp and 50 Nm increase over the previous 435i model. The new engine features a twin-scroll turbo, water-to-air intercooler, and a closed deck engine block for added strength. The 440i Gran Coupe retains its sporty design, generous head and leg room, and excellent handling, making it a versatile driving experience.

site_title: iPhone launch generates crowds, queues worldwide
summary: Apple's global iPhone 7 and 7 Plus launch generated excitement and frustration worldwide, with crowds and queues forming in stores. Despite initial enthusiasm, shortages of large-screen iPhone 7 Plus and jet-black iPhone 7 models left some disappointed. Analysts are divided on the cause of the shortages, with some attributing it to strong demand and others suggesting limited supply. Apple's shares dropped slightly, but analysts expect iPhone sales to grow 3.6% to 77.5 million in the final quarter of this year. The new iPhones' design, which eliminates headphone jacks, marks a new path for the tech giant, but its impact on sales remains uncertain.

site_title: Lessons from a much younger mentor
summary: A reverse mentorship program, where older workers seek guidance from their millennial colleagues, is gaining traction in offices. The article highlights the experience of a 55-year-old journalist who turned to his 27-year-old colleague, Talya, for help learning Snapchat, a popular social media platform. The mentorship taught the journalist valuable lessons about generational differences and the importance of bridging gaps between age groups. Experts suggest that while older workers may have declining cognitive abilities, they can compensate with discipline and experience, and that reverse mentorships can be beneficial, but ideally should work in both directions.

site_title: US inflation stirring as healthcare, housing costs surge
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in August, driven by a 0.3% increase in the core CPI, the largest since February. Healthcare costs surged 1% in August, the largest gain in 32.5 years, due to the expansion of healthcare coverage under the Affordable Care Act. This is likely to prompt the Federal Reserve to consider raising interest rates this year, despite a disappointing August retail sales report. The Fed's preferred measure, the core PCE price index, is expected to rise 0.2% in August, taking the year-on-year gain to 1.7%.

site_title: J&J buying Abbott's vision care assets for US$4.3b
summary: Johnson & Johnson (J&J) has acquired Abbott Medical Optics' vision care assets for $4.3 billion. The deal targets the growing vision care market, with J&J gaining access to Abbott's surgical ophthalmic portfolio, including cataract surgery and laser vision surgery. The acquisition is expected to make J&J a more comprehensive leader in vision care. Abbott CEO Miles White cited the company's shift in focus towards cardiovascular devices and diagnostics as the reason for the divestiture.

images.alt_text: Johnson & Johnson announced Friday that it reached a deal to buy opthalmic assets from Abbott Laboratories for US$4.3 billion as it targets vision care in an aging world.

site_title: Bullet train operator's IPO appeal boosted by Japanese real estate
summary: Japan's bullet train operator JR Kyushu plans to sell 392 billion yen (S$5.3 billion) in its initial public offering (IPO), drawing interest in its various businesses, including real estate and non-transportation services, which account for about half of its sales. The company benefits from record tourist arrivals, with its station and real estate businesses flourishing. The IPO, set to unshackle the company from government controls, is expected to make it the world's largest IPO this year, surpassing Postal Savings Bank of China Co's planned US$8.1 billion offering.

site_title: Suddenly alone, STI backtracks a little
summary: Singapore shares rebounded on Friday, posting a 0.78% gain to close at 2,827.45, despite regional markets being closed and central bank meetings looming. The Straits Times Index (STI) outperformed its week-ago reading, but still trailed by 1.6%. Trading volumes were thin, and investors remained cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan meetings. Key performers included Singapore Telecommunications, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A Federal International associate has received a letter of intent (LOI) for a $155 million project to engineer, procure, construct, and install offshore wellhead platforms for the Zawtika Development Project Phase 1C. The project is expected to take 19 months to complete. Rotary Engineering secured contracts worth $64 million and CSC Holdings invested $900,000 in a UK project. The Federal group's order book has increased to $90 million.

site_title: Suu Kyi urges businesses to invest in Myanmar
summary: Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi urged businesses to invest in the country, citing economic development as a key to advancing democracy. Suu Kyi said foreign investment would improve the livelihoods of the nation's 50 million people, while US President Barack Obama pledged to lift long-standing sanctions on the country. The sanctions were imposed in 1997 after decades of military rule and stifled dissent. Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy party won the first free national vote in 25 years, but has been criticized for lacking comprehensive economic policies.

site_title: New opportunities abound: Tharman (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Tharman Shanmugaratnam urges against pessimism, instead emphasizing the need for domestic politics to adapt to the changing global economy. He notes that despite challenges such as China's slowdown and Brexit, Asia's economies continue to grow, with global trade expected to reach 2.8% this year. Tharman advises governments to focus on unity and drafting policies to address domestic issues, rather than getting bogged down in ethnic and immigration debates. He also emphasizes the importance of workers upskilling and getting plugged into global value chains to remain resilient in the face of technological disruption.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end week lower, dragged down by Deutsche Bank
summary: European stocks declined on Friday, led by a 1.5% drop in Frankfurt's DAX 30, as Deutsche Bank shares plummeted 8.5% due to a record fine from the US Justice Department. The fine, potentially worth up to $14 billion, stems from mortgage securities sold in the 2008 crisis. This news sent ripples through the European banking sector, with shares in Royal Bank of Scotland and Societe Generale also falling. Global stocks lost ground on the week, with US stocks also declining due to weakness in bank and petroleum-linked equities.

site_title: Fertility treatment a potent S'pore business
summary: Singapore's fertility treatment business has seen significant growth, with over 6,000 assisted reproduction cycles performed in 2015, surpassing the 6,000 mark for the second consecutive year. This represents a substantial increase from the 5,000 cycles conducted in 2012. The rising demand for fertility treatments in the country suggests a strong and increasing need for assisted reproductive services.

site_title: Japan real interest rates show monetary policy is loose
summary: The Bank of Japan is considering shifting the focus of monetary policy at its upcoming review, with analysts urging the central bank to emphasize the low real interest rates achieved through quantitative and qualitative easing (QQE). Real interest rates have averaged minus 0.03% since QQE's launch in 2013, compared to 1.8% during Japan's longest bout of deflation. The BOJ should focus on communicating the low real rates to the public, rather than easing further, according to economists, as inflation expectations remain a key factor in keeping rates low.

site_title: Water protests in tech hub expose urban India's growing pains
summary: Water protests in Bengaluru, India's tech hub, have exposed growing pains in the city. Locals are angry at the pressure new inhabitants put on resources, with protesters demanding action on a water dispute. The protests led to the evacuation of major tech companies' offices, including Oracle's, and the closure of dozens of businesses to ensure staff safety. The issue highlights the strain on urban India's resources and the need for more effective management of water supplies.

site_title: New wave of IPOs expected in 2016/17
summary: A survey of 125 C-suite executives in Europe, North America, and Asia found that nearly two-thirds believe a new wave of initial public offerings (IPOs) is expected in 2016-2017. Respondents in North America are the most optimistic, with 76% believing a return to previous years' IPO levels is possible within 12 months. Despite recent global market volatility, 64% of respondents plan to be ready to move quickly when an IPO window opens, and 68% have a strategy in place to mitigate near-term challenges.

site_title: Jason Hldgs employee, ex-employee interviewed by CAD
summary: Jason Holdings, a timber flooring specialist, reported that two employees, New Sze Wei and Amy Chan Mei Lin, were interviewed by Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) for an ongoing investigation. The investigation, launched on August 30, is believed to be related to a possible offence under the penal code. The company also received a letter of demand from KPMG for payment of S$41,000, which could have a material adverse impact on its financial position. Jason Holdings' shares remain suspended, trading at S$0.062.

site_title: Japan to bring in more foreign workers as population falls
summary: Japan plans to bring in more foreign workers to bolster its shrinking labor force, with policies potentially doubling the number of overseas workers. The move aims to address the country's aging population and labor shortage.

site_title: Hedge fund-like mutuals losing shine
summary: Liquid alternative funds, which mimic hedge fund strategies, are losing their appeal. Despite recent peaks, the sector faces challenges, including lagging returns and setbacks at prominent funds. Retail investors, who have pulled billions from other funds, may soon follow suit. The AQR Managed Futures Strategy Fund, a trend-following financial futures fund, currently leads the sector with $14.3 billion in assets. Early warning signs suggest the sector's popularity may be waning, potentially marking a shift away from liquid alternatives.

images.alt_text: BANKING ON ALTERNATIVES: The liquid-alts sector took off after the financial crisis of 2008, when investors intensified their search for funds that could protect them from the full force of a severe stockmarket decline.

site_title: Air France's 'absurd' valuation lures buyers where many fear to go
summary: Air France-KLM's new CEO Jean-Marc Janaillac is bringing a conciliatory approach to labour, potentially boosting the airline's shares. Despite labour strife and a challenging competitive landscape, investors such as Roche-Brune Asset Management and Investors TFI SA are buying in, citing the airline's potential for profit. The stock price is undervalued at 3.1 times estimated earnings, and analysts like Bank of America Merrill Lynch recommend buying the shares. However, the French government's role in the airline's operations and the risk of strikes ahead of presidential elections may deter some investors.

site_title: Decades-old drug technology finally nears its big breakthrough
summary: Decades-old drugs are nearing a breakthrough with the use of hydrogen, a lighter form of the element that can slow their breakdown by the body, allowing patients to take them less frequently and potentially reducing side effects. This innovation could lead to improved treatment options for patients.

site_title: Game of Thrones bids to make Emmys history
summary: Game of Thrones is poised to make television history at the 68th Emmy Awards, with a total haul of 35 awards, surpassing Frasier as the most decorated fictional show since the awards began. The HBO series has nine nominations in top categories, including drama and writing, and is expected to win at least three trophies. FX's The People v. O.J. Simpson: American Crime Story has 13 nominations, making it a strong contender, while The Americans could also pull surprises. The ceremony, hosted by Jimmy Kimmel, is set to take place on Sunday.

site_title: Sale of affected Samsung Note 7 illegal with formal recall in US
summary: Samsung Electronics must restore consumer and investor confidence after the formal recall of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone in the US. The recall, which makes the sale of affected devices illegal, affects about 1 million phones sold in the US, with 92 reports of overheating batteries and 26 cases involving burns. The US Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) urges consumers to stop using and turn off their phones, and Samsung will start shipping replacement phones within days. The company must now manage the fallout and restore public trust, with experts saying it's a tough job that will define Samsung's future.

site_title: Revitalising touch (Amended)
summary: Singapore is witnessing a growing interest in holistic anti-ageing treatments, with alternative methods gaining traction. Life Infinity Clinic, a China-based healthcare company, has opened its first clinic in Singapore, focusing on functional medicine and offering services such as detoxification screening and anti-ageing screening. The clinic claims that by managing chronic diseases, individuals can live up to 40-50 years longer. Meanwhile, ELO Bath Lab has launched oxygen-rich water for drinking and soaking, claiming it increases tissue oxygen levels and improves cellular functions. The company also offers a bath soak treatment with even higher oxygen levels.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) acquires The Baltic Exchange, aiming to expand its dry-bulk Freight Forward Agreement (FFA) user base and develop the product for profit. The acquisition is expected to add approximately 1% to SGX's FY2016 profit after tax and minority interests. Analysts at Phillip Securities and OCBC Investment Research have varying views on the acquisition, with some seeing potential for growth and others expressing caution. Meanwhile, Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) is recommended as a "buy" due to favorable demand-supply dynamics in Australia's industrial real-estate market.

site_title: S'pore Grand Prix flags off into new chapter
summary: The Singapore Grand Prix marks the beginning of a new chapter for Formula One, as Liberty Media Corporation, a US media and entertainment group, acquires the sport for $8 billion. Despite declining viewership, revenues remain steady, and Liberty is expected to boost F1's reach through digital platforms and marketing. Industry observers believe Liberty is better placed to grow a new generation of race fans, and the Singapore Grand Prix may benefit from increased big-name acts and enhanced track-side entertainment. The deal's outcome will be determined in the first quarter of 2027, when Singapore's current contract expires.

site_title: Japan to step up engagement in South China Sea
summary: Japan's new defense minister, Tomomi Inada, announced plans to increase engagement in the South China Sea, amid China's reclamation of land around maritime features. Inada stated Japan will participate in joint training cruises, bilateral and multi-lateral exercises, and provide capacity building assistance to coastal nations. Her comments come after Chinese President Xi Jinping urged Japan to "exercise caution" in the waters, and Japan has frequently urged all parties to adhere to international law. Japan's actions aim to counter China's coercive attempts to change the status quo.

site_title: Shareholder move to oust SBI Offshore CEO stalls
summary: A shareholder meeting for SBI Offshore to oust CEO was adjourned after two hours due to lack of clarity on investigations into potential breaches of securities laws. The meeting, triggered by a major shareholder's "mutiny," saw intense questioning and remarks from directors and shareholders. The adjournment was due to the need for greater clarity on the investigations before proceeding with the vote. The outcome of the meeting remains uncertain.

site_title: Internet radio Pandora takes on streaming stalwarts
summary: Pandora, an internet radio leader, announced plans to challenge streaming stalwarts like Spotify by undercutting prices and offering on-demand music. This move comes amid market uncertainty over Pandora's future and the shift towards on-demand streaming, which is reshaping the music industry. By matching prices and offering on-demand content, Pandora aims to regain market share and compete with established players.

site_title: Team SunMoon take top prize
summary: The 2016 Business Times Corporate Golf League concluded with Team SunMoon taking the top prize, accumulating 541 stableford points. Edge Golf secured second place with 533 points, and defending champions Boustead moved to third spot with 525 points. The league featured over 120 golfers and concluded with a banquet dinner at Tanah Merah Country Club. The winner of Category A was SPH Swinging Scribes with 483 points, and sponsors like Audi Singapore and Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts supported the event.

images.alt_text: TRIUMPHANT: Team SunMoon continued their winning ways, having won from 2012-2014 in the Competitive Category and also in the social category last year.

RUNNERS UP: Team Edge Golf (above), with SPH's deputy CEO Patrick Daniel (second from left), and Team Boustead. More than 120 golfers teed off for the final showdown of the BT Corporate Golf League championship on Friday.
RUNNERS UP: More than 120 golfers teed off for the final showdown of the BT Corporate Golf League championship on Friday.

site_title: NZ extends anti-money laundering rules to capture property agents
summary: New Zealand will extend its anti-money laundering laws to cover real estate agents and other professions, including lawyers and accountants, amid concerns that laundered money has fueled the country's property market boom. The extension, set to be implemented in mid-2017, aims to align New Zealand's standards with those of countries like Canada and the UK. The move comes after the Panama Papers revealed how New Zealand trusts were used to create secretive, un-taxed vehicles. The government's consultation period with affected professions has closed, and experts say the extension is necessary to combat money laundering.

site_title: Lisbon landlords cry foul over 32-euro rent from century-old freeze
summary: The Portuguese government is set to extend a century-old rent-control rule for five more years, despite criticism from landlords. The rule, which limits rents to 32 euros a month, would delay a 2012 reform aimed at increasing property supply and attracting investment. Landlords, such as Joao Anastacio, are frustrated with the low rents, which have reduced their incentive to renovate properties. The extension may also deter foreign investment, which has driven a property boom in Portugal. The move is part of the government's efforts to protect tenants, particularly those over 65 or disabled.

site_title: S'pore distributor of BYD electric vehicles ties up with Uber
summary: S Dreams, a Singaporean subsidiary of S i2i, has partnered with Uber to offer a fleet of 3,000 BYD electric vehicles within a year. The cars, which cost around S$200,000, will be used for car rentals and drivers will be paid a basic salary plus incentives. This partnership aims to capitalize on the energy savings of electric vehicles, making the business "viable". The fleet will be upgraded with a longer range of 400km and faster charging times.

site_title: Avid gamers' must-haves
summary: Sony and Microsoft will release updated hardware for their PlayStation 4 and Xbox One consoles by the end of the year, breaking a three-year tradition of extended product life cycles. The new PlayStation 4 is a slimmer, more energy-efficient console with a matte black finish, but lacks an optical port, and the updated Dualshock 4 controller features a transparent strip showing controller color assignments. Microsoft will release the Xbox One S, which supports 4K resolution and can stream 4K content, and a more powerful Xbox One console, Project Scorpio, next year. Gamers are advised to wait for Microsoft to reveal its pricing before committing to a console.

site_title: Glut belies risk of thinner Opec output cushion
summary: Oil prices may jump 35% as Opec's spare capacity dwindles to its lowest since 2008, with global spending cuts reducing prospects for new output. The group's strategy of keeping production open leaves a smaller cushion for unexpected needs, prompting Citigroup and Gunvor Group to predict prices rising to $65 and $70 a barrel, respectively. Global petroleum stockpiles rose to 3.1 billion barrels, but demand growth is expected to be slow, and prices may rise as inventories are depleted.

site_title: IHC clarifies lenders' receivership of its Australian properties
summary: IHC, a Singapore-listed medical property developer, has clarified that two Australian bank lenders, Westpac and National Australia Bank, appointed receivers for its three Australian properties after Crest Fund lodged unlawful caveats. The caveats were voluntarily withdrawn, but Westpac and NAB have taken control of the properties. IHC claims the total fair value of the properties exceeds the outstanding loan amounts, and negotiations for the sale of two properties were at advanced stages. The dispute is now before the High Court.

site_title: No probe fallout for joining tax amnesty: Indonesia finance minister
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, has confirmed that Singapore will not consider participation in the country's tax amnesty program as a suspicious act. This assurance was given after a Reuters report revealed that private banks in Singapore were sharing the names of clients joining the amnesty with local authorities. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) also stated that participation in the amnesty program would not attract a criminal investigation in Singapore. This move aims to encourage Indonesians to declare their assets in Singapore as part of the tax amnesty, with over 60,000 taxpayers having declared assets worth 552.7 trillion rupiah.

images.alt_text: Singapore has given assurances that Indonesians declaring assets in the city-state as part of Jakarta's tax amnesty will not have their participation itself considered a suspicious act, Indonesia's finance minister said.

site_title: Consumers will have to wait to buy jet-black iPhones
summary: Apple's iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus in the jet-black finish will not be available for walk-in customers in Apple stores due to initial high demand, with only 128 GB and 256 GB models available. Pre-orders for the jet-black iPhone are available online with shipping dates in November, while other finishes will be available in Apple stores starting Friday. This decision may indicate Apple's concerns about sales, but carriers report strong pre-orders, with Verizon's executive vice-president stating pre-orders are "business as usual".

site_title: Where is Google placing its bets?
summary: Google is placing bets on its future, with 90% of its revenues coming from search-related advertising. The company's long-term bets are housed in X: The Moonshot Factory, focusing on radical ideas like autonomous cars, global Internet connectivity via floating wireless routers, and connected contact lenses for diabetes sufferers. Short-term bets include virtual reality, augmented reality, mixed reality, speech recognition, and machine learning, with Google aiming to collect data and sell advertising in new ecosystems. Whoever controls the future of human-machine interaction will own the search bar and the advertising universe.

site_title: Homing in on a green start
summary: Ikea and other furniture companies are promoting eco-friendly products and educating consumers on sustainable living. The Swedish retailer created a mock home at the Green Living event to demonstrate how a family of four can save over $1,300 a year by using sustainable practices. Manufacturers are incorporating eco-friendly materials, such as bamboo and reclaimed wood, and reducing energy consumption through LED lighting. Local retailers like Space Furniture and Journey East are also prioritizing sustainability, sourcing materials from environmentally responsible suppliers and reducing waste. This shift towards sustainability aims to benefit both consumers' wallets and the environment.

site_title: August's NODX flat; market expected worse (Amended)
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in August remained flat after two consecutive months of decline, dipping 0.6% from July. This marks a slight improvement from the 10.6% drop in July and 2.4% decline in the previous month. The flat NODX shipment is attributed to prevailing headwinds, with market expectations suggesting a possible further decline.

site_title: Traders agonise over 'the curve' as Japan upends world bonds
summary: Traders worldwide are speculating on a potential shift in Japan's monetary policy, which could steepen the yield curve and reverse this year's collapse in Japan's longest-dated yields. The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) next policy meeting on Sept 20-21 is expected to see a cut in negative interest rates and a reduction in long-term bond purchases. This could ripple across global bond markets, influencing investors and policymakers, and upend conventional wisdom on the Treasuries market. The move has the potential to benefit lenders and savers, but also carries risks for bondholders.

site_title: After Brexit blow, wind parks at sea undermine carbon prices
summary: The world's biggest carbon market is struggling with slumping prices due to the construction of offshore wind parks, such as those planned by Dong Energy A/S off the Dutch coast. The projects' costs are 60% cheaper than estimated a year ago, offering a "game changer" for lawmakers fighting climate change. This shift in energy economics highlights the range of options available beyond emissions markets, according to Barclays plc. The tariffs could be a significant factor in the changing energy landscape.

site_title: German banks count cost of global shipping crisis
summary: German banks are struggling to recover from their significant exposure to the global shipping crisis, with outstanding loans totaling up to a quarter of the world's $400 billion in shipping debt. As the shipping industry faces its deepest downturn ever, German banks may see a significant loss on their investments, forcing them to sell down their debt at a discount or write off loans. The crisis is exacerbated by a glut of ships, with many built before the financial crisis, and is affecting European banks already facing sluggish economies and tough capital demands.

images.alt_text: German banks are struggling to recoup tens of billions of dollars of loans as a global shipping industry slump hits them hard.

site_title: Singapore's bond market still a good bet
summary: Singapore's bond market has experienced a strong run in 2016, with SGD-denominated bonds recording a 15% growth in issuance volumes to S$15.6 billion year-to-date, outpacing the broader South-east Asia region. Low interest rates and strong demand from local and international investors, including institutional investors, have driven the growth. The market has seen a shift towards safer credits, with AAA-rated bonds dominating the market, and retail bonds gaining popularity. The market is expected to continue its strong run through the end of 2016, with positive market sentiment and a diverse issuer base.

site_title: EU faces 'critical situation' after Brexit, warns Merkel
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned that the European Union faces a "critical situation" after Brexit, calling for the bloc to improve. At a meeting of EU leaders in Bratislava, Merkel emphasized the need to address challenges such as mass migration, security, globalization, and a stuttering economy. The 27 leaders, excluding British Prime Minister Theresa May, aimed to demonstrate their ability to respond to these challenges.

site_title: Heritage comes alive
summary: A century-old landmark building in Clarke Quay, Singapore, has been transformed into a modern Chinese restaurant, VLV, and a club lounge. The two-storey heritage building, known as River House, was restored and received a URA Architectural Heritage Award in 1993. VLV's CEO, Dolores Au, aimed to create a unique experience with a name that doesn't set expectations, allowing guests to create their own personal experience. The restaurant, led by chef Martin Foo, serves modern Chinese cuisine with classic flavors and modern techniques. The club lounge and al fresco courtyard bar are set to open soon, offering a vibrant dining experience.

site_title: US: Wall Street weighed down by banks, energy stocks
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, weighed down by a 9% drop in Deutsche Bank shares and a 2.2% decline in oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 dropped 0.49% and 0.47%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.28%. The energy index was the second-largest loser, and investors await the Federal Reserve's meeting next Tuesday.

site_title: F1 drivers' plea to new owners: Make racing closer, faster and more exciting
summary: Formula One drivers are urging the new owners, Liberty Media, to make the sport more exciting by increasing competition among midfield teams, allowing them to win races and fight for titles. Drivers like Sebastian Vettel, Sergio Perez, and Daniel Ricciardo want to see closer battles, faster cars, and a return to the old V12 engines. They also believe the sport needs to appeal to a younger audience and are open to discussing their ideas with Liberty Media, possibly as early as Friday. The drivers hope to see changes that will make the sport more thrilling for fans.

site_title: Fifa says appoints PwC as new auditors
summary: Fifa has appointed PwC as its new auditors, replacing KPMG, which stepped down in June. The appointment will be valid until the next Fifa Congress in May 2017, after which the congress will decide on the auditors for a full three-year period.

site_title: Is your co-worker toxic or just annoying?
summary: A toxic colleague differs from an annoying one, impacting office performance and engagement. Toxic behavior is characterized by negativity, malcontent, and a poisonous effect on others, while annoying behavior is a matter of individual preference. Recognizing the difference can help individuals and organizations address the issue, saving careers and sanity. Effective management and leadership strategies can mitigate the negative effects of toxic behavior, promoting a healthier work environment.

site_title: Greenworthy
summary:
Here's a summary of the article in 100 words or less:

The article highlights eco-friendly products that can help reduce waste and promote sustainability in daily life. Smart Cara is a food waste converter that turns organic waste into compost, while the LED Lantern harnesses solar energy to power a lantern. The Crometta Showerhead is a water-efficient showerhead, and the Bittergurka Hanging Planter allows for vertical gardening. Other products, such as the Pringles Lounge Chair and Paloma II Reclaimed Wood Dining Table, are made from sustainable materials and reduce waste. These products demonstrate innovative solutions for a more sustainable lifestyle.

site_title: City of London should not suffer from Brexit: Boris Johnson
summary: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson expressed optimism about the UK's post-Brexit talks, stating London's financial sector is a "massive asset" to Europe. He argued that the sector should not be weakened by the EU separation negotiations. Johnson also drew parallels between the UK's relationship with Italy, citing the importance of trade and the need to avoid tariffs on Italian wine. The comments came as new Prime Minister Theresa May plans to invoke Article 50 in early 2017, marking the beginning of the UK's formal withdrawal from the EU.

site_title: Blow for Obama's TPP as Vietnam Parliament defers ratification
summary: Vietnam's parliament has deferred ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a trade deal signed by US President Barack Obama, until its next session in October. This decision adds to uncertainty over the future of the agreement, which Vietnam was expected to be the first to ratify. The delay may push ratification several months after the US presidential election, further complicating Obama's efforts to secure congressional approval for the deal.

site_title: Blow for Obama's TPP as Vietnam parliament defers ratification
summary: Vietnam's parliament has deferred ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a deal signed by US President Barack Obama, adding uncertainty to the agreement's future. The delay means Vietnam's ratification could be several months after the US presidential election, which has seen domestic scrutiny of trade policy. The TPP aims to create a trading zone of 12 members with a combined $27 trillion GDP, but its prospects for US legislative approval have looked increasingly dim, with both presidential candidates opposing the pact.

site_title: UK watchdog head cautions on using housing for retirement income
summary: UK Financial Conduct Authority head Andrew Bailey cautions against using housing or equity release mortgages to boost retirement income due to rising house prices and uncertain long-term returns. Bailey notes that while equity release mortgages have an appeal, their structure is complicated and can be expensive. He suggests alternative options, citing economic uncertainty as a factor in writing long-term financial contracts. Bailey's comments come as low interest rates and new pension freedoms encourage over-55s to withdraw pension pots and invest elsewhere.

site_title: The silly season?
summary: The 2016 Formula One season is nearing its end, with the Singapore Grand Prix marking the final event of the year. Amidst the usual pre-race concerns about haze and driver performances, the Zika outbreak has taken center stage, prompting the use of mosquito repellents and home remedies. Despite the health concerns, ticket sales remain unaffected, particularly among corporate spectators. Meanwhile, the Mercedes team is dominating the season, with Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg competing for the championship. The recent takeover by Liberty Media has brought significant changes to the sport, including a new corporate entity and a shift in leadership.

site_title: US refined products calendar spreads rally on Colonial outage
summary: US refined products calendar spreads rallied on Friday, with gasoline and ultra-low sulfur diesel spreads reaching fresh record highs, amid Colonial Pipeline's recovery from a leak discovery. The company resumed operations on its gasoline conduit and restarted its distillate line. This comes after the pipeline system shut down its main lines last week. The gains in calendar spreads continue a streak of gains following the leak discovery.

site_title: Ramba Energy raises S$11.3m from cash call
summary: Ramba Energy has raised S$11.3 million from a rights-cum-warrants issue to fund a planned field development in Indonesia's Akatara-Selong cluster field, transforming the company into a majority oil and gas play. The bulk of the proceeds will go towards the development, which is expected to commence production within weeks. Ramba Energy's CEO, David Soeryadjaya, is confident the project's economics remain robust despite low oil prices, with a projected cost per barrel of sub-US$20 in the short term. The company has also secured a farm-out deal with KKR-backed Mandala Energy to support the development.

site_title: India loses WTO appeal in solar power rift
summary: India lost its appeal at the World Trade Organization in a dispute over solar power, with WTO judges upholding an earlier ruling that India discriminated against importers by requiring India-made cells and modules. The ruling is final, and India is expected to bring its laws into compliance with WTO rules. The US complaint, filed in 2014, was over India's 2010 policy requiring solar power developers to use India-made components. This decision marks a significant setback for India's solar power industry, which relies heavily on imported components.

site_title: Federal International unit clinches US$155m project
summary: Federal International has secured a US$155 million project for the engineering, procurement, construction, and installation of two offshore wellhead platforms for the Zawtika Development Project Phase 1C. The project, awarded to PT Gunanusa Utama Fabricators, is expected to take 19 months to complete. Federal International has a 20.66% interest in PTG and will provide procurement and ancillary support services. The project is not expected to significantly impact the group's earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Global commodity investments at record high for Jan-Aug: Barclays
summary: Global commodity investments reached a record high of US$54 billion from January to August, surpassing the previous record of US$53 billion in 2009. August saw an inflow of US$3.2 billion into commodities, driven by uncertainty about the financial sector and global growth. Gold accounted for half of the total investment flow, with precious metals and energy assets under management standing at US$126 billion and US$60 billion, respectively. The total assets under management (AUM) stood at US$235 billion in August, with precious metals accounting for 54% of the total.

site_title: Abe cuts budget for centenarians' gifts
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government in Japan has reduced the cost of gifts for centenarians from sterling silver to silver plate, cutting the price to 3,812 yen (S$51) from approximately 7,800 yen (S$96) previously. This move aims to reduce the total spending on gifts by about 40% to 150 million yen. The change is attributed to the rising cost of supporting Japan's ageing population, with nearly 32,000 people eligible to receive the gift this year, a 4.5% increase from last year.

site_title: Years of war, refugee flight has wrecked Middle East economies: IMF
summary: Middle East economies have plummeted in the years of war since the Arab Spring, with countries like Syria, Yemen, and Libya experiencing significant declines in GDP and economic growth. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) report highlights the devastating impact of war on the region, with Syria's GDP falling by over half and Yemen's economy contracting by 25-35% last year. The report calls for concerted efforts from donor countries and coordination among humanitarian aid groups to address the economic and development challenges facing the region, including the need for investment in public infrastructure and the prevention of poverty in host countries.

site_title: Sweet recognition
summary: Pastry chefs are gaining recognition for their skills, with international events and TV shows like MasterChef showcasing their talents. Chefs Jaycent Lau, Melvin Chou, Jonathan Allaert, and Naoyuki Tanoue are featured in profiles highlighting their unique approaches and philosophies. They share the challenges of balancing flavors, incorporating local ingredients, and creating visually stunning desserts. With the rise of social media, pastry chefs are now able to share their work and connect with customers, leading to new opportunities and a shift in the kitchen dynamics.

site_title: Oil hits two-week lows as growing supplies stoke glut concerns
summary: Oil prices fell to two-week lows on Friday, trading below $46 a barrel, amid concerns of a global glut. Rising Iranian exports, Libya's and Nigeria's returning supplies, and weak US fundamentals contributed to the decline. Iran's crude exports doubled from a year ago, with most going to Asia and Europe. The US rig count is also expected to rise, fueling concerns about a recovery in US output, further weighing on the market.

site_title: TSH announces capital reduction and special dividend
summary: TSH Corporation, a Singapore-listed firm, announced a capital reduction of S$0.1072 per share and a special dividend of S$0.016 per share, following the disposal of its main businesses and becoming a cash company. The distributions come after the completion of these transactions, and the company is currently exploring new business opportunities to meet the Singapore Exchange's requirements for a new listing.

site_title: Indonesians declare 117.3t rupiah of Singapore assets under tax amnesty
summary: Indonesians have declared 117.3 trillion rupiah (S$12.2 billion) of assets in Singapore under the government's tax amnesty program, with only 14.1 trillion rupiah (12% of the total) repatriated so far. The program aims to collect 165 trillion rupiah in tax revenue, but progress has been slow, prompting concerns about meeting fiscal deficit targets. The government has removed a progress bar from its website, and analysts warn that the program may be faltering, potentially sparking political backlash.

site_title: British lawmakers to scrutinise executive pay and governance
summary: British lawmakers launched an inquiry into executive pay and corporate governance, following criticism of large businesses boosting top-level salaries while underpaying workers. Newly-appointed Prime Minister Theresa May vowed to align incentives with long-term firm interests, suggesting binding shareholder votes on corporate pay and publishing CEO pay ratios. May previously proposed making shareholder votes binding and publishing CEO pay ratios. The inquiry aims to address the "irrational and unhealthy" gap between executive and worker pay.

site_title: Quek Leng Chan relinquishes director post at GL Limited
summary: Malaysian tycoon Quek Leng Chan has relinquished his director post and non-executive chairman role at GL Limited, a member of the Hong Leong Group, effective September 15, 2016. Kwek Leng Hai has been appointed non-executive chairman and a member of the nominating and remuneration committees. Tang Hong Cheong has been appointed director and group managing director, replacing former CEO Michael DeNoma.

site_title: Oil market dips as Libya, Nigeria set to raise output
summary: Oil prices fell as Libya and Nigeria are set to increase production, exacerbating oversupply concerns. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) dropped 70 cents to $43.21 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude lost 76 cents to $45.83 a barrel. Libya's National Oil Corporation plans to double production within four weeks, and Nigeria is expected to increase oil exports. Analysts believe a meeting in Algeria may discuss price stability but doubt a deal can be reached to freeze or cut output, leading traders to focus on the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision next week.

site_title: Consumer prices in US increased more than forecast in August
summary: US consumer prices increased 0.2% in August, exceeding forecasts, driven by higher shelter and healthcare costs. The core CPI measure rose 0.3%, while medical care services increased 0.9%, the largest gain since 1990. Inflation is building gradually, with wage pressures and rent increases contributing to the rise. The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge remains below its 2% goal, but the central bank may consider a rate hike later this year if inflation pressures persist.

site_title: Good looks, good value
summary: The Kia Cerato Forte K3 has undergone minor refreshments three years into its model life, introducing a new Drive Mode Select system with eco, normal, and sport modes. The powertrain remains unchanged, with a 1.6-litre petrol engine and six-speed automatic transmission. Key updates include redesigned head and tail lamps, a re-profiled bonnet, and new rear bumper. The new features enhance usability, with Apple CarPlay, blind spot detection, and a digital speedometer. The refreshed model maintains its value for money without compromising on good looks, offering a blend of body control and ride comfort.

site_title: Swiber claims rise slightly to US$231.4 million
summary: Swiber Holdings, a beleaguered offshore marine group, received claims totaling US$231.4 million as of September 15, a slight increase from the previous week. The company's interim judicial managers are seeking legal advice on the claims.

site_title: Wake-up call for investors as ECB disappoints
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) failed to extend its quantitative easing (QE) beyond March 2017, disappointing investors and causing bond yields to rise. This has led to a "wake-up call" for investors who had been lulled into a false sense of security. Many believe tapering is not the most likely scenario, but some investors are positioning portfolios for potential tapering by selling long-end bond holdings and buying short-duration debt. Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan is set to meet next week, which could impact eurozone bond markets and potentially benefit the ECB.

site_title: EU leaders discuss 'critical situation' after Brexit
summary: EU leaders gathered in Bratislava to discuss a "critical situation" post-Brexit, focusing on migration, security, and globalisation. The 27 leaders aim to draw up a roadmap for the future, with a key emphasis on increasing EU defence cooperation. However, deep divisions remain, particularly over migration, with some Eastern European leaders opposing taking in more migrants. The EU is also under pressure to address the migrant crisis, Russia's intervention in Ukraine, and deadly terrorist attacks in Europe.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth in August was flat, following a 10.6% year-on-year drop in July. The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) has called in two more people to aid investigations into possible breaches at timber specialist Jason Holdings. Singapore Exchange Ltd is considering listing leveraged notes, while Temasek Holdings' offer for SMRT is seen as "in line or above" valuations of comparable companies. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.78% on Friday, breaking a four-session slide.

site_title: STI breaks 4-day slide to gain 0.8% for 2,827.45 close
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 0.78% to close at 2,827.45, breaking a four-day slide. Singtel, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank led gains, with Singtel up 0.5%, DBS Group Holdings up 1.3%, and UOB up 0.9%. Noble Group and Ezra were among the top losers, with Noble Group down 3.1% and Ezra down 2%. The gains came despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, with 191 gainers outnumbering 169 losers in trading.

site_title: Sterling records worst week in five, Brexit fears back in focus
summary: Sterling slumped to its worst week in five against the US dollar and euro, amid concerns over Britain's Brexit negotiations and potential interest rate cuts. The Bank of England kept rates at record lows, but signaled further cuts before year-end. Economic data showed a less significant impact from Brexit than expected, lifting sterling to a seven-week high last week, but it has since slipped due to renewed uncertainty. Investors are now focusing on the government's Brexit plans, which remain unknown, and warning of significant risks for long positions in sterling.

site_title: CSC dips into development work overseas with 21% stake acquisition in HK firm
summary: CSC Holdings Limited has invested £500,000 (S$900,000) in Coriolis Hertford Limited, acquiring a 21% stake in a UK company with full planning permission to develop a freehold land project. The investment is made through a wholly owned unit and is CSC's maiden overseas development work. The UK company, Railway Street Hertford Limited, will retain 40% ownership of the project. This move marks CSC's entry into overseas development work.

site_title: Singapore-flagged oil tankers held in Yemen port
summary: Two Singapore-flagged oil tankers, Chao Hu and Hong Ze Hu, have been prevented from leaving the rebel-held port of Hodeida in Yemen due to a commercial dispute. The ships, carrying crude oil, are not under arrest but have been caught up in a dispute between cargo interests. The owner, Ocean Tankers, stated that the vessels are safe and being held in the port until the dispute is resolved. The incident highlights the challenges faced by shipping companies operating in conflict zones.

images.alt_text: Two oil tankers have been stopped from leaving a rebel-held port in war-torn Yemen over a commercial dispute, the ships' Singapore-based owner said Friday.

site_title: Typhoon kills at least 11 in southeast China; another on the way
summary: Typhoon Meranti, the world's strongest storm this year, killed at least 11 people in southeast China, with seven fatalities in Fujian province and three in Zhejiang province. The typhoon made landfall near Xiamen, causing widespread flooding, power outages, and damage to homes and infrastructure. Over 1.65 million homes were left without electricity, and dozens of flights and train services were cancelled. The storm also affected Taiwan, where another typhoon, Malakas, was forecast to bring heavy rain on Saturday.

site_title: New Zealand extends anti-money laundering rules to capture property agents
summary: New Zealand is extending its anti-money laundering laws to cover real estate agents and other professions, amid concerns that laundered money has fueled the country's booming property market. The new rules, set to be implemented in mid-2017, will also cover lawyers, accountants, and other professionals who can set up secretive trusts. The move aims to bring New Zealand in line with international standards, following concerns raised by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) in 2013.

site_title: Deutsche Bank drops on US$14b DOJ claim lender rebuffs
summary: Deutsche Bank dropped 8.2% after receiving a $14 billion claim from the US Justice Department to settle an investigation into the firm's sale of residential mortgage-backed securities. The bank said it's not willing to pay the amount, and negotiations are ongoing. If the figure is reduced, analysts expect a more favorable outcome for the bank. Other European lenders declined, with UBS and Credit Suisse falling 2.2% and 4.1%, respectively.

site_title: Samsung Elec says to restart Galaxy Note 7 sales in S Korea on Sept 28
summary: Samsung Electronics will resume selling new Galaxy Note 7 smartphones to customers in South Korea starting on September 28, after halting sales due to faulty batteries. The company expects to resume sales in Australia in early October, but the schedule for other markets will depend on individual circumstances.
