The recall affects 10 countries, including the US, and was announced on September 2.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd said on Friday it will resume selling new Galaxy Note 7 smartphones to customers in South Korea starting on Sept 28, as the firm seeks to limit the fallout from a costly recall of the high-end device.

site_title: Temasek's offer price for SMRT 'in line or above' valuations of comparable companies: ISS
summary: Temasek Holdings' offer price for SMRT, a 54% shareholder, is "in line with or above" valuations of comparable companies and previous takeovers, according to Institutional Shareholder Services Inc (ISS). The offer price of S$1.68 per share is a premium of 8.7% to the unaffected price of S$1.545. ISS recommends shareholders approve the bid, citing the offer price's alignment with valuation metrics and providing assurance in the face of new uncertainties. Shareholders will vote on the proposal on September 29.

site_title: Australia's wheat crop threatened as La Nina climate indicator rises: analysts
summary: Australia's near-record wheat crop is at risk due to a La Nina climate event, analysts say. The Southern Oscillation Index (SOI) has risen to its highest level in two months, indicating a higher chance of La Nina developing. This could lead to crop-damaging rains, potentially reducing the quality of the grain. Australia, the world's fourth-largest wheat exporter, is set to harvest its second-largest crop on record, but dry weather in October is crucial for good quality and harvest preparation. This could support global wheat prices, which are near 10-year lows.

site_title: CAD calls in two more to aid investigations into possible breaches at Jason Holdings
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) has called in two more individuals, New Sze Wei and Amy Chan Mei Lin, to aid investigations into possible breaches at Jason Holdings. The company faces corporate governance and debt repayment issues, with its CEO, Jason Sim, previously interviewed by CAD. Jason Holdings also received a letter of demand from KPMG for payment of S$41,000, which the company believes will have a material adverse impact on its financial position. The company remains suspended from trading and advises shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its shares.

site_title: Ikea said close to agreeing one billion euros real estate sale
summary: Ikea is close to agreeing a 1 billion euro sale of 27 European retail parks surrounding its stores to asset manager Pradera, according to a person with knowledge of the matter. The sale, facilitated by broker Cushman & Wakefield, would leave Ikea with 25 retail parks in Europe. The move is part of a trend of retailers investing in European retail parks due to the region's growing economy and rising property values.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: European stock markets fell at the start of trading on Friday, with the FTSE 100 index down 0.3% to 6,707.78 points. Deutsche Bank shares plummeted 8% due to a record US fine of up to $14 billion for selling mortgage securities in the 2008 crisis. The news also affected other European banking stocks, with Royal Bank of Scotland shedding 4%.

site_title: Gold pares weekly decline as bets for September rate hike drop
summary: Gold prices rose, trimming a weekly decline, as traders reduced odds for a US interest rate hike at the Federal Reserve meeting. The metal advanced 0.2% to $1,317.65 per ounce, following disappointing US data that lowered speculation of a rate hike. The probability of a hike dropped to 18% from 22% earlier in the week, and traders now view a rate hike as unlikely, boosting gold prices.

site_title: Japan's real interest rates show policy is loose, but needs better selling
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan is considering shifting monetary policy, with real interest rates already lower than during past bouts of deflation. To keep rates low, the BOJ should focus on selling the message that inflation expectations are key, rather than easing further. Analysts suggest the BOJ should improve communication and tie inflation expectations to credit growth and fiscal stimulus, rather than relying solely on quantitative easing. The BOJ's goal is to lift inflation to 2% in two years, but so far, households' inflation expectations have decreased, and core consumer prices have fallen.

images.alt_text: As the Bank of Japan considers shifting the focus of monetary policy at next week's review, some analysts say the key will be how well it communicates the intent of the change as further significant easing is not necessary at this stage.

site_title: Update: Eran Feldhay to step down as Trendlines VP, Misgav CEO
summary: Trendlines Group announced that Dr. Eran Feldhay, 44, will step down as VP and CEO of Misgav by September 20, subject to mutual consent. Feldhay will remain in a senior position as CEO of ApiFix, one of the group's most valuable companies. Dr. Nitza Kardish will assume Feldhay's role in Misgav, pending further regulatory approvals.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares end firmer as US data dim Fed hike chances
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose for a third-straight session as weak US data reduced the chances of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. US retail sales fell more than expected, and manufacturing output dropped. Global liquidity remained relatively flush, bolstering riskier assets. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.1%, while the NZ benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.8%. Despite the gains, both indices still ended the week with losses, with the NZ benchmark suffering its largest weekly loss since February.

site_title: Brokers' take: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust primed for growth
summary: OCBC Investment Research has initiated a "buy" rating on Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) with a fair value estimate of S$1.09, citing favourable demand-supply dynamics in Australia's industrial real estate market. FLT has a high occupancy rate of 98.3% and a diverse tenant base, with supply expected to come in below 10-year average demand in 2016. The brokerage believes FLT has ample avenues for organic and inorganic growth.

site_title: US dollar losses mount as data douse rate hike talk
summary: The US dollar continued to decline on Friday in Asia, falling to 101.78 yen, after weak US data and declining chances of a September Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The probability of a December hike has fallen below 50%, according to senior trader Stephen Innes. The dollar's decline was also influenced by uncertainty over the Bank of Japan's potential rate cut next week, which could impact the yen. The euro strengthened against the dollar, while the yen rose against other major currencies.

site_title: Belgian brewery's pipe dream brings relief to medieval Bruges
summary: A Belgian brewery, Halve Maan, has completed a pipeline beneath the medieval city of Bruges, eliminating the need for large beer-laden trucks that weighed over 40 tonnes. The pipeline, costing 4 million euros, will transport beer to a bottling plant 3 km away, reducing traffic in the historic city centre. The brewery's managing director, Xavier Vanneste, said the project will increase production by a factor of four or more, with beer sales rising by 30% last year. The pipeline was funded through a subsidy from the Flemish regional government and a record-breaking crowdfunding campaign.

site_title: South African Air says competition, weak rand lead to loss
summary: South African Airways reported its largest loss in over a decade, with a 4.7 billion rand (S$446.5 million) loss in the year through March 2015. The loss was attributed to increased competition, rising finance costs, and a weakening of the rand, which hurt international ticket sales. Finance costs rose 86% to 490 million rand due to increased reliance on state guarantees. The airline's revenue fell to 30.1 billion rand in 2015, and a 13% weakening of the rand cost the airline 800 million rand.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as US rate talk fades
summary: Japanese stocks rose on Friday as weak US data reduced the likelihood of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike next week. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's Nikkei 225 index gained 0.70% to 16,519.29, while the Topix index rose 0.80% to 1,311.50. The US data, including a weak jobs report, has dimmed expectations of a rate hike, contributing to the market's rally.

site_title: Oil set for weekly drop as resilient supply seen sustaining glut
summary: Oil prices are expected to drop this week as a global crude glut is seen to persist due to resilient supply and slowing demand growth. OPEC members Libya and Nigeria, whose supplies have been disrupted, are preparing to boost exports. The International Energy Agency has revised its forecast, stating that the oil surplus will last longer than previously thought. Oil futures fell 0.5% in New York, extending a weekly decline to 4.8%.

images.alt_text: Oil headed for a weekly loss on speculation a global crude glut will persist as disrupted supply returns and demand growth slows.

site_title: Apple Japan unit ordered to pay 12b yen for underreporting income
summary: Apple Japan's iTunes unit was ordered to pay 12 billion yen (S$161 million) in tax for underreporting income. The Tokyo Regional Taxation Bureau found the unit had not paid withholding tax on profits earned from Japanese subscribers. The unit has since paid the amount. This follows a European Union ruling that ordered Apple to pay Ireland 13 billion euros (S$19.5 billion) in back taxes. Apple plans to appeal the EU ruling, arguing the tax treatment was in line with EU law.

site_title: China launches second experimental space lab module
summary: China launched its second experimental space laboratory, part of a plan to have a permanent manned space station in service by 2022. The move advances China's space programme, with President Xi Jinping aiming to establish the country as a space power. China's space programme is considered peaceful, but the US Defense Department has highlighted its increasing space capabilities, raising concerns about its activities.

images.alt_text: China launched its second experimental space laboratory on Thursday, part of a broader plan to have a permanent manned space station in service around 2022.

site_title: UK's Phoenix in advanced talks to buy Deutsche Bank's Abbey Life
summary: Phoenix Group Holdings, the UK's largest owner of life assurance funds closed to new customers, is in advanced talks to acquire Deutsche Bank's British insurance business, Abbey Life Assurance. Phoenix plans to raise £800 million to fund the purchase, which is expected to be finalized in the next couple of weeks. This move comes as regulatory changes and low interest rates have pressured industry players to deal with their legacy books, with Abbey Life valued at around £1 billion. The acquisition would be Phoenix's second major deal in the UK closed life sector.

site_title: Samsung's Note 7 recall is official, now comes the hard part
summary: Samsung has officially recalled its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone in the US, following reports of batteries overheating and exploding, with 1 million of the 2.5 million Note 7 phones sold in the US affected. The recall, announced by the Consumer Product Safety Commission, makes the sale of affected devices illegal and sets guidelines for replacement phones. Customers are advised to stop using and turn off their phones, and can receive a new, free phone with a different battery, a refund, or a replacement device. The recall is seen as a major blow to Samsung's reputation, with experts warning that restoring public trust will be crucial for the company's future success.

site_title: Game of Thrones bids to make Emmys history
summary: Game of Thrones is poised to make television history at the 68th Emmy Awards, potentially becoming the most decorated fictional show since the awards began. The HBO series has accumulated 35 Emmy wins, surpassing Frasier's record of 37, and is up for awards in five major categories, including outstanding drama. With three of its stars dominating the supporting actress category and a strong showing in writing and directing categories, Game of Thrones is expected to take home at least three trophies, breaking the record.

images.alt_text: Fantasy epic Game of Thrones is poised to make television history at the 68th Emmy Awards on Sunday by becoming the most decorated fictional show since the awards began.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars steady as traders eye key central bank meetings
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remain steady against the US dollar, following overnight gains after disappointing US economic data. The Australian dollar held at US$0.7510, while the New Zealand dollar stood at US$0.7318, largely unchanged. Investors await key central bank meetings next week, including the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, Bank of Japan, and Federal Reserve, which may impact currency markets. The Aussie is on track for its second weekly loss, weighed down by concerns about global central banks' policy stimulus.

site_title: Japan looks to bring in more foreign workers as population falls
summary: Japan plans to bring in more foreign workers to bolster its shrinking labor force, aiming to double the current number of foreign workers. The government is considering new visa categories, including for technology industry workers from India and Vietnam, and expanding a foreign "trainee" system. The expansion aims to address Japan's demographic woes, with a low birthrate and aging population. The move is seen as a step to create a sustainable system for accepting more foreign workers, despite concerns about the potential effect on a relatively closed society.

images.alt_text: Two aides to Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said the nation is planning to bring in more overseas workers to bolster the shrinking labour force.

site_title: Submarines surface as key tool in world's navies
summary: Submarines are experiencing a resurgence in global naval capabilities, with militaries in Asia, Russia, and the US investing heavily in their development and deployment. These underwater craft, once relatively neglected after the Cold War, are now being utilized for stealthy reconnaissance and strike missions. The increased focus on submarines reflects the changing nature of modern warfare, where undersea capabilities offer a significant advantage in covert operations and long-range surveillance.

images.alt_text: Gliding stealthily through the ocean depths, attack submarines quietly shadow their quarry, ready to strike with torpedoes or missiles.

site_title: Mitsubishi to raise Lawson stake in 144b yen deal
summary: Mitsubishi Corp plans to raise its stake in Lawson Inc. in a 144 billion yen (S$2 billion) tender offer, aiming to increase its holding to 50% from 33.4%. The offer is 17% higher than Lawson's closing share price and gives Mitsubishi a bigger slice of Lawson's profit, expected to jump 17% to 36.8 billion yen. The acquisition is seen as a plus for Lawson's expansion and supply chain support, with Mitsubishi to start buying shares in January.

site_title: Gold set for first weekly loss in three as investors seek riskier assets
summary: Gold prices are expected to decline for the first time in three weeks due to investors seeking riskier assets like equities amid low interest rate expectations. The Federal Reserve's decision next week remains uncertain, with a median 70% chance of an interest rate increase in December. Rising interest rates would increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding assets like gold, contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: Gold held steady on Friday amid lower trading activity because of Asian holidays but was set for its first weekly loss in three as investors were choosing more riskier assets such as equities rather than holding value in the yellow metal.

site_title: One year on, can Volkswagen leave 'dieselgate' behind?
summary: One year after the "dieselgate" scandal, Volkswagen still faces significant challenges in recovering from the crisis. The company has made efforts to make amends with mass recalls and a focus on building cleaner cars, but it continues to battle legal complaints and demands for compensation. Volkswagen has set aside 18 billion euros in legal provisions, and experts predict the total bill could reach 25-35 billion euros. Despite this, the company's new CEO has adopted a bold strategy, promising dozens of new electric vehicles and pushing into emerging technologies.

site_title: Australia's Qantas boosts Japan route as economic, tourism ties deepen
summary: Qantas Airways announced it will launch daily non-stop flights from Melbourne to Tokyo in December, in response to strengthened economic and tourism ties between Australia and Japan. This move follows a decline in Japanese tourists and business travelers, but a recent surge in interest, driven by improved trade relations and Japanese ski fields. The airline aims to capitalize on the growing demand for travel between the two countries, solidifying Qantas' position as a major player in the Asia-Pacific market.

site_title: US lawmakers ask Wells Fargo about taking back bonuses linked to scam case
summary: US lawmakers have asked Wells Fargo to take back bonuses given to executives linked to a scam that created 2 million phony bank accounts to meet sales quotas. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and regulators reached a $185 million settlement with the bank over the issue. The lawmakers, including five Democratic US Senators, are seeking to recover compensation provided to senior executives, including Carrie Tolstedt, the former senior executive vice-president of community banking.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.33% to 16,458.74, and the Topix index up 0.25% to 1,304.41. The move followed dimmed expectations of an imminent Federal Reserve interest rate increase, which boosted US stocks.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 9.28 points to 2,814.80 on Friday, opening marginally higher. The rally was partly driven by Wall Street's gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.99% and the SPNY energy index boosted by oil price advances. In Singapore, 36.6 million shares worth S$44.9 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 83 to 35.

site_title: Malaysian sovereign fund Khazanah appoints finance minister to board
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd has appointed Johari Abdul Ghani, the country's second finance minister, to its board of directors. Mr. Ghani replaces Ahmad Husni Hanadzlah, who served for seven years. This appointment was made on September 15, 2016.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand shares rally as US data could crimp Fed hike chances
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index jumped 1.1% to a 3-year high, driven by banking stocks and weak US retail sales data. The US data may dim chances of a Fed interest rate hike next week. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.8% after a 6-session losing streak, with consumer confidence reaching its highest level since January.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi calls for investment after Obama pledges sanctions relief
summary: Myanmar's Suu Kyi calls for foreign investment to drive economic development and advance democracy, a day after US President Barack Obama pledged to lift long-standing sanctions. Sanctions were imposed in 1997 after decades of military rule, but Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy swept to power in November elections. The US move is seen as a risk, forfeiting leverage on Myanmar's military, but Suu Kyi believes it's time for the country to depend on itself and its friends. The lifting of sanctions is expected to clear US businesses to work with previously off-limits companies.

site_title: Clinton resumes campaigning, targets swing state North Carolina
summary: Hillary Clinton resumed her presidential campaign in North Carolina, aiming to secure the state's 15 electoral votes as polls show Donald Trump closing the gap in other battleground states. Clinton, recovering from pneumonia, emphasized her focus on working families and criticized her campaign's handling of her illness. Trump, meanwhile, outlined a plan to create 25 million new jobs in a decade, targeting roughly a dozen states with a combined 164 electoral votes. Clinton's campaign believes North Carolina's demographic shifts and backlash against Trump's policies make it a key battleground state.

site_title: Apple, Samsung struggle in face of Chinese competition
summary: Apple and Samsung struggle in the Chinese smartphone market due to local competition from Chinese firms like Huawei, Vivo, and Oppo. In the first half of the year, Chinese companies took the top spots in the Asian market, with Huawei leading with a 16% share. Apple's iPhone 7 launch was seen as lacking innovative features, and the company's market share in China dropped from second to third place in the April-June period. Samsung's recall of Galaxy Note 7 handsets due to faulty batteries has also impacted its market share.

site_title: Asian fans snap up new iPhone but crowds smaller despite sell-out
summary: Apple's new iPhone 7 was launched in key Asian markets, with crowds smaller than expected despite being sold out. In Sydney, around 200 people waited in the rain to be the first to buy the phone, with some reporting difficulty in securing the desired model. In China, where sales will be a crucial test for Apple's year ahead, interest in the new phone appears muted, with an index of searches lagging behind previous iPhone launches. Apple will launch in China later on Friday, a holiday.

site_title: Britain's UKIP choosing new leader to follow Farage
summary: Britain's UKIP party has chosen a new leader to replace Nigel Farage, who stepped down after the country's Brexit victory. The new leader, Diane James, is a bookmakers' favorite, but the contest was marred by controversy, including the exclusion of immigration spokesman Steven Woolfe from the running. The party's future is uncertain, with some experts warning that it may struggle to sustain public support and could be "finished" if it fails to find a competent leader. The party is hoping to capitalize on Brexit's popularity and boost its chances in the 2020 general election.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore growth outlook still weak
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth in August 2016 was flat at S$12.7 billion, following a 10.6% year-on-year drop in July. Total trade rose 0.6% to S$71.5 billion, with non-electronic shipments increasing and electronic exports declining. This marks a slight improvement from the 11.4% decline in July.

site_title: Malaysia palm oil output seen dropping 10% in 2016 on El Nino
summary: Malaysia's palm oil production is expected to drop 10% in 2016 due to the effects of El Nino, which reduced yields in the first half of the year. Annual output will be around 17.96 million tons, the lowest since 2010. Despite a recovery in production in the second half, yields will trail last year's levels. Prices are expected to average between RM2,500 and RM2,600 a ton this year, up from about RM2,235 in 2015. The decline in production is expected to have a "slightly better" impact on exports due to better prices.

site_title: Asia: Stocks pare weekly loss as yen gains; oil falls
summary: Asian stocks rose, trimming this week's loss, after Apple's rebound in the S&P 500 Index, while the yen strengthened and oil fell. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index advanced 0.4% as stocks rallied in Australia, Japan, and New Zealand. Japan's currency rose for a third day, while oil dropped below $44 a barrel amid concern about a glut. The US central bank's interest-rate increase odds have slumped to 18% amid declining economic numbers, with the Federal Reserve meeting next week.

site_title: Snowden was a "disgruntled" employee: House committee report
summary: A US House Intelligence Committee report concludes that Edward Snowden was a "disgruntled employee" who leaked classified documents, contradicting the notion of a principled whistleblower. The report states Snowden had frequent conflicts with managers, was reprimanded just before leaking documents, and took advantage of his access to search colleagues' computers. The report also finds Snowden did not voice concerns to oversight officials and should not be considered a protected whistleblower. Intelligence Chairman Devin Nunes calls Snowden a "traitor" who betrayed his colleagues and country.

site_title: Eran Feldhay to step down as Trendlines VP, Misgav CEO
summary: Trendlines Group announced that Vice President Dr. Eran Feldhay will step down by September 20, relinquishing his role as Misgav CEO. Feldhay's position will be assumed by Dr. Nitza Kardish, with her appointment subject to further regulatory approvals in Israel. Feldhay will also step down as Misgav CEO.

site_title: SGX mulls listing leveraged notes on speculators' demand
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd is considering listing leveraged notes, popular in Europe for simple exposure to regional indexes, based on market demand. The move aims to profit from Asia's appetite for leveraged products, which have boosted market turnover to US$4 billion in Europe last quarter. SGX's review follows a hiatus in such structures after the 2008 crisis, where they exacerbated investor losses. The exchange seeks to capitalize on the interest in leveraged products and increase market turnover.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Ltd is considering listing structured products called constant leveraged certificates, whose popularity in Europe helped market turnover there top US$4 billion last quarter.

site_title: US seeks US$14b from Deutsche Bank over mortgage bonds: source
summary: US authorities are seeking up to $14 billion from Deutsche Bank to settle allegations over the sale of mortgage securities during the 2008 crisis. This would be the largest fine imposed on a foreign bank in the US, surpassing the $8.9 billion paid by BNP Paribas in 2014. Deutsche Bank claims it has "no intent" to agree to the proposed amount, stating negotiations will lead to a lower outcome. The US Justice Department has declined to comment, and the final amount may be lower as talks proceed.

site_title: Europe's biggest natural gas producer is running out of fuel
summary: The Netherlands, Europe's largest natural gas producer, has used up almost 80% of its reserves, with production falling 38% over the previous two years. The country is struggling to contain earthquakes linked to gas production in the Groningen province, where the EU's largest gas deposit is located. The government has capped extraction at 24 billion cubic meters per year for five years, leading to a decline in state income from gas. The nation's natural gas production is expected to fall further, impacting the government budget.

site_title: Rotary Engineering wins S$64m contracts
summary: Rotary Engineering secured contracts worth approximately S$64 million for the June-September period. The contracts include a key project in the UAE, fabrication works in Thailand, and an EPC contract for a grease-manufacturing plant in Thailand. Rotary's chairman, Roger Chia Kim Piow, attributed the new wins to customers' confidence and the company's growing presence in the Middle East and Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Japan Inc sees BOJ stimulus as failing to spur inflation: Reuters poll
summary: Japan Inc. sees the Bank of Japan's stimulus as failing to spur inflation, with only 6% of companies believing it has achieved its goal. A Reuters poll found that firms cited negative effects such as destabilization of financial markets and lax fiscal discipline. Companies are more focused on saving money and repaying debt, with 42% keeping their funds in the bank. The BOJ is expected to maintain its easing stance, possibly deepening negative interest rates or expanding asset purchases.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, SBI Offshore, SMRT
summary: Singapore Technologies (ST) Engineering's president and CEO Tan Pheng Hock will step down on September 30, with Vincent Chong taking over from October 1. SBI Offshore lodged a report with the Commercial Affairs Department regarding possible breaches of securities laws. SMRT Corporation will proceed with its restructuring plans regardless of the outcome of Temasek Holdings' offer to take the company private.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed on Friday
summary: Financial markets in China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, South Korea, and Taiwan closed on Friday for public holidays. Meanwhile, in Singapore, stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, valuing it above $1 billion.

site_title: Less loved but good value; investors in Asia look to buy on the cheap
summary: Investors in Asia are seeking good value in less-loved companies amid a world of slack growth and low returns. The gap between the MSCI Asia ex-Japan growth and value indices is the widest since 2003, with average price-to-forward earnings ratios significantly higher for growth stocks. This signals to investors that they are missing out on undervalued firms. As a result, funds are exploring cheaper names to capitalize on the disparity.

site_title: North Korea ready to 'counter-attack' in face of US 'provocation'
summary: North Korea's Foreign Minister Ri Yong Ho warned the US of a "counter-attack" in response to perceived provocations, amid heightened tensions following the country's fifth nuclear test. The test was justified as a necessary measure to counter US threats, with Ri stating that nuclear armament was the only option to safeguard national security. The US has maintained a military presence in South Korea since the Korean War, with around 28,000 troops stationed there. The warning comes after two US supersonic bombers flew over South Korea in a show of force.

site_title: Navy bribery probe snares two more from defence contractor
summary: Two former executives of foreign defence contractor Glenn Defense Marine Asia Pte Ltd, Neil Peterson and Linda Raja, were charged with conspiring to submit phony price quotes and invoices to the US Navy, allegedly stealing millions of dollars. The grand jury indictment, filed in 2014, accuses them of misrepresenting costs and submitting false claims to the Navy. Peterson and Raja, both of Singapore, are currently in custody awaiting extradition, while the owner, Leonard Glenn Francis, faces up to 25 years in prison. A total of 16 people have been charged in connection with the probe.

site_title: IHC clarifies lenders' receivership over its Australian properties
summary: IHC clarifies that the appointment of receivers by its Australian bank lenders, Westpac and NAB, was a consequence of Crest Funds' disputed appointment of receivers over IHC's Australian properties. Crest Receivers had lodged unlawful caveats, which were voluntarily withdrawn. As a result, Westpac and NAB appointed Australian receivers over two IHC properties. IHC stated that the caveats' withdrawal was due to a lack of legal basis, and the dispute is now resolved. The receivership is not a result of IHC's financial difficulties.

site_title: Brazil's Lula says graft charges aim to destroy him politically
summary: Brazil's former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has defended himself against corruption charges, calling the case an attempt to destroy him politically ahead of 2018 elections. Lula, a popular leftist leader, was accused of masterminding a massive corruption scheme at state oil company Petrobras. He claims the charges are part of an elite conspiracy against the Workers' Party he co-founded, and that his impeachment predecessor, Dilma Rousseff, was also targeted. If convicted, Lula's hopes of running for a third term in office would be dashed.

site_title: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports growth flat in August
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth remained flat in August after a 10.6% drop in July, according to International Enterprise Singapore. NODX to Taiwan, Hong Kong, and the US rose year-on-year, while electronic NODX continued to decline. Total trade increased 0.6% in August, with total exports rising 2.3% after a 10.6% decline in the previous month. The drop in oil domestic shipments eased from 29.1% to 8%.

site_title: Europe: Shares snap losing streak after choppy day
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on Thursday, snapping a five-day losing streak, after Wall Street's gains on weak economic data. The STOXX 600 index hit a six-week low earlier in the session, but recovered as investors took a wait-and-see approach on monetary policy. UK supermarket Morrisons led gains following a strong earnings update, while mining and healthcare stocks also boosted the market. The rebound follows concerns over tighter monetary policies and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: StanChart said to mull private-equity unit spin-out to managers
summary: Standard Chartered is considering spinning out its private-equity unit, Standard Chartered Private Equity (SCPE), to its managers, citing tougher capital rules and losses from the unit. The unit, which oversees $5 billion in assets, has posted significant losses, including $167 million in the first half of 2016. The move is part of CEO Bill Winters' efforts to simplify the bank and reduce risk. Regulators have made it harder for banks to invest in illiquid funds, leading to a series of spin-outs.

site_title: Study confirms Zika causes brain birth defects, questions remain
summary: A study in Brazil confirms a direct causal link between Zika virus infection in pregnant women and microcephaly, a birth defect marked by small head size, in their babies. The research, involving 200 cases and 400 controls, found that 41% of mothers of babies with microcephaly tested positive for Zika infection, compared to none of those without the defect. The study, published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal, provides evidence of a causal link, but many questions remain unanswered, including the role of previous dengue infection.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler recalls 1.9m cars over seatbelt issue
summary: Fiat Chrysler US recalled 1.9 million cars due to a potential issue with the airbag and seatbelt deployment, linked to at least three deaths and five injuries. The affected models include Chrysler Sebring, Dodge Caliber and Avenger, Jeep Patriot and Compass, among others, produced between 2010 and 2014. The recall is related to a fault in the occupant restraint-control module and front impact sensor, which could prevent airbags from deploying and seatbelts from functioning correctly in an accident.

site_title: US: Stocks surge as rate-hike odds fall; Apple jumps again
summary: US stocks surged 1% on Thursday, driven by weaker-than-expected economic data and dimming rate-hike odds by the Federal Reserve. Apple shares jumped 3.4% for the fourth straight session, as reports indicate strong sales of the new iPhone 7 models. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 1%, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 1.5%. The Fed's decision to hold off on a rate hike was confirmed by a poor retail sales report and lack of inflationary pressure.

site_title: Gillman redefines role at its four-year mark
summary: Singapore's Gillman Barracks art cluster, a former military camp, is shifting its focus beyond selling art. After struggling with poor sales and visitorship, the cluster is now aiming to present art and engage with the public. Three government agencies are working together to boost programming and integrate the cluster into the larger art scene. The cluster is partnering with the Singapore International Photography Festival and hosting an anniversary celebration with live music and pop-up food outlets. As it approaches its four-year mark, Gillman Barracks is entering a "consolidation phase" with a broader role in presenting art and conducting a discourse on art.

site_title: Clashes at new French demos over labour reforms
summary: French riot police clashed with protesters in Paris and other cities over the government's labour reforms, which aim to loosen France's rigid employment laws. Four demonstrators and 15 police were injured, including two police officers who sustained burns from Molotov cocktails. The law, which makes it easier to fire workers during downturns and for bosses to negotiate directly with employees, was forced through by the Socialist government despite violent protests earlier this year. The clashes occurred as air traffic controllers went on strike to protest the law, cancelling hundreds of flights nationwide.

images.alt_text: French riot police fired teargas and stun grenades on Thursday in clashes in Paris with angry opponents of labour reforms, in the latest outbreak of violence over the controversial new laws.

site_title: STI down for 4th day but closes off low
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,805.52, a net loss of 3.83 points, marking its fourth consecutive loss. The index fell 17 points to an intraday low of 2,791 before a late afternoon rebound due to short-covering. The STI has fallen 68 points or 2.4% over the past four sessions. Market sentiment remains weak, with concerns over weak oil prices and US interest rate uncertainty.

site_title: US dollar shrugs off weak economic data
summary: The US dollar remained stable despite weak economic data, including a 0.3% decline in August retail sales. Analysts believe the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike chances have diminished, but the dollar's resilience is attributed to the Fed's unique status as a leader in global borrowing rate increases. The British pound remained within a tight range after the Bank of England maintained its key interest rate at 0.25%. The dollar's stability reflects the Fed's influence on global interest rates, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: The dollar avoided major swings on Thursday after a trove of mediocre US economic data lessened the odds the Federal Reserve will hike interest rates next week.

site_title: Lady Gaga says new album a tribute to family roots
summary: Lady Gaga has announced her new album, Joanne, set to be released on October 21, in tribute to her late aunt Joanne, who died at 19 due to lupus. The album marks Gaga's first contemporary pop release in three years, following her experimental album Joanne (2016), which was named after her aunt. Gaga's decision to name the album after her aunt is a personal tribute to her family roots and heritage.

site_title: Libya oil exports to resume 'immediately'
summary: Libya's oil company announced an "immediate" resumption of oil exports from two key ports captured by forces opposed to the country's UN-backed unity government. The National Oil Company (NOC) said exports will resume from Zuwaytina and Ras Lanuf, with exports from Al-Sidra to resume as soon as possible. The US has stated that oil revenues should be deposited into the central bank in Tripoli, and warned that it will seek to enforce UN Security Council resolutions if oil is diverted. The resumption of oil exports is seen as a blow to the Tripoli-based Government of National Accord, which relies on oil revenues.

site_title: Are bond risks of developers really that worrying?
summary: A recent report by S&P highlights concerns over the health of the local bond market, particularly for small developers, due to liquidity risks. Over 40% of property developers with outstanding bonds have cash and operating cashflows less than their short-term debt maturities. Several developers, including Heeton Holdings, TA Corp, and Oxley Holdings, are vulnerable to repayment risks. However, the market's pricing in of higher risks for smaller developers may be premature, and some developers have substantial sales of residential units and strong development pipelines, which could mitigate repayment risks.

site_title: Rosberg vrooms into S'pore Grand Prix
summary: Nico Rosberg made a public appearance at the promotional event for the Singapore Grand Prix, courtesy of IWC Schaffhausen, Mercedes-Benz, and Hugo Boss. This marks his involvement with the event.

images.alt_text: German Formula One driver Nico Rosberg mobbed by autograph-hunting and selfie-seeking fans on Thursday, ahead of this weekend's F1 Singapore Grand Prix 2016.

At the invitation of IWC Schaffhausen, Mercedes-Benz and Hugo Boss, Rosberg - the Mercedes AMG Petronas F1 driver and official IWC Schaffhausen brand ambassador - made a public appearance at the promotional event.

site_title: Rupee hit by devaluation talk despite ministry denial
summary: India's rupee weakened 0.28% to 67.0750 to the dollar after a media report claimed the finance ministry would propose a devaluation to boost struggling exporters. However, the finance ministry denied the claim, stating that the rupee's value is determined by the market and there is no plan to change policy. Reserve Bank of India officials also dismissed the idea of devaluation, citing that imports exceed exports. The commerce ministry is considering the demands of exporters, but no proposal has been made to devalue the rupee.

site_title: UOB leverages its tech expertise in vigorous push into mobile payments
summary: UOB, a Singaporean bank, is expanding its mobile payment capabilities in the region, introducing digital card issuances and contactless ATMs in Singapore. The bank has invested S$500 million since 2011 to unify its technology processes across the region. This move is part of its push into the competitive mobile-payments arena.

images.alt_text: With its history of buying and integrating South-east Asian banks, UOB is an old hand at bringing different technology systems together.

site_title: Govt makes two key modifications to eligibility proposals
summary: The Singapore government has accepted two key modifications to eligibility proposals for the presidency, including retaining the existing three-year eligibility period and extending the "look back" period to 20 years. The government also agreed to update the eligibility criteria for private-sector applicants, including a new threshold of S$500 million in paid-up capital for companies. The government wholly accepted the Constitutional Commission's recommendation to ensure multi-racial representation in the presidency, including a "hiatus-triggered" safeguard mechanism to guarantee representation of all racial groups.

site_title: Singapore behind nine other cities in startup cost for tech firms: survey
summary: Singapore ranks 10th among 27 cities studied by Knight Frank in terms of startup costs for tech firms, with a 40% cheaper option available by switching to a co-working space. The city's One North tech district offers flexible, affordable options with rental costs around S$5 per square foot, compared to S$8-9 per square foot in the central business district. This trend reverses a previous trend of tech firms moving to the CBD, with Google, Apple, and Facebook relocating to the area in recent years.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SMRT Corp to hold two key meetings on Sept 29, including an EGM and scheme meeting, to seek shareholder approval for Temasek's S$1.68/share buyout. Analysts at OCBC Investment Research recommend accepting the offer, citing a soft earnings outlook and high downside risk, but note the risk of the buyout falling through if the scheme is not approved. Meanwhile, Ascott Residence Trust is highlighted for its "business as usual" operational performance in the UK, despite Brexit, and is recommended to be an outperformer with a target price of S$1.24.

site_title: Merkel says EU survival at stake as chiefs plot post-Brexit path
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned that the European Union's survival is at stake as its leaders gather for a summit in Bratislava to chart a post-Brexit path. Merkel, who said "Europe is not at all in a good state," urged fellow leaders to agree on a common approach in areas such as defense, growth, and border security. Economists warn that a weak response risks holding back growth and plunging the EU into an economic malaise, with the Bank of America Corp survey citing disintegration of the EU as the biggest "tail risk."

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel vowed to do everything she can to hold the European Union together in the face of a populist backlash, saying the bloc's survival is becoming a question of war and peace.

site_title: US pipeline outage boosts oil prices
summary: A US gasoline pipeline outage boosted oil prices, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 33 cents to $43.91 a barrel. The leak of 6,000 barrels near Birmingham, Alabama, from the Colonial pipeline, which carries fuel from the Gulf Coast to the eastern US, contributed to the price increase. However, analysts noted that other bearish supply news limited the gain.

site_title: Entrenchment provisions to be revised, says government
summary: The Singapore government has announced plans to revise entrenchment provisions related to the elected presidency in the Constitution, allowing it to evolve and keep pace with changing conditions. The changes will not come into force immediately, but rather after a period to assess the institution's effectiveness and make refinements as necessary. This approach aims to ensure the Constitution remains a living document, enabling it to adapt to changing circumstances.

site_title: One million Samsung smartphones in US recall
summary: The US Consumer Product Safety Commission has recalled around one million Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones due to faulty batteries that can cause them to burst into flames during charging. There have been 92 reports of overheating batteries in the US, including 26 reports of burns and 55 reports of property damage. Samsung will provide replacements for the affected phones, which will be available starting September 21. The recall affects around one million of the global total of 2.5 million handsets being recalled, casting a cloud over the South Korean electronics giant.

site_title: DBS awards S$175,000 to 5 social ventures; SPH invests more in ViSenze, Kudo
summary: DBS awarded S$175,000 to five Asian social ventures, including Thailand's Siam Organic and Taiwan's OurCityLove, through the DBS-NUS Social Venture Challenge Asia. Meanwhile, SPH invested S$10.5 million in Singapore-based AI startup ViSenze and further invested in Indonesia-based e-commerce platform Kudo. These investments aim to support sustainable social change and build a holistic ecosystem for budding social enterprises.

site_title: Statements made after careful and objective deliberation
summary: PrimePartners Corporate Finance, a sponsor of SBI Offshore, has responded to criticism, stating that their statements were made after objective deliberation. The company acknowledged the challenges faced by SBI Offshore since its listing but emphasized their commitment to impartial and fair duties. They referred to the Catalist Listing Rules and the Singapore Exchange's requirements, indicating they followed established framework and processes.

site_title: Ratings firms warn of risks in KL minister's proposal
summary: Malaysia's housing minister Noh Omar proposed a lending scheme allowing developers to finance home buyers, sparking concerns from ratings firms Fitch and RAM. The scheme, which would grant developers a licence to lend, could add to Malaysia's credit risk and worsen household debt. Analysts warn of a lack of coordination among ministries and potential risks of unregulated lending to households with weak financial profiles. The scheme would also run counter to measures taken by Bank Negara to tighten lending and rein in rising household debt.

site_title: EU meet to focus on post-Brexit future
summary: European leaders, excluding UK Prime Minister Theresa May, meet in Bratislava, Slovakia, to discuss the EU's post-Brexit future. The agenda focuses on enhancing security and border protection, with a "European pact for freedom and security" being proposed. Greater defence cooperation is also on the table, driven by Russian assertiveness and financial pressure on national defence budgets. The meeting aims to create a "window of opportunity" for the EU to move forward on security and foreign policy, but contentious issues like migration and economic integration are not on the agenda.

site_title: Ford sees 2017 performance falling from 2016 levels
summary: Ford Motor Co. expects its 2017 financial performance to decline due to increased spending on emerging opportunities like self-driving cars and rising costs. The company plans to offset these costs with cost efficiencies averaging $3 billion annually between 2016 and 2018. Ford also plans to shift its small-car production from US plants to Mexico, and will incur regulatory costs linked to tougher fuel economy and emissions standards. The company will maintain cash from automotive operations at or above $10 billion in a downturn and continue to pay regular dividends.

site_title: ST Engg CEO Tan Pheng Hock to step down on Sept 30
summary: ST Engineering CEO Tan Pheng Hock to step down on Sept 30, with Vincent Chong taking over from Oct 1. Chong, who has been with the group since 2014, will also become a director and adviser to Tan after his retirement. Tan, who has been CEO since 2002, has led the company through various challenges, expanding its footprint and revenue from $2.6 billion to $6.3 billion in 2015. Tan will become an adviser to Chong and step down from the board, citing the need to pass the leadership baton to someone with global experience.

site_title: Golfsmith bankruptcy brings fresh woes to Under Armour, Nike
summary: Golfsmith International Holdings Inc filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, affecting major athletic brands Nike, Adidas, and Under Armour. The golf retailer has 109 US stores and 55 in Canada, making it the largest dedicated golf retailer in North America. This bankruptcy adds to the financial struggles of these brands, which are still recovering from the shutdown of Sports Authority Inc earlier this year.

site_title: A strangely satisfying nostalgia fix
summary: Bridget Jones's Baby, the third installment of the series, follows Bridget Jones (Renee Zellweger) as she navigates middle age and a potential pregnancy. After her two main men, Mark Darcy (Colin Firth) and Daniel Cleaver (Hugh Grant), are no longer in the picture, Bridget meets a new man, Jack Qwant (Patrick Dempsey), and discovers she's pregnant. As she tries to determine the father's identity, both men vie for her affections, leading to a cheesy but charming movie with laugh-inducing moments. The film is a nostalgic fix, despite some predictable scenes and narrative pauses.

site_title: MPH: Cornerstones of S'pore's success
summary: Singapore's economic success can be attributed to its unique approach, known as "MPH" (Meritocracy, Pragmatism, and Honesty), which emphasizes good governance, strong leadership, and prudent economic policies. The country's strategic location, highly developed infrastructure, and favorable business environment have made it a hub for multinational corporations, particularly in the electronics sector. A unique exchange rate-centred monetary policy framework, prudent fiscal policy, and a well-managed sovereign wealth fund have also contributed to Singapore's macroeconomic stability. The government's emphasis on public housing, social cohesion, and infrastructure development has also played a crucial role in its economic success.

images.alt_text: Temasek was an integral part of Singapore's initial dualistic development strategy. But it is likely to play a more visible developmental role in the Republic in the future.

site_title: Trusting one's own tastes
summary: Wine critics and writers have long relied on rating systems, such as Robert Parker's 100-point scale, to evaluate wine quality. However, relying solely on these systems can lead to a loss of personal taste and judgment. Wine lovers are encouraged to create their own wine quality-scale by taking written notes and recording their sensory impressions, which helps to crystallize thoughts and imprint them into memory. This approach allows individuals to develop their own benchmarks for wine quality and appreciation, rather than solely relying on external ratings.

images.alt_text: Mr Parker's 100-point scores in The Wine Advocate were an instant hit. But the problem was that wine buyers and drinkers began to look at, to look for, to ask for, buy and drink only 100-pointer wines!

site_title: Of friendship and diversity
summary: The musical Wicked's lead actresses, Jacqueline Hughes (Elphaba) and Carly Anderson (Glinda), attribute the production's enduring popularity to their strong on-stage and off-stage friendship. The duo, both Scottish and having followed similar career paths, believe their characters' contrasting personalities bring out the best in each other. The musical's unique blend of special effects, catchy songs, and inspiring storyline, including the theme of friendship and self-acceptance, contribute to its universal appeal. The actresses praise the production's creators for adding special touches, making Wicked a dream come true for Hughes.

site_title: 110 Robinson Rd sold at S$45.1m to Indonesian tycoon Tahir
summary: A 12-storey freehold office block at 110 Robinson Road, owned by OCBC, has sold to Indonesian tycoon Tahir for S$45.1 million, or nearly S$3,169 per square foot. The sale is part of a string of commercial transactions, including the sale of six retail units at Holland Village and four office units at The Adelphi. The deals were facilitated by Cushman & Wakefield, CBRE, and Quillion Global. The sale of 110 Robinson Road is seen as bullish, with Michelle Lek describing it as a "rare opportunity" to acquire a freehold office building with a Robinson Road address for under S$50 million.

site_title: Good luck to May in tackling the UK's export malaise
summary: British Secretary of State for International Trade Liam Fox criticized major UK companies for their poor export performance, calling their bosses "lazy" and implying they prioritize golf over market expansion. However, the issue is more complex, with many companies sitting on large cash reserves, preferring to return them to shareholders through share buybacks or mergers and acquisitions. Fox's comments sparked a backlash from business leaders, but Prime Minister Theresa May's focus on worker participation and changing the UK's shareholder value model may be a more effective solution.

site_title: Celebration highlights
summary: The Supermama Porcelain Festival is being held from Sept 16 to Oct 31 at Block 47, Malan Road, showcasing porcelain as giftware, homeware, and objet d'art. The festival features ceramic works from Japan and local designers, including Koh Hong Teng, Phunk Studio, and Theseus Chan. Two locations will host the event: Supermama's flagship store in Beach Road and its gallery shop in Gillman Barracks.

site_title: Nokia CEO speeds up Alcatel integration
summary: Nokia CEO Rajeev Suri has sped up the integration of Alcatel-Lucent, aiming to form a competitor to Huawei Technologies and Ericsson by the end of the first nine months. He set a 90-day deadline for product portfolio decisions to avoid past mistakes. Despite a 26% drop in shares, Suri believes the company is on track, with cost-savings targets raised to 1.2 billion euros by 2018. Nokia plans to eliminate up to 15,000 positions, with Suri aiming for a double-digit operating margin.

site_title: Car sales drive July retail sales up by 2.8% y-o-y
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 2.8% in July from a year ago, driven by a 36.5% increase in car sales. However, excluding car sales, total sales fell 3.1%. The easing of auto loan rules and "pent-up demand" from prospective car buyers likely contributed to the increase. Other discretionary categories, such as medical goods and toiletries, also saw modest gains, while sales of computers and telecommunications equipment plummeted 18.8% year-over-year.

images.alt_text: Easing of auto loan rules likely drove up retail sales here in July, as cash tills saw 2.8 per cent more in receipts when compared to a year ago.

site_title: Examining an attitude that has global resonance today
summary: Playwright Chong Tze Chien's 2014 play "Starring Hitler as Jekyll and Hyde" has gained global resonance as xenophobia dominates the media. The allegorical play addresses the tension between locals and foreigners in Singapore, drawing parallels with pre-Holocaust Germany. Chong hopes to highlight how ordinary people enabled the Jewish Holocaust by not speaking out against xenophobia. The play is the first in a trilogy and has sparked discussions on the role of art and history in addressing such issues.

site_title: Teapots take up the slack, but...
summary: China's oil demand growth is expected to remain robust despite slowing economic performance, driven by its relatively healthy economic fundamentals and historically high petrol demand. However, three key risks could slow oil demand growth in the foreseeable future, including concerns over tax evasion, fictitious oil import data, and overflowing oil tanks, which may lead to a gradual slowdown in oil demand from China.

site_title: Record labels offering low-priced music streaming service in UK
summary: Two major record labels, Universal Music Group and Sony Music Entertainment, are launching a low-priced music streaming service in the UK called NOW Music+ for £4.99 (S$9) a month. The service offers playlists of hit songs and is seen as a response to the industry's shift towards flexible pricing. This move comes as streaming companies struggle to turn a profit and labels seek to bridge the gap between free, ad-sponsored tiers and paid subscriptions. The service will initially be limited to the UK but may expand in the future, with other companies like Amazon and Pandora also exploring similar pricing models.

site_title: Japanese pro-wrestling on the way here
summary: New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) will hold its first-ever full-length show in Singapore on November 15 at Marina Bay Sands. Top stars Hiroshi Tanahashi, Kazuchika Okada, Jyushin "Thunder" Liger, and Kenny Omega will perform, promising an exciting night of high-flying action and storytelling. The event is part of NJPW's recent surge in popularity, following a successful revival under new owner Takaaki Kidani and Bushiroad Inc. The show aims to attract fans from neighboring countries, including Singapore, and showcase the unique blend of wrestling and storytelling that NJPW is known for.

site_title: Currency market volumes flat at US$4.7 trillion in August
summary: Global currency market volumes remained flat in August, averaging US$4.68 trillion, with a 16% decrease in average daily input volume to 883,368 from July. This marks a slight change from the same month last year.

site_title: More job-seekers than jobs - a first since 2012 (Amended)
summary: Singapore's job market worsened in the second quarter, with job seekers outnumbering job openings for the first time in four years. The jobless rate among graduates reached its highest since 2009, at 4.3%. Job vacancies fell from 50,000 in March to 49,400 in June, and the hiring rate slipped to 2.2% due to increasing caution by businesses. Redundancies rose to 4,800 in the second quarter, the highest since 2009. Total employment grew by 4,200, smaller than in the first and previous quarters.

site_title: Myanmar abuzz over ending of US sanctions
summary: US President Barack Obama announced the end of sanctions on Myanmar, marking a new era of transparency and trade. The decision was made during Aung San Suu Kyi's first visit to the White House. Residents in Yangon are eager to access US brands, while politicians and business leaders see this as an opportunity for growth. The move comes after decades of military rule in Myanmar, and the country is expected to experience increased trade and economic activity as a result.

site_title: SMRT restructuring will continue whatever the outcome of Temasek's offer
summary: SMRT Corporation's restructuring plans will continue regardless of the outcome of Temasek Holdings' offer to take the transport operator private. CEO Desmond Kuek stated that privatisation would provide more room to push ahead with plans, but no details on how Temasek will help were provided. SMRT plans to remain a multi-modal group, strengthen working relationships, and sharpen engineering capabilities. The company will also vote on a new rail financing framework, which could save it from depreciation costs and capital expenditure. Despite potential risks, Temasek's bid is seen as a favorable option for shareholders, who can avoid future uncertainties and cash in on the offer price of S$1.68.

site_title: 16 graduate from UBS wealth management programme
summary: UBS has conferred dual degrees to 16 graduates of its Master in Wealth Management Programme, held in collaboration with the University of Rochester and University of Bern. The two-year programme provides training in managing client wealth, relationships, and risk. UBS President Juerg Zeltner stated that investing in employee growth is crucial for offering the best wealth management service to clients. The graduates now hold Master of Science in Wealth Management and Master of Advanced Studies in Finance degrees.

site_title: These old girls just wanna have fun, despite obstacles
summary: Veteran actress Shirley MacLaine wrote a book, "Above the Line: My Wild Oats Adventure," about the making of the low-budget indie film "Wild Oats." The film, directed by Andy Tennant, faced numerous delays, last-minute changes, and financial struggles. Despite these obstacles, MacLaine and her castmates took a positive approach, deciding to make the most of the situation. The film, which stars MacLaine, Jessica Lange, and Billy Connolly, received a C- rating and failed to deliver laughs, but MacLaine's book provides an inside look at the chaos that can afflict independent filmmaking.

site_title: 36 global agri-businesses team up to tackle challenges
summary: Thirty-six global agri-businesses, including Olam International, Wilmar International, and Golden Agri-Resources, have formed the Global Agri-business Alliance (GAA) to tackle environmental and social challenges in agricultural supply chains. The alliance aims to contribute to achieving UN Sustainable Development Goals by 2030, particularly in ending hunger, achieving food security, and promoting sustainable agriculture. The initiative seeks to address issues such as land loss, water scarcity, and climate change, and will set specific goals and workgroups to share best practices and develop tools to pursue these objectives.

images.alt_text: Olam's chief executive Sunny Verghese, speaking at the launch of the alliance at Olam's Building Sustainable Futures Forum on Thursday, said the agriculture sector was up against tremendous challenges - the loss of arable land, insufficient water resources and the impact of climate change on weather patterns.

site_title: Irish farm's ducks the go-to birds for many restaurants here
summary: London Fat Duck restaurant sources its roast duck from Silver Hill Farm in Monaghan, Ireland, a family-owned business since 1962. The farm's duck breed is specifically raised for roasting, making them a preferred choice for many Chinese restaurants in the area. Stuart Steele, the son of the original founders, oversees the farm's operations, which supply the sought-after ducks to restaurants over English and Dutch counterparts.

site_title: AI startup ViSenze raises US$10.5m Series B from Rakuten Ventures, SPH Media Fund
summary: ViSenze, a Singapore-based AI startup, raised US$10.5 million in Series B funding led by Rakuten Ventures and SPH Media Fund. The company develops visual-search and image-recognition solutions for e-commerce, retail, and content publishing, generating up to 70% uplift in conversion rates for its retail clients. The new funding will be used to enhance its proprietary image-recognition technology, expand its offices, and grow its team.

site_title: Keppel sells Shanghai mall stake for S$73m profit
summary: Keppel Corporation sold its 42.5% stake in Shanghai's Life Hub @ Jinqiao mall for S$73 million profit, aligning with its property arm's strategy to recycle assets for higher returns. The mall, completed in 2009, features retail shops and an office tower, with 97% of retail space leased and 100% of office space occupied. The sale was made to Star Champ Development, a subsidiary of the Chongbang Group, in a deal valued at US$516.9 million.

site_title: Internet browsers to be disabled on New York's free Wi-Fi kiosks
summary: New York's free Wi-Fi kiosks, designed to replace phone booths, will have their internet browsers disabled, but other functions will remain active. The decision comes after complaints about people lingering for hours, engaging in illicit activities, and using the kiosks for inappropriate purposes. The LinkNYC network operator is working with city officials to develop a new plan. The kiosks, which were launched in 2016, were intended to provide a convenient way for users to access information and charge their devices.

site_title: Cartier's US$600,000 watch shows risks of extending luxury brands
summary: Cartier, a luxury watch brand, has seen its first-half profit fall 45% due to collapsing Chinese demand. The company's push into fine watchmaking, which includes complicated timepieces priced over US$600,000, has been a costly endeavor. In response, Cartier is refocusing on more affordable pieces and cutting jobs. The move serves as a cautionary tale for the luxury industry, highlighting the risks of stretching a brand beyond its comfort zone. Cartier is seeking to re-establish itself by returning to its classic style and expanding its more affordable offerings.

images.alt_text: Cartier began its push into fine watchmaking in 2008, creating a division led by Carole Forestier- Kasapi, a watch industry veteran.

site_title: Hyperkinetic sensory overload
summary: Singaporean playwright Ong Keng Sen's new play "Sandaime Richard" reimagines Shakespeare's Richard III in a courtroom drama where both characters are on trial. The play blends Asian aesthetics, including Japanese theatre traditions and Indonesian music, to create a humorous and thought-provoking exploration of Singapore's governance and the power of storytelling. The cast delivers outstanding performances, but some critics argue that Ong's grand vision can be overwhelming, particularly when working with existing scripts. Despite this, "Sandaime Richard" presents rich thematic layers and keeps audiences curious about Ong's future projects.

site_title: CNMC share price could double in a year: PhillipCapital
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings' share price may double to S$1.03 in a year, according to PhillipCapital analyst Chen Guangzhi. The company's abundant resources, low all-in cost, and potential for production ramp-up support the bullish forecast. Chen's valuation method, using discounted cashflow, also suggests higher margins and cashflow generation if costs remain stable and gold prices rise. This contradicts other brokerages' 12-month target prices of S$0.82 and S$0.43, but reflects a strong investment thesis for gold as a safe-haven asset amidst economic uncertainty.

site_title: 'Omni-channel' retailing the way forward: Iswaran
summary: Singapore aims to boost the e-commerce share of total retail receipts to 10% from 3% in four years, while achieving an average annual productivity growth rate of 1% by 2020. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran introduced the Retail Industry Transformation Map, which will support local brand owners and skilled workforce. The "omni-channel" retail model, encompassing physical stores, internet, smartphones, and social media, is expected to drive innovation and productivity. The plan also includes upskilling the workforce to adapt to evolving job scopes and embracing emerging technologies like augmented reality and humanoid assistants.

site_title: JFDI dumps S'pore's first accelerator programme
summary: Singapore's first startup accelerator, JFDI, is closing its program due to high costs, limited tech talent, and immigration restrictions. JFDI raised S$3 million to support over 70 startups and cited the global startup ecosystem's evolution as the reason for its closure. JFDI chief Hugh Mason stated that accelerators must adapt to changes in the ecosystem. This move marks a significant shift in Singapore's tech startup landscape, and its legacy will be remembered as a stalwart of South-east Asia's tech ecosystem.

site_title: Tesla Autopilot blamed in fatal China crash
summary: A fatal car crash in China involving a Tesla Model S has raised questions about the safety of the company's Autopilot technology. The January 20 crash killed 23-year-old Gao Yaning when his car slammed into a road sweeper on a highway, with no signs of brakes being applied before impact. Tesla has stated that it cannot determine whether Autopilot was active at the time of the accident, citing damage to the car's systems. The incident has renewed scrutiny of Autopilot's capabilities and the company's disclosure of accident data.

site_title: SBI Offshore files CAD report, beefs up board ahead of shareholder revolt
summary: SBI Offshore has strengthened its board with four new members ahead of a shareholder vote on Friday, following a review by Pricewaterhouse Coopers (PwC) on transactions involving a 35% stake in a China company, Jiangyin Neptune Marine Appliance Co. The board has also lodged a report with the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) on possible breaches of securities laws and other offenses. The new directors will lead investigations into the PwC findings and actions to recover properties and moneys. A shareholder revolt is brewing, with major shareholder Tan Woo Thian and CEO Chan Lai Thong at odds over the company's direction.

site_title: US industrial output falls more than expected as utilities sag
summary: US industrial production fell 0.4% in August, exceeding expectations, due to a sharp decline in utilities output. Manufacturing and business equipment output also declined. The decline is attributed to weak global demand, a strong dollar, and low oil prices. Despite a rise in mining output, the sector continues to struggle. The percentage of industrial capacity in use fell to 75.5% in August, a leading indicator for inflation.

site_title: Will the real child poverty rate please stand up?
summary: The US median household income rose 5.2% in 2015 to $56,500, the largest increase since the 2007-2009 recession, but remains below the pre-recession peak of $57,423. The poverty rate also fell to 13.5% in 2015, down from 14.8% in 2014, but still higher than the 2007 level of 12.5%.

site_title: Wearable tech market cools, as consumers step back
summary: The wearable tech market is experiencing a slowdown in sales growth, with global sales expected to rise 29.4% to 103 million units in 2016, down from 171% growth in 2015. Consumers are hesitant due to technical issues, with basic wearables, such as fitness bands, accounting for 80.7 million units, and smartwatch shipments expected to grow just 3.9%. However, analysts predict stronger growth with the release of new devices, including smart eyewear and connected clothing, which could drive the market forward.

site_title: Pesticide maker, seed producer mergers draw scepticism
summary: Bayer AG's $66 billion takeover of Monsanto Co has drawn skepticism from farmers and analysts, who question whether bundling seeds, crop chemicals, and technology services will increase profits. Industry experts argue that there is no proven example of successful "integrated" suppliers, and farmers may prefer to choose individual products rather than bundled deals. Some farmer groups in the US have voiced concerns about reduced choice and higher prices, while Monsanto CEO Hugh Grant believes the combined company will provide better insights for farmers.

site_title: Institutional fund outflows accelerate to US$120b in Q2
summary: Institutional fund outflows accelerated to US$120 billion in Q2, with US stocks and actively managed equity strategies being heavily dumped. This represents a significant increase from the revised US$75.1 billion in the first quarter. Equity strategies reported net outflows of US$110.1 billion, while fixed income products saw inflows of US$13 billion. Investors are increasingly looking at alternative investment options or holding onto cash, according to eVestment.

site_title: Offer cheaper choices in CPF Investment Scheme
summary: The Singapore government is reviewing the Central Provident Fund Investment Scheme (CPFIS) due to declining participation and poor returns. Over 80% of CPFIS users would have been better off in the Ordinary Account, which earns 2.5% annually. High fees, behavioural biases, and regional market performance contribute to the poor performance. The government plans to introduce the Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme (LRIS), offering low-cost, passively-managed funds. The CPFIS should be reformed to offer more choices, including low-cost ETFs, allowing investors to choose between passive and active management.

site_title: New clashes in France at demos over labour reforms
summary: Clashes erupted in France on Thursday during protests against labour reforms, with riot police firing teargas and stun grenades at demonstrators throwing molotov cocktails. At least one demonstrator and five police were injured, and 12 people were arrested. The law, aimed at loosening France's rigid employment laws, has sparked violent protests nationwide, including in the cities of Nantes and Belfort. The government, led by President Francois Hollande, had hoped for a signature reform to boost his approval ratings, but the turnout was lower than at the start of the rallies six months ago.

site_title: SBI Offshore lodges report with CAD over possible breaches of securities laws
summary: SBI Offshore has lodged a report with the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) regarding possible breaches of securities laws and other offences related to transactions involving a former associate company, Jiangyin Neptune Marine Appliance Co. The company has appointed a special investigation committee to lead the investigation, following a Pricewaterhouse Coopers review on the NPT transactions. The report and investigation are ongoing, and no trading has occurred on SBI Offshore shares over the past two weeks.

site_title: US jobless claims rise less than expected as labour market firms
summary: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits rose 1,000 to 260,000 for the week ended Sept 10, less than expected. This marks the 80th straight week claims remained below the 300,000 threshold, indicating a tightening labor market. The four-week moving average of claims slipped to 260,750, suggesting the labor market is nearing full employment, with little room for further decline.

site_title: US producer prices unchanged, underlying inflation firming
summary: US producer prices remained unchanged in August, following a 0.4% drop in July, as energy costs declined and trade services fell. Underlying producer inflation firmed, with the core PPI increasing 0.3% month-over-month and 1.2% year-over-year, the largest gain since December 2014. The strong dollar and cheaper oil have contributed to the flat producer price index, but some of the drag is easing, and inflation remains below the Federal Reserve's 2% target.

images.alt_text: US producer prices were flat in August as the cost of energy products declined and trade services fell, but underlying producer inflation firmed.

site_title: Indonesia, EU, announce historic deal on timber trade
summary: Indonesia and the European Union announced a historic deal on timber trade, making Indonesia the first country to export wood products to the EU meeting new environmental standards. The agreement, set to take effect in November, will certify the legality of timber products and ensure they are sustainably sourced. Indonesia aims to double timber exports to the EU, valued at $2 billion a year, and curb illicit logging. The deal will also provide consumers in Europe with assurance that their wood products come from audited factories and forests.

site_title: EU says widespread use of geoblocking may breach antitrust rules
summary: The European Commission has found widespread use of geoblocking by online and electronic retailers to restrict cross-border sales within the EU, potentially breaching antitrust rules. The investigation, part of the EU's e-commerce sector inquiry, also revealed selective distribution and contractual sales restrictions to control products. Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager stated that these practices prevent European consumers from reaping e-commerce benefits. A final report is due in 2017, and the EU may take action against retailers on a case-by-case basis.

images.alt_text: EU antitrust regulators said on Thursday they may take action against online and electronic retailers restricting cross-border sales within the bloc but only on a case-by-case basis.

site_title: Indonesia central bank allows banks to sell FX call spread options
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, has allowed banks to sell foreign exchange call spread option contracts for hedging purposes. The regulation applies to banks with at least 5 trillion rupiah in capital and requires an underlying transaction such as trade, investment, or loans in currencies other than the rupiah. This move is part of Bank Indonesia's efforts to introduce new financial products and regulations.

site_title: Yen edges up as investors seek safe havens
summary: The yen edged up on Thursday as investors sought safe havens amidst stock market lows, despite central banks' decisions. The Bank of Japan and US Federal Reserve meet next week, while the Swiss National Bank and Bank of England held fire on policy decisions. The yen's gains were seen as a vote against the BOJ's ability to weaken the currency, amid concerns about policy effectiveness and steepening bond yields. Sterling inched down marginally after the BOE's decision, with the BOJ considering negative interest rates as a future easing measure.

site_title: Bank of England keeps rate at record 0.25% low
summary: The Bank of England maintained its record-low interest rate of 0.25% and bond-buying programme target of £435 billion, despite initial concerns about the Brexit impact. The decision was unanimous among rate-setters, indicating a likelihood of further interest rate cuts later this year. This move aims to support the economy, which has shrunk for the second month in a row, dealing a fresh blow to Labour leader Keir Starmer. The Bank's decision suggests the economy may be more resilient than expected.

site_title: Merkel, Hollande seek new EU 'roadmap' at summit
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande called for a new EU "roadmap" at a summit in Bratislava, aiming to address security, prosperity, and the bloc's post-Brexit future.
