Esure will continue to operate its insurance products while Gocompare.com will be an independent entity. The move is aimed at allowing both businesses to focus on their respective core activities.

site_title: Eid day suicide attack injures 4 in Pakistan: officials
summary: A suicide bomber injured four policemen, one critically, outside a Shiite mosque in Shikarpur, Sindh province, Pakistan, on Eid al-Adha Tuesday. Two attempted bombers were intercepted by police, with one critical and another injured. The attack occurred in the same district where 61 people were killed in a 2015 suicide attack. Pakistan has experienced frequent sectarian violence, mainly perpetrated by Sunni groups against minority Shiites.

images.alt_text: A suicide bomber injured four policemen, one critically, outside a Shiite mosque in southern Pakistan as the country marked the beginning of the religious festival Eid al-Adha on Tuesday.

site_title: Australia shares hit 2-month low as banks falter; NZ stocks slide
summary: Australian shares fell to a 2-month low, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 11.81 points, or 0.2%, at 5,207.8, due to weakness in financial and energy stocks. The decline was attributed to speculation over the Federal Reserve's meeting next week, with investors betting on US interest rates staying on hold. Financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, declined between 1% to 1.3%. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell, with the S&P/NZX 50 index down 0.42% at 7,249.23.

site_title: Verizon out to be more than 'dumb pipe' with Yahoo buy
summary: Verizon is focusing on creating a comprehensive online media platform by acquiring Yahoo for $4.8 billion. Executives, including AOL's Tim Armstrong and Verizon's Marni Walden, emphasized the deal's strategic value, rather than potential job cuts. The combined platform aims to leverage Verizon's mobile lead and Yahoo's strengths in digital media and advertising. The acquisition is part of Verizon's efforts to move beyond being a "dumb pipe" and become a more integral online services company.

site_title: Axiata said to seek buyers for US$700m of overseas holdings
summary: Axiata Group Bhd, Malaysia's largest mobile operator, is seeking buyers for up to $700 million worth of overseas holdings, including 11% of Indonesian unit PT XL Axiata and up to 30% of Sri Lanka's Dialog Axiata Plc and Cambodian subsidiary Smart Axiata Co. The company aims to cut borrowings using proceeds from the divestments, which have risen 55% since 2014 to $21.5 billion. Axiata has operations in 10 countries across Asia and has recently completed a $1.4 billion acquisition in Nepal.

images.alt_text: Axiata Group Bhd, Malaysia's biggest mobile-phone operator, is seeking to trim stakes in some of its overseas operations in deals that could raise as much as US$700 million, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Aussie budget gets A$6.3b boost as Turnbull wins savings
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's bid to reduce a budget deficit has been boosted after the main opposition, Labor, agreed to a package of laws resulting in A$6.3 billion in savings. The omnibus bill, which includes funding for renewable energy projects, will pass in the Senate despite the ruling Liberal-National coalition lacking a majority. While the deal brings savings, Treasurer Scott Morrison notes it doesn't resolve the budget deficit issue. The agreement marks a victory for Turnbull's economic plan and may help improve the country's AAA credit score.

site_title: EU reform plans to boost telcos, publishers due on Wednesday
summary: The European Commission plans to unveil reforms on Wednesday aimed at boosting telecoms operators and publishers. The proposals include allowing former telecoms incumbents to collaborate without competition rules and forcing EU governments to grant telecom spectrum licences for at least 25 years. Additionally, the Commission aims to give publishers more power to demand payment from Google for news snippets, benefiting publishers such as Axel Springer. The reforms are expected to face opposition from lawmakers and EU countries before they can become law.

site_title: German inflation stable in August
summary: German inflation remained stable in August, with consumer prices 0.4% higher than the same time last year. Falling energy prices, which decreased by 5.9%, were the main contributor to the low rate of inflation. This marks the second consecutive month of stable inflation in Germany, indicating a potential slowdown in price growth.

site_title: South Korea clearing up after strongest ever quake
summary: A 5.4 magnitude earthquake struck South Korea late Monday, causing widespread damage and panic. There were no reported deaths, but six people suffered minor injuries. The quake, the country's strongest since records began in 1978, sent people fleeing from buildings and caused significant damage to storefronts and buildings. Reactors at four nuclear power plants were shut down for safety inspections, but there were no indications of damage. The US Geological Survey reported two quakes, the first with a magnitude of 4.9 and the second at 5.4.

site_title: Big miners need a better plan for growth riddle in China
summary: Big miners in China, including Rio Tinto and Glencore, are re-evaluating their growth strategies due to the country's uncertain economic outlook. China's short-term demand remains difficult to predict, and miners are drafting scenarios to prepare for any future. The uncertainty means they need to boost productivity and review portfolios to focus on key commodities and regions. Companies must balance investment plans with strengthening balance sheets, as the producers face a difficult choice about how to allocate capital and create value.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ticks higher by close
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.34% to 16,729.04, driven by speculation of an imminent US rate hike and the Bank of Japan's monetary policy. The Topix index edged down 0.01%. The Nikkei's gain was attributed to traders' anticipation of a US interest rate hike, which could boost the Japanese yen and positively impact the Nikkei.

site_title: Singapore ranks top in sustainability among Asian cities, second globally
summary: Singapore ranks as the most sustainable city in Asia and second globally in the 2016 Sustainable Cities Index, surpassing its previous 10th global position. Zurich maintains the top spot, with Stockholm, Vienna, and London taking third to fifth place. Singapore excels in the Planet and Profit sub-indices but lags in the People sub-index due to high living costs and work-life balance issues. The city faces unique challenges as an island nation with limited land and natural resources, requiring innovative and sustainable management systems.

site_title: China must help close North Korea sanctions loopholes: US
summary: China must help close loopholes in sanctions on North Korea, US envoy Sung Kim said during a visit to Seoul. North Korea has carried out two nuclear tests and over 20 missile launches in 2016, prompting the international community to re-evaluate sanctions. Despite the toughest sanctions regime, Pyongyang has continued to disregard its commitments, leading to a scramble for new penalties. China, Pyongyang's sole ally, is urged to use its leverage to show North Korea the "serious consequences" of its actions, as sanctions are unlikely to produce immediate results.

site_title: Abe's support hits two-year high after North Korea nuclear test
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet support reaches a two-year high, with 62% of respondents in a Yomiuri survey supporting his administration. Support also rises to 57% in an NHK survey and 52% in an Asahi survey, with respondents citing Abe's increased defense budget and stance against North Korea's nuclear test as factors. The polls show majority support for Abe's economic policies, including a tax break for housewives, but conflicting views on his leadership duration.

site_title: Obama would veto bill allowing 9/11 families to sue Saudi Arabia
summary: President Barack Obama would veto a bill allowing 9/11 families to sue Saudi Arabia for damages. The bill, passed by both the House and Senate, would reverse a 2002 law blocking such lawsuits. White House spokesman Josh Earnest stated that Obama would veto the legislation, citing concerns it could lead to US diplomats or service members being sued in foreign courts. Congress has enough support to override a potential veto, but no vote has been scheduled. The Senate sent the bill to Obama on Monday, giving him a 10-day window to veto the measure.

site_title: US bombers in show of force against North Korea
summary: US strategic bombers, B-1B Lancers, flew over South Korea on September 13, 2016, in a show of force against North Korea following its fifth nuclear test. The aircraft, escorted by US and South Korean fighter jets, demonstrated the US military's capabilities. General Vincent Brooks stated that the US has an "unshakable commitment" to defend allies in the region and will take necessary steps to counter North Korea's nuclear threats. The overflight was aimed at sending a warning to North Korea about its nuclear test and containing further provocations.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate invests in Shanghai's largest private eldercare operator
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings (PREH) has invested 735.5 million yuan (S$148 million) in Renshoutang, the largest private eldercare operator in Shanghai, acquiring a 49.9% stake. Renshoutang operates 11 eldercare facilities with over 2,400 beds and four pharmacies. The investment provides PREH with immediate access to the largest integrated eldercare company in Shanghai, strengthening its 'asset-light' strategy. The deal is valued at 12.9 times Ebitda, and Renshoutang aims to become the largest eldercare services operator in the Yangtze River Delta Region.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks recover as Fed Sept hike talk ebbs
summary: South Korea's won and stocks rebounded early Tuesday following US Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard's comments suggesting the Fed may hold interest rates in September. The won rose 0.4% to 1,109.5 and the Kospi index gained 0.6% to 2,003.54 points. Analysts predict the won will stabilize at around 1,100 if the Fed keeps rates unchanged, but may weaken towards year-end. Shares of Samsung Electronics rose 5%, while Korea Electric Power Corp gained over 2%.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit near two-month lows
summary: Taiwan's stocks dropped to their lowest in almost two months, closing 0.14% lower at 8,934.51, amid volatile trading. Foreign selling and a decline in the electronics subindex contributed to the decline. However, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), the market's most heavily-weighted share, recovered later. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.625 per US dollar, and the main Taiex index had previously dipped to 8,885.55, its lowest level since July 15.

site_title: Australia plans its first ever 30-year bond offering next month
summary: Australia plans to sell its first-ever 30-year bond next month, with the government's debt pile set to reach A$500 billion. The move is seen as a way to take advantage of low borrowing costs and to establish a benchmark for the nation's longest outstanding nominal bond. The 30-year security is expected to be issued in a meaningful volume, with domestic investor support and the global search for yield expected to remain sufficient. The yield on the benchmark 30-year US security is currently 2.38%, compared to 2.85% for Australia's 2039 note.

site_title: China August investment growth steady, industrial output beats expectations
summary: China's fixed-asset investment growth remained steady at 8.1% in the January-August period, slightly better than market expectations. Industrial output rose 6.3% in August, surpassing analysts' estimates of 6.1%, while retail sales gained 10.6% on-year, beating expectations. The economy has shown stabilization thanks to increased government spending and a property rebound, but private investment remains weak.

site_title: North Korea floods 'major, complex disaster': Red Cross
summary: North Korea is experiencing a "major and complex disaster" after floods killed at least 133 people, left 140,000 in need of food and shelter, and destroyed 24,000 houses. The floods, triggered by torrential rains, have devastated entire communities and washed away buildings. Rescue workers face challenges reaching affected areas, and the risk of disease is looming. The disaster is expected to worsen North Korea's already chronic food shortages, with up to 600,000 people facing disruptions to their water supply.

site_title: LG and Samsung accused of Silicon Valley anti-poaching deal
summary: LG Corp and Samsung Electronics Co have been accused of conspiring to suppress wages by agreeing not to recruit each other's employees in Silicon Valley, according to a federal court complaint. The alleged "no-poaching" pact, dating back to at least 2005, allegedly resulted in frequent cross-hiring between the two companies due to similar work cultures. The lawsuit, led by a former LG sales manager, seeks class-action status on behalf of tens of thousands of US workers and comes after a similar $415 million settlement with Apple, Google, and other Silicon Valley tech companies.

site_title: China says industrial output, retail sales rise in Aug
summary: China's industrial output and retail sales rose in August, exceeding expectations with 6.3% and 10.6% year-on-year growth respectively. Industrial production accelerated from July's 6.0% and retail sales beat forecasts of 10.2%. However, analysts remain cautious, with some warning of a potential slowdown in the second half of the year. China aims to retool its economy from investment-driven growth to consumer demand, but the transition has been bumpy, with the country's economy slowing down in recent years.

images.alt_text: China's industrial output and retail sales growth accelerated in August, government statistics showed Tuesday, with both of them exceeding expectations in encouraging signs for the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Unlikely oil-trade routes arise after global shipping rates sink
summary: Ultra-low crude prices and cheap shipping rates are encouraging oil exporters to tap into new markets, leading to the emergence of exotic oil trade routes. The US has led the way, with oil shipments departing for Curacao, France, and Israel, while other traditional oil-producing nations, such as Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Oman, are also exploring new routes. The trend is expected to benefit oil refiners and traders, who can source crude from diverse locations, potentially pocketing hefty profits. Analysts attribute the shift to extremely low freight rates and accommodative inter-regional crude spreads.

site_title: Apple's Ireland bill puts US Treasury in tax-credit bind
summary: Apple Inc. has been ordered to pay €14.5 billion plus interest in back taxes to Ireland, a decision by European regulators. The US Treasury Department faces a tax-credit bind as Apple may claim a foreign tax credit, potentially lowering its US tax bill. The 35% corporate income-tax rate in the US is one of the world's highest, and the repayment could result in significant tax savings for Apple. The US Treasury's tax-credit claim could impact its revenue and influence US tax policies.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound on Fed Governor's dovish comments
summary: Australian shares rebounded 0.3% on Tuesday, boosted by materials and healthcare sectors, following dovish comments from US Federal Reserve Board Governor Lael Brainard. Brainard stated the Fed would hold interest rates steady, reducing prospects of a near-term hike. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 17.89 points, offsetting three straight sessions of losses, with gold stocks and mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto leading the gain.

site_title: Syria truce appears to be holding as it enters first full day
summary: A Syria ceasefire brokered by Moscow and Washington appears to be holding on its first full day, with no reported rocket fire or air strikes on the main battlefronts. AFP correspondents and activists reported a quiet night in Aleppo, with residents taking advantage of the truce to celebrate the Muslim Eid al-Adha holiday. The ceasefire, which went into force at sundown, is a significant development in the ongoing conflict, and its continued hold is seen as a positive sign for peace efforts in Syria.

site_title: Oil's slump stalls Merkel's push to expand natural gas in cars
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's push to expand natural gas vehicles in Germany faces a setback due to a slump in oil prices, cutting the cost of traditional fuels. Sales of natural gas cars fell 30% in 2015 and 31% in the past month, with only 0.15% of registered cars powered by methane. The decline threatens to miss Merkel's goal of capturing 4% of the market by 2020 and puts pressure on her government's climate policy. The low oil prices also raise concerns about the feasibility of reaching the target of one million electric and hybrid vehicles on the road by 2020.

site_title: Two men rush Lochte during "Dancing with the Stars": media
summary: Two men rushed the "Dancing with the Stars" stage in protest against Ryan Lochte, who fielded comments from judges after his performance on Monday. Lochte has been embroiled in scandal after admitting to exaggerating a robbery tale during the Rio Olympics. He lost sponsors and was suspended for 10 months after apologizing for lying. The protest occurred in response to Lochte's public appearance on the dance competition show, amid his ongoing public relations crisis.

site_title: Yen gains as US dollar holds loss after Fed hike odds scaled back
summary: The yen strengthened against the US dollar after Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard expressed a "less compelling" case for a rate hike, reducing market-implied probability to 22% from 30%. This move weakened the greenback against most major counterparts, with the yen gaining from Monday's gains. The dollar-yen pair is sensitive to Fed policy, according to Westpac strategist Sean Callow. The comments came ahead of the Fed's Sept 20-21 meeting, during which officials typically abstain from public comments on monetary policy.

site_title: China says should maintain South China Sea peace with Vietnam
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang urged Vietnam to work together to maintain peace and stability in the South China Sea, where China claims nearly all the waters and Vietnam has sovereignty claims. China has refused to recognize a court ruling invalidating its claims, while Vietnam welcomed the ruling and reasserted its own sovereignty claims. The two countries agreed to manage and control disputes, promote maritime cooperation, and maintain regional peace and stability. This comes as Vietnam is building a military deterrent to secure its Exclusive Economic Zone amid growing Chinese assertiveness.

site_title: Ford to sell driverless cars to public by 2025, CEO says
summary: Ford plans to start selling driverless cars to the public by 2025, according to CEO Mark Fields. The goal is to make autonomous vehicles affordable to millions of people by lowering costs. Initially, Ford will offer robot taxis to ride-hailing services by 2021, followed by vehicles available for personal purchase. The company aims to transform into an automotive and mobility company to succeed in the new era of autonomous cars.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit sinks as lower oil and 1MDB saga hurt demand
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell to its lowest in over two months due to a decline in oil prices and a 1MDB controversy. The currency weakened 0.6% to 4.0945 per US dollar, amid concerns over the state investment company's arbitration hearing against Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund. Brent crude dropped 0.7% and the ringgit's value was further damped by Federal Reserve comments suggesting no interest rate rise this month. The 1MDB saga remains a major risk for the Malaysian assets.

site_title: Singapore's CapitaLand callable bond gets risky bets, iFast says
summary: Singapore's CapitaLand callable bond trades at 102.1 US cents, suggesting investors are unaware of the risks associated with the notes' structure. The yield to call is minus 0.55% due to the low probability of early redemption, resulting in a higher bond coupon of 4.5%. Experts warn that individual investors are taking a high-risk bet, as CapitaLand can redeem or refinance the bonds at a cheaper cost. The company has sufficient cash and unused lines to support refinancing and working capital needs.

site_title: Billionaire Kuok said to seek buyer for US$500m cinema arm
summary: Billionaire Robert Kuok is seeking a buyer for Golden Screen Cinemas Sdn, Malaysia's largest movie theater chain, in a deal potentially worth up to US$500 million. The cinema business, with 345 digital screens in Malaysia and Vietnam, has received first-round bids from companies. This sale comes as Asian film exhibitors expand outside their home markets, with US$16.1 billion of entertainment acquisitions made in the past year. Kuok, Malaysia's richest person, controls PPB Group, which generated 65.6 million ringgit in profit from its film exhibition and distribution division last year.

site_title: China Jan-Aug property investment growth quickens to 5.4%
summary: China's property investment grew 5.4% in January-August, exceeding expectations, despite local governments tightening restrictions to curb rising prices. Property sales by floor area rose 25.5% in the same period. August property investment increased 6.2% from a year ago, while real estate investment drives about 40 other sectors. However, the country's debt problem remains a concern, with property developers' debt ratio nearing 80% and household loans making up over 90% of new loans.

site_title: Bitcoin technology harnessed to push electricity revolution
summary: Bitcoin technology is being harnessed to revolutionize the electricity industry, with researchers and utilities adapting blockchain systems to manage payments and transactions in real-time. The shift away from traditional centralized systems is driven by the rise of independent renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar farms. Utilities like RWE AG and Fortum OYJ are exploring the use of blockchain to track renewable energy usage, electric vehicle charging, and other transactions, with the goal of creating a decentralized and efficient energy market.

site_title: China yuan firm on higher PBOC fix, traders wary before holidays
summary: China's yuan edged up in early trade on Tuesday, set at 6.6726 per US dollar, after the People's Bank of China (PBOC) set a higher mid-point rate. The spot market opened at 6.6778 per US dollar, 9 pips firmer than Monday's close. Despite the rate increase, traders remained cautious ahead of upcoming holidays, keeping the yuan 0.1% weaker than the midpoint. The PBOC's decision comes after it denied reports of relying on foreign exchange sales by state-owned banks to stabilize the yuan.

images.alt_text: China's yuan edged up in early trade on Tuesday after the central bank set a higher mid-point although traders were unwilling to push the currency too high ahead of looming holidays.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.37% lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.37% to 2,833.86 at 9:02 am on Tuesday, despite a US stock market rebound on dovish Federal Reserve comments. Trading was light with 92.4 million shares worth S$99.6 million changing hands. The decline followed a one-day public holiday and was largely driven by Asian stocks mirroring the US equity rebound.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices ease 0.8% in August: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices eased 0.8% in August 2016, following a revised 0.7% decline in July. Prices in the city-fringe and suburbs declined 1.5% and 0.7% respectively, while Core Central Region prices rose 0.1%. Year-over-year, the overall resale price index fell 0.8%, with year-on-year declines in the city-fringe and suburbs. The median Transaction over X-Value (TOX) worsened to negative S$11,000 in August, indicating buyers are overpaying.

images.alt_text: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore eased 0.8 per cent in August 2016 over the previous month, based on SRX Property's flash estimate for last month released on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.09 points to 1680.27. Losers outnumbered gainers 229 to 47, and volume reached 55 million lots worth RM23.5 million.

site_title: Australia's central bank optimistic on economic outlook
summary: Australia's central bank is optimistic about the country's economic outlook, citing a decline in mining investment and higher commodity export prices as supportive factors. Reserve Bank of Australia Assistant Governor Christopher Kent stated that the economy is likely to sustain solid growth, leading to lower unemployment and rising wages and inflation. The Australian economy grew 3.3% in the year to June, beating forecasts, and the central bank has cut interest rates twice to a record low of 1.5%. Kent also noted the support of the local dollar to the services sector since 2013.

site_title: Asia: Stocks join US rebound as Fed outlook weighs on US dollar
summary: Asian stocks rebounded after Federal Reserve governor Lael Brainard's dovish comments, lifting the MSCI Asia Pacific Index 0.6% and triggering gains in US shares. The yen strengthened versus the dollar, while copper advanced and oil fell to around $46 a barrel. Brainard's comments eased concerns about the Fed's interest-rate hike and reduced the probability of a September rate hike to 22%. Markets in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore return after Monday's rout, with China's August data release expected to impact sentiment.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, following an upturn on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.58% to 16,769.54, while the Topix index gained 0.47%. This comes after a top Federal Reserve official argued against hiking interest rates quickly, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Facebook Messenger allows for direct merchant sales
summary: Facebook has introduced a new online payment system that allows businesses to sell directly to consumers on its Messenger app. The system, which uses customers' existing payment information stored on Messenger and Facebook, simplifies the checkout process and reduces friction. With over 30,000 bots already created for Messenger, the platform is being expanded to enable merchants to sell products and services directly to customers within the app, potentially generating revenue for Facebook. This move aims to monetize its free messaging application, which is used by over a billion people.

site_title: China Postal Savings Bank US$8.1b IPO mostly covered by cornerstone investors
summary: China Postal Savings Bank (PSBC) launched an initial public offering (IPO) worth up to US$8.1 billion in Hong Kong, with cornerstone investors covering about 72% of the deal, or US$5.86 billion. The IPO received tepid demand from retail investors and fund managers, underscoring Hong Kong's struggling market.

site_title: GM eyes growth in China as US auto sales ebb
summary: General Motors is focusing on growth in China as the US car market experiences a decline. In the first eight months of the year, GM's auto sales in China jumped 8.1% to 2.38 million, with a monthly record of 293,537 cars sold in August. GM aims to reach 30 million industrywide auto sales in China by 2020 and has invested $12 billion in the country over three years. However, the company faces competition from Chinese automakers with lower labor and material costs, and is increasing spending on promotions to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: As the US car boom begins to ebb, American auto giant General Motors is eyeing growth in China as an even more crucial component of its business.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.17% to 23,564.13, following a top Federal Reserve official's comments tempering expectations of a US rate hike this month. The Shanghai Composite Index also gained 0.10% to 3,025.03, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.54% to 1,987.77. The rally comes despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decisions.

site_title: Vard unit wins Cochin Shipyard contract worth 150m Norwegian krone
summary: Vard Holdings subsidiary Vard Electro AS secured a 150 million Norwegian krone (S$24.7 million) contract with Cochin Shipyard to deliver an equipment and electrical installation package for a vessel under construction for the Indian government. The contract follows years of cooperation between Vard and Cochin Shipyard, with support from a Vard Electro subsidiary in Kochi, India.

site_title: China tries to cool property boom just as mortgage bonds triple
summary: China's residential mortgage-backed securities (RMBS) market is booming, with issuance almost tripling to 72.8 billion yuan this year. However, regulators are taking steps to curb the property market, which is seen as a pillar of growth in China's economy. Despite this, Moody's Investors Service warns that investors could face losses in a sharp correction in housing prices. China's central bank has cut the minimum required mortgage down payment to 20% for first-home purchases and tightened requirements for second-home buyers to limit risks.

site_title: ISDN appoints HK compliance adviser ahead of dual primary listing in HK
summary: ISDN Holdings appoints Shenwan Hongyuan Capital (HK) as its Hong Kong compliance adviser ahead of its dual primary listing in Hong Kong, effective upon listing on the main board. The appointment ensures compliance with Hong Kong's listing rules and reviews financial reports. This move follows ISDN's March announcement of its plan to list in Hong Kong to enhance its profile and attract investors. The group has also taken measures to ensure compliance with laws and regulations in China, Indonesia, and Vietnam, assessing no material impact on its past operational practices.

site_title: Korean Air funds for Hanjin Shipping may take time: Yonhap
summary: Korean Air may take considerable time to secure a loan of 60 billion won from major shareholder Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd to unload cargo. The financial regulator cited uncertainty over the loan's approval, with chairman Yim Jong Yong stating that Hanjin Shipping's ability to secure the funding is uncertain. Hanjin Shipping must give Korean Air a stake in its Long Beach Terminal as collateral for the loan.

site_title: LinkedIn founder offers US$5m if Trump releases taxes
summary: LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman pledges up to $5 million to a crowdfunded campaign for veterans if Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump releases his tax returns. Hoffman's effort follows a similar 2012 pledge by Trump, who promised to donate $5 million to charity if President Barack Obama released his college records. Hoffman supports Marine Corps veteran Pete Kiernan's campaign to raise $25,000 for non-profit groups aiding veterans, matching the total amount raised if the goal is met.

images.alt_text: The co-founder of LinkedIn pledged Monday to donate up to US$5 million to a crowdfunded charitable campaign for veterans if Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump releases his tax returns.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GLP, CWT, Vard, ISDN, AusGroup
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) agreed to buy $1.1 billion of warehouses from Hillwood Development Co and plans a $700 million deal for fully leased properties by December. CWT, a logistics company, received a full capital market services license for trading in futures contracts. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty, as investors remained positive.

site_title: Malaysia plans US$1b spending to improve congested airports
summary: Malaysia plans to spend approximately $1 billion over five years to upgrade and expand its airports, addressing growing congestion and capacity issues. The main airport operator, Malaysia Airports Holdings Bhd, aims to benefit regional airlines such as AirAsia Bhd, which is expanding its fleet and adding routes. The investment will also support Boeing's projection of 100 million new passengers annually in the region. The Malaysian government will foot part of the investment, with the rest coming from Malaysia Airports Holdings.

site_title: Clinton says may restart campaigning in a "couple of days"
summary: Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton said she may resume campaigning in a "couple of days" after a bout of pneumonia caused her to nearly collapse at an event on Sunday. Clinton, 68, acknowledged she had ignored doctor's orders to rest and said she had had similar episodes before. Her campaign acknowledged it may have been too slow to disclose her pneumonia diagnosis, and both Clinton and rival Donald Trump said they will release more medical details in the coming days ahead of the Nov 8 election.

site_title: Fintech startup dives into big data for Japanese stock research
summary: A Japanese fintech startup, Nowcast Inc, is launching a big data-driven research service to challenge traditional securities firms. The company will provide automated earnings estimates for 200 Japanese consumer goods makers starting in October, analyzing millions of retail transactions. This move comes as Japan's financial regulator pressures brokerages to stop relying on unpublished company data. Nowcast's CEO, Ryota Hayashi, aims to replace routine work with big data analysis, freeing analysts to focus on long-term trends, and plans to expand the service to 1,000 companies next year.

images.alt_text: A Japanese startup is entering the equity-research business in a bid to challenge the dominance of securities firms by using computers to crunch vast troves of information and predict companies' earnings.

site_title: Japan's Renesas Electronics to buy US chipmaker Intersil for US$3.2b
summary: Japan's Renesas Electronics Corp will acquire US chipmaker Intersil Corp for $3.22 billion amid industry consolidation. Renesas aims to complete the transaction by June 2017 to control the Milpitas, California-based company. The deal expands Renesas' portfolio in analogue chips, which process signals used in industrial, mobile, and infrastructure applications. Renesas beat US suitor Maxim Integrated Products Inc to secure the deal, which will boost its auto-related business. The acquisition marks the latest wave of consolidation in the global semiconductor industry, driven by slowing growth in computers and smartphones.

site_title: US shale output drop seen for 11th straight month in Oct: EIA
summary: US shale oil production is expected to drop by 61,000 barrels per day in October, marking an 11th consecutive month of decline, according to the US Energy Information Administration. The Eagle Ford shale play in South Texas saw the biggest decline, falling by 46,000 bpd, while the Bakken formation in North Dakota is expected to drop by 28,000 bpd. In contrast, Permian output is expected to rise by 22,000 bpd. Total natural gas production is also forecast to decline for an eighth consecutive month.

site_title: CEOs' optimism ebbs, suggesting US growth to stay muted
summary: US CEOs have become less optimistic about their business prospects, with the Business Roundtable CEO Economic Outlook Index declining to 69.6 in the third quarter, down from 73.5 in the previous quarter. The index, which measures expectations for revenue, capital spending, and employment, has been below its long-run average of 79.6 since the end of last year. Corporate leaders project a 2.2% economic expansion in 2016, down from a 2.1% estimate in the previous survey, citing weak economic growth and uncertainty prior to the presidential election.

site_title: Oil prices fall on profit taking, eyes on China data
summary: Oil prices fell in early trade on Tuesday due to profit-taking after a near 1% rise in the previous session. Brent crude futures dropped 0.7% to $47.98 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures fell 0.9% to $45.88 per barrel. The price decline is attributed to increased drilling in the US and investors taking profits. Markets are also watching Chinese data release later in the day for clues on demand strength for crude, with a potential decrease expected to put downward pressure on prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell in early trade on Tuesday on concerns over increased drilling in the United States and as investors took profits after oil prices rose close to one per cent in the previous session.

site_title: UK house prices edge higher in 'muted' post-Brexit market
summary: UK house prices rose 0.1% in August to £292,921, the same pace as in July, according to a report by Acadata and LSL Property Services Plc. This represents a 4.3% annual increase, the weakest in three years. The housing market has slowed since the Brexit vote and a stamp-duty surcharge on investment properties. Despite a rebound in demand, the market remains "muted" due to these factors.

site_title: Soured property-debt sales slump in Europe amid Brexit concerns
summary: Europe's property-debt sales slowed in the first eight months of 2016 due to Brexit concerns, with 24.4 billion euros in soured loans and assets sold, a 39% decline from 2015. Investors delayed deals, and the total gross exposure to non-core real estate by European banks and asset managers stands at 462 billion euros. The UK's asset management agency is seeking a buyer for a 22 billion euro loan portfolio, which could impact full-year sales. Evercore Partners forecasts 50-60 billion euros in disposals this year, down from the 2015 record of 85.9 billion euros.

images.alt_text: The clear up of distressed real estate assets slowed in Europe as deals were delayed by investors concerned about the Brexit vote, according to Evercore Partners Inc.

site_title: AusGroup seek breather from provisions of S$110m notes
summary: AusGroup, an oilfield services provider, is seeking a breather from provisions of S$110 million notes issued under its S$350 million multi-currency debt issuance program. The company is proposing to waive non-compliance with trust deed and notes, extend the maturity date to October 20, 2018, and make interest payments monthly instead of semi-annually. AusGroup also aims to increase the interest rate to 7.95% and 8.45% per annum, and potentially trigger an upfront partial redemption of at least S$4 million. An extraordinary general meeting will be held on October 5 to vote on the resolution.

site_title: Weiye's unit to buy two residential plots in China
summary: Weiye Property Holdings has entered into a share transfer agreement to acquire two companies owning residential plots in China. The acquisition is valued at approximately 215 million yuan, with the plots totaling 6,271 sqm and 25,210 sqm. The deal will be funded from internal resources and bank loans, and is expected to have minimal impact on the company's financials for the current year. The agreement was concluded on a willing-buyer, willing-seller basis, with a 10% deposit paid upfront.

site_title: HSBC ropes in Jackson Tai, former CEO of DBS Bank, to its board
summary: HSBC has appointed Jackson Tai, a 66-year-old veteran banker with deep knowledge of Asia and China, to its board as an independent non-executive director, effective Monday. Tai, former CEO of DBS Bank, brings extensive experience in investment banking and regional leadership. His appointment is seen as a strategic move to enhance HSBC's presence in the Asian market.

site_title: Aussie banks lose out to Canada as China exposure and housing take a toll
summary: Australian banks are facing challenges in the US bond market due to China exposure and housing concerns. Despite having similar credit ratings as Canadian banks, Australian lenders yield higher interest rates, averaging 1.83% compared to 1.78% for comparable Canadian businesses. Risks from China and real estate are weighing on investors, with household debt in Australia climbing and residential property prices rising 35% over five years. The Australian government's budget deficit and fiscal policy gridlock also pose a problem for the banks, which receive a boost from their AAA credit rating.

site_title: Gold erases losses after US rate hike expectations ease
summary: Gold steadied on Monday after dovish comments from US Federal Reserve policymakers lowered expectations for an interest rate hike this month, easing losses. US interest rate futures prices rose, diminishing the implied probability of a rate hike. Spot gold rose 0.05% to $1,328.32 an ounce, while US gold futures settled down 0.7% to $1,325.60 per ounce. The comments followed a hawkish statement by Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren on Friday, which had raised the chances of a rate rise in September to 30%.

site_title: Brainard's argument for no September hike likely to sway Fed
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard has released a post-crisis monetary policy manifesto, suggesting that the Fed may not raise interest rates in September. Brainard argues that the risks of running the economy a bit hotter are lower than the risks of raising rates too quickly, and that the Fed should prioritize guarding against downside risks. Her remarks are likely to sway the Fed's decision, but not all officials agree, with some confident in their forecast of gradually diminishing economic slack lifting inflation over time.

site_title: Myanmar bets on hydropower in new energy plan
summary: Myanmar is overhauling its energy strategy to boost hydropower, aiming for 50-55% of its power mix by 2030-31, down from 63% currently. The new government is reviewing 49 hydropower projects approved by the previous government, seeking to secure funds and attract foreign investment. Coal's share is expected to drop to 3% from 38% as imports of liquefied natural gas (LNG) could make up for the loss. The review is crucial for attracting Chinese investment, as several projects involve Chinese companies, including a cancelled $3.6 billion megadam project.

site_title: Southwest Airlines engine fan blade broke off mid-flight last month
summary: A Southwest Airlines Boeing 737-700 engine fan blade broke off mid-flight on August 27, 2016, forcing an emergency landing in Pensacola, Florida. The incident, investigated by the US National Transportation Safety Board, found evidence of metal fatigue in the titanium-alloy blade. No one was hurt, but the plane sustained damage to the fuselage, wing, and tail. The cause of the failure remains unknown, but regulators view "uncontained" failures as serious risks to passenger safety.

site_title: Duterte wants US special forces to leave south Philippines
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has announced that the US special forces must leave the southern island of Mindanao, citing that their presence would worsen the situation in the Muslim-majority area. The move comes after a spat with President Barack Obama, which prompted the US leader to cancel a meeting. Duterte has criticized the US over its role in past conflicts and alleged atrocities committed by Americans on Filipinos, and has also denounced US criticism of his war on drugs. The US has not received a formal request to withdraw its forces, but has stated its commitment to its alliance with the Philippines.

site_title: Investment firms say yields are in Asia and EM economies
summary: Investment firm Allianz Global Investors has shifted its stance to favor Asia and emerging markets over Europe due to low yields and political uncertainty. Despite concerns over commodity price crashes and US rate hikes, Allianz is increasing its exposure to Asian telcos, internet names, and Korean tech companies. Asian bond valuations are also seen as fair, with opportunities in Indonesian and Indian local-currency bonds and Chinese industrials and property in the high-yield space. The firm expects earnings recovery and a falling risk premium to support the rally.

site_title: CWT unit obtains full capital market services license
summary: CWT Limited's subsidiary, Straits Financial Services Pte Ltd (SFSPL), has been granted a full capital market services license by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, allowing it to trade in futures contracts and expand its customer base. This upgrade follows a 2014 partial CMS license, enabling SFSPL to conduct regulated activity in commodity derivatives. The full license enables SFSPL to offer a full suite of financial and commodity derivatives, including centrally cleared over-the-counter contracts and contracts-for-differences.

site_title: Former British PM Cameron resigns from parliament
summary: Former British Prime Minister David Cameron has resigned from parliament, citing the need to avoid becoming a distraction to the new government. He initially promised to stay as an MP until 2020 but decided to step aside after the EU referendum defeat. A by-election will be held for his seat of Witney in Oxfordshire. Cameron denied any link to Prime Minister Theresa May's education policy changes and expressed his support for her leadership. He plans to continue making a public service contribution and may seek a new role on the world stage.

site_title: US dollar falters amid mixed Fed rate signals
summary: The US dollar weakened slightly on currency exchange markets as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's interest rate review. Despite Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard's caution against premature rate hikes, Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren's speech on Friday suggested "gradual tightening" of rates. The euro strengthened to US$1.1234, while the pound rose to US$1.3336. The mixed signals from Fed members led to a slight improvement in the dollar's position, with investors awaiting the Fed's decision next week.

site_title: Japan's big manufacturers turn optimistic in a sign economy picking up
summary: Japanese big manufacturers turned optimistic about business conditions in the third quarter, with companies revising up their capital expenditure plans. The positive outlook suggests the economy is gaining momentum, offering relief to the Bank of Japan ahead of its monetary policy meeting. This development shows the central bank's efforts to keep rates low are starting to spur corporate investment, encouraging policymakers to reenergise domestic demand.

site_title: Britain starts to spend new Churchill banknote
summary: Britain has started circulating a new £5 banknote featuring Winston Churchill, the country's wartime leader. The plastic note, with enhanced security features, was launched on Tuesday and will initially be issued with 440 million notes. The new design carries a portrait of Churchill and a quote from one of his World War II speeches. The Bank of England described Churchill as "one of the greatest statesmen of all time" and the note is seen as a tribute to his legacy.

site_title: Food commodities trader Olam sees low grain prices into 2017
summary: Olam International, a major food commodities trader, forecasts low grain prices into 2017 due to oversupply and softening Chinese demand. CEO Sunny Verghese predicts prices will remain low for six months, with wheat prices at a 10-year low and corn at levels seen during the 2009 global financial crisis. The low prices are a boon for consumers but hurt farmers and agribusiness. Verghese also downplays the risk of La Nina weather, which could boost prices, citing a low prospect of its emergence.

site_title: A*Star to launch Singapore's first open innovation lab
summary: Singapore's A*Star will launch the country's first open innovation lab, A*START Central, on September 21. The 980 sq meter facility has already attracted 10 medtech, biotech, and Internet startups, including Privi Medical and Kooki. The lab aims to foster a robust medtech and biotech community, providing infrastructure, mentorship, funding, and access to business networks. A*Star's executive vice-president, Sidney Yee, hopes the lab will attract a global network of talent and investors, inspiring the next generation of entrepreneurs and "value-adding" startups.

site_title: Oil bears dominate market as doubt grows over output limits
summary: Opec and other oil producers have failed to agree on output limits, fueling doubts about a ceiling on crude production. Despite a meeting between Russia and Saudi Arabia, no specific measures were taken to support prices. Money managers have increased wagers on falling prices, the most in three months. Producers have pledged to discuss action in Algiers later this month, but a concrete plan remains uncertain. The lack of action has led to a surge in oil prices, with oil bears dominating the market.

site_title: GLP agrees to buy US warehouses for US$1.1b
summary: Global Logistic Properties Ltd (GLP) agreed to buy US$1.1 billion of warehouses from Hillwood Development Co. for completion in phases over the next 18 months. The deal, worth US$700 million, is part of GLP's push into US industrial real estate. The company expects to retain a 10% stake in the properties while continuing to manage them. The acquisition comes as online shopping fuels demand for distribution and warehouse space, with the US industrial occupancy rate at its highest level since 2000.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop for third day but sell-off loses strength
summary: European shares ended at their lowest point in two weeks, dropping 0.95% as investors worried about a possible US rate hike and slowing European Central Bank stimulus. The Stoxx 600 index hit a one-month low before rebounding, with growth-sensitive sectors like basic resources and banks leading the decline. Analysts predict the sell-off could be short-lived, but some remain bearish on the market's prospects.

site_title: Thomson Medical eyes S'pore listing in near term
summary: Thomson Medical Pte Ltd, controlled by Singapore billionaire Peter Lim, is planning a local listing in the near future. The hospital is expanding its services and adding more beds to its Novena location. Chairman Roy Quek aims to achieve a Singapore listing within 12 to 18 months of taking over the business. This move is part of the company's growth strategy, which also includes exploring opportunities for expansion. The exact timeline and details of the listing are not specified.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce back on dovish Fed comments
summary: US stocks rebounded Monday after Fed Governor Lael Brainard suggested a moderate and gradual approach to lifting interest rates, countering hawkish comments from other officials. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.3%, the S&P 500 gained 1.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.7%. Technology companies led the gains, while shares of Potash Corp and Polaris Industries declined. The market's reaction was seen as a relief after a two-per-cent drop in US stocks on Friday.

site_title: Decline in marriages in China transforming families and finances
summary: China's declining marriage rate, largely due to its aging population and one-child policy, is transforming families and finances. Fewer couples are getting married, resulting in fewer babies and less spending on homes, appliances, and household goods. This shift is attributed to educated women delaying marriage to build careers and establish financial footing, leading to a more empowered female population. The decline in marriages also affects cultural notions of family, with parents struggling to find suitable mates for their children. Businesses are adapting to this shift by offering cheaper jewelry, smaller appliances, and online housing options to cater to single buyers.

site_title: S'pore, Switzerland to enhance cooperation on fintech
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority (Finma) have signed a cooperation agreement to enhance fintech cooperation. The pact aims to expedite discussions on introducing new fintech solutions, reduce regulatory uncertainty, and promote fintech companies' expansion into each other's markets. Both authorities will share information on emerging trends and regulatory issues related to innovation, deepening bilateral cooperation and exchange views on global financial market developments.

site_title: Abe warns of 'unprecedented' threats to the security of East Asia
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe warned of "unprecedented" threats to East Asia's security following North Korea's latest nuclear test, citing China's military presence in the region. Abe instructed Japan's Self-Defence Forces to implement the country's new security legislation, which includes provisions for expanding their duties. The United Nations Security Council convened an emergency meeting, vowing to work on "appropriate measures" to respond to North Korea's actions, including a possible sanctions resolution. Japan and the US agreed to coordinate a response, while North Korea vowed to continue strengthening its nuclear capabilities.

site_title: Why TPP, TTIP failures would be so damaging for Washington
summary: US Trade Representative Michael Froman will meet EU officials in Brussels to revive the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), but a breakthrough is unlikely before the end of the Obama presidency. TTIP failure would be a setback for Washington, which has promoted free trade growth globally, and could also impact the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). The Obama administration's efforts to create regional and global institutions have been a key ambition, but TTIP and TPP failures would undermine US influence internationally and contradict its post-Cold War goal of fostering free trade and security institutions.

site_title: Blockchain bootcamps' rising demand for software pros
summary: Blockchain bootcamps are gaining popularity as demand for software professionals with blockchain expertise increases. With venture capitalists investing over $1.1 billion in related startups, there's a shortage of experienced developers. The number of developers is projected to rise rapidly, with 7,000-8,000 people currently able to develop for the blockchain. Bootcamps, such as those offered by Coursera, Byte Academy, and Deloitte, are teaching the basics of cryptography and programming languages like Solidity, and tuition fees range from $1,200 to $10,000. Experts predict that blockchain developers will command high salaries, with some expecting a rise in high-paying jobs within the next few years.

site_title: When two and four point to seven
summary: Global markets are shifting towards emerging markets and riskier assets due to negative-yielding Europe. Fund managers expect US rates to rise to 2% and stocks to return 4% a year. Asian sovereign bonds and US high-yield bonds offer yields of 7%. The Federal Open Market Committee's target of 3% is lower than expected, and the Fed may not raise rates until December, supporting these assets. As a result, investors are seeking yields globally, particularly in Asia and the US.

site_title: Hanjin's fall will not fix the global shipping industry's ills
summary: The collapse of Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd has sent container shipping rates from Asia to the US soaring 50% due to a shortage of ships, but experts say this will not fix the industry's underlying issues. A capacity glut, fueled by overspending on larger vessels, will persist even after Hanjin's crisis is resolved. The industry's problems are long-term and structural, with 7.4% of ships worldwide idle and a record 150 vessels expected to be scrapped this year. Rival shippers are moving to fill the gap, and customers may seek more stable partners, potentially leading to a "flight to quality."

images.alt_text: Following the collapse of Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd, container shipping rates from Asia to the United States spiked 50 per cent as the carrier's customers scrambled for ships. Few shipping industry experts expect those price increases to fix what is wrong with the industry.

site_title: Oil rises on US dollar, US equities; crude inventories eyed
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 1% on Monday, driven by a softer US dollar and stronger US equity markets. Brent crude settled at $48.32 per barrel, up 31 US cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 41 US cents to $46.29 per barrel. Analysts forecast a potential 4.5 million-barrel build in US crude stockpiles, but some traders bet on near-term gains ahead of bearish data on Wednesday. Oil prices remain down about 5% from September 8, partly reversing a 10% rally earlier this month.

images.alt_text: Oil prices ended nearly 1 per cent higher on Monday as a softer dollar and stronger US equity markets helped crude futures rebound from an early drop pressured by worries about increased drilling activity for oil in the United States.

site_title: Google car project loses leaders, advantage as rivals gain
summary: Google's self-driving car project, led by Chris Urmson, has lost key leaders and is losing its advantage to rival companies. Urmson left in August, and other top technologists have departed, despite Google having driven over 1.8 million miles in tests. The project, started in 2009, has yet to launch a public autonomous vehicle service, with Google focusing on revolutionizing transportation through full autonomy. Rivals like Uber, Tesla, and Volvo are catching up, with Uber set to launch an autonomous ride-sharing service in Pittsburgh, and Tesla offering partially autonomous features in over 70,000 cars.

images.alt_text: Chris Urmson, the mild-mannered robotics expert who ran Google's self-driving car project, used to say that when his son reached driving age in 2019 the technology would be available so the teenager wouldn't have to take a driving test.

site_title: Communities take charge in Scotland's land reform 'revolution'
summary: In Scotland, a "land reform revolution" is underway, with communities taking charge of land ownership. The Scottish government has set a target of 1 million acres of land in community ownership by 2020, with over half a million acres already acquired. The reforms aim to address the country's least equitable property ownership, where half of land is owned by fewer than 500 people. Communities are using the land for sustainable development, such as building new harbours, wind turbines, and golf courses, with profits reinvested in the local area.

site_title: SGX goes after Swiber in potential rule breach (Amended)
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a letter to Swiber Holdings, alleging potential breaches of Rule 703 regarding disclosure of material information. The breaches relate to the company's failure to disclose a US$710 million West Africa project, which was announced in 2014, and its subsequent delay in the project execution. Swiber had also failed to disclose material litigation claims amounting to S$10.7 million and S$9.6 million. The SGX has invited Swiber's board of directors to make representations within 14 days or risk findings against their interests.

site_title: China regulators put brakes on onshore debt issues
summary: China's regulators have tightened controls on onshore debt issued by property developers, aiming to curb rising property prices amid record-high land costs. In August, few new developer bond applications were accepted, following a massive 1.1 trillion yuan (S$224.1 billion) in onshore deals over the past 16 months. Regulators are imposing restrictions on the use of proceeds, limiting land purchases and bank loans. This move is expected to slow the feverish pace of onshore debt issues, but some analysts predict more developers will turn to the offshore market for funding.

site_title: UK needs to change economic model to benefit from Brexit
summary: The UK's economic model needs to change to benefit from Brexit, as the initial vote has not had a lasting impact. Investment remains consistent despite uncertainty, and consumer spending remains unaffected. However, the exit from the single market may lead to losses of 2-3% of GDP. The UK's shift towards services and non-EU exports could cushion the blow, as it now relies more heavily on world markets than the EU's internal market. The financial services industry may survive Brexit, but the country will need to rebalance its growth model, potentially through a revival of manufacturing.

site_title: The Donald or Hillary: Who should Beijing prefer?
summary: US presidential nominee Donald Trump has vowed to impose punishing tariffs on Chinese imports, but experts in Beijing question the feasibility of this approach. Chinese observers believe Trump's promises are meant to mobilize support from angry American voters but would not survive in office. In contrast, Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton has a more coherent and tougher approach towards China, which is expected to prioritize strategic national interests over human rights. A Trump presidency could potentially strengthen China's strategic position in the Asia-Pacific region, but Clinton's tougher stance would likely damage US-China economic ties.

site_title: Creditors resume Greek audit as EU presses for progress
summary: Greece's creditors resumed an audit of the country's finances, starting talks on a revamped privatisation fund outside Greek state control. The move comes after Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said an EU-IMF rift was delaying progress. The audit was interrupted by the summer break, but meetings have now resumed, with the goal of making progress on Greece's financial reforms.

site_title: Safe-haven yen gets a boost on stocks selloff
summary: The Japanese yen strengthened against the US dollar and other major currencies, driven by a global stocks selloff and safe-haven flows amid concerns over US economic data and potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The yen rose 0.6% against the dollar, while the dollar fell 0.6% against the yen. The US dollar outperformed against higher-yielding currencies, with a 0.5% gain against the Australian dollar. Fed governor Lael Brainard's speech later in the day is expected to provide further guidance on the central bank's future policy decisions.

site_title: Singapore Stewardship Code expected to be launched by year-end
summary: A working group in Singapore is expected to launch the country's first Stewardship Code by the end of the year, outlining how investors should use their powers as shareholders. The code aims to enhance engagement between investors and companies to promote long-term interests of all stakeholders. The initiative, developed by industry leaders, complements Singapore's existing Code of Corporate Governance and targets institutional investors, who are expected to play a key role in corporate governance. The code's launch follows similar efforts in other countries, including the UK, where it originated.

site_title: SBF promoting S'pore as Maritime Silk Road hub at CAEXPO
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) is promoting Singapore as a hub for the 21st century Maritime Silk Road at the 13th China-Asean Expo in Nanning, Guangxi. 25 Singapore companies are showcasing their industries at the Singapore national pavilion, while 11 companies and eight trade associations are featured at the Commercial Pavilion. The event aims to boost trade between Singapore and China, with a focus on the China-Asean Free Trade Area. SBF Chairman SS Teo hopes to help businesses understand and participate in the One Belt, One Road initiative.

site_title: MBS moves more swiftly to remodel its hotel rooms
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) is renovating its 2,560 hotel rooms in three towers, with 1,000 rooms completed in Tower 3 and work set to begin on Towers 1 and 2 in early 2017. The S$8 billion integrated resort is doing brisk business, with hotel occupancy rates reaching 96.4% and average daily rates largely unchanged. MBS president George Tanasijevich plans to carry out renovations floor by floor, minimizing noise disruptions, and will also enhance luxury offerings in The Shoppes and Wonder Full, its largest light-and-water show. Despite the Singapore government's 10-year IR duopoly expiring in 2017, Tanasijevich remains confident that MBS will remain competitive.

site_title: Amazon and Pandora Media to embrace lower subscription charges
summary: Amazon and Pandora Media plan to launch new streaming services with pricing as low as $5 a month, challenging existing services like Spotify and Apple Music. The move aims to attract casual listeners and potentially boost sales. Pandora's expanded US$5 subscription platform will offer features like skipping unwanted songs and storing playlists online. Amazon's music service, expected to debut soon, will charge US$10 a month or half that amount for customers using Echo, Amazon's voice-activated speaker system. The new offerings reflect a growing willingness among record companies to experiment with pricing and shore up competitors.

site_title: BOE deputy governor resigns to become director of LSE
summary: BOE deputy governor Minouche Shafik resigned to become director of the London School of Economics (LSE) in February 2017, ending her nearly three-year tenure at the central bank. Shafik, 54, will take up the role in September 2017, leaving the Monetary Policy Committee with only one female policymaker. Her departure follows a shake-up of the BOE by governor Mark Carney, aimed at addressing a gender imbalance at the top of the institution. Shafik's appointment to LSE marks the first time a woman has held the position on a permanent basis.

site_title: Basel on right track with bank capital rules: central bankers
summary: Central bankers say the Basel Committee's bank capital reforms are on the right track, with a focus on avoiding significant increases in overall capital requirements. The reforms aim to enhance banks' ability to withstand shocks, but lenders have criticized them for potentially leading to hefty capital increases. The Group of Central Bank Governors and Heads of Supervision endorsed the reforms' direction, urging the Basel Committee to prioritize stability over significant capital requirements.

site_title: Superbull Sano sees bond rout in Japan easing
summary: Japanese bond superbull Kazuhiko Sano believes the recent surge in yields is driven by a "misunderstanding" over the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) policy review, which he thinks will not result in tapering of monetary easing. Despite a 13-year worst quarter for Japanese government bonds, Sano remains committed to his forecasts, predicting yields will fall to record lows due to the BOJ's continued buying. He expects the 10-year yield to reach minus 0.4% and the 40-year yield to find a floor at zero, with other yields also declining.

site_title: GLP to develop logistics facility in Osaka
summary: GLP, a Singapore-based fund manager and developer, plans to develop a 27,000-square-metre logistics facility in Osaka, Japan, at a cost of around $66.9 million. The project, GLP Neyagawa, is expected to be completed by Q1FY19. Located 14km from Osaka city centre, the facility will be part of GLP Japan Development Venture II, a 50:50 joint venture with the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board. GLP sees strong fundamentals in the Japan market and is committed to investing in the country.

site_title: 9/11: the date that keeps reminding the world of unfinished business
summary: The 9/11 attacks, 15 years ago, were intended to inflict devastating damage on the US, but instead unified the American people and led to the downfall of Al-Qaeda. The US invasion of Afghanistan and subsequent military campaigns in the Middle East, however, created a new threat in the form of the Islamic State (IS), which has been responsible for numerous attacks worldwide. The US and its allies are now facing a global threat from a more violent and widespread terrorist group, and it is unclear whether the current approach to combating terrorism will be enough to address this new threat.

site_title: Canada rakes in C$5.5b a year in film, TV production boom
summary: Canada's film and TV production industry has experienced a significant boom, generating C$5.5 billion annually. The surge in production is attributed to a fall in the Canadian dollar, favourable tax credits, and increased demand for original content. This growth has created jobs and opportunities for the industry, with the sector becoming a major contributor to the country's economy.

site_title: World of Warcraft creator enters fray with startup
summary: Rob Pardo, former lead designer of World of Warcraft, has formed a new startup called Bonfire Studios with a $25 million funding from Andreessen Horowitz and Riot Games. The company, based in California, plans to create online multiplayer games, potentially for PCs and/or mobile devices. Pardo aims to recreate the social connections formed by players in World of Warcraft, and has hired several former Blizzard employees to start generating ideas and making game prototypes.

site_title: Tesla's new Autopilot emphasises role of radar to guide cars
summary: Tesla has unveiled a new version of its Autopilot software, which prioritizes radar over cameras to guide semi-autonomous cars. The update, version 8.0, could have potentially saved the life of a driver who died in May after his Tesla crashed into a semi-trailer. The new system uses enhanced radar and a GPS database to recognize objects on the road, including trucks and junk metal. The software also includes automatic feedback to GPS systems to prevent false alarms and holds drivers more accountable for keeping their hands on the steering wheel.

site_title: Samsung slumps by US$22b as Note 7 alerts pile up
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. lost US$22 billion in market value over two days due to widening bans and warnings on its Note 7 smartphones, which have been linked to battery fires. The company's shares plummeted 11% since Friday, the largest two-day decline since 2008. Investors fear the damage to Samsung's brand could extend beyond the initial estimated US$1 billion recall, potentially impacting the entire portfolio. The US Consumer Product Safety Commission is in talks with Samsung on an official recall, and airlines have called on passengers to stop using the devices during flights.

site_title: Wawrinka conquers nerves to win US Open
summary: Stan Wawrinka won the US Open, defeating world number one Novak Djokovic in a 6-7 (1/7), 6-4, 7-5, 6-3 match. Wawrinka, 31, overcame nerves and physical pain to secure his third Grand Slam title in three finals. He had previously beaten a reigning number one in a major final, and praised Djokovic for describing him as a player who rises to the big occasion. Wawrinka attributed his success to years of dedication and a willingness to push the limit.

site_title: Trump says Fed keeping rates low because of pressure from Obama
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump claimed Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen is keeping interest rates low due to pressure from the Obama administration. Trump stated Yellen should be "ashamed" of her actions, which he believes are driven by politics. However, Fed officials, including President Neel Kashkari, denied that politics influence monetary policy decisions, emphasizing the importance of economic data and the Fed's dual mandate.

site_title: Giving SMEs a jumpstart on innovation
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) can accelerate their innovation by adopting open innovation (OI) strategies, which involve partnering with other companies to acquire and generate new knowledge. While 60% of SMEs in the ICT sector have adopted OI, most activities are limited to customer feedback, and only 17% engage in joint research activities. To speed up OI adoption, SMEs need to build a stronger innovation mindset and invest in OI capabilities. The government has introduced new schemes to support SME growth, and public sector agencies can review funding and talent support to address economic and management obstacles to OI.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, while open innovation (OI) adoption among SMEs in the ICT sector is moderately high at 60 per cent, most OI activities are limited to getting customer feedback, rather than other forms of OI such as joint R&D with research institutes. Only a minority (17 per cent) of SMEs engage in deeper levels of collaboration like joint research activities for value creation.

site_title: Australians grapple with less work, low pay
summary: Australia's labor market is experiencing a concerning trend, with historically high underemployment and unemployment rates, and muted wage growth. The rise of part-time jobs and the "gig economy" is contributing to this, as workers lack job security and stability. This trend is limiting the ability of workers to push for pay rises and feeds into lower consumer spending and confidence. The Reserve Bank of Australia may be forced to lower interest rates again, and policymakers are worried about the impact of slow global demand and low business investment on the economy.

site_title: New Afghan rail route boosts China trade ambitions
summary: China has launched a new rail route from Haimen to Hairatan in northern Afghanistan, marking a significant step in its Silk Road project to deepen its influence in the region. The 1,400km rail link is expected to boost China's trade ambitions and turn Afghanistan into a key transit hub for Asia. Afghan President Ashraf Ghani sees this as a crucial step towards his dream of connecting his landlocked country to the rest of the world. The project is part of China's broader strategy to expand its economic reach and secure strategic resources.

site_title: What can derail Sheng Siong's stock?
summary: Sheng Siong, a Singaporean supermarket group, is trading at a high 28 times its 2015 earnings, with its stock price rising due to its defensive qualities and dividend payouts. However, the company's earnings growth is largely driven by new store openings rather than fundamental improvements, and its valuations may be overvalued. As interest rates rise, the company's yield becomes less appealing, and its multiples may plummet once earnings growth slows down. This poses a risk to the company's share price, despite its solid fundamentals.

site_title: China swats 'a few flies' to temper excesses of electric-car makers
summary: China has cracked down on electric vehicle (EV) makers, fining five companies a total of $150 million for scamming the state of subsidies. The government aims to curb excesses in the industry, which has grown rapidly with billions in state funding. The crackdown includes stricter technology standards and limiting licenses to manufacture EVs, with the goal of reaching 5 million EVs on Chinese roads by 2020. The move is seen as a necessary step to prevent the industry from becoming plagued by "me-too" companies lacking the technology and appeal needed to compete globally.

site_title: Gold prices dip to reveal bargains for the longer term
summary: Gold prices dropped to monthly lows due to speculation of a US interest rate hike, with the Federal Reserve signaling that labor and inflation measures are close to targets. Despite initial market apprehension, the dollar's rally and Fed Chair Janet Yellen's hawkish stance at the Jackson Hole symposium led to the decline. However, analysts suggest that the Fed may proceed with caution if a more protectionist US president is in office, potentially changing gold market sentiment in the long term. This short-term weakness may be an opportunity for investors to buy gold at a lower price.

site_title: Sunrise Group's Wong buys 29% stake in ITE Electric
summary: Sunrise Group's Wong buys 29% stake in ITE Electric after its former non-executive chairman, Aw Cheok Huat, sold his entire stake for S$6 million. Wong now holds 39.83 million shares, making him a controlling shareholder. ITE reported a loss of S$66,000 for the six months ended June 30, with revenue falling to S$6.33 million due to weak construction sector and slower economic growth.

site_title: Opec now sees non-cartel oil output rising in 2017
summary: Opec revised its expectations of non-cartel oil output rising in 2017, with Kazakhstan, Norway, and Britain expected to produce more than forecast. This change is attributed to a lower-than-expected decline in US tight oil and a better-than-expected performance in Norway. Global oil demand is projected to continue growing, with a 1.23 million b/d increase this year and a rise in 2017, primarily driven by growth in India, China, and the US.

images.alt_text: Opec said Monday that oil production by countries outside the exporters' cartel was now expected to rise in 2017, revising its previous expectations of a drop.

site_title: Energy support sector's woes will continue even after oil price recovery
summary: The energy support sector, including oilfield services and shipbuilders, has struggled since the 2014 oil price boom due to a lack of major purchase orders from the industry. A recent report suggests this downturn could last for up to two years after the current bear market recovers. Manufacturers, such as those producing oil and gas equipment, are experiencing reduced revenues, with some stating they will be the last to return to work when oil prices recover, due to a significant portion of their fleet being idle.

site_title: MH370 'debris' handed to Australian agency
summary: An American amateur investigator, Blaine Gibson, handed possible debris from missing flight MH370 to Australian officials, raising the prospect of a flash fire onboard. The debris, which includes an internal panel, shows signs of melting and blackened paint, suggesting it may have originated from the cargo hold or avionics bay. The discovery could be a "game changer" if confirmed to belong to MH370, fueling speculation about a potential fire on the plane.

site_title: World's reinsurers predict premium respite at Monaco meeting
summary: Global reinsurance firms predict a premium respite in the coming year, with stabilisation expected after five years of falling rates. The US$600 billion industry, facing low returns, will see competition remain tough. Reinsurers, including Swiss Re and Hannover Re, expect a more flattish market, with premium declines slowing down. However, ratings agencies predict a 5% fall in premiums next year, and weak profitability may lead to a fresh wave of mergers and acquisitions globally in 2017.

site_title: 2011: PAP loses Aljunied GRC to WP
summary: In 2011, the PAP lost its Aljunied GRC to the WP, marking the party's worst election performance since Independence. The PAP's 60.1% popular vote was its lowest in history, forcing out Cabinet ministers and shattering notions of the party's infallibility. The loss was partly due to complaints about strained infrastructure, including MRT disruptions that sparked outrage. Meanwhile, a nuclear crisis in Fukushima, Japan, was the worst since Chernobyl in 1986, following an earthquake and tsunami that overwhelmed safety systems at a nuclear power plant.

site_title: From bricks to smuggled wigs: China's border trade with North Korea
