summary: China's border post with North Korea reopened on Monday after Pyongyang's fifth nuclear test, with trucks carrying goods such as bricks, exhaust pipes, and machinery crossing the border. Despite China's condemnation of the test and support for UN sanctions, trade continues, with drivers saying routine checks have increased but business remains steady. Smuggling of luxury goods, including wigs and eyelash extensions, remains common, with drivers making money by transporting prohibited items. China's stance on further sanctions remains ambiguous, with the country prioritizing its economic ties with North Korea.

site_title: Singapore, Switzerland to enhance collaboration on fintech
summary: Singapore and Switzerland have signed an agreement to enhance collaboration on fintech, providing a framework for innovative companies to introduce new solutions in each other's markets and understand regulatory requirements. The partnership aims to create opportunities for fintech businesses to expand into each other's markets, while also sharing information on emerging trends and regulatory issues. This collaboration is expected to foster greater cooperation and innovation in the fintech industry.

site_title: Samsung sells printing unit to HP for US$1.05b
summary: Samsung Electronics is selling its printing unit to HP for $1.05 billion, part of the company's efforts to concentrate on its core business areas. The sale, which includes 6,000 employees, follows a generational power transfer in the founding Lee family as Chairman Lee Kun-Hee prepares to hand over the reins to his son, JY Lee. The deal is subject to shareholder approval in October and will boost growth opportunities in the copier segment for HP.

site_title: India's August retail inflation at five-month low, raises hopes of rate cut
summary: India's August retail inflation fell to a five-month low of 5.05% due to smaller rises in food prices, raising hopes of an interest rate cut next month. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) left interest rates unchanged last month, with analysts predicting a 25 basis point cut in the October policy meet. The fall in food inflation and fuel index brought inflation within the RBI's target of 5.0% by March 2017. Economists expect further easing of inflation, giving the new RBI governor room to cut interest rates.

site_title: Clinton cancels California trip after health scare: campaign
summary: Hillary Clinton cancelled a campaign trip to California after falling ill at a 9/11 memorial ceremony due to dehydration from pneumonia, her doctor revealed. The Democratic White House hopeful, 68, was diagnosed with pneumonia just hours before the trip was cancelled. The cancellation comes just two weeks before her first presidential debate against Donald Trump. Clinton's campaign has paused her busy schedule, particularly fundraising, amid a tightening race.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares lose 1.73% on US rate hike talk
summary: Tokyo shares declined 1.73% on Monday, following a global sell-off, after top US Federal Reserve officials expressed support for a possible interest rate hike this month. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 16,672.92, while the Topix index dropped to 1,323.10. The move was driven by cautious investors, who reacted to the Fed's potential rate hike.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as investors fret over Sept rate hike
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday as investors fretted over a possible interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve as early as next week. Top Fed officials hinted at a possible raise, but Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari suggested little urgency to act. Financial stocks fell for the third straight day, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 47.84 points, or 0.26%, at 18,037.61. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the CBOE Volatility index reaching its highest level since the Brexit vote.

site_title: Former British PM Cameron resigns from parliament
summary: Former British Prime Minister David Cameron has resigned from parliament, nearly three months after losing the EU referendum. He stepped down as prime minister in June and handed over power to Theresa May. Cameron cited the need to avoid becoming a distraction in modern politics and expressed support for May's leadership. His resignation is unusually quick, as former prime ministers typically retain their seats for years. Cameron will be named as a Crown Steward and Bailiff, and a by-election will be held to pick his successor.

site_title: Swiss bourse looks for alternative EU gateway as Brexit looms
summary: Switzerland's stock exchange, SIX Swiss Exchange, is in talks with EU regulators to establish a new gateway to the EU's single market once Britain leaves the bloc, following the UK's Brexit decision. The move aims to ensure access to European markets for the Zurich-based bourse, which currently relies on London as a base for business across the EU. The talks highlight the potential erosion of London's role as the region's leading financial hub and the need for alternative centres to guarantee EU access.

site_title: European shares slide, poised for biggest loss since June
summary: European shares fell by 1.8% in early deals on Monday, poised for their biggest loss since late June, due to a global sell-off in stocks and bonds amid concerns over US monetary policy. Investors worried about a potential rate hike by the US Federal Reserve next week and the effectiveness of central bank policy. The basic resources sector slumped 3.5%, while bank stocks fell 1.9%. German-listed E.ON was the top loser after spinning off its Uniper division.

site_title: Oxford English Dictionary gains splendiferous moobs
summary: The Oxford English Dictionary has added over 1,000 words and phrases to its collection, including "splendiferous" (meaning full of or abounding in splendour), "yogalates" (a fitness routine combining pilates and yoga), and "moobs" (unusually prominent breasts on a man). Other new entries include "Westminster Bubble," "gender-fluid," and "YOLO." The dictionary is updated every three months and marks the centenary of Roald Dahl's birth with the addition of Dahl-inspired vocabulary, such as "Dahlesque" and "gremlins."

site_title: EU to hold post-Brexit summit in Malta in early 2017
summary: EU leaders will hold a summit in Malta in early 2017, excluding Britain, to discuss a future for the bloc following the Brexit vote. The 27 leaders will gather in Malta after a similar meeting in Bratislava and ahead of a Rome meeting in March. The summit aims to map out a new roadmap for Europe, focusing on security, borders, and defense, as EU President Donald Tusk seeks to rebuild a sense of political unity.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks post biggest one-day drop in 7 months
summary: Hong Kong's benchmark stock index plummeted 3.4% to 23,290.60 points, its largest single-day drop in 7 months, amid a global selloff in financial markets. The decline was driven by concerns that policymakers are reaching policy limits to boost weak growth. Financials and IT companies led the losses, and bond yields hit multi-month highs. Despite underperforming its peers this year, Hong Kong's market has recently outperformed the US market on a year-to-date basis.

site_title: London's Heathrow sets August record as runway ruling nears
summary: London's Heathrow Airport set a record 7.34 million passenger handling in August, a 0.1% increase from the previous year, with growth in Middle East and Latin America flights. The airport operates at 98% capacity and is awaiting government approval on a new runway, with a decision expected soon. This marks a recovery from potential traffic dips following the UK's June Brexit vote.

site_title: Australia: Shares slump as bets rise on Sept Fed rate hike; NZ lower
summary: Australian shares fell 2.3% to 5,218.6, their lowest since July, amid concerns of a potential US Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren's comments fueled the decline, with financials and materials stocks leading the drop. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 2.6%, while oil prices extended their 4% fall. The slump was attributed to rising bets on the Fed's interest rate hike and a strong US dollar.

site_title: Thai authorities downplay Zika risk, worried by tourism impact
summary: Thai authorities downplay the risk of Zika virus infections, despite a warning from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, citing concerns that disclosing information may harm the country's tourism industry. Health officials are combating the risk by misting and spraying mosquito-infested areas.

site_title: Google's former China chief raises US$674m in new funds
summary: Sinovation Ventures, a venture capital firm co-founded by Google's former China chief Kai-Fu Lee, has raised over $674 million for two new funds focusing on investments in China and the US. The firm now manages over $1.2 billion, expanding its portfolio of nearly 300 startups. Lee attributes the new funds to strengthening investment capacity, citing Sinovation Ventures' dual teams in China and the US. This successful fundraising comes as venture capital investment cools after a record pace in 2015, with Chinese-based firms raising the lowest amount in almost three years.

site_title: GLP to develop logistics property in Osaka
summary: GLP, a mainboard-listed company, will develop a 27,000 square meter logistics property in Osaka at a cost of around five billion yen (S$66.8 million). The project, GLP Neyagawa, is a 50:50 joint venture between GLP and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and is scheduled for completion in Q1 FY19 (April to June 2018).

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as Fed rate talk brews
summary: Asian markets sank on Monday as comments from top central bankers hinted at a potential interest rate hike, prompting investors to sell stocks. The US Federal Reserve's Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren and Governor Daniel Tarullo expressed support for a rate hike this month, citing the need to prevent overheating. The news led to a decline in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, and Wellington stocks. Oil prices also fell, and Samsung Electronics plummeted after US regulators warned against using its Note 7 smartphone due to battery risks.

site_title: North Korea flood death toll rises to 133 with 395 missing: UN
summary: A severe flood in North Korea's northeastern region has claimed 133 lives, with 395 missing, and left tens of thousands homeless. Over 107,000 people have been forced to flee their homes, and more than 35,500 houses have been destroyed, with 8,700 public buildings damaged. The UN has released aid, including food, shelter, and medical supplies, and North Korea's government is working to rebuild 20,000 homes by early October.

images.alt_text: The death toll from severe flooding in a North Korean border region has risen to 133 with another 395 missing and tens of thousands left homeless, the UN said.

site_title: Singapore: Market closed for public holiday
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) was closed on Monday, September 12, 2016, due to a public holiday. Trading resumed on Tuesday, September 13. This article is not relevant to the current date and does not contain any current news.

site_title: Fed's Kashkari says fiscal, rule reforms needed to boost growth
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari says fiscal and regulatory reforms are needed to boost economic growth due to limited scope of low interest rates. Kashkari attributes economic slowdown to demographic challenges, psychological scarring from the crisis, and lack of technological innovation. He suggests investing in infrastructure, simplifying the tax code, and reducing regulatory burden as policies with "little downside risk." Kashkari also questions the wisdom of raising the Fed's inflation target, citing a potential weakening of credibility.

images.alt_text: The US government should consider fiscal and regulatory reforms to boost economic growth because the scope for low interest rates alone to do so is limited, said Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari.

site_title: Oil prices extend losses in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell in Asian trade on Monday, with US West Texas Intermediate dropping 79 cents to $45.09 and Brent tumbling 76 cents to $47.25. The decline follows a sharp fall in US inventories last week and speculation about a potential Federal Reserve interest rate hike. Analysts expect US output to increase, despite weak demand, and a meeting between Opec and Russia is seen as crucial in addressing the global supply glut. A deal is unlikely, however, and prices may continue to decline.

site_title: China's state-owned banks sell dollars to support yuan: traders
summary: China's yuan strengthened on Monday as state-owned banks sold dollars to stabilize the currency after the People's Bank of China sharply weakened its official fixing. The midpoint rate was set at 6.6908 per dollar, the weakest since August 31, and softer than the previous fix of 6.6684. Traders reported that state-owned banks offered dollars to pull the yuan back to around 6.68, fearing a rapid descent. The move is seen as an attempt to prevent a too-rapid decline in the yuan's value.

site_title: Samsung slumps by US$22b as Note 7 safety warnings pile up
summary: Samsung Electronics Co lost US$22 billion of market value in two days due to widening bans and warnings on its Note 7 smartphones. The company's shares plummeted 11% since Friday, the largest two-day decline since 2008. US regulators and aviation authorities cautioned users to power down and refrain from charging the devices, threatening Samsung's brand reputation. The company had heavily invested in marketing its name and had a head start on Apple's new iPhone, but its advantage has now disappeared. The damage to Samsung's bottom line is expected to be significant.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Fed rate hike speculation
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Monday due to speculation about a possible US rate hike this month, which led to a decline on Wall Street last week. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.27% to 16,749.67, while the Topix index fell 1.42% to 1,324.77.

site_title: Samsung Electronics shares touch near 2-month low on Note 7 worries
summary: Samsung Electronics shares plummeted to a nearly two-month low, down 5.3% as of Monday, due to concerns over the recall of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphone. The recall, initiated on September 2, was caused by faulty batteries that caused phones to catch fire. Investors have wiped off $16 billion from Samsung's market capitalization, with estimates suggesting the firm may lose nearly $5 trillion in revenue due to the recall. The company has sold 2.5 million affected phones that need to be replaced.

site_title: Asia: Shares, bonds spooked by central bank jitters
summary: Asian shares slipped on Monday due to rising bond yields and speculation about the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index fell 1.1% and Australian stocks dropped 1.8% as investors became increasingly cautious. The Bank of Japan considered steepening the Japanese yield curve, further pressuring sovereign debt and risk appetite globally. The US stock market also experienced volatility, with the Dow shedding 2.13% on Friday. The yen gained strength as investors sought safe havens amid geopolitical concerns, including North Korea's nuclear test and US presidential election uncertainty.

site_title: Oil extends decline amid projected rebound in US stocks
summary: Oil prices extended their decline on Monday, falling 1.0% to $47.52 a barrel, amid projections of a rebound in US crude inventories. This erases gains of over 4% on Thursday, which were triggered by a weekly drop in stockpiles. Despite a consensus among Opec and non-Opec members to stabilize the market, Tehran has stopped short of joining a global deal, citing production levels. US drillers added oil rigs for a 10th consecutive week, while money managers cut their long US crude futures positions for the second week in a row.

site_title: Amazon and Pandora set to launch new music streaming services
summary: Amazon and Pandora are set to launch new music streaming services, with Pandora expected to announce plans to expand its US$5-per-month platform this week, possibly including features like skipping songs and storing playlists. Amazon's new platform, priced at US$10 per month, will compete with Spotify and Apple Music, and is expected to be launched by Christmas. The companies have completed negotiations with record companies and music publishers, paving the way for the services to become available.

site_title: US response to 9/11 increased terror threat: Hollande
summary: US President Francois Hollande stated that America's response to the 9/11 attacks increased the jihadist threat, with the Iraq war's consequences now affecting France. Hollande's comments echo the Le Monde headline from 2001, "Yes, on that day, we were all Americans."

site_title: EU to extend some telco rules to web companies
summary: The European Union is set to extend some security rules currently applicable to telecom operators to web services such as WhatsApp, Skype, and FaceTime, according to a draft proposal. The proposed reform aims to level the playing field between European companies and US tech firms, requiring web services to ensure security and integrity, report breaches, and have contingency plans. The proposal also includes measures to ensure affordable basic broadband for European consumers and will need approval from the European Parliament and EU member states before becoming law.

site_title: Hungry for power, Myanmar bets on hydro in new energy plan
summary: Myanmar is revamping its long-term power strategy to prioritize hydropower and reduce reliance on coal, aiming to boost electricity generation to support the country's economic growth. The new government seeks foreign investment to finance hydro and renewable energy projects, with the goal of increasing hydropower's share to 50-55% by 2030-31. The country is reviewing 49 hydropower projects approved by the previous government, with China being a major investor, but the Myitsone megadam project remains a contentious issue due to environmental concerns.

site_title: Japan's Abe says North Korea nuclear tests "absolutely unacceptable"
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that North Korea's two nuclear tests since January are "absolutely unacceptable". This comes after North Korea conducted its fifth and largest nuclear test, claiming it can mount a warhead on a ballistic missile. Abe's comments underscore the international community's inability to contain North Korea's threat, with the UN and other nations expressing concern over the escalating situation.

site_title: Dow may test 18,000 on rate hike fears
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by almost 400 points to 18,085.45 after a Federal Reserve official warned of potential rate hikes by the end of the year. This may lead to the Dow slipping to the psychologically significant level of 18,000, erasing summer gains. The market's complacency has been shaken, with some analysts predicting a slowdown in consumer spending and a correction in the housing market. The European Central Bank also signaled the end of the low-rate era, further fueling concerns.

site_title: North Korea ready for another nuclear test: Yonhap
summary: North Korea has completed preparations for another nuclear test, according to South Korean government sources. The test, potentially using a previously unused tunnel, could be the North's most powerful blast yet. The US has vowed to impose unilateral sanctions, while the UN Security Council is set to work on a resolution condemning the test. The latest test has raised concerns about the North's expanding nuclear capability and its leader Kim Jong Un's willingness to alter course. The US, Britain, and France are pushing for new sanctions.

images.alt_text: North Korea has completed preparations for another nuclear test, South Korea's Yonhap News Agency reported on Monday, citing South Korean government sources who said the North may use a previously unused tunnel at its mountainous test site.

site_title: S'pore investment income from US rises to US$928m
summary: Singapore's investment income from the US rose to US$928 million in 2015, a 9% increase from US$853 million in 2014. Despite this, Singapore's cumulative direct investments in the US declined by over US$1 billion to US$19.42 billion. Japan was the largest Asian investor in the US, with US$411.2 billion in investments, and accounted for nearly three-quarters of Asia's investments. Globally, foreign investments in the US increased to US$3,134.19 billion, but income from investments slipped to US$151.34 billion.

site_title: Ex-AIG chairman due in court to fight 11-year-old lawsuit
summary: Former American International Group Inc chairman Maurice "Hank" Greenberg is set to appear in state court in Manhattan to fight an 11-year-old lawsuit accusing him of using sham transactions at AIG to hide the company's financial troubles from shareholders. The lawsuit, filed in 2005, claims Greenberg and his associates engaged in a scheme to conceal losses and inflate profits. Greenberg, 91, has a history of successfully fighting regulatory and government actions, including a federal lawsuit in 2005. Opening statements are scheduled for Tuesday.

site_title: Tesla's Musk says new Autopilot likely would have prevented death
summary: Elon Musk, Tesla's CEO, announced updates to the company's Autopilot system, which likely would have prevented a fatality in May. The new version, Autopilot 8.0, will have stricter hands-off driving limits and rely on radar for better surroundings awareness. The update, available within a week or two, aims to address concerns that the system gave users a false sense of security. Musk stated that the new features would have prevented the accident, but no further details on the incident were provided.

site_title: Review your finances before a career break
summary: Millennials are increasingly dissatisfied with traditional 9-to-5 jobs and are opting for career breaks or alternative lifestyles, such as living in national parks. A recent study found that fewer than half of millennials are employed in their preferred career, and one in four would leave their current employer for a new opportunity. Experts stress the importance of reviewing finances before making a career break, particularly saving for retirement and healthcare coverage. Millennials should maintain professional contacts and be prepared to explain their career break to potential employers.

images.alt_text: ALSO REMEMBER: "If you intend to return to the workforce after the break, it's a good idea to maintain your professional contacts, and be prepared to have a succinct, positive answer when future employers ask why and how you took the break," Ms Pollak notes.

site_title: Where have the jobs gone? Australians grapple with less work, low pay
summary: Australians face a challenging job market, with a historically high underemployment rate of 8.5% and an underutilization rate of 14.2%. The trend limits workers' ability to push for pay rises, contributing to muted demand and confidence. Wages growth is at record lows, and inflation is likely to remain below the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3% until 2018. The low business investment, partly due to slow global demand and corporate managers' reluctance to spend on new projects, raises concerns about the economy's future growth.

images.alt_text: Sydney resident Raman Kumar recently lost his job as an electrician after his employer outsourced a big chunk of the work to China to slash costs - and then hired him back as a casual worker.

site_title: Uber's self-driving cars get run of the road
summary: Uber is set to introduce a fleet of self-driving cars in Pittsburgh, making it the world's first city to let passengers hail autonomous vehicles. The city has taken a hands-off approach to regulating the technology, allowing Uber to test its modified Volvo vehicles with human monitors behind the wheel. Pittsburgh has nurtured a greenlight governing approach, giving tech companies like Uber free rein to innovate, which has attracted numerous tech entrepreneurs and scientists to the city. The move has sparked both praise for Pittsburgh's forward-thinking approach and criticism about safety risks.

site_title: Political paralysis stalls Spain's building sector
summary: Spain's construction sector is facing a setback due to political paralysis, which has left the country without a settled government for over a year. Industry figures are concerned that no administration can sign off on new projects, hindering a return to the sector's pre-economic crisis state. This paralysis has stalled the sector's recovery, which was hoped to be underway after the national economic crisis subsided.

site_title: US investments in Singapore swell in 2015
summary: US investments in Singapore surged by 39.5% to $288.67 billion in 2015, with the stock of US investments more than doubling in the past five years. However, US investment income in Singapore decreased to $22.89 billion, lower than 2013's income. Globally, US investment returns fell to $402.29 billion, with the Asia-Pacific region experiencing a decline of 15.6% from 2014. Despite higher US investments overseas, the slowdown in global growth took a toll on US investment income worldwide.

site_title: SBI Offshore's legal counsel to review PwC findings and provide advice to board
summary: SBI Offshore, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine firm, is facing a boardroom tussle amid a PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) report that found two different sets of agreements for the purchase and subsequent sale of a Chinese firm, Jiangyin Neptune Marine Appliance Co Ltd (NPT). The report revealed conflicting considerations for the transactions, including possible breaches of China's tax laws. The company's board will review the findings and provide advice on the appropriate course of action, including referring the matter to relevant authorities if necessary.

site_title: Clinton diagnosed with pneumonia, 'dehydrated' at 9/11 event
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has been diagnosed with pneumonia and was dehydrated after being helped into her vehicle at a 9/11 memorial ceremony in New York. The incident raised concerns about her health, offering a new opportunity for Donald Trump to attack her. Clinton had previously faced criticism for a campaign blunder when she referred to half of Trump's supporters as "a basket of deplorables." Her health concerns come as the presidential election heats up.

site_title: Juncker calls for better telecom roaming plan
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has withdrawn proposals to limit mobile phone roaming charges, citing criticism that the rules did not favor consumers. The original proposal would have restricted roaming for more than 90 days a year or 30 days in a row, but Juncker has ordered a revised version. The telecom industry, however, was unimpressed, calling the original proposal "painful." The EU will abolish roaming charges entirely by June 2017, but the revised plan is seen as a step back for consumers.

site_title: US tobacco firms fight cigarette tax hike
summary: US tobacco firms are spending millions to defeat a proposed $2.87 cigarette tax increase in California, which could generate $1-1.4 billion in revenue for cancer treatment and prevention. The industry has outspent supporters 2-to-1, with $35.6 million in donations so far, and has successfully blocked similar tax hikes in the past. If successful, the tax increase could deter anti-tobacco advocates in other states from pursuing similar changes.

images.alt_text: BLOWING SMOKE: Tobacco leaves being harvested; as the harmful health effects of smoking have come to light, the industry has for years fought regulators and public health advocates over curbing the practice.

site_title: 4th telco hopeful wants to be data-led firm
summary: AirYotta, a company backed by a single-purpose fund, aims to become Singapore's first data-led telco. It plans to roll out the Republic's first 4.5G Advanced Pro network, providing unparalleled data and connectivity to consumers. The company, helmed by former OMGTel executives, plans to be fully funded to establish a fully built-out 4.5G network, with a topology and architecture that will form an "important infrastructure prelude to 5G." The company's bid faces competition from MyRepublic and Australia-listed TPG Telecom.

site_title: Inspiration between the pages
summary: Business leaders share their favorite books that have inspired them, citing various titles such as "Sink, Float or Swim" by Scott Peltin, "The Act of Creation" by Arthur Koestler, and "Churchill: A Life" by Martin Gilbert. They emphasize the importance of creativity, leadership by example, and self-awareness in driving sustainable performance and success. Many leaders also highlight the value of historical and biographical books, such as "The Shallows" by Nicholas Carr and "A Champion's Mind" by Pete Sampras, in shaping their perspectives and approaches to business.

site_title: Britain faces free trade headache after Brexit vote
summary: Britain's desire to become a free trade leader after the Brexit vote is seen as wishful thinking by analysts, citing the country's lack of experience in negotiations and its current status within the EU. The UK's hands are tied until a formal exit, with Brussels and Berlin emphasizing the European Commission's responsibility for trade negotiations on behalf of all member states. The UK's position as a major world economy and future economic growth are at stake, with some experts warning that it will take years for Britain to conclude free trade agreements.

site_title: Zika cases hit 329 with eight pregnant women among the cases
summary: Singapore reported 11 new locally transmitted Zika cases, bringing the total to 329, including eight pregnant women. The new cases have no known links to existing clusters. The Ministry of Health and National Environment Agency issued a joint statement confirming the cases.

site_title: UK govt cancels plans to privatise Land Registry
summary: The UK government has cancelled plans to privatise the Land Registry, a public record of property ownership that has been in operation for over 150 years. The decision was made after a change in leadership at the ministry responsible for the registry. The registry, which holds data for 24 million property titles, had been expected to be sold as part of a £5 billion programme of sales. Opposition members and anti-corruption experts had opposed the privatisation, citing concerns about the impact on transparency and the potential for corruption.

site_title: Time for a two-tier driving licence scheme
summary: Singapore is considering a two-tier driving license scheme, similar to those for motorcycles, to reduce road accidents caused by young and inexperienced drivers. The proposed system would classify cars based on their performance specs, such as horsepower, to restrict access to high-powered vehicles for younger drivers. However, implementing the scheme poses challenges, including classifying "super cars" and ensuring that only responsible drivers are allowed to operate them. Experts suggest that stricter enforcement of bad road behavior and a focus on responsible driving habits may be a more effective solution.

site_title: UK fraud agency charges three in Tesco accounting probe
summary: The UK's Serious Fraud Office has charged three former Tesco executives with fraud related to a £250 million overstatement of the company's first-half profits in 2014. The overstatement was due to booking deals with suppliers too early. The charges follow the suspension of eight senior staff members in the months following the discovery.

site_title: Hollywood is dead, festivals more needed than ever: Kidman
summary: Nicole Kidman warns that Hollywood is facing new challenges with the rise of online streaming, and that film festivals are more crucial than ever to get films noticed. With the decline of cinemas and the proliferation of streaming, Kidman believes smaller films and non-studio productions need festivals to gain visibility. She notes that Hollywood's heyday is behind it, and the industry must adapt to the changing landscape. Kidman has launched several films at prominent festivals, highlighting the importance of these events in today's cinematic landscape.

site_title: Patchwork of state laws in US hinders 21st century remote notarisation
summary: US mortgage lenders and state lawmakers are pushing for 21st-century remote notarization, a practice that uses secure webcams to link borrowers and notary publics. Despite the financial industry's support, a patchwork of laws hinders adoption, with only two states, Virginia and Montana, expressly approving remote notarization. Quicken Loans, Fannie Mae, and Freddie Mac are among the big players advocating for digital notarization, citing cost savings and better fraud safeguards. However, many counties and local clerk offices still require in-person signings, and a nationwide legal infrastructure remains lacking.

site_title: Greek banks struggle to fill top posts
summary: Greek banks are struggling to fill top corporate positions due to strict eligibility conditions, capped salaries, and the risk of potential penalties. The National Bank of Greece and Piraeus Bank have extended their deadlines for CEO and board applications, respectively, as qualified candidates are hard to find. The country's bailout agreement requires banks to reconstitute their boards by end-July, with requirements including experience on international banking groups and disqualifying those with public sector or political affiliations. Capped salaries and limited pool of Greek expatriates are also deterring potential applicants.

site_title: Kerber on top with US Open triumph
summary: Angelique Kerber won the US Open, defeating 10th-seeded Karolina Pliskova 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, her second Grand Slam title of the year. The victory marked Kerber's rise to world number one, a spot she will officially hold on Monday. Kerber, 28, credited her determination and believing in her game for the win, while Pliskova praised Kerber's skill and acknowledged her own growth as a player.

site_title: Reagan shooter John Hinckley Jr released from rehabilitation in mental hospital
summary: John Hinckley Jr., the 61-year-old man who attempted to assassinate President Ronald Reagan in 1981, has been released from a DC mental hospital after being deemed no longer a danger to others. Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity and spent decades in rehabilitation. He will live with his 90-year-old mother in Williamsburg, Virginia, and faces the challenge of rebuilding his life outside the institution. The release has sparked mixed reactions, with some expressing concern for security and others citing Hinckley's stable condition.

site_title: How America's 911 emergency response system can be hacked
summary: Researchers at Ben Gurion University in Israel have found a way to disable the US 911 emergency system by launching a "telephony denial-of-service" (TDoS) attack against 911 call centers. The attack involves infecting mobile phones with malware that causes them to make repeated bogus 911 calls, clogging call-center queues and preventing legitimate callers from reaching operators. With just 6,000 infected smartphones in a state, the system can be disabled for an extended period, and 200,000 infected phones across the US can significantly disrupt 911 services nationwide.

site_title: Setting the right board culture
summary: Companies today must adhere to governance guidelines that reflect best corporate practices, including board composition and diversity. However, the Enron, Tyco, and Worldcom failures demonstrate that dysfunction within boards was the primary cause of failure, rather than a lack of governance structures or best practices. Effective board culture is crucial for a company's success, driven by motivation and guided by shared values. Members must be guided by ethics, conflict-of-interest policies, and clear terms of reference to ensure the company's benefit.

site_title: The Caribbean is running out of coconuts
summary: The Caribbean is facing a severe shortage of coconuts due to storms, droughts, and the Lethal Yellowing disease. Since 1994, Caribbean plantations have shrunk by 17%, and production has dropped by 60% in two decades. Rich-world consumers, such as Starbucks and Rihanna, are driving demand for coconut milk, water, and oil, with the coconut water market projected to reach $4 billion by 2019. As a result, Caribbean farmers are struggling to meet demand, and other countries like Indonesia, the Philippines, and India are increasing coconut production to meet the global demand.

site_title: Why I won't be transferring my CPF OA to the SA
summary: A writer shares their decision not to transfer their Ordinary Account (OA) funds to the Special Account (SA) in the Central Provident Fund (CPF) for retirement, citing the opportunity cost of locking up liquidity too early. The writer believes they can use the OA for property purchases and potentially benefit from a property market downturn. They compare the interest rates of the OA (2.5%) and SA (4%) and conclude that the benefits of transferring the OA to the SA do not outweigh the opportunity cost. Instead, they suggest contributing cash to the SA through the Retirement Sum Topping-up Scheme to build up their SA monies while still enjoying tax savings.

site_title: Polish towns hit as border restriction stems flow of shoppers
summary: Poland has suspended a local border traffic agreement allowing visa-free travel with Russia's Kaliningrad exclave, citing security concerns. The decision affects around 1 million Kaliningrad citizens who rely on trade with Poland for everyday goods. The suspension, which began on July 1, has led to a 30% decrease in traffic at the Grzechotki-Mamonovo crossing. The move is seen as a response to the worst tensions between Moscow and the West since the Cold War, with the Polish government keeping mum on the exact reasons for the restriction.

site_title: Traders betting on eurozone building stocks
summary: The European Central Bank's stimulus program has shown limited success, prompting speculation that region's governments will increase public spending to boost growth. This has led to a 20% rally in a construction index, reaching a nearly nine-year high, as traders bet on construction companies. Firms such as Vinci SA and HeidelbergCement AG have seen significant gains, with the index outperforming other Stoxx Europe 600 Index industries.

images.alt_text: MARKET GAINERS: "Those industries, companies that have an activity in infrastructure - for example building materials and industrial companies - will clearly benefit."

site_title: Male homemakers on the rise in Japan
summary: In Japan, the number of male homemakers is rising, with over 100,000 men in the national pension system's category III for a dependent spouse. This shift is attributed to unstable employment and wives' increased earning capabilities. Men, such as Takatoshi Miyauchi, who became full-time homemakers to support their families due to health issues and wives' careers, now feel proud and fulfilled in their roles. Experts say this change is a natural response to societal shifts, with men choosing to assist their families rather than conform to traditional masculine norms.

site_title: Private investors tout EU real estate as 'biggest spread anywhere'
summary: Private investors, including Cheyne Capital Management and Marathon Asset Management, are touting European real estate as a lucrative investment opportunity due to banks' reluctance to lend. European banks are shedding property-related nonperforming loans, creating opportunities for private lenders. Value-add loans up to $100 million are yielding interest rates of 10% plus fees, while Marathon Asset Management is buying nonperforming loans at a 50% discount and managing properties. The spread is seen as the "biggest anywhere in the world," with potential returns of 7-8% on hard assets with ultra-low financing rates.

site_title: From Ah Boys to MM2 Asia
summary: Melvin Ang, founder and CEO of MM2 Asia Ltd, shares his expansion plans for the Catalist-listed entertainment outfit. The company, which has operations in Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and China, has seen its stock triple in value over eight years. MM2 has made strategic acquisitions, including a 51% stake in Unusual Group, and plans to list the latter on Catalist by mid-2026. Ang aims to tap into China's lucrative market, where local films have bigger budgets and better margins. He also plans to establish "creative spaces" throughout the region to spot talent.

images.alt_text: SPOTTING TALENT: Mr Ang's got another pet project lined up - to build "touch points" of "creative spaces" throughout the region, starting with the home base in Singapore.

site_title: EU to multinationals: pay your fair share of taxes
summary: The European Union is urging multinationals to pay their fair share of taxes, following the "Panama Papers" revelations of widespread tax avoidance practices. EU finance ministers are discussing stricter rules and controls to combat tax dodging, with the European Commission investigating multinationals' tax arrangements. Companies such as Amazon and McDonald's face probes, while Starbucks has been ordered to pay back taxes to the Dutch state. The EU is also planning to set up a common corporate tax base and single European blacklist for tax havens to counter tax avoidance.

site_title: Blackstone CEO launches scholars programme in China
summary: Blackstone CEO Stephen Schwarzman has launched the Schwarzman Scholars, a one-year Master's degree programme at Tsinghua University in China, aiming to foster global stability and dialogue. The inaugural class of 110 students from over 30 countries, including 40% from the US and 20% from China, will immerse themselves in academics and cultural exchange. The programme, valued at $435 million, is backed by global companies and industrialists, with Schwarzman seeking to promote cross-border economic and trade relations.

site_title: US-wary Venezuela opens up to tourist dollars
summary: Venezuela has eased its currency restrictions, allowing tourists to pay hotel bills in US dollars with bank cards. The move aims to boost foreign currency earnings, as the country faces a severe economic crisis. However, analysts question the effectiveness of this measure, citing concerns about inflation, foreign currency shortages, and the country's significant overseas debt. The government controls the supply of US dollars, and the new scheme allows hotels to keep 40% of the dollars they receive, which they must then sell to the central bank.

images.alt_text: A cash crisis has forced Venezuela's socialist government to ease its currency restrictions by letting tourists pay their hotel bills in US dollars with bank cards.

site_title: Learning the hard rules of upscale dining
summary: SPRMRKT Kitchen & Bar, a Singaporean restaurant, has expanded to an upscale location above its casual sister restaurant. However, the new space struggles to find its footing, with jarring music, over-salted dishes, and a menu that attempts to blend various styles without a clear direction. Standout dishes include well-executed flat iron steak and Brussels sprouts, but the pricey Spanish octopus falls flat. Despite some promising moments, the restaurant is still learning the rules of upscale dining, with room for growth and improvement.

site_title: 121 sheep from Ireland meant for korban die mid-flight
summary: A flight carrying 121 sheep from Ireland to Singapore for the Hari Raya Haji celebration died mid-flight due to heat stress. The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority launched an investigation, finding no signs of infectious disease. The remaining sheep are healthy and suitable for consumption. Affected individuals will have the option to have their korban performed in Australia or receive a refund. This incident is not the first, as 174 sheep imported from Australia died mid-flight in 2014.

site_title: Directors step up buying and pull back on selling
summary: Directors in Singapore increased buying by 21 companies worth S$4.1 million from September 5-9, while selling decreased by 24 companies worth S$0.008 million. Buyback activity also declined to 60 repurchases worth S$17.4 million. This marks a decrease from the previous week's 42 purchases and 81 trades.

site_title: Aussie boost to recycling in S'pore
summary: Australian waste management company TIC Group has opened its first international marketing office in Singapore to boost recycling in Asia and the Middle East. The company manages over 15 million products from retailers across Australia and sources products from Europe, Asia, and the US. TIC sells unsold or defective products at a fraction of retail prices, with 50% of products collected in working condition. The Singapore office serves as a hub for traders from countries like Malaysia and Myanmar, and has opened up new business opportunities for TIC.

site_title: Yahoo Japan sought merger with Yahoo before Verizon deal
summary: Yahoo Japan proposed a merger of equals with Yahoo Inc, offering 50% ownership and $14 billion in cash, but was rejected due to lack of premium and tax implications. The proposal came from SoftBank Group Corp, which owns 43% of Yahoo Japan, and was part of a months-long sales effort. Verizon ultimately acquired Yahoo's core assets for $4.8 billion, beating out other bids, including those from AT&T and Quicken Loans. Yahoo's board found Verizon's proposal more favorable, and co-founder David Filo was restricted from backing a proposal.

site_title: Cash in a box catches on in Switzerland
summary: Switzerland is seeing an increase in companies taking out insurance policies to protect their cash hoards from theft or damage, amid negative interest rates. The Swiss National Bank's sub-zero rates, imposed in 2015, charge banks for excess deposits, with lenders passing on the burden to cash-rich clients. Insurance companies are reporting a surge in demand for coverage for sums ranging from $696 million to $500 million. Economists warn that the side effects of negative interest rates could outweigh benefits, and the central bank's rate review may see the rate remain steady.

site_title: Merkel under fire from coalition ally over refugee policy
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's open-door refugee policy is under fire from her coalition ally, Bavaria state premier Horst Seehofer, who has threatened to skip a key party congress unless she changes her stance. Seehofer claims Merkel's refusal to introduce upper limits on refugees will make the far-right Alternative for Germany stronger. Merkel has repeatedly refused to compromise, saying there can be no limits on refugees. This dispute could lead to a split in the conservative bloc and may impact the upcoming election. Seehofer's threat to skip the party congress is unprecedented.

site_title: Based in Ireland but enjoying US privileges
summary: US medical device maker Medtronic has shifted its headquarters to Ireland, saving the company over $3 billion in taxes and allowing it to fund an acquisition spree. The move, known as an "inversion," has raised concerns about tax avoidance and has been criticized as unpatriotic. Despite this, Medtronic still participates in US trade missions and holds government contracts, sparking debate about the benefits and drawbacks of such arrangements. The practice of US companies moving their headquarters overseas to lower their tax bills has become a contentious issue, with implications for the US corporate tax code and presidential campaign issues.

site_title: Would-be Reagan assassin released from psychiatric hospital
summary: John Hinckley Jr., the 61-year-old would-be assassin of US President Ronald Reagan, was released from a psychiatric hospital in Washington, 35 years after the attack. Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity in 1982 and diagnosed with depression and psychosis, which are now in remission. He will move in with his elderly mother in a gated community in Virginia, under the watchful eyes of the US Secret Service, after a federal judge deemed him no longer a danger to himself or others.

site_title: Thailand, Malaysia consider border wall to boost security
summary: Thailand and Malaysia agreed to boost security cooperation and consider building a border wall to combat transnational crime and smuggling. The move comes after a crackdown on human traffickers and separatist insurgents operating in Thailand's deep south, who often use Malaysia as a base. The two countries plan to step up intelligence gathering and sharing, and discuss the construction of a border wall, although details remain to be worked out. The proposal reflects a similar plan by US presidential candidate Donald Trump to build a wall on the US-Mexico border.

site_title: Business jet makers deepen discounts to fly out of turbulence
summary: Business jet makers such as Bombardier and Textron are offering deep discounts to attract buyers amid sluggish global growth, with discounts ranging from 5-15% on list prices. The discounts are driven by high inventory levels and a competitive market, with pre-owned jet sales adding to the glut. Deliveries are expected to drop 11% in 2016, the steepest percentage decline since 2009, and production cuts are slowly happening as demand remains weak.

site_title: Following protests, US halts North Dakota oil pipeline construction
summary: The US government has halted construction on the proposed $3.7 billion North Dakota oil pipeline, following protests by Native Americans. The decision was made after a federal judge rejected a request to block the project, prompting the Department of Justice to appeal for calm and suspend construction on federal land. The move reflects growing Native American activism and highlights the need for nationwide reform to consider tribal views on infrastructure projects.

site_title: Trump escalates attack on Clinton, defends Putin rhetoric
summary: Donald Trump escalated his attacks on Hillary Clinton, calling her "above the law" and suggesting she wouldn't face prosecution if she shot someone. Trump defended his comments on Vladimir Putin, saying they were "fine" and that he's "nice" to him. Trump also pushed back against Bill Clinton's claim that his "Make America Great Again" slogan is racist, showing video footage of Bill Clinton using the same phrase. The comments come after Trump's campaign has tried to temper his public comments, but the Florida rally showed a return to his more aggressive tone.

site_title: Taiwan prosecutors search home of former Mega Financial chief
summary: Taiwan's prosecutors searched the residence of former Mega Financial Holding chairman Mckinney Tsai, amid a government probe into the New York banking branch's US$180 million fine for lax risk exposure. Tsai, who was questioned and released on bail, is under suspicion and prohibited from traveling outside Taiwan. The search follows more than 20 people being questioned in the case, which also involves alleged violations in Panama. Prosecutors will review the evidence found.

site_title: Manhattan developer accused of US$1 million tax evasion
summary: Manhattan real estate developer Michael Shvo, 43, was charged with felony tax fraud and falsifying business records for allegedly evading over $1 million in state and local taxes on luxury art purchases. He used methods such as misusing resale certificates and setting up a limited liability company in Montana to register a Ferrari. Shvo pleaded not guilty and was released on $500,000 bail. This case marks the latest by state authorities to scrutinize art dealers and collectors for tax evasion, following similar cases involving Aby Rosen and Victoria Gelfand.

images.alt_text: THE SHVOS: Mr Shvo allegedly used several methods to avoid taxes. He's accused of fraudulently using a New York resale certificate to buy more than US$65,000 in jewellery for his wife Seren, and furniture for his office. The certificates are intended for dealers who buy items solely for resale and don't have to pay taxes.

site_title: China verifying more EV funding wrongdoing, automaker group says
summary: China is verifying information gathered during its investigation into electric vehicle (EV) subsidies to identify wrongdoing, widening the scope of the crackdown into the fast-growing industry. Five manufacturers, including Gemsea Coach, were identified for scamming the government of $150 million in subsidies. The investigation found instances of unsold vehicle claims, fabrication of sales and documentation, and other breaches of policies. The Chinese government aims to refine support policies, raise the qualification bar for EV manufacturers, and phase out subsidies to encourage industry development.

site_title: Football: Manchester braces as United and City collide
summary: Manchester United and Manchester City face off in a highly anticipated local derby at Old Trafford, with Jose Mourinho's United looking to stop Pep Guardiola's City from winning their third consecutive Premier League title. Both teams have started the season strongly, with United's recent improvement under Mourinho and City's dominance under Guardiola. The match is seen as crucial in the title race, with Mourinho believing that the points could be vital in the long run.

site_title: Japan, Russia seen deepening ties to counter China's influence
summary: Japan and Russia are strengthening ties to counterbalance China's growing influence in Northeast and Central Asia. This rapprochement is part of a broader geopolitical shift, as both nations seek to secure their interests in the region. Japan's investment in Russia's underdeveloped Far East region could also benefit Russia, further solidifying their partnership. The move is seen as a strategic response to China's expanding power projection, potentially altering the balance of power and alliances in the region.

site_title: Coal rises from grave to become one of hottest commodities
summary: Coal prices surge to near 18-month highs, driven by Chinese imports to compensate for lower domestic production and the potential impact of a La Nina weather pattern. European prices jumped 30% this year, while Australian benchmark contracts rose 40%. Analysts predict further gains, citing factors such as extreme weather and China's continued drive to curb pollution and boost imports. La Nina's potential to disrupt production and transport in major coal-producing countries, including Australia, Indonesia, and South Africa, also supports the price increase.

site_title: US Open champion Kerber turns dreams into reality
summary: Angelique Kerber won the US Open, becoming the new number one player in women's tennis. The 28-year-old German defeated Karolina Pliskova in a display of hard work, patience, and love for the game. Kerber's victory marks her second grand slam title this year, following her win at the Australian Open. She credits her improvement in fitness, being more aggressive, and mental toughness for her success, saying believing in herself and her dreams is key to achieving her goals.

site_title: US honours Sept 11 victims 15 years after attacks
summary: On the 15th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, Americans commemorated the victims with a ceremony at the 9/11 Memorial plaza in lower Manhattan, where the names of the 2,983 victims were read slowly. The ceremony included six moments of silence, tolling church bells, and a tribute in lights. Dignitaries, including Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, attended, paying tribute to the lives lost and the responders. The event marked a day of sadness and remembrance, with a sense of hope and unity.

images.alt_text: NOT FORGOTTEN: The names of the 2,983 victims were read slowly by relatives as classical music played during a ceremony at the 9/11 Memorial plaza.

site_title: SpaceX explosion occurred with engines off: Musk
summary: SpaceX's billionaire founder Elon Musk described the company's Falcon 9 explosion as its most perplexing failure in 14 years. The rocket exploded on its launchpad on September 1, 2016, destroying a satellite intended for Facebook to provide internet access in Africa. US investigators are investigating the cause of the blast, which has set back launches worldwide. Musk called the failure "most perplexing" and expressed his frustration with the incident, which has deepened the mystery surrounding the loss of the rocket.

site_title: Failed attempt at China-N Korea connection
summary: A major China-North Korea project, the New Yalu River Bridge, remains unfinished and abandoned, with no signs of infrastructure work on the North Korean side. The 2.2 billion yuan bridge, intended to boost investment in free trade zones, was launched in 2012 but has failed to materialize due to China's anger at North Korea's nuclear tests. The project's failure has had a negative impact on the local economy, with empty apartment complexes and shopping malls in the Dandong New Zone. The bridge's closure has also hindered trade between China and North Korea, with bilateral trade limited to just 17.7 billion yuan between January and July.

site_title: Apple tapping brakes on self-driving cars: report
summary: Apple has reportedly closed parts of its self-driving car project, project Titan, and laid off dozens of workers as part of a "reboot." The Silicon Valley-based company had invested heavily in the project, but faced challenges in differentiating itself from competitors. Apple's decision comes as other companies, including Tesla, Google, and Uber, continue to invest in autonomous vehicle technology. The company had also made a $1 billion investment in Chinese ride-sharing company Didi Chuxing earlier this year.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit one-week low after Wall Street drops; TSMC drags
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell to a one-week low after a global decline, with the main Taiex index dropping 1.3% to 9,042.20 points. TSMC, a key supplier to Apple, dropped 1% after announcing its August sales results. The decline was driven by overnight losses on Wall Street, triggered by comments from Federal Reserve officials and weak German trade data. The Taiwan dollar also softened to NT$31.542 per US dollar.

site_title: Slumping US meat prices help feed appetite for jerky
summary: US meat prices have declined, benefiting the growth of the jerky market. With lower costs, meat processors are increasing production and marketing of jerky products, which have become a popular choice for consumers seeking protein-rich snacks with fewer calories and less sugar. US jerky sales have risen 14% since 2012, reaching $1.5 billion, and the industry is expanding with new brands and products, including those with exotic meats and healthier ingredients.

site_title: China eyes closer military ties with Myanmar
summary: China's military is seeking to strengthen ties with Myanmar, with Vice Chairman Xu Qiliang stating that China "highly values the friendly cooperation between the two countries" and supports Myanmar's national reconciliation process. China wants to enhance cooperation on the border and maintain peace and stability. The country has been pushing Myanmar to resume work on the $3.6-billion Myitsone dam project, which was suspended due to environmental protests. China and Myanmar's leader Aung San Suu Kyi reached a consensus on furthering strategic cooperation during her recent visit to China.

site_title: US oil drillers add rigs in longest streak in 5 years: Baker Hughes
summary: US oil drillers added 7 rigs for the 10th week in 11, bringing the total to 414, the highest level since February. This marks the longest streak of rig additions since 2011. The increase is attributed to rising oil prices, which have reached above $46 a barrel, making drilling more viable. Drillers expect slow rig growth, but analysts predict an increase in production as prices rise, with estimates suggesting a 3,000-18,000 barrels per day boost in the Permian basin.

site_title: France ponders ripping up EU budget rules
summary: France is considering revising the 3% cap on government deficits, a eurozone rule seen as a constraint on governments' ability to stimulate their economies. The requirement, which aims to maintain eurozone stability, is viewed by many as overly restrictive. France's presidential election is set for next year, and the move to revise the rule could be a key campaign promise. The potential change could have significant implications for the European economy and the future of the eurozone.

site_title: UK fraud agency charges three in Tesco accounting probe
summary: Britain's Serious Fraud Office has charged three former Tesco executives with fraud in a probe into accounting practices. The charges relate to a £250 million overstatement of Tesco's first-half profits in 2014 due to early booking deals with suppliers. The overstatement occurred in August 2014, leading to the suspension of eight senior staff members. The charges mark a significant development in the investigation into Tesco's accounting practices.

site_title: GM recalls 4.3 million cars, trucks over airbag fault
summary: General Motors issued a recall notice for 4.3 million cars and trucks worldwide due to a faulty airbag system that could prevent deployment in an accident. The issue was discovered after a 2014 Silverado truck's airbag and tensioners failed to activate in a crash. The affected vehicles include models from Buick, Chevrolet, GMC, and Cadillac from 2014-2017. The recall covers 3.6 million US vehicles and 640,000 sold internationally. GM will replace the faulty airbag sensing and diagnostic module software to ensure proper airbag deployment.

site_title: Yahoo Japan sought merger with Yahoo before Verizon's purchase
summary: Yahoo Japan Corp proposed a merger of equals with Yahoo! Inc in February 2016, offering 50% of the combined entity and $14 billion in cash. However, the deal was rejected due to lack of premium and tax implications. After a months-long process, Verizon Communications Inc acquired Yahoo's core assets for over $4.8 billion in July 2016, excluding intellectual property to be sold separately. Yahoo will retain stakes in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan.

site_title: Dutch police closes probe into fatal Tesla crash
summary: Dutch police closed an investigation into a fatal Tesla crash, accepting the US electric car firm's findings that the driver, who was killed, was in control of the car at the time of the accident. The Tesla Model S sedan was traveling at 155 km/h when it crashed into a tree near Baarn, Netherlands. The police did not dispute Tesla's claims that the auto-pilot system was not activated. As a result, prosecutors indicated there would be no criminal probe, and the police will not investigate further.

site_title: Asian nations plan fund to better prepare for health emergencies, says WHO
summary: Eleven South and East Asian countries have agreed to establish an emergency fund to strengthen their health services and prepare for outbreaks of diseases such as Zika, Sars, and pandemic influenza. The fund aims to enhance preparedness by investing in infrastructure and human resources. The countries, including India, Indonesia, and Thailand, have agreed to increase the number of health workers and provide them with training and better conditions. This move is seen as crucial to prevent outbreaks from becoming crises, with experts citing the Ebola crisis in West Africa as an example.

site_title: US Marshals Service detains oil vessel in Philadelphia port
summary: The US Marshals Service has detained an oil vessel, the Advantage Avenue, in Philadelphia's port until a civil dispute is resolved. The vessel, chartered by Royal Dutch Shell, was carrying up to 600,000 barrels of crude oil. The dispute involves a payment disagreement between PSARA Energy and the vessel's owners. The vessel will be allowed to discharge its cargo but will remain in port until the dispute is resolved.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping gets US court order, cash to unload ships
summary: A US judge has granted Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd provisional protection from creditors, allowing four vessels to dock and unload at US ports. The company, the world's seventh-largest container carrier, filed for receivership in a Seoul court last week. Hanjin has authorized at least $10 million to service the four ships, and cargo owners can make arrangements to retrieve goods stranded in warehouses. The move aims to prevent creditors from seizing Hanjin ships or property and to allow cargo to be unloaded ahead of the year-end holiday season.

site_title: Facebook backs off censoring 'napalm girl' photo
summary: Facebook has reversed its decision to censor a historic Vietnam War photo of a naked girl escaping a napalm bombing, after widespread outrage and criticism. The photo, taken by Nick Ut Cong Huynh in 1972, was initially blocked for violating Facebook's standards regarding inappropriate posts. However, Facebook acknowledged the image's historical significance and importance, and has reinstated it. The move comes after Norwegian Prime Minister Erna Solberg defied Facebook's initial block, and sparked a debate about freedom of expression and the role of social media in shaping history.

site_title: Oil tumbles most in month as US supply plunge seen as one-off
summary: Oil prices plummeted 3.7% in New York, the largest decline in over a month, after the US stockpile slump was attributed to a one-off disruption caused by Tropical Storm Hermine. The largest decline in 17 years was 14.5 million barrels, with imports falling 21% due to the storm. This setback was seen as a temporary event, with oil prices expected to retrace yesterday's losses.

site_title: US dollar jumps as rising September Fed-hike odds burn rand to real
summary: The US dollar surged for a third consecutive day, jumping 0.5% in the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, as traders increased bets on a Federal Reserve interest-rate hike in September. Emerging market currencies, including the South African rand and Brazilian real, plummeted, while commodity prices halted their four-day rally. The US dollar has almost erased its weekly loss, with the probability of a Fed hike rising to 30% this month and 58% by year-end. The Fed's decision to raise interest rates is seen as a response to concerns about overheating the US economy.

site_title: Gold investors brace for lower prices on interest-rate outlook
summary: Gold prices are expected to drop due to interest rate hikes, with the US Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren warning that waiting too long to raise interest rates risks overheating the economy. This has led to increased trading of put options, with over 2,500 lots exchanged on Friday. Gold futures for December delivery fell 0.5% to $1,334.50 an ounce, marking the third straight loss. Investors are taking protective measures, with holdings in gold-backed ETFs falling for a second day.

site_title: PwC review of SBI Offshore's deals casts spotlight on 2 ex-CEOs
summary: SBI Offshore has called a trading halt pending an announcement following a report by The Business Times on a board tussle between its founder and CEO. A review by Pricewaterhouse Coopers (PwC) has found two sets of conflicting agreements on the purchase and sale of a China-incorporated company, raising concerns of breaches in securities and tax laws. The company's founder, Tan Woo Thian, is seeking an extraordinary general meeting to remove CEO Chan Lai Thong and appoint new directors, including Hui Choon Ho, a major shareholder.

site_title: Paralympics: Gold and a new world record for Yip Pin Xiu
summary: Singapore para-swimmer Yip Pin Xiu broke the world record to win gold in the 100m backstroke S2 event at the Rio Paralympics, marking the country's first medal at the Games. Yip, competing against six swimmers, achieved a new world record time in the event. This historic achievement marks a significant milestone for Singapore's Paralympic team.

images.alt_text: Singapore para-swimmer Yip Pin Xiu broke the world record to win gold in the 100m backstroke S2 event on Saturday (Sept 10) morning (Singapore time).

site_title: US, Russia clinch Syria deal, aim for truce from Monday
summary: The US and Russia have reached a deal to implement a nationwide ceasefire in Syria, effective from Monday, along with improved aid access and joint targeting of banned militant groups. The agreement includes a halt to aerial bombardments and attempts to gain territory, and both sides will work together to develop military strikes against Nusra and Islamic State. The deal marks a breakthrough in the peace process, which has been stalled for a long time, and is seen as a step towards ending the catastrophic conflict in Syria.

images.alt_text: The United States and Russia hailed a breakthrough deal on Saturday to put Syria's peace process back on track, including a nationwide ceasefire effective from sundown on Monday, improved aid access and joint targeting of banned militant Islamist groups.

site_title: Asia's oldest stock exchange BSE files for long-awaited IPO
summary: BSE Ltd, Asia's oldest stock exchange, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) seeking to list its shares on the National Stock Exchange (NSE). The IPO, valued at approximately US$150 million, will see shareholders including Singapore Exchange sell up to 29.96 million shares, representing a 27.9% stake. The offering aims to raise funds for long-time investors, who are looking to cash out.

site_title: Indian acid attack survivor wows New York runway
summary: Reshma Qureshi, an Indian acid attack survivor, walked the New York catwalk during New York Fashion Week, defying her physical scars and inspiring others. At 19, she wore a stunning gown to promote her campaign to end the open sale of acid in India. Qureshi's participation aimed to challenge industry stereotypes of beauty and send a powerful message to other survivors, who often face ostracism and social scars. Her confidence and determination have changed her life, and she hopes to finish high school and attend college.

site_title: US: Wall St drops amid worries over North Korea test, rate outlook
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with the S&P 500 experiencing its worst day since June, amid concerns over North Korea's nuclear test and the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 2.13% and the S&P 500 lost 2.45% as investor nervousness increased. The Fed's comments lifted rate hike bets, with the perceived chances of a September rate hike rising to 24%. Traditionally, September is a month of lower returns for stocks, and traders said the recent uncertainties could mark the start of a pullback.

site_title: Top airlines globally ban use of Samsung's fire-prone phones
summary: Top airlines globally, including American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and United Airlines, have banned the use of Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones due to faulty batteries that can catch fire. The US Federal Aviation Administration advises travellers not to charge or turn on the devices in flight. The ban follows a recall of the Note 7 in 10 markets, including the US, and a report by the FAA citing at least 171 incidents of battery-related issues since 1991. Shares of Samsung fell 3.9% after the advisory.

site_title: Wholesale inventories unchanged in July
summary: US wholesale inventories remained unchanged in July, as previously reported, with sales falling 0.4% after a 1.7% increase in June. This suggests limited economic growth boost from restocking in the third quarter. Inventories excluding autos were also unchanged, while inventory investment subtracted 1.3 percentage points from GDP growth in the second quarter, the largest drag in over two years. Some economists expect restocking to drive a rebound in GDP growth in the third quarter, with the Atlanta Federal Reserve forecasting a 3.5% rate.

site_title: Obama in diplomatic jam as House sends him Saudi 9/11 bill
summary: The US House of Representatives has unanimously passed a bill allowing families of 9/11 victims to sue Saudi Arabia, despite President Barack Obama's likely veto. The legislation would carve out an exception to sovereign immunity, allowing plaintiffs to sue Saudi Arabia for alleged state-sponsored terrorism. The move is expected to strain relations with Saudi Arabia, which has denied culpability in the 9/11 attacks. The bill's passage could lead to a veto override, potentially impacting Obama's influence with Congress and the US-Saudi relationship, which has already grown increasingly strained.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rocked by return of volatility after summer lull
summary: European stocks plummeted 1.1% on Friday, the largest one-day fall since August, amid concerns over the European Central Bank's lack of action on economic stimulus and US Federal Reserve official Eric Rosengren's comments on potential rate hikes. The dollar rose, and German 10-year bond yields surged above zero. Retail and healthcare stocks fell, while mining shares rose. The Stoxx 600 index ended the week down 1.4% and hit an eight-month high just a week earlier.

site_title: Indonesia evaluating mining rules as deadline on metal exports nears
summary: Indonesia's mining ministry is racing against time to resolve a regulatory deadline that could impact copper and other metal exports. The 2014 regulation restricts mineral exports to partially processed minerals until January 2017, after which only refined metals can be exported. US-based Freeport-McMoRan Inc and other miners are at risk of not meeting the deadline. The ministry is exploring alternative solutions to find a way around the restriction, which could have significant economic implications for the country's mining industry.

site_title: Pence said ready to release tax returns, as Trump withholds
summary: Republican vice-presidential nominee Mike Pence plans to release his tax returns, which may pressure Donald Trump to do the same. Trump has said he will release his taxes once an audit is complete, while Pence aims to release his returns this week. Democrats, led by Hillary Clinton, have criticized Trump's withholding of his returns, calling for transparency about his businesses and tax rate. Pence's move is seen as part of a more traditional campaign style, contrasting with Trump's decision to hold back.

site_title: Paris unveils pre-election income tax cut of 1b euros
summary: The French government has unveiled a 1 billion euro income tax cut in its 2017 budget, benefiting over 5 million households with an average gain of 200 euros. This move aims to ease the economic burden ahead of the 2017 presidential election. The cut brings total income tax reductions since 2014 to 6 billion euros. The government plans to cut the public deficit to less than 3% of economic output next year, but has not disclosed how it will finance the tax cut.

site_title: Fund managers get EM bonds warning
summary: Investors in emerging-market corporate bonds are facing warnings of a correction as yields rise and default rates climb. Despite a 12.4% return this quarter, Societe Generale and Bank of America predict a correction due to complacency and deteriorating economic fundamentals. The market value of high-yield emerging-market corporate bonds has surged 30% to $260 billion, with 33% of issuers in developing countries on negative outlook. Analysts warn that investors should be more selective and cautious amid a 40% increase in maturing debt and economic surprises.

site_title: At global summits, the action is behind the scenes too
summary: World leaders attending international summits often engage in behind-the-scenes discussions and informal meetings, revealing the complexities of international diplomacy. At the G-20 Summit in China and the Asean Summit in Laos, leaders such as US President Barack Obama, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, and Russian President Vladimir Putin engaged in bilateral meetings and impromptu talks. These meetings, sometimes marked by humorous moments like Putin's gift of Russian ice cream to Chinese President Xi Jinping, provide insight into the often-tricky world of international protocol.

site_title: Hypercars from Bugatti, Aston Martin to debut in S'pore
summary: Aston Martin and Bugatti will debut their hypercars, the AM-RB 001 and Bugatti Chiron, in Singapore next week, ahead of the Formula One weekend. The Bugatti Chiron, priced at S$3.67 million, will be the first time the car is showcased in Asia, while the AM-RB 001, priced at S$3.34 million, will have a limited production of 150 units. The launch has been highly anticipated, with strong demand for niche limited edition collectors' cars, and is seen as a way to attract ultra-wealthy buyers despite a slumping economy.

site_title: US crude imports likely to surge after storm-related slowdown
summary: US crude imports likely to surge after a 21% decline in the week ended Sept 2, the largest drop since 2012. The decline was due to Tropical Storm Hermine disrupting shipping and output in the Gulf of Mexico. Crude inventories fell 14.5 million barrels, the largest drop since 1999, but remain at their highest seasonal level in over 20 years. Analysts expect a surge in imports in the coming weeks, with Bill O'Grady predicting a significant increase.

site_title: Well heeled
summary: A new range of comfortable heels is gaining popularity, offering a compromise for those who still want to wear high heels without sacrificing comfort. Brands like Miu Miu and Manolo Blahnik are introducing cork-platform sneakers and other styles that allow high heel enthusiasts to wear fashionable footwear without sacrificing comfort. Despite this, Manolo Blahnik remains skeptical, stating that sneakers will never replace traditional high heels. The trend is seen as a compromise for those who want to prioritize style and comfort, but still want to indulge in high-heeled fashion.

site_title: Tattoo parlours, e-cigarette shops take up UK's vacant retail space
summary: In the UK, vacant retail spaces are being filled by tattoo parlours and e-cigarette shops, with 1 in 10 retail sites unoccupied in town centres. The number of tattoo parlours has increased by 79% over six years to 2,288, while vape shops have quadrupled to 1,783. Analysts predict this trend may be short-lived due to the UK's economic uncertainty and changing consumer behavior. Landlords are offering incentives to fill vacant spaces, but experts warn that these businesses may not be sustainable in the long term.

site_title: First-timers lead the charge
summary: Four first-time head chefs in Singapore are opening new eateries, offering unique dining experiences. Khaled Elelimi's Pistachio Middle Eastern and Mediterranean Grill serves healthier versions of Middle-Eastern dishes, while Hunter Moyes' Fat Prince offers 10 different kebab options inspired by various Middle-Eastern regions. Chef Charles Yoshida's Ash and Char is an Asian-inspired small plates gastrobar with a focus on grilling and smokiness.
