Local chef Jonathan Ong's SPRMRKT Kitchen & Bar offers "New American" cuisine with globally influenced dishes.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific narrows Q1 losses with restructuring savings
summary: Del Monte Pacific narrowed its Q1 losses to US$8.7 million, down from US$10.7 million the previous year, thanks to restructuring savings. Revenue declined 2.8% to US$465.5 million, primarily due to lower non-branded sales in the US. The group's US subsidiary, Del Monte Foods Inc, recorded a 6.1% year-on-year decline in sales. Del Monte expects to be profitable for FY2017 through cost optimization and procurement synergies, generating annual savings of over US$9 million.

site_title: Diesel dynamo
summary: The new Porsche Panamera 4S Diesel is the world's fastest diesel sedan, boasting a 0-100km/h time of 4.3 seconds with all-wheel drive. Powered by a 3.956cc V8 turbodiesel, it produces 422 horsepower and 850 Nm of torque, making it a fuel-sipping yet powerful vehicle. Despite its diesel engine, the Panamera 4S Diesel is surprisingly quiet and has a sporty feel, thanks to its eight-speed dual-clutch transmission and rear-axle steering system.

images.alt_text: MORE THAN MEETS THE EYE: This is the first time the Panamera 4S Diesel is being offered with all-wheel-drive, which mates its V8 turbodiesel to a new eight-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission.
MORE THAN MEETS THE EYE: This is the first time the Panamera 4S Diesel is being offered with all-wheel-drive, which mates its V8 turbodiesel to a new eight-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission.

site_title: Rivals Mourinho and Guardiola lock horns again
summary: The English Premier League's Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City is set to be an explosive match, with both teams eager to protect their perfect start to the season. The match, featuring some of the world's most decorated managers and lavishly assembled squads, will be the most expensive in the sport with a £670 million worth of talent on display. Manchester United's Jose Mourinho and Manchester City's Pep Guardiola will renew their fierce rivalry, with Mourinho looking to gain a psychological advantage in their 17th game in Manchester.

site_title: Rebooting Acer
summary: Acer CEO Jason Chen is leading a turnaround effort to transform the company into a multi-dimensional technology company. With 80% of revenue coming from the PC industry, which is declining, Chen is focusing on building multiple business engines to cushion each other when the industry goes up and down. He's exploring new areas like the long-term care industry, virtual reality, and sports technology. Acer has acquired a stake in US tablet maker grandPad Inc and partnered with Comfort Keepers to offer senior care services. Chen also plans to launch a biking computer and a social website for sports enthusiasts. Acer is focusing on commercial use of virtual reality, partnering with game developers and movie companies to provide location-based entertainment. Chen aims to create a new business model that combines hardware, software, and services, rather than just manufacturing and selling devices.

images.alt_text: 'Years ago, when Wistron was spun out of Acer, the entire R&D team went along with it and Acer did not have any R&D. We have worked on that and last year, we filed more than 400 patents to the level that competitors came to us asking to license our technology. This has given us confidence that we are doing right.'

site_title: Spike in trading of Ezra shares prompts SGX query (Amended)
summary: A spike in trading volumes for Ezra Holdings' shares led to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) triggering a trading query. The offshore marine group stated that its board of directors is discussing possible transactions, including fund-raising via new loans, issuing new securities, or refinancing existing loans. The company's shares rose to the top of the volumes chart on Friday, prompting the SGX inquiry.

site_title: UN threatens fresh sanctions on North Korea after nuclear test
summary: The UN Security Council has condemned North Korea's fifth nuclear test, calling it a "clear threat to international peace and security". The council will discuss new "significant measures" against Pyongyang, with US President Barack Obama and South Korean President Park Geun Hye expressing strong opposition to North Korea's actions. China, North Korea's largest trading partner, has called for Pyongyang to curb its nuclear plans, but may tighten sanctions. The test has heightened tensions in the region, with the US and China disagreeing on how to address North Korea's nuclear ambitions.

site_title: North Korea nuclear blast hits stocks
summary: North Korea's nuclear test on Friday led to a decline in emerging market (EM) stocks, particularly in Asia, as investors sought safety in European markets. The European Central Bank's decision not to provide further stimulus also dampened EM stocks. The test, which was more powerful than the Hiroshima bomb, raised concerns about global security and economic instability. As a result, Asian garment industry and other sectors are expected to face higher US tariffs, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler's rising US star in hot water
summary: Reid Bigland, head of US sales and CEO of Fiat Chrysler Canada, is at the center of a US criminal and regulatory investigation into whether the company fraudulently hyped its monthly sales numbers. The probe, which began in July, has implications for the US car industry's way of reporting sales, and may lead to changes in how companies report sales. Bigland's signature is on documents containing disputed sales figures, and federal investigators are examining whether documents were falsified and if company officials knew what they were signing.

site_title: EU risks trade impotence as critics target Canada deal
summary: The EU's Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with Canada is facing growing public backlash against free trade and globalization, threatening its future. Critics blame the deal for factory closures and widening income gaps, echoing the sentiment behind Britain's "Brexit" vote. EU supporters argue CETA is a modern trade deal that boosts the EU economy by 12 billion euros. The deal, which eliminates tariffs on almost 99% of goods, is set to be approved by EU member states next month but may face significant delays or even rejection.

site_title: Zika set to take centre stage in parliament on Tuesday
summary: The Singapore parliament will discuss the Zika outbreak on Tuesday, with two ministerial statements and 13 written questions from MPs. They inquired about setting up a National Zika Registry, free screening, and support for pregnant women. The MPs also asked about vector control measures, economic impact, and government assistance for businesses affected by the outbreak. Additionally, the opposition MP Sylvia Lim will ask the Prime Minister about SGX's performance and reputation.

site_title: Postal Savings Bank of China seeks US$8.2b in HK IPO
summary: Postal Savings Bank of China (PSBC) plans to raise up to $8.2 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO), selling 12.2 billion shares at an indicative range of HK$4.68 to HK$5.18 each. The company has lined up five cornerstone investors, including China State Shipbuilding, Shanghai International Port Group, and HNA Group, which will buy nearly 75% of the shares. Overseas fund managers remain cautious over valuations, despite PSBC's low non-performing loans compared to peers.

site_title: Ascendas Reit buys two Australian properties for A$168m
summary: Ascendas Reit has acquired a business park in Sydney for A$143.4 million and a logistics property in Melbourne for A$24.8 million, expanding its Australian portfolio. The acquisitions are part of the Reit's plans to diversify its portfolio and generate stable cash flows. The initial net property income yield for both properties is expected to be about 6.5% post-transaction costs. The deals are expected to add 0.017 cents to its FY15/16 actual distribution per unit.

site_title: EU orders rethink of mobile 'free roaming' plan
summary: EU Commission head Jean-Claude Juncker has ordered officials to redraw plans for the EU's free mobile phone roaming policy after consumer groups criticized the 90-day limit. The original plan, unveiled last year, was met with outrage, as groups felt the limit was too restrictive. The Commission claims the review is about "modalities" and not the objective, but consumer groups remain skeptical. The EU aims to end roaming charges by June 2017, but the decision may be seen as embarrassing for Juncker, who is set to deliver his State of the Union address next week.

site_title: China SWF eyes Asian hedge funds
summary: China's $814 billion sovereign wealth fund (SWF) may increase investments in Asian hedge funds, betting they can outperform rivals in developed markets. Asian hedge funds have consistently outperformed global funds from 2012 to 2015, returning 9.5% annually against 5.7%. The fund's managing director, Roslyn Zhang, said the quality of talent in Asia has improved, increasing the chances of top managers producing alpha in the region.

site_title: Fine cracks found on 11 Sengkang-Punggol LRT trains
summary: Fine cracks have been found on 11 Sengkang-Punggol LRT trains in Singapore, but they do not compromise the trains' ability to bear weight, according to the Land Transport Authority and SBS Transit.

site_title: Coal resurrects to become one of the hottest commodities
summary: Coal prices have surged to near an 18-month high, with European prices jumping due to increased Chinese imports and lower domestic production. The market is also looking to La Nina weather patterns later this year, which could further boost prices if extreme weather hits major producers. Analysts predict potential price increases of up to 18-27% in Europe, with some experts warning that the impact of La Nina may be overstated. Despite this, coal has the potential for further gains, driven by global demand and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Holland V's Cold Storage space sold
summary: The owner of Rio Casino in Macau, Loi Keong Kuong, and his family have bought the ground-floor space leased to Cold Storage at Holland Road Shopping Centre for S$61 million, or S$4,976 psf. The space comprises seven strata units, all leased to Cold Storage until 2020. The sale price is significantly lower than the initial valuation of S$92 million in 2014, reflecting a more subdued retail sales market. The buyer gains immediate security of tenancy, with potential to rent out the units individually or partition the space for higher yields.

site_title: Pride and joy
summary: A modern tropical house in Singapore's Tanjong Katong area was designed by Aamer Taher of Aamer Architects for Michael Soo, managing director of Aquatech Products & Services. The 9,000 sq ft house features a unique layout, with a raised first storey and clever placement of skylights, providing a spacious feel. The home includes a steam room, gym, entertainment area, and a saltwater lap pool with a glass bottom. The design incorporates eco-friendly features, such as vertical bamboo screens and a natural palette of materials, making it a showcase of cutting-edge work.

site_title: Cross-border tie-ups
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore is hosting various cross-cultural collaborations and exhibitions, showcasing local artists and designers. British autistic artist Stephen Wiltshire's helicopter-observed cityscapes are on display at the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Singapore City Gallery, while Swiss expatriate Isabella Eckart's Singapore-centric posters and prints are available at her Eck&Art Design Studio. The Metro Meets Japan event brings Japanese products and lifestyle items to Metro Centrepoint, with sake tastings and workshops. The Supermama Porcelain Festival features Japanese ceramics and works by Singaporean and Asian ceramic artists, while Marou & Co Chocolates offers artisanal chocolates inspired by the National Gallery Singapore's architecture.

site_title: Regulations gnawing at corporate profits
summary: A Credit Suisse report suggests that Singapore's regulatory changes may have negatively impacted corporate profitability, leading to a potential slowdown in GDP growth to 1.1% in 2017. Rising labour costs and falling corporate margins are cited as key concerns, highlighting the need for the country's productivity drive to accelerate.

site_title: Make a Statement of Support to uphold & advance standards
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is holding the 7th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2016, with the theme "Change and Innovation in Governance", from September 26-30, 2016. The week-long program includes a Statement of Support by 48 companies to uphold and advance good corporate governance standards. Key supporters include The Association of Banks Singapore, the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, and the Singapore Exchange. Corporate leaders emphasize the importance of good governance in enhancing shareholder value, mitigating risks, and promoting sustainable growth.

site_title: A Mercedes as parking space locator
summary: Bosch and Mercedes-Benz have teamed up to launch a pilot project for community-based parking in Stuttgart, Germany, using ultrasonic sensors integrated into vehicles. The system, called a "parking spot locator," allows cars looking for a space to communicate with cars already parked, simplifying the search for kerbside parking. This innovative approach aims to reduce congestion and make parking easier for drivers.

site_title: Zika and the carrier connection
summary: The Zika virus has reached Singapore, with the first locally transmitted case diagnosed on August 27, 2016. The mosquito Aedes is the primary vector, carrying the virus alongside Dengue and Chikungunya. The mosquito's habitat destruction is crucial in preventing the spread of the virus, particularly for pregnant women. The virus is likely to have arrived on Singapore's shores before the first diagnosed case, and the three mosquito species (Aedes, Anopheles, and Culex) carry different diseases.

site_title: Toronto film fest opens with Western remake
summary: The Toronto film festival opened with a Western remake of The Magnificent Seven, starring Denzel Washington. The remake features a diverse cast, including Washington, and is part of the festival, which runs through September 18. As the largest film festival in North America, it attracts numerous filmmakers and actors, including Oscar-conscious studios and distributors. The festival aims to provide a platform for new and innovative storytelling.

images.alt_text: MOTLEY CREW: Washington (centre) with the cast of The Magnificent Seven.

site_title: US tech firms adding lobby strength as EU gets tough
summary: US tech firms, including Google and Facebook, are increasing lobbying efforts in Brussels as the European Commission introduces new business regulation. Google's lobbying budget has surged by 15-20% compared to the previous year, reaching 4.25-4.50 million euros in 2015. Facebook spends less, with a budget of 700,000-800,000 euros, but is expanding its team. This increase in lobbying follows a more confrontational approach by EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager since her arrival in 2014.

images.alt_text: STRONG PRESENCE: Google's spending surge has come since Ms Vestager's arrival in 2014 brought what many competition specialists see as a more confrontational approach from the commission.

site_title: When smartphone becomes a TV
summary: A portable DVB-T/T2 receiver, AVerTV Mobile 510, allows Android users to receive free-to-air broadcasts on their smartphones or tablets. The device connects to the phone via a micro-USB port and comes with two antennas, one for better outdoor reception and a high-gain antenna for stronger signals indoors. The app is basic, and reception varies depending on location, with signal breaks occurring despite a full signal bar. The device is priced at S$70 and is best used with headphones for better audio.

site_title: Murmurs of early GE as Najib rallies party
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak is reportedly considering an early general election, potentially as soon as March 2017, amid opposition disunity and turmoil over a funding scandal. Najib has been weathering criticism over alleged embezzlement from state investment company 1MDB, and an early election could help him gain a new mandate to implement economic reforms. The opposition's fractured state and weakening growth also make it a potentially favorable time for Najib to hold the vote. Analysts say an early election could be beneficial for Najib, but others argue it may not be the best time due to economic challenges.

site_title: Fastest Flying Spur
summary: The Bentley Flying Spur W12 S is set to arrive in the second quarter of 2017, boasting a top speed above 200 mph. The car features a 6.0-litre twin-turbo W12 engine, producing 635 hp and 820 Nm, an increase from the previous 625 hp and 800 Nm. The W12 S has more oomph and dark styling cues, hinting at improved dynamic abilities. This marks the first four-door Bentley with a top speed above 200 mph, solidifying its position as a luxurious and high-performance vehicle.

site_title: Philippine leader's insults, drug war worry US investors
summary: US investors in the Philippines warned that President Rodrigo Duterte's brutal drugs war and insults, including a derogatory remark towards US President Barack Obama, could harm foreign investment. The US is the Philippines' largest trading partner, and investors are concerned about the impact on the rule of law. Duterte's domestic popularity has soared due to the war, but international condemnation and US investor sentiment have been strained. The American Chamber of Commerce stated that the increased killings during the anti-drug campaign is harming the country's image and reducing investor optimism.

site_title: Manhattan's peak season for leasing favours renters
summary: Manhattan's peak apartment-leasing season ended in August with no rent growth for landlords, despite a 40% jump in listings. The median monthly rent was $3,399, down $1 from last year, due to increased competition from new, high-end buildings. To attract tenants, landlords are offering more concessions, with 19% of new leases in August including incentives such as free rent or broker fees. This season's slow start is expected to continue, with landlords facing a "cat-and-mouse game" with tenants over the coming months.

site_title: FHT acquires Novotel Melbourne for A$237m
summary: FRASERS Hospitality Trust (FHT) has acquired Novotel Melbourne for A$237 million. The deal will be funded through a 32-for-100 underwritten rights issue, raising S$266.3 million. The acquisition strengthens FHT's balance sheet and increases financial flexibility, with the hotel's prime location in Melbourne's CBD enhancing income diversification and mitigating yield dilution. The rights issue is expected to pare gearing down to 34.1% and raise free float to S$536.5 million.

site_title: Multitask with this selfie stick
summary: DJI has released the Osmo Mobile, a handheld gimbal that allows smartphone users to capture smooth, professional-looking footage on shaky terrain. The device, priced at $445, features a three-axis gimbal, Bluetooth controls, and a bracket that supports devices of various widths. It offers advanced features such as active tracking, time-lapse, and motion time-lapse videos, and has a battery life of 4.5 hours. The Osmo Mobile aims to bridge the gap between smartphone cameras and professional camera equipment, making it a valuable tool for vloggers, photographers, and anyone looking to improve their mobile video recording capabilities.

site_title: STI up 2.5% for the week but falls into the red for 2016
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended a volatile week with a 21.15-point loss, cutting its 5-day gain to 2.5% and falling into the red for 2016. The index closed at 2,873.33, with banks, telcos, and oil and gas stocks being the most traded. Despite a muted earnings recovery forecast by Credit Suisse, some brokers believe banks' exposure to the oil and gas sector may be over, while others predict more bad news. Turnover was low, with 1.4 billion units traded worth S$815.6 million.

site_title: Wealth succession proves tricky for some top execs: BT poll
summary: A survey by The Business Times found that one in five business leaders in Singapore have failed to consider wealth-succession plans, despite believing in educating the next generation on wealth management and financial planning. This highlights the challenges in planning for the future of wealth succession among top executives.

site_title: UN's role in fighting slavery today
summary: The United Nations is urging the Security Council to take action against human trafficking in conflict zones, with 45.8 million people estimated to be enslaved worldwide. The rise of groups like Islamic State and Boko Haram, which openly encourage and organize slavery, has made the problem worse. The UN has requested a report on human trafficking in conflict and is considering a special international tribunal to address Islamic State's war crimes. The Council can also denounce involvement, monitor and disrupt human trafficking, protect displaced civilians, and enlist the private sector to prevent human trafficking in conflict.

images.alt_text: CURRENT FORM OF SLAVERY: More than 5,000 Yazidi women, children and men are thought to be enslaved by Islamic State right now. It has set up slave registries and markets, openly advocates the revival of slavery through official mouthpieces, and has issued "how-to" manuals on slavery.

site_title: To compete with mobile, Sony tailors PlayStation to next-generation TVs
summary: Sony announced the PlayStation 4 Pro, a more powerful version of its console, to compete with next-generation TVs. The new console will display games at higher resolutions and use high dynamic range (HDR) technology for improved image quality. It will cost US$400 and go on sale on November 10, while a slimmer version of the base model PlayStation 4 will sell for US$300 starting September 15. This move aims to innovate at a faster pace, influenced by the mobile industry's rapid change, and is expected to persuade 10-20% of existing PlayStation 4 owners to upgrade.

images.alt_text: NEW KID ON THE BLOC: The PlayStation 4 Pro, launched at an event in New York, uses the high dynamic range technology and offers big improvements in colour and other image enhancements. It goes on sale on Nov 10.

site_title: The economic trend is our friend
summary: The article argues that despite current global pessimism, the long-term economic trend is optimistic. Since 2008, economic growth has been disappointing, but looking at the past 30-60 years, the picture is brighter. Global economic growth is driven by the adoption of productivity-enhancing technologies, trade, and a declining population. The Penn World Table data shows that global material wellbeing has tripled since 1950, with countries like China and India making significant progress. However, global inequality remains a concern, and the world economy may be entering a period of slower growth.

site_title: Tengah to feature novel smart technologies
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) will utilize novel smart technologies in the development of Tengah, Singapore's first public housing estate project since Punggol. The town will feature energy and water conservation facilities, a car-free town centre, and greenery to promote sustainable living. A smart planning software will analyze urban microclimatic conditions to optimize building configurations and reduce heat. The project will include smart lighting, eco-pedestals, and a pneumatic waste conveyance system, aiming to minimize waste and promote efficient resource use. The first batch of flats will be launched in 2018.

site_title: Jakarta's tax amnesty hampered by limited investment options
summary: Indonesia's tax amnesty, aimed at boosting revenue and easing budget pressure, is being hindered by limited investment options for individuals and companies. Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro stated that big taxpayers prefer to wait and see, and only 4.6% of the government's revenue target has been reached so far. The amnesty plan, which runs until March, aims to add 165 trillion rupiah to revenue, but growth in the country remains under pressure due to falling commodity prices and weak consumer demand.

site_title: Homes delivered via courier - in flat packs
summary: Singapore may see the emergence of DIY modular housing, where homes are delivered in IKEA-style flat packs, as a potential housing model. Startups like Avava Systems have already popularized this concept globally, offering high-end, flat-pack homes with a living area, kitchen, bathroom, and elegant wood finishes. However, regulators and industry players have raised concerns about safety and quality, citing the need for qualified architects and engineers, as well as technical clearances from various agencies. The Building and Construction Authority and Surbana Jurong have advised that such flat-pack homes would be subject to regulatory and technical laws, while Christine Li, research director at Cushman & Wakefield, is skeptical about the concept's viability in Singapore due to the country's land scarcity and existing housing policies.

site_title: China's factory deflation eases in August
summary: China's factory-gate deflation eased to the least in four years in August, with the producer-price index improving for an eighth straight month. Consumer prices rose 1.3%, trailing estimates, while food prices also increased 1.3%, the least since January 2015. The data suggests the price outlook is stabilizing along with demand, giving policymakers fresh evidence that the worst of deflation is behind China.

images.alt_text: CHEAPER FOOD: The National Bureau of Statistics says the slower increase in consumer prices in August was mainly due to food prices, which rose 1.3 per cent, the least since January 2015.

site_title: Volkswagen engineer indicted in US emissions case
summary: A Germany-based Volkswagen engineer, James Liang, was indicted in Detroit federal court for his role in developing an emissions-cheating device on diesel cars. Liang helped design the "defeat devices" from 2006 and misled US environmental regulators about the system's performance. He is expected to cooperate with US prosecutors and has pleaded guilty. The indictment claims Liang and co-conspirators cheated emissions tests by allowing vehicles to emit higher pollutants on the road, while appearing to meet emissions standards during testing. This is part of the ongoing Volkswagen emissions scandal.

site_title: BMW bosses to skip Paris show to thrash out electric car strategy
summary: BMW's management board is skipping the Paris Motor Show to discuss the company's electric car strategy, including the potential production of a battery-powered Mini. The decision comes after Tesla's success in the electric car market and amid pressure from governments to reduce pollution. BMW has been torn about accelerating electric car development, citing high investment costs and lacklustre sales of its i3 model. The company is considering alternative strategies, such as expanding its luxury and performance car range, to compensate for lower profits from smaller electric vehicles.

site_title: Airbnb revamps its anti-discrimination policy
summary: Airbnb has revamped its anti-discrimination policy, aiming to address widespread racial discrimination against non-white guests. The company will display photos less prominently on its website, promote instant bookings, and change its technology to downplay users' photos. By the end of the year, Airbnb will expand its instant book program to one million listings, requiring hosts to provide government-issued ID or a 4.5-star rating for approval. The company also introduced hiring rules to increase diversity among senior-level positions and made anti-bias training mandatory for all staff.

site_title: Facebook grilled by EU's Vestager over WhatsApp merger u-turn
summary: EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager is questioning Facebook over its use of WhatsApp customer data after the US$19 billion acquisition in 2014. Facebook had previously stated it wouldn't merge data, but announced changes allowing advertising to draw on WhatsApp data. Vestager says the EU is "asking some follow-up questions" and may revoke European Union approval for the merger if Facebook provided incorrect information. Facebook is cooperating and providing detailed information, but Vestager warns that personal data gathered by tech companies can be used to pay for free services, potentially breaking competition rules.

site_title: Twitter shares fall as pressure for growth mounts
summary: Twitter shares fell 6% on Thursday, closing at $18.70 after losing $1.17, as pressure mounted for growth or a potential suitor for its global one-to-many messaging service.

site_title: Samko proposes rights issue to raise net proceeds of S$34.6m
summary: SAMKO Timber has proposed a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue of up to one billion new shares at 3.5 cents each to raise S$34.6 million. The move aims to improve working capital and strengthen its financial position. The group plans to start an organisational rationalisation process to improve staffing and costs efficiencies. Shareholders will be sought specific approval for the rights issue and the proposed disposal of shares in PT SLJ Global Tbk at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Tighter curbs sought on investments by US banks
summary: US regulators seek to impose stricter controls on Wall Street banks' investments, including prohibiting them from buying and selling commodities like copper and shutting down in-house private equity operations. The proposed rules, part of a long-awaited report, aim to prevent banks from engaging in "safety and soundness" risks. The recommendations are unlikely to take effect soon, requiring Congressional approval.

images.alt_text: FIRST TARGET: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency is moving to immediately ban Wall Street banks from buying and selling copper.

site_title: 12 new cases of Zika in Singapore to push total over 300
summary: Singapore has reported 12 new locally transmitted Zika cases, bringing the total to over 300 as of Sept 8. The cases are linked to two clusters: Aljunied Crescent/Sims Drive/Kallang Way/Paya Lebar Way and Elite Terrace. The Ministry of Health continues to monitor the situation and provide updates.

site_title: Gold slips after Fed comments boost dollar
summary: Gold prices slipped for a third day on Friday, down 0.25% at $1,334.61 an ounce, following hawkish comments from a top Federal Reserve official that boosted the US dollar to a session peak. The metal is on track for a second successive weekly gain after US data fueled speculation that the Fed will hold off raising interest rates at its September meeting. Despite a 0.8% weekly gain, gold is still down from its peak of $1,352.65 an ounce after rallying 1.8% on Tuesday.

site_title: My boss just quit. What next?
summary: When a high-potential employee's boss quits without warning, it can be devastating. However, panicking is premature and can harm one's career. Instead, take proactive steps to salvage the situation. Meet with the new manager to gather context, wish the departing boss well, and show support. Clarify how the departure will affect day-to-day work and ensure team goals and deliverables remain clear. Be prepared to take on additional responsibilities, and document your workload and contributions. Showing maturity and leadership during this transition can reflect positively on future appraisals and promotion opportunities.

site_title: Barclays conducts first blockchain-based trade finance deal
summary: Barclays has conducted the world's first blockchain-based trade finance deal, cutting the time for a typical 7-10 day process to under four hours. The deal, involving Irish cooperative Ornua and the Seychelles Trading Company, guaranteed the export of US$100,000 worth of cheese and butter. The blockchain platform, set up by Wave, provides electronic record-keeping and transaction-processing, making transactions faster, more reliable, and easier to audit. This marks a significant step towards widespread adoption of blockchain technology in the trade finance sector.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported mixed Q1 results, with increased losses in the Americas business due to higher marketing expenses. However, the company's strategy to drive growth through cost optimization and top-line growth is on track. Accordia Golf Trust's loan-to-value ratio is 28.8%, and the company aims to acquire 50 billion yen worth of golf courses by March 2017. Office Reits may see a bottom in rents, with CapitaLand Commercial Trust and Keppel Reit upgraded to "buy" from "hold".

site_title: Etihad airline bans use of Samsung 'exploding' mobiles
summary: Etihad Airways has temporarily banned the use of Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones on its flights due to reports of exploding batteries in the devices. The airline's move follows a global recall by Samsung, which has suspended sales of the affected smartphones and recalled 2.5 million units worldwide. US and Japanese aviation authorities have also warned passengers not to turn on or charge the devices on aircraft. The ban is in place until the issue is resolved by the manufacturer.

site_title: Oil heading for first rise in 3 weeks on Opec hopes, US stocks
summary: Oil prices are set for their first weekly gain in three weeks after a 4% surge on Thursday, driven by a large drawdown in US crude stocks. Major Opec producers Saudi Arabia and Russia agreed to cooperate on stabilizing the oil market, boosting hopes for supply cuts. The International Energy Agency predicts demand will finally exceed supply in the third quarter, leading to falling crude stockpiles. However, analysts from Morgan Stanley see risks of delayed supply and demand rebalancing, citing increasing probability of unexpected bearish developments.

site_title: VLCC rates to slip as low-cargo volumes weigh on overtonnaged market
summary: VLCC freight rates are expected to decline next week due to a surplus of ships and limited cargo availability. Charter rates have fallen to around $14,000-$17,000 per day on routes from the Middle East to Asia, down from over $100,000 per day in January. The market is expected to remain sluggish until November, with a planned refinery shutdown in Asia in October potentially affecting cargo volumes.

site_title: Britain should make up its mind on start of Brexit talks: Eurogroup head
summary: Britain's formal divorce from the European Union is stalled due to uncertainty, with the EU's finance ministers urging the country to initiate exit talks. Eurogroup head Jeroen Dijsselbloem expressed concern that the prolonged uncertainty would damage Britain's economy the most. EU leaders are pressing for a swift start to the exit process, while British Finance Minister Philip Hammond considers a fiscal response to Brexit. The UK's Prime Minister Theresa May has given little away on her plans, saying she won't trigger Article 50 until the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Britain must make up its mind on the start of formal divorce procedures with the European Union as its economy stands to lose the most from the prolonged uncertainty, the head of eurozone finance ministers Jeroen Dijsselbloem said on Friday.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower amid President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow eyes higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: China New Town takes 27.3% stake in education project in Danyang for 300m yuan
summary: China New Town Development Company (CNTD) has entered into a strategic cooperation framework agreement with the Danyang municipal governments to establish a college development project. CNTD will take a 27.27% stake in the project for 300 million yuan (S$61 million). The project, valued at 2.75 billion yuan, aims to construct various campus facilities. This marks CNTD's first foray into the education sector, with the investment returns expected to contribute to the company's revenue.

site_title: US: Wall St falls after North Korea test, Fed comments
summary: US stocks fell on Friday amid investor caution following North Korea's fifth and largest nuclear test and comments by a US Federal Reserve official that supported an interest rate hike. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.73%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell 0.8% and 0.72%, respectively. The Fed's Boston President Eric Rosengren said the central bank faces risks if it waits too long to raise interest rates, and expectations for a September rate hike remain high at 18%.

site_title: Facebook censors iconic Vietnam War photo, angering Norway
summary: Facebook has censored a historic Vietnam War photo, including a post by Norwegian Prime Minister Erna Solberg, sparking outrage in Norway. The 1972 Pulitzer Prize-winning photo of a naked Vietnamese girl running from a napalm attack was deleted by Facebook, citing nudity rules, despite being considered one of the war's defining images. The incident has raised concerns about Facebook's editorial policy and its impact on freedom of expression.

site_title: Soccer: Blatter and two others facing Fifa investigation over salaries
summary: Former FIFA president Sepp Blatter and ex-secretary general Jerome Valcke are facing a fresh investigation over salaries and bonuses received while in office. The investigation, led by FIFA's ethics committee, alleges "bribery and corruption" and breaches of rules related to general conduct, loyalty, and gifts. The three officials, who have already been banned for ethics violations, could face further punishment. FIFA's internal investigation found they received 79 million Swiss francs in compensation over five years, with Blatter and Valcke previously denying wrongdoing.

site_title: Samsung Elec considers sale of printer business to HP: Seoul Economic Daily
summary: Samsung Electronics is considering selling its printer business to HP Inc for approximately $2.45 billion, according to a report by the Seoul Economic Daily. The company plans to announce its position next week. This move would mark Samsung's exit from its non-core business, following previous exits in chemicals and defense. A Samsung spokesman declined to comment on the rumors, while HP's office in Seoul was unavailable for immediate comment.

site_title: Britain doesn't need an EU trade deal, Wetherspoon's Martin
summary: Britain doesn't need a trade deal with the EU, according to JD Wetherspoon's chairman Tim Martin, who said the UK is in a stronger negotiating position and should focus on its own economy. Martin stated that EU countries sell twice as much to Britain as Britain sells to the EU, making a trade deal less important for the UK. This comes as Wetherspoon forecast slightly improved results, while rival Greene King reported tougher trading ahead due to Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Global airport traffic up 6.4% in 2015, fastest rate since 2010
summary: Global airport traffic increased 6.4% in 2015 to 7.2 billion passengers, the fastest rate since 2010, according to Airports Council International. The Asia-Pacific region saw the highest number of passengers, 2.46 billion, with emerging markets growing 8.1% and mature markets 5.2%. The world's busiest airport, Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson, handled 104 million passengers. The growth trend is expected to be tempered by security concerns and potential bottlenecks, with cautious optimism recommended for 2016.

site_title: French government moves to cut taxes as election approaches
summary: France's government has unveiled plans to lower taxes on households and companies ahead of the 2017 presidential election. The proposals include a 20% reduction in income taxes for the middle class and a reduction in corporate tax rates to 28% for small and medium-sized companies. The measures are expected to benefit around 5 million households and are seen as a bid to boost the government's popularity. Despite the tax cuts, France will honor its pledge to reduce its public spending deficit to 2.7% of gross domestic product in 2017.

site_title: Hot stock: Ezra falls amid high volumes, attracts SGX query
summary: Ezra Holdings' shares fell 5.2% to 5.5 Singapore cents amid high trading volumes, with 291.9 million shares changing hands, drawing a query from the Singapore Exchange. The stock jumped 35% on Thursday, trading 182.1 million shares, making it the most active counter on the SGX.

site_title: Fed's Rosengren says 'gradual tightening' will prolong recovery
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren warned that delaying interest rate hikes could lead to overheating the US economy and risk financial stability. He argued that the labor market's tightening and modest wage gains justify gradual rate increases. The Fed is set to consider raising rates for the first time since December, amid solid employment reports and modest wage gains, despite some concerns about global growth.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Eric Rosengren moved more firmly into the camp of hawkish policy makers, warning that waiting too long to raise interest rates threatened to overheat the US economy and could risk financial stability.

site_title: ICBC said poised to promote company veteran Gu Shu to president
summary: ICBC is poised to promote Vice President Gu Shu to president, pending final government approval. Gu, who joined ICBC in 1998, would oversee the lender's day-to-day management with approximately $3.5 trillion in assets. A potential announcement is expected as early as this month.

site_title: STI gains 2.5% for the week, slips into the red for the year
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,873.33 on Friday, down 21.15 points, and lost 2.5% for the week, slipping into the red for the year. The index had previously reached a 2016 high of 2,896 on Tuesday but fell short-lived. Turnover on Friday was 1.4 billion units worth S$815.6 million. The decline was driven by expectations of Wall Street performance, with traders closely monitoring Dow futures.

site_title: Claims received by Swiber hit US$230.7m
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singaporean offshore marine company, has received US$230.7 million in claims as of Thursday. The company, which defaulted on local currency notes last month, is seeking legal advice on the claims and has opted for judicial management instead of winding up. This decision came after its winding-up petition in July rocked the oil and gas industry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.940 points to 1,686.440. The index saw 1.342 billion lots traded worth RM1.364 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 324 to 401.

site_title: Oil prices fall in Asia following sharp gains
summary: Oil prices in Asia fell on Friday, reversing a sharp gain from the previous day, as investors digested data suggesting last week's US stockpile decline was likely a one-off. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped 40 US cents to US$47.22, while Brent fell 44 US cents to US$49.55. Analysts warn that a rebound is expected next week, and experts are skeptical about a successful agreement at an upcoming Opec and Russia meeting aimed at addressing a two-year-old global supply glut.

site_title: Asia-Pacific crude: Pertamina closes crude import tender
summary: Pertamina, Indonesia's state-owned oil company, closed a crude import tender for November delivery, with loading programs and offers expected to emerge next week. Murphy Oil and Pertamina are likely to have sold October Kidurong cargoes at premiums, while Japanese refiner Idemitsu Kosan shut down its refinery due to a power blackout. India plans to expand its refining capacity to over 1.2 million barrels per day by 2030, while Iran's oil output growth has stalled. Commercial oil production at the Kashagan field in Kazakhstan will begin in November.

site_title: 20 years on, Tupac reigns as potent global force
summary: Twenty years after his death, Tupac Shakur remains a potent global force in music, with his influence extending across borders and generations. Artists worldwide, including DAM and rappers in Iran, sub-Saharan Africa, and eastern Europe, cite Tupac's impact. His emotional directness, range, and message of social justice continue to transcend borders, with his music and legacy being used in various contexts, from guerrilla warfare to mainstream hip-hop. Despite controversy surrounding his death and the commercialization of his image, Tupac's enduring legacy is a testament to his artistic and cultural significance.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end week with rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.75% on Friday, driven by upbeat Chinese inflation data and relaxed rules on insurance firms investing in the city. The Hang Seng Index closed at 24,099.70, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.55% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.73%. The rally follows a 5-day gain in Singapore stocks and comes as traders brush off new US President Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Hairline cracks found on 11 Sengkang-Punggol LRT trains
summary: Eleven Sengkang-Punggol LRT trains have been withdrawn from service due to hairline cracks found on their bogie frames. The cracks, discovered during a fleet-wide inspection, do not compromise the trains' ability to bear weight. A sample of an affected bogie frame has been sent to Japan for analysis, and the manufacturer plans to redesign and replace the structures on all 57 light rail vehicles in the fleet. Six trains have been restored and returned to service, with the remaining five expected to be reinstated by mid-October.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore dollar forwards have dropped to a four-year low, indicating expectations that the Monetary Authority of Singapore will refrain from easing monetary policy next month. Singapore Airlines banned the use of Samsung Galaxy Note 7 phones during flights. Hairline cracks were found on 11 Sengkang-Punggol LRT trains, but do not compromise the trains' ability to bear weight. Shares of Ezra Holdings fell 5.2% due to high trading volumes. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended a volatile week with a 2.5% gain for the week, despite slipping into the red for the year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end flat after North Korea nuke test
summary: Tokyo shares closed flat on September 9, 2016, amid concerns over a North Korean nuclear test. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.04% to 16,965.76, while the Topix index fell 0.16% to 1,343.86. Speculation about the Bank of Japan expanding stimulus measures offset the market's reaction to the North Korean test.

site_title: Duterte says he told Obama he never insulted him, thinks UN's Ban a fool
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte denied calling US President Barack Obama a "son of a bitch", saying he never made the statement. Duterte maintained his stance on his war on drugs, criticizing UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon as a fool for bringing up human rights issues. The two leaders met briefly at a banquet, easing a standoff after Obama cancelled a planned meeting due to the alleged insult. Duterte defended his war on drugs, which has killed at least 2,400 Filipinos, and said he was not fighting with America.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte told Barack Obama he never called him a "son of a bitch", he said on Friday, but he maintained a defiant stance on his war on drugs, saying UN chief Ban Ki Moon was a fool for bringing up human rights.

site_title: Europe: Stocks weaken at open on ECB disappointment
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 dipping 0.3%. The European Central Bank's failure to deliver new stimulus measures dampened sentiment, with investors instead focusing on North Korea's nuclear test and US-EU trade talks. The ECB kept its asset-buying policy steady and interest rates unchanged, with President Mario Draghi urging "patience" to see the effect of existing stimulus measures. Markets are awaiting the outcome of the Bank of England's next policy meeting.

site_title: SIA bans use of Samsung Galaxy Note 7 during flights
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) advises passengers not to turn on or charge Samsung Galaxy Note 7 smartphones during flights or stow them in checked baggage due to concerns over the phone's fire-prone batteries. Singapore Airlines, Qantas Airways, Jetstar Airways, and Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd have banned the use of the phones during flights, while Delta Air Lines Inc is studying the issue. The FAA does not order US airlines to take action, and other carriers are conducting risk assessments.

site_title: China 'firmly opposes' North Korean test: Foreign ministry
summary: China has "firmly opposed" North Korea's fifth nuclear test, according to the Chinese foreign ministry. The test, which Pyongyang's state media described as successful, was conducted despite international opposition. China's statement was made in response to the test, which Pyongyang said achieved its goal of fitting a miniaturized nuclear warhead on a rocket.

site_title: French police shoot, arrest 'IS' gas car suspect
summary: French police arrested three female suspects, aged 39, 23, and 19, in a car containing six gas cylinders in Paris. One woman was shot and arrested after pulling out a knife and stabbing a police officer. The suspects were planning "new violent and imminent actions" and swore allegiance to the Islamic State group. The car was found near the Notre Dame cathedral, where a series of attacks have occurred in recent months, including last November's coordinated bloodshed that killed 130 people.

site_title: New Tokyo chief determined to hold down Olympic costs
summary: Newly appointed Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike aims to slash costs for the 2020 Olympic Games, with up to 18 months to come up with a plan. She plans to review Olympic plans, propose a mid-term report, and consider temporary venues to reduce construction costs. Koike, who has halved her own salary, aims to cut expenses by halving the city's budget, which has grown to six times its original estimate. Her efforts come amid a series of scandals surrounding the Olympic bid, and she faces opposition from the Tokyo assembly.

site_title: UK expectations for rate hikes lowest on record: BoE
summary: The Bank of England's survey shows a record low 21% of British people expect interest rates to rise in the next 12 months, following the central bank's rate cut in August after the Brexit vote. Expectations for inflation rose to 2.2% for the coming year, while those for five years' time fell to 3.0%. The Bank of England has cut interest rates to a record low of 0.25% and expects to cut them again later this year if the economy slows due to the Brexit shock.

images.alt_text: The proportion of British people who think the Bank of England will raise interest rates over the next year has plunged to record low, reflecting the central bank's decision to cut borrowing costs after Britain's Brexit vote in June, a BoE survey showed.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay more than US$2.4b to settle mortgage case
summary: Deutsche Bank is expected to settle a US$2.4 billion mortgage case, following a 100-page statement of facts from the US Department of Justice. The settlement marks a significant development in the bank's ongoing litigation cases, which also include investigations into foreign exchange rates, equities trades, and money laundering. The announcement comes after Deutsche Bank's CEO, John Cryan, expressed hope to resolve the four remaining cases this year. The bank has declined to comment on the settlement.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank is expected to settle US investigations into past misselling mortgage-backed securities for more than US$2.4 billion, a German monthly magazine reported.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares fall on friday, ECB sours mood
summary: Australian shares closed at their lowest since early July, falling 0.9% due to a European Central Bank meeting that left investors uncertain about future monetary policy moves. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 46.55 points to 5339.2. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also fell 0.9%. The "Big Four" banks in Australia lost between 1.2% and 1.7%. Despite China's moderation in producer price deflation, investors were spooked by the ECB's lack of clarity.

site_title: Malaysian Air in talks to offload A380s to Chinese operators
summary: Malaysia Airlines is in talks to offload its six Airbus A380 jets to Chinese operators due to the aircraft being no longer needed in its fleet. The airline is negotiating with Airbus to add 90 seats to each A380, making them more attractive to second-hand buyers. This move would make Malaysia Airlines the first A380 customer to cease flying the model, potentially softening the blow for Airbus and creating a new used superjumbo market.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks near one-week low as Apple suppliers drag
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell to a one-week low on Friday, with the main Taiex index dipping 1% to 9,169.69, following Apple's disappointing iPhone 7 release. TSMC and other Apple suppliers, such as Hon Hai Precision, also declined. The Taiwan dollar softened against the US dollar.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares lower as ECB disappoints
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Friday, with financials losing heavily after the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting failed to provide clarity on future monetary policy moves. The ECB cut its 2017 economic growth forecast to 1.6% and maintained the March end-date for its asset purchase programme, disappointing investors who had expected an extension. The Australian main index fell 0.8%, while New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.7%. Gains in basic materials and energy were offset by losses in financials and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Retro Taiwan lunchboxes cash in on train nostalgia
summary: Taiwan's retro-style "biandang" lunchboxes, originally designed for convenience and simplicity, have become a nostalgic food trend. The simple rice lunchboxes, containing braised or fried meat and pickles, are now selling in millions across the island, with many fans buying them as comfort food, regardless of travel plans. The Taiwan Railways Administration expects to sell a record 10 million boxes this year, with traditional combinations still preferred over fancier, pricier options.

site_title: Kerry in Geneva to push Russia on Syria ceasefire
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry met with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov in Geneva, seeking a deal on a Syria ceasefire. Kerry's visit comes after the collapse of a UN-backed ceasefire in February, with Washington wanting concrete steps from Russia to force Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to stop bombing civilians and lift the siege of Aleppo. In exchange, Russia seeks closer military cooperation with the US to target jihadist groups. While a deal is uncertain, Kerry emphasized the need for progress, warning that continued negotiations without purpose would be futile.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks sag on North Korea's nuclear test, won edges down
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 1.3% to a one-week low after North Korea conducted its fifth nuclear test and claimed to have mastered warhead deployment on ballistic missiles. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,037.87 points. The won initially declined but recovered, gaining 1.7% for the week, its largest weekly gain in seven weeks, as exporters sold the greenback later in the session. Foreign investors sold 115.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares, ending a five-day buying streak.

site_title: Asia: Stocks decline as Korean shares fall, investors weigh ECB
summary: Asian stocks declined as investors weighed the European Central Bank's decision not to discuss an extension to its bond-buying program. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell 0.7% due to concerns over North Korea's potential nuclear test, which South Korea's government confirmed. The ECB's move also raised speculation about the Bank of Japan's stimulus plans, leading to a decline in Japanese shares. Other regional markets, such as Hong Kong and China, rose, while the US and Europe's stocks fell slightly.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet unit to drop burritos by drone
summary: Google's parent company, Alphabet, will test drone delivery of burritos on a college campus in Virginia. The project, led by Astro Teller, aims to develop a prototype drone delivery system. This follows US officials' announcement that Alphabet is joining tests for commercial drone deliveries, with the White House unveiling accelerated rule making for unmanned aircraft operations. The test is part of Alphabet's work on unmanned aerial systems, including drones and self-driving cars.

site_title: Amitabh Bachchan still the big boss of Bollywood at 74
summary: Bollywood megastar Amitabh Bachchan, now 74, remains a dominant figure in the Indian film industry despite his age. His latest film, "Pink", a courtroom drama about women's rights, is set to release on September 16 and aims to challenge conservative attitudes in India. The film, which Bachchan has described as "very emotional" to make, centers on three women who are molested and then put on trial. Bachchan has expressed his commitment to tackling tough subjects and remains hungry for new challenges, with no plans to slow down at 74.

images.alt_text: Bollywood megastar Amitabh Bachchan turns 74 next month but he says he's still hungry for new challenges after his latest movie about sexual violence against women left him deeply moved.

site_title: China August inflation slows to 1.3%, weakest since Oct 2015
summary: China's consumer price inflation slowed to 1.3% in August, its weakest pace in almost a year, driven by abating food costs. The producer price index fell 0.8% from a year earlier, the first decline since March 2012. Analysts expect China to have room to loosen monetary policy if needed, but policymakers have differing views on stimulus. This moderation in inflation adds to evidence of a steadying economy, with China's imports rising for the first time in nearly two years and strengthening producer prices tempering the need for short-term interest rate easing.

site_title: China property bond curb calls revive on overheating market
summary: China's property bond market is facing calls to curb its rapid growth due to concerns over an overheating real estate market. Total debt for 119 listed developers has surged 30% to a record 2.8 trillion yuan, with onshore bond sales exceeding 443 billion yuan in 2015. S&P Global Ratings and Citic Securities Co are urging authorities to impose limits on property developers' bond sales to prevent a market correction. This comes as the government reviews its previous decision to lift a ban on bond sales two years ago.

site_title: China's yuan weakens on renewed speculation of depreciation
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar on Friday amid speculation of depreciation following the G20 summit in Hangzhou. Traders believe the People's Bank of China may allow the yuan to depreciate after the summit, contrary to its usual practice of maintaining stability during major events. This move could raise pressure on policymakers as China's GDP growth is expected to slow. The yuan's decline adds to concerns about the country's economic stability and the impact of US tariffs.

images.alt_text: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar on Friday amid fresh speculation that the Chinese currency will depreciate after the conclusion of the G20 summit in the city of Hangzhou.

site_title: Yen up, won hit as North Korea atomic test jolts markets
summary: North Korea's atomic test reignited geopolitical tensions, causing investors to buy the Japanese yen and sell the South Korean won. The yen strengthened to 102.09 yen, while the won dropped 0.7% against the US dollar. Markets reacted cautiously, with the euro rising to US$1.1279, and shares in Seoul declining over 1%. The test confirmed North Korea's ability to mount a nuclear warhead on a rocket, increasing uncertainty and contributing to a risk-off mood.

site_title: Draghi asset buying deepens the hole in Europe's pension funds
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's asset buying may deepen the financial hole in pension funds, as low interest rates force them to buy more bonds or diversify investments to meet long-term income needs. Currently, occupational funds in Europe can only pay about 76% of their commitments on average, with regulators warning of underestimated risks and recommending measures to improve transparency. The situation is mirroring that of US and Japanese pension funds, which are also being affected by central bank monetary policy, and may lead to cuts in pension payments or increased capital contributions.

site_title: North Korea hails 'successful' nuclear test
summary: North Korea has successfully conducted its fifth nuclear test, with an estimated yield of 10 kilotonnes, according to state-run TV. The test, described as the largest-ever by Pyongyang, will enable the North to produce a variety of smaller, lighter and diversified nuclear warheads. The test's location and exact timing were not disclosed. The North's ruling Workers' Party of Korea congratulated its nuclear scientists on the successful test, which is seen as a significant escalation of the country's nuclear program.

images.alt_text: North Korea has conducted a "successful" fifth nuclear test, state-run TV said Friday, in an explosion described by the South as Pyongyang's largest-ever such blast.

site_title: Murmurs of early Malaysia election as Najib rallies his party
summary: Malaysia is rumored to be heading for an early election, potentially as soon as March 2017, amid Prime Minister Najib Razak's efforts to rally his party and capitalize on the fractured opposition. Najib has been weathering a funding scandal and graft allegations, and an election win could bolster his leadership. Umno leaders are planning to appeal to the youth and urban vote, while the opposition is attempting to unify. Analysts weigh the timing of the election, considering factors such as economic conditions and global probes into 1Malaysia Development Bhd.

site_title: Korean Air Lines delays decision on funding plan for Hanjin Shipping
summary: Korean Air Lines has delayed a decision on a funding plan for Hanjin Shipping, the world's seventh-largest container carrier, which is struggling due to cargo stranded at sea. Hanjin Group had pledged 100 billion won (S$121.22 million) to help rescue the stranded cargo. A decision on the funding plan was expected to be made on Friday but will now be discussed again on Saturday. The delay comes as Hanjin Shipping faces significant financial challenges.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.20% in early trade, following the previous day's rally on Chinese trade data. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,966.02, while the Shanghai Composite Index was marginally lower. Investors await mainland inflation figures.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won drop on suspected North Korean nuclear test
summary: South Korean shares and the won dropped early Friday following a suspected North Korean nuclear test, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index down 1.2% at 2,038.21 points. The won fell 0.7% to 1,100.1 won per US dollar. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics Co Ltd lost 2.6%, while offshore investors sold 55 billion won worth of Kospi shares. A National Security Council meeting is scheduled at the Blue House to discuss the situation.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.82% lower on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.82% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index losing 23.78 points to 2,870.7. About 105.1 million shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 88 to 63. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Trump says Russian interference with election 'probably unlikely'
summary: Donald Trump stated in an interview with RT that Russian interference with the US presidential election is "probably unlikely". Trump also praised Russian President Vladimir Putin, saying he's a better leader than President Obama. His comments came after Democratic rival Hillary Clinton criticized Trump for praising Putin. The Trump campaign denied knowledge of the RT interview, but Trump's comments have raised concerns about his ties to Russia.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars nurse ECB-caused losses, set for weekly gains
summary: The Australian dollar steadied on Friday after a three-week high was knocked down when the European Central Bank (ECB) offered no hint of further near-term easing. The currency remained on track for a weekly gain, trading at US$0.7646. The euro jumped to a one-week high of A$1.4712 after the ECB meeting, with ECB head Mario Draghi stating that expanding its asset-purchase program was not discussed. The Australian dollar failed to stay above 77 US cents, further weakening its value.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar steadied on Friday after it was knocked down from a three-week high when the European Central Bank (ECB) offered no hint of further near-term easing, although the currency remained on track for a weekly gain.

site_title: Singapore dollar forwards drop as traders see MAS policy on hold
summary: The Singapore dollar forwards have dropped to a four-year low, signaling expectations that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will refrain from easing monetary policy next month. Six-month forwards fell to minus 15.64 points, while the US Federal Reserve's likelihood of raising interest rates at the September meeting decreased to 22%. Economists predict a full-year growth rate of 1.8%, the slowest pace since 2009. MAS managing director Ravi Menon stated the current policy stance remains appropriate, citing weak fundamentals but no deterioration in the economy.

site_title: China's Li tells Duterte he hopes ties can get back on normal track
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang expressed hope for normalizing bilateral ties with the Philippines, amid tension over disputed South China Sea territory. Li and Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte met at a regional summit, with Li stating he wants "healthy, stable development" in their relations. Duterte welcomed Li's remarks, expressing his desire to improve relations with China. The two countries have differing claims in the South China Sea, with China rejecting an international arbitration ruling that deemed its island-building activities illegal.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds interest rate steady as household debt rises
summary: The Bank of Korea held its key interest rate steady at 1.25% for a third consecutive month, citing improving economic data and household debt at a record high of 1,257.3 trillion won. Despite rising household debt posing long-term financial risks, the BOK will wait for US and Japanese central bank meetings later this month before taking action. The economy showed signs of improvement, with exports rising and GDP growth revised upward to 0.8% in the second quarter.

site_title: Gold holds decline as ECB downplays prospects for more stimulus
summary: Gold prices declined 0.1% to $1,336.53 an ounce after the European Central Bank downplayed the need for more economic stimulus. US unemployment filings unexpectedly dropped, further weighing on gold. Despite this, gold remains 26% higher in 2016, driven by the Federal Reserve's hesitation to raise interest rates and weak growth elsewhere.

site_title: North Korea suspected to have conducted fifth nuclear test
summary: North Korea is suspected to have conducted its fifth nuclear test, according to a seismic tremor recorded at 0030 GMT on Friday. The tremor was detected at surface level by US, European, and Chinese seismological agencies. A South Korean government official confirmed the suspected nuclear test, prompting an emergency National Security Council meeting. The incident has raised concerns about North Korea's nuclear ambitions and its potential impact on regional and global security.

site_title: Update: North Korea carries out 'biggest ever' nuclear test
summary: North Korea has conducted its fifth and largest nuclear test, detected by South Korea's military as a 5.3-magnitude "artificial earthquake" near its main nuclear site. The test, estimated to be around 10 kilotonnes, is the most powerful to date and has sparked international condemnation and increased tensions. The US National Security Council is monitoring the situation, and Japan is preparing to dispatch aircraft to analyze air samples for radiation. The test is seen as a show of force, timed to coincide with the anniversary of North Korea's founding, and may further strain relations with China and the international community.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.260 points to 1,691.120. Volume was 21.5 million lots worth RM4.936 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 65 to 57. This was a contrast to Singapore's 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Empty seats - but plenty of passion - at Rio Paralympics
summary: The Rio Paralympics kicked off with mostly empty stadiums, but passionate fans and Brazilian hosts are optimistic about the event's start. Despite low attendance, enthusiasm filled the gaps, with many spectators cheering on athletes and enjoying the opening ceremony. Organizers are pleased with ticket sales, exceeding 1.7 million, and are confident about healthy attendance figures. The Games aim to promote inclusion and accessibility, with many praising the event's efforts to improve wheelchair access and services.

site_title: US FAA issues air travel advisory about Galaxy Note 7 phones
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has issued an air travel advisory due to concerns over Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 phones. Passengers are advised not to turn on or charge the devices during flights or stow them in checked baggage due to fire-prone batteries. The recall was announced by Samsung last week after finding the batteries prone to catching fire. The FAA strongly advises passengers to follow its guidance to ensure safety.

site_title: ECB, Bank of Italy allow Italian banks' merger
summary: The European Central Bank and the Bank of Italy have approved the merger of Banco Popolare and Banca Popolare di Milano, creating Italy's third-largest bank by assets, known as Banco BPM. The deal aims to consolidate Italy's fragmented banking sector, which has been weighed down by 200 billion euros of non-performing loans. The merger, initially delayed due to capital requirements, now has the backing of both central banks, pending shareholder approval. The new bank will have an 8.2% market share, 25,000 staff, and 4 million customers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma Strategic, Oceanus, Del Monte Pacific
summary: Yoma Strategic's subsidiary Convenience Prosperity Company Ltd has been appointed as the exclusive distributor for the Myanmar market, boosting the company amid accelerating infrastructure and construction activities. Oceanus Group has signed a binding term sheet with two key creditors to reduce its total outstanding debt balance by S$71.85 million, 82.8% of its total debts. Del Monte Pacific narrowed its first quarter loss to US$8.7 million, down from US$10.7 million a year ago, due to lower operating expenses and a restructuring that started last year.

site_title: Samsung seeks court order to remove goods from Hanjin vessels
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd has asked a US judge to allow the company to pay cargo handlers to remove its goods from Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd's vessels stationed near US ports after the South Korean carrier filed for bankruptcy. Hanjin's collapse has stranded around $14 billion of cargo globally, with ports and cargo handling firms refusing to work for the carrier due to uncertainty over new financing plans. This move aims to prevent losses and ensure the safe removal of Samsung's cargo.

site_title: UK firms to lower investment after Brexit: accountancy body
summary: British firms are expected to cut investment by 2.9% in 2016 and 3.7% in 2017 due to the Brexit vote, according to the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales. This forecast adds to signs of caution from companies responding to the referendum result, reversing a 5% rise in 2015. The government must quickly demonstrate its plan for moving forward with leaving the European Union, which has impacted business investment.

site_title: Nasa spacecraft blasts off to collect asteroid dust
summary: NASA launched the OSIRIS-REx spacecraft on September 9, 2016, to collect dust from the near-Earth asteroid Bennu, estimated to be around the size of a small mountain. The $800 million mission aims to gather dirt and debris from the asteroid's surface, returning it to Earth by 2023 for further study. The spacecraft will map the asteroid's surface and shed light on the origins of life and the beginning of the solar system, as well as how to find precious resources like water and metals in asteroids.

site_title: China, Japan could be among Asia's biggest winners from Brexit
summary: The UK's vote to leave the EU could benefit countries like China, Japan, and Hong Kong, which already have strong ties to the UK. According to a Bloomberg Intelligence report, these countries will gain from deeper trade and investment links, as well as tourism and financial ties. China ranks third, behind Japan and Hong Kong, due to its trade and tourism ties but weakened yuan. Businesses and investors are eager to capitalize on the Brexit opportunity, which will take time to materialize but is expected to happen soon.

images.alt_text: The UK's vote to leave the European Union could throw up some winners in Asia.

site_title: US: Apple weighs on Wall Street; energy shares a boost
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, led by Apple's 2.6% drop after its latest iPhone failed to impress Wall Street. Energy shares gained, driven by sharp oil price gains. The S&P 500 information technology index fell 0.9%, while the S&P energy index rose 1.7%. Investors are anxious about the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, citing concerns about its potential impact on the market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.25%, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.46%.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Friday, gaining 0.27% or 46.54 points to 17,005.31, following two days of losses. The move was attributed to a lower yen as Europe's central bank left stimulus policies unchanged. The broader Topix index also inched up 0.09% or 1.16 points to 1,347.11.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific narrows Q1 loss to US$8.7 million
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited reported a narrowed net loss of US$8.7 million in the first quarter of its 2017 financial year, down from US$10.7 million in the previous year. Lower operating expenses due to a restructuring led to a 2.8% decline in revenue to US$465.5 million. The group's Q1 loss per share decreased to 0.45 US cents from 0.55 US cents in the year-ago period. This was attributed to strong performance in the Philippines and Asia, but lower non-branded sales in the US.

site_title: Twitter shares drop as pressure for growth mounts
summary: Twitter shares fell nearly 6% at close, ending the day at $18.70, as pressure mounted to boost growth. The company's shares lost $1.17, despite a 3% increase in monthly active users to 313 million. Revenue rose 20% to $602 million, but lagged behind expectations. Twitter's loss narrowed to $107 million in the second quarter, but the company has yet to post a profit since its 2013 IPO. Analysts remain skeptical about Twitter's ability to reverse its fortunes.

site_title: 15 years after 9/11, terror threat now 'home-grown'
summary: US counter-terrorism officials say the country is still vulnerable to home-grown attacks, despite being hardened against well-developed plots. The threat from the Islamic State group and Al-Qaeda remains complex, with online communication and encryption giving them an edge. Recent attacks in Orlando and San Bernardino demonstrate the threat of home-grown violent extremists. US officials predict that the defeat of the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria will not end the overall extremist threat, as sympathisers could go underground and plot future attacks.

site_title: Oil prices surge on sliding US crude stockpiles
summary: US oil prices surged on Thursday, with West Texas Intermediate rising $2.12 to $47.62 a barrel, and Brent North Sea oil gaining $2.01 to $49.99 a barrel. A massive 14.5 million barrel drop in US commercial inventories, largely due to the suspension of imports and production shutdowns caused by Hurricane Hermine, led to the price increase. However, analysts predict a rebound in US inventories next week, which could impact the market's expectations of an agreement to limit output at an upcoming Algeria meeting of major producers.

site_title: 50 people remain stuck in cable cars suspended over French Alps
summary: Around 50 people remain stuck in cable cars suspended over the French Alps after a helicopter rescue operation was suspended at nightfall. The cable cars, which carry four passengers each, got stuck at an altitude of 3,800 meters after cables were crossed "for unknown reasons." The rescue operation involved three helicopters from Switzerland, France, and Italy, and 60 people were evacuated in an hour and a half. The remaining passengers have water and some means of communication, but are waiting for the night to pass. A press conference is scheduled for 2030 GMT to discuss the situation.

site_title: SBI Offshore calls for trading halt
summary: SBI Offshore has requested a trading halt pending an announcement following a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) on a potential breach of securities laws in past transactions. The report allegedly found conflicting agreements on the acquisition and disposal of a stake in an associate company, raising concerns of misstatements in the firm's initial public offering prospectus and possible breaches of Singapore's securities and listing rules. The firm's founder and CEO are reportedly at odds over the matter.
