site_title: US dollar rises after US oil inventories data boost bets on Fed move
summary: The US dollar rose 0.75% against the yen after oil prices surged 4% due to a drop in US crude stocks, boosting inflation expectations and increasing the likelihood of a Federal Reserve rate hike. Fed fund futures now show a 57% chance of at least one interest rate increase by December. The euro reached a two-week high against the US dollar after the European Central Bank left interest rates unchanged, disappointing market expectations of further stimulus.

site_title: US fund investors seem to bet against near-term rate hike
summary: US fund investors are betting against a near-term interest-rate hike by pouring new cash into corporate bonds, emerging markets, and US stocks. Investment-grade bond funds took in $2.8 billion, while emerging markets equity funds and debt funds also saw inflows. The "general consensus" among investors is that the Fed will not raise interest rates in September, with some weak US economic data supporting this view. However, investors are cutting exposure to bond proxies, such as utilities sector funds, which may be vulnerable to higher rates.

site_title: Apple ditches earphone jack with iPhone 7
summary: Apple has removed the earphone jack from its new iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus models, instead opting for its proprietary Lightning port. The new EarPods come with the phones and can be connected using an adapter. The iPhone 7 also features the S$238 AirPods wireless headphones, which have a five-hour battery life and a charging case. This move marks Apple's final departure from a non-proprietary physical standard.

site_title: Mining the past to reshape the present
summary: The Singapore Writers Festival (SWF) is returning with a focus on reviving old narratives and languages. The festival, which features 330 literary acts over 10 days, highlights the importance of preserving heritage and forgotten stories. Veteran comic performer GT Lye warns that the Peranakan way of speaking Malay is disappearing, while theatre writer-director Chong Tze Chien creates a play that looks back on Singapore's literary history. The festival also features international writers, including Lionel Shriver, Eka Kurniawan, and Vijay Seshadri, as well as a special focus on Asian scribes.

site_title: China August imports up 1.5%, exports down 2.8%
summary: China's August trade figures showed imports rising 1.5% year-on-year and exports decreasing 2.8% in US dollar terms, contrary to a 12.5% drop in July. This marks a reversal in the almost two-year decline in imports. The data contradicts expectations and may signal a shift in China's economic outlook. The results come as the country faces economic pressure and policymakers may need to reassess their strategies.

site_title: Federal Reserve asks Congress to limit Wall Street merchant banking
summary: The Federal Reserve Board recommended to Congress that it limit Wall Street's ability to own physical commodities and engage in other aspects of merchant banking due to possible risks to the financial system. The recommendation was made in a report issued jointly with two other regulators, citing "safety and soundness concerns as well as competitive issues." The Fed suggested repealing permission granted in 1999 for Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley to conduct activities like storing and transporting physical commodities. This move is seen as a response to public and political scrutiny over the role of banks in raw materials markets.

site_title: Insurer FWD upbeat about selling direct to consumers online
summary: FWD Singapore, a composite insurer, is exploring direct-to-consumer online sales, leveraging the growing trend of online bill payments. CEO Abhishek Bhatia believes this is a "not a big leap of faith" given the increasing online shopping habits. FWD's approach aims to capitalize on the competitive insurance market in Singapore, where consumers are increasingly turning to online channels.

site_title: Wells Fargo to pay US$185m over bogus accounts
summary: Wells Fargo agreed to pay over US$185 million in fines for secretly opening 1.5 million unauthorized deposit accounts between 2011-2015, resulting in customer fees. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau fined US$100 million, and the bank also paid US$50 million to the City of Los Angeles and US$35 million to the Treasury Department. Wells Fargo fired 5,300 employees tied to the illegal conduct and took responsibility for the unauthorized accounts. The company will also compensate affected customers with US$5 million.

site_title: Food-services industry needs 'major makeover', says Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has launched the Food Services Industry Transformation Map (ITM) to address the manpower crunch in the industry due to ageing workers retiring. The blueprint aims to boost productivity and efficiency, with a focus on innovative business models and technology. The ITM targets an annual productivity growth of 2% over five years, without relying on more manpower, and will integrate efforts from various government agencies and associations.

images.alt_text: The food-services sector is running out of manpower as ageing workers retire, and this calls for a "major makeover" to reverse the trend, Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said on Thursday.

site_title: Medical concierges under fire for fee practices
summary: Medical concierges in Singapore have faced criticism for their fee practices, with some doctors questioning their charges. These services, which link patients with doctors and hospitals, offer a range of services including doctor recommendations and accommodation booking. The controversy has sparked debate over the fairness of these fees, with some calling for greater transparency and regulation.

site_title: Euro at 2-week high as ECB holds rates steady
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) held interest rates steady and stopped short of extending its asset-purchase programme, causing the euro to reach a two-week high. The euro gained 0.7% to US$1.1316, its strongest since August 26. The US dollar hit a two-week low against a basket of major currencies. Analysts say the ECB's cautious approach may not be sustainable, and the euro's value is still relatively strong compared to its value in January 2015.

site_title: Federal Reserve says it may ask banks for extra capital in a crisis
summary: The Federal Reserve may require large US banks to boost their reserves to protect against losses in a financial crisis. The "countercyclical capital buffer" would give regulators time to assess the situation and demand additional capital from banks like JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, and Wells Fargo. This measure, conceived in the Dodd-Frank legislation, aims to prevent a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis and is part of the Fed's efforts to fortify banks against catastrophic losses.

images.alt_text: Large US banks may have to boost their reserves to protect against losses in the face of a financial crisis, the Federal Reserve said on Thursday as it outlined exactly how it may demand such capital.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: FITCH Ratings assigned a "A+" rating to United Overseas Bank's HK$700 million 3.19% Basel III-compliant Tier 2 subordinated notes due 2028. Oceanus Group signed a binding term sheet with two creditors for a debt restructuring, converting S$54.2 million of debt into new shares. Yoma Strategic appointed Convenience Prosperity Company as the exclusive distributor for the Myanmar market.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop as ECB's Draghi cools stimulus talk
summary: European stock markets fell on Thursday after the European Central Bank stuck to its stimulus program schedule, with President Mario Draghi stating no extension had been discussed. Despite this, the euro rose. The Stoxx 600 hit session lows, while investors await US-EU trade talks and the release of US GDP data.

site_title: Oil production can still be more efficient, says Statoil
summary: Statoil, the third-largest net seller of crude oil, believes additional efficiency gains can be made in oil production, despite already achieving cost reductions. The company's senior vice-president, Tor Martin Anfinnsen, attributed the cost reduction to standardization and off-the-shelf solutions, which improved the cost base. Statoil's break-even price of under $25 a barrel is expected to remain sustainable, but capacity within the industry will tighten, leading to increased costs. The company expects to maintain cost control and grow again in a measured manner.

site_title: South China Sea tensions have hurt regional prosperity: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that South China Sea tensions have a significant impact on regional prosperity, affecting trade and investments worth over $5 trillion annually. Despite the lack of an international ruling rejecting China's claims, Lee emphasized the need for countries to navigate the issue together, as differences in perspectives are fundamental to the strategic situations of the countries involved. He urged caution and cooperation to mitigate risks, with the aim of coming up with a binding code of conduct for the South China Sea by the middle of next year.

site_title: Doctors in uproar over third party administrators' charges
summary: Doctors in Singapore are protesting against third-party administrators (TPAs) for charging excessive fees, which are eating into their profit margins. The Singapore Medical Association (SMA) has called for transparency and regulation of TPAs, citing concerns over lack of medical expertise, complex claims procedures, and low remuneration for GP consultations. Some TPAs, such as Fullerton Health, argue that their fees are necessary to cover operating costs and maintain a sustainable healthcare system. Industry experts warn that the lack of regulation and transparency could drive up healthcare costs in the long term.

site_title: PTC Logistics is on an expansion path
summary: PTC Logistics, a Singapore-based homegrown logistics firm, is expanding its operations to tap into the growing e-commerce trend. The company plans to hire more IT and e-commerce experts and train employees in logistics IT to reinforce its leading position in home delivery services. PTC Logistics also aims to expand its warehousing capacity, transport fleet, and chemical drumming capacity, with a focus on cost management and productivity. The company's chairman, Poh Choon Ann, credits the Singapore government's foresight in developing the logistics sector for the group's growth.

site_title: New HDB town in Tengah to be 'forest town'
summary: Singapore's first new HDB town in two decades, Tengah, will be a 'forest town' featuring a car-free town centre, lush greenery, and community farms. The 700-hectare town will have 30,000 public and 12,000 private housing units, with the first flats available in 2018. The town will be divided into five districts and feature a 5km long verdant corridor connecting the Western Catchment Area and the Central Catchment Nature Reserve, with dedicated walking and cycling paths to support Singapore's "car-lite" initiative.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's share price has lost 11.4% since the rating downgrade on Aug 8, with its target price revised to S$0.81. CEI's share price has gained 5.7% after CIMB Research upgraded it to "Add" with a target price of S$1.04. Singapore O&G's share price has risen 23.9% after UOB Kay Hian Research upgraded it to "Buy" with a target price of S$1.43, citing its diversified business model and resilience to potential risks.

site_title: A land eager to look rich: luxury brands edge into Myanmar
summary: Luxury brands are entering the Myanmar market, with Swiss watch company Franck Muller opening its 44th location worldwide in Yangon. The country's economy has grown swiftly since 2012, fuelled by foreign investment and a high-end domestic jewellery trade. Despite being a relatively new luxury market, demand for high-end goods is expected to grow, driven by an emerging middle class and Myanmar émigrés. Other luxury brands, such as Jaguar Land Rover, BMW, and Mercedes-Benz, have also established a presence in Yangon, with prices starting from a few hundred dollars for Tissot and Rado models.

site_title: Bosch allegedly sought VW cover for defeat device in 2008
summary: Bosch allegedly conspired with Volkswagen in 2008 to develop a defeat device for diesel engines, enabling them to evade US pollution-control tests. Bosch demanded eight years ago that Volkswagen indemnify it for its role in the scheme, despite continuing to develop and sell the device for US vehicles. The German car-parts supplier is accused of misleading US regulators and concealing its knowledge of the device. Bosch previously rejected claims of employee involvement but now faces lawsuits from US car owners seeking damages. The company developed software to enable Volkswagen to beat emissions testing, with Bosch maintaining a "tight grip" over the engine control module software.

site_title: TEE International awarded S$95m worth of contracts
summary: TEE International Ltd, a Singapore-based engineering company, has been awarded S$95 million worth of contracts from August to September 2016. The group's total outstanding order book now stands at S$324 million. Contracts include architectural and structural works for AXA Tower and interior fit-out works for PSB Academy's new campus. TEE's deputy group managing director, Eric Phua, stated that the new contracts demonstrate the company's commitment to quality services, despite economic headwinds.

site_title: M'sia to allow developers to offer loans
summary: Malaysia plans to allow qualified developers to provide home loans to buyers, amid a stricter lending climate that has hurt property sales. The move aims to help developers sell more stock in the short term, but experts believe it may have limited impact due to developers' limited resources and funding restrictions. The proposed loans could be partial or up to 100% with interest rates up to 18%, but analysts see it as a short-term remedy for a struggling market. The measure is part of a broader effort to support growth and avoid defaults in a stuttering economy.

site_title: The power of Agile in bringing innovation to customers efficiently
summary: John Deere, a 179-year-old manufacturer, has successfully adopted Agile methods to accelerate innovation, reducing product development time from 1.5 years to 8 months. By prioritizing key features and focusing on one segment at a time, the team can deliver working prototypes quickly and efficiently, resulting in higher customer satisfaction and increased productivity. This approach has been applied to various areas, including marketing and corporate strategy, and has shown to increase success rates and lead to higher employee satisfaction.

site_title: Planned coal-fired power generation dips 14%, says study
summary: A study found that coal-fired power generation under development worldwide decreased by 14% in 2016, driven by China's efforts to reduce oversupply and promote cleaner energy. This decline resulted in a 158 GW reduction in coal generating capacity, equivalent to the EU's coal capacity. China reduced its pre-construction pipeline by 114 GW, while India decreased its by 40 GW. Despite this, the report concluded that planned coal capacity remains too high to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

site_title: Olam sells US$150m senior notes
summary: Olam International has sold $150 million in senior notes with a 4.5% coupon, priced at 101.651% of the principal amount. The notes are due in 2021 and will consolidate with existing debt. The deal, managed by joint bookrunners BNP Paribas, Credit Suisse, and others, saw orders totaling $300 million from private banks, fund managers, and banks. Proceeds will go towards general corporate purposes, including debt repayment.

site_title: Khazanah to sell stake in Tenaga: sources
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd plans to sell 82 million shares of Tenaga Nasional, a national power utility, at a price of RM14.30 to RM14.56 per share, potentially raising up to US$294 million. The sale, part of Khazanah's divestment strategy, would reduce its stake in Tenaga to 7.3%. Khazanah is the largest shareholder with a 29.7% stake.

site_title: Board tussle at SBI Offshore as PwC submits troubling report
summary: SBI Offshore is embroiled in a board tussle after its founder and CEO, Tan Woo Thian, and his business partner Hui Choon Ho, requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting to remove current CEO Chan Lai Thong and appoint four new directors. The move comes after PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) submitted a report alleging possible breaches of securities rules in transactions involving Hui. The report highlights conflicting agreements on the acquisition and disposal of a stake in a Chinese company, potentially raising questions about the firm's prospectus and listing rules.

site_title: The Art of probing the 'why' and 'what' of friends and friendships
summary: The article discusses Yasmina Reza's play "Art," a 22-year-old classic that explores the nature of friendships and why people form and maintain relationships. The play revolves around a conversation between two friends, Marc and Serge, who disagree over the value of a painting purchased by Serge. The actors deliver a nuanced performance, taking the audience through the complexities of their friendship. The play's central question - why friends are friends and what friendships are built on - remains relatable and thought-provoking.

site_title: STI manages to stay in the black
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed with a 0.83-point gain at 2,894.48 on Thursday, despite a 16-point drop earlier in the day. The index broke above the 2,882 resistance level for the third time since the year's start but lost its grip later. Banks had a mixed performance, with DBS unchanged and UOB and OCBC recording small gains. Analysts UOB-Kay Hian and Maybank Kim Eng have differing views on the sector, with UOB-Kay Hian maintaining an "overweight" recommendation due to cheap valuations, while Maybank Kim Eng keeps a "negative" view citing multiple stress points.

site_title: MAS passenger traffic dips in Q2; sees smaller FY loss
summary: Malaysia Airlines reported a decline in passenger loads in the second quarter, with a load factor of 68.6% and lower demand during Ramadan. However, cost savings are expected to help the airline post a smaller-than-expected annual loss. The airline expects business class loads to improve in the last quarter of the year, driven by cabin upgrades. Competition is intense, with domestic and global markets likely to worsen in the second half of the year, prompting the airline to increase marketing and sales initiatives and strict cost control.

site_title: HDB resale volume up 19.5% in August: SRX
summary: HDB resale transactions in Singapore increased 19.5% in August, reaching 1,879 flats, but prices slipped 0.7% due to a correction, with 3-room and 5-room flats experiencing a 0.6% decline. The market is now at a "compromise situation" between buyers and sellers, with prices matching affordability and willingness to purchase. Experts expect further stabilization of prices but unlikely notable increases, with buyers likely to be "opportunistic" and wait for lower prices.

site_title: Banyan Tree partners Nef for Turkey resort
summary: Banyan Tree, a Singapore-based resort developer, has partnered with Turkish developer Nef to open its first resort hotel in Turkey, Banyan Tree Bodrum, in Yalıkavak, Bodrum, in spring 2017. The 70-key resort will feature 14 spa suites, 40 standard rooms, and 30 branded suites, offering luxurious amenities and services. The project is expected to create job opportunities in the hospitality sector and contribute to the Turkish economy, amidst declining tourism investments. This marks Banyan Tree's first project in Europe and Nef's first venture outside of Istanbul.

site_title: China tax crackdown threatens to curb 'teapot' refiners' demand
summary: China's tax crackdown on private refiners, known as "teapots," threatens to curb demand for imported crude, potentially impacting global oil markets. The crackdown, aimed at curbing tax evasion, could reduce import quotas by 400,000-1 million barrels per day. This would be equivalent to the amount of oil Saudi Arabia supplies to the US, the world's second-largest oil importer. The move could also lead to a decrease in refining capacity and a rise in prices.

site_title: AAF ups price cap to grow with artists
summary: The Affordable Art Fair Singapore (AAF) will increase its price cap from S$10,000 to S$15,000 starting with the November edition. The change aims to accommodate the growing number of high-spending collectors and artists, with 75% of artworks still priced below S$7,500. The fair's regional marketing director notes that the increase will allow the return of some artists who have raised their prices above S$10,000, and will also enable galleries to present more curated booths, potentially leading to solid sales despite a challenging art market.

site_title: S'pore property owners win big for sustainability
summary: Singapore property owners were recognized for their sustainability efforts in the 2016 Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark (GRESB) Real Estate Assessment. CapitaLand was crowned regional sector leader of Asia in the mixed development segment for the sixth consecutive year, while CapitaLand Mall Trust topped the retail segment. Keppel Land ranked first globally in residential, China, and East Asia sectors, and Keppel Reit ranked second globally across 733 diversified entities and sectors, including the office sector. These rankings are based on the companies' environmental, social, and governance performance.

site_title: Showing more discord than cooperation
summary: The Hangzhou G-20 summit highlighted deepening global divisions, with leaders struggling to address immediate crises and manage globalization. Key issues included competition among great powers, the South China Sea dispute, and the Syrian civil war. The summit also underscored growing discontent with globalization, as many citizens feel their governments are unable to effectively manage its impacts. This sentiment is evident in the Brexit vote in the UK, anti-immigrant sentiment in Europe, and support for Donald Trump's "America First" agenda. The summit's inability to address these challenges suggests that the current order is facing significant disruptions, with the risk of direct clashes among great powers.

site_title: Two more Starwood brands to arrive in Singapore
summary: Two new Starwood brands, The Luxury Collection and Tribute Portfolio, will debut in Singapore this year and next, increasing the total number of Starwood properties in the city-state to eight. The Duxton Club, consisting of two pre-war colonial heritage buildings, will open in early 2017 with the 50-room Duxton House and July 2026 with the 138-room Duxton Terrace.

site_title: A return to Bordeaux
summary: A vertical tasting of 12 vintages of Château Pichon Lalande from 1978 to 2005 was recently held, bringing back memories of the late May-Eliane de Lencquesaing, former owner of the Château. The tasting showcased the wine's evolution over time, with 1978 standing out as a top vintage, rivalling the 1970. The 2005 vintage was also praised for its youthful yet mature flavor profile. The tasting highlighted the wine's timelessness, nobility, and generosity of flavor, solidifying Pichon Lalande's legacy as one of Bordeaux's greatest wines.

images.alt_text: This tasting has reminded us of the greatness and the timelessness of Pichon Lalande.

site_title: Young talents to find inspiration from Judy Ongg
summary: Taiwanese singer-actress Judy Ongg will headline a charity concert, "The Love Concert Judy Ongg 2016," to raise funds for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, which has supported over 13,000 young artists. The event aims to provide education in the arts for financially disadvantaged children and youths. Ongg, known for her hit songs and iconic roles, claims to be uncomfortable being labeled a "charity queen" but emphasizes the importance of spreading happiness and giving back. The concert will also feature a segment where beneficiaries collaborate with Ongg.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Newest Canadian bank aims to woo country's Chinese families
summary: Canada's newest bank, Wealth One Bank of Canada, aims to serve the country's Chinese community with high-interest savings accounts, term deposits, and mortgages in Toronto and Vancouver. Founded by Charles Lambert and Shenglin Xian, the bank targets individuals and businesses with online banking services and a retail branch in Markham. Wealth One's focus is on culturally sensitive services, and the bank does not offer lending to non-residents. The bank's expansion plans include wealth and business banking services, despite government measures to cool housing in Vancouver and Toronto.

site_title: Going places with digital signs and more
summary: TOV Virtual Singapore, a provider of digital interactive solutions, is expanding its range of products. Founded in 2012 by Ngiam Tee Chang, the company offers digital signages, shopping mall kiosks, and media walls. Its digital directory kiosks have increased efficiency by allowing users to find their way in shopping malls in just two minutes. The company has recently launched a pilot smart bus stop project in Jurong, a collaboration with the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore. TOV Virtual Singapore aims to stay ahead of trends by integrating mobile payments and enabling users to download perks like discount coupons via NFC.

site_title: Fed sees modest economic growth amid 'slight' inflation
summary: The US economy experienced modest growth in July and August, with a strong labor market failing to drive up wages and prices. The Federal Reserve's Beige Book report showed "slight" inflation and modest expectations for wage growth. Consumer spending remained little changed, and business contacts expressed concerns about the upcoming presidential election. The Fed's policy-setting committee meets on September 20-21 to decide on interest rates, which have been held steady this year. Mixed economic readings and sluggish progress towards the Fed's 2% inflation target have prevented another rate hike.

site_title: Fluid voguing, done butoh-style
summary: American artist Trajal Harrell combines voguing, a dance style from the Harlem ballroom scene, with butoh, a Japanese performance art, in a unique aesthetic. His 2016 performances, including "Return to La Argentina," feature slow, deliberate movements and exploration of fashion and domesticity. Critics praise the fluidity and individuality of the dancers, but acknowledge that the performances may be challenging for those unfamiliar with butoh. Harrell's work offers insight into his research and practice, showcasing his innovative approach to dance and performance.

site_title: Moving towards dual-class listings would be ill-advised
summary: A Singapore Exchange (SGX) proposal to allow dual-class shares, granting higher voting power to privileged shareholders, has sparked debate. Proponents argue the commercial benefits outweigh governance concerns, while opponents claim it's impossible to build watertight safeguards, potentially harming non-controlling majority shareholders. The proposal aims to attract big-name companies like Alibaba and Manchester United, but experts warn that introducing such a system would be ill-advised, compromising the principle of equal voting rights.

site_title: S-Reits' total returns average 14.2% so far this year
summary: S-Reits in Singapore have achieved an average distribution yield of 6.7% and a total return of 14.2% year-to-date, beating the 3.9% dividend yield for the Straits Times Index and the MSCI World Reit Index. Top-performing S-Reits include Mapletree Commercial Trust, Keppel Reit, and Fortune Reit, with Saizen Reit showing significant gains of 73.1% due to a special distribution. The S-Reit Index has also outperformed the STI, with a 11.2% year-to-date gain.

site_title: Investors can no longer ignore climate change: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock Investment Institute says investors can no longer ignore climate change, citing increasing climate-related market risks. The report highlights four areas of climate-related market risks, including regulatory and policy developments, technological disruption, and extreme weather events. Investors can incorporate climate awareness into their portfolios through tools and processes, and opportunities are developing to generate climate-related "alpha." BlackRock has partnered with Stoxx to create low-carbon indices, and 120 investors with $10 trillion in assets have committed to the Montreal Pledge to measure and publicly disclose their carbon footprints.

site_title: UK's Hammond: considering whether fiscal response to Brexit needed
summary: British finance minister Philip Hammond is considering a fiscal response to the UK's Brexit vote, potentially involving increased spending or tax cuts. Hammond's previous comments about a "reset" of fiscal policy were made in July, sparking speculation about a major policy change. The UK's budget statement is due on November 23, and Hammond's decision will impact the country's economic recovery from the Brexit shock. The move could also influence the UK's economic trajectory and its relationship with the European Union.

site_title: Dell gets bigger and Hewlett Packard gets smaller in separate deals
summary: Dell Technologies completed its $67 billion merger with EMC, changing its name to Dell Technologies. Meanwhile, Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) sold its software assets to Micro Focus for $8.8 billion, marking a significant shift in the company's strategy. Both deals are in response to the decline of traditional data storage and computing markets due to cloud computing and mobile computing. Dell's move to take the company private has raised concerns about its debt and ability to survive in a changing industry.

site_title: Microsoft offering wide range of cloud services from UK data centres
summary: Microsoft is launching a range of cloud services from its UK data centres, catering to British customers in the legal, banking, public, and utility sectors. The move aims to address regulatory and data security concerns, allowing these customers to run operations online. This is Microsoft's second-biggest market for cloud-based software after the US, as demand for data localisation spreads across Europe and globally. The new offering is seen as a significant step in Microsoft's expansion in the UK cloud services market.

site_title: Extending theory into World Bank practice
summary: World Bank chief economist Paul Romer emphasizes the importance of creating new rules for better societies in charter cities to address urbanization, inequality, and poverty. Romer cites China's experience with special economic zones and controlled market economies as a successful example. He believes that his charter cities construct can turn around outdated norms and implement technological advancements. Despite past challenges, Romer sees his role at the World Bank as an opportunity to build on enlightened thinking and create meaningful change on a large scale.

site_title: Enough material here to stir the emotions
summary: Woody Allen's latest film, Café Society, is a nostalgic tribute to America's Golden Age of music and movies. Set in the 1930s Hollywood Hills, the story revolves around Bobby (Jesse Eisenberg), a young man from New York who moves to Hollywood and gets a job as an errand boy. He falls for Phil's (Steve Carell) secretary, Veronica (Kristen Stewart), but their romance ends when she has an affair with Phil. Bobby eventually finds success in the nightclub business with his brother Ben (Corey Stoll) and reunites with Veronica, but their past and present collide. The film explores themes of love, fate, and identity, showcasing Allen's signature wit and neurotic charm.

images.alt_text: Eisenberg (left) and Stewart in Cafe Society. Woody Allen's latest confection is a sweet if insignificant bonbon, populated with themes that will be familiar to fans of his films.

site_title: BOJ 'split' over further easing causes turbulence in markets
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) Policy Board is divided over whether to launch further monetary easing later this month, causing turbulence in Tokyo's financial markets. The yen has gained 1% against the dollar, while stocks slid due to the yen's increase. Analysts believe the BOJ will ease monetary policies to achieve its 2% annual inflation target, but some warn against expecting "fireworks" from the central bank. The divisions raise concerns about the credibility of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Abenomics policies.

site_title: New era for F1 as Liberty agrees on US$8b takeover
summary: Liberty Media, backed by US billionaire John Malone, has agreed to a US$8 billion takeover of Formula One, ending years of speculation over the sport's future. The deal values F1 at US$8 billion and will be completed next year, pending regulatory approval. Liberty Media will retain F1's long-time CEO Bernie Ecclestone, who will continue in his role, while Chase Carey, 21st Century Fox's vice-chairman, will become chairman. The takeover marks a new era for F1 and raises questions about the role of Ecclestone.

images.alt_text: Mr Ecclestone said he would stay on as CEO and "continue to do all the things I have previously done".

site_title: Perceptions about air pollution can affect stocks
summary: A study found that perceptions of air pollution in China can affect stock prices and trading volume. Investors in cities with worse air quality relative to Beijing tend to sell more stock, leading to lower prices and reduced trading volume. This effect is attributed to the psychological theory of social comparison, where investors compare their local air quality to Beijing's and adjust their behavior accordingly. The study suggests that environmental factors like pollution can influence investor sentiment beyond fundamental economic factors, highlighting the need to consider the true economic cost of pollution.

site_title: The trials of an authentic American hero
summary: Clint Eastwood directs Sully, a film based on the true story of US Airways Flight 1549, which ditched in the Hudson River after hitting geese minutes after take-off. Captain Chesley "Sully" Sullenberger made a heroic water landing, saving all 155 passengers and crew. The film explores the intense media scrutiny and self-doubt Sully faces, but also his calm and confident decision-making. Tom Hanks stars as Sully, and the film is praised for its pacing, acting, and faithfulness to the source material, despite not soaring to the same heights as Eastwood's other films.

site_title: ECB's Draghi looking at options to drive QE forward
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) president Mario Draghi said the bank is exploring options to continue its unprecedented money-printing program despite eurozone inflation still below the official target. The bank stopped short of confirming an extension of its 80 billion euro monthly asset purchases, which would continue until next March or beyond if necessary. The euro reached a two-week high, while bond yields rose across the eurozone, and stock markets fell in reaction to the news.

site_title: Dell Technologies says it's committed to Asia
summary: Dell Technologies has completed its $67 billion acquisition of EMC Corporation, creating the largest privately held enterprise technology company with 140,000 employees and a turnover of $74 billion. The merger aims to help customers transform their IT and protect their most important asset, information. The combined company will operate as Dell Technologies, with Amit Midha and David Webster leading the Asia-Pacific region from Singapore and Sydney, respectively. The merger is expected to create a unique family of companies that will guide customers in the digital future, leveraging the Internet of Things and data-driven applications.

images.alt_text: The combined company is hiring in many locations both in Asia and globally, says Mr Midha

site_title: PEs and VCs may emerge as O&M white knights
summary: Pareto Securities predicts the bottom for exploration and production spending is near, making it a buying opportunity for offshore and marine (O&M) stocks. However, investors have yet to capitalize on this, with Singapore-listed O&M counters still near 52-week lows. The slump is attributed to a lacklustre equity market, debt market squeeze, and the off-limits bond market following Swiber Holdings' winding-up petition. Lenders must take necessary haircuts before PEs and VCs can emerge as potential white knights for the sector.

site_title: Airbnb takes new steps to fight discrimination
summary: Airbnb has implemented new policies to combat racial discrimination on its platform. The company will introduce an "Open Doors" policy, allowing guests who feel discriminated against to be booked in a similar place or an alternative accommodation. Airbnb will also create a permanent team to root out bias and reduce the prominence of guest photos in the booking process. The move comes after a review led by former US attorney general Eric Holder and a high-profile incident in North Carolina where a host sent hateful, race-based messages to a black woman.

site_title: Asean buys time for unity in face of larger states' dominance
summary: Asean bloc and China agree on a code of conduct for the South China Sea without mentioning the international court ruling, allowing them to advance on two other measures to reduce tension. The agreements include guidelines for unplanned naval encounters and setting up hotlines for emergency diplomacy. The Asean states and China also agreed to avoid mentioning the ruling in official statements, giving them "time to unity" in the face of larger states' dominance. The agreements were reached during a dialogue in Vientiane, Laos.

site_title: Google to buy software developer Apigee in US$625m deal
summary: Google is acquiring software developer Apigee Corp in a deal valued at approximately US$625 million in cash. Google will pay Apigee shareholders US$17.40 per share, a 6.5% premium to the stock's Wednesday close. Apigee's API platform allows companies to integrate backend services with mobile and web-based apps. The acquisition is Google's second major software deal this year, following its purchase of Android Things in January.

site_title: South China Sea tensions shake trade and investment confidence, affect regional prosperity: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that South China Sea tensions have negatively impacted trade and investment confidence in the region, affecting prosperity. The tensions have disrupted the region's atmosphere of peace and calm, essential for progress. Lee emphasized the need for careful consideration to resolve maritime disputes, as changing each country's position is challenging. He noted that a peaceful environment is crucial for investors, particularly for developing countries like China. Despite shelving mention of an international ruling against China's claims, Lee does not foresee the issue fading out soon, citing fundamental differences in perspectives.

site_title: Taiwan says to offer US$960m in preferred loans to tourism sector as Chinese tourist numbers fall
summary: The Taiwan government announced it will offer NT$30 billion (S$1.28 billion) in preferred loans to the tourism industry amid a 15% drop in Chinese tourist numbers in July. This move comes ahead of a planned protest by hotels, tour bus companies, and travel agents demanding government support. The loans have lower interest rates and tax deductions to attract more Chinese tourists. The decision is seen as a response to the decline in Taiwan-China ties, following President Tsai Ing-wen's refusal to recognize the "1992 consensus".

site_title: US crude stocks plunge more than 14 mln barrels: EIA
summary: US crude stocks plummeted by 14.5 million barrels last week, exceeding expectations, according to the US Energy Information Administration. Crude inventories at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub fell by 434,000 barrels. Gasoline stocks declined by 4.2 million barrels, while distillate stockpiles rose by 3.4 million barrels. US crude imports also dropped by 1.7 million barrels per day. The refinery utilization rate increased by 0.9 percentage points, and refinery crude runs rose by 315,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Why 'campaign on terror' isn't being won 15 years after 9/11
summary: The 15th anniversary of the 9/11 terrorist attacks is marked this Sunday, yet international terrorism remains a concern. The US-led offensives in Afghanistan and Iraq have reshaped the global terrorism environment, with the Islamic State (IS) rising to prominence. Despite IS's decline, recent attacks across Europe underscore the issue. The emphasis on hard power has fueled controversy and alienated many worldwide. Policymakers continue to address the concern, with the global landscape remaining a pressing concern 15 years after the devastating attacks.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

In City Buzz, Singaporean audiences can enjoy various events and performances. English comedian Jimmy Carr brings his Funny Business tour to Singapore, featuring witty wordplay and jokes. The PianoBotanica 2016 concert celebrates the friendship between Brazil and Singapore with a free classical music event. The Sandaime Richard play, a radical adaptation of Shakespeare's Richard III, is staged as part of the Singapore International Festival of Arts. New menu items have been added to Crystal Jade Prestige, and artist Aaron Gan's painting exhibition Joy reflects his optimistic mood after winning the UOB Painting of the Year 2015.

site_title: Amazon launches low-cost tablet with Alexa assistant
summary: Amazon has launched a low-cost tablet with Alexa assistant, starting at $89 for US customers. The eight-inch Fire HD tablet offers premium features at a non-premium price, with increased battery life, storage, and performance. This move follows the company's strategy to expand into the connected home and internet of things. The tablet's price is competitive with other options in the market, and Amazon's sales figures have seen a significant increase year-over-year, with the company now ranking as the fifth largest tablet vendor globally.

site_title: Eat your heart out
summary: Three upcoming food festivals in Singapore will not only showcase local cuisine but also incorporate design, French culture, and wine. The events aim to offer unique experiences, with each festival featuring different themes and makers. Retail designer Naiise is launching its first food-meets-design festival, while other events will highlight mod-Indian cuisine and financial literacy for women. The festivals demonstrate the evolving tastes of Singaporeans, who prioritize variety and experience over over-saturation. The events are set to take place this weekend, offering a diverse range of culinary and cultural experiences.

site_title: US: Apple drags down Wall Street
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, with Apple dragging down the S&P 500, falling 2.1% and its technology index dropping 0.51%. The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the Nasdaq losing 0.33% and the Dow down 0.29%. Oil prices rose due to a large drawdown in crude stocks, while Tractor Supply and Tesla fell after disappointing earnings announcements.

site_title: British parliament should decamp for £3.9b repairs: lawmakers
summary: Britain's lawmakers should temporarily relocate from the Houses of Parliament for £3.9 billion repairs due to air pollution and rodent infestation. The Joint Committee on the Palace of Westminster recommends MPs move to the nearby Department of Health building for six years. The move comes amid warnings of a "catastrophic event" unless urgent renovations are carried out to prevent the building's collapse.

site_title: New cluster at Ubi Crescent; 292 cases of Zika in Singapore
summary: A new cluster of Zika infections has formed in Singapore's Ubi Crescent area, with 9 locally transmitted cases confirmed as of Thursday noon. This brings the total number of Zika cases in Singapore to 292. Authorities are investigating the potential cluster, but no further information is available.

site_title: US jobless claims fall at start of September
summary: US jobless claims fell to 259,000 last week, a decrease of 4,000 from the previous week, marking 79 consecutive weeks of initial claims below 300,000. The four-week moving average also dropped to 261,250. This low level of claims is seen as a positive indicator for the US jobs market, which will be a key factor in policymakers' decisions on interest rates later this month.

site_title: Charming way to reflect life and emotions
summary: Chinese artist Gao Xiaowu's sculptures, often perceived as "cute," reflect his research into Chinese traditions and philosophy. His works, such as the City of Dreams series, comment on societal expectations and conformity, while others, like the Pet God series, critique the loss of reverence for traditional symbols. Gao, an optimist, uses humor and irony to convey his ideas on social issues, aiming to engage his audience and promote a positive, do-good spirit. His art seeks to have an impact on people's lives and encourage a better society.

images.alt_text: Gao's Chinese zodiac animals (above) and one of the works from his Discrepancy series. He says dreams boost us and give us "big bellies", but the sculptures' mini wings are a reminder that reality keeps us grounded.

Gao's Chinese zodiac animals and one of the works from his Discrepancy series (above). He says dreams boost us and give us "big bellies", but the sculptures' mini wings are a reminder that reality keeps us grounded.

site_title: EU-Canada passenger data deal infringes privacy: EU adviser
summary: The EU and Canada's agreement to share airline passenger data to combat terrorism must be redrafted due to its infringement on the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, according to an EU adviser. The deal allows authorities to use the data beyond necessary for security purposes and leaves room for Canadian authorities to transfer data to non-EU countries. The adviser's opinion is expected to impact the Canada-EU Passenger Name Record (PNR) Agreement, which could also affect a separate data transfer deal with the US.

site_title: Football: Fifa propose fine in 2006 World Cup bid probe
summary: Fifa's ethics committee has recommended former German FA secretary general Helmut Sandrock be fined 50,000 Swiss francs for violating Fifa's code of ethics in the 2006 World Cup bid probe. The investigation found violations, but Sandrock may request a hearing before a final decision is made by the adjudicatory chamber. The chamber also ordered Sandrock to perform "social work" as part of his punishment.

site_title: Apple iPhone 7 not a game changer: analysts
summary: Analysts say the Apple iPhone 7 is not a game changer, lacking significant upgrades compared to its predecessors. The new phone features a high-resolution camera and a jet-black glossy finish, but retains the same price point as the 6s. Analysts expect Apple to sell 14-15 million of the new iPhones in the first weekend, with some predicting a decline in annual sales. The iPhone 7 Plus model, with its two cameras and richer feature set, may boost Apple margins. The company's stock price was down 2% on the first day of sales.

images.alt_text: Not even Chief Executive Tim Cook singing "Sweet Home Alabama" on Carpool Karaoke could get Wall Street excited about the launch of Apple Inc's iPhone 7.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks rise as inflows from China intensify
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.8% to 23,919.34 points, driven by fresh inflows from mainland China under the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme. The scheme has led to a series of one-year highs, with nearly half of the daily southbound quota used. The Fed's Beige Book report showed the US economy expanded at a modest pace in July and August, but wage pressures remain low.

site_title: Trendlines, B Braun team up to invest in healthcare incubator
summary: Trendlines Group, a Singapore-listed medical and agricultural tech incubator, has partnered with B Braun, a German medical device manufacturer, to invest in and incubate early-stage healthcare companies in Singapore and the region. The two companies have signed a memorandum of understanding to jointly invest in Trendlines Medical Singapore, with B Braun as a minority shareholder. The partnership aims to support the commercialization of Trendlines' portfolio companies and provide medtech-related expertise. Eric Loh, CEO of Trendlines Medical Singapore, targets to bring on board three to four startups in the next 12 months.

site_title: Masterplan for HDB's upcoming Tengah town unveiled
summary: Singapore's latest HDB town, Tengah, will feature a car-free town centre, community farms, and lush greenery. The 700-hectare town, located between Jurong East, Choa Chu Kang, and Bukit Batok, will offer 30,000 public and 12,000 private housing units. A 100-metre-wide forest corridor will connect the Western Catchment Area and Central Catchment Nature Reserve, while community farmways will promote social interactions and shared recreational activities. The masterplan aims to create a "forest town" and revitalize the western region with new job, residential, and recreational opportunities.

site_title: Japan's Takata to take bids from 7 potential rescuers on Sept 19: sources
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese air bag maker at the center of the auto industry's largest global recall, will receive initial bids from seven potential rescuers on September 19. The company is seeking a financial lifeline to address billions of dollars in liabilities for faulty air bag inflators linked to at least 14 deaths worldwide. A steering committee is narrowing the list of suitors to two finalists by early next month, aiming to finalize a bailout by the end of the year.

site_title: Yoma unit appointed exclusive distributor for JCB construction equipment in Myanmar
summary: Yoma Strategic's subsidiary, Convenience Prosperity Company Ltd (CPCL), has been appointed as the exclusive distributor for JCB construction equipment in Myanmar. The partnership is seen as a significant opportunity for JCB in the country's expanding construction industry, valued at $8.2 billion in 2015 and expected to grow to $13.5 billion by 2020. CPCL already has 11 branches and plans to increase its number to 14 by December 2016, augmenting Yoma's offerings in the automotive and equipment division.

site_title: Reliance of smaller Chinese banks on interbank funds raises credit worries
summary: China's mid-sized and smaller banks rely heavily on short-term interbank funds, raising concerns of a credit crunch. These banks, accounting for half of the interbank market's trading value, borrow from larger peers to fund investments and shadow-bank loans, classifying them as investments to minimize bank capital buffers. Regulators are pushing banks towards more stable funding, while a permanent rise in interbank interest rates could squeeze profit margins and increase the threat of contagion if a bank fails.

site_title: Aussie slightly firmer after China data, NZ dollar up
summary: The Australian dollar rose slightly after China's August imports unexpectedly increased for the first time in 22 months, boosting demand in the world's second-largest economy. The Aussie briefly traded above the 77 US cents resistance level but was unable to sustain the move. Despite this, the currency has been among the best-performing G10 currencies this year, driven by offshore interest in carry trades and robust domestic data. The New Zealand dollar also rose, with its value increasing 16% since mid-January due to a strong economy and recovering commodity prices.

site_title: Aged sake makes for perfect pairing with food
summary: Aged sake, specifically Tengumai from the Shata brewery in Ishikawa prefecture, is gaining recognition for its perfect pairing with food. The premium sake adheres to the classic Yamahai brewing style and is aged between one and eight years, resulting in a richer flavor and longer finish. Tengumai was paired with a seven-course dinner at Waku Ghin restaurant, showcasing its compatibility with various dishes, including white fish sushi, oysters, and fatty tuna belly. The sake's unique flavor profile, achieved through its natural lactic acid and soft water, makes it an ideal match for food.

images.alt_text: At a sake pairing at Waku Ghin recently, the Tengumai Bunsei Rokunen (above) went perfectly with a Gillardeau oyster in rice vinegar dressing.
At a sake pairing at Waku Ghin recently, the Tengumai Bunsei Rokunen went perfectly with a Gillardeau oyster in rice vinegar dressing (above).
The Tengumai Yamahai Junmai Daiginjo (above) was paired with marinated botan ebi, uni and caviar.
The Tengumai Yamahai Junmai Daiginjo was paired with marinated botan ebi, uni and caviar (above).

site_title: HK regulator urges banks to ease rules on startup account openings
summary: Hong Kong's banking regulator, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), urged banks to ease rules on startup account openings to support the development of fintech companies. The regulator launched a "sandbox" regime to promote innovation, but initially did not specifically target fintech companies. 20 banks have volunteered to welcome accounts from startups and small-and-medium enterprises (SMEs), with HSBC and Standard Chartered not on the list. The measures aim to balance anti-money laundering and terrorist financing measures with ensuring SMEs have access to banking services.

site_title: ECB keeps interest rates unchanged as Brexit shock fades
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) maintained its record-low interest rates unchanged, citing the need for a clearer picture on the Brexit impact before making drastic policy changes. The benchmark refinancing rate remained at zero percent, while the marginal lending facility rate and bank deposit rate remained at 0.25 percent and -0.4 percent, respectively. The ECB expects interest rates to remain at current or lower levels for an extended period.

site_title: Oil prices rise before US inventory data
summary: Oil prices rose before US inventory data, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing 63 cents to $46.13 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude rising 57 cents to $48.55 a barrel. The price rally was driven by a softer dollar, which made US oil cheaper for holders of rival currencies. US crude inventories fell 12.1 million barrels last week, and China's energy imports rose in August, raising hopes that the economy is stabilizing. A potential production cap by Opec and Russia is still uncertain, despite recent comments from key leaders.

site_title: Malaysian sovereign fund Khazanah selling stake in utility Tenaga: sources
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional Bhd is selling 82 million shares of utility company Tenaga Nasional, approximately 1.5% of its total shares outstanding, valued at up to $294 million. The sale is part of Khazanah's divestment strategy, following previous sales of stakes in IHH Healthcare Bhd and Tenaga Nasional in January. The fund holds a 29.7% stake in Tenaga, with shares closing at RM14.56 on the Kuala Lumpur stock exchange.

site_title: Oceanus signs deal with creditors to convert debt balance into equity
summary: Oceanus Group, a seafood supply chain manager, has signed a binding term sheet with two of its key creditors, Ocean Wonder International and BW Investment, to convert S$71.85 million of debt into new shares. The conversion price is between S$0.003 and S$0.02167 per share. If the third creditor, Ocean King Group, agrees, Oceanus's remaining debt will decrease from S$81.43 million to approximately S$20 million. The group plans to engage new investors and management to subscribe for new shares and aims to start a new chapter on a clean slate.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.810 points to 1,691.380. A total of 1.693 billion lots were traded, worth RM1.577 billion, with 402 gainers outnumbering 374 losers. The rally comes despite global market uncertainty due to US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns.

site_title: Singapore shares close slightly higher; STI manages to stay in the black for 2016
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,894.48, a 0.83-point gain, after a volatile session. It initially broke above 2,882 but dropped 16 points before recovering in the afternoon. The index finished the day with a net gain, despite a firm opening for Europe and gains in Hong Kong and US futures. Turnover was 1.5 billion units worth S$1 billion, with 216 rises versus 172 falls.

site_title: Pacific nations open summit with eye on climate fight
summary: Pacific island nations gathered at their annual regional summit in Micronesia, focusing on the pressing issue of climate change. The 16-nation Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) aims to combat over-exploited fisheries, poverty, and obesity, but climate change is the top concern, threatening the existence of low-lying nations like Kiribati and Tuvalu. PIF nations, including Cook Islands and Marshall Islands, vow to continue lobbying for global action on climate change, following their successful advocacy at last year's Paris climate talks.

site_title: Road map to restructure food services industry rolled out
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam launched the Food Services Industry Transformation Map (ITM), a blueprint to steer growth in the food services industry through innovative business models and technology. The ITM aims to achieve an annual productivity growth target of 2% without increasing manpower over the next five years. The initiative includes revamping traditional business models, such as coffee shops, and introducing new distribution channels like food-vending machines. The goal is to make the food services industry highly efficient and create high-quality jobs.

images.alt_text: A BLUEPRINT to steer growth in the food services industry through the adoption of innovative business models and technology has been mapped out.

site_title: Addvalue responds to SGX query on unusual trading activity
summary: Addvalue Technologies, a technology-focused investment holding company, has been approached by an unrelated third party to consider taking a significant interest in the company, potentially resulting in a change of control. The company is responding to a query from the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) regarding unusual trading activity of its shares. Addvalue maintains it is in compliance with SGX listing rules and is reaching out to the party to clarify its intention. The company's shares traded at S$0.037, up 0.2 cent or 5.7 percent, following the announcement.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady, near eight-month highs before ECB meeting
summary: European stock markets remained steady, near eight-month highs, ahead of the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1%, driven by a 20% surge in Micro Focus shares after a $8.8 billion deal with Hewlett Packard Enterprise. Despite weak growth and inflation, the ECB is expected to refrain from new stimulus, as President Mario Draghi may have exhausted its firepower.

site_title: ECB revises 2016 growth up but trims forecast for 2017, 2018: Draghi
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) revised its 2016 growth forecast to 1.7% from 1.6%, but lowered its projections for 2017 and 2018 to 1.6% each, citing uncertainties caused by the Brexit vote. ECB President Mario Draghi attributed the change to reduced trade growth. Inflation expectations remained largely unchanged at 0.2% for 2016, 1.2% for 2017, and 1.6% for 2018.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank on Thursday raised its 2016 growth forecast slightly but lowered its projections for 2017 and 2018, with bank chief Mario Draghi saying "uncertainties" caused by the Brexit vote would weigh on trade.

site_title: Australian bank fee refunds reignite calls for market power review
summary: Westpac Banking Corp refunded A$20 million to over 800,000 customers for foreign transaction fees on credit cards, following ANZ's similar move. The refunds come after a series of banking scandals and calls for a review of banks' market power. Consumer advocacy groups want to restrict the market share of major banks, with some supporting a banking Royal Commission. The issue is expected to be raised again when parliament resumes next week, amid concerns about banking practices and the need for greater transparency.

site_title: Hong Kong yuan borrowing rate spikes after highest fixing since February
summary: Hong Kong's overnight yuan borrowing rate surged to 5.446% on Thursday, its highest level since February 19, amid concerns over tighter liquidity. The CNH Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate benchmark was set by the city's Treasury Markets Association, sparking worries about economic growth and monetary policy. The rate increase may signal a shift towards more conservative monetary policies in the region.

site_title: Britain should start EU divorce talks soon, says Tusk
summary: European Council President Donald Tusk urged Britain to start EU divorce talks as soon as possible, following the country's June 23 referendum on leaving the bloc. However, Prime Minister Theresa May said Britain won't trigger Article 50 to start the exit procedure this year, citing a need for her government to come up with a negotiating stance. Tusk stated that starting negotiations "as soon as possible" would be beneficial for both parties, but May's government remains unclear on its stance.

site_title: Fitch rates UOB's Basel III Tier 2 notes 'A+'
summary: Fitch Ratings assigned a rating of "A+" to United Overseas Bank's (UOB) HK$700 million 3.19% Basel III-compliant Tier 2 subordinated notes due August 2028, citing the bank's strong financial position and compliance with regulatory requirements. The notes are issued under UOB's S$15 billion euro medium-term note programme.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Nakaso dismisses idea of buying foreign bonds
summary: Bank of Japan deputy governor Hiroshi Nakaso has dismissed the idea of the central bank buying foreign bonds to weaken the yen, stating that monetary policy is focused on domestic inflation targets, not exchange rates. This comes after some academics, including Shinzo Abe's adviser Koichi Hamada, suggested the BOJ consider buying foreign bonds.

site_title: 'Serious' blow to London banks if UK quits single market: EU commissioner
summary: The EU will not allow the UK to maintain its financial industry advantages while blocking free labor movement, EU Commissioner Valdis Dombrovskis warned. If the UK leaves the EU and single market, London's financial district will face "serious effects." The EU will not tolerate "cherry-picking" and will require the UK to implement all financial regulations, including those from the European Banking Authority. This could lead to thousands of jobs leaving the City of London if passporting rules are lost.

site_title: Nintendo turns to Mario on iPhones to top Pokemon Go's success
summary: Nintendo unveiled plans to bring Mario to iPhones as a game app, Super Mario Run, in December for the holidays. This follows years of anticipation to combine Nintendo's iconic characters with mobile gaming. The move comes after the success of Pokémon Go, a franchise partly owned by Nintendo, released in July. The introduction of Mario on iPhones is seen as a bid to top Pokémon Go's success, with Super Mario Run expected to be released just in time for the holiday season.

site_title: French central bank sees Q3 GDP growth at 0.3%, estimate unchanged
summary: France's central bank estimates the country's GDP will grow 0.3% in the third quarter, marking a return to growth after a stagnating three-month period. The Bank of France's business climate survey reported unchanged confidence indices in the industrial and services sectors, while the construction sector saw a one-point increase to its highest level since October 2011. Business executives expect activity to rise in September, despite stagnant consumer spending and investment in the second quarter.

site_title: World food prices rise to highest since May 2015 in August: FAO
summary: World food prices rose to their highest since May 2015 in August, led by dairy, oils, and sugar, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization. The FAO's food price index averaged 165.6 points, a 1.9% increase from the previous month. Global cereal production is forecast to reach nearly 2.566 billion tonnes for the 2016-17 season, 40 million tonnes higher than last year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

A blueprint for the food services industry has been rolled out, focusing on innovative business models and technology. HDB resale transactions in Singapore rose 19.5% in August, despite prices slipping 0.7%. The Zika outbreak in Singapore is not believed to be caused by a more severe strain than in the Americas. Olam International plans to issue $150 million senior notes. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed slightly higher, staying in the black for 2016. A centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia has been set up, and a new grant of up to $100,000 has been announced for tariff-hit businesses.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends lower, stocks recover on foreign buying
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.2% to 1,092.6 against the US dollar after the government indicated it would no longer monitor currency movements, raising concerns of potential intervention. The won has risen 7% against the dollar this year, putting pressure on exporters struggling with weak global demand.

site_title: No evidence Zika in Singapore more or less severe than strain in Americas: media
summary: Singapore's Zika virus cases, found in two local transmissions, are of an Asian lineage and likely evolved from a strain already in Southeast Asia, according to a health ministry analysis. The strain does not appear to be more severe than the one in Latin America, with no evidence of more severe symptoms. The analysis will be made available to the global scientific community, including the World Health Organisation.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares close lower ahead of ECB meeting
summary: Australian shares ended the day 0.7% lower, closing at 5,385.80, as investors await the European Central Bank's meeting. The ECB is expected to extend its asset purchase program by year-end, according to a Reuters poll. This move is seen as a response to pressure for further easing. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose marginally on Wednesday.

site_title: Platinum market to tighten this year, but catalyst demand to fall: WPIC
summary: The platinum market is expected to tighten more than previously forecast this year, with a 520,000-ounce deficit predicted due to a shrinking supply of mined and recycled metal. Despite a deficit, platinum prices rose nearly a quarter this year, thanks to increased investment. Automotive consumption is expected to shrink, while jewellery demand will be slightly higher. Supply from major producer South Africa is forecast to fall 6%, leading to a 3% decline in overall mining supply.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower but Nintendo soars on Apple tie-up
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower due to soft Japanese growth data, but Nintendo surged 4.3% after announcing a Super Mario game tie-up with Apple. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.32% to 16,958.77, while the Topix index lost 0.27% to 1,345.95.

site_title: Obama warns China over South China Sea ruling
summary: US President Barack Obama warned China that it cannot ignore a tribunal's ruling rejecting its claims to the South China Sea, citing the July verdict as "binding" and urging constructive dialogue to lower tensions and promote stability. The ruling rejected China's claims to most of the waters, which pass $5 trillion in global shipping trade annually, and deemed its artificial island-building activities as illegal. China has vowed to ignore the ruling, escalating tensions in the region.

site_title: Update: No evidence Zika in Singapore more or less severe than strain in Americas
summary: Singapore has detected over 280 Zika infections, with no evidence that the local strain is more severe than the one in Latin America. The country's health ministry has confirmed no link between Zika and microcephaly, a severe birth defect, unlike in Brazil where over 1,800 cases have been reported.

site_title: Euro treads water ahead of ECB policy meeting
summary: The euro remained stable ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, trading at US$1.1246 and 114.20 yen. Analysts expect the ECB to consider cutting its growth and inflation outlook, potentially leading to an extension of its asset purchase program. This would be seen as "euro negative." The eurozone's economic outlook remains tepid, with Germany's factory output disappointing. The US dollar slipped against the yen following the Federal Reserve's Beige Book report, which described July and August growth as "modest."

site_title: Iran says too early to discuss oil output freeze at Algiers
summary: Iran's state-oil company says it's too early to discuss freezing crude output at the upcoming Algiers meeting of global producers. Iran aims to reach pre-sanctions levels of 2.35 million barrels per day, which it expects to achieve by the end of 2016 or early next year. Iran's current output is 3.8 million barrels per day, and the nation is expected to maintain its current level until it reaches its target. Oil prices are stable at around $40-$50 per barrel, according to Iranian officials, who say the market is in a stable condition and that production costs are less than $10 per barrel.

site_title: AB InBev, Asahi among suitors for Vietnam's biggest brewery
summary: Several major brewers, including Heineken, Anheuser-Busch InBev, Asahi, and Kirin, are vying to acquire a stake in Vietnam's largest brewery, Sabeco. The Dutch brewer Heineken, along with its merger partner SABMiller, and Japanese brewer Asahi, have expressed interest in acquiring a stake in the company, which is valued at at least $1.8 billion. The Vietnamese government plans to sell its entire 89.59% stake in Sabeco in two tranches, with the first sale expected in 2016.

site_title: Oil-battered Norway turns to booming housing market refuge
summary: Norway's economy is experiencing a boost from a booming housing market, which has risen 12% over the past two years, surpassing oil and gas spending. This growth is driven by record low interest rates and has helped spare the economy from recession. The housing sector's relative weight is expected to increase, with home prices rising 10% annually and housing starts up 20% over the past year. The central bank has cut interest rates and signaled further easing to support the economy, which has become increasingly reliant on the housing sector.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges down on government warnings, stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won decreased 0.4% to 1,093.8 as of 0159 GMT on Thursday, following government warnings about market volatility. Foreign exchange authorities are closely monitoring the situation, citing the won's increased volatility compared to other Asian currencies. The move comes after the government issued verbal warnings about the market's moves for the second consecutive day.

site_title: New era for F1 as Liberty agrees US$8b takeover
summary: Liberty Media, led by US billionaire John Malone, has agreed to a US$8 billion takeover of Formula One, valuing the sport at the new enterprise value. The deal will be completed next year, pending regulatory and shareholder approval. Liberty Media will retain Formula One CEO Bernie Ecclestone and appoint 21st Century Fox vice chairman Chase Carey as chairman. The takeover marks a new era for Formula One, with questions over Ecclestone's future role and the sport's financial and fanbase challenges.

site_title: Gold holds near three-week high as odds drop for Fed rate rise
summary: Gold prices held near a three-week high as weaker US economic data reduced the likelihood of a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase this month. The metal traded at $1,346.53 an ounce, with demand surging for haven assets following the Fed's hesitation. Odds for a September rate hike dropped to 22%, while the probability for December remained at 52%. Analysts expect gold to rise further if the Fed defers or hikes rates by 25 basis points.

images.alt_text: Gold held near its three-week high as weaker US economic data damps prospects for an interest-rate increase this month by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.16% in the opening minutes on Thursday, September 8, 2016, as investors awaited Chinese trade data release. The Hang Seng Index dropped 36.85 points to 23,704.96, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.06% to 3,089.95.

site_title: Russian jet came within 3 metres of US spy plane: US officials
summary: A Russian Sukhoi Su-27 fighter jet intercepted a US Navy P-8 surveillance plane flying a regular patrol over the Black Sea, coming within 3.05 meters of the American aircraft. The incident occurred at a time of heightened tensions between the US and Russia, who are on opposing sides of the Syrian civil war. The Russian jet's behavior was deemed "unsafe and unprofessional" by US officials, who are reviewing the incident to determine whether it will be included in a US-Russia meeting about serious intercepts.

site_title: Qantas, Virgin Australia ground Samsung Note 7 after recall
summary: Australian carriers Qantas and Virgin Australia have grounded Samsung Note 7 devices on flights due to faulty batteries that can cause explosions. The move follows Samsung's global recall of 2.5 million units after reports of exploding smartphones. The carriers advise passengers not to use or charge the devices during flights, affecting domestic and international flights. This is the first recall for Samsung's top-of-the-range phone, which was released just before arch-rival Apple's iPhone 7.

site_title: Asia leaders tiptoe around South China Sea tensions
summary: Asian leaders issued a statement on tensions over the South China Sea, downplaying regional strains while refraining from directly addressing China's claims. The draft statement, agreed upon by 10 South-east Asian nations and US President Barack Obama, reaffirmed the importance of maintaining peace and freedom of navigation in the strategic waterway. However, the statement avoided mentioning a court ruling that invalidated China's claims to the sea. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang expressed willingness to work with South-east Asian countries to "dispel interference" from outside powers, while the US has been conducting patrols near Chinese-held islands to ensure freedom of navigation.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines' passenger traffic slips in Q2, expects smaller FY loss
summary: Malaysia Airlines reported a decline in passenger loads in Q2, with a 0.3 percentage point drop in its load factor to 68.6%. Despite lower demand, the airline expects a smaller-than-expected annual loss due to cost savings. Booking patterns have strengthened, and business class loads are expected to improve in the last quarter of the year. CEO Peter Bellew plans to increase marketing and sales initiatives and cut costs in the second half of 2016 to compete with intense global and domestic competition. The airline aims to become sustainably profitable by 2018.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines Bhd on Thursday reported a decline in passenger loads in the traditionally slower second quarter, but said cost savings would help it post a smaller-than-expected annual loss.

site_title: Apple hones marketing for Watch with focus on fitness
summary: Apple has released a second-generation Apple Watch, focusing on fitness and athletic features, aiming to appeal to its core audience. The new device starts at $369 and includes a GPS chip and is waterproof, with a special edition designed by Nike. While the new features are well-received, analysts predict the watch will remain a niche product, generating $4.1 billion in revenue for Apple this year. A breakthrough app is still needed to bring the smartwatch into the mainstream, and analysts question whether Pokémon Go will be the solution.

site_title: Dyna-Mac floats proposal to noteholders
summary: Dyna-Mac, a module fabrication yard operator, has proposed a call option to noteholders for the S$50 million Series 001 medium-term notes maturing in August 2017. The company is seeking approval for a call option that would allow it to redeem all outstanding notes at 99% of their principal amount, plus accrued interest. Noteholders must respond by September 28 to the consent solicitation exercise, and those voting in favor will receive a 0.10% consent fee. The proposed purchase price for the notes is 100% of their principal amount.

site_title: Global steel industry wins reprieve as Chinese exports contract
summary: China's steel exports dropped to 9 million metric tons in August, the lowest level since February, providing relief to the global steel industry amid concerns over a growing glut of the metal. Despite this, China's steel shipments for the first eight months reached a record high of 76.35 million tons, a 6.3% gain from last year. The drop in exports follows a pledge by the Group of 20 leaders to establish a global forum on steel overcapacity, amid criticism of China's record exports.

site_title: China CFOs are swapping dollars for the yuan in statements
summary: Chinese companies listed in Hong Kong are shifting from reporting earnings in US dollars to the yuan, citing reduced impact of currency fluctuations. Want Want China Holdings Ltd and Hengan International Group Co made the switch, while China Resources Beer (Holdings) Co cited the move to simplify reporting. Analysts attribute the shift to the yuan's growing international importance and China's currency devaluation, which has fallen 9.2% against the US dollar since 2014. The yuan is expected to decline further by the end of December.

site_title: Hong Kong land prices baffle tycoon with 50 years experience
summary: Hong Kong land prices have left billionaire Lui Che-Woo, with over 50 years of experience in the industry, bewildered. Despite submitting 16 land bids, he failed to win any, as large developers have become cautious due to the market's uncertainty. Mainland Chinese firms and smaller local companies have outbid Hong Kong developers, with prices reaching nearly twice the expected valuation.
