site_title: Keppel Land to jointly develop Yangon serviced residences
summary: Keppel Land has signed a conditional joint venture agreement with Shwe Taung Group to develop premium serviced residences and offices in Yangon's Junction City. The US$48.6 million investment will be held by Keppel Land, which will own 40% of the project. The development, set to start construction in 2018, will feature 260 serviced apartments and a gross floor area of 50,000 sq m. This marks the next phase of the Junction City project, following the successful completion of the 23-storey Grade A office building in 2016.

site_title: UK factory output posts biggest drop in a year after Brexit vote
summary: British manufacturing output fell 0.9% in July, the largest drop in a year, following the Brexit vote. However, overall industrial output unexpectedly rose 0.1% due to strong oil and gas production. The data confirms earlier signs that factories took an immediate hit after the EU referendum. Economists had expected a 0.4% drop, and there is no immediate benefit from the devaluation of the pound. The Bank of England is expected to cut interest rates again later this year due to a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: British manufacturing output fell in July at the fastest pace in a year, confirming earlier signs that factories took an immediate hit after the vote to leave the European Union, official data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Renault's Turkey unit to begin production of new sedan
summary: Renault's Turkish unit Oyak-Renault will begin production of the Megane sedan model with a 200 million euro investment. The Istanbul-based company aims to produce 500,000 sedans annually, with 90,000 units produced locally and 80% exported. Oyak-Renault is 51% owned by Renault and 49% by Oyak, the Turkish military's pension fund.

site_title: VW to explore new green car venture with China's JAC Motor
summary: Volkswagen AG signed a preliminary deal with China's Anhui Jianghuai Automobile (JAC Motor) to explore a new joint venture for electric and hybrid cars. The two companies aim to sign a formal agreement within five months. This partnership follows China's rapid growth in electric car sales, with sales more than quadrupling last year. The investment size and business model of the joint venture have not been finalized, and a final agreement will be subject to approvals and filing procedures. Volkswagen is locked in a competitive market in China, where it is tied with US automaker General Motors for the largest market share.

site_title: Elected presidency review: Safeguard needed if no minority president after five terms
summary: A Singapore constitutional commission report recommends introducing a safeguard mechanism to ensure a minority president is elected after five terms, if free and unregulated elections do not produce one. The proposal comes after a period of 30 years, with the last minority president, SR Nathan, serving from 1999 to 2011. The report also suggests revising the eligibility criteria for presidential candidates to include those with S$500 million in shareholders' equity and enhancing the role and powers of the Council of Presidential Advisors.

site_title: China's top steel city cuts industrial production to clear air
summary: China's top steelmaking city, Tangshan, has ordered industrial plants to cut production for two weeks due to pollution concerns. This is the third suspension since July, affecting steel mills, power plants, and cement producers that fail to meet emissions standards. The move is part of China's efforts to tackle overcapacity and pollution, with the country aiming to cut 45 million tonnes of steel capacity this year. The city will also strengthen inspections of emissions, following global pressure to address China's record steel exports and G20 leaders' pledge to tackle excess capacity.

images.alt_text: China's top steelmaking city of Tangshan has told industrial plants to cut production for two weeks from Saturday, its third such suspension since July, as Beijing battles overcapacity and pollution, according to a document seen by Reuters.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine to meet noteholders to discuss options as notes' maturity nears
summary: Marco Polo Marine has appointed KPMG Services as its adviser to conduct an independent business review ahead of the maturity date of its Series 001 S$50 million notes on Oct 18. The company will hold an informal meeting with noteholders on Sept 13 to discuss options. This comes as the notes' maturity date approaches, and the company aims to present a review to noteholders and explore various options. Marco Polo Marine is an integrated marine logistics group with businesses including ship chartering and repair services.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 1.8% in 2016, according to a Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) poll. The new Funan mall will feature retail innovation and a new live-work-play paradigm. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that while RCEP negotiations have slowed, it remains a feasible alternative for an Asia-Pacific free-trade area. The Singapore Exchange reported a total market capitalisation value of S$909.7 billion for its listed companies at end-August, while Apple is set to release the iPhone 7, with many consumers and investors looking forward to the iPhone 8.

site_title: China August forex reserves fall to US$3.19 trillion, lowest since 2011
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell to $3.19 trillion in August, the lowest level since 2011, according to central bank data. The reserves dropped by $15.89 billion, the largest decline since May. This marks a decrease in line with market expectations and economists' predictions. The drop may raise pressure on policymakers, as China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank holds key rate, sees steady growth track ahead
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, kept its key interest rate at 3.00% on Wednesday, as expected, despite the country's second-quarter growth slipping to 4%, the slowest in nearly seven years. The bank expressed optimism that the economy will remain on a steady growth path in 2017, citing sufficient economic activity. This decision aims to support the economy without hindering growth, maintaining the current growth trajectory.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end down after four-day rally
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.19% to 23,741.81 after a four-day rally, following data showing a decline in US services sector activity last month. The Shanghai Composite Index edged up 1.22 points, while the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.18%. The decline in Hong Kong stocks follows a global rally, with other markets also experiencing fluctuations.

site_title: Asia: Stocks hit 1-year high as soft US data quells Fed hike talk
summary: Asian stocks reached a one-year high as US services sector data showed weaker-than-expected activity, quelling expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike this month. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.4%, while the US dollar fell against other currencies. The data led investors to shift their focus to emerging markets and Asia for yields, with the Fed now likely to keep interest rates on hold this month.

site_title: Amazon to start restaurant deliveries in London
summary: Amazon is launching its "Amazon Restaurants" service in London, offering meal deliveries from partner restaurants to Prime subscribers, with free delivery over £15. This move enters a competitive market dominated by Just East, UberEats, and Deliveroo. The service is available in some parts of London, providing customers with a convenient option for restaurant meals without leaving their homes.

site_title: Germany's Merkel hits back at critics of immigration policy
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has defended her country's immigration policy, stating that the situation is better now than a year ago. She vowed to strengthen security at home and speed up repatriations of migrants denied asylum. Merkel also defended her handling of German-Turkish relations and a European Union deal with Turkey to curb migrant flow, calling it a model for other countries. Her comments came after her conservative party lost ground to the anti-immigrant Alternative for Germany party in a regional election.

site_title: Small car COE premium softens
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums have softened in the first bidding exercise of September. Category A premiums for cars below 1,600 cc or 130 hp fell to S$51,506, while Category B premiums for cars above 1,600 cc and 130 hp rose to S$57,002. Category C, for goods vehicles, spiked up to S$49,801, driven by a smaller quota. The decrease in Category C's quota is the largest in percentage terms, dropping by 23.2% to 350 COEs per month.

images.alt_text: CERTIFICATE of entitlement (COE) premiums were mixed after the first bidding exercise in September, with the commercial vehicle category's relatively sharp rise standing out.

site_title: Malaysia confirms first case of Zika in pregnant woman
summary: Malaysia has confirmed its first case of the Zika virus in a pregnant 27-year-old woman. This marks the first locally transmitted case of the virus in the country. The Zika virus has been linked to microcephaly and other brain abnormalities in pregnant women. This case comes after the country previously confirmed an imported case of Zika in a 58-year-old woman who had visited Singapore.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady near 8-month high
summary: European shares remained near an eight-month high on Wednesday, supported by a rise in Weir Group and positive company results, despite weak data from Germany, which saw its industrial production fall for the first time in 23 months. The Stoxx Europe 600 index remained flat at 349.43, hindered by weak data from the US.

site_title: Malaysia-bound AirAsia X plane ends up in Melbourne
summary: An AirAsia X plane bound for Malaysia took off from Sydney on March 10, 2016, but ended up in Melbourne after the pilot entered the wrong longitudinal position, causing the aircraft to fly in the wrong direction. The pilot attempted to fix the issue but further degraded the navigation system, leading to a manual landing in Melbourne. An investigation by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau found that the plane was not equipped with an upgraded flight management system that could have prevented the data entry error. The incident led to changes in training for AirAsia X pilots.

site_title: China regulator launches rules curbing insurance product risks
summary: China's insurance regulator launched new rules to curb the growth of short and mid-term life insurance products, aiming to reduce risks from insurers investing in stocks. The rules require annual insurance premiums for these products to be less than two times the insurer's invested capital or net assets. Additionally, premiums for products with terms between one and three years should comprise only 50% of total premiums by 2018. Higher pay-out rates were also set for life insurance and personal care insurance. The move aims to prevent sudden liquidity crises during market volatility.

site_title: Taiwan tourism industry hit by drop in Chinese visitors
summary: Taiwan's tourism industry is experiencing a 22% decline in Chinese visitors since President Tsai Ing-wen took office in May, with thousands of tour buses sitting idle. The decline is attributed to China limiting tour groups to Taiwan amid cooling cross-strait ties. The industry is struggling to survive, with hotels only half-full and tour operators seeking government help. A protest is planned for September 12 to attract thousands of demonstrators. The decline in visitors is expected to have a significant impact on the island's economy, with many businesses struggling to repay loans.

site_title: UK house prices extend losses in August: Halifax
summary: British house prices fell 0.2% in August, marking a second consecutive month of decline, and taking the annual growth rate to 6.9%, its lowest in over a year. The drop follows a 1.1% decline in July. Economists had forecast a 0.4% monthly fall, but the slowdown in house price growth is consistent with previous forecasts, attributed to increasing difficulties in purchasing a home due to rising prices outpacing earnings.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Stocks close higher on Wednesday
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% higher on Wednesday, driven by a strong economic expansion in the April-June quarter. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 10.6 points to 5,424.2, boosted by surging exports, pre-election government spending, and modest gains in household spending and home building.

site_title: Seoul: Won soars to year-plus high, stocks reverse course
summary: The South Korean won reached its highest level in over a year, closing at 1,090.0 to the US dollar, after weak US economic data reduced the chances of a Federal Reserve rate hike. South Korean shares, however, declined 0.2% on the Kospi index, despite offshore investors buying 86.9 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The dollar slump was attributed to the weak US economic data, which may impact the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates later this month.

site_title: German industrial production takes surprise tumble
summary: Germany's industrial production unexpectedly fell 1.5% in July, according to official data, far short of the predicted 0.1% expansion. This marks a sharp decline amid sluggish global demand, fuelling concerns of a further cooling of the economy. The drop corrected for price, calendar, and seasonal effects, with July's production being lower than the previous month.

images.alt_text: Industrial production in Germany unexpectedly fell back sharply in July amid sluggish global demand, official data showed Wednesday, fuelling concern of a "further cooling" of the economy.

site_title: US said to weigh HSBC charge that could upend 2012 settlement
summary: The US Justice Department is considering a criminal charge against a unit of HSBC Holdings Plc for improper trading on its foreign-exchange desk, potentially upending a 2012 settlement that allowed the bank to avoid prosecution. The bank admitted in 2012 to helping Mexican drug cartels launder money and doing business with Iran and other sanctioned nations. A deferred-prosecution agreement, which required HSBC to improve internal controls, is at risk of being terminated if prosecutors determine the bank breached its terms. If a charge is filed, it could lead to a conviction and threaten the bank's ability to move beyond its legal troubles.

site_title: Philippines to lift restrictions on rice imports by 2017
summary: The Philippines will lift its restrictions on rice imports by 2017, complying with a World Trade Organization (WTO) agreement. The country will no longer seek extensions to its quantitative restrictions, which set tariffs at 35% and cap annual imports at 805,200 tonnes. This decision aims to introduce competition in the domestic market, encouraging local farmers to improve efficiency. The restrictions had been in place since 1995, with previous extensions granted until June 2017.

site_title: This paint from Kansai can repel mosquitoes
summary: A Japanese-based firm, Kansai Paint, has developed a mosquito repellent paint suitable for Singapore's equatorial climate. The ALES Anti-MosQ paint uses synthetic pyrethroid insecticides to repel mosquitoes, including the Zika-carrying Aedes aegypti mosquito, with over 80% success rate. Approved by the National Environmental Agency, the paint is the sole anti-mosquito paint in Singapore for commercial sale, and has secured contracts for 18 HDB blocks. The product is deemed non-lethal to humans and has been tested for skin and oral consumption.

site_title: Malaysia exports tumble the most in 15 months, put central bank in play
summary: Malaysia's exports declined 5.3% in July, the largest drop in 15 months, amid persistent pressure on the export-reliant economy. This slump, combined with tepid domestic demand, led to a 4.8% fall in imports. The central bank may not cut interest rates again at its upcoming meeting, despite economists predicting a rate cut before year-end due to soft growth and weak sales to key trading partner China.

site_title: Progress for RCEP has slowed, but still viable: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that despite slowed RCEP negotiations, the agreement remains a viable alternative for a free-trade area in the Asia-Pacific region. Lee emphasized the need for all RCEP members to engage their domestic stakeholders on the benefits of the arrangement. He highlighted trade, terrorism, and unity issues that Asean must address, while RCEP negotiations continue.

site_title: Duterte outbursts taking toll as Philippine stock losses mount
summary: Philippine stocks have declined for a third day, losing 1.2% to 7,624.25, amid speculation that President Rodrigo Duterte's outbursts are hurting investor sentiment. Foreign funds have pulled $276 million from local shares in a 10-day run, with the Philippine Stock Exchange Index falling 5.9% from its 15-month high. Analysts attribute the decline to uncertainty over US interest rates, elevated valuations, and Duterte's unpredictable behavior, which may disrupt the economy and business.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei falls as yen firms after weak US data
summary: Japanese stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Nikkei index ending 0.4% lower at 17,012.44, after a strengthening yen hit exporters and cyclical shares. Weak US service sector data reduced the chances of a US interest rate increase, supporting the yen's value. The Topix index dropped 0.2% to 1,349.53 and the JPX-Nikkei Index 400 fell 0.3% to 12,119.24.

site_title: China's online chatter muted ahead of Apple iPhone 7 launch
summary: China's online chatter about the upcoming Apple iPhone 7 launch is muted, with many consumers expressing a wait-and-see approach due to concerns about minor updates. In contrast to last year's iPhone 6, which generated 15 times more comments, the current model has drawn fewer comments on Sina Weibo. Apple's sales in China have been declining, with revenue dropping by over a quarter in the April-June period. Experts attribute this to "iPhone fatigue" and fierce competition from local vendors, with some predicting a decline of 20% in iPhone shipments in the second half of the year.

site_title: Daimler to sell Mercedes-Benz branded all-electric battery cars in China
summary: Daimler AG plans to sell Mercedes-Benz branded all-electric battery cars in China, capitalizing on government initiatives to grow the market for new-energy vehicles. The company's China chief, Hubertus Troska, stated that the government's push has led to over 300,000 NEVs sold last year, making China the world's biggest market for electric vehicles. Daimler aims to capitalize on this trend and expand its presence in the Chinese market, with a focus on higher-end electric cars and plug-in hybrids.

site_title: Australia terror threat is real, after lone wolf attacks urged: PM
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has confirmed the country's terror threat is "real" after the Islamic State urged followers to target Sydney's Bondi and the Melbourne Cricket Ground. The threat level is considered "probable," and authorities are taking the situation seriously. Officials have stopped 10 terror attacks in Australia over the past two years, and police are monitoring the situation closely. The threat does not change Australia's fundamentals, and authorities will continue to learn from incidents to keep Australians safer.

site_title: Vietnam's 'Silicon Valley' sparks startup boom
summary: Vietnam's startup sector has experienced significant growth, driven by local techies trained overseas who are returning home to develop apps, mobile games, and e-commerce software for the local market. The sector has caught the attention of foreign firms, with French President Francois Hollande visiting Ho Chi Minh City to meet tech investors. The country's large, young, and growing population, combined with rapid internet expansion, has created a lucrative market for startups. However, challenges such as red tape and murky laws remain, and some observers warn that it may take several years for Vietnam's startup culture to mature.

site_title: Oil prices up in Asia as US dollar weakens
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia due to a weaker US dollar, with West Texas Intermediate up 34 cents to $45.17 and Brent crude up 29 cents to $47.55. However, optimism about an upcoming Opec meeting to limit output was tempered by officials' vague comments, fueling doubts about a deal. Iran's President Hassan Rouhani expressed support for stabilizing the oil market, while Saudi Arabia and Russia said they would work together to boost oil prices, but stopped short of committing to a production freeze. A meeting in Algeria is set for three weeks.

site_title: India not ready to privatise public sector banks: Jaitley
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley stated that the country is not ready to privatize public sector banks, as public opinion has not converged on the issue. The government is consolidating public sector banks to strengthen them, but plans to maintain a state share of at least 52%.

site_title: Seoul: Won rises to 3-week high, stocks firm on weak US data
summary: The South Korean won reached a three-week high against the US dollar after weak US economic data, which dented expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike this month. The won rose 1% to 1,094.6, while US stocks also edged up, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) up 0.3% at 2,072.80 points. The weak US data, including a 6-1/2-year low in services sector activity, led to a decline in the US dollar, supporting the won's gains.

site_title: Australia marks 25 years of unbroken economic growth
summary: Australia's economy has marked 25 years of unbroken growth, with a 0.5% increase in the June quarter driven by government spending and household spending, offsetting a decline in net exports. Annual growth stands at 3.3%, in line with expectations. Treasurer Scott Morrison cautioned against complacency, while chief economist Paul Dales welcomed the result, saying it eases pressure for further interest rate cuts. The Reserve Bank held interest rates steady at 1.50% amid the transition towards non-resources growth.

site_title: Thailand 'supports' China's efforts to maintain maritime peace
summary: Thailand expressed support for China's efforts to maintain maritime peace in the South China Sea, a region disputed by China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Brunei. The statement came after the Philippines released images of Chinese boats near a disputed shoal. Thailand's neutral stance on the issue was reiterated, with a government spokesman saying discussions should reduce mistrust and promote peace for all parties involved. The international arbitration panel previously ruled that China's artificial island-building was illegal and its claims had no legal basis.

site_title: PSA Peugeot Citroen opens new plant in China
summary: PSA Peugeot Citroen has opened its fifth plant in China, a joint venture with Dongfeng Motors, in Chengdu, Sichuan province. The new factory, producing 300,000 vehicles annually, aims to boost sales by catering to the growing demand for sport-utility vehicles. The company's sales in China have declined 20% in the first half of the year, but the new plant is expected to help increase sales. The factory's opening is seen as a strategic move to expand PSA's offerings and increase its market share in the country.

site_title: North Korean nuclear envoy visits China: Yonhap
summary: A senior North Korean diplomat, Choe Son Hui, visited China, amid international condemnation of the country's ballistic missile test launches. The UN Security Council issued a fresh rebuke, with China endorsing the criticism. This visit comes as China joins the international pressure on North Korea, following its nuclear programme. Choe's visit is seen as a significant development, highlighting the strained relations between North Korea and its main diplomatic ally, China.

site_title: Economists still expect Singapore GDP growth of 1.8% for 2016: MAS poll
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 1.8% in 2016, according to a MAS poll of 22 private sector economists, unchanged from the June survey. The economy expanded 2.1% in Q2, beating the median forecast, and is expected to expand 1.7% in Q3. Median inflation forecasts for 2016 fell to -0.5%, while core inflation is expected to be 1%. The unemployment rate is projected to be 2.2% at year-end, with GDP growth also expected to remain at 1.8% in 2017.

site_title: Aussie pauses after 5-day rally; NZ dollar firm
summary: The Australian dollar paused at US$0.7673 after a 1.4% gain on Tuesday, marking its fifth consecutive day of advancement. The currency is up 5% this year, driven by offshore interest in carry trades. Downbeat US economic data and a weaker US dollar boosted the Aussie. Meanwhile, the New Zealand dollar rose strongly due to stronger dairy prices and a weaker US dollar. The kiwi currency is now leading global commodity currencies.

site_title: New Funan mall to feature retail innovation, new live-work-play paradigm
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust announced plans for a new mall called "Funan" set to open in the fourth quarter of 2019. The mall will feature retail innovation, a live-work-play paradigm, and a mobile-first digital platform. It will offer online-to-offline retail services, including a drive-through and click-and-collect service, and feature smart car parking and access systems. The mall will have a total gross floor area of 887,000 sq ft, with retail, office, and co-living spaces. The development aims to support Singapore's move towards a car-lite society and promote healthy living.

site_title: New Zealand's largest media firms NZME and Fairfax Media NZ sign merger deal
summary: New Zealand's largest media firms NZME and Fairfax Media NZ have signed a merger deal, combining audiences of 3.7 million, or 80% of the country's population. The merger aims to enhance integrated offerings to audiences and advertising clients, and increase competitiveness in digital advertising. However, concerns have been raised about job losses and reduced competition in the already concentrated media sector. The deal still needs approval from the competition watchdog and will be put to shareholders in October or November.

site_title: Stranded Hanjin fleet delivers Japan shippers brief reprieve
summary: A South Korean shipping company's filing for court protection has temporarily boosted Japanese shippers' profits and reduced bond risk. The Shanghai Shipping Exchange index has risen, with Kawasaki Kisen's bond yield dropping to its lowest since June. However, analysts predict that Hanjin's troubles will not be a long-term benefit, as the company's ships are likely to resume operations in a month. Freight rates may rise as a result of the filing, leading to increased competition in the sector.

site_title: Australia shares up, aided by solid GDP data; NZ hits a record
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,424.4, tracking US Wall Street, after data showed the economy expanded 3.3% in the April-June quarter, just short of forecasts. New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record high, up 0.7%, driven by gains in cyclicals and staples. US interest rate expectations dropped to 15% following slower-than-expected service sector growth, and the US jobs report.

site_title: Opec giants are too sour for top oil buyer in coveted market
summary: Opec's largest producers, including Saudi Arabia and Iran, are losing market share to smaller suppliers in the Asia-Pacific region due to their sour crude oil. China's private refineries prefer 'sweeter' cargoes with lower sulfur content, which are more easily processed. This shift is attributed to Zhang Liucheng, director of Shandong Dongming Petrochemical Group, who stated that the independent companies are seeking more desirable crude oil. As a result, Opec's influence in the coveted Asian market is diminishing.

site_title: Singapore's ViewQwest to offer Internet services in Malaysia
summary: Singaporean internet service provider ViewQwest has announced a joint venture with Malaysian telecom engineering services firm Televenture to offer internet services in Malaysia. ViewQwest, the first Singaporean ISP to do so, will provide fibre broadband access and enterprise networking services. The company will launch its 1Gbps fibre broadband service for select residential homes by the end of 2016, making it the fastest residential broadband service in Malaysia. This marks a significant expansion into the Malaysian market for ViewQwest, which has already started selling its services in select areas since July 2016.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 9.420 points to 1,680.350. The market saw a 40.024 million lots worth RM39.73 million, with 92 gainers outnumbering 70 losers.

site_title: Clinton, Trump war of words escalates as race narrows
summary: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump intensified their verbal attacks as the US presidential election nears its end, with Clinton branding Trump a "demagogue" and Trump accusing Clinton of choking. New polls show a dead heat between the two candidates, with Trump leading in some surveys and Clinton maintaining a six-point lead in others. The candidates clashed on issues such as immigration, national security, and tax returns, with Clinton accusing Trump of hiding something and Trump labeling Clinton as "temperamentally unfit" for office.

site_title: Brent oil holds losses amid speculation global glut persisting
summary: Brent oil futures remained stable despite speculation of a global glut, after the world's largest producers failed to agree on output limits. US crude stockpiles likely expanded by 705,000 barrels last week, and Saudi Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih stated there's no need to freeze output. The lack of concrete steps from producers has led to ongoing concerns about a persistent global glut, resulting in minimal price changes for Brent oil.

site_title: Total market cap of SGX-listed companies stands at S$909.7b at end-August
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a total market capitalization value of S$909.7 billion for its 767 listed companies as of end-August. The market turnover value decreased by 2% month-on-month and 27% year-on-year to S$20.6 billion in August. Daily average securities value fell by 11% month-on-month and 37% year-on-year.

site_title: Malaysians to protest against scandal-tainted PM
summary: Malaysian opposition group Bersih plans to hold a rally in November to protest against Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is under fire over alleged involvement in looting billions of dollars in state funds. The group, which has staged large demonstrations in the past, demands Najib's resignation. The rally's date will be announced on September 14. The US Justice Department has filed lawsuits alleging a massive international conspiracy by Najib's relatives and associates to steal from a state-owned investment fund. The protest comes as Najib denies any wrongdoing and faces mounting calls for accountability.

site_title: Korean won rises with Malaysian ringgit as Fed seen holding fire
summary: South Korea's won jumped 1.2% to 1,092.35 per US dollar, its largest intraday gain since August 10, following disappointing US services data that reduced the odds of a Federal Reserve interest-rate hike in September. The Malaysian ringgit also rose 0.6% to 4.0595 per US dollar, its biggest one-day gain in a month. The decline in US Treasury yields and the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index's worst day in almost six weeks contributed to the Asian currency surge. Bank Negara Malaysia is expected to keep the overnight policy rate at 3% on Wednesday.

site_title: Tens of thousands of jobs go as China's biggest banks cut costs
summary: China's four biggest banks reported a 1.5% decline in staff numbers to 1.62 million workers in the first half, the largest drop in at least six years. Analysts expect the workforce to "dwindle" due to technological advances and cost-cutting measures. The decline is attributed to an economic slowdown, rising bad loans, and increased competition from online and mobile players. Staff compensation costs also fell 2.6% from last year, with some banks experiencing larger declines.

site_title: UK seeks to avoid Iraq mistakes in bid for Syria peace
summary: British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson has called for the removal of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad to avoid the turmoil that followed the 2003 ousting of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Johnson argues that Assad is a weak leader who cannot hold his country together after the atrocities he has committed. Johnson's comments come ahead of talks with the Syrian opposition, with the goal of finding a peaceful solution to the conflict. The UK seeks to learn from past mistakes and find a more stable solution in Syria.

site_title: Gold holds biggest jump since Brexit vote on lower Fed rate bets
summary: Gold surged 1.7% to $1,349.16 an ounce, its largest daily increase since the Brexit vote, as the dollar weakened amid diminished bets on a September interest-rate rise. The Federal Reserve's non-manufacturing index slumped, reducing the likelihood of a policy tightening. The dollar traded at its lowest level this month, fueling gold's rally, which is expected to continue before the Fed's Sept 20-21 meeting. Analysts attribute the price surge to the dollar's weakness, with one stating the US dollar may weaken a little and gold firm up before the Fed's decision.

site_title: Fed's Williams says economy is in good shape and hike warranted
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President John Williams stated the US economy is in good shape and headed in the right direction. He believes a gradual rate increase is warranted, arguing that delaying rate hikes could allow imbalances to grow and limit the Fed's ability to respond in the next downturn. Williams pointed to declining unemployment and inflation near its target of 2% as evidence that the economy is on track. This stance contradicts recent disappointing data and investors' reduced bets on an interest-rate increase later this month.

site_title: Asean, China agree on key South China Sea issues
summary: Asean and China reached agreements on unplanned encounters and hotline communications in the South China Sea at the 19th Asean-China summit in Vientiane, Laos. The agreements come as the 25th anniversary of Asean-China dialogue is commemorated, despite a recent international ruling against Beijing's territorial claims. The agreements aim to manage risks and establish emergency communication channels among senior diplomats. Formalizing a binding protocol is expected by mid-2017, as the two sides look to maintain positive relations, with Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressing optimism about the agreements.

site_title: US Senate blocks Zika funding for third time
summary: The US Senate blocked a $1.1 billion bill to combat the Zika virus for the third time, with 52 Republicans voting against the measure and 46 Democrats. The bill's failure was due to Republican provisions that would end funding for Planned Parenthood and allow Confederate flags to fly at military cemeteries. Funding is now expected to be included in a bipartisan stopgap spending bill. President Barack Obama urged Congress to fund the fight against Zika, citing concerns about the virus spreading and putting Americans at risk.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing sales volumes rise 2.8% on quarter
summary: New Zealand manufacturing sales volumes rose 2.8% in the second quarter, with dairy and meat products experiencing a 8.6% increase. This follows a 6.7% decline in the March quarter. The growth in dairy and meat manufacturing sales is attributed to a rebound from a previous decline.

site_title: Apple sets stage for iPhone 7, many already waiting for 8
summary: Apple is set to unveil the iPhone 7 on Wednesday, but many are already looking forward to the 2017 iPhone 8, expecting significant advances. The new iPhone is expected to feature a headphone jack removal, touch-sensitive home button, double-lens cameras, and other incremental improvements. This will be the second major redesign of the iPhone since the iPhone 6 in 2014, with Apple typically updating its main product every other year.

images.alt_text: The iPhone 7 is expected to make its global debut on Wednesday, but many consumers and investors are already setting their sights on Apple Inc's 2017 version of the popular gadget, hoping for more significant advances.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks flat in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Wednesday, edging up 10.07 points to 23,797.75, after four days of gains. The Shanghai Composite Index was also barely moved, and the Shenzhen Composite Index inched down 0.01 points. A weak US services sector reading further doused expectations for an interest rate hike.

site_title: LG seeks mobile spark from new V20 smartphone
summary: LG Electronics Inc unveiled its new V20 premium smartphone on Wednesday, seeking a mobile spark in the second half after continuing losses from its smartphone business. The V20 features a 5.7 inch display, metal body, replaceable battery, dual rear cameras, and improved photo and video functions. The phone's success will be crucial for LG's mobile division, which reported a fifth straight quarterly operating loss in April-June. LG did not disclose pricing for the V20, which aims to compete with Samsung's Galaxy S7 phones.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 1.03% and the Topix index down 0.99%. The yen surged against the dollar due to diminished US rate hike odds, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Rickmers offered US$260.2m restructured loan facility to refinance debts
summary: Rickmers Maritime has been offered a restructured secured amortising term loan facility of up to US$260.2 million to refinance its outstanding debt. The new facility, conditional upon restructuring of 2017 notes, would extend maturities to 2021 and include a moratorium on principal repayments. The trust is also considering a debt exchange with noteholders to exchange existing principal for new perpetual convertible securities. This move aims to align stakeholder interests and improve long-term solvency amidst adverse industry conditions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Mall Trust, Rickmers, SGX, China Minzhong Food
summary: Singapore stocks saw significant developments, including CapitaLand Mall Trust announcing its new Funan mall, which will be a retail and tech hub, and Rickmers Maritime securing a restructured secured loan facility to refinance its debt. Meanwhile, Singapore Exchange reported a 2% month-on-month decline in turnover value to S$20.6 billion in August, and China Minzhong Food submitted a pre-conditional offer to acquire the company at S$1.20 per share.

site_title: Bosch concealed VW use of 'defeat device' software: lawyers
summary: Lawyers for American Volkswagen owners alleged that Robert Bosch GmbH concealed the use of VW's "defeat device" software, which deactivated pollution controls on over 11 million diesel vehicles. Bosch allegedly demanded legal protection in 2008 for its role in designing the software. VW has admitted to the improper software and agreed to spend $16.5 billion in the US to address emissions issues. Bosch has previously denied claims of being a "knowing and active participant" in the scheme.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.4% higher on Wednesday after firmer Wall Street
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.41% to 2,908.29 points on Wednesday, driven by a firmer Wall Street, where the Nasdaq hit a fresh record and the Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.3%. The move was attributed to lacklustre US economic data suggesting the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates low.

site_title: Zika could live in eyes, spread through tears: study
summary: Researchers have found that the Zika virus can live in the eyes of mice and persist for up to 28 days, potentially allowing it to spread through tears. The study suggests that people with Zika may have infectious virus in their eyes, raising concerns about the virus's transmission. One third of babies infected with Zika in utero develop eye disease, and in adults, Zika can cause conjunctivitis and uveitis, leading to permanent vision loss. Further human studies are planned to investigate the virus's persistence in human eyes.

site_title: Rebates on bond sales should be disclosed: MAS
summary: MAS urges private banks to disclose rebates on bond sales, citing concerns over potential conflicts of interest. Managing Director Ravi Menon notes that some form of disclosure is necessary, but a ban on incentive practices could be "draconian." The MAS is reviewing the practice with industry leaders, and Menon emphasizes the importance of financial institutions prioritizing customer interests.

site_title: Chinese coast guard involved in most South China Sea clashes: research
summary: China's coast guard has been involved in 30 of 45 maritime law enforcement incidents in the South China Sea since 2010, according to new research. The incidents include clashes and standoffs with other regional states and vessels, characterized by "bullying, harassment, and ramming." Experts warn that the actions of China's coast guard risk destabilizing the region and pose a significant threat to civilian vessels. The research highlights China's increasingly assertive maritime enforcement efforts, which have been exacerbated by the country's growing coast guard fleet.

site_title: Washington Post to roll out speedy mobile news site
summary: The Washington Post is launching a mobile news site with near-instant load times, using Progressive Web Apps and Google's Accelerated Mobile Pages (AMP) technologies. The site aims to provide a faster user experience, with load times under one second, even on low-bandwidth or no Wi-Fi. This move is part of the Post's efforts to upgrade its technology and challenge The New York Times as the country's newspaper of record. The site will be available by the end of the year and will deliver fast articles and ads while protecting user privacy.

site_title: Europe: Shares pull back from highest level since January
summary: European shares dropped 0.3% on Tuesday, falling back from their highest level since January, due to weak US data and a slump in France's Ingenico Group. The dollar fell against the euro, and the growth-sensitive banking sector fell 1.7%. Oil prices dropped as Brent crude slipped below $47 a barrel, and French payments firm Ingenico Group plummeted 13.6% after cutting its full-year targets. Despite this, Germany's DAX ended in positive territory.

site_title: Australia pursues UK for free trade agreement after Brexit
summary: Australia is pursuing a free trade agreement with the UK, despite the UK's post-Brexit uncertainty, as its Prime Minister and Trade Minister have expressed interest in a bilateral deal. This move is seen as a notable exception to the UK's tough talks with EU member states and international allies. Australia aims to capitalize on the UK's new globalized trade profile and potentially strengthen its own economy.

site_title: Macau's biggest casino operator: don't call it a comeback yet
summary: Macau's casino industry, led by Galaxy Entertainment Group, has seen a 1.1% increase in gaming revenue in August, halting a two-year decline. However, billionaire chairman Lui Che-Woo remains cautious, citing the need for more sustained growth before declaring a recovery. Galaxy aims to boost revenue from recreational gamblers by 20% over the next two years, shifting focus from VIP clients. The industry faces increasing competition from new resorts, including Wynn Palace and Parisian, and the government's efforts to attract middle-class tourists.

site_title: Pre-conditions to be satisfied before offer to privatise China Minzhong goes through
summary: Marvelous Glory Holdings plans to acquire China Minzhong Food Corporation at S$1.20 apiece, but two pre-conditions must be met. Firstly, Indonesia-listed Indofood Sukses Makmur's independent shareholders must approve the disposal of 543.24 million shares, representing 82.88% of CMZ's total shares. Secondly, Hong Kong-listed First Pacific Company's independent shareholders must approve the disposal of the same shares. If both conditions are met, the offer can proceed.

site_title: Brazil's new government buffeted by pension fund scandal
summary: Brazil's new President Michel Temer's government is facing a multibillion-dollar pension fund scandal, with police arresting five people linked to fraudulent investments in four huge pension funds. The scandal, valued at around 8 billion reais (S$3.4 billion), involves dozens of businessmen and fund managers, and is expected to spread to Brazil's political establishment. Temer's office claims the irregularities occurred during the 13-year Workers Party rule and has no connection to the current administration, but the scandal may undermine Temer's efforts to restore credibility and turn the page on the previous government.

site_title: Paper trail
summary: Paper Carpenter, a local company, transforms everyday cardboard into 3D artworks. Founded in 2013 by Adrian Chua and Irene Ng, the duo aims to expand into international projects and the consumer market. Initially, Chua was a prop maker and Ng was a consumer marketing expert, combining their skills to create unique cardboard designs. The company has worked with clients such as Archifest, Changi Airport Group, and Google, and has gained a reputation for its eco-friendly and creative solutions. Paper Carpenter's success stems from its ability to find gaps in the market and create innovative products.

site_title: Consider hiring a contingent workforce
summary: A contingent workforce can provide SMEs with flexibility to manage workers according to specific needs. This approach allows employers to adjust staffing levels in response to changing business requirements.

site_title: UN Council condemns North Korea missile tests
summary: The UN Security Council strongly condemned North Korea's latest missile tests, calling them a "grave violation" of international obligations and UN resolutions. The council, including China, issued a unified statement calling for North Korea to refrain from further actions, including nuclear tests. The US warned that further measures would be taken if necessary, while North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un hailed the tests as "perfect." The council also expressed concern over the North's diversion of resources to its ballistic missile program, while US President Barack Obama stated that provocations would only deepen North Korea's isolation.

site_title: Embattled Sarkozy defiant over presidential bid
summary: French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy vowed to continue his presidential bid despite prosecutors recommending a trial over alleged illegal campaign financing. Sarkozy described the move as "manipulation" and said nothing would stop him from running. A trial could be ruled as early as October, potentially impacting his campaign in the runup to presidential primaries. Sarkozy's lawyer dismissed the news as a "shoddy new political manoeuvre", and a trial for 13 others, including Sarkozy, is also pending.

site_title: Oil markets split as traders dubious of supply freeze
summary: Oil markets were mixed on Tuesday, with a barrel of West Texas Intermediate rising 39 cents to $44.83, while North Sea Brent fell 37 cents to $47.26. Despite Russia and Saudi Arabia's pledge to cooperate on oil prices, market hopes of a supply freeze were dashed, with Iranian President Hassan Rouhani stating that Iran aims to regain pre-sanctions production levels. Traders expressed skepticism, citing the market's volatility, with one analyst saying that the market's reaction to the initial pledge was "headline-driven" and ultimately led to a return to pre-agreement levels.

site_title: Global coal power plans fall in 2016, led by China, India: study
summary: Global coal power plans have declined by 14% in 2016, driven by China's efforts to reduce oversupply and promote cleaner energy. India introduced policies to curb plans for coal-fired plants, partly due to under-utilization of existing plants. The decline is attributed to environmental concerns and deteriorating economics of coal, with China's drop being the largest at 114 GW. Despite this, the planned capacity remains too high to limit global temperature rise to 1.5°C.

site_title: US judge grants Hanjin temporary protection from US creditors
summary: A US judge granted Hanjin Shipping temporary protection from US creditors, allowing its vessels to dock at US ports without fear of creditor actions. Hanjin filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy protection in the US, seeking recognition of proceedings in South Korea and protection for its US assets. The order, which is temporary and will be reviewed on Friday, prevents US creditors from taking actions against the company's ships and other assets. This move comes as US retailers, including HP Inc, rely on Hanjin for holiday shipments, and the company's parent company has pledged to raise $100 million to meet cargo commitments.

site_title: Disgraced Bill Cosby faces June 5 sex assault trial
summary: Bill Cosby will stand trial on June 5, 2017, for allegedly sexually assaulting a woman at his Philadelphia home in 2004. He faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted. Cosby's legal team has denied the allegations and accused prosecutors of waging a campaign built on racial bias. More than 50 women have publicly accused Cosby of being a serial sexual predator, but the Constand case is the only criminal charge brought against him. Cosby has admitted to giving the accuser a pill but denies the assault.

site_title: Asean must unite in 'extended campaign' against Zika: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the 10-member Asean bloc to unite in an "extended campaign" against the Zika virus, which has been transmitted locally in several countries, including Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam. Lee emphasized the need for regional unity to prevent disruption to trade and commerce, and pledged to work with Asean partners and the international community to combat the disease.

site_title: Britain, not China, top foreign landowner in Australia
summary: Britain owns more agricultural land in Australia than China, according to the country's first foreign land register. 52.1 million hectares, or 13.6% of all agricultural land, is in foreign hands, with Britain holding over half. The UK is followed by the US, Netherlands, and Singapore, while China owns only 0.38%. Foreign ownership is growing, with Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce stating that the register confirms previous estimates of increasing foreign ownership. The government warns against protectionism, citing the importance of foreign investment to Australia's economy.

images.alt_text: Contrary to perceptions, British investors own far more agricultural land in Australia than Chinese nationals, an inaugural foreign land register showed Wednesday as the government warned against the rise of protectionist sentiment.

site_title: False market: 50 shades of grey
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced a handbook for brokers to clarify its approach to false markets, which involve misleading price swings to create the impression of demand. The handbook aims to provide clarity on what activities are allowed and what are not, with the goal of reducing market misconduct. However, critics argue that selective prosecution has led to confusion and that the handbook should address past cases of market manipulation, such as the 2013 penny stock crash. The handbook's release is seen as a step towards providing transparency and education for brokers and the public.

site_title: G-20 summit: Talk of 'secular stagnation' emerges amid a weakened global economy
summary: The G-20 summit in Hangzhou, China, concluded with a "Hangzhou Consensus" on policy measures, despite acknowledging a weakened global economy. Leaders expressed concerns about "secular stagnation" and a critical moment for the world economy. China emphasized the success of the meeting, while Japan's former vice-finance minister noted the diplomatic tone, but the consensus fell short of addressing pressing economic issues. The G-20 meeting comes as the world economy faces challenges, including slowing GDP growth and rising tensions between countries.

site_title: The many extremes of Donald Trump
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's positions on immigration, Muslims, and rationality are being scrutinized as his advisors urge him to shift towards more mainstream Republican positions. However, any such shift would not necessarily lead to moderate positions, as the Republican establishment hopes. Instead, it may result in a continuation of extreme policies, such as deregulation and tax cuts that would disproportionately benefit the wealthy. Trump's running mate, Mike Pence, and the House Republicans are pushing for these policies, which could lead to a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis and damage to the US economy.

site_title: Delayed placement: Asiatravel says it's keeping options open
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings has clarified the delay in its proposed S$100 million share placement, citing internal factors and keeping options open. The online travel company responded to media reports and a call by the Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) to investigate. The Securities Industry Council (SIC) was not required to look into the matter. Asiatravel.com Holdings did not specify the cause of the delay.

site_title: Girl power
summary: There is no article about "girl power" in the provided content. The provided articles cover various business and industry news, including a focus on women's timepieces, a startup aiming to reduce the price of sustainable marine fuel, and business closures in Singapore.

site_title: Private sector to build Laos transshipment centre
summary: Business leaders from across ASEAN are spearheading the development of a transshipment hub in Laos, set to become a key connectivity point between ASEAN and China. The hub, expected to be operational by next year, will be built by private sector companies and will facilitate transport, technological, and people-to-people ties. The initiative aims to narrow the development gap among ASEAN member states and enhance regional competitiveness. The project is part of ASEAN's Master Plan on Connectivity 2025 and the Initiative for ASEAN Integration Work Plan III, which focus on sustainable infrastructure, digital innovation, and people mobility.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff leaves presidential palace for good
summary: Brazil's impeached president Dilma Rousseff left the Alvorada Palace in Brasilia for the last time, marking the end of her 13-year rule. She flew to her coastal hometown, surrounded by supporters and former ministers. Rousseff's departure comes as President Michel Temer returned from the G-20 summit in China. The event symbolically closes the chapter on the Workers' Party's era in power, following Rousseff's impeachment in May 2016.

site_title: Scoot, Tigerair sign MOU with ITE on passenger services education
summary: Singapore's budget carriers Scoot and Tigerair have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) to provide passenger services education. A simulated cabin will be developed at the Scoot-Tigerair Service Skills Centre at ITE College West, featuring a mock cabin, galley, and lavatory for hands-on learning. The partnership aims to foster a talent pool for the aviation industry.

site_title: US dollar weakens on service sector slowdown
summary: The US dollar weakened on Tuesday after the Institute for Supply Management reported a sharp slowdown in the US service sector, with its purchasing managers index falling to 51.4 from 55.5 in August. The drop in service sector activity may argue against predictions of an interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve this month, contradicting official figures showing the US added 155,000 jobs in August. The euro strengthened against the dollar, while the pound and yen also gained ground.

images.alt_text: The US dollar weakened on Tuesday after data showed activity in the US service sector slowed sharply last month, diminishing the odds of an early rate hike by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Getting innovation right
summary: A culture to sustain innovation is crucial for SMEs, as fancy machinery and technology are not enough. Researchers at NUS are working on sustainable marine fuel, aiming to halve its price. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Meanwhile, Shatec cuts 42 staff and puts its campus up for sale, while Chinatown Business Association seeks S$77,700 from Nanyang Old Coffee over outdoor area use. These developments highlight the need for innovative business strategies and cultural shifts in the industry.

site_title: Kolkata - where Saint Teresa left an imprint
summary: Kolkata residents gathered to celebrate Mother Teresa's canonization, despite some ambivalence about her work. Volunteers, including men who had been cared for by Mother Teresa's organization, delivered gifts and attended a private ceremony at the Nirmal Hriday Home for the Dying Destitute, where Mother Teresa's work began. Many praised her selflessness and compassion, while others expressed concerns about her conversion efforts and the medical care provided in her homes. The canonization marked a rare moment of unity in the city, with Hindu worshippers and residents from different backgrounds coming together to honor her legacy.

site_title: Food for thought
summary: Local F&B brands Mr Bean and Brotzeit have implemented measures to manage manpower and operations costs. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz plans to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka. site_title: Australian central bank keeps interest rates on hold, awaits further inflation data
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept interest rates unchanged at 1.5% in its latest decision, awaiting further inflation data and weighing the impact of recent rate cuts. Governor Glenn Stevens stepped down, and Philip Lowe took over, inheriting an economy with increased resource exports, a housing boom, and services growth, but anaemic wage growth and weak inflation. Traders predict Lowe may cut rates by December, but see a more likely move in the first quarter of next year. The RBA aims to achieve sustainable growth and inflation target over time.

site_title: Saudis tightening their belts for Eid in age of austerity
summary: Saudi Arabia is experiencing its most austere Eid al-Adha holiday period in over a decade due to low oil prices forcing the government to implement spending cuts. The budget deficit of $98 billion last year has led to reduced consumer spending, with imports decreasing 24% and non-oil sector shrinking 0.7% in the first quarter. The official unemployment rate is around 11.5%, with foreign workers bearing the brunt of layoffs, while domestic workers are adopting a more frugal approach to their staff. The government is expected to run a budget deficit in the tens of billions of dollars this year, with plans to introduce value-added tax in 2018.

site_title: Singapore must position itself as an innovation-led economy: Iswaran
summary: Singapore must prioritize innovation to position itself as an innovation-led economy, said Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran. The government is creating industry transformation maps for over 20 sectors, focusing on productivity and embracing calculated risks and failures as essential for growth. Businesses and workers must innovate and upskill, respectively, to stay competitive in the digital economy. A mindset shift is needed to accept setbacks as learning experiences and venture into uncharted waters, complemented by a willingness to take calculated risks and tolerate failure.

site_title: Fend off cyber thieves with blockchain tech
summary: Singapore organisations face significant cyber threats due to inadequate security measures. Experts say adopting blockchain technology can help protect transactions, facilitate counterparty validation, and mitigate traditional cyber problems. However, ensuring the security and integrity of distributed ledgers is crucial. Implementing smart contracts on a blockchain can also improve risk management, but requires significant integration work and updates to existing infrastructure. A whole-of-organisation approach is necessary to tackle cyber threats, including forming a dedicated committee to review cyber security management strategies and investing in continuous cyber awareness training.

site_title: New beginnings
summary: The SME Magazine article discusses various business and industry developments in Singapore. Royal Healthcare is set to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after being acquired by Sojitz. Researchers at NUS are working on reducing the cost of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants of Hao Mart's Taste Orchard are struggling due to poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. site_title: STI back in positive territory for year
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has returned to positive territory for the year, closing at 2,896.55 with a 1.6% gain, following a strong day in local markets. The index's year-to-date gain is 0.5%. Asia's major markets also saw upward movements, while US payroll numbers eased concerns of a Federal Reserve tightening. Oil prices slipped due to oversupply fears. Key stocks like Singtel and DBS led the gains, with Singtel climbing 2% and DBS adding 1.2%.

site_title: Carving a niche
summary: Singapore's future economy will focus on quality and standards development. A specialist centre, Royal Healthcare, is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Researchers from NUS aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Meanwhile, tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard express concerns over poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and cuts staff, putting the building up for sale.

site_title: Largest freehold automobile mega hub in S'pore tops out
summary: BS Capital has topped out Carros Centre, Singapore's largest freehold automobile mega hub. Located in Sungei Kadut, the 8-floor, 2.3 million sq ft development will house automobile-related facilities and comprises 383 strata units. Scheduled for completion in Q1 2017, the building is designed with a column-free layout and will be marketed by Knight Frank Singapore. The owner plans to retain 75% majority say in property management and will sell only certain units, with the rest leased to car-related companies.

site_title: Sim Lian offer turns unconditional
summary: Singapore's Sim Lian Group has received a 90.1% stake in its construction and property group, making the offer to take the company private unconditional. The offeror, Coronation 3G, has the right to compulsorily acquire shares from non-accepting shareholders. The offer, which was initially conditional, will remain open for acceptance until October 10. The company's shares have fallen 71% in net profit for the full year ended June 30, 2016, and its shares closed at S$1.075 on Tuesday.

site_title: SGX sets up group to get to bottom of July 14 trading breakdown
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has established a Securities Industry Working Group (IWG) to investigate the July 14 trading breakdown, which caused a technical glitch and resulted in the suspension of trading for two-and-a-half hours. The group, comprising SGX members, independent experts, and software vendors, will assess and make recommendations to improve the stock market's operational resilience. The assessment is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2017, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reviewing the findings before deciding on supervisory actions.

site_title: JPMorgan cautions Europeans about a world without QE
summary: JPMorgan warns investors to prepare for a correction in bond yields as the European Central Bank's quantitative easing may be nearing its end. The bank's head of foreign exchange research, John Normand, believes "circumstantial evidence is building" that ECB easing is reaching its limits, potentially pushing debt yields up from record lows.

site_title: Amid fickle fortunes, Singapore could slip into irrelevance: MAS chief
summary: Singapore's central bank chief Ravi Menon warns that the city-state's economy is at risk of slipping into irrelevance due to fickle fortunes. He cautions that a recession is unlikely if the economy continues at its current pace, but notes the Zika outbreak may still have a minor impact. Menon describes his agency as "schizophrenic," struggling to balance optimism and concern.

site_title: Vietnam carriers splurge US$6.5b on Airbus jets
summary: Vietnam Airlines and low-cost carrier VietJet signed deals worth $6.5 billion to purchase 40 Airbus jets, marking the largest single commercial airplane purchase in Vietnam's aviation history. The deals were announced as French President Francois Hollande visited Vietnam to strengthen business ties. Hollande also discussed maritime freedom with Vietnamese President Tran Dai Quang, while avoiding human rights issues. The purchases come as Vietnam's aviation sector expands to meet demand from a growing middle class.

site_title: SMRT privatisation offer fair and reasonable: IFA, IDs
summary: SMRT Corporation's minority shareholders are urged to vote in favor of Temasek Holdings' offer to take the company private through a scheme of arrangement. The independent directors and Rothschild (Singapore) agree the offer is fair and reasonable from a financial standpoint, with a scheme price of S$1.68 per share. Minority shareholders can choose to sell their shares in the open market if they can obtain a higher price. The vote is scheduled for September 29.

site_title: Putting safety first in the Singapore Strait
summary: The International Safety@Sea Conference was held in Singapore, bringing together 30 international speakers and industry specialists to discuss maritime safety. The conference, part of Safety@Sea Week, focused on building a safety-first culture and promoting best practices. Key initiatives include the establishment of a Community of Practice to share knowledge and best practices, the annual ferry exercise (FEREX), and the launch of the "Safe Passage in the Singapore Strait" training resource package, which provides navigational information to mariners before transiting the strait.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Research raised oil price forecasts for 2016 and 2017 by $10 per barrel to $45-50/bbl and $50-55/bbl, citing narrowing supply-demand gap and potential risks from Middle East tensions, production cuts, and Opec's stance.

site_title: OUE Realty pares stake in OUEHT through married trade
summary: OUE Realty, the holding company of OUE Hospitality Trust's sponsor, disposed of 64,752,176 stapled securities, reducing its stake from 40.1% to 36.48%. The transaction, known as a "married trade," was done with an independent third party, but the buyer's identity remains unknown. The move was made to disclose changes in its shareholding, as required by law, but the parties involved are not disclosed. This comes after OUEHT's trading volume surged to eight times its average last week due to block trades.

site_title: PM Lee holds bilateral meetings with Philippine, Australian and Chinese leaders
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong held bilateral meetings with Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte, Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang during the Asean summits in Vientiane, Laos. The meetings reaffirmed the "long and close" ties between Singapore and the Philippines, elevated bilateral relations with Australia, and reaffirmed Asean-China relations. Lee extended an invitation to Duterte to visit Singapore and expressed commitment to advancing the relationship for mutual benefit.

site_title: Merkel's ebbing power boosts Theresa May's EU leverage
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's power is waning as the Alternative for Germany (AfD) party, an anti-immigration and anti-euro party, forced her ruling centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU) into third place in regional elections. This shift boosts Britain's negotiating leverage in the EU withdrawal process and strengthens Theresa May's position in the UK's talks with European leaders. Merkel's losses in her electoral home region also constrain her maneuvering room ahead of the 2017 general elections, potentially weakening the resolve of creditor countries to impose budgetary targets on economically pressed states.

site_title: China's swoop on Boeing supplier points to aluminium's future
summary: China has acquired US-based Aleris for $2.3 billion, further solidifying its position as the world's largest aluminium maker. This move indicates Chinese firms are expanding their downstream capacity by acquiring overseas assets. The acquisition is a result of China's emergence as a major player in the industry, forcing competitors to close plants and reducing profits. This development has significant implications for the global aluminium market, with US producer Alcoa Inc. shuttering all but one smelter and planning to split itself in two.

site_title: Import ban on US chicks hits China's market
summary: China's two-year ban on US chicken imports has led to a first-ever shortfall in chicken meat supplies in at least a decade, pushing up prices. The ban, imposed in response to a 2014 bird flu outbreak, has reduced the supply of white-feathered broiler chickens, which account for over half of China's chicken supply. Imports from the US, UK, and other countries have dropped sharply, leading to a potential 20% price increase, although alternatives like duck meat and increased imports may keep prices in check.

site_title: China considering wide-ranging consumer tax overhaul: sources
summary: China is considering a consumer tax overhaul, with the Finance Ministry proposing changes to tax rates on cosmetics, toiletries, alcohol, and tobacco. The plan aims to encourage consumption and healthier spending habits, while also shifting the balance of government finances. Tax cuts on cheaper cosmetics and toiletries are favored, while raising taxes on these items and energy-related products may be discussed. The overhaul is part of a broader effort to speed China's shift toward a more consumption-led economy.

site_title: Ford shelves compact car programme for EMs
summary: Ford has shelved plans to produce a new compact car family, the B500, designed for emerging markets like India and China, due to disappointing sales of mainstream models in these markets. The program, expected to begin production in 2018, was planned to include a premium sedan, hatchback, and SUV. Instead, Ford will redesign existing models, such as the EcoSport and Figo, in India by 2020-2021, focusing on SUVs and crossovers to boost profit margins.

site_title: An off-the-shelf online marketplace for businesses
summary: Arcadier, an online marketplace for businesses, was founded by co-founders Dinuke Ranasinghe and Kenneth Low after a meeting with PayPal's president sparked the idea of creating a platform where merchants can be discovered online. The company aims to democratize marketplaces by providing a do-it-yourself solution, allowing businesses to create their own marketplaces quickly and inexpensively. Despite facing challenges such as limited funding and access to local talent, Arcadier has raised $3 million in capital and has launched multiple enterprise marketplaces globally. The company plans to focus on product development and expanding its user base before generating revenue.

site_title: Hotels dangle freebies to encourage more direct bookings
summary: Hotels are offering discounts to encourage direct bookings, as occupancy rates in the US have reached a record high of over two-thirds of available rooms. To entice travelers, hotels are providing perks such as upgrades, free shuttle services, and complimentary breakfast. Loyalty program members can often book rooms at 10-20% lower rates. Online travel agencies still account for about one-third of all bookings, but hotels are gaining leverage, with occupancy rates not seen since 1984.

site_title: Buybacks get costly for S&P 500 CEOs burning cash
summary: The S&P 500's corporate cushion is shrinking due to six consecutive quarters of negative earnings growth. Cash reserves have fallen to a median $860 million, the lowest in three years, as companies reduce balances to concentrate funds among the top 50 richest firms. Buybacks and dividends account for 128% of annual earnings, leaving little room for replenishment. Experts warn that dwindling cash levels and reduced capital expenditures may hinder growth and slow the stock market's ascent, as investors prioritize companies with high capital expenditures over those with significant buybacks.

site_title: Ambitious project aims to coax oysters back to New York waters
summary: Scientists in New York have successfully installed nearly 50,000 oysters in Jamaica Bay, the largest single installation in the city, in a bid to restore a self-sustaining oyster population and improve water quality. The project, funded by a $1 million grant, aims to revive habitats for fish and wildlife, and is part of the city's efforts to restore one billion oysters to New York Harbor. The oysters, shipped from Massachusetts, will be released into the bay to grow and potentially reproduce, marking a significant step towards reviving a species that once blanketed the harbor but is now nearly extinct.

site_title: Sumitomo said to liquidate Japan hedge fund as clients pull out
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc is liquidating its Japan-focused hedge fund, Sumi Trust Japan L-S I Alpha, due to client redemptions cutting assets to just over US$10 million. The fund, launched in 2007, suffered annual losses over the last two years and has declined in four of the last eight full years. This is part of a broader trend of investors pulling an estimated US$25.2 billion from hedge funds globally in July, the largest outflow since 2009, and a net US$7 billion from Asian hedge funds this year.

images.alt_text: Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc is liquidating a Japan-focused hedge fund after investors withdrew money following poor performance, according to people familiar with the matter, adding to the list of casualties as the industry suffers its biggest outflows since 2009.

site_title: SGX sustainability reporting requirements timely: Masagos
summary: Singapore's SGX introduces mandatory sustainability reporting requirements for listed companies, aligning with global demand for such data. Environment Minister Masagos Zulkifli emphasized the importance of sustainability reporting, stating it enhances transparency and builds investor trust. The SGX has partnered with the United Nations Sustainable Stock Exchange initiative to promote corporate transparency and sustainable investment. A report released by the Asia Investor Group on Climate Change found significant progress in embedding climate-risk and responsible-investment principles into financial sector activities, but more work remains to be done.

site_title: Singapore-Shandong collaboration deepens
summary: Singapore and Shandong province have strengthened their collaboration through 11 memoranda of understanding, focusing on modern services in education, healthcare, logistics, and waste management. The agreements aim to tap emerging opportunities in these sectors, particularly in healthcare and logistics. Singapore is Shandong's third-largest foreign investor, with US$1.4 billion in actual investments in 2015. The collaboration aims to meet the growing demand for healthcare services in Shandong, driven by its ageing population.

site_title: Global pension funds' assets down, but Singapore's CPF fares better
summary: Global pension funds' assets declined by 3.4% in 2015 to $14.8 trillion, marking the first drop since the global financial crisis. However, Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) fared better, rising to 8th position globally and experiencing 7.9% growth in US dollar terms from 2010-2015. Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund maintained its top spot, while North America had the highest five-year compound growth rate at 5.6%. The research highlights the challenges faced by pension funds and the importance of effective governance and investment practices.

site_title: Brexit negotiators won't budge on border controls
summary: Brexit negotiators, led by David Davis, are insisting on border controls, prioritizing the reduction of migrants, despite potential risks to the UK's access to the EU's single market. The UK aims to stop tens of thousands of EU citizens from entering the UK for low-skilled employment. Davis claims that EU nations will want to talk once they realize the UK won't budge on border control, but critics argue that this approach could lead to tariffs and increased costs. The UK government is preparing for the triggering of Article 50, with plans to build a national consensus on exiting the EU.

images.alt_text: Mr Davis and aides of Mrs May are working on proposals including work permits, but the bottomline is that EU citizens wishing to work in the UK would have to have a job to secure residence.

site_title: Goldman Sachs bans partners from giving to certain campaigns
summary: Goldman Sachs has banned all partners from making campaign contributions to state and local candidates and officials, effective September 1. The policy change aims to prevent inadvertently violating pay-to-play rules, which can result in severe penalties, including fines and a ban from doing business with government clients. The move is intended to ensure compliance with rules covering transitions into roles covered by these regulations.

site_title: On a sugar high
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Cheng Yew Heng Candy Factory, a 70-year-old family-owned business in Singapore, is the country's biggest and oldest rock sugar supplier and manufacturer. The company, run by brothers Cheng Liang Kheng and John Cheng, has increased revenue from S$63 million in 2013 to S$122 million in 2015 despite a falling trend in sugar futures. The company has expanded into the consumer space with its Cheng sugar brand and Jewels by Cheng brand, and is exploring new directions such as bulk logistics and educational experiences. The brothers aim to increase manufacturing space and expand the business.
