Moody's analysts expect SoftBank's debt-to-earnings ratio to worsen over the next few years, increasing the risk of a downgrade.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars gain on robust domestic data
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Monday, with the Australian dollar up 0.3% to US$0.7592, nearing a one-week high. Company profits and wage growth data beat expectations, supporting GDP growth expectations and reducing the likelihood of a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The New Zealand dollar also rose 0.3% to US$0.7304, driven by strong economic data, including retail sales and home building growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hold rates at 1.5% at its September meeting.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust to sell 2 Ubi View for S$10.5m
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) has agreed to sell its remaining leasehold interest in 2 Ubi View for S$10.5 million, a 6% premium above its book value of S$9.9 million. The sale is part of CIT's FY2016 business strategy to divest non-core properties and recycle capital. The proceeds will be used for debt repayment, acquisition opportunities, asset enhancement, and working capital. The sale is expected to be completed in October, with the property having a remaining land tenure of 42 years and a gross floor area of 43,654 square feet.

site_title: IDA-accredited companies can now tap on Surbana Jurong, Lendlease projects
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) has partnered with Surbana Jurong and Lendlease to provide IDA-accredited companies with increased access to larger infrastructure and urban development projects. The partnerships, through MOIs, will allow IDA-accredited companies to participate in masterplanning projects globally, leveraging Surbana Jurong's and Lendlease's "worldwide footprint". This move aims to empower local tech companies to win projects beyond those offered by government agencies.

site_title: Macau approves 150 tables for new Sands casino resort
summary: Macau's government has approved 150 gaming tables for Sands China Ltd's $3 billion Parisian casino resort, set to open on September 13. This allocation is sufficient to support revenues in the world's biggest casino hub, according to analysts. The move comes after Wynn Macau Ltd's $4 billion Wynn Palace property was also awarded 150 tables. Sands will initially open with 100 new table games and receive additional tables in 2017 and 2018. The approval is seen as a positive for Sands, with shares rising 1.4% in morning trading.

site_title: Axiata CEO signals interest in raising stake in Singapore's M1
summary: Axiata Group Bhd CEO Jamaludin Ibrahim expressed interest in raising the company's stake in Singapore's M1 Ltd as part of plans to expand into a bigger regional carrier. He stated that increasing the stake "strategically" would be beneficial, but no negotiations are underway. If the price is right, Axiata will consider the move. This potential investment would be part of Axiata's efforts to expand its regional presence and compete with other carriers.

images.alt_text: Axiata Group Bhd chief executive officer Jamaludin Ibrahimsignalled Malaysia's biggest mobile-phone operator would be interested in raising its stake in Singapore's M1 Ltd as part of plans to turn the company into a bigger regional carrier.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.330 points to 1,667.31. Volume was 29.576 million lots worth RM10.27 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 98 to 52.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong shares surged over 1% at the open on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.20% to 23,546.99, amid a slowdown in US jobs creation and lowered expectations for an interest rate hike this month. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The rally follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes as traders brush off new Trump threats, with stocks to watch including Singtel and Sinarmas Land.

site_title: South Korea says the North's nuclear test, missiles pose challenge to China ties
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye stated that North Korea's nuclear test and missile launches pose a challenge to South Korea's ties with China. The provocations have gravely damaged peace and stability in the Korean peninsula and North-east Asia. China, North Korea's lone major ally, is under pressure to address these concerns. Park's comments were made during a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Group of 20 leaders' meeting in Hangzhou, China.

site_title: China outbound investment to jump at least 20% in H2: think-tank
summary: China's non-financial outbound direct investment (ODI) is expected to jump at least 20% in the second half of 2016, reaching $108.3 billion, according to a think-tank report. This growth is driven by abundant foreign exchange reserves and decreasing opportunities at home due to the country's economic slowdown. However, rising global geopolitical risk and national protectionism are seen as major barriers to expansion. China's foreign direct investment (FDI) growth is forecast to slow to around 4% year-on-year in the second half, due in part to the depreciation of the Chinese currency yuan.

site_title: Xi, Abe plan talks at G-20 amid spike in East China Sea tensions
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plan to meet on the sidelines of the G-20 summit, amid escalating tensions over territory in the East China Sea. The meeting comes after recent spikes in tensions, despite ongoing trade and tourism between the two nations. The leaders' discussion is seen as an attempt to ease tensions and find common ground, but the long-standing disputes over territory and Japan's wartime history remain unresolved.

site_title: US dollar holds gain as Fed rate-hike odds weather hiring slowdown
summary: The US dollar maintained its gain against the yen after the release of weaker-than-expected August jobs growth data. The Federal Reserve's rate-hike expectations remained intact, with futures showing a 32% likelihood of a September rate increase. Average monthly hiring of 240,000 suggested little change in the labor market trend, supporting a rate increase this year. The dollar's strength was expected to remain shallow despite some corrections, driven by rate-hike expectations.

site_title: Hong Kong residents-only housing project sells out on first day
summary: A China Overseas Land & Development Ltd housing project in Hong Kong sold out all 300 apartments on its first day, exceeding demand for the 228 units at a rival project. The sales follow a rebound in prices from earlier this year, with transactions rising to 5,821 units in August, the highest level in 14 months. The One Kai Tak project, restricted to Hong Kong residents, was priced between HK$15,080 and HK$18,418 per square foot, and ranged in size from 386 to 833 square feet.

site_title: Canada open to tweaking rules to spur China investment: government MP
summary: Canada's Liberal government is open to easing foreign investment restrictions to foster better trade ties with China. Parliamentary secretary David Lametti stated that the government considers proposals to enhance trade, but no formal exploration of changes has taken place. This comes after Canada's former Conservative government clamped down on takeover bids for energy companies by foreign state-owned enterprises in 2012. The move follows Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's recent visit to China, where he sought deeper ties with the country and signed 56 deals worth over C$1.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Canada's Liberal government is open to the idea of fostering better trade ties with China by easing foreign investment restrictions, a senior legislator said on a national political talk show broadcast on Sunday.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping shares dive 30% in resumed trade
summary: Hanjin Shipping, South Korea's seventh-largest container shipper, saw its shares plummet 30% in resumed trade on Monday as it struggles to recover from its collapse. The company filed for US court receivership and a Seoul court initiated a rehabilitation proceeding. Shares had been suspended since August 30 and dropped to their lowest since 2009. Hanjin made a "Chapter 15" filing to protect its vessels from creditor seizure.

site_title: Young anti-China activists victorious in Hong Kong vote
summary: In Hong Kong's legislative election, a new generation of young anti-China activists, led by Nathan Law, won seats with 90% of the vote, securing a landmark victory in advocating for Hong Kong's independence from China. The election comes as Beijing tightens its grip on the city, and the young campaigners emphasize Hong Kongers' right to choose, with a referendum on independence on the horizon. The outcome is seen as a significant win for the pro-democracy camp, with the democrats likely to maintain their veto power, despite concerns that Beijing's influence may continue to grow.

site_title: Jasper in talks to raise funds to meet working capital needs
summary: Jasper Investments, a transportation services provider, is in talks with its controlling shareholder to raise funds to meet its working capital needs. The company, which has a negative working capital position, said it has been able to meet its short-term obligations and is cautiously optimistic about further improvements. Jasper is working closely with its shareholder to secure additional funding to address its working capital requirements.

site_title: Nico Steel on SGX watch-list
summary: Nico Steel Holdings, a mainboard-listed provider of metallurgical solutions, has been placed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) watch-list due to concerns over its financial health. The company must restore its financial health and meet SGX's requirements within 36 months, or risk delisting. If not, the SGX will suspend trading in its shares with a view to delisting. This move aims to ensure the company complies with Listing Rule 1314(1) and maintains the trust of investors.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher after soft US jobs data
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Monday after a weaker-than-expected US August jobs report, reducing odds for a US rate hike this month. The Nikkei 225 index jumped 1.21% to 17,131.00, while the Topix index added 1.22% to 1,357.14. The US jobs report fell short of forecasts, boosting market sentiment and supporting the rally.

site_title: Vallianz requests trading halt
summary: Vallianz Holdings has requested a trading halt due to a dispute over US$63.5 million owed to Swiber Holdings and Swiber Offshore Construction. The company claims extended credit and netting off practices have been part of their dealings. Vallianz is awaiting a response from the interim judicial managers and will make further announcements when appropriate.

site_title: IJMs present 'reasonable prospect' of saving company: Swiber
summary: Swiber group, facing financial difficulties, believes Interim Judicial Managers (IJMs) have presented a "reasonable prospect" of saving the company. The IJMs suggest that securing US$1.67 billion worth of projects will be crucial, allowing for a potential restructuring exercise that benefits creditors. Key stakeholders, including suppliers and creditors, have expressed willingness to support the company's completion of ongoing projects, highlighting its strengths in upstream engineering and construction. The IJMs have received 24 expressions of interest, including proposals for equity and debt financing, and will evaluate these options together with Swiber's management.

site_title: EU will not release more bailout money for Greece this month: paper
summary: The euro zone will not release additional bailout money for Greece this month, according to European Union diplomats. Greece has only implemented two of 15 required political reforms, with a key condition being the privatization of state assets. The European Central Bank and International Monetary Fund had agreed to provide up to 86 billion euros in financial assistance to Greece by 2018 in exchange for the reforms.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vallianz, Jasper, CIT, Nico Steel
summary: Vallianz Holdings halted trading due to a pending announcement. Jasper Investments sought additional funding to meet working capital requirements. Cambridge Industrial Trust Management (CIT) agreed to sell a leasehold interest for S$10.5 million. Nico Steel was placed on the Singapore Exchange watch-list. These companies made material announcements before Monday's market opening, citing various reasons including pending releases, working capital requirements, and unsolicited offers.

site_title: Philippine nickel ore exports may drop 30%, top miner forecasts
summary: Philippine nickel ore exports are expected to drop by 20-30% this year due to government audits and mine suspensions. The country, the world's top nickel supplier, will likely export between 22.6 million and 25.8 million tons, down from 32.3 million tons in 2015. The audit, initiated by President Rodrigo Duterte, aims to ensure responsible mining practices. Nickel prices have risen to a one-year high, potentially lifting prices further, but the impact of the audit is being closely watched.

site_title: Carney's stimulus questioned as BOE faces pro-Brexit lawmakers
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney will face criticism from pro-Brexit lawmakers during a parliamentary hearing, questioning his decision to implement stimulus measures in response to the Brexit referendum. Critics argue the package was premature and may be counterproductive, while some economists see it as necessary to mitigate economic risks. The BOE predicts slower growth and faster inflation ahead, and Carney will be asked about the impact of Brexit on the economy and whether he acted too quickly.

site_title: Brazilian police break up anti-Temer rally in Sao Paulo
summary: Brazilian police used tear gas to disperse thousands of demonstrators at a peaceful march in Sao Paulo, protesting the removal of President Dilma Rousseff and new President Michel Temer. The march, which drew 50,000 people, called for new elections and chanted "Out with Temer!" Temer downplayed the protests, saying they were "small groups" not representative of the population. Smaller anti-Temer demonstrations were held in other Brazilian cities, including Rio de Janeiro and Curitiba.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.13% higher on Monday after weak US job data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 1.13% higher on Monday following weaker-than-expected US August jobs data, which may reduce odds for a US rate hike this month. The index gained 31.63 points to 2,835.55 at 9am, with about 50.1 million shares worth S$73.4 million changing hands. Gainers outpaced losers 98 to 32, with top stocks including Singtel, DBS, and Singapore Exchange.

site_title: UK shop prices fall at faster pace in August, but pressures ahead: BRC
summary: British shop prices fell 2.0% in August, the fastest pace on record, with food prices dropping 1.1% from 0.8%. Despite a weak pound, retailers won't feel the full impact of the cost increases until existing contracts with foreign suppliers expire. BRC Chief Executive Helen Dickinson warned that the devaluation of sterling will put upward pressure on shop prices, but this is likely to take several months.

site_title: Crude oil prices edges down on glut worries
summary: Crude oil prices dropped by 3% on Monday, amid concerns over a global oil glut. London Brent crude fell to $46.65 a barrel, and NYMEX crude decreased to $44.26 a barrel. Russia and Saudi Arabia are seeking to prop up the oil market, with cooperation expected to bring benefits. Iran also expressed readiness to support a decision to restore balance to the oil market. The price drop comes after a weak US jobs report and a report that Russia supports Opec's output freeze efforts.

site_title: KrisEnergy begins drilling of Bangora well in onshore Bangladesh
summary: KrisEnergy has begun drilling the Bangora-6 development well in onshore Bangladesh's Block 9. The Bapex Bijoy 10 rig started operations on Monday. The Bangora field has an average daily production of 106 million cubic feet of gas and 291 barrels of condensate. KrisEnergy holds a 30% working interest in the block, with Niko Exploration and Bangladesh Petroleum Exploration and Production Company Limited sharing the remaining interests.

site_title: South Korea's August foreign reserves rise to record high
summary: South Korea's foreign exchange reserves surged to a record high of $375.46 billion in August, driven by a rise in the value of foreign currencies. This increase was largely attributed to a $7.97 billion gain in securities and a $3.91 billion rise in deposits. South Korea now holds the seventh largest stockpile of foreign exchange reserves globally.

site_title: Samsung SDI shares touch 10-wk low on Galaxy Note 7 recall
summary: Shares of Samsung SDI plummeted 4.6% on Monday, touching a 10-week low, following Samsung Electronics' announcement of a Galaxy Note 7 phone recall due to fire-prone batteries. This weighed heavily on the company's earnings concerns. The broader market declined 0.6% in comparison.

site_title: Japan July real wage growth hovers at 6-year high due to low prices
summary: Japan's real wage growth in July remained at a six-year high, increasing 2.0% from a year ago, driven by falling prices rather than strong wage gains. The core consumer price index fell 0.5% in July, and nominal cash earnings rose 1.4% for the third consecutive month. However, the boost in real wages may not translate to increased private consumption, as the economy remains stubbornly weak. The government faces challenges in beating decades of deflationary trends despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to stimulate growth through monetary easing and fiscal spending.

images.alt_text: Japanese real wage growth in July stayed around six-year highs, data showed on Monday, but the gain was boosted in part by the effect of falling prices, highlighting the challenges the government faces in beating decades of deflationary trends.

site_title: May says UK must be prepared for 'difficult times' on economy
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May warned of "difficult times ahead" for Britain's economy in an interview, citing the uncertainty following the Brexit referendum. She ruled out a new general election, stating the country needs stability to address post-Brexit issues. May expressed optimism about the economy's health but acknowledged potential challenges. The government is expected to make a statement on Brexit progress, and May is meeting world leaders at the G20 summit to discuss future trade deals.

site_title: Survey finds giant pandas no longer 'endangered' in China
summary: China's giant panda has been downlisted from "endangered" to "vulnerable" due to a population rebound, according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List. The latest estimates show 1,864 adult pandas, with a projected total population of 2,060. Conservation efforts, including replanting bamboo forests and a captive breeding program, have contributed to the population increase. However, experts warn that climate change may threaten the pandas' habitat, potentially reversing gains made in conservation.

site_title: Traders get no clarity on Fed outlook after jobs data
summary: Foreign-exchange traders remain uncertain about the Federal Reserve's policy outlook after a Labor Department report showed weaker-than-expected August jobs growth and wage gains. The greenback slumped and rebounded, with futures indicating a 32% likelihood of a September interest-rate increase. The Fed's rate calculation is based on the assumption of a December interest-rate hike, with analysts citing ongoing interest-rate uncertainty and the potential for a gradual rate increase. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index remained little changed, indicating a lack of clear direction for the US currency.

site_title: May expresses doubts about Brexit campaign's key promises
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May expressed doubts about key Brexit campaign promises, including a points-based immigration system and leaving the single market. May criticized Boris Johnson's immigration proposals, saying a points-based system may not work. She also refused to endorse other commitments made by her Cabinet members, including increased NHS spending and tax cuts. May stated her negotiating position, focusing on introducing "controls" on EU citizens settling in Britain, and vowed to achieve a deal that benefits the UK. She warned of difficult times ahead for the UK economy but expressed confidence in Britain's ability to thrive as a global free trade champion.

site_title: Merkel party suffers first defeat by anti-immigration populists
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democratic Party suffered its first defeat by anti-immigration populists, Alternative for Germany (AfD), in a state election in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania. The AfD secured 22% of the vote, while the Social Democrats won 30.3%. Merkel's party fell to third place, highlighting the persistence of public anxiety over her open-border refugee policy. The result is seen as a warning to Merkel ahead of potential national elections, where she may seek a fourth term.

images.alt_text: Chancellor Angela Merkel's party was beaten by the populist Alternative for Germany for the first time in a state election, showing the persistence of the backlash against her open-border refugee policy.

site_title: StanChart faces longer US supervision over Iran lapses
summary: Standard Chartered expects to remain under US supervision for several more years due to ongoing lapses in Iran-related anti-money laundering efforts. The bank needs more time to improve its internal standards, despite increasing compliance spending to over $1 billion in 2015. A deferred prosecution agreement with US authorities was initially set to expire in 2017 but is now expected to be extended, possibly by several years. The bank faces ongoing investigations and the possibility of fresh penalties.

site_title: Cheeky tweet from US spy agency after awkward moment at G-20 summit
summary: A US spy agency's Defence Intelligence Agency (DIA) posted a sarcastic tweet about a tarmac incident at the G-20 summit in China, where US President Barack Obama was arriving. The tweet was quickly deleted after being noticed by the Wall Street Journal, but not before the incident was captured on camera. A Chinese official shouted at White House staffers, prompting US National Security Adviser Susan Rice to intervene. The DIA later apologized for the tweet, stating it did not represent the agency's views.

site_title: Asia: Stocks set to bounce as payrolls weigh on yen; oil slips
summary: Asian stock markets are expected to bounce back after weaker-than-expected US jobs data, which may weigh on the yen and boost interest rates. Futures suggest gains of at least 0.6% for stocks from Sydney to Seoul, while the yen extends its decline against the dollar. The US payrolls report showed a slower but solid growth in August, with economists interpreting it as a steady improvement in the economy. Odds of a September interest-rate hike have dropped to 32%, down 10 percentage points from a week ago.

site_title: Seaweed farming, a sudden slimy success, needs greener rules: UN
summary: The UN report warns that seaweed farming, a $6.4 billion industry, needs tighter regulation to prevent environmental damage. Despite its benefits, such as creating jobs and food in coastal areas, seaweed can cause harm by spreading diseases and pests, and out-competing local plants. The report recommends measures like seed banks, better monitoring, and government-sponsored insurance schemes to mitigate risks. Countries like Norway and the Philippines have already implemented regulations after experiencing devastating losses due to aquaculture-related diseases.

site_title: Motor racing: Ecclestone could stay on if F1 sale proceeds
summary: Bernie Ecclestone may remain Formula One's chief despite a potential takeover by Liberty Media, a deal worth $8.5 billion. Insider reports suggest the first payment is expected to be made on Tuesday, but Ecclestone's future role would be his decision. Some, like Christian Horner, believe he will stay on for some time, while others speculate he could be forced out. Ecclestone will attend the upcoming Singapore Grand Prix, according to Niki Lauda, and has met with potential investors, including Mercedes team principal Toto Wolf, who sees the deal as positive for the sport.

site_title: Record voter turnout in key Hong Kong election
summary: Hong Kong saw a record 2.2 million voters cast ballots in key elections, with young independence activists calling for a complete break from China. The vote, the largest since 2014's mass protests, has early indications of candidates advocating for a break with Beijing potentially becoming lawmakers. The city's concerns over Beijing's tightening grip on the semi-autonomous city were heightened by the election.

site_title: Baidu banks on growing artificial intelligence expertise
summary: Baidu, China's largest search engine, is investing heavily in artificial intelligence (AI) to boost its slowing search and advertising business. The company has partnered with Nvidia to develop driverless cars and taxis, and plans to release its PaddlePaddle software on GitHub. Baidu aims to create detailed profiles of users using its web crawling abilities, facial and voice recognition technology, and will invest in autonomous cars. The company's shares jumped 3.2% after the announcement, with analysts predicting long-term growth and profitability.

site_title: It takes a global village to raise a child
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based real estate giant, has dedicated over S$25 million to its philanthropic arm, the CapitaLand Hope Foundation, since its establishment in 2005. The foundation supports underprivileged children across Asia through various programs, including the CapitaLand Kids Programme, which provides financial support and mentorship. CapitaLand also aims to foster a culture of volunteerism among its partners and staff, with initiatives such as the #100KHopeHours Challenge and paid volunteer leave. By focusing on sustainable philanthropy, CapitaLand believes it can break the poverty cycle and create a better future for its beneficiaries.

site_title: Rosberg wins at Monza; Formula One sale to US media group to go ahead next week
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Italian Grand Prix, cutting Lewis Hamilton's Formula One world championship lead to two points with seven races remaining. Hamilton, favored to take his 50th career victory, finished second after a slow start. Rosberg's dominant Mercedes performance secured his first win at Monza.

site_title: Europe 'close to limits' on refugee influx: Tusk
summary: Europe is "close to limits" on accepting new refugees, EU President Donald Tusk said, amid a steady influx of migrants fleeing the Syrian civil war. The EU's borders have hardened since a major backlash to Germany's open borders, with anti-migrant sentiment soaring. Tusk urged the international community, including China, to share the burden and provide financial assistance and development aid for migrant countries of origin. With 65 million displaced people worldwide, Tusk called for global efforts to address the issue.

images.alt_text: Europe is "close to limits" on its ability to accept new waves of refugees, EU President Donald Tusk said Sunday, urging the broader international community to shoulder its share of the burden.

site_title: Iran's pistachio farms are dying of thirst
summary: Iran's pistachio farms are facing severe water scarcity due to decades of over-farming and climate change. The industry, a significant export for Iran, is dwindling as underground water reserves are depleted, causing sinkholes and land subsidence. The government is introducing financial incentives to encourage water conservation, but changing ingrained attitudes will take time. Some farmers, like Farhad Sharif, have successfully implemented drip-irrigation systems, but many others struggle to adapt. The pistachio industry's collapse poses a threat to Iran's economy and food security.

site_title: Brexit may delay building of tallest City tower
summary: Developers of London's 22 Bishopsgate project, the city's tallest office tower, may delay construction due to higher construction costs and short-term doubts about tenant demand following the Brexit vote. The pound's devaluation has increased costs by up to 8%, and about 4 million square feet of planned office space is now uncertain. Investors, including Temasek Holdings and Public Sector Pension Investment Board, will be asked if they want to proceed with the project, which would add 1.4 million square feet of offices and shops.

site_title: Sanofi seeks US govt funding in race to develop vaccine for Zika
summary: Sanofi is seeking US government funding to develop a Zika vaccine, aiming to combat the mosquito-borne virus that can cause brain damage in babies and neurological disorders in adults. Sanofi will join forces with the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research to develop a vaccine candidate using an inactivated version of the virus. The initial human study is set to begin on October 1, and results may be seen as early as the first quarter of next year, significantly reducing the typical 12-15 year vaccine development timeline.

site_title: G-20 must take action and not be a 'talk shop': Xi Jinping
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged the G-20 to take action, warning that the group should not be a "talk shop" but a team that implements commitments. The G-20, comprising 19 major economies, must address the global economy's sluggish demand, financial market volatility, and weaker trade and investment. Xi emphasized the need for countries to boost trade and investment, and not introduce protectionist policies. The summit aims to provide solutions to global economic problems, with China hosting the event for the first time.

site_title: Nudged by dad, but going her own in money matters
summary: Grace Lim, 21, a third-year accountancy undergraduate from Singapore Management University, plans to venture into long-term investments, driven by her accountancy background and recent investment conference. She initially resisted her father's advice to invest, but now believes it's essential to strike a financial pot of gold at a young age. Lim aims to budget and save effectively, having created a separate account for online purchases to curb her spending. She's also considering a career in auditing or risk management after graduation.

site_title: Amsterdam neighbourhood lures hipsters with cheap waterfront housing
summary: Amsterdam's northern harbour, once a derelict area, is undergoing significant transformation with the development of cheap waterfront housing. The area, where 33-year-old Vincent Vollenbronck grew up, is now booming with new student homes and businesses. The transformation is being driven by developers and investors, with BNP Paribas Real Estate brokered the sale of 403 student homes on a former shipbuilding wharf. The area's growth is expected to continue, making it a popular destination for hipsters and young professionals.

site_title: Violence erupts as Native Americans resist oil pipeline
summary: Violence erupted at a protest site in North Dakota as Native American activists clashed with construction workers over an oil pipeline. Hundreds of protesters confronted a bulldozer crew, accusing them of destroying sacred burial grounds and cultural artifacts. The Standing Rock Sioux Tribe claims the pipeline would endanger its drinking water and destroy historic sites. Protests have been ongoing since the pipeline's developer paused construction, with the tribe seeking a court injunction to stop the project. Three private security guards were injured, and several protesters were left bloodied in the confrontation.

site_title: Chinese banks' shadow loans grow despite regulatory glower
summary: Chinese banks' shadow loans, also known as opaque lending structures, have surged in the first half of the year, reaching 12.6 trillion yuan in 2015, five times China's annual economic output. Despite regulatory efforts to rein in these products, mid-tier banks have increased their use of shadow lending, making it harder for regulators to assess systemic risk and the volume of lending in the economy. This has raised concerns about financial stability, with non-performing loans already at a record high.

site_title: Tesla's Musk lost US$779m in a day, but faces bigger threat from SolarCity merger
summary: Elon Musk's proposed merger of Tesla Motors Inc with SolarCity Corp has raised concerns about his personal finances. Despite the deal's potential benefits, Musk's net worth has decreased by $779 million due to the companies' stock prices and his increased collateral for personal borrowings. The merger could pose a bigger threat to Musk's bank accounts if SolarCity's debt is not repaid. Musk has a history of taking on significant debt for his ventures, but experts warn that his tolerance for risk may be too high, potentially leading to personal financial instability.

site_title: Drowning Hanjin not alone among global carriers: analyst
summary: South Korea's Hanjin Shipping, the world's seventh largest shipping firm, filed for bankruptcy due to its massive debt of $5.37 billion and cashflow management issues. The company's problems are part of a broader industry issue, with excess capacity and low trade volumes leading to fierce competition and price cuts. Nearly 80% of global goods are transported by sea, and the industry has been impacted by the global economic downturn, with analysts estimating 25% of global container capacity now sits empty, resulting in losses of at least $6 billion this year.

site_title: PM Lee says he is 'all right' after fainting on stage two weeks ago
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in a televised interview that he is "all right" after fainting on stage two weeks ago, attributing it to vasovagal syncope, a common type of fainting. He underwent thorough medical checks and received no harm, taking a week's break before returning to work. Lee, 64, who has twice survived cancer, is now in China attending a G20 summit, discussing changes to make it easier for minorities to become president in Singapore, including potentially reserving the presidential role for minorities if needed.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in a televised interview broadcast on Sunday that he was "all right", after he took ill two weeks ago during a national day rally speech.

site_title: 2010: IRs open for business
summary: In 2010, Singapore's entertainment and tourism scene underwent significant changes. The country's first integrated resorts (IRs), Resorts World Sentosa and Marina Bay Sands, opened in January and established themselves as prime tourist destinations. The IRs contributed to the economy through tourism dollars, jobs, and construction activity, vindicating Singapore's bet on the IR concept. The success of the IRs marked a new era for Singapore's entertainment and tourism scene, solidifying its position as a major player in the region.

site_title: Property investors now have more reason to care about air-con
summary: Property investors are increasingly concerned about the carbon footprint of their buildings, as regulators and politicians crack down on the sector's contribution to climate change. Studies show that energy-efficient buildings also outperform financially. A recent analysis by GeoPhy found that top-performing REITs own newer, better-designed buildings in better locations, resulting in higher rents. Conversely, data centers and properties in areas with high coal usage tend to have higher carbon footprints. The industry's carbon emissions are expected to double or triple by the middle of the century, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

site_title: Venturecraft launches S$50m venture fund for medtech, ICT
summary: Singapore-based private investment group Venturecraft has launched a new S$50 million venture fund to invest in growth and late-stage startups in the medtech and ICT sectors. The fund's first investment is in MiRXES, an A*Star spinoff that aims to revolutionize cancer detection with affordable blood test kits. Venturecraft's investment offers not only financing but also access to regulatory expertise and industry leaders, enabling MiRXES to enter key markets. The fund's target areas include in-vitro diagnostics, diagnostics devices, and healthcare analytics, with plans to attract medtech companies from the US to Asia.

site_title: A mix of colourful desserts and meals with an artistic touch
summary: Acclaimed pastry chef Janice Wong has opened a new eatery in the National Museum of Singapore, offering a whimsical and artistic experience with colorful desserts and meals. The restaurant, which is open daily from 11am to 11pm, features edible squiggles and shapes sculpted with colorful chocolate paint. Wong invites customers to unleash their imagination and creativity, making it a unique and fun dining experience for those with a playful spirit.

site_title: Digital disruption - the SME imperative
summary: Digital disruption has profoundly impacted companies, with the average lifespan of an S&P 500 company now around 15 years. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are not exempt from this disruption, with examples of disrupted SMEs by new technology-enabled business models. To stay competitive, SMEs must adopt digital transformation strategies, embracing new technologies and changing their thinking. Boards must prioritize digital disruption and cybersecurity, engaging with management and directors with technology expertise. SMEs that fail to adapt risk being disrupted or going bankrupt.

site_title: SGX to issue surveillance handbook to brokers
summary: SGX plans to issue a surveillance handbook to brokers, containing case studies on market rigging and manipulation, to educate brokers on legitimate trading activities. The handbook aims to increase awareness of what constitutes market misconduct and reduce instances of manipulation. The book will cover topics such as layering, marking the close, and spoofing, which are illegal activities that can create a false market. The handbook's release is part of SGX's strategy to engage brokers as part of the market's governance framework.

site_title: Abe-Putin meetings in Vladivostok highlight the need for regional statesmanship
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Vladivostok, where they discussed a long-standing territorial dispute over a group of small islands off Hokkaido. The talks ended inconclusively, with no clear end in sight to the dispute that has held back Russo-Japan relations since World War II. Both leaders agreed to meet in December for further talks, but no breakthrough was reached. The dispute has been a major obstacle to cooperation between the two nations, which have significant economic interests in the region and are also wary of China's growing influence.

site_title: Mobile app to promote youths' financial literacy
summary: A new mobile game, "1 Million Dollar Journey," aims to promote financial literacy among young adults in Singapore. Developed by students and staff from the Singapore Management University and the Institute of Technical Education, the app simulates a 12-year financial journey, allowing users to make decisions on budgeting, saving, and investing. The game was officially launched during a Financial Literacy Awareness Day event and is available on both iOS and Android platforms. The app's objective is to have a net worth of a million dollars by the end of 12 years, and it complements existing financial literacy programs in the country.

site_title: Gold jumps as US jobs disappointment dims prospects of tightening by Fed
summary: US employment data showed a 151,000 payrolls gain in August, missing estimates, boosting gold's appeal as a haven. Gold futures rose 0.7% to $1,326.70 an ounce, erasing a weekly decline. The metal's appeal increases as the Federal Reserve considers holding off raising interest rates, reducing its appeal compared to assets like bonds and equities. Gold mining companies expanded their hedge book to 295 tonnes, the highest level in six years, amid uncertainty over gold prices in 2016.

site_title: Tech firms support Microsoft's case against US Justice Dept
summary: Microsoft has garnered support from dozens of tech firms and civil liberties groups in its case against the US Justice Department, challenging the use of secrecy orders to access customers' electronic communications. The lawsuit argues that the secrecy orders violate the Fourth Amendment and the company's First Amendment right to communicate with customers. Backers include Amazon, Google, Snapchat, and Salesforce, as well as media organizations like Fox News and The Washington Post. The move is part of a growing resistance to government attempts to snoop on customers' electronic communications, following revelations by Edward Snowden about the extent of electronic surveillance by spy agencies.

site_title: Doing away with cash and cheques
summary: Singapore is poised to become a cashless society, with ubiquitous electronic payment infrastructure in place. However, businesses and consumers are hesitant due to security concerns and the possibility of data breaches. Experts agree that robust digital security and public awareness are crucial to overcome these challenges. To achieve a seamless, cashless experience, businesses must invest in technologies to support e-payment solutions, such as online payment options and e-invoicing. Governments can also help drive adoption by boosting confidence in e-payment through public education programs and mandates for data protection.

site_title: Consumer giants court Muslims with halal face creams, shampoos
summary: Global consumer giants Unilever, Beiersdorf, and L'Oreal are adapting their supply chains to cater to Indonesia's growing Muslim population, ahead of a new labelling law requiring halal labelling for food and toiletries. The companies see demand for halal beauty products increasing as the Muslim middle class grows, with estimated sales of halal cosmetics projected to grow 14% per year until 2019. Multinationals are investing in halal certification to unlock new revenue streams and comply with the law, which is part of a broader push to cater to growing Muslim populations worldwide.

site_title: UK plans house building fund to boost sector post-Brexit
summary: The UK government plans to announce a £3 billion house building fund to boost the sector post-Brexit, providing cheap loans to small and medium-sized developers. The fund, expected to combine existing schemes, aims to reduce red tape and encourage developers to build new homes. Finance Minister Philip Hammond is set to outline the government's fiscal response in an autumn Budget statement, although no date has been confirmed. The move follows mixed housing market data, including a sharp decline in construction output in May and an immediate impact on the housing market from the Brexit vote.

site_title: PM Lee offers preview of elected presidency report
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has outlined proposals to increase diversity in the country's elected presidency, including reserving elections for minority groups after a six-term gap and rotating the presidency by race. The proposals aim to ensure qualified candidates from minority races stand a chance of being elected, despite concerns that the current system may favor candidates from the private sector. Lee also suggested revising the minimum capital requirement for presidential candidates and exploring alternative mechanisms such as a team presidency with representatives from different races.

site_title: Smart solutions for a smart nation
summary: Singapore's demand response aggregator, Diamond Energy, aims to change the electricity market with smart energy solutions. The company's technology aligns with the government's "Smart Nation" vision, providing unconventional solutions to conventional problems. By managing supply and demand through flexible consumption, Diamond Energy hopes to reduce the need for peaking power plants. The company offers a power-plant-on-demand model, where customers earn monthly payments for reducing their non-essential electricity demand. With 71.8 MW in the market, Diamond Energy is expanding its base and working on international opportunities, particularly in Southeast Asia and the Middle East.

site_title: Greek photographer who brought the migrant crisis home wins prize
summary: Greek photographer Aris Messinis has won the Visa d'Or for News at the Visa Pour L'Image festival for his dramatic images of the migrant crisis on Greek island shores. Messinis, 39, risked his own safety to help migrants and document the crisis, capturing emotional moments and providing a humanizing record of the humanitarian tragedy. His work, which has been displayed at the festival, aims to raise awareness and shock viewers into action.

site_title: Rising oil import costs may become Asia's growing pain
summary: Asia's oil import bill is projected to exceed $500 billion in 2017 for the first time in three years, driven by a widening gap between oil production and demand. The region's net imports surpassed North America's in 2015, and forecasters predict demand growth will outpace declining domestic production, leaving Asia vulnerable to rising prices. Oil production is expected to decline, with China, Indonesia, and India investing in overseas production assets to supplement domestic output. The region's reliance on Middle Eastern oil, a key source of geopolitical risk, is also expected to remain unchanged.

site_title: 'Recession-proof' stocks soar but doubts persist
summary: Singaporean analysts differ on what makes a "recession-proof" stock, with some citing consumer staples firms, telcos, and Reits as examples. Sheng Siong, a supermarket operator, has seen significant gains this year, but its valuation may have run too far ahead. Analysts like Maybank Kim Eng and Nikko AM view Sheng Siong as a defensive stock due to its high dividend yield and stable earnings. However, others, such as Azure Capital and HSBC, argue that no sector can be completely recession-proof. Analysts also consider pawnshops as a possible alternative, as they are linked to the price of gold. Ultimately, traditional defensive stocks with decent dividends remain the favorites of many brokers.

site_title: Yellen's speech signals Goldilocks' days are numbered
summary: US stocks ended the week and month of August flat, with a survey of the services sector being a rare highlight. The jobs report showed 151,000 workers added to US payrolls, removing urgency for a September interest rate hike. Janet Yellen's speech at Jackson Hole warned that "Goldilocks' days are numbered," but the report provided a temporary reprieve. Investors are now anticipating a Fed hike later this year, with Treasury bonds and the dollar remaining relatively unchanged. The health-care and biotech sectors are under pressure, while energy and commodity stocks are experiencing a sense of calm before the storm due to rising oil inventories.

site_title: BlackBerry to help German govt toughen 'spy-proof' Samsung tablet
summary: BlackBerry is providing encryption technology to a "spy-proof" Samsung tablet used by German government agencies handling classified information. The device, Samsung Galaxy Tab S2, includes a security card and encryption software developed by BlackBerry's Secusmart, locking down data. Knox, a Samsung security product, is also integrated. This partnership aims to enhance the security of sensitive data, making it more difficult for unauthorized parties to access it.

site_title: Chinese consumers take credit for car loans boom
summary: Chinese consumers have increased their use of credit to buy cars, with nearly 30% of car buyers using credit in 2025, up from 18% in 2013. This shift is attributed to carmakers offering financing deals to boost sales and margins. The rebound in the car market follows a sticky 2015. This change in consumer behavior has helped the car market recover, with a significant increase in car sales.

site_title: Jakarta pins software job hopes on its Slipicon Valley
summary: Jakarta is investing in its Slipicon Valley, a tech hub aimed at boosting the country's software industry. Located near the Ciliwung River, the area is about a 15-minute drive from Jakarta's CBD. The initiative hopes to rival the tech hubs in Silicon Valley, California, and create a higher-tech future for Indonesia. The government plans to support startups and innovation, with the goal of becoming a major player in the global tech industry.

site_title: New Kenya land title law may end conflicts, spur development
summary: Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta has signed the Community Land Bill into law, aiming to end land conflicts, boost development, and improve investor relations. The law grants land titles to communities, addressing issues with corrupt individuals selling or leasing land without community knowledge. The move is hoped to reduce poverty in marginalized areas and aid Kenya's goal of achieving middle-income status by 2030, but implementation challenges remain due to the sensitive nature of land ownership in Kenya.

site_title: Italy rebuffs German calls to step up scrutiny of Fiat Chrysler emissions
summary: Italy has rebuffed German calls to increase scrutiny of Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) over emissions, citing tests showing no unauthorized devices were used on vehicles. The Italian Transport Ministry stands by its previous assessments, and the EU has not received a formal request from Germany to intervene. The dispute stems from a loophole in EU regulations allowing carmakers to adjust pollution-control systems. FCA shares have dropped 30% this year due to the scrutiny.

site_title: Japan warns Brexit may drive banks, pharma investment to EU
summary: Japan has warned Britain that its exit from the European Union could prompt Japanese financial institutions to relocate from London, citing concerns over access to unskilled labor, tariff protection, and the "single passport" that allows them to operate across the bloc. The report also raises worries about the impact on pharmaceutical research and development investment. Despite this, Japan expects the British government to handle its exit smoothly, and the country has no doubt that the UK and EU will overcome the difficulties.

site_title: Shale drillers in US resume growth run in low-cost Texas plays
summary: US shale drillers resumed oil and natural gas rig operations, with 482 rigs now in use, up 14 from last week. The Permian and Eagle Ford plays in Texas led the growth, with 93 rigs added since June. Despite crude prices below $30, wells in the Permian remain profitable, with some operators achieving a 10-15% return. Oil production fell 60,000 barrels a day to 8.49 million, but the increase in rigs brings the total number back above 1,400, the pre-2014 peak.

site_title: Chongqing project significant for China-Singapore relations: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong described Chongqing, China as an "ideal place" for the country's third government-to-government project, the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative. The project aims to enhance cooperation between the two cities, following a similar initiative launched in Hangzhou last year. This visit marks the first time PM Lee has visited Chongqing since the project's launch in November 2016.

site_title: Morgan Lewis sets up shop in Shanghai
summary: LAW firm Morgan Lewis has opened an office in Shanghai, its second in China, with a 35-strong team. The new office, part of Morgan Lewis Stamford, will provide a range of legal services to clients with interests in China and Asia. The move underscores Morgan Lewis' commitment to growing its presence in Asia, with chairman Jami McKeon stating the office will serve as a conduit for China companies expanding to other parts of Asia and globally.

site_title: At MBS, a strong culture of giving back
summary: Marina Bay Sands (MBS) CEO George Tanasijevich emphasizes the importance of corporate social responsibility (CSR) and having a strong culture of giving back to the community. As one of the largest employers in Singapore, MBS is expected to make a significant impact through charity efforts. Tanasijevich believes that a good concept and proper execution are key to successful CSR efforts, and he aims to inspire others to follow suit.

site_title: Are you as stupid as your financial adviser thinks?
summary: Research firm Dalbar's annual study found individual investors underperform mutual funds by at least 4 percentage points a year, citing poor market timing. However, experts argue the gap may be due to factors outside of investors' control, such as market fluctuations or investor behavior. Dalbar's formula is not transparent, and other firms, like Morningstar, find narrower gaps between reported returns and actual investor returns. Financial planners suggest investors should choose fiduciary advisers who prioritize their interests and provide broader financial guidance, rather than relying solely on investment advice.

site_title: Terms of bond restructuring not conclusive yet: AusGroup
summary: AusGroup, an oilfield services provider, is still negotiating with noteholders and stakeholders to restructure its debt. The company has clarified that terms are not yet conclusive, despite a report suggesting they had been "set." Noteholders are seeking a small early repayment and improved coupon rates. AusGroup has obtained a waiver for breaching debt covenants and will continue to make announcements as developments occur. The company's shares traded at S$0.039 following the clarification.

site_title: Britain, Russia hope to improve strained relations
summary: Britain and Russia held a meeting between Prime Minister Theresa May and President Vladimir Putin, aiming to improve strained relations. The discussion focused on terrorism, Syria, security, and drug trafficking. May expressed a willingness for open dialogue despite differences, while Putin acknowledged the challenges facing Britain. The two leaders agreed to resume bilateral relations to a higher level than currently, with the Russian economy minister stating they searched for common ground. The meeting was the result of a previous telephone conversation between the two leaders last month.

site_title: G20 countries should boost policy coordination, avoid protectionism: Xi
summary: China's President Xi Jinping urged G20 countries to boost policy coordination and avoid protectionism during the opening of the G20 summit in Hangzhou. He emphasized the need for countries to balance supply-side reform and demand management to mitigate accumulating global economic risks. This is the first time China has hosted the G20 summit.

site_title: Zika update: 27 new cases, bringing total to 242
summary: Singapore reported 242 locally transmitted Zika cases, a 27-case increase from the previous day, as of September 4, 2016. This marks one week since the outbreak was first reported. The country is tracking the outbreak closely, with the full story available on bt.sg/zika.

site_title: Bad news is still good news
summary: Wall Street experienced a rise after a weak August jobs report, reinforcing the notion that "bad news is good news." This is due to the delay in interest rate hikes, which decreased from 24% to 21% in the federal funds futures market. The result is a temporary bounce in the market, but short-sellers who drove down the Straits Times Index last week may need to cover their positions, potentially leading to a short-term correction.

site_title: US bans key chemicals in antibacterial hand soap over health risks
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) banned 19 key chemicals, including triclosan and triclocarban, in antibacterial hand soap due to potential health risks and lack of effectiveness. The ban aims to protect consumers from immune system damage and does not apply to hand disinfectant products used in hospitals. Manufacturers have a year to comply with the ban, and some are already removing the banned ingredients from their products. The FDA advises washing with plain soap and water or using hand sanitizers with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.

site_title: China's Xi sombre about world economy at G20, warns against protectionism
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping warned at the G20 summit that rising protectionism threatens the global economy, urging leaders to defend free trade and globalization. The global economy faces challenges including sluggish demand, financial market volatility, and weak trade and investment. Xi emphasized China's commitment to safeguarding its sovereignty and maritime rights in the South China Sea. The summit also discussed Britain's exit from the European Union, with leaders warning against isolationism and advocating for a defense of global trade.

site_title: AusGroup: No certainty yet on terms for bond restructuring
summary: AusGroup, a beleaguered oilfield services provider, has stated that negotiations with noteholders and stakeholders regarding debt restructuring are ongoing but have not reached a definitive outcome. The company had an informal meeting on August 31 and acknowledged the request for a small early repayment of around 5% of its medium-term notes. AusGroup's board has clarified that negotiations with potential buyers of its scaffolding and access business ceased in June 2016, and the company has obtained a waiver for a breach of its minimum net worth position.

site_title: Director buying slows; buyback activity rebounds
summary: Singapore Exchange filings from Aug 29 to Sept 2 show a slowdown in buying among directors, with 23 companies making 42 purchases worth S$3.6 million. In contrast, 26 companies made 74 repurchases worth S$30.5 million, a sharp rebound from the previous week. Rare buybacks were recorded in Asia Enterprises Holding, CH Offshore, HupSteel, and Yanlord Land Group, with DBS Group Holdings resuming buying after a sharp rebound in its share price. Conversely, directors made rare sales in Sino Grandness Food Industry Group following a 32% drop in its share price.

site_title: Millions of US bees die from spray to fight Zika mosquitoes
summary: Millions of US bees died from a pesticide spray aimed at controlling Zika mosquitoes in South Carolina. The aerial spraying, which took place on August 28, targeted areas with confirmed Zika cases, but resulted in the loss of 46 hives and 2.5 million bees. Beekeepers have expressed concerns about the safety of the pesticide Naled, which has been used since 1959 despite environmental health concerns. The US Environmental Protection Agency has deemed it safe when used sparingly, but many are calling for alternative methods to control mosquito populations.

site_title: India PM offers Vietnam US$500m credit line for defence cooperation
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a $500 million credit line for Vietnam to enhance defence cooperation, amid growing tensions with China in the South China Sea. The move is part of a dozen cooperation agreements signed in Hanoi, with Vietnam undergoing a major military buildup. Analysts see the move as a sign of closer ties between the two countries, with India's credit line aimed at deterring China's assertive claims in the region.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi said on Saturday his country would provide a credit line of half a billion dollars to Vietnam for defence cooperation, the latest sign of closer ties between two countries with separate territorial disputes with China.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise to highest level in more than three months
summary: European shares rose 2% to their highest level in three months, driven by weaker-than-expected US jobs data and reduced expectations of a US interest rate hike. The STOXX 600 index reached 350.44 points, its best level since late May. Weaker-than-forecast jobs data and tepid US ISM factory growth figures reinforced the expectation that the US Federal Reserve would raise rates later rather than sooner.

site_title: Young activists take on China in key Hong Kong election
summary: Young Hong Kong activists, seeking a break from China, ran in major elections for the Legislative Council, with some potentially winning seats. The pro-democracy camp, which includes those demanding independence, faces a high bar to gain a majority, as Beijing-backed candidates dominate the legislature. The election's outcome could determine the balance of power in Hong Kong, with the pro-democracy camp risking veto power if it loses four seats. Polls show some pro-independence candidates may win, but many consider their cause unrealistic.

site_title: Formula One: Rosberg wins as Hamilton suffers at start
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Italian Grand Prix, edging out Lewis Hamilton who struggled at the start, and narrowed the championship lead to two points. Rosberg took the lead at the start, pulling away to control the race and finish 15 seconds ahead of Hamilton. Sebastian Vettel came home third, boosting Rosberg's championship challenge with seven races remaining. This was Rosberg's first Italian win, his seventh of the season, and 21st of his career, ending Hamilton's chance to equal Juan Manuel Fangio's record of three Italian wins.

site_title: Beyond the baguette: France's food legacy in Vietnam
summary: French colonial rule in Vietnam has left a lasting legacy in the country's cuisine, particularly in the popular "banh mi" sandwich. Introduced in the late 19th century as a convenient food for French soldiers, the sandwich evolved with local ingredients and flavors, becoming a staple in Vietnamese cuisine. French bakers, such as Nguyen Ngoc Hoan, played a significant role in popularizing banh mi in Vietnam, while also incorporating their own culinary traditions. Today, the banh mi remains a beloved food in Vietnam, with its French and Vietnamese influences evident in its flavors and ingredients.

site_title: Ex-VW engineer seeks millions in row over patents
summary: A former Volkswagen manager, Wolfgang Schreiber, has filed a multi-million-euro lawsuit against the car giant in a dispute over patents. Schreiber, the former head of VW subsidiaries Bugatti and Bentley, is seeking 10 million euros (S$15.2 million) in the case, which is described as the country's largest-ever patent suit by an employee. The lawsuit was filed before the state court in Munich.

site_title: A straight-talking retailer
summary: Harvey Norman CEO Katie Page-Harvey attributes the group's success in Singapore to its focus on customer experience, despite the retail industry's challenges. The company's flagship store at Millenia Walk has seen strong sales, and its recent launch of a dedicated gaming hub has been a hit. Page-Harvey credits the tech-savvy Singaporean market and changing demographics within the gaming community for the hub's success. She emphasizes the importance of partnerships with suppliers and being hands-on in understanding customer needs to drive business growth, even in the face of e-commerce trends.

images.alt_text: Ms Page- Harvey says: "If you give customers the experience they want. . . they're going to shop with you."

site_title: Microsoft gets support in gag order lawsuit from US companies
summary: Microsoft's lawsuit against a gag order law seeking to prevent companies from informing customers that the government is seeking their data has garnered significant support from major US companies and corporate groups. The US Chamber of Commerce, Delta Air Lines, Eli Lilly, BP America, and tech giants such as Apple, Google, and Amazon have filed briefs in support of Microsoft's case. The filings demonstrate broad backing for the technology industry's stance on digital privacy and surveillance, further solidifying Microsoft's position in its high-profile clash with the US Justice Department.

site_title: May defends delays on China-backed nuclear project
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May defended her decision to delay a China-backed nuclear project at Hinkley Point in southwest England, citing national security concerns. The £18-billion project, which involves a one-third stake by Beijing, was unexpectedly delayed in July after EDF gave it a green light. May stated that she takes a cautious approach to decision-making, and a decision is expected this month. Critics have raised concerns about the project's enormous cost and security risks, echoing Australia's recent decision to block a similar deal with a Chinese consortium.

site_title: SpaceX to shift Florida launches to new pad after explosion
summary: SpaceX will shift its Florida launches to a new pad at NASA's Kennedy Space Center after damage to its launch pad from a rocket explosion. The Federal Aviation Administration has suspended SpaceX flights pending the investigation into the disaster, which destroyed a $200 million communications satellite. The company plans to use the new pad, 39A, which is expected to be operational in November, and has over 70 missions on hold worth $10 billion. SpaceX's priority is to safely return to flight for its customers, with the damaged pad still being assessed for damage.

site_title: Clinton used eight BlackBerrys, but FBI couldn't get them
summary: Hillary Clinton used at least eight mobile devices to send private e-mail during her tenure as secretary of state. The FBI investigation found she flouted security standards by relying on private e-mail for government business. The agency sought at least 13 devices, but was unable to recover any, despite its probe. Clinton's use of private e-mail was a subject of scrutiny during her presidential campaign.

site_title: China ratifies Paris climate agreement: Xinhua
summary: China has ratified the Paris climate agreement, a key step towards the deal's implementation. The move, made by the National People's Congress legislature, brings the deal closer to coming into force. China, the world's biggest polluter, is responsible for around 25% of global carbon emissions. The Paris pact aims to cap global warming at well below 2°C and 1.5°C if possible. With the US also expected to join the agreement, Greenpeace says it's time for the Paris accord to "move from agreement to action."

site_title: Deadly Philippine bomb attack 'terrorism': Duterte
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has branded the bombing of a night market in Davao, which killed at least 14 people, as an act of terrorism. Duterte announced extra powers for the military to combat the threat, but did not confirm suspects. He named two Islamic militant groups and drug lords as potential culprits, including the Abu Sayyaf and the Maute gang. Duterte declared a "state of lawlessness," giving the military more powers to conduct law enforcement operations, amid concerns of reprisals from the Abu Sayyaf following a recent military offensive.

site_title: China passes bill to slash customs duties on 201 IT products
summary: China has passed a bill to slash customs duties on 201 information technology products as part of a US$1.3 trillion World Trade Organisation (WTO) deal. The bill, approved by China's legislature, ratifies an amendment to a tariff concession schedule, marking the first global tariff-cutting deal in 18 years. The move is part of a WTO deal finalized in July 2015, which aims to boost trade between China and other countries. The elimination of customs duties is expected to benefit the IT industry and promote China's participation in the global economy.

site_title: Barack Obama to meet with Theresa May at G-20 in China
summary: US President Barack Obama will meet with British Prime Minister Theresa May on Sunday at the G-20 summit in China, their first official meeting since May took office. The two leaders will discuss bilateral and global issues, including the US-UK special relationship, following Obama's strong opposition to Brexit. Obama will also meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping and Turkish counterpart Recep Tayip Erdogan, amidst complex relations with Turkey. The meeting highlights the importance of maintaining strong alliances during a time of global uncertainty.

site_title: China's Hangzhou turns ghost town as G-20 leaders arrive
summary: China's Hangzhou city was largely deserted on September 3, 2016, ahead of the G-20 summit, with residents and businesses clearing out to accommodate the international leaders. The city, usually home to 9 million people, was eerily quiet, with roads and malls closed, and construction sites halted. The unusual preparations for the summit highlighted the significant security measures in place, as the city transformed into a "ghost town" in anticipation of the high-profile gathering.

site_title: Japan PM urges Putin to work together to resolve island dispute
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged Russian President Vladimir Putin to work together to resolve a decades-long island dispute, warning that the issue could continue for more decades if left unresolved. Abe made the appeal in Vladivostok, Russia, during a business conference where Putin was in attendance. The island dispute has marred ties between the two countries for over seven decades. Abe emphasized the need for a resolution to leave better possibilities for future generations.

site_title: US: Soft jobs report boosts Wall Street shares
summary: US stocks closed higher on Friday after the August jobs report came in short of forecasts, with 151,000 jobs created compared to the 190,000 average of the previous three months. This led to a lower likelihood of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in September. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained 0.4%. Shares in the oil sector rose due to a rebound in crude oil prices, while Mylan and Valeant lost value after Hillary Clinton's comments on prescription drug prices.

site_title: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
summary: China's Commerce Ministry is investigating two US companies, Didi Chuxing and Comcast Corp, over their takeover proposals involving China units. Didi is being probed for its planned acquisition of Uber's China unit, while Comcast's purchase of movie studio DreamWorks Animation is under scrutiny due to its potential impact on the Chinese market. The ministry requires companies to notify it of transactions before they close if they meet certain thresholds, and failure to do so may result in fines and asset sales. The probes underscore China's growing regulatory influence on global deals.

site_title: US dollar gains vs euro, yen on mediocre jobs report
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen after a lackluster US jobs report, with 151,000 net new jobs in August, below the expected 180,000. Analysts split on whether this report supports a Federal Reserve rate hike in September. Some believe it's enough for a September hike, while others expect the Fed to act in December due to potential seasonal adjustment issues. The dollar reached a one-month high against the yen at 103.99 yen.

images.alt_text: The US dollar gained on the euro and yen on Friday after a lackluster US jobs report that supported a Federal Reserve rate rise later this year but not necessarily this month.

site_title: Brazil's sacked leader Rousseff to head home, fight on
summary: Brazil's ex-president Dilma Rousseff, 68, will leave the presidential residence in Brasilia within a month after being sacked by senators over budget manipulation charges. Rousseff claims the impeachment was a "coup" by her successor Michel Temer. She plans to continue fighting from her adopted hometown, Porto Alegre, and has lodged an appeal against the impeachment. Rousseff's Workers' Party is calling for early elections to restore democracy.

site_title: World oil prices rise on Putin remarks
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday following Russian President Vladimir Putin's remarks that Russia and other producing nations should freeze output to stabilize oil prices. Putin stated that a compromise could be reached, despite previous failed efforts. Oil futures rose $1.28 to close at $44.44 per barrel for West Texas Intermediate and $1.38 to settle at $46.83 per barrel for North Sea Brent. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to convene in Algeria later this month, amid speculation that the cartel could agree to limit supply.

site_title: Trump catches up to Clinton: Reuters/Ipsos poll
summary: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has pulled into an effective tie with Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, erasing a substantial deficit as he consolidated support among his party's likely voters. According to the Reuters/Ipsos national tracking poll, 40% of likely voters now support Trump, while 39% back Clinton. This marks a reversal of Clinton's steady decline in support since August 25, and Trump's gains are attributed to Republican support for the party's candidate increasing by six percentage points over the past two weeks.

site_title: Market bomb attack kills 12 in Davao, Philippines
summary: A bomb attack at a night market in Davao, Philippines, killed 12 people and injured dozens. The blast, caused by an improvised explosive device, occurred in the heart of the city, close to a major university and a hotel where President Rodrigo Duterte sometimes holds meetings. Authorities are investigating possible links to drug traffickers or Islamic militants, but have not ruled out the possibility of a drug lord attack. The attack comes amid Duterte's war on crime, which has led to over 2,000 deaths.

site_title: Son of former Chinese premier promoted to transport minister
summary: China's parliament has named Li Xiaopeng, son of former premier Li Peng, as the new transport minister, part of President Xi Jinping's reshuffle ahead of a 2017 party congress. Li Xiaopeng replaces Yang Chuantang and will oversee China's road, air, rail, and water transport networks. This appointment is part of Xi's efforts to consolidate power and appoint close allies to key positions. The move is seen as a key step in Xi's bid to cement his hold on power.

site_title: Putin blasts both Trump and Clinton for 'shock' campaign tactics
summary: Vladimir Putin criticized US presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton for using "shock tactics" during their campaigns. Putin stated he doesn't think they're setting a good example, but refused to publicly favor either candidate, saying he would work with whoever wins. This stance has been disputed by both Trump and Clinton, who have accused Putin of secretly favoring Trump.

images.alt_text: Vladimir Putin blasted both Donald Trump's and Hillary Clinton's tactics on the campaign trail but refused to publicly take sides in a US presidential race in which he's been accused of secretly favouring the New York real estate billionaire.

site_title: Sony misses the big picture
summary: The Sony Xperia X, a premium smartphone, fails to impress with its outdated hardware and features. Despite its 23MP camera and full HD display, its performance is sluggish and image quality is marred by grain and jagged edges. The phone's design is also criticized for its lack of innovation, with a box-like design and unusual placement of features such as the NFC chip and fingerprint sensor. At a price point of S$848, the Xperia X is not a compelling option, and its lack of notable features makes it unlikely to draw buyers into the shop.

site_title: Territorial dispute dominates Abe-Putin meeting in Vladivostok
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Russian President Vladimir Putin held talks in Vladivostok, where they discussed a territorial dispute over the Kurile islands, with Abe expressing optimism about a resolution based on mutual trust. The issue has restricted economic cooperation between Japan and Russia since World War II. Abe presented economic cooperation proposals, which analysts say could influence their diplomatic relationship. The two leaders agreed to continue talks on the territorial dispute, with Putin stating that neither side would feel defeated or a loser in finding a solution.

site_title: Marina One gains from 'flight to efficiency'
summary: Singapore's office market is experiencing a "flight to efficiency" as companies seek larger, more efficient floor plates in new developments. Julius Baer signed a lease at Marina One for a 100,000 sq ft high-density floor, while Guoco Tower has secured over 70% pre-commitment leases for its 890,000 sq ft of prime Grade-A office space. Effective rents remain in the single-digits, with market watchers attributing the trend to economic uncertainties and businesses not growing. The trend is expected to continue, with larger floor plates becoming more attractive to tenants seeking workspace flexibility and efficiency.

site_title: Ahead of Suu Kyi visit, Obama weighs Myanmar sanctions relief
summary: US President Barack Obama is considering easing or lifting sanctions against Myanmar ahead of Aung San Suu Kyi's visit to Washington, a move seen as a key part of his foreign policy achievements. Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, will meet with Obama and other US leaders to discuss ways to balance economic rewards with pressure on the country's generals for reforms. The sanctions, imposed during her years as a jailed opposition leader, restrict business with military-run enterprises and impose import bans on Myanmar's jade and gemstones.

site_title: Oxley to develop medical hub in Chongqing
summary: Singapore property developer Oxley Holdings has signed a 5 billion yuan (S$1 billion) deal to develop Lijia Health City in Chongqing, China. The 533,000 sq m mixed-use development will feature a hospital, specialist clinics, residences, nursing homes, and medical research centre. Oxley's CEO Ching Chiat Kwong believes the project will take around five years to recoup the initial investment and is optimistic about its potential. The development will cater to China's growing middle and upper-class population seeking high-quality medical facilities.

site_title: Beijing probes 2 high-profile takeover bids
summary: China's Ministry of Commerce is investigating two high-profile takeover proposals: Didi Chuxing's acquisition of Uber's China unit and Comcast's purchase of DreamWorks Animation. The probes underscore China's tough stance on firms striking deals without its approval, even those with limited impact in China. This move highlights China's increasing influence over foreign companies' dealings in the country.

site_title: Exxon ignores LNG near-term glut to focus on long-term view
