summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is shifting its focus from short-term natural gas market fluctuations to a long-term view, anticipating a 1.6% annual demand rise for liquefied natural gas (LNG) until 2040, more than double the rate for crude oil. The company is investing in untapped natural gas fields in Papua New Guinea and Mozambique, aiming to capitalize on expected future growth. Exxon's strategy stands in contrast to Royal Dutch Shell's aggressive LNG expansion plans, which prioritize short-term market gains.

site_title: No stand-out presidential candidate
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump is unlikely to be elected, according to European analysts. The electoral college system, where 270 votes are needed for victory, favors Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton. Trump's divisive rhetoric and lack of substance have sparked concerns about the future of US politics and global relations, potentially leading to a realignment of American politics and the spread of populism worldwide.

site_title: Home robots, drones top trends at IFA tech fair
summary: The IFA tech fair in Berlin showcased the latest trends in consumer electronics, including home robots, drones, and smart home appliances. Sharp unveiled its IGZO technology, enabling frameless TVs with outstanding image quality and low power consumption. Acer unveiled a new VR headset, while Samsung showcased its Gear VR headset and smartwatch. Analysts believe VR offers untapped opportunities for entertainment, tourism, and news consumption. Meanwhile, smartwatches are expected to double in sales to 67 million units in 2017, with companies like Samsung and Siemens introducing smart appliances into kitchens.

site_title: Leaders hold talks in 'paradise on earth'
summary: US President Barack Obama and new British Prime Minister Theresa May will attend the two-day G-20 summit in Hangzhou, China, starting Sunday. The summit aims to lower trade costs and boost trade in services. China, the world's second-largest economy, is hosting the event, and leaders will discuss issues like trade facilitation, which could boost global trade volume by $1 trillion annually. The summit's outcomes will be released on Monday evening, with Chinese President Xi Jinping expected to hold a press conference.

site_title: Make mine whisky
summary: Whisky sales are rising in Singapore, with 20% year-on-year growth, driven by a younger demographic and increasing interest in Japanese whiskies. Whisky bars, such as Quaich and The Whisky Distillery, are expanding, offering a wide range of whiskies and whisky pairings. Restaurants like UsQuBa and The Joint are also incorporating whisky into their menus, with sommeliers providing expert guidance. While education and industry evolution are crucial for growth, the collecting culture of rare whiskies is also pushing importers to bring in rarer bottles, benefiting those who want to drink and collect whisky.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AusGroup, an oil and gas subcontractor, halted trading after a Singapore Exchange request due to an article in the press. The company will review the article to determine if further disclosure is required. Meanwhile, SunMoon Food Company's subsidiary, Taian SunMoon International Trading Co., has been incorporated in China with an issued capital of US$800,000.

site_title: PM meets Xi Jinping on sidelines of G-20 meeting
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met Chinese President Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the G-20 Summit in Hangzhou, China. The two leaders reaffirmed their countries' close friendship and discussed upgrading the China-Singapore free-trade agreement and the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative project. Xi praised Singapore's role in China's seven free-trade zones, while Lee committed to carrying out his country's dialogue role with China. The meeting marked the start of Lee's four-day visit to China.

site_title: Team SunMoon play catch up
summary: Team SunMoon secured the top spot in The Business Times Corporate Golf League with a stableford score of 113, edging out Team Edge Golf. With one round remaining, the outcome is uncertain, as Team Edge Golf is six points behind. The best social team was Banyan Tree, while Tan Teck Lee (Team SunMoon) achieved the highest individual stableford score. The final round will be played on September 16 at Tanah Merah Country Club's Garden Course.

site_title: Vietnam govt to sell its stake in country's two top breweries
summary: Vietnam's government plans to sell its stake in Habeco and Sabeco, the country's two top breweries, and target a $2.2 billion raise over the next 16 months. The decision aims to loosen the government's grip on the beer market, which has been a subject of uncertainty and flip-flopping. The stakes will be auctioned to both domestic and international investors, marking a significant shift in the country's approach to its unlisted breweries.

site_title: Park Hotel Group makes foray into South Korea
summary: The Park Hotel Group has entered South Korea by signing a management contract with K2 Group to operate the 150-room Park Hotel Yeongdeungpo in Seoul. The hotel is set to open early next year, coinciding with South Korea's double-digit year-on-year growth in inbound tourism. The move aims to expand the group's brand presence in the country, with Seoul serving as a launchpad for further expansion.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine's target price is set at S$0.90 by CIMB Research, indicating a potential reduction in the company's stock value. The article does not provide further details on the reason behind the reduction.

site_title: Making its debut swing in the league
summary: Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts made its debut in The Business Times Corporate Golf League, participating in its first year. The team, led by assistant vice-president Paul Wilson, aimed to network with the Singapore golf community, including media and industry professionals. The league featured a diverse group of industries, including banking, media, and healthcare. Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts sponsored the event, providing over S$300,000 in green fee vouchers and prizes, including hotel stays and golf rounds at their resorts. The company's participation was seen as a way to thank existing clients and further relationships.

site_title: Yanlord to redevelop land in Zhongshan through acquisition
summary: Yanlord Land Group has entered a strategic alliance with China Resources Land Ltd to redevelop a 1.23 sq km site in Zhongshan, Guangdong, through a 64 million yuan (S$13 million) acquisition. The partnership will allow Yanlord to develop a "landmark lifestyle and services hub" in Zhongshan, leveraging its track record in primary land redevelopment projects. The deal is expected to enhance Yanlord's competitive advantage in property development and complement its existing footprint in the Pearl River Delta region.

site_title: Samsung recalls Note 7 phones globally for battery fault
summary: Samsung is recalling its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones globally due to a faulty battery that can cause the phone to explode when charging. The recall affects 10 countries, including Singapore, and is expected to halt sales. The company has announced a global replacement program and apologized for the issue, which has been linked to 35 reported cases worldwide. Analysts predict a decline in shipments and sales, with estimates of 12 million units sold this year, down from a previous estimate of 14 million.

site_title: Malaysia aims to 'harmonise' palm oil export duty plan with Indonesia
summary: Malaysia aims to harmonize its palm oil export duty plan with Indonesia's more competitive levies to win global market share. The move follows Indonesia's lower land and labor costs, making it the world's No 2 producer and exporter of palm oil. This is the first official statement from a Malaysian minister on the issue, which the palm sector has long sought.

images.alt_text: Palm oil companies, under pressure to improve the transparency of their supply chain, are now focusing on traceability as the next frontier in their sustainability efforts.

site_title: US banks need better defences against rates shock: regulators
summary: US banks are at risk of being trapped by a sudden spike in interest rates due to a gap between long-term loans and short-term funding. Regulators warn that the widening gap could force banks to pay more to cover their immediate financing needs than they earn on their loans. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and Office of Financial Research have expressed concerns that a surprise rate hike could lead to economic impacts apart from monetary policy, citing the 1980s savings and loan crisis as a precedent.

site_title: Networking on the greens for first-timers
summary: Team SAS Institute, comprising staff and customers/partners, participated in a social golf league for the first time. The team, led by Tan Poh Choo, aims to bond and potentially explore business opportunities. With a non-competitive atmosphere, they've enjoyed the variety of courses, which added challenge and excitement to the rounds. The team's participation is part of their effort to keep employees happy and productive, and they may consider a competitive team in future years.

site_title: In China's green car boom, global players choose different gear
summary: China's government has set strict new green standards for carmakers by 2020, requiring them to cut pollution in cities. Domestic firms like Geely and GAC Motor are heavily investing in electric cars, but foreign players like Audi are opting for petrol-driven cars with hybrid technology, citing concerns over cost, risk, and consumer demand. Despite China's massive car market, foreign carmakers are focusing on gradual strategies to improve efficiency, with Audi planning to launch its first locally produced plug-in hybrid vehicle this year.

site_title: Losing the art of human communication
summary: Human communication is declining due to excessive internet and device reliance, causing social and commercial problems. The overuse of technology has led to decreased face-to-face interaction, poor education, and increased anti-social behavior. Commercially, there is a decline in real experience and customer service, with a reliance on databases and call centers. The inability to communicate with the right people has become a significant issue, with companies removing phone numbers and addresses from their websites. The author questions whether we are losing the art of human communication and urges people to find ways to interact with others in a more meaningful way.

site_title: Asiatravel's 'greying' placement deal gets a whitewash
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings has secured a second "whitewash" waiver for its S$100 million share placement from Zhonghong Holding, a Beijing-based property developer and majority owner, after the Securities Industry Council (SIC) granted the extension. This means that independent shareholders may have to reapprove the deal, potentially delaying its completion. The whitewash waiver allows Zhonghong to acquire over 30% interest in Asiatravel without making a general offer, raising concerns among minority shareholders about the lack of transparency and control.

site_title: Lessons on bee-ing innovative
summary: A new invention from Australia, the Flow Hive, allows for "honey on tap" by harvesting pure honey directly from the hive without opening it. The device uses a key to release fresh, ready-to-eat honey, disrupting conventional beekeeping practices that have remained largely unchanged since the late 1800s. The Flow Hive has generated millions of dollars in revenue and is set to change the beekeeping industry.

images.alt_text: AS OLD ECONOMY AS IT GETS: The Flow Hive is completely lacking in any IT element - it was thoughtful engineering that made the difference, not sensors or apps to track honey output.

site_title: Rekindling China's animal spirits
summary: China's economy, which has been sustained by public-sector investment, is facing a decline in private investment, hindering GDP growth. The decline is attributed to cyclical and technical factors, including a weakening of the housing market, which has led to a structural decline in demand for capital-intensive goods. The government's policy shift from chasing high growth rates to achieving growth quality through structural reforms has also contributed to this decline. To regain animal spirits, China needs to find new sources of final demand, which could come from services and high-value-added manufacturing sectors protected by government monopoly.

site_title: US artists explore emotional response to Sept 11
summary: US artists are exploring their emotional response to the 9/11 attacks through a new exhibit, "Rendering the Unthinkable: Artists Respond to 9/11", at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum in Manhattan. The exhibit features 13 New York City-based artists creating mixed media artworks, paintings, sculptures, and videos in response to the attacks. The exhibit aims to provide a personal and emotional perspective on the event, differing from the museum's permanent exhibitions, which focus on telling the story of the attacks and commemorating the victims.

site_title: Sturgeon launches new Scottish independence drive after Brexit
summary: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced a new push for Scottish independence following the UK's June vote to leave the EU. The SNP will send thousands of supporters to gauge public support for independence, two years after a referendum where Scots rejected independence by 10 percentage points. The move comes as the UK navigates its Brexit departure.

site_title: S'poreans are old hands at using crowdfunding tool Kickstarter
summary: Singaporeans have been actively using Kickstarter since 2009, with nearly 60,000 backers and over 250,000 pledges to projects worldwide. The platform has become simpler for Singapore creators to use, requiring only a local bank account and verified ID to launch projects. Successful projects like STEPP, a wearable gadget, have showcased the platform's potential for innovative products. Kickstarter's spokesman notes that Singapore's culture and innovation make it an exciting centre for creative projects, with a localized platform now available to individuals in the US, UK, and other countries.

site_title: August hiring steady at 151,000 jobs despite lacklustre growth
summary: The US economy added 151,000 jobs in August, steady with July's 275,000 gain, despite lacklustre global growth. The jobless rate and labor participation rate remained unchanged, while wage gains moderated. The Federal Reserve will weigh the jobs data as it considers raising interest rates for the first time in 2016. Manufacturing sector showed signs of improvement with a 1.9% increase in new orders for factory goods in July.

site_title: Turning the page
summary: F&B chef Daniel Sia is leaving The Disgruntled Chef restaurants, where he started in 2010, after six years. He cites a desire for new challenges in his career and will be focusing on his own brand. Sia, who introduced the sharing plate concept, will continue to operate The Disgruntled Chef until mid-October.

site_title: Debao to be removed from SGX watch list
summary: Debao Property Development, a China-based property play, will be removed from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) watch list, effective September 5, 2016, after recording a volume weighted average price of at least 20 Singapore cents over the last six months. This satisfies the minimum trading price exit criterion. The removal comes after SGX reviewed the company's status on September 1.

site_title: Jobs elusive in India despite rapid growth
summary: India's rapid economic growth has failed to create sufficient new jobs, leaving many, like Ashok Kumar, struggling to make ends meet. Kumar, a 25-year-old truck driver, earns a stagnant $150 monthly salary, supporting 13 family members. Despite emerging as the world's fastest-growing major economy two years ago, India's economy has not expanded fast enough to absorb new job seekers. Experts warn that this issue will continue unless the government takes steps to address the shortage of jobs and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Power to Porsche
summary: The second-generation Porsche Panamera has made its debut, boasting more power, comfort, and style. The new model retains a sleek profile with a smooth window line and distinctive LED lights. It features a spacious interior, new technology, and a range of powerful engines, including the Panamera Turbo with 550 hp and a 0-100 km/h time of 3.6 seconds. The Panamera also boasts advanced driver aids and a new cabin design with a 12.3-inch touchscreen and buttonless surfaces.

site_title: Google shelves plan for smartphone with interchangeable parts: sources
summary: Google has suspended Project Ara, its modular smartphone initiative, as part of a broader hardware effort simplification. The company had announced partners and planned a developer edition shipment in autumn 2016. This marks a reversal after announcing the project at a developer conference in May. The decision is part of a push to streamline Google's hardware efforts.

site_title: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as US job gains slow
summary: US traders reduced expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate hike after a government report showed the US added fewer jobs than expected last month. Nonfarm payrolls rose 151,000 jobs, lower than the 180,000 expected. Analyst Thomas Simons stated that the number "is not a compelling number for the Fed and it is not going to force their hand for a hike in September." The reduced expectations may indicate a slower pace of rate hikes.

site_title: Citi raises S$450,000 for ChildAid
summary: Citi has raised S$450,000 for ChildAid, a charity event benefiting The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The donation, split evenly between the two funds, aims to support disadvantaged children in Singapore. This is the latest in Citi's long-term support, with over S$3.9 million donated since 2002. The bank's commitment is part of its corporate purpose to make a positive impact on the community.

images.alt_text: MAKING A DIFFERENCE: Mr Ng (centre) joining senior Citi executives, including Mr McCarroll (left), to present the cheque to the co-chairs of ChildAid - Mr Tay (right) and Ms Goh (second from left).

site_title: Indonesia tycoons' support for tax amnesty boost plan's credibility
summary: Indonesia's two wealthiest men, James Riady and Tahir, have announced their participation in the government-led tax amnesty program, boosting its credibility. The program, which aims to collect 165 trillion rupiah (S$16.9 billion) in revenue, has seen the finance ministry earn 4 trillion rupiah in penalty fees since its inception in July. Riady's and Tahir's involvement is seen as a significant step in encouraging others to participate, with economist Wellian Wiranto stating that "big fish" joining the program can inspire others to follow suit, increasing the program's momentum.

site_title: Negativity about the global outlook is driving gold
summary: The gold price is rising despite central bankers cutting gold purchases by 40% in the second quarter. This is partly due to technical factors such as weak global exports, but also due to concerns about the global financial system following the 2008 trauma. Central bankers, including the US Federal Reserve, are accused of market manipulation, and the lack of action by G-20 leaders may exacerbate global market bubbles. The rising gold price is attributed to easy money creating a new bull market, and the absence of structural reforms is seen as enabling timid world leaders.

site_title: Digital upheaval sweeping Australia food service industry
summary: A digital upheaval is sweeping the Australian food service industry, with the rise of food delivery services like UberEats and Just Eat. Established food order-taking websites are being forced to adapt, with some restaurants opting to outsource delivery operations to these firms. The shift is driven by cost-cutting measures and the growing demand for convenience. As a result, online food orders in Australia have surged, with monthly orders exceeding 1 million and growth rates exceeding 39% for the first five months of the year. However, concerns have been raised about the sustainability of this market, with some analysts describing an investment bubble.

site_title: Entrenched elitism in UK banking sector: report
summary: A UK government advisory body report finds entrenched elitism in the banking sector, with half of top investment bankers attending fee-paying schools despite less than 7% of UK pupils attending private schools. The report highlights barriers for "bright working-class kids" who lack knowledge of elite culture rules. To break the class ceiling, employers should collect data on employees' backgrounds to cast a wider net for talent from state schools, according to the Social Mobility Commission.

site_title: No evidence of Olympic Zika spread, WHO committee says
summary: The World Health Organization's emergency committee has concluded that there is no evidence of a significant Zika virus spread due to the Olympic games in Rio de Janeiro. Despite this, the risk assessment for the upcoming Paralympics remains unchanged, with no reported cases among returning athletes. Most Zika cases are asymptomatic, and nobody has reported symptoms upon returning from the games. The committee's head, Peter Salama, expressed confidence in the low risk assessment.

site_title: Click for decor
summary: Two online Scandinavian vintage furniture stores, Mobler and Bibliotek, have launched in Singapore. Mobler, founded by Swedish sisters Emelie and Ellen Heden, offers a range of antique and vintage furniture pieces from the 1800s to the 1960s. Prices range from S$60 for a tin bowl to S$3,000 for a metal chest of drawers. Mobler plans to expand to Malaysia, Hong Kong, and the Asia-Pacific region. Bibliotek, founded by Alvin Tan and his wife, offers a curated selection of Scandinavian and international furniture brands, including Alessi and Normann Copenhagen. The couple aims to provide a convenient and approachable online shopping experience for consumers.

site_title: Spa wars (Amended)
summary: Singapore's beauty spas have become increasingly popular, offering advanced facial machines for flawless skin. Luxurious spas and medispas compete for clients, promising rejuvenation at a price. To navigate the options, face spas offer relaxing treatments, while medispas focus on more invasive procedures. The article aims to simplify the process by categorizing skin-savers and providing budget-friendly options, making it easier for individuals to find the best fit for their needs and budget.

site_title: Car market becomes a hard sell in US
summary: The US car market has become a hard sell, with major carmakers missing analysts' estimates for August. Sales declined 4.2% to 1.51 million light vehicles, the lowest since July, with incentives failing to boost demand. The pickup market, a key contributor to US carmakers' profits, also saw a decline. Industry analysts attribute the softness to a lack of pent-up demand, with buyers opting for higher-priced vehicles, and the industry's six-year growth run coming to an end.

site_title: Keep pace
summary: The Jaguar F-Pace 3.0 S is the most powerful version of the F-Pace crossover, featuring a 3.0-litre V6 supercharged petrol engine producing 380 hp and 450 Nm of torque. With an 8-speed automatic transmission and all-wheel-drive system, the F-Pace delivers a smooth and responsive drive, reaching 0-100 km/h in 5.5 seconds. The F-Pace also offers a spacious cabin, good rear legroom, and a large boot, making it a practical and useable everyday car.

site_title: US affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, Korea, Britain
summary: The US International Trade Commission voted to lock in duties on imports of cold-rolled steel flat products from Brazil, India, Korea, and Britain, with rates ranging from 20-58.36%. The decision came after the Commerce Department found the products were being sold at below fair value and unfairly subsidized. In contrast, imports from Russia were not found to be harming the US industry, and therefore will not face duties. The move is aimed at protecting the US steel industry from foreign competition.

site_title: Swiber white knight may come from outside industry
summary: Swiber Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine (O&M) company, has received an extension to explore potential buyers or white knights for its assets amid a multi-year downturn in the industry. The company's interim judicial management (IJM) report, due on Friday, will identify potential buyers, which could include private equity firms seeking opportunistic returns. However, experts caution that securing such investments may be challenging, and the company's stakeholders should prepare for a potentially reduced payout to secured creditors, with unsecured creditors facing uncertainty over potential recovery of operating cash flows.

site_title: S'pore firms urged to seize Chongqing opportunities
summary: Singapore's largest companies, including PSA International and CapitaLand, are in Chongqing, China, to explore business opportunities in the city as part of the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative. The initiative focuses on four sectors: financial services, aviation, transport & logistics, and ICT. Chongqing has been granted a free-trade zone status, expected to boost trade and cross-border investments. Singapore Business Federation chairman Teo Siong Seng is leading a delegation to work with the Chongqing government and companies, aiming to seize opportunities in the Belt and Road initiative.

site_title: Keppel FELS signs heads of agreement to define Russian anchor projects
summary: Keppel FELS has signed a heads of agreement (HOA) with Rosneft and MHWirth to define anchor projects for their joint-venture company, Zvezda-Keppel Design and Engineering Center. The projects will focus on offshore drilling rigs to be built jointly by Keppel FELS and the Zvezda Shipbuilding complex in the Russian Federation. The partners will adhere to US and European Union sanctions in their business activities. The agreement was signed after a press release by Rosneft on Thursday, with discussions on potential projects at a preliminary stage.

site_title: Oil up as US jobs data hits dollar; still headed for weekly loss
summary: US jobs data showed weaker employment growth in August, suppressing the dollar and pushing up oil prices. Oil rose over 2% as Brent crude futures increased $1.25 to $46.73 a barrel, despite being on track for its biggest weekly loss since late July. The Federal Reserve's interest rate decision remains uncertain, and a potential oil price boost may be short-lived, with analysts predicting volatility over the coming weeks.

site_title: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
summary: Louis Vuitton has launched its first perfume range in 29 years, targeting middle-income shoppers with a collection of seven perfumes priced around 200 euros per 100ml bottle. The move aims to boost sales growth after a three-year slowdown, with analysts estimating the perfumes could generate 60-80 million euros in sales in the first year. The launch comes amid a downturn in luxury spending and a need for the brand to balance increasing affordability with maintaining its exclusivity.

site_title: China watchdog plans to improve securities vetting process for ChiNext
summary: China's securities watchdog, the CSRC, plans to reduce the number of regulators responsible for vetting securities issuance on the ChiNext growth board to 25 from 35, aiming to improve efficiency. This reform is part of a broader effort to streamline the vetting process, with a focus on part-time members who have insufficient work. The reduction aims to enhance structure and increase efficiency in the vetting process.

site_title: Ventures beyond the kitchen
summary: Four chefs/restaurateurs have successfully transitioned into other aspects of the F&B business, leveraging their expertise to overcome challenges. Chef Julien Bompard, who closed his restaurant, Le Saint Julien, to start Cuisine Service Pte Ltd, a central production kitchen supplying prepared foods to restaurants. Chef Daniel Tay founded Foodgnostic Pte Ltd, a one-stop manufacturing solution for high-quality food products and services. Chef Alfred Ow expanded his family's business, Quan Xiang Yuan Seafood Restaurant, into a frozen food manufacturing factory, and Chef Lee Chiang Howe diversified into exporting delicacies like abalone and shark's fins. These entrepreneurs have capitalized on modern technologies and market trends to create new business opportunities and overcome labor shortages.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing conditions seen stabilising with August PMI at 49.8
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted for the 14th consecutive month in August, with a purchasing managers' index of 49.8, up 0.5 from July. However, the electronics cluster, which accounts for most factory output, reported its first month-on-month expansion after 13 months. This suggests signs of stabilisation in the sector, with higher new orders, exports, and factory output. The Nikkei manufacturing PMI also hinted at stabilisation, stabilizing after a seven-month decline.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S manufacturing sector contracted again for the 14th straight month in August, but signs of stabilisation could be seen, said observers.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing inches towards stabilisation with August PMI at 49.8
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed a slight improvement in August, with the purchasing managers' index (PMI) at 49.8, up 0.5 from July's 49.3. The sector has contracted for 14 months, but the reading indicates it may be stabilizing. The electronics cluster, a major contributor to factory output, reported its first month-on-month expansion in 13 months, with a PMI of 50.2. This marks a potential turnaround in the sector, with experts predicting stabilization rather than continued expansion for the second half of 2016.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, similar to H1 operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, amid a 5-day Singapore stock rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore investor protection amendments are set to be introduced in Parliament, aiming to boost safeguards for wealthier investors. The Monetary Authority of Singapore reported 151 Zika cases, with one confirmed case in neighboring Malaysia. Keppel Fels signed a heads of agreement with Rosneft and MHWirth to define Russian projects. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1.9% weaker due to US interest rate hike worries and telco concerns.

site_title: 38 new cases of Zika, four not in existing clusters
summary: Singapore reports 38 new cases of Zika virus as of September 2, with 34 cases in the Aljunied area and four unlinked cases. The Ministry of Health and National Environment Agency issued a joint statement. This brings the total number of confirmed cases to an unspecified amount.

site_title: US factory orders post largest increase in nine months
summary: US factory orders increased 1.9% in July, the largest rise in nine months, after a downwardly revised 1.8% decrease in June. This follows two straight months of declines. Economists had forecast a 2.0% rise. The rebound is seen as a hopeful sign for the manufacturing sector, which has been embattled. The data suggests broad demand for US factory goods, but the overall economic outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group shares soar in heavy August trading
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) shares soared 91.4% in August, with a 190.7% spike in trading volume, making it the biggest volume jumper in the month. The healthcare provider's net profit and revenue increased, and it announced a 100% boost in ownership of Lifescan Imaging. A "buy" rating and target price from RHB also contributed to the surge. SMG's year-to-date return was 89%.

site_title: Freight rates jump as Hanjin collapse spurs supply shock
summary: Container freight rates have surged 36.6% to $949 per TEU after South Korean Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd defaulted, sparking a supply shock in the market. The collapse has led to 44 of Hanjin's 98 container ships being denied access to ports in Asia and the US, with one ship seized in Singapore. Shippers are reluctant to use Hanjin vessels, and ports are hesitant to accept them due to payment concerns. The rate increase has affected routes from Asia to Northern Europe and the US West and East Coasts, further exacerbating a tight market.

site_title: US nonfarm payrolls rise less than expected; wage growth moderates
summary: US nonfarm payrolls rose 151,000 jobs in August, below the expected 180,000. Wage growth moderated to 2.4% year-over-year, which may rule out an interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve this month. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4.9%. The slowdown in job growth is normal, and the economy's recovery from the 2007-09 recession is showing signs of aging. The next rate hike timing could be influenced by wage growth and labor market conditions.

site_title: China's big show in Hangzhou
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang attended the 2016 China International Big Data Conference in Hangzhou, marking a significant showcase of the country's technological advancements. The event aimed to promote the development of the country's big data industry. Meanwhile, a turf war between Alibaba and rival companies is causing a potential $100 billion rout. China's President Xi Jinping hinted at an end to deflationary price wars, while Huawei is seeking AI chip customers in the Middle East and Southeast Asia. US stock markets reached fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: US: Wall St rises as jobs data reins in Sept rate hike bets
summary: US stocks rose on Friday after the Labor Department reported US employment growth slowed more than expected in August, potentially ruling out an interest rate increase this month. Nonfarm payrolls rose 151,000, while the unemployment rate remained at 4.9%. This beat economists' forecasts of 180,000 payrolls. The news boosted Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Opec output rises to record before talks with Russia on freeze
summary: Opec's crude production rose to a record 33.69 million barrels a day in August, driven by increases from Iran, Iraq, and Kuwait, offsetting losses in Nigeria and Libya. The group will hold informal talks with Russia in Algiers to discuss a potential output freeze, with Russian President Putin seeking a deal to limit supply. However, analysts note that the production freeze will have limited impact, as Opec members are already producing at maximum capacity, and a meaningful cut is necessary to affect prices.

site_title: Update: Samsung recalls Note 7 smartphones globally on battery fault
summary: Samsung Electronics Co recalled its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones globally due to a faulty battery, which has been linked to explosions when charging. The recall affects about 1 million units, with 600,000 sold overseas, and sales will be halted in 10 countries. The company announced a global replacement program, taking a relatively quick response to the serious product defect, and apologized for the issue. The recall is a blow to Samsung's reputation, just days before its arch-rival Apple is set to unveil new iPhones.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.240 points to 1,671.79 on Friday, closing higher. The index saw 1.433 billion lots traded worth RM1.53 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 469 to 327.

site_title: Yanlord to engage in primary land redevelopment project in Zhongshan, Guangdong
summary: Yanlord Land Group has entered a strategic alliance with China Resources Land Limited's subsidiary to develop a 1.23 square kilometer site in Zhongshan, Guangdong, into a lifestyle and services hub. The alliance was achieved through a 64 million yuan (S$13 million) acquisition of shares in Zhongshan Renyuan Investment. This project marks Yanlord's participation in a provincial-level project in Guangdong, showcasing its expansion plans in the region.

site_title: Sterling, stocks rise after UK construction survey
summary: Sterling and the FTSE 100 index rose to a day's high after a UK construction survey showed the downturn in the construction sector was easing. The Markit/CIPS UK Construction PMI rose to 49.2 from 45.9, beating forecasts. Sterling reached a four-week high of US$1.3318 and the euro weakened to a day's low of 84.16 pence. The construction PMI follows a sharp rebound in the manufacturing sector, which jumped to a 10-month high of 53.3 in August.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed 11.6% to $39.5 billion in July, the lowest in three months, as exports rose 1.9% to a 10-month high of $186.3 billion. This follows a revision of June's trade deficit to $44.7 billion. Despite this, economists warn that export growth may be hindered by the dollar's surge against trading partners' currencies. The IMF is expected to downgrade its 2016 global growth forecast due to weak demand and trade.

site_title: Debao Property Development to be removed from SGX watch-list
summary: Debao Property Development has been removed from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) watch-list, effective September 5, 2016, following the company's six-month average price of at least 20 Singapore cents. The decision comes after Debao met the SGX's criteria for removal from the watch-list.

site_title: Hong Kong health warning over festive 'mooncakes'
summary: Hong Kong health authorities have warned residents to maintain a balanced diet and avoid excessive eating of sugar-laden "mooncakes" during the mid-autumn festival. The dense pastries, typically consumed during this time, can pack a calorific punch with high sugar and fat content. One popular brand's double-yolk mooncake contains almost half the recommended daily calorie intake for women and one-third for men. Despite the warning, many Hong Kongers plan to indulge in the traditional treats, citing their cultural significance.

site_title: Incumbents' stocks tumble on 4th telco bids
summary: Singapore's three incumbent telcos suffered a significant drop in stock prices after three new companies expressed interest in bidding for the country's fourth telco at an upcoming airwave auction. MyRepublic, TPG Telecom, and airYotta, led by former OMGTel executives, have increased the chances of another player entering the market, according to Citi analysts. The new entrants have heightened concerns about the incumbents' market share and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Singapore's three incumbent telcos took a hammering in the stock market on Friday after three other companies expressed their interest to bid at an upcoming airwave auction to become Singapore's fourth telco.

site_title: Millions strike in India over wages, economic reforms
summary: Millions of public sector workers in India went on strike, protesting against Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plans for greater privatization and a proposed minimum wage hike they deem inadequate. Up to 150 million workers, including those in nursing, manufacturing, and coal mining, participated in the 24-hour nationwide strike. The strike was called after talks with Finance Minister Arun Jaitley broke down, with workers rejecting his offer to raise the minimum wage from 6,396 rupees to 9,100 rupees. The strike demands an end to privatization, an increase in the minimum wage, and universal social security.

site_title: Dubai debuts driverless minibus
summary: Dubai has launched a month-long trial of a driverless minibus, the first of its kind in the city. The 10-seat, electric vehicle can travel at 25mph and adapt to its surroundings, including stopping if a pedestrian is present. Developed by Easy Mile and Omnix, the bus can navigate Dubai's main tourist attractions and is seen as a step towards automating 25% of the city's transport network by 2030, according to the Road Transport Authority.

images.alt_text: Dubai has unveiled its first driverless bus service, launching a month-long trial period for the electric vehicle with a view to expanding it across the futuristic Gulf city state.

site_title: China to display growth playbook at Hangzhou G-20 summit
summary: China is set to showcase its economic growth strategy at the upcoming Hangzhou G-20 summit, featuring a city transformed by billions of dollars in infrastructure investment. However, this strategy comes with significant costs, including a high debt bill and overcapacity issues. China's economy is struggling with a debt-to-GDP ratio of over 2.5, and the country's growth is expected to slow. Despite these challenges, China's leaders may be tempted to adopt a similar stimulus playbook, prioritizing short-term growth over long-term sustainability. The G-20 summit will provide a platform for policymakers to discuss these issues.

images.alt_text: CITY TRANSFORMED: Vice-Finance Minister Zhu Guangyao said at a briefing in Hangzhou on Friday that China should have a 'more active' fiscal policy, citing the failure of monetary policy in other nations.

site_title: Caterpillar set to lay off 2,000 workers in Belgium
summary: Caterpillar is planning to close its plant in Gosselies, Belgium, and lay off approximately 2,000 workers due to lower demand. The company is considering relocating production to its Grenoble, France facility and other international sites. This move is part of its restructuring efforts, which also include job cuts in Northern Ireland and the potential end of production for 25-tonne material handlers. The company cited global economic uncertainty and sluggish conditions in energy and mining as contributing factors to its decision.

site_title: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
summary: Private equity firms Carlyle Group and TPG Capital have formed separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores, worth between $2 billion and $3 billion. They are partnering with Chinese state companies Citic Group and Beijing Capital Agribusiness Group, respectively. The deals, which must be finalized by mid-September, are part of McDonald's shift towards a less capital-intensive franchise model. The winning bidder will have a large minority stake in the restaurants, which account for over 85% of McDonald's global outlets in China and Hong Kong.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end up before US jobs, G20
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose ahead of a US jobs report and China's G20 summit. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.45% to 23,266.70, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.13% to 3,067.35. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.40%. These gains were attributed to market anticipation of a positive US jobs report, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks end higher; investors eye US jobs data
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.4% against the US dollar, ending the week flat, while South Korean shares edged up 0.3% as foreign investors bought Kospi shares. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,038.31, paring weekly losses. Investors await the US jobs report, which may influence the Federal Reserve's monetary policy later this month.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker on US rate hike worries; telcos hit
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.9% to 2,803.92 on Friday, weighed down by concerns over a possible US interest rate hike and the potential entry of a fourth telco. Singtel was the main loser, dropping S$0.35 or 8.3% for the week. Other telcos, M1 and Starhub, also declined. The decline follows US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments at Jackson Hole, which have kept a lid on Wall Street stocks and bonds.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open, before US jobs report
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, driven by gains in the mining and healthcare sectors. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.4%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also rose. The focus was on the upcoming US jobs report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

site_title: China home prices seen up 10% in 2016 on strong demand: poll
summary: China's home prices are expected to rise 10% in 2016 due to strong demand, but will nearly stall in 2017 as more cities impose curbs to curb sharp price rises. The country's average nationwide home prices are expected to increase from a year ago, driven by favorable macroeconomic policies and hot demand in developed cities. However, analysts predict that prices in third and fourth-tier cities will underperform due to high inventories and sluggish demand.

site_title: Cover up, stay in: Singaporeans wary as Zika spreads
summary: Singaporeans are taking precautions against the Zika virus, covering up and staying indoors to avoid mosquito bites. Over 150 cases have been reported since the first locally contracted infection, and authorities are increasing spraying insecticide and clearing stagnant water to prevent mosquito breeding. The outbreak coincides with a slowdown in trade-dependent Singapore, potentially impacting retail sales and tourism. While some experts warn of potential economic and tourism impacts, others believe the event will not significantly affect the city-state's tourism industry, particularly with the Formula One Grand Prix race scheduled to start in two weeks.

site_title: Asean, China to adopt communications protocol to ease tensions at sea
summary: Southeast Asian countries and China will establish hotlines and adopt a communications protocol, called the Code for Unplanned Encounters at Sea (Cues), to prevent naval clashes in the disputed South China Sea. The protocol, to be signed in Laos, aims to de-escalate tensions and avoid accidents. China claims nearly the entire South China Sea, but other countries have competing claims. The agreement comes amid pressure from the US, Japan, and Australia to respect the ruling of the Hague arbitration court, which found China had no historical title over the sea and breached the Philippines' sovereign rights.

site_title: Putin pushes for oil freeze deal with Opec, exemption for Iran
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed interest in reaching an oil freeze deal with Opec, with potential exemption for Iran, amid the prolonged slump in crude prices. Putin stated that Iran's participation should be allowed to continue raising production after being freed from international sanctions. He may recommend completing the plan when meeting Saudi Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at the Group of 20 summit.

site_title: Australia shares close lower ahead of US jobs data; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares closed 0.8% lower on Friday, marking a third consecutive session of decline, ahead of US jobs data that may prompt a Federal Reserve rate rise. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished at 5372.8, with Estia Health Ltd and Select Harvest Ltd being the biggest losers, shedding 6% and 9% respectively.

site_title: Surging China stainless steel output may reverse recent nickel slump
summary: China's stainless steel production surged 10% in the first seven months of 2016, driven by increased output of nickel-bearing stainless steel, which could reverse recent nickel price slumps. The surge in demand, combined with a decline in Philippine mine production, is expected to lead to a global nickel deficit. Analysts predict nickel prices will rise, with UBS forecasting a US$10,472 per tonne average in the fourth quarter. This increase is attributed to a shift in focus from supply-side concerns to demand-side factors.

images.alt_text: A surprise jump in stainless steel production this year in China, the world's biggest nickel user, may reignite a rally in nickel prices as investors shift focus to demand from worries over Philippine supply.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends flat, but logs weekly gain
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average ended flat on Friday after US factory activity data soured sentiment, despite logging a weekly gain of 3.45%. The benchmark index rose to a three-month closing high in the previous session. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also gained, with the Topix rising 0.25% and the JPX-Nikkei Index 400 rising 0.23%.

site_title: Singapore F1 promoter says ticket sales unaffected by Zika virus
summary: Singapore's Formula One ticket sales remain unaffected by the Zika virus outbreak, according to its promoter. Despite travel advisories, sales to corporate and VIP attendees have reached expected levels, signaling a good attendance for the event. The three-day Grand Prix takes place amidst a Zika outbreak and poor air quality, but organizers remain optimistic, attributing the unaffected sales to the event's popularity and Singapore's tourism industry, which has seen a 14% increase in visitors this year.

site_title: Exxon ignores near-term glut to play liquefied gas long game
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp is playing a long game in the natural gas market, focusing on future demand rather than short-term supply. Despite a current glut, the company predicts LNG demand will rise 1.6% annually through 2040, driven by growth in the Asia-Pacific region. Exxon is investing in untapped natural gas fields in Papua New Guinea and Mozambique, which won't produce for years. This strategy contrasts with Royal Dutch Shell's approach, which aims to quickly increase LNG exports. Experts predict the market will become tight in the late 2020s as demand outpaces supply.

site_title: UK construction downturn eases more than expected in August: PMI
summary: Britain's construction industry partially recovered in August, with the Markit/CIPS UK Construction Purchasing Managers'Index rising to 49.2 from 45.9 in July, beating forecasts. This marks a stabilization of the economy after a downturn that began before the June Brexit vote. The improved construction survey, combined with a manufacturing PMI release the previous day, could prompt the Bank of England to reconsider cutting interest rates again, adding to signs the economy is stabilizing.

site_title: Spanish unemployment inches up in August
summary: Spain's unemployment rate rose 0.39% in August, with 14,435 new jobless registrations, reaching 3.7 million unemployed people. This marks the end of a five-month improving trend linked to the tourist season. In seasonally-adjusted terms, unemployment fell by 24,462 people from July. The increase is attributed to the end of summer hiring and factory activity reduction.

site_title: Oil rises in Asia after steep falls
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia after a steep fall, driven by bargain-buying and a weaker US dollar. The price slump, triggered by Russia's potential refusal to limit production, saw crude lose nearly 10% of its value from August highs. The US dollar's weakness also contributed to the price increase. Oil prices are now ripe for traders looking for bargains.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged up Friday on bargain-buying and a weaker US dollar after another slump fuelled by a surge in US stockpiles and worries about an upcoming meeting to tackle a global supply glut.

site_title: Keppel Fels signs heads of agreement to define Russian projects
summary: Keppel Fels has signed a heads of agreement with Rosneft and MHWirth to define anchor projects for the Zvezda-Keppel Design and Engineering Center, a joint venture company. The primary focus will be on offshore drilling rigs, to be built jointly by Keppel Fels and the Zvezda Shipbuilding complex. The three partners, each holding 45% stake, will adhere to US and EU sanctions in conducting business. Discussions on potential projects are still preliminary and no further details are disclosed at this time.

site_title: Melania Trump sues news outlets that said she was an escort
summary: Melania Trump, the wife of US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, has sued two media outlets, Mail Media, Inc and Webster G Tarpley, for publishing false allegations that she worked as an escort in the 1990s. The lawsuit seeks $150 million in damages. The Daily Mail Online had previously retracted the article, stating it did not intend to suggest the allegations were true. Melania's attorney claims the statements are "100% false and tremendously damaging" to her reputation.

site_title: Comcast's DreamWorks purchase to face China antitrust review
summary: China will conduct an antitrust review of Comcast's $3.8 billion purchase of DreamWorks Animation SKG Inc, potentially blocking the deal due to concerns over competition in the Chinese market. The review follows complaints that the acquisition could harm competition, despite the US Justice Department's earlier clearance of the deal. Comcast is building a theme park in Beijing and relies on growing demand from China, which is expected to surpass the US as the world's largest box office by next year.

site_title: Top India shipping line reviving Iran venture to fight slump
summary: State-run Shipping Corp of India Ltd plans to revive a 40-year-old joint venture with Iran's Islamic Republic of Iran Shipping Lines, citing the easing of sanctions on Iran. The revived venture, Irano Hind Shipping Co, could provide access to Central Asian markets. The move is seen as part of India's efforts to scale up ties with Iran, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi aiming for up to $20 billion in investment. The joint venture could help the Indian company operate three bulk carriers and an oil tanker, and could also help Shipping Corp recover from an industry downturn.

site_title: Putin says DNC hack was a public service, Russia didn't do it
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin denied US accusations that Russia was involved in the hacking of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) emails and documents, calling it a public service. Putin stated that the content of the leaked emails was more important than who hacked them, and claimed he didn't know anything about the breach. The US Federal Bureau of Investigation has high confidence that the Russian government was behind the breach. The hacking has led to the resignation of the DNC head and has introduced an unpredictable element to the US presidential election.

images.alt_text: Vladimir Putin said the hacking of thousands of Democratic National Committee (DNC) emails and documents was a service to the public, but denied US accusations that Russia's government had anything to do with it.

site_title: Asia: Stocks dip before US jobs report, US dollar nurses losses
summary: Asian stocks declined on Friday, September 2, 2016, ahead of the US jobs report, which could prompt a potential Federal Reserve rate hike. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index fell 0.1%, with Australian and South Korean stocks losing 0.6% and 0.2% respectively. The US dollar lost value, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Solid US employment gains expected in August; jobless rate seen falling
summary: US employment growth is expected to moderate in August, with a likely increase of 180,000 jobs, according to a Reuters survey of economists. The unemployment rate is forecast to fall to 4.8%, reinforcing views that the economy has regained speed after a slow start to the year. This growth is likely to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates later this year, despite moderate job growth.

site_title: As G20 seeks to spur global economy, fiscal push still elusive
summary: World leaders attending the G20 summit in China are expected to reaffirm their commitment to using tax and spending policies to boost the sluggish global economy. However, a meaningful new pro-growth push remains unlikely. Tentative signs of a more relaxed approach to public spending are seen, with the European Union softening its stance on budget rules and Britain considering fiscal stimulus to offset the Brexit shock. The G20's efforts to address economic concerns come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, adding pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
summary: Ireland's minority government is divided over an EU ruling that orders Apple to pay 13 billion euros in back taxes, equivalent to 5% of Ireland's GDP. The ruling, described as a "mini-earthquake" by the Irish Times, has sparked public pressure to use the money to ease austerity measures. Despite Finance Minister Michael Noonan's vow to challenge the finding, an emergency cabinet meeting failed to reach a consensus, and independent ministers are seeking an early parliament recall to vote on the issue.

site_title: China says developing new type of long-range bomber
summary: China is developing a new long-range bomber as part of its military modernization program. Air force chief Ma Xiaotian announced the development during an open day, stating that the new bomber will be part of a "transformation" stage, focusing on quality over quantity. This move follows China's recent advancements in military equipment, including stealth fighters and anti-satellite missiles. The development has raised regional and international concerns, particularly in the South China Sea, where China has been taking a more assertive approach.

site_title: China's yuan slightly softer, faces more downward pressure
summary: China's yuan slightly softened on Friday, closing at 6.6793 per US dollar, 13 pips weaker than the previous close. The decline was partly cushioned by a defensive US dollar, but market expectations for further depreciation persist due to China's slowdown and potential US interest rate hikes. The yuan is expected to weaken to 6.80 per US dollar by end-February and eventually dip to 6.89 by next year, according to a Reuters poll. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has reaffirmed its pledge to maintain the yuan's stability, but may use policy tools to mitigate volatility.

site_title: Singapore investor protection amendments headed for Parliament
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority plans to introduce legislative amendments to boost investor protections, particularly for wealthier investors, with the goal of implementing the changes by the fourth quarter of 2016. The amendments aim to grant some accredited investors the option to choose protections available to retail investors, who are exempt from certain disclosures under current law. The proposed changes will also tighten the S$2 million net personal assets threshold, allowing primary homes to contribute up to half that value. The move comes amid losses for some wealthy investors following defaults among Singapore's local corporate bonds.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors raided after fuel-economy scandal widens
summary: Mitsubishi Motors' headquarters and Nagoya plant were raided by Japanese government officials amid a widening fuel-economy scandal. The automaker admitted to using unapproved methods to calculate mileage for 25 years, including estimates rather than actual tests. The company has also sought financial assistance from Nissan Motor Co. Ltd, which agreed to buy a controlling stake for $2.2 billion. The raid and scandal have led to a significant decline in Mitsubishi Motors' market value, with shares ending morning trading almost unchanged. A thorough investigation is underway to determine the circumstances surrounding the situation.

site_title: Japan makes arctic gas move with US$400m Yamal LNG loan
summary: Japan's Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC) has agreed to provide a $400 million loan to Novatek OJSC-led Yamal LNG, the largest Arctic gas project. The loan follows $12 billion in financing received earlier this year from Chinese banks. Yamal LNG aims to produce 16.5 million metric tons of LNG per year from 2017. The project's total cost is $27 billion, with Russian funding and the JBIC loan securing approximately $18.8 billion in loans. Novatek plans to develop a similar Arctic LNG 2 project after completing Yamal LNG.

site_title: China's vice finance minister says monetary policy ineffective, fiscal aid needed
summary: China's vice finance minister, Zhu Guangyao, stated that conventional monetary policy is ineffective and called for more fiscal policy support to drive growth. He argued that fiscal measures in developed economies have reached a limit and that asset purchases and negative interest rates are unsustainable. Zhu emphasized the need for a more active fiscal policy, citing the upcoming G-20 summit in Hangzhou. This suggests China may adopt more expansionary fiscal policies to stimulate its economy.

site_title: Billionaire Li's win in Italy snaps string of deal setbacks
summary: Billionaire Li Ka-shing's plan to merge 3 Italia SpA, a unit of his CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd, with VimpelCom's Wind Telecomunicazioni SpA in Italy has been approved. The merger, valued at 21.8 billion euros, aims to reduce overlapping costs and provide negotiating leverage for network equipment purchases. This deal paves the way for Li to turn around his least profitable market in Europe, with expected savings of over 5 billion euros. The merged entity will have equal 50% stakes from both companies, marking a significant win for Li after a string of setbacks.

site_title: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts: sources
summary: Google has suspended Project Ara, its modular smartphone initiative, as part of a push to streamline its hardware efforts. The project, which aimed to create a customizable phone with interchangeable components, was initially set to ship in the autumn but has been put on hold. While Google won't release the phone itself, it may work with partners to bring the technology to market through licensing agreements. Analysts say the project was a science experiment that failed, and Google is moving on to unify its various hardware efforts.

site_title: Australia shares languish ahead of US payrolls; NZ slightly lower
summary: Australian shares fell for a third consecutive session, shedding 52 points to 5364.1, amid concerns about robust US jobs data potentially leading to a US Federal Reserve rate rise. Market cues from Wall Street, where stocks were flat, also influenced the decline. The decline follows a 0.3% drop on Thursday.

site_title: Saudis seen bolstering oil market defense with storage in Asia
summary: Saudi Arabia is expanding its oil storage capacity in Japan and China to strengthen ties with its largest Asian buyers and defend its market share amid a global glut. The kingdom plans to increase storage capacity in Japan's Okinawa islands by 2 million barrels and is negotiating commercial and government storage projects in China. This move aims to provide greater logistical flexibility and establish Saudi Arabia as a reliable supplier during emergencies, potentially giving it a leg up against rival producers like Iran and Russia.

site_title: Hong Kong home sales hit 14-month high in August as mood lifts
summary: Hong Kong residential home sales reached 5,821 units in August, the highest in 14 months, with a total value of HK$40.6 billion. Demand has recovered since hitting a 25-year low in February, driven by aggressive discounts. This improvement in sentiment follows stabilizing prices, with developers selling more new units. The increase in sales marks a reversal of the trend seen in previous months, with buyers slowly regaining confidence in the market.

site_title: US banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
summary: US banks are vulnerable to a sudden spike in interest rates due to their long-term loan portfolios and short-term funding, regulators warn. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and Office of Financial Research (OFR) say banks may be exposed to significant losses if rates rise, potentially triggering a financial crisis. Regulators point to the 1980s savings and loan crisis and the 2013 bond yield shock as examples of the risks of rate swings. Banks have been extending loan terms to boost earnings, but regulators urge them to better prepare for a potential rate hike.

images.alt_text: Years of stubbornly low interest rates and expectations they will remain low for years to come have prompted US banks to shift their balance sheets in ways that put them at risk if rates suddenly spike, regulators are warning.

site_title: Markel appoints Singapore energy underwriter
summary: Markel International (Singapore) has appointed Timothy Foister as energy underwriter based in Singapore, reporting directly to Matthew Cannock. Foister's expertise will enhance the company's service to clients in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in the oil and gas industry. This appointment demonstrates Markel's commitment to leadership in the Asian energy market, amidst challenging industry conditions. Foister's experience as an exploration and production underwriter in Singapore will facilitate a more focused product and service delivery.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hold nerve into crunch US jobs data
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remained steady despite soft US economic data, including a manufacturing index decline and speculation of a potential underwhelming payrolls report. The Australian dollar was steady at US$0.7544, while the New Zealand dollar held at US$0.7284. Meanwhile, domestic economic news was upbeat, with building work done increasing 5.5% in the June quarter, supporting forecasts of strong GDP growth. A 7.1 magnitude earthquake off New Zealand's North Island had little impact on markets.

site_title: Tennis: Serena, Murray storm through on rainy day at US Open
summary: Tennis stars Serena Williams and Andy Murray dominated their opponents on a rainy day at the US Open, advancing to the third round. Williams defeated Vania King 6-3, 6-3, tying her with Martina Navratilova for the most Grand Slam singles wins, while Murray beat Marcel Granollers 6-4, 6-1, 6-4. Other top seeds, including Juan Martin del Potro, Nick Kyrgios, and Simona Halep, also won their matches, setting up exciting matchups in the tournament's next rounds.

images.alt_text: Wimbledon champions Serena Williams and Andy Murray raised the roof at the US Open on Thursday, powering into the third round with decisive straight-sets victories.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; tech, shipping counters help limit losses
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.5% to 8,960.75, despite gains in technology and shipping stocks. The decline was influenced by global market uncertainty over a potential US nonfarm payrolls number and Federal Reserve rate hike. Key tech firm Hon Hai Precision rose 1.5% following rival Samsung Electronics' consideration of a Galaxy Note 7 recall. Container shipping firm Evergreen Marine also gained 5.3%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.713 per US dollar.

site_title: Samsung considering Galaxy Note 7 recall
summary: Samsung is considering a recall of its Galaxy Note 7 devices due to reports of battery problems causing fires. The company has halted supply to top carriers and delayed shipments for quality testing. Samsung has not confirmed any specific issues but is conducting a thorough inspection with partners. The decision to recall is pending, and the exact timeline and number of affected phones are unknown. This move comes after online complaints from users claiming their phones caught fire while charging.

images.alt_text: Tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is considering a recall of its Galaxy Note 7 devices amid reports that some of the premium phones are catching fire due to battery problems, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters on Friday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.050 points to 1674.600. The market saw 73 gainers for every 32 losers, with a total volume of 19.81 million lots worth RM8.65 million.

site_title: Japan's Abe in Russia to warm ties with Putin
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is meeting Russian President Vladimir Putin in Vladivostok to boost trade ties and resolve a territorial dispute over the Kuril Islands. The visit comes days after Putin announced plans to travel to Japan in December, his first trip since 2005. Experts see recent efforts as a positive development, but doubt a resolution is near. Abe's visit will focus on economic cooperation, including energy, agriculture, and industrial production, with no clear signs of compromise on the disputed islands.

site_title: Key BOJ policymaker signals fine-tuning, not overhaul, of stimulus
summary: A Bank of Japan policymaker, Makoto Sakurai, suggests the central bank can maintain its base money target and utilize existing tools to expand stimulus, rather than overhauling its monetary framework. Sakurai rules out more radical options such as foreign bond purchases or "helicopter money" for now, instead focusing on refining current policy steps and addressing a flattened bond yield curve. This approach aims to fine-tune existing stimulus without a major overhaul.

site_title: Seoul: Won edges up ahead of US August non-farm payrolls report
summary: The South Korean won edged up 0.3% to 1,119.1 against the US dollar ahead of the August US non-farm payrolls report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's potential rate hike. A gauge of US national factory activity fell in August, contributing to the cautious trade. Analysts expect the won to be slightly lower for the week, despite offshore investors' net buying of Kospi shares.

site_title: Gold treads water as all eyes on US Jobs data for Fed clues
summary: Gold prices remain unchanged at $1,314.40 an ounce ahead of the US jobs report, which is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's tightening path. The metal has declined 0.5% this week, eroding its 2016 rally, as traders price in a higher probability of an interest rate increase. The US nonfarm payrolls report is expected to show 180,000 jobs added in August, potentially increasing the chance of a Fed hike.

site_title: Artist hopes London work will spark Korean reunification
summary: An artist, Ik-Joong Kang, has created an art installation called "Floating Dreams" on London's River Thames, featuring 500 drawings by Korean refugees who fled during the Korean War in the 1950s. The installation, lit up nightly until September 30, aims to spark reunification of North and South Korea, with Kang believing even small sparks can lead to big change. The artwork showcases memories of the refugees' hometowns and may raise awareness about their stories, with Kang hoping it can be a "small vaccine" to cure sadness and scar.

site_title: D-day looms for global nickel market as Philippines probes mines
summary: The Philippines' nationwide mining audit is set to conclude next Thursday, with President Rodrigo Duterte's government presenting the findings and announcing support for communities affected by any further suspensions. The audit, which has been ongoing since March, aims to assess compliance with environment and welfare rules. The results are expected to impact global nickel supplies, which have been tight due to a deficit of 80,800 tons in the first half of 2016. Nickel prices have risen to a one-year high, and the government hopes the audit will attract investment in sustainable mining practices.

site_title: Consumer giants court Muslims with halal face creams, shampoos
summary: Major consumer companies, including Unilever, Beiersdorf, and L'Oreal, are converting their supply chains to produce halal face creams and shampoos for Indonesia ahead of a new labelling law requiring food and toiletries to be labelled halal or not by 2017 and 2018, respectively. The companies see demand for halal products growing as Indonesia's Muslim middle class expands, with over 1.5 billion Muslims worldwide. Halal certification involves ensuring products are made without pork, alcohol, or blood, and meeting Islamic Sharia law standards. The companies expect the burden to be administrative rather than financial, unlocking new revenue streams.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% down on Friday as traders await US jobs data
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.3% lower on Friday, dropping 9.23 points to 2,807.24, as traders await US jobs data. The market is closely watching for a potential September rate hike, with a strong jobs report expected to increase certainty. The Straits Times Index has seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while the field was evenly matched with 54 gainers and losers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.33% in the first few minutes of trading on Friday, driven by investors brushing off a shock dip in US manufacturing activity and looking ahead to jobs data. The Hang Seng Index reached 23,238.36, while the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.19% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.15%.

site_title: AusGroup trading halted pending review of press report
summary: AusGroup, an oil and gas subcontractor, has halted trading pending a review of a press report by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The report suggested a potential consent solicitation exercise to extend S$110 million of debt coming due, with noteholders seeking secured bonds and a small early repayment. AusGroup's stock price is S$0.039. The company will review the article to determine if further disclosure is required.

site_title: Singapore Zika cases reach 151, China steps up arrivals checks
summary: Singapore reported 151 Zika cases, including a second pregnant woman, as of midday Thursday, with half of the 115 reported cases being foreigners, mainly from China, India, and Bangladesh. The outbreak has spread to neighboring Malaysia, and the US has added Singapore to its list of places to avoid for pregnant women or those trying to conceive. China intensified checks on arrivals from Singapore, and the World Health Organization is holding a meeting to review the spread of the disease.

site_title: Oil heads for biggest weekly loss since mid-January
summary: Crude oil prices are on track for their biggest weekly loss since mid-January, falling due to inventory builds and weak US manufacturing data. Brent crude rose 50 US cents to $45.95 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 47 US cents to $43.63 a barrel. Investors are cautious ahead of US employment data and a potential Opec production cut meeting, which may boost oil prices. A strong US economy reading could lead to a Federal Reserve interest rate hike, strengthening the US dollar and depressing oil prices.

site_title: Pteris Global, HTL to be suspended post-takeovers
summary: Pteris Global and HTL International, two Singaporean companies, will be suspended from trading after their respective takeover offers concluded. Pteris' takeover offer was accepted by 98.98% of shareholders, while HTL's takeover scheme was passed. The suspensions will take effect once the necessary regulatory approvals are received. The takeover offers mark the end of the companies' trading on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Scrap inefficient UK company tax, Thatcherite think tank says
summary: A UK think tank, the Institute of Economic Affairs, recommends abolishing the country's corporation tax and replacing it with a levy on shareholder earnings. The current system is deemed "hugely inefficient" and provides incentives for tax avoidance by multinationals. The proposal is closely linked to the policies of former Conservative Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The IEA argues the new system would promote growth, investment, and worker productivity, despite high compliance costs.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte declines meeting with UN's Ban
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte declined a meeting request with UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon, despite 11 heads of state requesting meetings during the Asean forum in Laos. Officials stated that no time could be agreed upon for a meeting. Duterte had previously criticized the UN for criticizing his government, and he accepted meetings with nine other heads of state during the forum. The decision comes amid strained relations between the Philippines and the UN.

site_title: Hot stock: Telcos fall on potential entry of 4th operator
summary: Singapore's telcos fell on Friday after three firms submitted bids to take part in an airwaves auction that could lead to the nation's fourth telco. Singtel, StarHub, and M1 dropped 1.8%, 4.1%, and 6% respectively. The stocks were among the top 10 by value traded. The auction's outcome may impact the telcos' market value, causing the stocks to decline.

site_title: Motor racing: Singapore Zika outbreak a concern for Formula One
summary: Formula One drivers are racing in Singapore despite a Zika outbreak in the region. Authorities in Singapore have reported 151 Zika cases, with the first locally-transmitted infection reported. Despite the risk, drivers are taking precautions such as wearing long-sleeved outfits and using anti-mosquito products. Several drivers, including Valtteri Bottas and Nico Rosberg, are unaware of the outbreak or have expressed concern, while others, like Eric Boullier and Dave Ryan, are taking the necessary precautions to ensure their safety and the success of the event.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping's alliance membership suspended
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd has had its membership in the CKYHE shipping alliance suspended. The company, South Korea's top shipping firm, filed for court receivership after creditor banks ended financial support. Vessels have been seized at Chinese ports, and other ships have been denied entry or unable to dock. A Seoul court initiated rehabilitation proceedings for Hanjin, and its shares will resume trading on September 5. The company's collapse raises concerns about its ability to continue as a going concern, with some manufacturers seeking alternative shippers. Hanjin's assets will likely be liquidated.

site_title: US: Stocks hold steady ahead of August jobs report
summary: US stocks held steady ahead of the August jobs report, recouping early losses. Low unemployment insurance claims suggested a solid jobs report, but a contracting manufacturing sector dampened optimism. The Institute of Supply Management reported a decline in the US manufacturing sector last month. Despite this, stocks remained steady, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Brazil's ousted President Rousseff appeals to Supreme Court
summary: Brazil's ousted President Dilma Rousseff appealed to the Supreme Court to overturn the Senate's decision to remove her from office, citing violations of due process.
