The Senate voted 61-20 to dismiss Rousseff, confirming Vice President Michel Temer as president until 2018. Rousseff's lawyer argued that her accusers changed their case, and she also sought to change the 1950 budget law that led to her impeachment. The Supreme Court has rejected all of Rousseff's defense requests, making an injunction unlikely. Rousseff's removal was seen as clearing the way for austerity measures under Temer, who inherits a divided nation.

site_title: Hanjin ships get stranded in high seas, roiling supply chain
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co, South Korea's largest sea container-shipping firm, has filed for court protection, leaving its vessels stranded at sea and disrupting the global supply chain. The company's shipments account for 15-20% of LG Electronics' deliveries to America, ahead of the holiday season. Hyundai Merchant Marine Co has stepped in to add 13 more vessels, while LG Electronics is seeking new carriers for its goods. This disruption threatens to affect the supply chains of global companies, particularly those reliant on Hanjin's services.

site_title: US dollar on defensive after manufacturing disappoints ahead of jobs data
summary: The US dollar declined after a surprise contraction in US manufacturing in August, with the Institute for Supply Management's index of national factory activity falling to 49.4, the first contraction since February. The dollar slipped to 103.21 yen and 95.669 on the dollar index, ahead of closely-watched employment data due later in the day, which is expected to show 180,000 jobs added in August. The euro rose to US$1.1195, and the British pound jumped to a one-month high of US$1.3318 on data showing a sharp rebound in the British manufacturing sector.

site_title: UK business confidence improves after post-referendum slump: YouGov/Cebr
summary: British businesses regained some confidence after the post-Brexit vote slump, with 48% optimistic about their prospects over the next 12 months, up from 46% in July. The overall confidence index rose to 109.7 in August, regaining lost ground after falling to 105.0 in July. However, companies remained pessimistic about the economy, with 45% of businesses pessimistic in August, compared to 49% in July. Prime Minister Theresa May has delayed triggering Article 50 until next year, which may ease business concerns.

site_title: Facebook Messenger adds live video broadcasting
summary: Facebook Messenger has added live video broadcasting, allowing users to stream real-time video in text exchanges. The feature, called Instant Video, is available in the latest version of the Messenger app on mobile devices and matches a feature offered by rival Snapchat. Users can tap on a video icon to begin sharing live video, with sound turned off by default. The addition is seen as a reflection of the ubiquity of video and comes as Facebook continues to compete with Snapchat and other social media platforms.

site_title: Energy management made easy with Evercomm
summary: Evercomm Uni-Tech Singapore, an energy management startup, was founded in 2013 by two NTU graduates, Ted Chen and Phyo Koko, to provide solutions for large manufacturing enterprises, data centers, and commercial buildings to reduce energy management complexity. The company uses data-driven approaches to identify energy efficiency problems and offers end-to-end management solutions, including software algorithms and hardware solutions. With its Internet of Things and machine learning technologies, Evercomm aims to simplify energy management and help clients save up to S$1 million a year.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's Cryan weighs drastic steps as revamp sputters
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan is reassessing his overhaul plan after the bank lost over half its market value since he unveiled it last year. Cryan will meet with top managers to evaluate progress on cutting risky assets, eliminating jobs, and conserving capital. The bank has struggled to adapt to tougher capital requirements and diminished trading revenue, and analysts suggest drastic measures may be needed, including selling core assets or exiting non-core parts of its asset management unit. Cryan's strategy has been criticized as failing, and a merger with Commerzbank is seen as unlikely at this time.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open down ahead of US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.16% lower on Friday, awaiting US jobs data that may influence a possible US rate hike. The Nikkei 225 index fell 27.29 points to 16,899.55, while the Topix index slipped 0.12% to 1,335.71. Investors await the US jobs data, which may provide fresh clues on a potential rate hike.

site_title: Goldman Sachs says 'halcyon days' for BRICs consigned to history
summary: Goldman Sachs' chief emerging-market macro strategist, Kamakshya Trivedi, says the 'halcyon days' for BRIC countries are over due to China's slowing demand, which accounts for 40% of emerging-market output. The countries' growth rates, which reached 10.6% in 2010, are unlikely to recapture the 2005-2007 levels. However, Trivedi notes that emerging markets are starting to accelerate again, driven by "significant easing of financial conditions" in developing nations, with Brazil and Russia expected to alleviate economic slumps.

site_title: Hong Kong government hacked by Chinese cyberspies: FireEye
summary: US cybersecurity firm FireEye reports that two Hong Kong government agencies were targeted by Chinese cyberspies in early August, using "spear-phishing" attacks. The attacks, attributed to group APT 3, aimed to gain information without transparency, and their targets were likely politically motivated. The Hong Kong government confirmed receiving the alerts but declined to disclose which agencies were attacked. The incident occurred ahead of legislative elections in Hong Kong, where Beijing's influence is a key campaign issue.

site_title: Jobs elusive as India clings to fastest-growing economy tag
summary: India's economy, the world's fastest-growing major economy, has slowed to 7.1% in the quarter to June, a 15-month low, despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi's promise to create 250 million jobs over the next decade. Many, like 25-year-old truck driver Ashok Kumar, struggle to find better-paying jobs, with new positions hard to come by, and unemployment rates rising. The government has launched initiatives to boost job creation, but experts say the economy remains "demand-starved," with more focus needed on creating jobs to match the growing workforce.

site_title: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
summary: Global automakers are taking different approaches to China's electric car boom, with some, like Audi, focusing on petrol-powered cars with hybrid technology, while Chinese firms like Geely and GAC Motor aim to meet Beijing's ambitious electric vehicle goals. Despite China's US$4.5 billion in green car subsidies, some industry officials warn that electric cars may be too costly and not a good fit with foreign automakers' operations elsewhere. Beijing's 2020 requirements call for cars to consume less than 5 litres of petrol per 100 kilometres, but concerns over driving range and home charging remain.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde warns G20 to avoid 'low-growth trap'
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warned G20 leaders to avoid a "low-growth trap" as the global economy stagnates, with five years of growth below the 3.7% average since 1990. The warning comes ahead of the G20 summit in China, where member states face a mix of low long-term growth and rising inequality, creating political temptations to populism. Analysts say the summit is unlikely to achieve a breakthrough due to differing interests and pressures among major economies.

site_title: G20 watchdog to reinforce banker pay rules to deter misconduct
summary: Global regulators plan to reinforce banker pay rules to deter misconduct, potentially avoiding multi-billion dollar fines that could destabilize banks. The Financial Stability Board will develop guidance by the end of next year to link compensation with conduct, addressing limitations in recouping or stopping bonuses after misconduct emerges. This move aims to encourage greater consistency across countries and foster more effective compensation policies, ultimately reducing the risk of excessive risk-taking and financial instability.

site_title: Grab locks in Trans-cab's pool of 7,000 drivers with exclusive tie-up
summary: Grab, Singapore's second-largest taxi operator's external app, has secured an exclusive partnership with Trans-cab, a taxi operator with 7,000 drivers, to handle on-demand passenger bookings. Trans-cab drivers will undergo training and receive subsidised smartphones. This move may weaken Uber's driver supply pool and help Grab establish itself as a partner for taxi companies, as the government considers levelling the playing field for taxi operators and ride-booking services.

site_title: Offshore quake prompts temporary evacuation of New Zealand coastal area
summary: A magnitude 7.1 earthquake struck off the coast of New Zealand's North Island, prompting a temporary evacuation of coastal areas. The quake, 55 km deep and 130 km northeast of Te Araroa, caused fears of a tsunami, but authorities later lifted the evacuation order and tsunami warning. People in Gisborne were advised to go inland or higher ground, but were allowed to return home. There were no reported tsunami waves on the Pacific coasts of the Americas, and the market reaction to the quake was muted.

site_title: China's growth playbook on display to G20 in city transformed
summary: China is showcasing its economic growth strategy to the G20, with a focus on infrastructure development to boost productivity and spur growth. The country's approach, which involves investing billions in infrastructure projects, has led to a surge in Hangzhou's economy, with a 11% growth rate in the first half of the year. However, critics warn that the strategy may not be directly translatable to other countries due to differences in physical landscapes and political systems. The global economy is facing a "hysteresis" trap, where pessimism hinders investment, and governments are urged to adopt fiscal policies to stimulate growth.

site_title: Aussie parliament rejects sweeping probe into banks
summary: The Australian parliament rejected a motion for a sweeping Royal Commission into the banking sector, citing concerns about its potential impact on confidence and international investment. Instead, a limited inquiry into bank misconduct was approved, targeting mistreatment of small business customers. The decision was seen as a compromise by the Liberal-led government, which used its one-seat majority to defeat the opposition's motion. The four major banks, controlling 80% of lending, have faced criticism for abuse of market power and misconduct, including scams and refusing to pass on interest rate cuts.

site_title: Harley-Davidson says plans to cut about 200 jobs
summary: Harley-Davidson plans to cut approximately 200 jobs due to a lower forecast for motorcycle shipments in 2016, with most reductions scheduled for the fourth quarter. The company revised its 2016 shipment guidance to 264,000 to 269,000 motorcycles, down from its previous estimate of 269,000 to 274,000. This adjustment is aimed at adjusting production schedules accordingly.

site_title: City buzz
summary: There is no article content provided to summarize. The text appears to be a list of article titles and publication dates.

site_title: Rocket explodes on launch pad in blow to Elon Musk's SpaceX
summary: A Falcon 9 rocket belonging to SpaceX exploded on a launch pad in Cape Canaveral, Florida, two days before its scheduled launch, destroying a communications satellite for Facebook and a rocket owned by Israel-based Space Communication. The cause of the explosion is unknown, but SpaceX has a backup launch site in California and is expected to continue with its launch schedule. The incident is a blow to SpaceX's plans, including its mission to launch a satellite network into orbit for Iridium and a cargo mission to the International Space Station.

images.alt_text: An explosion destroyed a Falcon 9 rocket belonging to Elon Musk's SpaceX and its cargo during preparations for a routine test firing at Cape Canaveral in Florida on Thursday, two days before it had been due to blast off and place a satellite in orbit.

site_title: Formula One: Vettel apologises as Raikkonen warns against "payback"
summary: Sebastian Vettel apologized to Ferrari teammate Kimi Raikkonen for their collision at the Belgian Grand Prix, admitting he didn't give Raikkonen enough space. Raikkonen warned against "payback" mentality, saying it's not the place for revenge in racing. Vettel also downplayed talk of a row with Red Bull's Max Verstappen, saying he didn't see him in the mirrors and would give more space if the incident happened again. The incident has put pressure on Ferrari to perform at their home track, the Italian Grand Prix.

site_title: Europe: Shares end off highs after disappointing US data
summary: European shares closed flat on Thursday, weighed down by disappointing US factory data, which cast doubts over the US economy's strength. Despite hawkish comments from Federal Reserve officials, European bank stocks rose 0.8% as investors anticipated higher interest rates. The healthcare and oil sectors fell, while Belgian investment holding company Ackermans & Van Haaren rose 6% after an upgrade to "buy". The Stoxx 600 ended 0.04% higher, giving up earlier gains.

site_title: Plenty of magic - and life lessons - in these woods
summary: The article discusses the family-friendly film "Pete's Dragon," a reboot of the 1977 Disney movie. Directed by David Lowery and written by Lowery and Toby Halbrooks, the film tells the story of a young boy and his fire-breathing pet dragon living in the Pacific Northwest. The movie blends computer graphics and reality, conveying wholesome family values and messages about nature and imagination. Local woodcarver Robert Redford plays a key role in the film, sharing stories of the mythical Millhaven Dragon. The film is a seamless blend of art and imagination, appealing to Disney's signature style.

site_title: Ezion Hldgs wades into marine transport for oil products
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine company, has entered the oil product tanker business through a joint venture with Indonesia-based private equity firm Quvat. The joint venture, Pelita Bara Samudera (PBS), has taken delivery of an oil product tanker, Mahakamah I, which is set to charter with Pertamina for three years. The three-year term charter is expected to generate a charter value of around US$10 million. This move marks Ezion's first foray into marine transportation of oil products, following its entry into China's wind farm market and expansion of its liftboat-focused business.

site_title: IE S'pore tightens focus on which firms to help expand overseas
summary: Singapore's International Enterprise Singapore (IE Singapore) is shifting its focus to high-potential firms that create jobs and add economic value, prioritizing those growing faster than 6% per year. The agency will allocate more resources to support these companies, providing assistance through overseas centers, partnerships, and mergers and acquisitions. This new direction aims to capture economic value from high-growth companies and benefit Singapore.

site_title: Technology bringing more assurance to insurance industry
summary: Asia's insurance industry has grown, but faces an image problem with customers. To address this, insurance firms are focusing on customer service and using technology, such as software and enterprise information platforms, to improve communication and personalization. This includes digitizing non-digital communications, automating business processes, and using analytics to build trust. By leveraging technology, insurers can provide a more efficient and personalized service, appealing to the "Facebook generation" and increasing customer loyalty and retention.

site_title: Kickstarter officially launches in Singapore and HK
summary: Kickstarter has officially launched in Singapore and Hong Kong, allowing entrepreneurs and creators to start projects from their home cities. Localised platforms will support innovative projects from the region, with backers able to take advantage of experiential rewards. The platform will not have separate pages for Singapore and Hong Kong, with projects listed alongside global projects on Kickstarter.com. Two local projects, the GIY Stick and Hydra, have already been launched, with successful projects charged a 5% fee and users incurring an additional 4-5% payments processing fee.

site_title: SGX needs more than dual-class shares to woo tech companies
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) aims to attract tech companies for initial public offerings (IPOs), but a dual-class share structure may not be enough. Despite the appeal of such a structure, allowing founders to retain control and majority voting rights, several factors, including valuation, liquidity, and the prevalence of mergers and acquisitions as an exit strategy, hinder the process. Tech companies like Catcha Group and PropertyGuru are considering listing on SGX, but valuation and liquidity remain top priorities. SGX's efforts to woo tech companies may not yield significant results until these concerns are addressed.

site_title: UK investors prefer alternative property
summary: UK investors are shifting their focus to alternative property, such as student flats, health centres, and care homes, due to the post-Brexit market uncertainty. This shift has led to a 3% increase in alternative property investment, accounting for 16% of total UK property investment in July. Investors are drawn to long leases and steady tenants, seeking less risk and more defensive investments. Traditional property investments, including offices and retail, have seen declines in returns, while alternative sectors have seen modest gains, with some assets experiencing 25% value increases.

site_title: UOB US$600m notes 7.3 times subscribed
summary: UOB's upcoming US$600 million Basel III-compliant Tier 2 subordinated notes were 7.3 times subscribed, attracting a US$4.4 billion order book. The notes, to be issued on September 8, 2016, pay a 2.88% coupon rate and are expected to be rated 'A2' by Moody's Investors Service and 'A+' by Fitch Ratings. UOB plans to use the net proceeds for general business purposes, citing strong investor confidence in its robust capital position and business fundamentals. The notes will be due in 2027 and callable in 2022.

site_title: By the people, for the people
summary: We The People, the first store in Singapore and among the first in Asia to exclusively sell products funded through Kickstarter, has launched in the country. The store, founded by Ryan Sim, offers a curated selection of 17 products, including a levitating lightbulb, a smart phone grip, and watches made from natural materials, all at the same prices as recommended retail prices on Kickstarter. The store aims to provide customers with confidence in the products they purchase, as it handles the curation process and has tangible stock of the products.

site_title: US banks setting sky-high ceilings for director pay
summary: US banks have set high ceilings for director pay, primarily to fend off shareholder lawsuits rather than control pay increases. The caps are typically 2-3 times the current median director pay, with Morgan Stanley's limit set at $750,000. Advocates argue the pay ceilings lack teeth, while consultants say they help protect companies from litigation. The median annual board compensation at the six biggest US banks was $349,027 in 2015, nearly $80,000 more than the median director pay at S&P 500 companies.

site_title: UOB fund invests US$25m in Vietnam hydropower firm
summary: UOB's private equity arm, UOB Venture Management, is investing US$25 million in Bitexco Power Corp, one of Vietnam's largest hydropower companies, alongside Japanese financial services group Orix Corp. The investment aims to expand Bitexco Power's business and consolidate its market leadership in the renewable energy sector. Bitexco Power operates 18 hydropower plants in Vietnam, generating enough renewable energy to power 2.7 million people annually. The investment is part of UOBVM's Asean China Investment Fund III, which focuses on growth-oriented companies in East and South-east Asia.

site_title: Scheduled passenger flights to Cuba resume - now with jets
summary: Scheduled passenger flights to Cuba resumed on September 1, 2016, with the launch of JetBlue's 9.45am flight from Fort Lauderdale to Santa Clara, Cuba. This marks the first regularly scheduled flight from the US to Cuba in over 50 years. The move aims to normalize relations between the two former Cold War foes, reducing airfares and easing travel between the nations. The resumption of flights is seen as a significant step forward for tourism and commerce between the US and Cuba.

site_title: US set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait: sources
summary: The US is set to approve sales of Boeing fighter jets to Qatar and Kuwait, worth $7 billion, after years of delays. The deals, pending for over two years, are aimed at increasing military capabilities in the region amid rising tensions with Iran. The sales include 36 F-15 fighter jets to Qatar and 28 F/A-18E/F Super Hornets to Kuwait, valued at $4 billion and $3 billion, respectively. The White House has given its formal approval, and US officials will notify lawmakers and Congress within the next 40 days.

site_title: US orders tougher warning on painkiller-sedative mix
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration has ordered tougher warning labels to caution patients against taking opioid painkillers with benzodiazepines, such as Xanax and Valium, due to the increased risk of overdose and death. The combination can lead to extreme sleepiness, coma, and death. The number of patients prescribed both drugs rose 41% from 2002 to 2014, and overdose death rates tripled from 2004 to 2011. The new labels aim to raise awareness about the danger of taking both drugs, but some doctors question their impact on prescribing practices.

site_title: Tax ruling not political, based on Apple data: European Commission
summary: The European Commission rejected Apple's claim that an EU order to pay back taxes to Ireland was political, stating that the calculations were based on facts and Apple's own data. The EU imposed a 13 billion euro back tax bill on Apple, citing it as an abnormal state aid. Apple CEO Tim Cook criticized the ruling, stating it was motivated by anti-US bias, but EU competition chief Margrethe Vestager disagreed. France supports the EU's decision, while the US has expressed concerns over the ruling.

site_title: MAS kneads out refinancing knots posed by TDSR
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has relaxed rules for refinancing property loans, allowing borrowers with debt-to-income ratios above 60% to refinance their loans with a commitment to repay at least 3% of the outstanding balance over three years. This change applies to both investment properties and owner-occupied residential properties, giving overleveraged borrowers more flexibility in refinancing their loans. The move aims to help borrowers manage their existing debts and is seen as a step to address the needs of homeowners trying to better manage their monthly cash flow through refinancing.

site_title: Takata truck blast revives concerns over airbag propellant
summary: A deadly explosion of a truck carrying 14,000 cylinders of ammonium nitrate, the propellant linked to deadly airbag failures, occurred on US Highway 277 in Texas, killing one and injuring four others. The incident raises questions about the safety of ammonium nitrate, which critics say is inherently unstable and has been linked to Takata's airbag failures. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has requested documents related to the explosion, and senators are calling for a full investigation into the matter, citing Takata's "terrible track record of cutting corners to put profits before safety."

site_title: Hutchison, VimpelCom win EU approval for phone merger
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd and VimpelCom Ltd have received EU approval for a phone merger in Italy, creating the country's largest wireless provider. The deal, worth 7.9 billion euros, includes concessions to help smaller rival Iliad SA become Italy's fourth mobile carrier, ensuring the industry remains competitive and reducing the risk of price increases and reduced quality. The merger will allow Hutchison to take on rivals Telecom Italia and Vodafone, and comes after Iliad agreed to acquire assets from the merging entities.

site_title: China wealth management products rise to record 26.3 trillion yuan
summary: China's households, companies, and banks held a record 26.3 trillion yuan of wealth management products (WMPs) as of June 30, up 11.8% from last year. The products, used by over 450 banks to extend funds to risky borrowers, have fueled the growth of shadow banking. The China Banking Regulatory Commission has drafted new rules to limit smaller banks and mass-market investors' involvement in WMPs, aiming to mitigate risks in the financial system.

site_title: Comedy about price of war hits target
summary: The biographical comedy-drama "War Dogs" follows two childhood friends, Efraim Diveroli (Jonah Hill) and David Packouz (Miles Teller), who start a small-time arms-dealing business in Miami during the Bush-Cheney invasions of Iraq and Afghanistan. As they become more successful, they attract shady characters and struggle with the moral implications of their actions. The film, directed by Todd Phillips, balances dark humor with a commentary on the international arms black market, ultimately concluding that the price of war is a heavy one.

site_title: Stocks weaken ahead of key US jobs report
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) initially rebounded 12 points before closing down 4.12 points at 2,816.47 due to thin trading volume. The index's decline was influenced by concerns over the US jobs report, which could lead to interest-rate hikes. Turnover was below average, with 987 million units worth S$851.3 million traded, mostly in the 30 STI components. The poor trading volume and cautious market sentiment suggest that the STI's upward momentum may not be sustainable.

site_title: Walmart plans early layaway programme to catch Star Wars boost
summary: Walmart is launching its holiday layaway program two weeks early, starting September 2, in an effort to boost toy sales driven by the upcoming Star Wars movie release. The program, which allows customers to pay for gifts in instalments, is expected to account for 15% of holiday revenues at Walmart stores in poorer areas of the US. Last year's program contributed to strong toy sales, and Walmart anticipates similar demand this year, with sales projected to increase 6.7% to $19.4 billion, driven by toy sales inspired by movies, including Star Wars.

site_title: The reluctant artist whose works you can use
summary: Renowned potter Iskandar Jalil is exhibiting his comprehensive 50-year body of work at the National Gallery Singapore (NGS) and the National Institute of Education (NIE). Despite receiving the Cultural Medallion, Jalil disagrees with being labeled a "ceramic artist," instead emphasizing his focus on functionality. He expressed dissatisfaction with the exhibition's "arty" approach, stating that his works should be recognized for their practicality. The exhibition, "Kembara Tanah Liat (Clay Travels)," showcases Jalil's mastery of pottery, coinciding with his 76th birthday and a cancer diagnosis.

site_title: Energy Absolute seeks 15b baht in loans for new wind farm
summary: Energy Absolute Pcl, Thailand's largest renewable energy company, is seeking 15 billion baht (S$590 million) in loans to finance a 260-megawatt wind farm project in Chaiyaphum province. The project aims to triple the company's generating capacity to 664MW, with a goal of increasing power generation from solar and wind energy to 20% of total installed generation by 2036. The company has secured contracts to sell electricity to the state-owned Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand and expects to begin commercially operating wind farms with a total capacity of 126MW in Nakhon Si Thammarat province later this year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings will be added to the Straits Times Index (STI) while Sembcorp Marine will be removed, effective September 19. DBS Group appointed Shee Tse Koon as group head of strategy and planning, and Standard Chartered Bank hired Paul Skelton as global head of banking. Julius Baer appointed Bhaskar Laxminarayan as chief investment officer for Asia. Pteris Global will be delisted from September 7 after receiving 98.98% acceptances for a cash offer.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank held talks in Aug on tie-up: source
summary: Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, Germany's two largest banks, held talks on a potential merger in late August, but have since shelved the project due to a desire to complete restructuring before proceeding. The talks were initiated by Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan, who has called for cross-border mergers to address the sector's fragmentation and squeeze on profits. Cryan cited the need for consolidation to increase pricing power and open the way to healthier profits, but faces opposition from Germany's public savings banks, which have expressed concerns about the potential risks of mergers to financial market stability.

site_title: A feast for the mind and senses
summary: SIFA's fourth week continues to showcase provocative shows, including "Paradise Interrupted," a genre-crossing performance at Drama Centre Theatre, featuring Huang Ruo, Jennifer Wen Ma, Qian Yi, and the T'ang Quartet, inspired by John Milton's "Paradise Lost."

site_title: Call for stronger UK response to Volkswagen's emission scam
summary: The UK government is urged to take a tougher stance against Volkswagen over its emissions scandal, with the Environmental Audit Committee calling for increased action against the carmaker. The committee recommends that the government consider making electric vehicles more attractive through changes to vehicle taxation. The scandal, dubbed "Dieselgate," has cost VW billions of dollars and hurt its reputation, with the company yet to fully recall affected cars in the UK. The committee's conclusions are non-binding, but highlight the need for the government to address air pollution from transport and increase the use of electric cars.

site_title: Singapore forex volume up 35% even as global tally slides
summary: Singapore's foreign exchange market saw a 35% increase in average daily trading volume to US$517 billion in April 2016, driven by volatility and growth in G-10 and Asian currencies. The country remains the third-largest FX centre globally, after London and New York, with a market share of 7.9% in 2016. The yuan doubled its share to 4% and became the world's eighth most actively traded currency. The US dollar remained the dominant vehicle currency, and foreign exchange swaps accounted for 48% of all trades.

site_title: Putting Shakespeare on trial
summary: Shakespeare's iconic character Richard III is set to go on trial in a radical adaptation called "Sandaime Richard" at the Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA). The play, written by Hideki Noda, reimagines Richard as an ikebana master plotting his way to the top, with Shakespeare himself as the defendant, accused of distorting historical facts to serve his own creative license. Director Ong Keng Sen, who also helms SIFA, is using this production to explore the relationship between creators and their creations, and the power dynamics between the Bard and his characters.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing PMI at 50 in August, below Asean's 50.3
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector saw a stabilization in August after a 7-month decline, with a PMI reading of 50, below Asean's 50.3. The sector's performance improved due to higher output and a slowdown in job losses, but was offset by a decline in new orders. The Philippines and Vietnam led the region with higher PMI readings, while Thailand and Malaysia saw lower readings. Despite a mixed picture, economists note that the sector remains well-positioned for future growth.

site_title: CapitaLand's Raffles City Chongqing on track, within budget
summary: CapitaLand's Raffles City Chongqing, a 24 billion yuan (S$4.9 billion) mixed-use development, is on track and expected to open in the second half of 2018. The project, designed by Moshe Safdie, features office towers, hotels, shopping malls, and a transport hub, with a prime location in Chongqing's Yuzhong district. CEO Lim Ming Yan hailed the location as a key selling point, citing its ideal status for Chinese companies. The project has stayed within budget, with the China business accounting for 45% of CapitaLand's total assets.

site_title: Celebrating past and present S'pore music
summary: The Mosaic Music Weekend festival in Singapore will feature a diverse lineup of local singer-songwriters, including Leslie Low, The Observatory's frontman, who will perform new and old material, including songs from his past band Humpback Oak. Other notable acts include indie-pop darling Cherie Ko, who will debut her new project Tomgirl, and rising stars Deon, R&B funk pop star Dru Chen, and acoustic folk troubadour Anise. The festival will also showcase a new generation of homegrown talents and indie icon Leslie Low will play special solo shows as part of the free line-up.

site_title: Malaysia Inc needs to redefine its talent proposition to draw calibre
summary: Malaysia Inc's telco Axiata Group has appointed a German national, Michael Kuehner, as the head of its Malaysian subsidiary Celcom, sparking debate over why a native Malaysian wasn't chosen. Axiata defended the move, saying it was for the short term to groom a bumiputera successor, but critics argue it sends the wrong signal to foreign talent. The appointment weakens Axiata's proposition to tap foreign talent, and other government-linked companies face similar challenges. Malaysia Inc needs to redefine its talent proposition to include a mix of non-bumiputeras and foreigners to progress.

site_title: Cloud-storage firm Dropbox confirms 2012 breach bigger than previously known
summary: Dropbox has confirmed a 2012 data breach that affected almost 69 million accounts, with over 60 million accounts impacted. The breach, previously disclosed in 2012, involved passwords being reset for users who signed up before the middle of 2012. The company assured users that the reset protected their accounts and that even if passwords are cracked, they cannot be used to access accounts. This incident highlights the challenges of responding to hacking attacks and the lack of a uniform approach to password reset procedures.

site_title: Victoria Park Villas semi-Ds priced at S$4.4m to S$7.6m
summary: CapitaLand is launching 106 semi-detached houses and three bungalows in Victoria Park Villas, priced between S$4.4 million and S$7.6 million each. The project, which occupies 403,000 sq ft, offers private lifts, smart home systems, and move-in-ready homes. Prices are comparable to recent landed resale transactions in the area, and the company has factored in estimated costs for additions and alterations. The project is marketed with a 12% early-bird discount and up to 3% additional discount for certain buyers, appealing to those looking for landed homes in the Good Class Bungalow area.

site_title: US presidential race: nobody's a sure thing
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's chances of winning are uncertain, despite being favored by many polls, due to the unpredictability of the election. Unlike previous "Everyone-Knew" (EK) elections, where the outcome was clear, this year's election is a "No-One-Knew" (NOK) who-was-going-to-win scenario, with many factors that could influence the outcome, including Trump's recent controversies and debates. Nate Silver's FiveThirtyEight predicts a 79.5% chance of Hillary Clinton winning, but polls have been inconsistent, and some experts believe that Trump's popularity could rise in the aftermath of major events, such as terrorist attacks or scandals involving Clinton.

site_title: Three companies express interest in airwaves auction
summary: Three Singaporean companies, airYotta Pte Ltd, MyRepublic, and TPG Telecom, have expressed interest in participating in the country's airwaves auction, which could introduce a fourth telecom operator. The auction aims to increase competition in the market, which currently has three operators. The deadline for submissions was met, and the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore will assess the applications before determining pre-qualification. The auction's outcome will determine if a new entrant will be allowed to operate in the market.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says it won't flood oil market before Opec meeting
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Khalid Al-Falih, stated that the country won't flood the oil market before an Opec meeting to discuss stabilizing crude prices. Despite a drop in prices and a slower economy, Saudi Arabia isn't concerned about global demand and is producing near-record levels to preserve market share. Al-Falih said Saudi Arabia will meet demand if it rises, and the country is negotiating for crude storage projects with China and pursuing refinery ventures valued at over $20 billion.

site_title: Samsung unveils two new versions of Gear S3 smartwatches
summary: Samsung unveiled two new versions of Gear S3 smartwatches, the Frontier and Classic, with up to four days of battery life. The watches boast digital features and are set to go on sale by year-end. This move aims to outshine the Apple Watch, highlighting Samsung's focus on consumer electronics. The introduction comes ahead of the IFA trade fair in Berlin, showcasing the company's latest offerings in the smartwatch market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo by the Trump administration on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2 and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. In Indonesia, a Trafigura employee was detained in a graft case. Singapore stocks staged a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long set to take over. MAS and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Audi may extend rent-by- hour service to mainland China
summary: Audi plans to extend its rent-by-the-hour service to mainland China, following successful launches in Hong Kong, San Francisco, and Miami. The luxury carmaker sees China as a lucrative market, expecting a 5-10% sales expansion this year. The service allows users to rent an Audi by the hour through a smartphone app, appealing to jet-setters who own cars but don't use them frequently. Audi partnered with developer Kerry Properties in Hong Kong to launch the service, with plans to expand to more locations. The move aims to tap into China's restricted car ownership market.

site_title: Two execs sentenced to jail for money laundering
summary: Two Singapore executives, Thomas Philip Doehrman and Lim Ai Wah, were sentenced to 70 months and 60 months in jail, respectively, for money laundering in a 2010 Papua New Guinea community college project. Doehrman, 68, and his spouse, Lim, conspired to issue a fake invoice to Chinese telecommunications equipment maker ZTE Corp for $3.6 million. A third individual, Stephen Li Weiming, has absconded and a warrant of arrest has been issued. The Singapore Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau said the country has a zero-tolerance approach to corruption.

site_title: Manhattan luxury-condo builders fighting glut
summary: Manhattan luxury-condo developers are adjusting sales strategies amid a glut of available units. To boost momentum, builders are offering discounts, dividing larger units into smaller ones, and providing incentives such as gift cards and reduced transfer taxes. The market has slowed due to global economic turmoil, oil price drops, and the 2016 presidential election uncertainty. Contracts for luxury homes above $4 million fell 21% in the first 35 weeks of 2016, with average sales times increasing by 54 days. Developers are adapting to the new reality, with some projects delaying marketing efforts until they reach completion.

images.alt_text: Some builders with projects close to completion are touting their within-reach move-in dates, while for others, the answer has been to delay a marketing push until the chance of success seems greater.

site_title: Row over Mylan EpiPen boils down to plastic cap
summary: Mylan is opposing Teva's generic version of the EpiPen, citing a design difference in the plastic cap as a key reason for its rejection by the FDA. Teva's two-cap version, which includes a removable cap, differs from Mylan's one-cap design. Mylan argues that this difference could lead to confusion among patients in emergency situations. The FDA previously rejected Teva's application, citing "major deficiencies" in the proposal. Mylan is seeking the FDA to approve the generic devices only if they are truly equivalent and won't pose a risk to patients.

site_title: In the lap of lux(e)ury
summary: A recent luxury wine dinner, BT Luxe, was held at ION Art, featuring a four-course meal paired with fine wines selected from The Business Times Wine Challenge. Guests enjoyed canapés, starters, entrée options, and a dessert course, all complemented by premium wines. The event included a multimedia showcase of designer watches, a wine expert talk, and live music, showcasing the perfect combination of luxury and indulgence. The dinner was jointly organized by The Business Times and ION Orchard.

site_title: S'pore-Chongqing connectivity project making speedy progress: Chun Sing
summary: Singapore and Chongqing have sealed cross-border renminbi financing deals worth over US$6 billion, exceeding expectations for the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative. This milestone is attributed to the successful launch of bilateral projects in financial services, aviation, transport & logistics, and ICT. Minister Chan Chun Sing described the progress as "the tip of the iceberg," indicating potential for further growth. The initiative, launched in November, aims to promote modern connectivity and modern services, with the three priority areas of collaboration showing promising results.

site_title: SIIC to buy 60% stake in HK firm
summary: SIIC Environment to acquire 60% stake in Ranhill Water (Hong Kong) for 273.9 million yuan (S$55.8 million) in cash. The target company provides wastewater treatment services to industrial parks in China and Malaysia, with a total design capacity of 260,000 tonnes a day. The acquisition is expected to be profitable and aligns with SIIC's ordinary course of business.

site_title: PM Lee to visit Chongqing and Hangzhou
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will visit China from September 1 to 4, stopping in Chongqing and Hangzhou. In Chongqing, Lee will meet with Chongqing party secretary Sun Zhengcai to discuss the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative, a government-to-government project to boost growth in China's western regions. In Hangzhou, Lee will attend the G-20 Leaders' Summit, where he will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping and discuss global economic cooperation.

site_title: Uniqlo makes biggest South-east Asia bet as CEO looks abroad
summary: Uniqlo, a unit of Fast Retailing Co, is opening its largest store in South-east Asia in Singapore, spanning 2,700 square meters on three floors. This marks the brand's biggest bet in the region as it seeks to boost growth outside Japan to revive flagging profits. The move aims to generate five trillion yen (S$65.9 billion) in sales by 2020, with billionaire chairman Tadashi Yanai targeting a significant expansion in South-east Asia.

site_title: SCCB: Slight uptick in business optimism, but cautious outlook holds
summary: Singapore's business optimism has improved slightly in Q4 2016, with the Business Optimism Index (BOI) increasing to 2.87 percentage points, up from 1.11 percentage points in the previous quarter. However, overall optimism remains low, and growth prospects are expected to remain stagnant. Key sectors showing optimism include manufacturing, services, and health and social services, while the financial and construction sectors remain cautious due to slowdowns in bank loans and private building projects.

site_title: Businesses to enjoy single corporate ID for govt e-services
summary: Singapore will introduce CorpPass, a single corporate digital identity, to simplify online transactions with government agencies. Businesses can use a single login ID to access 11 e-services starting September 15, including the Intellectual Property Office of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry. By December 2017, all 200 digital services managed by 60 government agencies are expected to be available. CorpPass is designed to reduce red tape and compliance costs for businesses, and the Singapore government is seen as a pioneer in corporate digital identity, with other governments watching closely.

site_title: China's PMI jumps in August, but private sector trails behind
summary: China's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) jumped to 50.4 in August, its highest reading in nearly two years, driven by infrastructure in state-owned companies. However, the private Caixin PMI index fell to 50, indicating stagnant conditions in the manufacturing sector. Analysts say weaknesses remain, including unaddressed government debt and overcapacity, and that private investment remains stagnant. The government has put reforms on hold to avoid an economic slowdown, maintaining accommodative monetary policies and boosting spending in key sectors.

site_title: Soaking in the prose on wine
summary: A wine enthusiast advocates for learning about wine through tasting and reading. The author recommends tasting a wide variety of wines and reading books written by renowned wine writers, such as Michael Broadbent and Hugh Johnson. They also suggest traveling to wine regions and reading wine magazines, like Decanter and The World of Fine Wine. The author finds that reading and tasting provide valuable knowledge and insights into the world of wine, allowing for a more enriching experience and understanding of the culture surrounding wine.

site_title: Silicon Valley dream collapses in fraud allegations
summary: WrkRiot, a Silicon Valley startup founded by Isaac Choi, has collapsed amid allegations of fraud. Former head of marketing Penny Kim claimed the company paid employees in cashier's cheques and forged wire transfer documents to make it appear as if compensation was on the way. WrkRiot has taken itself offline and Choi's credibility is in question, with his résumé and background also under scrutiny. The startup's implosion has sparked concern about the darker side of the tech industry, with many startup investors and employees sharing similar experiences of chaos and dysfunction.

site_title: Sterling soars after stunning UK PMI data
summary: Sterling jumped one percent against the dollar to a one-month high after the UK manufacturing sector's PMI data showed a 10-month high of 53.3 in August, rebounding from a three-year low in July. This led to a one percent rise in the pound to US$1.3267 and a fall in the euro to 84.125 pence. The dollar extended its advance against the yen and euro, while the Australian dollar rose 0.2 percent after China's manufacturing sector data showed a modest increase in August.

site_title: Developing world set to get charter cities boost
summary: Paul Romer, a prominent economist and proponent of "charter cities" to boost development, takes over as World Bank chief economist in September. He replaces Kaushik Basu and Justin Yifu Lin, marking a shift from selecting chief economists from developing countries. Romer's appointment follows that of Nobel laureate Joseph Stiglitz, who criticized the Washington consensus and Western influence on international aid. The move is seen as a significant change in the World Bank's approach to economic development, with Romer's charter city concept aiming to generate growth and promote economic growth in developing regions.

site_title: China encourages more VC funding, promises foreign firms equal treatment
summary: China is encouraging foreign venture capital investors to increase funding, promising equal treatment and improved market access. The government will cut red tape and provide tax cuts to enhance direct financing. State-owned companies will be allowed to set up venture funds, and insurance companies will be encouraged to invest in startups. This move aims to boost China's economy, which is growing at its slowest pace in 25 years, and address challenges faced by the venture capital industry, including policy clarity and unpredictable capital market access.

site_title: Insurance companies, pension funds dominate currency trading: BIS
summary: Insurance companies, pension funds, and mutual funds now account for more than 50% of daily foreign exchange market turnover, according to a Bank for International Settlements survey. This increase reflects growing demand for hedging through foreign exchange swaps to protect against currency fluctuations. The share of trading by hedge funds and proprietary trading firms declined by 29% and 37%, respectively, as tougher regulatory rules and a decline in prop trading have led to a shift in market structure.

images.alt_text: Non-bank financial institutions like insurance companies, mutual funds and pension funds account for more than 50 per cent of daily turnover in the currency market, a survey of the foreign exchange market showed on Thursday.

site_title: US second-quarter labour costs revised sharply higher
summary: US labour costs rose sharply higher than initially reported, increasing at a 4.3% annual rate in the second quarter, with hourly compensation per hour jumping 3.7%. Productivity slumped at a 0.6% annual rate, the third consecutive quarterly drop, while output per worker increased at a 1.1% rate. Weaker productivity and rising labour costs may pressure corporate profits and fuel inflationary pressures.

site_title: AusGroup bondholders set terms for nod to debt issue's extension
summary: AusGroup, a Singaporean oil and gas engineering services provider, is seeking to extend its S$110 million debt issue by two years, pending conditions set by bondholders. The conditions include securing the debt, early redemption of around 5% of the notes, and a slight improvement in coupon rates. If met, this could give AusGroup the breathing space to dispose of assets and meet its funding needs, avoiding a potential judicial management scenario like Swiber Holdings. A consent solicitation exercise is expected to be launched as early as Sept 7.

site_title: Iron ore is Clarksons' 'least favourite' commodity
summary: Iron ore prices face renewed pressure due to rising global supply, which is expected to offset improved Chinese demand. Benchmark spot prices have fallen to $58.97 a tonne, with some analysts predicting prices may sink below $40 a tonne by year-end. Despite a 35% surge in iron ore prices this year, Clarksons Platou Securities Inc considers it its "least favorite commodity" due to its supply profile. Rising exports from Australia and Brazil, as well as increased output from Vale and Gina Rinehart's Roy Hill, are contributing to the supply surge.

site_title: Handling the yakuza's pervasive presence in Japanese business
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe welcomes foreign investment to Japan, but lacks an official briefing on yakuza, Japan's pervasive and all-pervasive organized crime elements. The yakuza's influence is seen in various industries, including real estate, finance, and entertainment, posing risks of reputational damage, extortion, or blackmail for businesses that unknowingly or knowingly do business with them. Authorities have tolerated the yakuza, viewing them as a necessary evil, and have implemented laws to regulate them, but critics argue this does not align with the government's emphasis on corporate governance and improved regulation.

site_title: Taking on Hokkien TV drama Eat Already?
summary: Singaporean filmmaker Royston Tan worked on his first TV drama, "Eat Already?", a Hokkien-language series about senior citizens, and found it to be a challenging yet rewarding experience. The series, set in a coffee shop, features a mix of veteran actors and celebrity cameos, and was created to address issues faced by the silver generation. Tan, who had to brush up on his Hokkien language skills, praised the dialect's unique blend of Malay and Chinese influences, saying it brings people together.

site_title: May draws a red line on immigration for upcoming Brexit negotiations
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has drawn a red line on immigration, stating that Britain will pursue a unique model after leaving the EU and won't adopt an "off-the-shelf solution." She confirmed that the UK will invoke Article 50 and begin the formal process of leaving the EU without a parliamentary vote, despite opposition from some MPs. May aims to control immigration and establish a deal that benefits both the UK and the EU, with a focus on welcoming high-skilled workers and professionals.

site_title: US jobless claims edge higher; jobs market remains firm
summary: US jobless claims rose to 263,000 in the week ending August 27, but remain below 300,000 for the 78th consecutive week. Strong hiring by US businesses offsets layoffs, with analysts expecting firm hiring in July. The unemployment rate is forecast to fall to 4.8% in July, based on 180,000 jobs added.

site_title: MAS adjusts TDSR rules for refinancing; cooling measures to remain
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has refined rules for refinancing housing loans, allowing overleveraged borrowers to refinance above the 60% total debt servicing ratio (TDSR) threshold with a debt restructuring plan. Borrowers must repay at least 3% of the outstanding balance over three years. The refinancing allows for better debt management, but cooling measures remain unchanged. This adjustment aims to support borrowers in managing their debt through refinancing.

site_title: IMF urges G20 leaders to boost demand, make case for trade
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) urged G20 leaders to boost demand, revive trade, and implement structural reforms to their economies. The IMF noted that global trade growth has slowed, with most countries falling short of their 2014 goals to boost collective growth by two percentage points within five years. The IMF called for leaders to make the case for globalization and adopt policies that foster innovation and new industries, while also helping those affected by trade changes through re-training and skill-building.

site_title: Asia swaps trading stumbles amid confusion over margin rules
summary: Asia's over-the-counter (OTC) swaps market has ground to a halt due to confusion over new margin rules, which could increase global funding costs by over $500 billion. Major banks in the US and Japan have halted dealing in various derivatives products, including foreign exchange non-deliverable forwards and interest rate swaps, until they can comply with the rules. The rules, which were effective on September 1, aim to increase transparency and reduce risks in the OTC derivatives market, but have created an uneven playing field and led to regulatory arbitrage.

site_title: Hangzhou G-20 summit faces formidable task in reviving growth, warns IMF
summary: The IMF warns that the G20 summit in Hangzhou, China, faces a daunting task in reviving global economic growth. The report notes that growth in the G20 is falling short of targets, with only 55% of commitments fully implemented, and that structural reforms and boosting trade are necessary to lift growth. The IMF cautions that the legacy of the Hangzhou summit will depend on governments working all policy levers to address the obstacles hindering global economic stagnation.

site_title: US stocks edge higher in opening trade
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.1%, the S&P 500 up 0.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite up 0.3%. The jobs market remains strong, with low unemployment insurance claims, which could lead to a solid July jobs report and a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. A positive jobs report could endorse solid US economic growth and push the Fed to raise interest rates by the end of the month.

site_title: Manufacturing in US contracts for first time in six months
summary: US manufacturing contracted in August for the first time in six months, with the Institute for Supply Management's index dropping to 49.4, down 3.2 points from July. Fresh orders to American factories shrank, production was cut by the most since 2012, and employment fell. The decline suggests manufacturers remain hesitant to invest due to uncertainty over the US presidential election and global demand. This marks the first time manufacturing has contracted since January 2014, raising concerns of renewed industrial weakness.

images.alt_text: Manufacturing in the US unexpectedly contracted in August for the first time in six months amid slumping orders and production that raise concern of renewed industrial weakness.

site_title: Jardine Matheson Holdings to be added to STI; Sembcorp Marine to be removed
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings will be added to the Straits Times Index (STI) while Sembcorp Marine will be removed, effective September 19. The changes follow a review by FTSE Russell, which added the five highest-ranking non-constituents to the STI reserve list. Companies on the reserve list will replace ineligible constituents before the next review on December 1.

site_title: Two Singapore firms formally express interest in becoming country's fourth telco
summary: Two Singapore firms, airYotta Pte Ltd and MyRepublic, have formally expressed interest in becoming the country's fourth telecom operator. The move aims to increase competition in the city-state's telecommunications market, which currently has three operators - Singapore Telecommunications Ltd, M1 Ltd, and StarHub Ltd. The Singapore regulator will conduct an airwaves auction later this year to determine which firm will be granted the necessary licenses. The new operator is expected to enhance competition and improve services for consumers.

site_title: Fast Retailing aims to triple Asean countries' share of sales
summary: Fast Retailing aims to increase its sales in Asean countries to 30% of its global sales in the next 5-10 years, tripling the region's current share. The goal was announced by CEO Tadashi Yanai, who stated that the target is to reach around 30%. This would represent a significant expansion for the Uniqlo operator in the region.

site_title: Chinese yuan is most actively traded emerging market currency: BIS
summary: The Chinese yuan has surpassed the Mexican peso as the most actively traded emerging market currency, according to a Bank for International Settlements survey. The yuan's average daily turnover nearly doubled from $120 billion to $202 billion between 2013 and 2016, increasing its global share to 4% from 2%. This reflects China's growing influence on the global economy.

site_title: JPMorgan gets wholly-owned asset management license in China
summary: JPMorgan Chase has been granted a wholly-owned asset management license in China, allowing it to set up an office in the Shanghai free-trade zone. The move comes as China seeks to further open its financial markets to foreigners ahead of the G20 summit in Hangzhou. The license enables JPMorgan to operate a fully-owned fund management business in China, following a joint venture with state-owned Shanghai International Trust Co. The decision is seen as a step towards China's economic reforms and a loosening of regulatory controls, which have been a concern for overseas investors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing PMI fell to 50 in August, slightly below Asean's 50.3, marking a seven-month high. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) refined rules for refinancing housing loans, allowing overleveraged borrowers to refinance under a debt restructuring plan. Businesses in Singapore will soon use a corporate digital identity, CorpPass, to transact with government agencies. Two senior executives were sentenced to jail for money laundering. UOB issued US$600m subordinated notes at 2.88% interest. A Kickstarter platform launched in Singapore and Hong Kong, while the Straits Times Index (STI) closed weaker ahead of the US jobs report.

site_title: China steps up arrivals checks from Singapore amid Zika outbreak
summary: China intensified arrivals checks from Singapore amid the Zika outbreak, which has spread to at least one person in neighboring Malaysia. The outbreak, which has reached 115 cases in Singapore, has prompted warnings from the US, Australia, and other countries for pregnant women or those trying to conceive. Singapore remains a "safe travel destination," but the outbreak coincides with a dip in exports and economic growth in both countries, potentially affecting tourism and trade.

site_title: Upcoming G-20 could be the most important since 2009
summary: The G-20 summit in Hangzhou, China, is set to be the most important since 2009, with China as its chair. The summit's agenda focuses on an innovative, inclusive, and invigorated world economy, and reforms to global governance. Key issues to be discussed include the recent surge in tensions in Ukraine, the South China Sea, and terrorism and migration. The summit also aims to promote invigorated, innovative, and inclusive global growth, with a focus on climate change and the Paris agreement. The event is expected to solidify China's international prominence and the G-20's role as a premier forum for international economic cooperation and global economic governance.

images.alt_text: As preparations for the Hangzhou G-20 get underway, China is keen that the summit's agenda stays laser-like on economics to avoid sensitive geopolitical controversies. But several such issues are likely to cloud the event.

site_title: China puts on best face for G20 summit
summary: China hosts the G20 summit in Hangzhou, seeking to project its economic strength despite a slowdown in its giant economy. The country has struggled with industrial overcapacity, government lending concerns, and a volatile stock market. Beijing's aggressive stance in the South China Sea is also a sensitive issue. The summit aims to showcase China's financial accomplishments and assume international leadership, but it faces challenges in addressing these pressing issues. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to address the country's economic concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.510 points to 1670.550. The index saw 1.810 billion lots traded worth RM2.028 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 564 to 279.

site_title: German engineering orders plunge as growth in manufacturing slows
summary: Germany's engineering orders plunged 19% in real terms in July, with domestic orders down 34% and foreign orders 9% lower. This slowdown in manufacturing growth, despite a slightly slower pace in August, suggests factories in Europe's largest economy are facing headwinds. Economists attribute the decline to weaker exports, with some expecting growth to slow to 1.2% in 2017. Despite this, the overall manufacturing sector remains in good shape, with production and new business showing strong figures.

site_title: Oil steadies as Saudi sees Opec 'common position'
summary: Oil prices steadied on Thursday as Saudi Arabia indicated that Opec is moving towards a common position on oil production, which could support prices. Brent crude futures fell 5 cents to $46.84 a barrel, while US crude futures remained unchanged at $44.70 a barrel. Saudi Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir stated that Opec and non-Opec producers are moving towards a common effort, citing a collective responsibility to support oil prices. Despite this, analysts remain skeptical, citing past failed output freezes and the influence of speculative long positions.

site_title: Nestle to buy medical device company Phagenesis in stages
summary: Nestle announced a deal to buy Phagenesis, a British medical device company, in stages. Nestle will make an upfront payment followed by milestone-based funding after Phagenesis completes its Phagenyx device evaluation by 2019. The acquisition is part of Nestle's growth strategy in the medical sphere, which is seen as faster and more profitable than traditional food operations. The deal is expected to accelerate the development of Phagenyx, a device treating dysphagia, and will be led by Ulf Mark Schneider, Nestle's new chief executive. Estimated sales of Nestle's health business are expected to reach $10 billion.

site_title: Zika outbreak: Another pregnant woman among 31 new cases
summary: Singapore reported 31 new Zika cases, including one pregnant woman, as of September 1. The Ministry of Health and National Environment Agency confirmed the cases, with the pregnant woman linked to the Aljunied Crescent/Sims Drive cluster. The government is providing support and counseling to the affected individual. This brings the total number of confirmed Zika cases in Singapore to over 100, with the majority linked to the Aljunied Crescent/Sims Drive cluster.

site_title: Demand for bonds is so strong, there's not enough to trade
summary: Global debt has reached an all-time high, with central banks and institutional investors holding over $27 trillion in bonds, accounting for nearly half of the global bond market. This surge in demand is leaving a shrinking supply of bonds available for trading, threatening the functioning of major bond markets. The "turnover rate" in German government debt has halved over the last decade, and repo rates have fallen as low as -100 basis points due to a severe shortage of bonds for collateral. This is leading to reduced market liquidity, making it difficult for investors to buy and sell bonds tactically.

images.alt_text: Global debt has never been higher yet the amount of bonds available to trade is shrinking rapidly, potentially threatening the functioning of major bond markets.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker ahead of Friday's US jobs report
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) initially rebounded by 12 points but ended the day with a net loss of 4.12 points at 2,816.47 due to thin trading volume. The cautious market sentiment was attributed to concerns about a potential US interest rate hike following the August jobs report. Turnover was below average, with 987 million units traded at S$851.3 million, and 154 stocks rose while 218 fell. The market's uncertainty was also fueled by ongoing global economic issues and earnings worries.

site_title: Europe needs US$800b investment in digital infrastructure: Commissioner
summary: European Union Commissioner Guenther Oettinger urges the need for $800 billion investment in digital infrastructure to catch up with the US and China. He warns that Europe's inability to develop fibre-optic networks and 5G applications will lead to losing technological advancements. Oettinger emphasizes the need for unified digital standards to compete with digital giants like Amazon and Google, with a goal of having a European-wide data regulation within two years.

site_title: Protesters descend on UN as Ban Ki Moon visits Sri Lanka
summary: Dozens of Sri Lankan nationalists protested outside the UN compound in Colombo, criticizing the UN's actions during Sri Lanka's 37-year ethnic war. Buddhist monks led the rally, holding signs blaming the UN for siding with Tamil rebels and failing to protect civilians. The protesters handed over a petition to UN officials, while the UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon held talks with the Sri Lankan government, pushing for a special court to investigate war crimes.

site_title: US construction spending unchanged in July
summary: US construction spending remained unchanged in July, contrary to expectations of a 0.5% rise. This was due to a 0.9% increase in June being revised to 0.6%, while government outlays declined. Despite this, construction outlays were up 1.5% from a year ago, suggesting a boost to second-quarter economic growth.

site_title: PM Lee to visit Chongqing and Hangzhou
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will visit China from Friday to Monday, stopping in Chongqing and Hangzhou. This is his first visit to Chongqing since the launch of the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative in 2015. He will meet with Chinese officials and visit the CapitaLand Chaotianmen Project. In Hangzhou, Lee will have a bilateral meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping ahead of the Group of 20 Leaders' Summit, where he will discuss global economic cooperation. Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean will act as acting prime minister during Lee's absence.

site_title: Swiss launch criminal probe of German soccer great Beckenbauer
summary: Swiss federal prosecutors have launched a criminal probe into German soccer great Franz Beckenbauer, suspected of money laundering and breach of trust related to his role in organizing Germany's 2006 World Cup bid. The investigation is based on a German news report and has not been confirmed to be directly related to money laundering. Beckenbauer has previously denied any wrongdoing. The Office of the Attorney General of Switzerland has confirmed the ongoing operation but has not disclosed further details.

site_title: German manufacturing growth slows in August but remains strong, PMI shows
summary: German manufacturing growth slowed to 53.6 in August, down from 53.8 in July, but remained solid, according to Markit's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI). This is in line with the long-run average of 51.9, signaling business conditions for manufacturers are improving. The slowdown was a surprise, but the PMI still indicates growth, supporting expansion in Europe's largest economy.

site_title: Apple CEO expects to repatriate billions of dollars to US next year
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook expects to repatriate billions of dollars in global profits to the US next year, with a total of $181 billion held offshore. Cook stated that $800 million was paid in taxes in 2014, and billions more have been provisioned for US payment. This move is seen as a response to criticism that Apple is using offshore profits to avoid US taxes.

site_title: Mazda recalling 2.2m vehicles over tailgate defect
summary: Mazda is recalling approximately 2.2 million vehicles worldwide due to a tailgate defect. The affected models, including the CX-3 and CX-5, were sold in Japan and exported to 1.8 million units in other countries. The recall is expected to cover around 400,000 vehicles in Japan. Mazda has not specified the cause of the defect or the timeline for the recall.

site_title: Japanese probe finds no bribery in Tokyo 2020 bid
summary: A Japanese investigative panel has found no evidence of bribery in Tokyo's successful bid to host the 2020 Olympics. The probe, led by three lawyers, investigated a $2 million payment made during the bid process, which has been linked to a son of Lamine Diack, a disgraced former world athletics chief. The panel concluded that the payment was for consulting services and did not violate any Japanese laws or the International Olympic Committee's code of ethics. Japanese officials have consistently denied wrongdoing, and the investigation's limitations were emphasized.

site_title: Pokemon Go hunters snare real thief in New Zealand
summary: In Napier, New Zealand, a group of Pokémon Go players caught a real thief who broke into a car. The young people, out hunting virtual Pokémon, heard a car alarm and saw a masked man run past. They held the thief until police arrived, referring to their actions as using "Pokeballs" to capture the suspect. The incident occurred on Wednesday night in the North Island town.

site_title: Hong Kong shares up, Shanghai down after China data
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.81% to close at 23,162.34 following a better-than-expected report on Chinese factory activity, while Shanghai fell 0.72% due to fears of delayed stimulus. The Hang Seng Index surpassed Shanghai's benchmark Composite Index. The market reaction was attributed to the Chinese data, which was seen as a positive sign for the economy.

site_title: Banks cut 4.1% of Switzerland jobs in first half as profit falls
summary: Switzerland's banks reduced their domestic workforce by 4.1% in the first half of 2016, resulting in 3,454 job losses, according to a survey by the Swiss Bankers Association. This decline was attributed to declining profitability due to low interest rates and strong competition. The number of workers fell to 103,041 in 2015, and assets under management slipped 1.3% to 6.57 trillion Swiss francs in 2015. Despite this, banks are boosting headcount in emerging-market regions such as Asia, with a net 6,700 job additions outside Switzerland in the first half.

site_title: Oil gains as Saudis see steady output after US stockpiles rise
summary: Oil prices rose 0.7% in New York after Saudi Arabia stated it won't boost output to meet market demand, citing a global inventory surplus. US crude inventories increased by 2.28 million barrels, and Opec members plan to meet in September to discuss stabilizing prices. The market is expected to be saturated with stored crude, with some analysts warning of speculation-driven volatility. Oil rose 7.5% in August, but prices may not sustain a strong rally due to the surplus.

site_title: Singapore Court sentences 2 execs to jail for money laundering
summary: Two senior executives, Thomas Philip Doehrman and Lim Ai Wah, were sentenced to 70 months and 60 months of jail time respectively for money laundering in a Singapore court. The pair conspired to issue a fictitious invoice to Chinese telecommunications equipment maker ZTE to extract US$3.6 million from a US$35 million contract for a community college project in Papua New Guinea. A third individual, Stephen Li Weiming, has absconded and a warrant of arrest has been issued.

site_title: Secura Group partners Cellebrite Asia Pacific to expand offerings
summary: Secura Group has partnered with Cellebrite Asia Pacific to expand its offerings, with Soverus Technology Pte Ltd becoming the primary reseller of Cellebrite's mobile forensics products in Singapore, and the secondary reseller in Cambodia and Laos. The partnership, which started on Wednesday, is set to last for three years, allowing Soverus to sell, promote, and market Cellebrite's products in these three countries.

site_title: Shell announces new natural gas discoveries in Egypt's Western Desert
summary: Royal Dutch Shell announced new natural gas discoveries in Egypt's Western Desert, with estimated quantities of about half a trillion cubic feet. The discovery could produce 10-15% of the total production of Badr el-Din Petroleum company, a joint venture between Shell and the Egyptian state-owned Egyptian General Petroleum Corporation. Shell owns the license of the entire area, with Badr el-Din expected to manage operations.

site_title: Gold deal-making heats up as Canada-based miners agree to merge
summary: Canada-based gold miners Kirkland Lake Gold Inc and Newmarket Gold Inc agreed to merge in an all-stock deal valued at C$1.01 billion. The combined company will produce over 500,000 ounces of gold a year and have all-in sustaining costs of less than US$1,015 an ounce. The move is part of the industry's consolidation efforts as companies look to cut costs and boost production. The deal is the latest in a busy quarter of deal-making in the gold industry, driven by surging metal and stock prices.

site_title: French manufacturing activity slows in August as demand weakens, PMI shows
summary: French manufacturing activity slowed in August, with the purchasing managers' index falling to 48.3 from 48.6 in July, marking the sixth consecutive month below the 50-point line. This decline was attributed to weak demand, which weighed on new orders. The result is a further indication of the ongoing slowdown in France's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Palm in steepest fall in over a month on weak export demand
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures fell 2.2% to RM2,605 a tonne, their weakest since September 19, due to weaker export demand and lower rival oils. Despite expectations of improved demand from India, palm shipments for September 1-25 fell 16% from the same period in August. India's reduction in import taxes on palm oil and refined vegetable oils could spur demand, but market sentiment remains cautious. Weaker demand from top consumers China and India, combined with colder temperatures, may slow palm exports towards the end of the year.

site_title: Australia shares end lower in cautious trade; NZ reverses losses
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Thursday, closing at their lowest in over six weeks, due to cautious trade amid economic data and anticipation of US job data on Friday. Nickel miner Western Areas Ltd and coal miner Whitehaven Coal Ltd were among the biggest decliners. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index rebounded 0.3% after earlier losses, driven by gains in industrials, healthcare, and financials.

site_title: UK factory activity rebounds in August, helped by slump in sterling: PMI
summary: The UK's manufacturing sector rebounded in August with a 10-month high of 53.3 in the Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), driven by a boost to exports from sterling's post-Brexit slump. This rebound, the largest in nearly 25 years, suggests the economy is weathering the initial impact of the vote better than feared. However, the weaker currency is likely to fuel inflation, with input costs rising by the biggest margin in over five years and prices charged by manufacturers increasing at the sharpest rate since 2011.

images.alt_text: British manufacturing staged one of its sharpest rebounds on record in August as factories recovered from the initial shock of June's vote to leave the European Union, helped by a boost to exports from sterling's post-Brexit slump.

site_title: Eurozone factory growth eased in August and may slow further, PMI shows
summary: Eurozone factory growth slowed in August, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dipping to 51.7 from 52.0. The decline was driven by reduced sales to the UK, which voted to leave the EU, and a slowdown in growth in France and Italy. The eurozone's manufacturing sector remains focused in the north, with Germany, the Netherlands, and Austria driving growth.
