The slowdown hints at further economic challenges, with inflation remaining stable at 0.2% and the European Central Bank facing pressure to loosen monetary policy.

site_title: Jakarta says one Indonesian woman infected with Zika virus in Singapore
summary: An Indonesian woman has been infected with the Zika virus in Singapore, according to the Indonesian Foreign Ministry. The woman, whose name and age were not disclosed, is receiving treatment at a hospital in Singapore. This marks the first case of the disease affecting an Indonesian national. The information was communicated by the Singapore Ministry of Health to the Indonesian Embassy.

site_title: Walmart in talks to invest up to US$1b in Flipkart
summary: Walmart is in advanced discussions to invest up to $1 billion in Flipkart, India's largest online retailer, as the two companies compete with Amazon in the e-commerce market. Walmart would take a minority stake in Flipkart, valuing the company at $16 billion. The deal could benefit both parties, providing Flipkart with much-needed capital and Walmart with exposure to India's growing e-commerce market. Negotiations are ongoing, and final terms have not been worked out.

site_title: The midas of publishing (Amended)
summary: Forbes CEO Mike Perlis has transformed the 95-year-old business magazine into one of the best-read digital publications in the world. Under his leadership, the company shifted its focus from print to digital and expanded its content platform to include contributors from around the world. The platform allows veteran reporters and non-full-time employees to post their own content, which has led to a dramatic increase in traffic, from 15 million unique visitors in 2010 to 53 million in July 2016. Forbes also introduced native advertising and sponsored content, which has been successful in monetizing online. The company's events and conferences, targeting specific groups, have also seen high energy and attendance. Additionally, Forbes has taken its brand global, with 36 international editions in local languages.

site_title: Apple's Cook confident of victory in tax fight as Irish dither
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook expressed confidence that the company will win a court fight against a European Union decision requiring it to pay up to $19 billion in tax arrears to Ireland. The EU ruled that Apple received selective tax treatment, while Cook called the decision "maddening and disappointing." The Irish government is still considering an appeal, and the final amount Apple may have to pay could take years to resolve.

site_title: More than 100 injured in New Jersey commuter train crash
summary: A New Jersey commuter train crashed into a station in Hoboken during morning rush hour, killing three people and injuring over 100, many critically. The train failed to stop and hit a concrete block at full speed, causing major damage and partial roof collapse. An investigation is ongoing to determine the cause of the accident, which occurred at 9:00 am with 250 passengers on board. Emergency vehicles responded to the scene, and passengers described a chaotic and intense situation with many injuries and head trauma.

site_title: Oil prices slip on profit-taking as investors eye US stockpile data
summary: Oil prices declined in Asian trade on Tuesday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude falling 38 US cents to $45.55 a barrel, and Brent crude futures slipping 43 US cents to $46.91 a barrel. The decline was attributed to profit-taking after prices rose 3.3% in the previous session. Investors are awaiting US stockpile data and a meeting of major oil producers in Algeria, where a potential deal to cut or freeze oil output could support prices.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GMG Global, United Engineers, Rowsley
summary: Key developments include a Securities Investors Association call for GMG Global to raise its offer, a surge in United Engineers shares after OCBC Bank and affiliates reviewed options for their combined stake, and Rowsley receiving approval to issue new shares for a multimillion-dollar acquisition.

site_title: UK finance minister confirms end to support for high loan-to-value mortgages
summary: UK finance minister Philip Hammond confirmed the end of government-backed mortgage guarantee scheme at the end of 2016, as previously scheduled. The scheme, part of the Help to Buy housing program, aimed to help homebuyers with high loan-to-value mortgages. Although the scheme's reliance on government support has decreased, the government remains committed to the overall Help to Buy program and other housing market supports.

site_title: PBOC drains most funds in six months amid debt curb speculation
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, drained a record 245 billion yuan (S$50.31 billion) from the financial system in a single day, amid efforts to curb excessive leverage. This move follows a 670 billion yuan injection last week to meet pre-holiday demand. The benchmark money-market rate surged the most in five months, while the 10-year government bond yield fell two basis points. The PBOC aims to limit runaway borrowing and bring down leverage ratio growth, with Deputy Governor Yi Gang stating that the goal is to curb leverage.

site_title: Greek lawmakers pass fresh reforms sought by creditors
summary: Greek lawmakers passed fresh austerity measures, including expediting the privatization of utility companies, to secure 2.8 billion euros in loans from creditors. The reforms were adopted by 152 of 293 parliamentary deputies, paving the way for the loan release. The new law foresees the reorganization of the electricity market, acceleration of privatization programs, and management of non-performing loans. Over 500 people protested outside parliament against the "selling off" of public companies.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Corp's target price is set at S$4.54, with analysts recommending a "sell" due to limited value unlocking of assets. OCBC Investment Research notes the oil glut has led to a shortage of storage facilities, benefiting downstream companies. SATS Ltd is recommended to "buy" with a target price of S$5.50 due to its strong relative performance and potential inclusion in the MSCI Singapore Index.

site_title: Japan's August retail sales slip renews pressure on policymakers
summary: Japan's retail sales fell 2.1% in August from a year earlier, marking the sixth consecutive annual decline, due to weak sales of clothes and home appliances. Policymakers face pressure to boost household spending, which has been weighed down by slow wage growth and gloomy economic prospects. The government has already implemented a stimulus package, but economists question whether wages will rise fast enough to spur consumer spending, potentially prompting the Bank of Japan to lower its assessment of consumption.

site_title: Taiwan 'double agent' gets 18 years for spying for China
summary: A Taiwanese court sentenced Major Wang Tsung-wu, a former intelligence officer, to 18 years in prison for spying for China and violating national intelligence laws. The High Court convicted Wang of espionage and national security law violations, citing national security restrictions for further details. This sentencing comes amid worsening relations between Taiwan and China.

site_title: Chinese yuan set to be inducted into IMF currency basket
summary: China's yuan is set to be inducted into the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket of currencies, marking a significant milestone for the country's economy. The yuan's induction, which will occur on Saturday, follows a decision made in November last year, after the IMF determined that the currency was "freely usable." This move elevates the yuan to the status of a global reserve asset, alongside the US dollar, pound, yen, and euro. The decision is seen as a major policy achievement for the Chinese government, which oversees the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won gain; end the week higher
summary: South Korean shares ended the week higher, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing up 0.2% at 2,054.07 points, marking six straight days of gains. This is the Kospi's biggest weekly percentage gain in nine weeks. The rally follows policy decisions from major central banks the previous day.

site_title: Two new training schemes launched for hotel industry workforce
summary: The Singapore Workforce Development Agency has launched two new training schemes for the hotel industry workforce, aiming to equip employees with relevant skills and create better matches between jobs and workers. The Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) for professional executives will help mid-career Singaporeans reskill and switch to sales, project-management, and administrative roles, while the Skills Framework for Hotel and Accommodation Services (HAS) will provide information on job openings, skills required, and relevant education and training programs. The initiatives are part of the government's efforts to address structural unemployment and promote quality growth.

site_title: Pocket change: Myanmar banks on mobile money
summary: Myanmar is introducing mobile banking to bridge its vast, underbanked population, with an estimated 90% lacking access to traditional banking services. Mobile banking firm Wave Money, in partnership with a telco operator and private bank, has built a network of 4,000 shops where clients can deposit and withdraw cash by phone. The service aims to provide a safe and efficient way for people to manage their finances, particularly in rural areas where traditional banks are scarce. Experts believe mobile money can help overcome trust issues and link the poor to safer financial services, a crucial step in Myanmar's economic revival.

site_title: 'LA Confidential' director Curtis Hanson found dead at California home
summary: Movie director Curtis Hanson, known for his work on "LA Confidential," was found dead in his California home at 71. Hanson died of natural causes, having retired in recent years due to Alzheimer's. He won an Oscar for best writing for the 1997 film, which also earned nominations for best picture, director, and several other categories. Hanson's film career included "The River Wild," "Wonder Boys," "8 Mile," and "In Her Shoes."

site_title: Valuers drop Brexit clauses from most contracts
summary: Five major property services firms, including CBRE, Jones Lang LaSalle, Savills, and Colliers, are dropping Brexit uncertainty clauses from their valuation reports for most UK assets as market conditions steady. The clauses, which previously stated a reduced probability of valuers' opinions matching property sale prices, have been dropped for most sectors, including commercial property, with only subsectors with greater uncertainty retaining reworded clauses. This move follows easing concerns over property demand and prices post-Brexit.

site_title: Britain gives nod to US$24b Hinkley nuclear plant
summary: Britain has given the green light to a $24 billion nuclear power plant, Hinkley Point C, after a comprehensive review. The project, backed by $8 billion of Chinese cash, will be built by French utility firm EDF. However, the UK government will have greater control over future deals with foreign energy partners, including the ability to stop the sale of EDF's controlling stake without prior notification. The decision aims to ease concerns about Prime Minister Theresa May's investment policy and openness to foreign investment.

site_title: Death toll from Indonesia floods, landslides, rises to 19
summary: Indonesia's death toll from landslides and flash floods has risen to 19, including 16 in the west of Java's main island, with eight others still missing. Torrential downpours caused floodwaters to reach 2 meters, killing an eight-month-old toddler and four children under 10. Landslides and flooding are common in Indonesia, with the country's disaster agency warning of potential disasters due to a La Nina weather phenomenon.

site_title: EU fails to comply with Airbus subsidy ruling: WTO
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has ruled that the European Union (EU) failed to comply with Airbus subsidy rulings, with billions of dollars in subsidies remaining in place. The EU and four nations, including Britain, France, Germany, and Spain, failed to address concerns over government loans to Airbus, which cost US$22 billion, including US$4 billion for the A350. The WTO rejected US claims that the A380 was a "prohibited" aid case. US officials urged Europe to end subsidised financing "immediately," while the EU plans to appeal the findings.

site_title: Powerful blast injures at least 29 in Manhattan
summary: A powerful explosion in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood injured at least 29 people, believed to be caused by a homemade bomb. Authorities found a second explosive device four blocks away, raising concerns of a possible terrorist attack. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo stated the blast was not linked to international terrorism, but a powerful bomb designed to kill. No immediate claim of responsibility was made.

site_title: Deutsche Asset Management sees mid to high single-digit returns for Asia-Pac office sector
summary: Deutsche Asset Management forecasts mid to high single-digit returns for the Asia-Pacific office sector over the next five years due to healthy demand and moderate supply. Good entry points are expected in cities like Singapore, Hong Kong, and Perth, which are anticipated to recover from market volatility around 2017-2018. The report also notes that cap rates in Singapore and Hong Kong have remained tight, and investment activities in prime office assets continue, driven by sovereign capital, pension funds, and insurance firms.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat; profit-taking erases early gains
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Thursday, erasing early gains as investors engaged in profit-taking after a three-session winning streak. The main Taiex index remained unchanged at 9,228.15 points, following the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged. The cautious trading is attributed to key export-related data due to be released later, which could show growth for the first time in 17 months and impact the trade-oriented economy.

site_title: Developers' EC sales shine in dull August
summary: ECs outperformed other residential projects in August, accounting for 41% of 805 units sold by developers. Despite a lack of new project launches, EC sales this year have already surpassed last year's total. Mass-market homes made up 60% of private home sales, while the Hungry Ghost Festival may have influenced buyers' reluctance to purchase. Experts note that sales volumes in 2016 should be similar to 2015, with an estimated 7,500-8,000 private condominium units and 3,500-4,000 EC units sold.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Analysts at KGI Fraser Securities and NRA Capital have initiated coverage on Health Management International (HMI) with a "buy" and "overweight" recommendation, respectively. HMI's target price is set at S$0.60 and S$0.285, based on discounted cash flow valuation and expected 21% CAGR growth in profit after tax. Analysts also note LHN's acquisition of Golden Mile Tower and potential for net profit growth in FY17, with estimated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) margins expected to improve.

site_title: Talent aplenty on the small stage
summary: Singapore's small theatre companies, such as Couch Theatre and Asylum Theatre, are producing high-quality productions despite financial struggles. These companies, comprising highly-trained professionals and semi-professionals, are thriving on word-of-mouth and low budgets. Original scripts, like Dark Matter Theatrics' "Micromanage Overwork Exasperate," are gaining attention, selling out shows quickly. The companies are also attracting established talents, such as Chio Su Ping, who is working with The Second Breakfast Company. These small theatre companies are challenging traditional notions of professionalism and talent, proving that quality theatre can be achieved with limited resources.

site_title: There's a US$300b exodus ahead as new money-fund era dawns
summary: The US$2.6 trillion money-market industry is set for a significant overhaul, with prime funds facing a potential US$300 billion exodus due to regulatory changes. Since 2015, prime funds' assets have plummeted by almost US$700 billion, leading to a ripple effect in financial markets and increased funding costs for banks. The outflow has been attributed to the increasing scrutiny of funds by regulators, prompting money managers to reassess their strategies and potentially shift assets to less-regulated areas.

site_title: Funds load up on risk in search for returns
summary: Investors seeking higher yields in a low-interest-rate environment are turning to complex financial products, similar to those that contributed to the 2008 financial crisis. European pension funds, insurers, and hedge funds are investing in synthetic securitizations, which can be risky, with some returning double-digit returns. Experts warn that this trend could lead to ugly consequences, echoing the era of the last credit boom. Regulators are pushing banks to reduce risk, and some major financial institutions are packaging junk-rated corporate bonds and loans into securities, which can be difficult to track.

site_title: Consumer protection Act gets more teeth; Spring to be its administrator
summary: Singapore's Parliament has passed the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) (Amendment) Bill, giving Spring Singapore more teeth to protect consumers. The changes will close loopholes allowing errant businesses to evade injunction orders by closing and reopening under different names. The new administrator will have investigation and enforcement powers, and the amended Act will raise consumer awareness of unfair practices, strengthen measures against errant businesses, and make it harder for them to side-step injunction orders.

site_title: How sugar industry shifted blame to fat
summary: The sugar industry secretly funded Harvard researchers in the 1960s to downplay the link between sugar and heart disease, instead blaming saturated fat. The researchers, including D Mark Hegsted, received funding equivalent to $50,000 today and published a review that minimized sugar's role in heart health. This shift in focus led to decades of research emphasizing saturated fat as the culprit, contributing to the obesity crisis. The sugar industry's influence on nutrition science continues to this day, with recent reports of funding studies that play down the link between sugary drinks and obesity.

site_title: Hanjin fall is Lehman moment for shipping, Seaspan CEO says
summary: South Korea's largest container line, Hanjin Shipping Co, has filed for bankruptcy, similar to Lehman Brothers in 2008, with about 93 ships stranded at 51 ports worldwide. The crisis has disrupted global supply chains, particularly during peak season. Seaspan Corp, a Hong Kong-based container-ship leasing company, has seen its impact minimal, with its leased vessels over 90% full ahead of the holiday season. CEO Gerry Wang says the fallout will help demand and supply, while the shipping industry faces long-term sustainability issues due to overcapacity and slowdown in global trade.

images.alt_text: The fall of South Korea's biggest container line Hanjin Shipping Co is similar to the 2008 collapse of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc and has materially impacted the shipping industry, Seaspan Corp chief executive officer Gerry Wang said.

site_title: Malaysia to spend US$1b on improving airports
summary: Malaysia plans to spend approximately US$1 billion over five years to upgrade and expand its airports, including Kuala Lumpur International Airport. The upgrade is expected to benefit regional airlines such as AirAsia, which is expanding its fleet and routes. The investment is a fraction of Hong Kong International Airport's estimated spending plan and Singapore's Changi Airport's expansion project. The move aims to accommodate the growing passenger traffic in the region, with Boeing projecting 100 million new passengers annually.

site_title: US wholesale inventories flat, boost to Q3 growth seen modest
summary: US wholesale inventories remained unchanged in July, following an upwardly revised 0.3% increase in June, and sales recorded their biggest drop in six months. This suggests a modest boost to third-quarter economic growth from inventory investment. Economists believe the inventory correction is close to running its course, with some estimating GDP growth will be well above 2% in the third quarter.

site_title: Korean Air approves loan for Hanjin Shipping
summary: Korean Air Lines has approved a 60 billion won (S$73.9 million) loan to Hanjin Shipping, the world's seventh-largest container carrier, as a condition of securing the Long Beach Terminal as collateral. Hanjin Group aims to raise 100 billion won to rescue stranded cargo at sea. Chairman Cho Yang-ho will raise 40 billion won from private funds next week.

site_title: Select Group opens Senoko headquarters
summary: Select Group Limited, a Singapore-based restaurant chain operator, has launched its new headquarters in Senoko South, which will double its food-service production capacity by 2020. The $60 million facility will house production and central kitchens, enabling the company to enter the ready-to-eat meals market and expand globally. The company aims to set up over 1,000 F&B outlets worldwide and has donated $250,000 to five non-profit organizations to mark the launch.

site_title: SoftBank Group in joint venture to build driverless buses
summary: SoftBank Group is launching a joint venture, SB Drive, to develop driverless buses, with a prototype already navigating a closed course. The company, in partnership with Advanced Smart Mobility Co, aims to cut operating costs by half. Four Japanese towns have signed up to test the vehicles on actual bus routes next year, with plans to sell the self-driving buses to cities and transit operators. The technology has lower technical barriers than self-driving cars, and the company is seeking to capitalize on Japan's aging population and public transportation crisis.

site_title: A US$12m Florida plantation to live like a robber baron
summary: Bob Williamson, a US businessman and convicted felon, has put his 5,000-acre Florida plantation, Honey Lake Plantation, on the market for $12 million. The estate, which includes a 7,000-square-foot mansion, was purchased by Williamson after he turned his life around and became a successful entrepreneur. He plans to sell the property to devote his time to evangelizing full-time. The plantation, located near Tallahassee, features spring-fed lakes, meandering roads, and a boathouse, and is surrounded by other large-scale private plantations.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat, hover at 14-month highs
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat near 14-month highs on Thursday, mirroring other overseas markets, as TSMC and Apple suppliers remained unchanged following the new iPhone launch. The main Taiex index closed at 9,266.63, with the electronics subindex nearly flat and the financials subindex gaining 0.2%. The flatness in Taiwan's market was consistent with other regions, such as Singapore and the US, where stocks continued their rallies despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Keeping an ear out for disruption
summary: Ed Eger, president and CEO of online foreign exchange trading platform OANDA, emphasizes the importance of listening to customers and understanding their needs in order to provide radical disruption in the financial services industry. Eger believes that a new product or business model can become game-changing only if it addresses an unmet need in the marketplace. He uses an Agile development process to prioritize and execute ideas, focusing on small bets and quick wins before scaling up successful projects. Eger also stresses the importance of being data-driven and willing to take calculated risks, and of shutting down bad decisions quickly while being patient with projects that need more time.

images.alt_text: 'When you look at what takes place on a credit card transaction, in fractions of a second as you're at the point of sale, think about what's happening when you dip a card or swipe a card, the amount of technology behind that in terms of how does that transaction get authorised, get processed, payment happens, all in a fraction of a second. That's disruption.'

site_title: Smaller developers may face liquidity squeeze: S&P
summary: A report by S&P Global Ratings warns that smaller Singaporean real estate developers may face liquidity squeezes due to weak liquidity positions and high leverage. The sector remains resilient overall, with larger developers and Reits having more financial flexibility. About 40% of property developers have cash and operating cash flows less than their short-term debt maturities, with some having liquidity of less than 0.5 times their short-term debt. The ability of these developers to refinance or push back debt maturities is key to avoiding repayment risks.

site_title: Building wall may trigger broad immigration policy overhaul
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's proposal to build a wall across the southern border with Mexico may trigger a broad overhaul of US immigration policy. The wall could be a catalyst for bipartisan agreement, despite opposition from Democrats. A recent Pew poll found that 63% of Republicans supported a wall, while 84% of Democrats opposed it. While the wall's effectiveness is debated, its potential to spark meaningful negotiations on immigration policy makes it a significant consideration.

site_title: UK July construction output bucks expectations for post-Brexit fall
summary: British construction output remained steady in July, defying expectations of a post-Brexit fall, with volumes unchanged from the previous month. Compared to the same period last year, output was 1.5% lower, the largest decline since April 2013. Despite this, new construction orders rose 8.6% in the three months to June, and private housing saw a 28.2% increase on the quarter. The UK's trade deficit narrowed slightly to £4.502 billion in July, with goods export volumes rising 2.0% and imports dropping 3.6%.

site_title: Tens of thousands of jobs go as China's biggest banks cut costs
summary: China's four biggest banks, including the Bank of China, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank Corp, and Agricultural Bank of China, reported a 1.5% decline in staff numbers in the first half of the year, the largest drop in at least six years. Analysts expect the workforce to continue to dwindle due to technological advances and cost cutting. The decline in employment is attributed to factors such as a slowing economy, rising bad loans, and increased competition from online and mobile players.

site_title: Indonesia's tax amnesty seen missing revenue target: central bank governor
summary: Indonesia's nine-month tax amnesty programme is unlikely to meet its revenue target of 165 trillion rupiah (S$17 billion) in 2016, with the central bank estimating only 18 trillion rupiah (11% of target) in 2016 and an additional 3 trillion rupiah in 2017. The shortfall could make it harder for President Joko Widodo's government to fund its infrastructure projects, which were banked on the amnesty revenue.

site_title: Iron ore eyes third weekly drop as it falls to lowest since July
summary: Iron ore prices fell to their lowest since July, reaching $57.40 a tonne, amid expectations of rising supply and a decline in Chinese steel output. Analysts expect prices to decline by year-end due to increased low-cost supply and a shift in China's focus from stimulating the economy to consumption and services. The decline is attributed to softer steel prices, resumption of production among Chinese mills, and limited physical iron ore demand.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits fresh record as rate hike expectations dim
summary: The Nasdaq index reached a fresh record on Tuesday, rising 0.5% to 5,275.91 points, driven by confidence in the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates low. This optimism was fueled by lackluster US economic data, including a slowdown in services sector activity in August. Key tech stocks such as Amazon, Facebook, and Tesla Motors also contributed to the gain. The Nasdaq's last record was set on August 15, and the index's gain of 14 points was a significant milestone.

site_title: Singapore stepping up misconduct probes, central bank chief says
summary: Singapore's central bank chief, Ravi Menon, announced the country will increase risk assessments of financial institutions to combat misconduct. Menon emphasized that financial institutions must promote a moral tone and that senior management and boards are responsible for ensuring compliance. This comes after Singapore charged a banker for alleged financial misconduct related to the 1Malaysia Development Bhd investment fund, the first country to do so. Prosecutors in multiple countries are investigating money flows from the fund, linked to corruption and money laundering.

site_title: Forum discusses ways to keep family-owned firms competitive
summary: A forum on family-owned firms in Singapore discussed challenges and strategies for remaining competitive. Participants shared experiences on balancing family and business, with key takeaways including prioritizing the company over family interests and implementing meritocracy to manage non-performing employees. The event also highlighted the need to professionalize family businesses and adapt to changing mindsets of older workers, particularly in innovating and overcoming skills gaps.

site_title: Traders, banks team up in 'dark pool' trading
summary: A group of asset managers and banks, including Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, and AXA Investment Managers, have partnered with the London Stock Exchange Group unit Turquoise to reduce the cost of "dark pool" trading. The deal aims to increase transparency in trading and simplify market structure. Turquoise, which trades shares across 19 European countries, will rename its "midpoint dark order book" Turquoise Plato, which will handle large trades. The partnership seeks to ensure fairness for all participants and protect orders. The agreement coincides with a planned merger of the London exchange and Deutsche Boerse.

site_title: Hanjin seeks to steer its ships to Singapore, Hamburg, Busan
summary: South Korea's government is attempting to contain global supply-chain disruptions caused by Hanjin Shipping Co.'s court receivership filing by offering loans and allowing the company's ships to steer to ports in Singapore, Hamburg, and Busan, where cargo is less likely to get stuck. Hanjin's 79 vessels, including 61 container ships, have had operations disrupted. The government aims to ease bottlenecks in the supply chain and help customers like LG Electronics receive their cargo back on land before the year-end shopping season. Hanjin Group will receive 100 billion won (S$122.6 million) of loans.

site_title: OUEHT leads volume jumpers last week
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUEHT) saw its volume surge to eight times its three-month average, followed by Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) at twice its average. These two Reits led the biggest volume jumpers on the Singapore Exchange, with OUEHT trading 117 million shares on Friday. The surge was attributed to block trades, and an announcement is expected on Tuesday. The two Reits, along with other 10 volume jumpers, averaged a 2.6% gain, outperforming the FTSE ST All Share Index, which declined 1.3% last week.

site_title: Fed officials push financial stability to centre of rate debate
summary: Federal Reserve officials are pushing for financial stability as a key factor in deciding whether to raise interest rates, amid low inflation. Chicago Fed president Charles Evans argues that preserving financial stability is crucial, while Fed Chair Janet Yellen's comments suggest a more cautious approach. The Fed's preferred inflation gauge remains below target, and officials are concerned about the risk of misallocated capital and mispricing of risk. Evans' comments suggest that the Fed may delay rate hikes to avoid triggering a surge in yields, but others argue that a slower pace of tightening could still pose risks.

site_title: Saudi state fund plans stake in big industrial zone: source
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is planning to invest in King Abdullah Economic City (KAEC), a major industrial zone on the Red Sea coast near Jeddah, as part of the country's efforts to diversify its economy and reduce its reliance on oil exports. The fund aims to inject capital into the project, which is currently being developed by Emaar the Economic City (EEC), and could either buy a stake in KAEC or take a stake in EEC itself. This investment would be part of the PIF's expansion plans, which include taking over the King Abdullah Financial District and restructuring state firms.

site_title: SMRT scheme meeting to be held on Sept 29
summary: SMRT Corporation announced a scheme meeting on September 29, 3:30pm, at The Star Theatre, Level 5, to determine if Belford, a 100% owned company of Temasek, will acquire 100% shareholding of SMRT at a scheme price of S$1.68 apiece. The meeting follows the proposed sale of SMRT's operating assets to transition to a new rail financing framework. If approved, minority shareholders will receive S$1.68 per share, and SMRT shares will no longer trade on the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: The meeting will determine if Belford will acquire 100% shareholding of SMRT at a scheme price of S$1.68 apiece.

site_title: Singapore's FX volumes up 35%, remains world's 3rd largest FX centre
summary: Singapore's foreign exchange market saw a 35% growth from 2013, reaching $517 billion in April 2016, making it the world's third-largest FX centre. The market share of Singapore increased to 7.9%, driven by growth in G-10 and Asian currencies, particularly the yuan, which doubled its share. The US dollar remained dominant, while the euro's trading volume declined. The Monetary Authority of Singapore aims to enhance price discovery, liquidity, and transparency in the market, with interest rate derivatives experiencing a 57% surge.

site_title: EU finds Volkswagen broke consumer laws in 20 countries: Die Welt
summary: The European Commission has found Volkswagen broke consumer laws in 20 EU countries by cheating on emissions tests, citing the Consumer Sales and Guarantees Directive and Unfair Commercial Practises Directive. Industry Commissioner Elzbieta Bienkowska has invited Volkswagen to consider voluntary compensation, but the company has not responded. Consumer Commissioner Vera Jourova is working with consumer groups to pressure Volkswagen to compensate European clients, similar to the US settlement. Jourova believes Volkswagen breached European consumer laws in most member states, and is coordinating a European-level strategy for claiming compensation.

images.alt_text: The European Commission has found that Volkswagen broke consumer laws in 20 European Union countries by cheating on emissions tests, German daily Die Welt reported, citing Commission sources.

site_title: Swiber names John Swinden as new CEO
summary: Swiber Holdings appointed John Swinden as group president, chief executive officer, and an executive director, effective September 2, 2016. This comes after Yeo Chee Neng's resignation, allowing for a seamless transition. Swinden has extensive experience with the company, having served in various senior capacities since 2011. He will oversee the group through the oil and gas sector's challenging landscape, with the company seeking legal advice on approximately US$227 million in claims received.

site_title: F1 to be sold next week, says German magazine
summary: Formula One is set to be sold to an American media group, Liberty Media, next week, according to a German magazine. The deal, valued at $8.5 billion, will see current owners CVC Capital Partners leave the sport. Bernie Ecclestone, the sport's commercial ring-master, has confirmed the sale and stated he will remain in a role, with Liberty Media expected to take control of the company. The sale is expected to be completed with the first payment made on Tuesday.

site_title: China opens anti-trust probe into Uber, Didi merger
summary: China has launched an anti-trust probe into the merger between Didi Chuxing and Uber's local operations, citing a lack of approval. The deal, worth $35 billion, was completed without Chinese approval, with Didi holding 80% control. The investigation aims to protect fair competition and defend public interests. The merger has sparked complaints among drivers and passengers who benefited from subsidies. Uber aims to shed losses in China, which could help clear its way for a future flotation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at more than 1-year high, won jumps
summary: South Korean shares reached a one-year high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing up 1.1% at 2,060.10 points. The won jumped to a three-week high against the US dollar, reaching 1,105.1. Weaker-than-expected US jobs data lowered expectations for a September Federal Reserve interest rate hike, contributing to the market's positive sentiment. Foreign investors bought 270.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares, further supporting the rally.

site_title: Iran banks to set up in Germany
summary: Iran's two private banks, Middle East Bank and Sina Bank, will establish branches in Munich, Germany, marking the Islamic republic's first major banking move in the country since the 1979 revolution. This move aims to circumvent ongoing international financing barriers. The central bank is also working with German banks to settle oil exports in euros, following the lifting of international sanctions in 2015.

images.alt_text: Two private Iranian banks will open branches in Munich, officials confirmed Monday, as the Islamic republic looks for ways around ongoing barriers to international financing.

site_title: STI ends week 54 pts lower on looming US rate hike, entry of 4th telco
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 54 points, or 1.9%, to 2,803.92 due to concerns over a US interest rate hike and the possibility of a fourth telco in Singapore. Singtel, M1, and StarHub were the main losers, with Singtel losing 8.3% for the week. The US Federal Reserve's comments by Janet Yellen at Jackson Hole weighed on sentiment, and low trading volume contributed to the decline.

site_title: Housing cancellations up following Brexit vote: McCarthy & Stone
summary: McCarthy & Stone, Britain's largest builder of homes for retired people, reported fewer new house reservations and increased cancellations following the country's Brexit vote. The company cited weakness in the housing market since its last trading update, with property being one of the hardest hit sectors. Despite some stabilisation in demand, McCarthy & Stone noted that consumer sentiment was still uncertain, and it was too early to determine if improved conditions would persist. Legal completions increased by 20% to 2,299 units in the year ended Aug 31, 2016.

site_title: Huawei powers on
summary: Huawei has partnered with German optics brand Leica to create the Huawei P9, a smartphone featuring a dual 12MP camera lens with Leica's stamp of approval. The camera takes great photos, thanks to Huawei's software, which combines images from a traditional RGB sensor and a monochrome sensor. The phone also boasts a slim profile, dual SIM capabilities, and a newer USB-C connector. However, its Android implementation is marred by bloatware, and users need to purchase a separate fast charger. The P9 is priced at S$888 for the 64GB model.

images.alt_text: POWER PIXELS: China handset giant Huawei has partnered with German optics and camera brand Leica to up the ante in phone cameras.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks rise as Federal Reserve's Sept rate hike seems unlikely
summary: South Korea's won and stocks rose to their strongest levels in over two weeks after weaker-than-expected US jobs data reduced speculation of an imminent US interest rate hike. The won reached 1,109.3 per US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) gained 0.8% to 2,055.58 points. US employment growth slowed, making an interest rate increase unlikely this month. Analysts expect the won to be sensitive to comments from US officials this week, potentially impacting market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The South Korean won and shares rose to their strongest in over two weeks early on Monday as weaker than expected US jobs data reduced speculation on an imminent increase in US interest rates.

site_title: 11 dead, dozens wounded in Pakistan court blast: police
summary: A suicide bomber attacked a court in Pakistan's city of Mardan, killing 11 people and wounding dozens. The bomber detonated his vest among morning crowds, targeting lawyers and clerks. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, but Jamaat-ul-Ahrar, a faction of the Pakistani Taliban, claimed responsibility for a similar attack in Quetta three weeks ago. The incident comes amid a surge in violence against the country's legal community, with the Pakistani Taliban regularly targeting minority groups and soft targets.

images.alt_text: At least 11 people have been killed and up to 40 wounded after a suicide bomber attacked a court in the Pakistani city of Mardan Friday, police said, the latest assault targeting Pakistan's legal community.

site_title: Update: Samsung Electronics says to halt Galaxy Note 7 sales on battery problem
summary: Samsung Electronics has halted the sale of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones due to battery problems, citing a two-week timeframe for replacing devices already sold. The company will provide replacement devices for the affected phones, but it's unclear when new sales will resume. This decision comes after finding issues with the battery cell used in the devices.

images.alt_text: Tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd said on Friday it will halt the sales of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones and will prepare replacement devices for phones already sold after finding problems with the battery cell used.

site_title: Hot stock: Some 117m OUEHT shares change hands at S$0.65 to S$0.655
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUEHT) saw a block trade of 117 million shares on Friday, with prices ranging from S$0.65 to S$0.655. The shares traded in four blocks, with the last trade at S$0.67, down a cent, at 4:07pm.

site_title: BNP promotes head of Asia private wealth unit to Singapore CEO
summary: BNP Paribas Investment Partners has promoted Christian Bucaro to Singapore CEO, replacing Puay-Lit Tan, who has taken time off. Bucaro, head of private wealth for Asia-Pacific, will oversee the bank's Singapore business and drive its local strategy. He joined the firm in 2005 and previously held senior roles in London and Singapore. The move is effective immediately.

images.alt_text: BNP Paribas Investment Partners said on Friday that Christian Bucaro will replace Puay-Lit Tan as its chief executive officer for Singapore with immediate effect.

site_title: Building icons of tomorrow
summary: AccorHotels Asia Pacific, led by CEO Michael Issenberg, has acquired FRHI, a US$2.9 billion purchase that gives the company a strong foothold in the luxury hotel business. The acquisition includes 155 properties worldwide under the Raffles, Fairmont, and Swissotel brands. Issenberg sees room for growth in Asia-Pacific, where he believes there's "real scope for growth" of the Raffles, Fairmont, and Swissotel brands. The company plans to expand its footprint in North America and Asia-Pacific, and has already received significant enquiries from across the world. Accor estimates it will generate 65 million euros in revenue and cost synergies from the acquisition, with plans to refurbish hotels in Singapore and introduce new brands.

images.alt_text: 'The digital is to enable, to make sure people come to our properties. But creating experience, at the end of the day, that's the business we're in.'

site_title: Clinton raises record US$143m in August: campaign
summary: Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign raised a record US$143 million in August, exceeding the Democratic Party's fundraising goal. This brings the campaign's total to over US$68 million, allowing it to enter the election's final stretch with sufficient resources. The majority of the funds, US$62 million, was raised for Clinton's campaign. This surpasses Barack Obama's August 2012 fundraising total of US$97 million. Clinton participated in 37 private fundraising events across 11 states and the capital, with minimum contributions ranging from US$500 to US$250,000.

images.alt_text: Hillary Mrs Clinton's presidential campaign raised an eye-popping US$143 million in August for her candidacy and the Democratic Party, the best showing of her campaign, her team said Thursday.

site_title: Silverlake Axis continues to sell down Global Infotech stake
summary: Silverlake Axis reduced its stake in Global Infotech from 18.53% to 17.79% by selling 1 million shares for 63.85 million yuan (S$13 million). The sale price was 4.5% below the market price, resulting in an estimated gain of 31.13 million yuan. The proceeds will be used for general working capital, special dividends, debt repayment, and business opportunities. Silverlake Axis shares fell 2 cents to S$0.65 before the announcement.

images.alt_text: SILVERLAKE Axis has reduced its stake in financial information software provider Global Infotech (GIT) from 18.53 per cent to 17.79 per cent, it said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Thursday evening.

site_title: Credit Suisse replaces head of global markets
summary: Credit Suisse has replaced Timothy O'Hara, head of its global markets division, after 10 months, with 39-year-old Brian Chin. Chin, who led the trading unit that contributed to $1 billion in losses earlier this year, will become one of 11 managers on CEO Tidjane Thiam's executive board. The move comes as the bank faces significant restructuring efforts, including cost cuts and job losses, following a 37% decline in shares this year. Thiam has announced two restructuring plans since taking over in 2015, aiming to shift away from securities trading.

images.alt_text: Mr Thiam has announced two restructuring plans since taking over in July 2015, eliminating thousands of jobs and risky investments to shift away from securities trading.
